title: 34 Revelers Seized At Fort Lauderdale And Miami Beach
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 1 (UPI) The police in Miami Beach and nearby Fort Lauderdale Beach used tear gas early to: day to break up rowdy crowds of young New Year's revelers, who had spilled onto the streets and began blocking traffic and smashing car windows.

title: Josephine Baker Charms Everybodee
description: How can you resist a warm, gracious woman with magnificent legs who spends a raw New Year's Eve professing her love and demanding yours? You don'tnot if her name is Josephine Baker.

title: R.I. Assembly Opens
description: PROVIDENCE, R. L, Jan. 1 (AP)The Rhode Island General Assembly opened its 1974 session today with brief formal meetings in the House and Senate. Attendance was nearly 100 per cent in both chambers, de spite the holiday.

title: Nixon Named Wife To a Job Illegally
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 1President Nixon's appoint. ment of his wife to serve or, a national advisory council was illegal, the White House said today.

title: View From the Mideast: The CeaseFire Is Shaky
description: A pillar of smoke climbed from a shellburst on the saddle of land between the Egyptian and Israeli lines. It hung, white against the blue sky, and was joined by another. The crump, crump of Egyptian guns sounded above the roar of supply trucks on the SuezCairo road.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES, WEDIUSDAY JANUARY 2, 1974
description: PLAINVIEW, L. I.  An unusual public survey sonsored the Plainview School District has produced some contradictory findings, according to results released this week.

title: 1.5Billion Capital Budget Adopted by Planning Body
description: The City Planning Commission has adopted a $1.52billion capital budget for the fiscal year beginning next July 1, more than $300million below the budget it proposed last month.

title: First Homicide of the Year A Minute After Midnight
description: DETROIT, Jan. 1 (UPI) Detroit recorded its first homicide of the new year today at one minute past midnight just hours after ending 1973 with a record 750 slayings

title: Connors, Goolagong Win Finals
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 1 (UPI)  Jimmy Connors became only the fourth American to win the Australian men's national tennis championship since 1946 when he beat Phil Dent of Sydney, 7.6, 64, 46, 63, today in the final of the $50,000 event.

title: Ski Jumping UpstateWor By McNeill
Football Upstages Law
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 1 (AP) The nation's only onehouse state Legislature convened its 1974 session on New Year's Day, but met for only 19 minutes so lawmakers could get to television sets to watch football games. The noon opening preceded by about one hour the televised kickoff of the NebraskaTexas Cotton Bowl game, prompting what was believed the shortest firstday setting in Nebraska legislative history.

title: Blind Welfare Recipients In Search for Heating Oil
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 1 (AP)Mr. and Mrs, James Payne, blind welfare recipients, ran out of heating oil on New Year's eve with outside temperatures near zero.

title: 2 AGENCIES CLASH ON PGILUTION CURBS
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 1 (AP)The Tennessee Valley Authority and the Environmental Protection Agency are approaching a confrontation over pollution controls.

title: She Prefers Elephants (in Kenya) to Buffalo (in New York)
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  After seven years of counseling students on how to get more out of life, Phyllis Strickland decided it was time to get more out of hers. She quit her job as a psychologist at the State University of New York in Buffalo, withdrew her savings from the bank, and came to East Africa to study wild elephants.

title: Security Strict for Picking A Jury in Chesimard Trial
description: MORRISTOWN, Jan. 1Police and court authorities here are playing down the firm security measures they will put into effect tomorrow when selection of a jury begins in the trial of Joanne Chesimard and Clark E. Squire on murder charges.

title: INFLATION IS SEEN IN COMMODITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1An ominous new rise during the last two months in prices of commodities  things grown on the earth or dug from the earthhas increased prospects for inflation in 1974, in the view of private and govern. ment economists.

title: CHARLES BOHLEN, DIPLOMAT,69,DIES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 Charles E. Bohlen, for more than 30 years one of the Government's most influential advisers on Soviet relations, died of cancer this evening in the Washington Medical Center. He was 69 years old.

title: Wife of Edward Nixon Asserts He's Being Paid to Do Nothing
description: ALDER WOOD MANOR, Wash., Jan. 1 (AP)  Mrs. Edward Nixon, the President's sisterinlaw, says she is staying home trying to teach school and rear two children while her husband is off being paid to do nothing.

description: Theater

description: BASKETBALL

title: Syracuse Five Leads Poll
description: Syracuse, winner of seven, of eight games, was the unanimous choice for the third straight week yesterday as the No. 1 University Division basketball team in the state.

title: Colombia Prepares For U.S. Cup Test
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 1 (AP) The Colombian Davis Cup team is depending heavily on the altitude of this city and the coaching help of two Chileans, Jaime Fillol and Patricio Cornejo, to beat the United States team in the Davis Cup American Zone final. The American team is expected tomorrow, night in Bogota, which is 5,660 feet above sea level. A Colombian Tennis Federation spokesman said the Americans would undergo intense training for eight days to get used to the rare air of the capital city.

title: Market Bloc Spars Movement of Goods
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 1 (Reuters)  The nine countries of the European Common Market took a major concrete step today toward the creation of a common market and the unhindered flow of goods between old and new member states.

title: Japan's Foreign Minister Leaves for Visit to Peking
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. (UPI)Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira left Tokyo today for a fourday visit to Peking to sign a new ChineseJapanese trade treaty, and try to negotiate a start of air service between the two countries.

title: JOSEPH DURST, 92, REAL ESTATE MAN
description: Joseph Durst, founder and retired president of the Durst Organization, developers, builders and operators of real estate in midManhattan, died Monday at his home, 1136 Fifth Avenue. He was 92 years old and until a few months ago was freqbently to be seen in the offices of the company, now led by three of his four sons.

title: MRS. WEIR'S PARTY LOSES STRENGTH BUT RETAINS RULE
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 1With military ballots still uncounted, unofficial returns showed today that Premier Golda Meir's Labor alignment had polled 39.9 per cent in the voting for Parliament, compared with 46.2 per cent four years ago, in the previous election.

title: Calman Triumphs In Rye Regatta
description: RYE, N.Y., Jan. 1  Michael Calman of the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Frostbite Association, who held a 21point lead with 13 points after Sunday's racing, was the leader again today with 22 points to win the American Yacht Club's 10th annual New Year's Frostbite regatta for the second time in three years.

title: Brazilian Band to Perform in Summit
description: SUMMIT, Jan. 1 A jazz band that has been playing in Brazil for 15 years will mike its American concert debut next Saturday. Soonsor of the event is the Summit Junior Fortnightly Club, a women's service organization that has never presented a musical program.

title: Grant for Air Navigation
description: SYRACUSE, Jan. 1 (AP)The Federal Aviation Agency has awarded Syracuse University a oneyear $44,174 grant for research studies to improve aviation navigation systems. The project will be directed byi Bradley Strait, associate proi Jessor of electrical engineering, and Harry Gruenherg, professor of electrical engineering at Syracuse.

title: American Tuna Boats Stay in Port in Price Dispute as Fishing Season Opens.
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 1  The opening today of the internationally controlled yellowfin tuna fishing season in the eastern Pacific found the American tuna fleet immobilized at its berths here by a deadlock over the price that canneries will pay for the fleet's catch in 1974.

title: Indonesia, Mindful of Thai Overthrow, Heeds New Student Stirrings
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The students of Indonesia, a powerful political force that lapsed into splintered disarray, have begun stirring again, and the Government is showing some nervousness.

title: Venezuelan Leader Calls for TakeOver Of Major Industries
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan.1 (AP)Retiring President Rafael Caldera recommended tonight that Veneitielan oil operations and other keY indtiStrieS with foreign holdings be converted to state ownership sas soon as possible.

title: NEW YEAR FIRES TAKE LIVES OF 12
description: Gabriel Tichi, a fire marshal, was to have retired this year after 25 years with the Walla Walla, Wash., fire department. But Mr. Tichi was killed early yesterday when the wall of burning twostory building colLapsed.

title: GIORGIO MUTARELLI
description: Giorgio Mutarelli, the Duke of Saragnano, a former assistant managing editor of II Progresso ItaloAmericano, died Monday in the ColumbiaPres1 byterian Medical Center of what was tentatively diagnosed as pulmonary fibrosis. He was 52 years old, had been living in Rome.

title: Giant Marine Test Tubes To Gauge Ocean Pollution
description: Seven oceanographic institutions have joined in a multimilliondollar international effort to assess the longterm effect on the oceans of pollution levels so low they are permissible in drinking water, yet are high enough, some fear, to wreak havoc in the seas.

title: Nixon Will Sign SpeedLimit and Railroad Bills
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., 1 (UPI)President Nixon decided today to sign energy-conserving legislation aimed limiting state highway speed to 55 miles an hour and a bill that would merge seven bankrupt Midwestern and Northeastern railroads.

Gibson, a civilian scientist who have the best view of anyone, said today that the tail of the comet Kohoutek was becoming more prominent and they could easily pick out vibrant orange and yellow colors.

title: Red Smith
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1When James J. Braddock was an unemployed longshoreman on relief, he knocked out Corn Griffin in a semiwindup. I did that on hash, he told his manager, Joe Gould. Get me a piece of steak and see what I can do. Gould got him a piece of steak and he whipped Max Baer for the heavyweight championship of the world.

title: CHINESE GIRL, 12, IS STUDENT HERO

title: Death of Woman, 85, Laid To Being Trapped in Garage
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 1 (UPI) Lenora Holtegel, 85 years old, was trapped and killed by her own car, officials believe.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Jan. 2 (AP)A South Korean Army sergeant shot upa tea room in Taegu last night, seized about 30 hostages and still was holding off 200 policemen and military policemen this afternoon, the Defense Ministry said.

title: Title Soccer Semifinals On Tonight
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer semifinals get under way at the Orange Bowl in Miami tonight, with Brown meeting St. Louis and Clemson taking on the University of California, Los Angeles. The winners will meet for the university division title on Friday night.

description: The State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene has ordered an investigation of reports of crime and thefts by staff members, patients and outsiders at Creedmoor State Hospital that a State Senator described as having reached epidemic proportions.

description: Abe Beame opened yesterday. He said he wanted everyone to be proud to he New Yorkers once again, and to believe in the city for a change. description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 1 (UPI)  Mark Weems, a 22yearold Californiaborn pitcher belonging to the Baltimore Orioles, drowned last Sunday while swimming at a beach on the central coast of Venezuela, local authorities reported today. Weems disapreportd today. Wems disapPatanemo Beach 100 miles west of Caracas, and rescue workers had still not recovered his body late Sunday.

description: The nation's major securities and commodities markets are reopening today after being closed yesterday for New Year's Day. Banks, business and Government offices and Canadian and European markets also were closed yesterday.

title: Gunmen Kill a Local Leaderi Of Bangladesh Ruling Party
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Jan. 1 (AP)Gunmen assassinated local leader of Prime Minister Mujibur Rahman's party last night and wounded the Premier's political secretary.

title: MRS. ALEXANDER BLUM
description: Mrs. Elizabeth Kuhn Blum, widow of Alexander Blum, a stockbroker, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived at IiJ2 Park Avenue.

title: From Beach 131st Street to City Hall
description: His wife, Mary, had to get up early to make him a scrambledegg breakfast and their son Buddy had to stay home and babysit because two of the grandchildren were sick. Otherwise, Abraham D. Beame became Mayor of New York yesterday without incident.

title: Cougars Rally to Top Blazers, 54
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (AP) Ralph Backstrom's goal with 22 seconds left in the game gave the Chicago Cougars a 54 victory over the Vancouver Blazers tonight in a World Hockey Association game.

title: Theodore Rousseau Dies at 61; Vice Director of Met Museum
description: Theodore Rousseau, the controversial curator in chief and vice director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died of cancer Monday, a day before he was to have retired and become a trustee of the museum. He was 61 years old.

title: Kramer to Do A.B.C. Drama on Rosenberg Trial
description: A television drama based on the 1951 trial of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg, who were convicted as atomic spies and executed, will be produced for the American Broadcasting Company by the noted film maker Stanley Kramer. The network Will present it as 90minute special at 9 P.M. on Monday, Jan. 28.

title: Decline in Fighting Reported In South Vietnam for Day
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 1 (UPI)Fighting fell off sharply today in South Vietnam, with the Saigon military command reporting only four significant incidents in the 24 hours ending at 6 A.M.

title: Girl, 3, Dies in L.I. Fire
description: NORTH AMITYVILLE, L. I., Jan. 1 (UPI)A 3yearold girl died today after a fire of undetermined origin broke out in her home, the Suffolk County police reported. The victim, Lee Rosa Young, was pronounced dead at Brunswick Hospital of injuries suffered in the blaze at 3477 Great Neck Road. Her mother, Mrs. Betty Young, a brother, Thomas, 4, and a sister, Wendy, 14, were all treated at Brunswick Hospital in Copiague for lacerations and smoke inhalation, the police said.

title: 1.5Billion Capital Budget Adopted by Planning Body
description: The City Planning Commis sion has adopted a $1.52billiot capital budget for the fisca year beginning next July more than $300million below the budget it proposed las month.

title: Beer Drinking on Coast Up
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 (UPI)Beer drinking continues to rise each year in California. The United States Brewers Association reported today that Californians drank a record 13.5 million barrels in 1973, or 4 per cent more than in 1972. Tax revenues from the sale of beer also increased 4 per cent, to $227million.

title: SUN OIL COMPANY ACCUSED ON PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) The Federal Energy Office was investigating today at least two complaints of possible price gouging by the Sun Oil Com,pany in the sale of heating oil.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: COLLEGE IN HAWAII AIDS BUSY ADULTS
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 1 (UPI)Housewives come to the Learning Resources Center here after grocery shopping.

title: Rheingold Meeting Approves a Merger
description: The Rheingold Corporation, the New Yorkbased brewery and softdrink bottling company, has announced that a special meeting of its shareholders has approved a merger with Capital N.V. New York, Inc.

title: 100,000 Japanese See Hirohito in Annual Rite
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan, 2 (UPI)  Emperor Hirohito made his regular New Years public appearance today behind a sheet of bulletproof glass on a porch at the imperial palace office building.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Hawley Begins 74 With 3 Winners

title: Johnson, Buckeye Freshman, Gets 3 Rose Bowl Scores
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1Vindication on three levelscompetitive, political and tacticalwas enjoyed to the fullest today by Ohio State and its supporters as its football team overpowered the University of Southern California, 42.21, in the 60th Rose Bowl game.

title: 50 Pulitzer Jurors For 1974 Awarth Listed by Col umbi
description: Columbia University a nounced yesterday the appoin ment of 50 editors and write as jurors for the 1974 Pulitzi Prizes in journalism.

title: Security Program For Courts Set Up
description: A court security program featuring intercom systems for judges to summon help during disturbances and the experimental use of metal detectors to keep weapons out of courtroomswill be instituted here this month.

title: Oif Washes Up on Beach
description: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP)Oil from a damaged Navy transport ship washed up on a twomile stretch of Oceano Beach today.

title: Newark: A City That Has Its Positive Aspect as Well
description: NEWARK, Jan. 1From 8 A.M. to 5 P.M., downtown Newark hums with people. The majority pour in from the surrounding suburbs to work at such places as the Pru, Prudential Life Insurance Company; Public Service, the state's major utility, or Bane's  Bamberger's, one of the city's few remaining big retail stores.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Seatrain Lines Sells 225,000Ton Tanker
description: Seatrain Lines, Inc., has sold its 225,000ton supertanker, Brooklyn, to the General Electric Credit Corporation, one of the nation's largest leasing companies.

title: Frostbite Sailor Wins Third Time
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 1Randy Bartholomew won four of today's six races to capture Interclub class dinghy honors as the 43d annual New Year's Frostbite regatta ended a three  day stand on Manhasset Bay.

title: PRISONERS PROTEST RECREATION RULES
description: CRANSTON, R. I. Jan. 1 (AP)About 55 inmates of the maximum security section of the Adult Correctional Institutions in Cranston refused to return to their cells after supper tonight. The men, all awaiting trials, demanded more recreation time.

title: Penalty for NoShows
description: The airlines have for years been notoriously guilty overbooking flights on occasion, with the result that ticket holders with longstanding reservations have often been left stranded without space. Such disregard of passengers rights clearly constitutes a breach of contract.

title: Pope Urges Italians to Shun A MafiaStyle Mentality
description: ROME, Jan 1Pope Paul VI urged Italians today to shun a mafiastyle mentality of cunning, violence and vendettas.

title: BRITON SHOT BY ARAB IS MAKING RECOVERY
description: LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters)Joseph Edward Sieff, the prominent British Zionist and chainstore executive shot by an Arab guerrilla two days ago, continued to make good progress in a hospital today and was removed from the intensive care unit.

title: Pay of Fat Executives Is Found Leaner Than Checks of Others
description: DETROIT, Jan. 1 (UPI) A survey of 15,000 executives by an employment agency showed today that fat executives received less pay than lean ones did.

title: Orange Bowl at a Glance
Lottery Off for Holiday
description: There was no New Jersey daily lottery yesterday because of the holiday.

title: CHARLES BOHLEN, DIPLOMAT,69,DIES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 Charles E. Bohlen, for more than 30 years one of the Government's most influential advisers on Soviet relations, died of cancer this evening in the Washington Medical Center. He was 69 years old.

title: Leafs Defeat Wings, 43, After Trailing by 3 Goals
description: TORONTO, Jan. 2 (UPI) Tim Ecclestone came back to haunt his former team by scoring two goals tonight and Inge Hammarstrom scored a goal with 5 minutes 35 seconds to play to help the Toronto Maple Leafs overcome a threegoal deficit and defeat the Detroit Red Wings, 4.3.

title: 5th House Term Is Sought
description: PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 2 (AP)  Representative Peter N. Kyros, Democrat of Maine, announced today that he would seek a fifth term. Citing the advantage of his seniority, Mr. Kyros said that he would continue to work for Maine's interests in rail transportation on the Interstate and Foreigri Commerce Committee and for the fishing industry on the Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee.

description: SCOTTISH LEAGUE

description: A.C. Israel & Co. and the Louis Dreyfus Corporation, both leading commodity trading houses, yesterday dissolved their joint venture, ACLI International, Inc.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 2The Internal Revenue Service announced today that it was reexamining President Nixon's tax returns, but it would not say which ones.

title: Officer Knifed in Harlem School; Mayor Visits Him in Hospital
description: A probationary police officer, was stabbed and seriosly wounded in an East Harlem school yesterday, allegedly by a distraught father of a student there.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Turbodyne Corporation has received letter of intent from the Houston Lighting and Power Company to purchase six Turbodyne industrial gas turbine generators. The order, which the company said was worth $26million, raises Turbo. dyne's backlog to $228million. Last week, the company received an $81.2million order from the San Diego Gas and Electric Company.

title: Jordan Takes Over Hudson Government
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 2Mayor Paul T. Jordan established his control of Hudson County's governmental apparatus today when the 59yearold grandmother he had picked for the post was selected to be director of the Board of Freeholders.

title: Bicentennial Items Off to Lively Start
description: Long before the bicentennial rolls around, it will be possible to dine from patriotic plates etched with 24karat gold eagles, to sit on George Washington chairs, to fire a blast on ersatz 1776 cannons, to douse oneself with Historic Charleston cologne and to decorate living room windows with the sort of floral print that Thomas Jefferson might have viewed while penning the Declaration of Independence.

title: U.C.L.A. and St. Louis Gain Title Soccer Final
description: MIAMI, Jan. 2  St. Louis University and the University of California, Los Angeles won their National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer semifinal games at the Orange Bowl tonight and will meet for the championship Friday night.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Welfare Reform: Step
description: Several million Americans who are aged, blind or disabled and also poor are a bit better protected against the ravages of inflation as a result of the introduction this week of the first broad Federal guarantee of a floor under income for the needy.

title: NIXON APPROVES LIMIT OF 55 M.P.H.
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Jan. 2President Nixon signed today a bill requiring states to limit highway speeds to a maximum of 55 miles an hour as a condition for continuing to receive Federal highway trust funds.

title: The Times and KimberlyClark Get All Stock of Newsprint Unit
description: The New York Times Company and the KimberlyClark Corporation have signed an agreement to purchase all of the stock interest in the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company, Ltd., held by The Evening Star Newspaper Company of Washington, D.C.

title: 1Nixon Signs the Rail Reorganization Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 President Nixon signed into law today the Regional Rail Reorganization. Act of 1973 to restructure seven bankrupt railroads in the Northeast section of the country into one Federally backed private corporation.

title: ChesimardSquire Trial Delayed 24 Hours by Judge
description: MORRISTOWN, Jan. 2The opening of the trial of Joanne Chesimard and Clark E. Squire on murder and assault charges was delayed here today for 24 hours to permit the defendants to confer with their attorneys.

title: U.K. Credibility Gap?
description: 13,ritain's threeday work week has begun with a vengeance. Threequarters of a million workers were thrown onto the unemployment rolls yesterday, on top of the nearly halfmillion already there. If the abbreviated week long continues, unemployment could climb to six million, a level of joblessness the British have not experienced since those years on the dole before World War II.

title: PRICE CUT IN OIL A HINT IN MIDEAST
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 2 (AP) An official spokesman for the Persian Gulf oil producers said today that the price of oil would be reduced if industrialized nations lowered the cost of their exports.

title: People and Business
description: J. David Parkinson has been named president and chief executive officer of the Thomas & Betts Corporation. He succeeds Robert McK. Thomas Jr., who died last month at the age of 64. Mr. Thomas was a son of a cofounder of the electrical and electronics manufacturer.

title: Del Bello, Sworn In, Vows More Open Government
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 2 Alfred B. Del Bello, the first Democratic County Executive in Westchester history, took the oath of office today, pledging more open and responsive government.

title: G.I.'s Said to Be Used To Build a Golf Course
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (Reuters)  Congressional investigators have found that United States Army troops and equipment were used to clear land for a private golf course in West Germany, Senator William Proxmire said today.

title: G.A.O. Asked to Investigate Submarine Buoy Program
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (ReutersThe General Accounting Office has been asked to investigate the possibility of collusion between the Navy and a Texas concern that produced $16million worth of communications buoys that were too large for United States submarines.

title: BROTHER KILLED 5, YOUTH TESTIFIES
description: DONALSONVILLE, Ga., Jan. 2 (AP)  Billy Isaacs testified today that his older brother Carl Isaacs and two other accused killers had shot five male members of the Ned Alday family one by one as they entered a trailer on the family farm.

title: Teachers Strike
description: WISCONSIN RAPIDS, Wis., Jan. 2 (UPI)Teachers walked off their jobs today and set up picket signs in 10 belowzero weather. Classes for 7,400 students were called off by the school board after teachers went on strike after a vote last night. Some 350 teachers are involved. The main issue is salary.

title: Soviet Terms New Book By Solzhenitsyn Slander
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 2  The Soviet Union today ridiculed Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's newly published expos of the Soviet prison system as a blanket slander of the Soviet people born of the author's impotent rage against the Communist achievements of the Soviet Union.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2George G. Montgomery, former board chairman of the Kern County Land Company here, died yesterday in Mills Memorial Hospital in San Mateo. He was 79 years old.

description: James Saunders's Next Time I'll Sing to You, which opened yesterday at the Billy Rose Theater, is a rare contemporary excursion for the City Center Acting Company. I mean the word rare in two senses, which is several senses fewer than Mr. Saunders means most of his words.

title: A.M.C. to Lay 011200
description: DETROIT, Jan. 2 (UPI)The American Motors Corporation said today that 200 workers would he idled at two Wisconsin plants as it cut back production of larger cars to make sure there was enough parts to build the fastselling small models.

Kassubas real estate interests from assaults by creditors until Feb. 5. Cornpanies controlled by Mr. Kasisuba filed a petition under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act on Dec. 21.

description: Pennsylvania's Insurance Commissioner has issued a Shopper's Guide to Health Insurance in which he rates the 25 largest health and accident insurance companies in that state and finds that 15 of them do not rank as good buys for the consumer.

title: Required Cash Payment For Stocks Is Cut to 50%.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2The Federal Reserve Board reduced today from 65 to 50 per cent the required margin, or cash payment, for purchasing or carrying stocks on credit.

description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 2 (UPI)The AVCO Corporation said today it would phase out during the next six months all operations of its precision products division at Richmond, Ind. The facility employs 840 perSons.

As the American Basketball Association's most valuable player recuperates from surgery for a kidney blockage at Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital in Manhattan, the Cougars have turned from the powerful Eastern Division leaders to a struggling team.

Nixon and the new 25member National Voluntary Service Advisory Council.

title: Konstantin Vershinin Dies at 73; ExChief of the Soviet Air Force
description: Chief Air Marshal Konstantin A. Vershinin, former commander of the Soviet Air Force, died Sunday in Moscow. He was 73 years old.

title: DANIEL J. O'CONOR JR. OF CYANAMID IS DEAD
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J. Jan 2Daniel J. O'Conor Jr., former executive vice president and director of the American Cyanamid Company, died today at his home here. His age was 57.

description: HOULTON, Me., Jan. 2 (AP) Ricker College has announced the resignation, effective Friday, of its president, Dr. Robert E. Matson. Chauncey Robbins of New Limerick, the retired executive director of the State Bar Association, has been appointed acting president.

title: U.S. Steel Shifting Stainless Products
description: We may make adjustments in some areas. but we are in the stainiess business to stay.

title: Tex Ritter, 67, Singing Cowboy Of Screen and Records, Is Dead
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 2 (AP)Tex Ritter, the country music star, died of a heart attack here tonight. The 67yearold singer, guitar player, actor and politician was visiting a friend at the county jail when he was stricken.

title: California Child Abuse Study Indicates Insufficient Effort to Change the Parents
description: LOS ANGELESJudy was a victim of child abuse. By the time she was 12 years old, the Los Angeles Juvenile Courts had placed her in succession of foster homes; by the time she was 21, emotionally distraught, she had knifed her therapist, assaulted others on the street and ended up with a threeyear prison term, Some years later, when she had a daughter of her own, the child was subjected repeatedly to slappings and other forms of physical abuse.

description: News that the Federal Reserve Board has reduced margin requirements was greeted happily in Wall Street, where any factor that promised to encourage stock purchases is regarded as positive.

title: Tremor Shakes North Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 2 (Reuters)A strong earth tremor shook northern Chile today, but only three people were reported injured and property damage was light.

title: U.S. STILL HOPEFUL ON GENEVA PARLEY
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Jan. 2  Defense Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel will meet Secretary of State Kissinger in Washington on Friday, with the Nixon Administration reasonably certain that the results of the Israeli election will not impede the current Middle East negotiations.

description: American Airlines announced yesterday that it would ground 10 of its 16 Boeing 747 jumbo jet airliners, effective Monday, because of the fuel shortage.

title: Bombs Explode in Cyprus, Damaging Cars and Houses
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 2 (AP)Seven bombs exploded during the night at Larnaca, in southeast Cyprus, wrecking several cars and damaging houses. No one was hurt, thei police said.

title: E. P. PARKER DIES; GAMES EXECUTIVE
description: SALEM, Mass., Jan. 2Edward P. Parker, chairman of Parker Brothers, the games manufacturers here founded by his greatuncle in 1883, died of cancer yesterday in Salem Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in nearby Beverly Farms

title: G. M. to Lay Off 8,000 Workers In Jersey and Westchester Units
description: About 3,000 workers at two General Motors Corporation assembly plants in New Jersey are to be laid off indefinitely this month and 5,000 more in New Jersey and Westchester County are to be laid off for two weeks, all because of the drop in sales for standardsize cars, a company spokesman yesterday.

title: Suffolk Executive Warns: Hard Times Are Coming
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I, Jan. 21 A pessimistic economic outlook that included a prediction of a 10 per cent unemployment rate in Suffolk County was offered today by County Executive John V. N. Klein.

title: Radio: C B.S Mystery Theater Starts Nightly Run
description: The revival of radio drama attempts to get considerably more serious this Sunday evening with the debut of C.B.S. Radio Mystery Theater, which will offer complete and different 52minute story to listeners seven nights a week. Because WCBSAM in New York will continue as an all news station, the series will be carried on WOR in the metropolitan area  at 7:07 P.M. Monday through Friday, i$:07 P.M. Saturday and 5:07 Sunday.

title: Court Calls Lottery Hot News, Overruling an F.C.C. Air Ban
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit ruled today that radio and television stations could broadcast winning lottery numbers in drawings conducted by states because they are hot news.

title: MRS. HENRY C. VON ELM
description: Mrs. Margaret Meyer Von Elm, widow of Henry C. Vow Elm, who was chairman of the Manufacturers Trust Company, now the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died yesterday in Parkway Hospital, Forest Hills, Queens. She was 85 years old and lived at 150 Greenway Terrace, Forest Hills.

title: Bibby Stands Out in LastMinute Rescue Role
description: LARGO, Md., Jan. 2The Knicks paid their first visit to the Capital Centre, the new home of the Capital Bullets, and survived a frantic final five minutes to post a 9281 victory tonight before a roaring crowd of 17,328 fans.

title: Gives Up After 30H our Siege
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 2 (Reuters)  A military police sergeant who held about 30 people hostage in a railway station tearoom in Taegu, in southeastern Korea, surrendered tonight after 30hour siege, radio reports said.

title: Islanders Lose by 51 To Hawks
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 2 (AP) Jim Pappin scored his 10th and 11th goals of the season to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 51 victory over the New York Islanders in a National Hockey League game tonight.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange issued its latest report on changes in stockholdings by major shareholders, directors and officials in listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not issue an insiders report yesterday. Following are the changes reported on the Amex:

description: On Oct. 20, 1972, amid the symbolic panoply of Independence Hall in Philadelphia, President Nixon signed a bill that he later described as the first step in a new American Revolution designed to restore power to the people.

title: Talks Resume to Avert an Off Broadway Stage Strike
description: Producers and performers resumed negotiations yesterday in an effort to avert an Off Broadway theater strike of actors and stage managers.

title: STRIKE IN BOMBAY POINTS UP UNREST
description: BOMBAY, India, Jan. 2The Bombay docks were silent today. Along Mahatma Gandhi Road, the center of the city, children idly played soccer as policemen stood in small clusters near lockedup banks and shops., By midafternoon, when the sun was intense, the streets were nearly deserted except for a handful of strollers and ragged women and infants curled up on the pavement, sleeping.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES CANCELED POLICY
description: TRENTON, Jan. 2A woman whose automobile insurance policy was canceled because she was living with man without benefit of wedlock is seeking damages in Federal Court here.

title: I.R.S. REEXAMINES RETURNS OF NIXON; WON'T SAY MICH
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2The Internal Revenue Service announced today that it was reexamining President Nixon's tax returns, but it would not say which ones.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: DELIVERIES ABATE GASOLINE DROUGHT
description: The easing of the great New Year's gasoline drought in the metropolitan area yesterday was marked by new deliveries of fuel and new warnings of shortages from service station operators.

title: 3 Jersey Women to Join Special Army Company
description: NEWARK, Jan 2 (AP)Three New Jersey women enlisted in the Army today to become members of a special American company being formed to mark the first peacetime opening of a basictraining center for the Womens Army Corps.

title: Waking Up
description: BOSTON, Jan. 2One of the most sensible comments to come out of the United States Government in a very long time was made the other day by William E. Simon, the energy administrator. If and when the Arab oil embargo is lifted, he said, his major concern will be not letting the American people go to sleep again.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2Drawings by member countries from the International Monetary Fund in 1973 were their lowest level in 10 years, the fund reported today.

title: S.E.C. Names Canusa in Suit
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged Canusa Holdings, Ltd., of Canada, and Canusa Holdings, Ltd., of Delaware, with securities fraud. The S.E.C. said the two companies, their officers, and other defendants had sold about 850,000 unregistered shares of the two corporations stock from 1970 through 1973. The S.E.C. sought to enjoin the companies from further sales.

title: Boy Killed in Avalanche
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Jan. 2 (UPI)The body of Mark Rainey, 15 years old, was recovered today from a huge mass of snow that suffocated him yesterday in an avalanche down Mount Kotoya near here.

title: Vietcong and Saigon Seek Accord on P.O.W.'s by Tet
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 2 (UPI)The Vietcong urged the Saigon Government today to release all military and civilian prisoners before Tet, the Lunar New Year, on Jan. 23. The South Vietnamese said they would try to comply.

title: BIG OIL CONCERNS INCREASE PRICE
description: Several major oil companies announced yesterday that they were raising prices of gasoline and other products, effective immediately.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX ANDOT.O
description: Continuing the yearend rail! into the first day's trading o the new year, prices closet higher yesterday on the Amer ican Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market Volume declined.

title: FIGHTING ON HEIGHTS REPORTED BY SYRIA
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon Jan. 2Syria reported new fighting today with Israeli forces on the Golan Heights. to strengthen positions captured by Israel during the October war.

title: Wottle Weighs Joining Pro Track Tour
description: Dave Wottle, the Olympic 800meter champion and one of the world's top milers, said yesterday he was thinking very strongly about running as a professional this year.

title: COURTHOUSE TO FIND SPACE IN HOTEL HERE
description: The state plans to rent space in a hotel near the Bronx County Courthouse to free enough space in the building for six more courtrooms, officials said last night.

title: Stocks Climb in Late Rally
description: The opening session of 1974 proved a bonanza yesterday for gold, silver and other precious metal issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Advertising: Katz Dutch Treat

In Libya, meanwhile, Premier Abdul Salem Jalloud estimated that the real price of oil in the international market was $20 $25 a barrel. And n Venezuela, the Minister of Mines and Hydrocarbons, Dr. Hugo Perez la Salvia, said a global pricing sytem, aimed at averting continuing price increases, would be discussed by members of the Organization Petroleum Exporting Countries in Geneva this weekend.

title: Screen:Life of Wolf Pack Seen in 'Cry of the Wild'
description: So few animal documentaries for family viewing are filmed these days that one called "Cry of the Wild" is doubly welcome. Even so, don't be misled by those television trailers, heralding a close-up study of snarling wolves in the wild.While the footage has an atmospheric opening and closing in the Canadian Arctic, the wolf pack we see here in fascinating and remarkably intimate detail is roaming a carefully surveyed forest enclosure near Quebec. This middle portion of the picture, which was produced by the National Board of Canada and had a multitheater opening yesterday in the metropolitan area, is superb. At one Manhattan theater yesterday, the uptown Olympia, a capacity audience of children and parents drank it in raptly. No wonder.The picture has a curious history. Made in 1972, running only 50 minutes and titled "Death of a Legend," it was widely shown nontheatrically (schools, clubs, etc.). This release is its first theattrical exposure, through an American company, with a new title and 40 more minutes of the original footage restored.This footage is undoubtedly the prelude, which zeroes in scenically but rather meanderingly on the Canadian wilds, as the director-photographer, Bill Mason, and a narrator, generalize factually about the wolves, who snarl away in the distance.It's another matter entirely back at the Mason enclosure, with the charming Mason family overseeing their semi-tame pack. The camera records the animals' life cycle, including tribal hierarchy, feeding rituals, courtship and birth. A candid, tastefully shown birth sequence of a litter, with the wolf as tenderly solicitous as a doe, is a touching, even beautiful sight.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI) The Interior Department opened today 7.7 million acres of California's ocean shelf, some of it just off Los Angeles and its beaches, to oil and gas exploration.

title: U.S. OFFERS A PLAN ON BENEFIT CHECKS
description: Treasury officials met yesterday with New York City bank officials and leaders of the American Bankers Association, and broached a Federal proposal to ease checkcashing problems for recipients of Federal benefits.

title: High School Sports
description: I have had news for you, you have an ineligible player. When any Public Schools Athletic League coach hears those words, he shudders. When those words may mean forfeiting three games and a shot at a basketball title, the shudder gets worse. With the coaches at New Utrecht, which lost the Chance for its football division title because of a forfeit, the shudder may become shattering.

title: Horses
description: UNUSUAL PONY CARRIAGE with canopy top & wicker seat, excellent condition 51500. Horscdrawn Carriage completely restored. Details 2153557100, Mr. Epstein.

title: U.S STILL HOPEFUL ON GENEVA PARLEY
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Jan. 2  Defense Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel will meet Secretary of State Kissinger in Washington on Friday, with the Nixon Administration reasonably certain that the results of the Israeli election will not impede the current Middle, East negotiations.

title: Statement on Solzhenitsyn
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 2Following, in translation by The New York Times, is the text of a commentary distributed in Russian today by Tass, the official Soviet press agency, on Alehsandr I. Solzhenitsyn's book The Gulag Archipelago, 19181956:

title: Turf Publicists Choose Mrs. Tweedy for Prize
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP)Mrs. Helen (Penny) Tweedy, who managed the racing careers of Secretariat and Riva Ridge, was named today as winner of the Big Sport of Turfdom award by the Turf Publicists Association.

title: Chessie Raises Net 61.5% in Quarter
description: Chessie System, Inc., the first major company to issue calendar 1973 results, reported yesterday the second highest fourthquarter earnings and the highest annual net ever achieved by the Chesapeake OhioBaltimore & Ohio Railroads.

title: Builder Who Told of Bribes To Gurney Aide Goes to Jail
description: Miami, Jan. 2 (UPI)John Priestes, one of the first builders to implicate Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, in alleged corruption involving the Federal Housing Administration, surrendered today to United States marshals to begin serving a oneyear sentence.

title: DELIVERIES ABATE GASOLINE DROUGHT
description: The easing of the great New Year's gasoline drought in the metropolitan area yesterday was marked by new deliveries of fuel and new warnings of shortages from service station operators.

title: BEAME SAYS AIDES MUST NEW TO LINE ON CIVIL SERVICE
description: Mayor Beame, in his first full day of work at City Hall, issued an executive order yesterday that virtually forces a commissioner to choose Civil Service aides from the very top of the list.

title: MIDEAST PARLEY ON FORCES GAINS
description: MIDEAST PARLEY

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: Judge Rejects Motion by Carpi For Dismissal of Murder Case
description: TRENTON, Jan. 2Judge Arthur A. Salvatore in Mercer County Superior Court denied a motion today to dismiss murder charges against Colin C. Carpi, a Princeton investment consultant.

title: Til Lykke!
description: On Jan. 3, 1749, as the Age of Enlightenment was beginning to flourish across Europe, Ernst Henrich Berling of Copenhagen founded a newspaper. From that day to this, his Berlingske Tidende has survived in continuous publication under the continuous ownership the founder's family, spreading its solid influence across Scandinavia and the rest of Europe.

title: Chess: Karpov, Player of the Year, Gets in Some Last Licks
description: Ana toly Karpov, crowding in one last competition before his world championship quarterfinals match with Lev Polugaevsky begins Jan. 14 in Moscow, captured first prize in the Madrid International tournament. His impressive score was seven victories, no losses and eight dra ws.

title: Ray Petition Is Denied
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 2 (AP)James Earl Ray, convicted slayer of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was denied today his petition to prevent his transfer from state to Federal orison.

title: A Coach Is Hired
description: EL PASO, Tex., Jan. 2 (UPI)  The new TexasEl Paso football coach, Gil Bartosh, hired the Texas Christian University offensive backfield coach, Marvin Kristynik, as his offensive coordinator today.

title: Top Military Men Replaced by Peron
description: BUENOS AIRES. Jan. 3 !President Juan D. PerOn began I the new year by weathering his I most serious crisis with the armed forces since his return to power.

title: Beanie Throws Party For 200 at Mansion
description: Mayor Beame held his first reception at Gracie Mansion late yesterday just to say hello to about 200 legislators of both parties, their wives and members of his new administration.

title: An Important Stage
description: Diplomats are properly reticent in the midst of sensitive negotiations; one should not take casually, therefore, the official announcement that Egyptian and Israeli negotiators have reached an important stage in their Geneva talks. Secretary of State Kissinger spoke yesterday of progress being made, and predictions are rife that the two belligerents could complete agreement on a disengagement of their frontline forces before the month is out.

title: Humor About gaddafi Strains LibyaItaly Tie
description: ROME, Jan. 3  An Italiar newspaper jokingly suggester some time ago that peopli wanting to sound wellinformer would soon say that Presiden Muammar elQaddafi of Libyt was really an agent of thr United States Central Intel ligence Agency or was a homo sexual or had a secret haren of 48 women in Switzerland.

title: Progress Reported In Contract Talks For Off Broadway
description: Paul Libin, president of the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers, said yesterday that headway had been made with Actors Equity in negotiations for a new contract covering Off Broadway actors and stage managers.

title: Notes on People
description: Money contaminates the political process, said Representative Charles A. Vanik, Democrat of Ohio, in announcing yesterday that he would spend no funds other than his own, and accept no contributions, during his reelection campaign this year.

title: Sen. Dodd Acts to Revive Offshore Oil Port Debate
description: TRENTON, (AP)  The dormant controversy about a possible deepwater oil port of( New Jersey may be revived by legislation filed by the Senate Presidentdesignate, Frank J. Dodd. It would establish a state! agency to build and operate an offshore oil facility.

title: Byrne Names Ann Klein Chief of State Institutions
Screen: Outrageous Films Serves Outrage Poorly
Rainstorm Washes Out Crosby Golf
description: PEEBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 3The 1974 pro golf tour got under way today then came to a complete stop. The first round of the Bing Crosby tournament, which was to be the official kickoff of the $8.4million circuit, was canceled because :of severe rains and unplayable conditions.

title: Jury Selected in Carpi Murder Trial; Arguments to Open Monday in Trenton
description: TRENTON, Jan. 3A jury for the Carpi murder trial was ;selected so quickly today that Judge Arthur A. Salvatore of Mercer County Superior Court had to rearrange his schedule.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Jan. 3After scoring the most impressive victory in New Jersey college basketball this week, Rich Adubato, the coach at Upsala College, had a big grin and a happy tale to tell basketball writers today.

title: NEWS SHIELD BILL SPURRED IN HOUSE
description: Media Representatives and Judiciary Unit in Accord

title: Suit of Smelting Unit Off
description: HOLMDEL, N. J., Jan. 3 (UPI) Triangle Industries, Inc., has dropped the American Smelting and Refining Company from the defendants in its antitrust suit against major copper producers. Triangle said today it had reached an outofcourt settlement with Asarco,

title: MultimillionDollar Bet Ring Is Raided
description: The police raided in Harlem last night what they said was the headquarters of a multiminiondollar numbers gambling operation that took bets in the five boroughs as well as in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: Life Magazine to Reappear as a Monthly
description: Time Inc. is well along with plans to bring Life back next year as a monthly magazine.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Arthur Daley died yesterday at the age of 69. Following is an article written about hint in. December of 1966 Robert Lipsyte, then a member of The New York Times sports staff, for Times Talk, the newspaper's house organ.

title: CORPORATE BONDS MARK QUIET DAY
Japanese Millionaires Buy Miro Paintings, Not Fame
description: TOKYO, Jan, 3They build tape recorders and arrange flowers. They hang Miro paintings in their bathrooms and own beach houses in Hawaii., They help make Japan's foreign policy and marry Miss Tokyo. They are Japan's millionaires in Japanese, okuman choja (billionaires)  the men who have succeeded most in the phenomenal economic growth of the last two decades. That growth may now be endangered by the oil crisis, but the millionaires seem secure in their positions.

title: Author Wins Right To Talk to Brother Of Dr. King's Slayer
description: BOSTON, Jan. 3 (AP)  A Unjted States District Court judge has ordered the director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons to allow an author to interview the brother of James Earl Ray in the Federal penitentiary in Marion, Ill.

title: RETURN OF HUGHES DEEMED UNLIKELY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  A high Justice Department official conceded today that there was little hope of extraditing How ard R. Hughes from his Bahamas refuge to stand trial in a Las Vegas, Nev., stock fraud case.

title: WILSON OUTLINES ENERGY PROGRAM
description: ALBANY, Jan. 3Governor Wilson intends to seek emergency authority to deal with the energy shortage, including optional power to allocate limited fuel supplies if necessary, the assignment of state inspectors to combat price gouging and the purchase of 1,200 smaller cars for the state's use.

title: Experts Believe a Renewed Middle East War Could Be Wider and Deadlier
Bonn Acts to Curb Decline in Mark. Gold Price Rises
description: PARIS, Jan. 3  West German national bank authorities signaled today through the official sale of 38million in dollars that they were prepared to arrest at least temporarily the depreciation of the mark against the dollar.

title: EARL JOHNSON, 73, LED UNITED PRESS
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 3 (UPI) Earl J. Johnson, the editor for 30 years of the worldwide i news operations of United Press International and its predecessor, The United Press, died today at his home. He was 73 years old.

title: Atherton W. Hobler, 83, Dead; A Founder of Benton &
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 3 Atherton W. Hobler, founderchairman of Benton & Bowles, Inc., one of the country's largest advertising agencies, died today in Princeton Medical Center. He was 83 years old and had lived in Princeton for 33 years and for 27 years had had a winter home in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Dance: Hawkins Troupe
description: Nothing is quite so puzzling at first sight as Erick Hawkins's straightforward simplicity. He creates dances of varied but clear mood and then assigns sometimes obscure poetic titles to them. The titles often make them seem more complex than they really are, and the secret of enjoyment is to relax and keep one's eyes on the movement. The company opened its brief season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night.

title: G.M. Workers Call Layoffs A Death Knell for Big Car
description: LINDEN, N. J., Jan. 3Assemblyline workers about to he laid off at the General Motors plant here said today that their upcoming furloughs marked the beginning of the end of the big American automobile.

title: 20,000Gallon Oil Spill Coats River at Trenton
description: TRENTON, Jan. 3 (UPI)A storage tank containing 600,000 gallons of home heating fuel overflowed during a refilling operation today, causing an oil slick that coated the Delaware River for miles.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Bondrating houses are expected to make their decision today or early next week on the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority's application for a rating of the $295million bond issue to finance the Hackensack Meadowlands sports complex. Two earlier attempts to have bond issues rated by Standard at Poor's Corporation and by Moody's Investor Service were unsuccessful.

title: Ailing Reed Is Hoping To Join Knicks March 1
description: While the Knicks are winning without Willis Reed, the man of many aches and pains, Reed is laboring for still another comeback.

title: Drivers Waiting to Fill Empty Tanks Pour Out Their Many Tales of Woe
description: They came to the Mobil station on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn as nomads to an oasis.

title: BRITISH MUSEUMS CHARGINGPATRONS
description: LONDON, Jan. 3"You are proper tidy lady, the British Museum guard gallantly observed as he inspected the contents of Elizabeth Jennings's handbag, a perfunctory search accorded all museum visitors since the Irish Republican army began leaving bombs about London.

title: SAM TO CONDUCT AN INQUIRY ON OIL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UPI  Attorney General  designate. William B. Saxbe said today that he would pursue strict,i vigorous enforcement of the antitrust laws and would conduct an investigation of the oil companies to see if they had done anything to contrive the fuel shortage,

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS 11% BENEFIT RISE IN SOCIAL SECURITY
Owner of Company Is Slain in Kitchen Of Queens Friend
description: The owner of a pipe insulating company was found shot to death yesterday afternoon in the home of a friend in the Whitestone section of Queens, the police reported.

title: Errett Cord Is Dead at 79; Developer of Luxury Car
description: RENO, Nev., Jan. 3Errett Lobban Cord, the designer of the sleek streamlined Cord automobile of the nineteenthirties, died here yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, He was 79 years old and lived here.

title: RELIGIOUS PARTY COURTED IN ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 3After, retaining a narrow plurality in the parliamentary election Mon; day, officials of Premier Goldai Meir's ruling Labor party have plunged into a feverish roundi of negotiations with possible partners for a new coalition! government. Their first act, as it has often been in the last 25 years, was a pilgrimage to the offices of the National Religious party.

title: ParkRide Center to Open Monday at Willowbrook Mall
description: A parkandride operation at the Willowbrook Mall shopping center in Wayne will begin Monday, John J. Gilhooley, president of Transport of New Jersey, has announced.

title: When Seconds Count
description: Our radio car had just turned right onto Ocean Parkway from Avenue X when another call came over the air; SixOne, John.

title: Rheingold Brewery Held Ready to Close
description: The Rehingold brewery in Brooklyn, one of the two brewAhern, Rheingold's president, eries left in the city, faces imminent closing, Richard said last night. The company's directors will meet tomorrow The Rheingold brewery vote on discontinuing brewing operations after nearly 40 years.

title: S.E.C. URGES SHIFT IN INVENTORY DATA
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday urgedbut did not requirecorporations to disclose the profits they reap on inventories that rise in price from inflation.

title: Gypsy Moth Eggs in the Skylab Hold a Key to Control of Insect
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 Scientists for the Department of Agriculture are anxiously awaiting word on the hatching of 1,000 gypsy moth eggs now orbiting the earth in Skylab.

title: Cost of Market Basket Rises 1.2% to $56.74, a New Record
Wilson Asks More Power To Handle Fuel Shortage
description: ALBANY, Jan. 3Governor Wilson intends to seek emergency authority to deal with the energy shortage, including optional power to allocate limited fuel supplies if necessary, the assignment of state inspectors to combat price gouging land the purchase of 1,200 smaller cars for the state's use.

title: FASHION TALK
description: The Scarlett O'Hara dress, now that's me, said Glady Solomon, a hint of Old Virginny still lingering in her accent.

title: Japan Is Cutting Exports by 15% to 25%
description: TOKYO, Jan. 3Under the pinch of the oil crisis, Japan's enormous exports are being cut back 15 to 25 per cent, imperiling the economies of half a dozen Asian nations whose industries and agriculture are heavily dependent on Japanese supplies.

title: Advertising: MONY on the Move
description: In 1967 the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York (MONY for short) moved its advertising out of Benton & Bowles and into house agency headed by its former ad director. Now it's going back to a fullservice agencythe Marschalk Company, one of the Interpublic Group.

title: COUNCIL REFORMS PROPOSED BY TROY
description: Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., who is the county Demo cratic leader in Queens, pre sented seven proposals yesterday to overhaul the structure of the City Council and increase its budgetary powers.

title: Dealers See Panic Buying
description: Panic buying was blamed yesterday by gasoline manufacturers and retailers for the fact that, even while New York City motorists were lining up at pumps more often, they were doing less driving.

title: Ailing Dent Forfeits to Tennis Foe
description: SYDNEY, Jan. 3 (Reuters) Phil Dent of Australia, who was seeded fourth, retired because of shoulder trouble today in the third round of the New South Wales open tennis championships.

title: People and Business
description: T. Kirk Parrish, whose consumerproduct marketing experience includes the presidency of Life Savers, Inc., and of the American division of the WarnerLambert Company, has been named president and chief executive officer of LanvinCharles of the Ritz. He succeeds Frank W. Green, 48, who resigned after two years in the post to pursue personal interests.

title: NOVEMBER DEFICIT AT PENNSY REDUCED
description: The bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company anflounced yesterday that it reduced its loss in the month of November to $11.4million from a deficit of $20.6million in November, 1972.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: A Soup That Makes a Meal
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: Skylab Gyroscope Falters, Puzzling Ground Engineers
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 3 (UPI) One of the Skylab's ontrol gyroscopes faltered today for the second day in a row, leaving !ground engineers here puzzled as to the cause.

title: Reforming Judges ...
description: Governor Wilson's appointment of Justice Harold Stevens and Justice Samuel Rabin to fill vacancies in the Court of Appeals symbolizes his recognition of the importance of downstate in the judicial structure of New York. The elevation of the presiding justices of the First and Second Departments of the Appellate Divisionencompassing New York City's five boroughs and also seven suburban countiesbrings two seasoned jurists to the high bench in Albany, which is one of the most respected courts in the United States.

title: Pop Music:
description: Perhaps rock n roll only gives the appearance of change and pace. Mountain was a hard rock trio (the basic format of guitar, bass and drums) that broke up two years ago when apparently at the height of its popularity.

title: SPANISH CHANGES FAVOR RIGHTISTS
description: MADRID, Jan. 3  Spain's new Premier today produced a Cabinet in his own imagepolitically conservative and strong on authority and order.

title: ROBERT C. TYSON, 68, OF U.S. STEEL, IS DEAD
description: NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 3Robert C. Tyson, former chairman of the finance committee of the United States Steel Corporation, died yesterday at Norfolk General Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived here.

title: 70 Gas Stations Ordered To Roll Back High Prices
description: More than 70 gasoline stations in New York and New Jersey were found in violation of Federal price guidelines over the New Year's holiday and were ordered to adjust their prices, Internal Revenue Service spokesmen said yesterday.

title: To Clemson, A Bad Day For Soccer
description: MIAMI, Jan. 3There is proverb in the Middle East that says by morning one can tell what kind of day it's going to be.

title: TRISTAR PURCHASES 2 DETROIT BUILDINGS
description: TriStar Development, Inc., has purchased two major office buildings in Detroit for approximately $20million. The buildings are the 28story Fisher Building and the 11story New Center Building, both about three miles north of the city's downtown area.

title: 6 Arraigned as Abductors In Leftist Deprograming
description: Six young members of a local Communist antiSoviet group were arraigned in Criminal Court yesterday on charges kidnapping one of its own members and holding her against her will for three days an apartment in Washington Heights.

title: Flanders, 39, Ages to Cheers in O'Neill Play
description: On stage at the Morosco Theater, where he is appearing to critical raves as Colleen Dewhurst's father in the hit revival of Eugene O'Neill's A Moon for the Misbegotten, Ed Flanders is a crochety, profane, sly and scheming old gamecock of an Irishman, who masks a tender love for his only daughter behind a steady spate of abrasive insults and wild Celtic curses.

title: Accountant Queried by I.R.S. and Congressional Aides on Nixon's Tax Returns
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The staff of a Congressional jointi committee and two agents of! the Internal Revenue Service; questioned President Nixon's accountant privately today on, what the accountant said was every issue that has been raised concerning the legality of Mr. Nixon's tax returns during his Presidency.

title: Film Maker Records Religion in America for TV
description: Philip Garvin is one film maker who believes in getting involved with his subjects.

title: SOVIET ATTACKS WESTERN PRESS
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 3The Soviet Union charged today that the reactionary Western press had seized upon the new book by Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn as a pretext to mount a fresh antiSoviet campaign calculated 'to poison the atmosphere of detente.

title: Good Guy in Town William Charles Virdon
description: Bill Virdon must have made many friends in Pittsburgh. When the news reached the Pirates office yesterday that Virdon, dismissed as manager in the final month last season, was named to the post at the Yankees, the front office was elated. I'm tickled pink, said Danny Murtaugh, who replaced Virdon at Pittsburgh. You're gonna love him in New York. I think you're going to be in for an exciting brand of baseball.

title: Energy Ideas Set By Kuhn
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The Federal Energy Office said today that it had received general agreement among a wide variety of sports and recreation associations on a voluntary goal of reducing energy use by 20 to 25 per cent this year.

title: Oil and Gas Flow Stemmed
description: GLENROCK, Wyo., Jan. 3  Work crews yesterday finally stemmed the flow of oil land gas that has been gushing for the last 33 days from a well about 40 miles north of here

title: Energy Conservation Urged As Way of Life for U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  A Presidential advisory committee on the environment told Americans today that they must accept  and ultimately demand  energy conservation and make it a way of life.

title: Rain, Sleet, Snow Glaze the Streets And Roads Here
description: Snow, freezing rain and sleet buffeted the metropolitan area yesterday, creating icy streets that were expected to remain hazardous to motorists through this afternoon.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 58,000 increase in the number of workers 6,612,000  in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area last October was reported in the latest Bureau Labor Statistics report from the United States Department of Labor. Herbert Bienstock, assistant regional director for the bureau, noted that the rise reflected seasonal increases in employment by government, up 38,000. Seasonal employment increases in wholesale and retail trade, up 15,000, and services, up 5,000, also contributed to the monthly rise, he said.

title: Clear Track
description: Under pressure of the energy crisis, President Nixon has overcome his many reservations about the Northeast railway reorganization bill and signed the measure into law. His action was fully justified though there remains abundant basis for anxiety about the expense of the proposed rescue operation and about its chances for ever becoming selfsupporting.

title: Canada to Regulate Campaign Financing
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 3Canada's House of Commons adopted tough new rules today to govern the financing of election campaigns.

title: Market Place: One Man's Way To Turn Profit
description: Before the individual returns to the stock market on the assumption that yesterday's vigorous upbeat session signals the return of generally rising stock prices, he might well Consider the advice of 80yearold James Maratta,

title: Stratton Has Operation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP)Representative Samuel S. Stratton, Democrat of New York State, underwent surgery today at the United States Naval Hospital in Bethesda, Md., for removal of his gall bladder. He had been treated since September for a gallbladder condition. A spokesman for Mr. Stratton's office here said doctors expect him to resume his Congressional duties when the House reconvened Jan. 21.

title: Judge Denies 2 Defense Motions In Chesimard Murder Trial
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. The presiding judge in the trial of Mrs. Joanne D. Chesimard and Clark E. Squire denied two defense motions today in an abbreviated court session that focused largely on the racial aspects of the case.

title: G.M. Workers Say Layoffs in Linden Presage an End to Big American Car
description: LINDEN, N. J., Jan. 3Assemblyline workers about to be laid off at the General Motors plant here said today that their upcoming furloughs !marked the beginning of the end of the big American automobile.

title: People in Sports: Simpson Is Voted Best on Offense
description: It was the time of year for naming last year's bests and the voting was easy in the National Football League. O. J. Simpson Buffalo's power runner, who gained a record total of 2,003 yards was easily voted offensive player of the year and Dick Anderson, peripatetic safety for Miami, the defending Super Bowl champion, and N.F.L. interceptions leader with 8, for 168 returned yards was voted the defensive player of the year by the Associated Press,

title: Jury Convicts Youth Of Killing a Family Of Six in Georgia
description: DONALSONVILLE, Ga., Jan. 3 (UPI)  Carl J. Isaacs, the first of three Maryland prison escapers to go on trial for the mass murder of a south Georgia farm family, was convicted today on six counts of firstdegree murder and sentenced to die in the electric chair.

title: Kan Is Brooklyn Museum's Acting Head
description: Michael Kan, curator of primitive art at the Brooklyn Museum, has been named the niuseum's acting director. While the search for a new director proceeds, he will hold the post vacated by Duncan F. Cameron, who resigned under fire Dec. 18.

title: Our Trucker's Gone, but His Boss Knows a Place...
description: The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Watershed in Ulster
description: Continuation of savage terrorism by extremists both sectarian camps cannot obscure a historic achieve. ment in Northern Ireland. For the first time since creation of the province through partition of Ireland 52 years ago, Protestants and Catholics have joined forces to govern Ulster in coalition.

title: Gas Data Aid Skiers In Poconos
description: STROUDSBURG, Pa., Jan. 3The Pocono Mountains regirt operators have a hot line all their own. It's designed to keep cool the tempers of skiers anxious about gasoline. It's a simple setup, said Bob Uguc eioni, the head of the P oco n Mountains Vacation Bureau. All a skier has to do is phone our number and he'll receive the locations of a few dozen service stations that are open. It's our bit in guaranteeing skiers that they'll be able to get home once they get here.

title: Fog at Florida Air Base Delays Release of Barker
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3Foggy weather over Florida's Eglin Air Force Base has delayed the release of Bernard L. Barker, one of the seven convicted Watergate conspirators, from Federal custody, the Justice Department said today.

title: Quinichette Adds Warmth to Kerr Group
description: Paul Quinichette, who was known as Vice Pres when Lester Young was Pres among jazz tenor saxophonists in the nineteenforties and fifties, is back in town and playing regularly for the first time since 1958, when illness in his family led him to take a day job in electronics Mr. Quinichette has joined the little band led by Brooks Kerr at Churchill's, 1277 Third Avenue, turning what was a provocative trio Into a joyfully jumping quartet.

title: BIG BOARD FIRMS SLIP INTO DEFICIT
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its member firms lost an aggregate $6.7million in November, despite earlier Wall Street estimates that the month was profitable.

title: BROKER CHARGES BANK WITH FRAUD
description: Officers of the National Bank or North America, a large. New Yorkbased institution, allegedly solicited and received payoffs from a financially troubled shipping company in return for approving more than $7million in apparently illegal loans, according to documents filed in United States District Court here.

title: 8 Killed in Phnom Penh Rocket Attacks
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 3 (AP).Communistled insurgents killed 8 people and wounded 37 in a rocket attack on the Cambodian capital yesterday and today, according to official reports.

title: Bolshoi Stars Give Surprise Gala
description: MOSCOW, Jan, 3The Bolshoi Ballet school paraded the stars of three generations, including those of the future, in a surprise gala performance tonight to celebrate its 200th anniversary.

title: The Suburban Car Pool: Even More Vital Today
description: DOBBS FERRY, N.Y.  If it hadn't been for the midnight car pool and for mothers like Marilyn Sophos, the Dobbs Ferry High School Hockey Club might never have seen a faceoff last season.

title: The Pop Life
description: Glen Campbell is tired of being a pimple on stage, which means that Mr. Campbell, one of the top middleoftheroad musical draws in the country, is fed up with playing large arenas and stadiums. In New York last week he said: You have to look at appearances from the standpoint of the people. In some of these huge places they're lucky if they can see you, let alone hear. You're just a pimple on stage. I'm looking now to play smaller halls, theaters in the round, that sort of thing. Not nightclubs. Vegas apart, there are not too many of them around.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UPI)The Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today that $1.1billion in net savings flowed into thrift institutions in November, the highest level in six months. Despite the intlow, federally insured savings and loan associations made the lowest dollar value in mortgage loan closings in 23 months.

title: INDICTMENTS VOIDED FOR 12 WEATHERMEN
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (UPI) United States District Court Judge Julius J. Hoffman dismissed today a fouryearold indictment against 12 members of the Weatherman organization. The 12 were charged with leading riots in Chicago in 1969.

title: New U.S. Pullouts Leave 35,000 Men in Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 3 (AP)The United States has withdrawn 3,700 troops from Thailand since September, a top Thai defense official said today

title: Aeroflot to Install Units Made in the U.S.
description: The transfer of high technology from the United States has had little impact on the man in the street in the Soviet Union thus far, but one business. deal announced recently may ultimately benefit the average Russian by making air travel more pleasurable.

title: PRICES OF WHEAT MOVE UP SLIGHTLY March Contract Is at $5.55 Copper Gains Sharply
Israelis Obstruct Supplies For Egypt's Sinai Forces
About New York
description: Public School 127 was built in Brooklyn in 1900, which was two years after Brooklyn surrendered its sovereignty and became a part of New York, and considerably before anyone spoke of decentralization, open enrollment or guidance counseling. P.S. 127's first principal was John Malarky, and its fifth was John McGreevy. Mr. Malarky is long since gone. Mr. McGreevy, however, is with us today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HARD OF HERRING The Bronx Opera Company, which has been performing since 1967, will be doing Benjamin Britten's threeact comedy Opera Albert Herring, based on a Maupassant story, tonight, and tomorrow at 8 at the Bronx High School of Science, 75 West 205th Street. This infrequently staged work will involve a cast of 15 singers and, as Britten required, a chambersize orchestra of about 15 musicians. All involved onstage and in the pit are paid, and many of the trained singers have come out of Juilliardand other schools.

title: LAOTIANS IN ACCORD ON POLICING SYSTEM
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 3 (Reuters)The Laotian Government and the proCommunist Pathet Lao Agreed in principle today on the functions of joint police force in the country's two capitals.

title: Grandfather Frost Warms Young Hearts in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 3Grandfather Frost, whom Americans know better as Santa Claus, dropped in on an eager throng of Soviet schoolchildren today and doled out dollops of MarxismLeninism with his holiday candy.

title: Margin Cut Lifts Stocks
description: Stock prices soared yesterday following the Federal Reserve Board's reduction in margin requirements to 50 per cent from 65 per cent. The DowJones industrial average rose 25.37 points to 880.69. Also helping the market was a lowering of the prime rate to 9 per cent from 10 per cent by Chase Manhattan. Details, Page 43.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 3 (AP)The Jersey Knights of the World Hockey Association were sold today to Joseph Schwartz, a Baltimore businessman who said he planned to keep the team in New Jersey.

title: Women to Be Eligible to Take City Test for Sanitation Worker
description: For the first time, women will be eligible to take the Sanitation Department examination on March 2 to qualify for an appointment as sanitation workers.

title: Ali Safe in Bus Accident
description: DEER LAKE, Pa., Jan. 3 (AP)  Muhammad All escaped injury when his private bus skidded on an icy hill and struck an embankment today. Ali, who was driving the bus, was taking a group of people from his training camp in this wooded area near Reading to Philadelphia when the accident occurred.

title: Kuwait Sets 60% Control Of Western Oil Venture
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 3 (AP)  Kuwait has reached agreement with two major Western oil companies to take over 60 per cent of their jointly owned Kuwait Oil Company, a high Kuwaiti oil official was quoted as saying today. Sheik Saad al Abdullah, the Minister of Defense and the Interior, was reported by the Beirut newspaper An Nahar to have said in an interview that the agreement with the Gulf Oil Corporation and the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., included the option of complete nationalization in five years, The two companies jointly own the Kuwait Oil Company.

title: Silent Nights Ahead
description: When I first met him, he was already old. People treated him with respect just because of that, just because he was the oldest guy in the gym. Not that he was a big deal or anything. Guys weren't shaking his hand or giving him tips on the horses like they do to a trainer whose fighter was going some place. But nobody gave him a hard time and that was something at the gym. He was just short, old man. And nice enough, guess.

title: Drop in Margin a FactorOil Issues Gain
description: Natural resource stocksthe new glamour group on Wall Streetspearheaded a powerful market advance yesterday on heavy volume. Leading gold stocks fell on profit taking.

title: Attica Reopened
description: Maybe New York State and some of its highest officials will have to accept the responsibility, after all, for the use of excessive force and violence in the bloody recapture of the Attica Correctional Facility from rebellious inmates on Sept. 13, 1971.

title: AbdulJabbar Scores 38 In 120105 Buck Victory
Secretariat Declared Fertile
description: PARIS, Ky., Jan. 3 (AP)H. K. Taylor, manager of Claiborne Farm, said today that Secretariat was fertile one of his test mares is in foal.

title: Dramatic Military Shifts in China
