Wilson Planning to Offer Daily, FastAction Lottery
description: Governor Wilson plans to propose a new state lottery that would be conducted on daily basis with fast payoffs and a choice of bets in an attempt to compete more successfully with illegal numbers gambling.

title: Miss Edith Rockefeller Fiancee of E. C. Laird 3d
description: RYE, N. Y., Jan. 5  The engagement of Miss Edith McKee Rockefeller to Edwin C. Laird 3d of Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William Rockefeller of Rye and Paul Smiths, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. Laird Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Mrs. Harper Woodward of Rye.

title: 7 in Family Die in Crash
description: AUBURNDALE, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP)Eight persons, including seven members of one family, were killed early today when speeding car plowed head  on into a Volkswagen bus on a narrow curve, the police said. The victims in the bus were identified as Dana Smith, 28 years old, of Winter Haven; his wife Theresa, 28; and children Bunny Anne,11.Ronald Joseph, 5, Michael, 3, Vanessa Lee, 1, and Rose Califore, 11 months. Also killed was Michael Labun of Auburndale, 22, the lone occupant of the car. Three other Smith children, Dana Jr., 10, David, 8, and Anthony, 8, were hospitalized in nearby Winter Haven in serious condition.

title: A Jealous Suitor Hired a Killer To Slay Girlfriend, Police Say
description: A jealous suitor, who the police said hired a man to the girl who had spurned him, was held without bail day with the alleged slayer on homicide charges in Criminal Court,

title: 3 Subway Workers in Robberies Seized Of Cash and Tokens
description: Two clerks and a porter, working in the city's subway, system were arrested yesterday and charged with a chain of robberies of subway change booths over the last several months in which, the Transit Authority said, they had stolen $75,000 worth of cash and tokens.

title: Rx for Language Barrier
description: When the doctors scolded the young Korean nurses, they smiled. When the patients complained that they were being ignored by the nurses, they smiled. When the hospital threatened to discharge them, they tried smiling even harder.

description: CHELSEA, Mass., Jan. 5 (AP) The state civil defense director, Louis F. Saba, presented a check for $184,144 from the Federal Government to Chelsea Mayor Philip Spelman as par tial reimbursement for dam ages to the city in a fire that destroyed 18 blocks last Oct. 14.

C., have announced the engagement of Mr. Leib's daughter, Miss Melissa Carr Leib, to Robert Illingworth veghte, son of Mrs. Robert Debow Veghte Jr, of Bernardsville, N.J., and Siasconset, Mass., and the late Mr. Veghte. A late June wedding is planned.

description: REIDSVIILLE, Ga. Jan. 5 It's not that Joe Hopper is a recruiter or bird dog, mind you. But when he read about a prominent 7foot professional basketball player being convicted recently, he knew what that might do for his basketball team.

title: The new novel by the new Nobel Prize winner
description: Great literature is like moral leadership: everyone deplores the lack of it, but there is a tendency to prefer it from the safely dead. Contemporary writers who threaten to alter us with knowledge and extend us with pleasure and pain seem to pass through a period of ritual resistance from critics. Reviewers whimper that familiar ground is being reworked, that the latest books are not up to the early works (which they had inadvertently neglected to praise at the time), with the implication that this somehow invalidates the whole. During this interregnum, the writer's humanity is stigmatized as indulgence, his discernment as embitterment; he is getting soft, or harsh, or nowhere. Until we submit, at last, to our own enlargement through his intention, revelation and particular

title: The World
description: The Labor alignment of Premier Golda Meir has slipped a little in national parliamentary elections, but the results are not expected to force any immediate fundamental change in Israel's position at negotiations in Geneva. That longrange position essentially reflects a willingness to give up an unspecified amount of formerly Arab territory in exchange for notyetdefined secure boiders.

title: Legal Notices Ruling Is Disputedin Nassau
description: MINEOLA, L. I.A valuable footnote in the practice of denoecracy  the smallprint legal notice that newspapers carry to alert the public to bearings and issues has escalated to political headline proportions in Nassau County.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT Raw Materials Flap
description: WASHINGTON  Prob. ably the hottest intellectual debate in town is getting few headlines, though the issue involved may be much more Important than, for example, Watergate. It is over the seemingly simple but extremely uncertain question of whether the world is running out of resources  or at least of whether we all face constantly increasing prices for those resources.

title: Dr. Maurice Lenz, Radiologist And Columbia Professor, Dead

J.) Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 1375 River Road, Edgewater, N. J.

title: Does new math add up?
description: Throughout the nineteensixties, the new math, or, as mathematicians prefer to call it, modern mathematics, was heralded as a revolution mathematics teaching. Its purpose, according to its proponents, was to stress the whys rather than the hows of mathematics, and to deemphasize the drill and rote learning that had been the substance of traditional mathematics education.

title: DISABLED VETERANS GET PENSION RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UPI) Higher pensions have gone into effect for about 2.7 million disabled American veterans, dependents and survivors to help offset the rising cost of living.

title: New &Novel
description: In this documentary novel a Swedish novelist tries to face up to a corner of a massive scandal. The scandal is the forcible repatriation (by several nations, including ours) of millions of reluctant Soviet nationals (Hungarians, Baits, etc.) after World War II. Per Olov Enquist focuses here on the deportation to the U.S.S.R. of 146 Latvians who had served in the German Army and sought asylum in Sweden. This incident has been a durable cause cabre in Swedish politics, and Enquist decided to provide an objective account. He interviewed rightwing politicians, leftwing politicians, and some surviving Baltic legionnaires in Riga. He wrote to Mao Tsetung for counsel, regarding the Chariman as his special Ann Landers. (I am writing because I need advice. Chariman Mao, what is your answer? I have for

title: The taxing trials of I.R.S.

The 13,000 revenue agents don't know where to begin. Voluntary selfassessment, which former Commissioner Johnnie M. Walters used to call a marvel of the world, collapses. The Government goes broke.

title: Sellout Is Likely for Super Bowl
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 5The Super Bowl game, to be played here next Sunday in Rice Stadium, is expected be a sellout. Of the 71,882 seats in Rice Stadium, 24,000 were set ..aside for the fans of the competing teams, the Miami Dolphins. and Minnesota Vikings. The ,sale began last Wednesday, and any leftover tickets will be returned here. There are not expected to be any.

Snider, Mr. Wallace's chief of staff for national affairs.

It becomes almost a duty to read them, for in one way or another they all obviously intend to do us a great deal of practical good.

title: The President Was Right

Nixon, tormented daily by a scandal he could not thrust away, exploded in anger at the television networks on Oct. 26, all but lost in the debris was an observation he made before he lashed out. The magnified effect of public affairs on public opinion now, compared to what it was 25 years ago, the President said, is the result of the growth of television.

title: Movies So They Robbed a Bank and Lived Happily Ever After

description: For many years, incometax deductions and other tax allowances have been likened to Federal subsidies to favored taxpayers. In 1959, for example, Walter Heller applied the label backdoor spending to tax provisions designed to encourage home ownership, business investment, oil exploration and other activities. He complained that these subsidies originate in the taxwriting committees of Congress rather than in the appropriations committees, that they are administered by the Internal Revenue Service rather than by the Federal agencies with general responsibility for and expertise in the activities favored in the tax legisla

description: Profits in the textile industry turned up sharply last year, but there is a deep concern about the loss of markets resulting from fiber shortages and inflation and doubt that the profit level can he maintained.

description: THE nicest setting, by far, by far, in the Phoenix Repertory Company's revival of Philip Barry's Holiday is an upstairs nursery in the multiroomed mansion of the very rich. There, upon occasion, the idle daughter and idler son of the household can repair to lick their pretty wounds, mourn their comfortable but ever so inhibited lives, and try for a spot of brightness again as they remember the world of rocking horses, Humpty Dumpty astride his and their wall, and gay trapezes hung from the ceiling.

title: Athens Daily Gives Back Gift to Greek Government
description: ATHENS. Greece, Jan. 5 (AP) An Athens newspaper says it has returned a holiday gift of liquor from the Greek Government with the request that. it he sent to a member of the newspaper's staff in an island prison camp.

title: The Ten Best Films of 1973
description: SOMETHING quite peculiar happened in 1973: five of my best films of the year were made by American directors, as were six of the 10 runnersup. One way of reading this is to assume that more good films weremade here in 1973 than in any recent year. Or one can be blunt and say simply that foreign films were worse, even though we usually receive the best of the lot.

title: Toward a New Ethic
description: How does a society of more than 200 million persons go about changing its lifestyle? The oil shortage, exacerbated by Arab nations for their own political purposes, has brought this fundamental question before the American people. It is an inescapable question. If the Middle Eastern crisis had not arisen, oil shortages and unacceptably high prices would have made their appearance in the 1980's. As it is, the timetable has only been speeded up.

title: Esposito Has Reportedly Been Under Investigation for 4 or 5 Years for Possible IncomeTax Evasion

title: INTENSE FIGHTING AT SUEZ REPORTED
description: CAIRO, Jan. 5Intense outbreaks of fighting between Israeli and Egyptian forces in and around the city of Suez were reported today by the headquarters of the United Nations Emergency Force here, which described the situation at tense.

title: Top Syrians Said to Disagree On Policy Toward Peace Talks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan, 5Disagreement is reported to he growing among Syrian Government leaders on the policy the nation should follow on the Middle East negotiations.

title: The Age of the AvantGarde
description: Contemporary art looks and acts increasingly like a frameup. Trivial or ghastly objects are placed in an art context and are certified as art works. When its most publicized events resemble a conspiracy to defraud the public of any continuity of understanding or canon of taste, art has little identity left. The avantgarde ideal that has sustained it for decades is as vulnerable to revision as kindred concepts of progress and economic growth.

title: Daylight Time Begins
description: The United States has begun a nearly nationwide experiment to see whether pushing back nightfall by an hour will help depress America's winter thirst for fuel.

title: Plainfield Teams Advance in Curling
A Traveler's Guide To FuelShort Europe From A (Amsterdam) to Z (Zurich)
description: AMERICANS headed for Europe this winter will find the various countries quite differently affected by the fuel shortage. The Netherlands, for example, is hardest hit because it will not benefit directly from the recent Arab decision to increase the flow of oil to friendly nations by 10 per cent starting this month. Even so, spokesmen for other countries ranging from President Pompidou of France to , the Minister of Trade of Denmark have warned their countrymen that the recent Arab decision should not inspire .undue optimism. It will take a while for increased shipments to arrive, and the effects of an enormous jump in the price of fuel will be feltperhaps indefinitely. Some countries that depend heavily on tourism have announced policies of priority allocation of fuel for tourist travel and for resort industries, but, at the same time, the traveler will find Sunday driving bans not uncommon, some trains crowded and some flights curtailed. One American overseas, however, saw a bright side to the fuel shortage. The Sunday driving ban in Rome, he breathed contentedly, had allowed heavenly quiet to descend on that normally cacophonous city. Herewith a roundup of reports from Britain and the Continent.

title: World Cup Teams Seeded
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Jan. 5 (AP)Brazil, Uruguay, were seeded today to head fourteam groups for the first round of the 1974 World Cup soccer championships.

title: DOCTORS ORGANIZE CHILDABUSE UNIT
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 5A group of pediatricians here have formed committee to heir Nassau doctors handle child. abuse cases so that the children they see are not mistreated again, sometimes fatally.

title: Television
description: ABOUT a year ago, CBS News started work on a family portrait and the result, shown a week ago Friday, was a twohour documentary called The Rockefellers. With Burton Benjamin as executive producer, the product was good journalism. If the warts and all weren't dwelt on, they were at least mentioned during the course of the program.

title: MORE MILITARY AID SOUGHT FOR SAIGON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5The Nixon Administration is moving ahead with plans to ask Congress for increased arms aid to South Vietnam during the current fiscal year, according to number of Administration officials.

title: Terrorists Attack Phnom Penh Home Of the Army Chief
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sunday, Jan. 6 (AP)Terrorisis attacked the home of the Cam. bodian Army commander with rockets and grenades today, the military police reported.

title: Less is more is practical
description: I t's like a great dress that doesn't wrinkle, says fashion designer Chester Weinberg about his new city apartment. He wanted a place to live in that embodied the same elegance, absence of fussy detail and practicality that he has achieved in the design of his clothes. That meant replacing fragile antiques and delicate fabrics with well designed, functional furnishings. The hanging lamps used throughout, for instance, are the porcelainfinished, white. metal fixtures that were originally designed for use in factories. Tables are made from standard, restaurantstyle, black metal pedestals with black Formica tops. Scaleddown versions of the classic drafting chair are used as occasional chairs. Commercial  grade wool carpeting in a warm beige covers the floors and the seating platform in the living room. The only furniture specifically designed for use in homes is the two lounge chairs with bleachedwood frames which were created in the nineteenthirties by Finnish architect Alvar Aalto. The beiges and taupes of the carpeting and and natural woods dominate the apartment's three rooms  a 20by20foot living room, a 12by16foot bedroom and the breakfast nook in the small kitchen. This unified color scheme and the repetition of the basic elements of furnituretables, lamps and chairsgive the place the illusion of being much larger than it is. Joseph D'Urso, who designed the apartment, shares Mr. Weinberg's views on what constitutes elegance today, and that doesn't mean expensive furniture. They believe that machinemade objects can be well constructed and beautiful and that dull, highrise spaces can be personalized without major architectural changes. Mr. Weinberg hates to treat furniture and art as investments. I'd rather make the investment in terms of daily living, he says. A bachelor working in a frenetic business, he especially appreciates the ease with which the apartment can be kept tidy. Even when it looks like a cyclone hit it, he says, I can pull it together in half an hour. Getting ready for guests means grabbing a few spectacular flowers as I get off the subway and putting them in the glass vases makes the look festive.

title: Baylor Gets Aide
description: WACO, Tex., Jan. 5 (UPI) Dal Shealey, who compiled a 3012 wonlost record as head coach at CarsonNewman College in Jefferson City, Tenn., has been named backfield coach and administrative assistant to the Baylor head coach, Grant Teaff. Shealey is a former head coach at Mars Hill College in North Carolina.

title: Israel Lists Population Gain
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 5 (Reuters) Israel's population at the end of 1973 was 3,305,000, including 2,803,000 Jews, 496,000 Arabs (including East Jerusalem) and other minority groups, according to the Israel Bureau of Statistics. This represented an increase of 3.2 per cent over last year's figures, the bureau said.

title: JERSEYANS FACE MURDER CHARGES

Joseph Jacobs gives her no name in particular, but she is always the same folk figure: the inept childwife, short on wits but pure in heart, rushing in where angels fear to tread, bumbling her goodnatured way to unexpected triumph amid the wreckage of her household and her husband's cornposu re.

description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 5 (UPI)President Nixon reappointed two union leaders Wednesday to a 13member panel that advises the United States Postal Service on all mail operations.

title: The English version of
description: The worlds of Alice, Wonderland and Through the LookingGlass, are worlds of violence encased in fantasy played out by a river bank on a sunny afternoon. Alice is a serious, soberfaced child hemmed in and confronted by grownup games. Cards and chess and English academic politics suffer a seachange in the hands of a Victorian author sexually attracted only to little girls. All the elements of nightmare are present, including knowing, courageous innocence in a word of swelling, twisting chimeras and malicious small animals running, falling and even stoning a beleaguered heroine with stones that turn into cakes when they landand for a moment, Alice becomes the English version of Marquis de Sade's Justine. But only for a moment. For in fantasy, terror never takes root; one never does drown in one's own tears but rather is fed and comforted by them. English tea always arrives to round off each adventure, and children's narrow beds finally

description: LONDONBritain is filled with wartime spirit of panic and nostalgia, pleasant and exciting. Is there crisis, or isn't there? Should one start to stockpile lentils and sardines, should one buy a bicycle?

title: Italy Suspends Driving Ban
description: ROME, Jan. 5 (Reuters).Italy's ban on Sunday driving will be lifted this weekend to allow families to return home from their Christmas and New Year holidays, the Government has announced. The suspension of the ban  introduced six weeks ago as part of a package of fuelsaving measures was ordered because Sunday is the Feast of the Epiphany, traditionally the last day of extended Christmas holidays taken by Italians.

title: It May Be Too Late To Save the City Opera
description: THIS is going to be a dull article, all about statistics. It is no news that the New Year brings problems to the leading cultural organizations of the city. From the Metropolitan Opera comes gritting of teeth, tightening of belt buckles and modification of plans. From the New York Philharmonic, formerly one of the symbols of stability on the American orchestral scene, comes stories of an unprecedented deficit, lack of back.up funds and the possible necessity of eating into capital. From ballet companies come sheer horror stories, and one or two of them are hanging on by the sheerest of threads.

title: A Shoestring Cruise On the Sea of Cortes
description: SAILING time is 5 P.M., but the Mexicans have the foresight to board an hour earlier. With sacks of food, bedrolls, babies and even an occasional crate of live chickens, they stake out the choicer sleeping spots the underside of a stairwell, a padded bench in the ship's cafeteria, a sheltered corner of the stern deck. The ferryboat La Paz will be their home for 17 hours on the cruise between Mazatlan on the Mexican mainland and La Paz in Baja California, and Mexican families such as these learned centuries ago how to cope with crowded quarters, scant privacy and physical vliscomfort far worse than this. One simply builds an invisible wall of dignity and patience, settles down behind it, and endures.

This year's show, comprising about 30 paint ings and pieces of wool em broidery, has been extended at least through the end of this week  further indication, if any is required, of her vast popularity.

The play, untitled at this time, is by John Weidman, a new playwright who is in his third year of law school at Yale University. Its leading character is Commodore Matthew Perry, the American naval officer who in 1852 was sent to Japan by President Millard Fillmore to establish diplomatic and trade relations. The play calls for cast of about 20.

title: America In Legend
description: You can almost tell this book by its colorful dust jacket. And if the book makes claims for itself that go beyond the plain pleasures on each slickly designed page, these pleasures are nonetheless what strike a reader immediately. The first thing you get for your $15 is a treasury of illustrationsmore than 150 photographs, lithographs, engravings and paintings, . not to mention playbills, posters and songscores. All this helps to carry Richard M. Dorson's chronicle a long way: from Salem to Berkeley; from Colonial ghosts, demons and providences (The Religious Impulse) to heads, narcs and the LSD millionaire Stanley Augustus Owsley (The Humane Impulse); from folk remedies such as bottling the urine of witches, to latrinalia like Ronald Reagan mainlines Koolaid.

title: A Bit Lucky Wins Two Show Titles
description: SCARSDALE, Jan. 5  A Bit Lucky didn't need any luck today and easily captured both the suitable and local working hunter championship at the Boulder Brook Horse Show. Owned by Mrs. James Fulton of White Plains and ridden by Jim Arnott, A Bit Lucky scored 13 points in each division. By coincidence, he collected first and second place ribbons and captured the under saddle test in both competitions.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Vandals have caused up to $15,000 damage inside the First Presbyterian Church of Toms River, N.J., a 115yearold landmark. It was the second historical church in the arca to he damaged by vandals in recent weeks. Two days before Christmas, a fire set in Lacey Township, seven miles south, destroyed the preRevolutionary War building in which the Universalist Church of the United States was founded.

description: The Panama Canal is part of the coastline of the United States. Its protection is just as important in the defense of the Western Hemisphere as that of the Chesapeake or San Francisco Bays.

title: Narrow Base in Spain

He has removed from the Cabinet the last of the oncepowerful technocrats of the Opus Dei Catholic lay movement the men who worked hard to lure foreign investment, modernize and expand the economy, push Spain toward membership in the European Common Market and even increase trade with the Soviet bloc.

title: A. C. Starkey Jr. Becomes Fiance Of Miss Haines

title: Consumerism. Uphill Struggle
description: Consumerism Is probably the most important sociological pressure faced by business in many years. title: Recordings At Last, All of Caruso
description: LAST February, the world celebrated the centenary of Enrico Caruso's birth. The world didbut not the record company whose fortunes he built. Back in the 1940's, RCA Victor used to recall this debt at Christmas, making special pressings of Caruso recordings as gifts for favored friends and customers, there being nothing more prized, nothing more characteristic of the company's heritage. But corporate memory cells aren't what they used to be, and only now, months later, has RCA's Caruso celebration materialized in the shops.

title: Football people
description: As it must surely be impossible not to know, George (Paper Lion) Plimpton once spent some time in training camp with the Detroit Lions. During the summer of his romance with pro football, he became particularly friendly with two of the Lions best linemen: John Gordy, an offensive guard known as The Bear (because his body was covered with a thick peltlike thatch of hair, and on his way to the shower . . .one of his teammates would invariably. . .call out, Hey, John, don't forget to take off your overcoat ) and Alex Karras, a defensive tackle whose quickness of foot and savage bustling style of attack earned him the title The Mad Duck. Plimpton, Gordy and Karras undertook to write a manual about the technique of linemen. What evolved was, instead, in Plimpton's words: an irreverent, roguish account of their lives as football players, full of anecdote, reminiscence and story, often tempered by grievance, but always with an under

title: Photography Puerto Rico to New York
description: DOS MUNDOS or Two an exhibition of Puerto Rican photography at the New York Cultural Center to Feb. 10, is handsomely installed. The large main gallery is divided into smaller viewing areas by groups of square pillars that suggest garden walls. Tropical plants from the island trail over the walls, and in the open areas between them large blowups of selected photographs counterpoint groups of smaller prints. .

title: Suit Against Indianapolis Alleges Negligence in Fire
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 5 (UPI) A lawyer has filed a $250million class action suit against the city of Indianapolis and five persons alleging negligence in, a fire that burned out part of the downtown business district last November.

title: There Is One Surfeit: Shortages
description: WHILE gasoline and heating oil are most conspicously lacking on the national shopping list, the catalogue of shortages the country faces is much longer than that. There are shortages of raw materials that do not reach the eye but are essential to finished goods. There are shortages derived from other shortages, as in fertilizer and textiles. There are shortagesin coarse paper, for examplecreated by the very effort to deal with shortages by government controls. Despite the Arab embargo, the shortages of gasoline and heating oil reflect not so much a lack of oil an absence of refinery capacity to replace the overseas capacity. Even before the Arabs acted, E.N.I., the Italian oil monopoly, had halted shipments of heating oil the United States East Coast, preferring to serve the rising European gasoline market. Shipments from Spain and Belgium had been reduced, but not ended, for the same reason.

title: Ideas&Trends Education, Medicine, Media, Oceanography, Ethology
description: Many of the country's college professors, librarians and student counselors are learning the same tough lesson absorbed by the migrant farm workers who stumbled out of the dustbowl into the San Joaquin Valley in the 1930's. When money is tight, demand low and there are too many applicants for one job, salaries stay low, working conditions deteriorate and job security does not last any longer than it takes to say you're fired.

title: Music Why Does She Conduct Herself That Way?
description: SHORTLY after 2:30 on Saturday afternoon, a fraillooking little woman with snowwhite hair will step out onto the stage of Carnegie Hall and make her way to the front of the orchestra waiting there. Once arrived, she will peer nervously at the audience assembled before her and, after a shy acknowledgement of the welcoming applause, will mdunt the podium and pick up a big baton. In that tensionfilled instant before the downbeat, she will probably be saying to herself, Steady C. Bergen, steady.

title: Beame Has Job for Dinkins If He Settles Tax Problem
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that he hoped to name a new Deputy Mayor within a few days to replace David N. Dinkins, who withdrew because of tax difficulties, but that he hoped to bring back Mr. Dinkins into his administration as soon as those problems can be settled.

But a lot of even more serious questions will be on the table when the National League club owners meet in Chicago Wednesday.

title: A Specter of Recession
description: WASHINGTONIt's going to be a rough year for the Government officials responsible for keeping the American economy in tune. For added to the problem of inflation, which persisted throughout 1973, the specter of a recession in 1974. Not just a typical, cyclical downturn in business that would respond to the traditional tools of economic stimulus, but a recession caused by a shortage of energy and of the materials produced by energyand therefore not as responsive the traditional methods as previous recessions. The danger of both widespread unemployment and soaring inflation is real.

title: The eatallyournwant Chinese diet Filling, not fattening
description: To eat welland not gain weightseems like the impossible dream, but the Chinese have known how for centuries. The everyday family menu for four outlined on this page is an example. The caloric intake (see chart) is modest, yet the meal is so filling that no dessert is needed. There are those who object (and I'm sure you've heard this), I love Chinese food, but half an hour later I'm starving. The reason is that they don't know how to eat a Chinese meal. They dip into one vegetable or meat or fish dish, then another, but skimp on the rice because they think it is fattening. In fact, generous portion of rice represents no more than 125 to 150 calories and makes all the difference between feeling satisfied or ravenous a few hours later. The dieter who passes up the rice may find himself gorging later on a piece of layer cake, which represents more calories (perhaps 800) than his dinner. Al! four dishes in this menu should be placed on the table at once, so that diners may have a mouthful of beef, a sip of spicy soup, a little fish, then some rice and enjoy the variety

title: Broadway Theaters Under Pressure
description: As the long, steady decline in the number of Broadway productions continues, a drama Involving Manhattan's theatrical real estate seems about to unfold. It involves new playhouses and old ones, and its denouement could have farreaching implications for the future of the stage.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 Grenada, southernmost of the Windward Islands, is moving uneasily but on schedule toward independence on Feb. 7, according to reports reaching here from the Caribbean.

title: Criminals At Large
description: John D. MacDonald's paperbacks have sold more copies than there are hamburgers at McDonald's. His Travis McGee books have been especially successful. Travis McGee is the battered Galahad who lives on a houseboat in Florida, observes caustically our life and times, dispenses Deep Thoughts about life and society, helps people out for a 50 per cent fee and gathers girls unto him like a fisherman bringing up pilchards in a net. MacDonald has assumed the status of a legend. There is a newsletter devoted to the man and his works, and he has a following whose fervency would shame that of a Mohammedan on his to Mecca.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the author's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: The Year of the Tiger
description: HAPPY New Year of the Tiger, and farewell year of the ox. In the Chinese lunar calendar, observed in much of the Oriental world, years have their annual animal symbols. This is the year of ChiaYin, reckoned by the traditional Chinese system of Celestial Stems and Terrestial Branches, and the symbol of the year is the tiger.

title: Pop The Sound That Sells a Million
description: BACKSTABBERS (Philadelphia International KZ 31712), the O'Jays previous album for Philadelphia producers Kenny Gamble and Leon Huff, was both innovative and commercially successful. Thom Bell's arrangements of the title tune and of Love Train set new standards of polish and complexity in black popular music, and these tracks became millionsellingsingles. The O'Jays gritty vocals were equally important factors in the phenomenal success of Backstabbers. The Cincinnati, Ohio, trio projects an earthy, occasionally abrasive quality which contrasts with the sweet harmonies and falsetto leads characteristic of most Philadelphia International groups.

title: Lawyer Labors to Turn Workers Into Owners
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For 20 years now, unfazed by rebuffs that would have snuffed out the enthusiasm of most men, San Francisco attorney Louis O. Kelso has plumped unceasingly for an idea he is convinced would solve virtually all our economic problems  universal capitalism.

title: In Japan, Oil May Expose Ills of Growth
description: TOKYORushing through lunch atop one of Tokyo's gleaming new skyscrapers last week, a Japanese business executive pulled out sheaf of carefully prepared estimates of Japan's economic prospects for 1974.

title: A Cellist in Search of Repertory
description: FOR Robert Sylvester, the important thing is to enlarge the traditional repertory for his chosen inntrument. When the New Yorkborn cellist made his debut here as a solo recitalist in 1969 in Tully Vali, he included not only a new work by Michael Ries,man but also a recently discovered Boccherini sonata and Chopin's Grand Duo on Themes from Meyerbeer's gobert le Diable. Tonight he returns to Tully Hall for another recital, and again the program will mix standard material with works not often encountered nowadays.

description: Some of the beat privately told stories in Wall Street these days Involve brokers who sold short the stocks of rival brokerage firms and later netted a profit when these stocks nosedived.

He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Corsa Jr. of Bay Shore. L. I. An autumn wedding is planned.

title: Mr. Nixon, the WouldBe Kennedy
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.The Saturday Night Massacre, the kamikaze escapade during which President Nixon fired Special Prosecutor Archibald Cox and accepted the resignations of his two top Justice Department aides, Elliot Richardson and William Ruckelshaus, has been attributed to poor staff work, a lack of political sensitivity, or, at best, cynical miscalculation. I don't believe it.

Educational expenditures and enrollments climbed rapidly, and the country was in the mood for new gadgets and techniques, from electronic multimedia centers to the new math, that promised to ease the slow and painful process of learning.

description: BOSTON, Jan. 5 (AP)  A proposal to enlarge four suburban airports so they may take over some traffic from Boston's Logan International Airport has met opposition by local officials in the four communities.

title: Lee Ann Davidson To Be Wed Feb.16
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 5Mr. and Mrs. Harold Osborn Davidson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lee Ann Davidson, to Pelham Wilder 3, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilder Jr. of Durham, N. C. The wedding is planned for Feb. 16 in Chevy Chase, Md., where the Davidsons formerly lived.

title: Notes of a Sumo Wrestling Fan
description: ONE afternoon at a sumo wrestling match in Tokyo, I let out a wild cheer when the only American wrestler in the competitionJesse Kuhaulua of Maui, Hawaiithrew his opponent to win his bout. A Japanese fan, who was sitting on the tatami mat in the next box, chuckled and reached over the low railing between us to shake hands. As I took his hand, I said: Yoku gambarimashita, ne, which means roughly he really did well, didn't he? My neighbor chuckled again and replied, Eh, gambarimashita, na or yep, he really did.

title: News of the Screen
description: Harry Saltzman, who struck it rich as the coproducer of the highly profitable series of James Bond movie adventures, said that he had paid $500,000 for film rights to The Greek, the bestselling French novel about the superrich international set by Pierre Rey that G. P. Putnam's Sons is planning to publish in June. He will producc The Greek with Serge Silberman.

title: Humphrey Reported Fine After Tests for Tumor
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UPI) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, was reported in fine spirits today at Bethesda Naval Hospital where he is undergoing followup tests for a tumor of the bladder.

description: ALTON, Ill., Jan. 5 (UPI)Twelve narcotics agents will stand trial March 6 on charges of violating the constitutional rights of persons whose homes were the targets of bungled drug raids.

description: MIAMI, Jan. 5The National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament here proved that the United States collegiate soccer scene is no longer dominated by a plethora of players from overseas, which was the case in the near past. Of the 81 players who made the trip to Miami with the four teams, 57 are AmeriCan citizens and the majority of them have scholarships.

title: Maplewood Rejects Project for Elderly

title: JOSEPH RAFTON
description: Joseph Rafton, an industrialarts teacher at Margaret Knox Junior High School in East Harlem, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 33 Riverside Drive.

title: The Critical Point
description: Irving Howe has had a long, admirable and increasingly enviable career. An academic who is never musty and a journalist who is never merely quick or content with flash, he seems to have grown over the years, and his prose is sharper, his insights more precise and flexible. Of course he loves polemical situations too much, and a taste for battle born in the days when the Old Left was new has never left him. So here, in his tenth book, The Critical Point, a collection of 14 recent essays, he begins and ends with two inferior, pieces, scoldings of the New Left and Kate Millett, both of which choke their efforts to be capacious with that old embattled assurance that there are two sides here, mine right, yours wrong. But in between these two is a good deal of vintage Irving Howe, and two or three essays rank among his very best, which is to say among the best criticism now written in America.

title: They don't know when they're hungry They don't know when they're full
description: We eat too much.Everybody knows that eating too much makes you obese, and obesity is bad for you. Obesity shortens your life span, leads to or aggravates hypertension, diabetes, gallstones, varicose veins and unsightly blemishes. Furthermore, in our society today, fat is ugly, or to put it more delicately, being obese is cosmetically unacceptable. It is the latter fact, and not the fear of impending medical misfortunes, that compels the American public to be diet conscious, to spend vast sums of money on diet foods and diet doctors, and to periodically propel the latest diet book to the top of the bestseller list.

title: Puerto Rico Hit By Oil Shortages
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto RicoOur biggest industry is petrochemicals, and we don't produce a single drop of oil on the island. Need I say more?

title: Parts of Oregon, Idaho Exempt on Time Shift

title: MRS. HARRY G. JACOBI

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Most forecasters now agree that the American economy will suffer a marked slump in 1974. Estimated increments in the gross national product (in real terms) range from 0 to 2 per cent. My forecast, made with the aid of the threemonth United States econometric model, shows an increase of 1.9 per cent and 0.2 per centwithout and with consideration of the aggravating effect of the oil shortage, respectively.

title: NADER UNIT DISPUTED ON CANDLE HAZARDS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP)  A member of the Federal Consumer Products Safety Commission has accused a Ralph Nader group of presenting worthless calculations . . intended to inflame rather than inform the public about possible lead  poisoning hazards from certain candles.

description: HUNTINGTON BAY, L.I.Two women who have inventoried the job market in Nassau and Suffolk Counties are helping women from 17 to 65 to determine where they fit into the market and showing them how to equip themselves for their new roles,

title: MADELEINE LOEB, EXREPORTER, DIES
description: Madeleine H. Loeb, writer, publicrelations representative and a former reporter for The New York Times, died of a heart attack yesterday at the White Plains Center for Nursing. Her age was 69.

title: Auto Racing Sponsors Awaiting Clear Track
description: Denis HuIme, standing in the paddock area at some European grand prix track, looked down upon his driving suit, upholstered with patches and decals advertising everything from per. fume to gasoline. Look at me, he growled, I'm a bloody billboard. The Bear sounded almost resentful of having to earn his porridge in such a demeaning manner. But commercialism and automobile racing are so closely wedded that not even an energy crisis tear them asunder.

title: KILLIAN WILL TRY FOR MESKILL POST
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 5Connecticut's Attorney General, Robert K. Killian, announced today that he would seek the Democratic nomination for Governor this year, and ignored a demand by Gov. Thomas J. Meskill that he resign.

title: Home Improvement Brush, Roller or Pad?
description: DOITYOURSELF home painters can choose from a wide variety of applicator tools when it comes to deciding on how to put the paint onbut these can be roughly divided into four categoriesconventional bristle brushes, foamtype disposable brushes, paint rollers, and flat padtype applicators that are also known as shake painters (because they were first put on the market for painting cedar shakes). Choosing the best type for each job is largely a matter of becoming familiar with the advantages and limitations of each form, and the right choice can often result in a saving of time and/or money on many projects around the house.

title: 'scoop'Jackson: His Issues Have Come of Age
description: WASHINGTONIn an atmosphere where politics has joined the list of hazardous occupations, Henry Martin Jackson has been the exception. The hardworking, unglamorous Senator from Washington has become rising political figure, if not yet a household name.

title: Venezuela and Oil
description: Venezuela has long been one of the United States best friends in Latin America. American business has invested $3billion in Venezuela, $2billion of it in oil; many more billions have been returned on that investment.

title: THEODORE SEDGWICK

title: Niederhoffer Upset In Squash Racquets

description: PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 5 Three fishing concerns have filed a complaint in Cumberland County Superior Court here, seeking to nullify a 32yearold law that has protected Maine lobsters against competition from any species except that native to the state's waters.

description: City and state housing officials are pressing ahead with plans for 10 electrically heated housing projects despite charges that electric heat wastes the city's energygenerating capacity.

description: THE travel industry Is battling for what it considers its fair share of fuel in the cutback proposals being considered by the Federal Energy. Office. Industry spokesmen are basing, their fight on economic argumentsthey soundest possible basis in Washington.

Heading the list are the three varieties of poodles, with 186; followed by Afghan hounds, 98; the three varieties of dachshunds, 88; Labrador retrievers and Irish setters, 72 each, and Lhasa Apsos, 65.

title: LONDON'S AIRPORT GUARDED BY TANKS
description: LONDON, Jan. 5 (AP)Armored cars and light tanks ringed Heathrow Airport today, apparently to guard against terrorists.

So it was only natural that at the hotel trade show at the Coliseum in New York few weeks ago two demonstrations of electronic security systems played Lu the largest audiences gathered on the four floors of exhibits. One was the ADT Cardgard, ADT being American District Telegraph Company with nearly 100 years in the business of protecting industrial and commercial installations against fire, theft and pilfering. The other was Telebeam Corporation's Total Communications System which includes sepurity, pay television for movies and sports events, electronic delivery of telephone messages and other room serv

title: Episcopaltan Is Named To World Council Post

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The United States will continue on a growing inflationary course, registering one of the sharpest rises since World War II. The energy shortage makes it unlikely that inflation can be curbed appreciably during the year.

title: COAST SUIT RAISES POWERRATE ISSUE
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5  Environmental activists have been contending for years that one important way to conserve Power would be to end the large discounts given big power users such as industry.

description: To the outsider, the tone of the Lower East Side as a residential area is set by its rows of tenements, relieved by occasional housing projects.

title: Record of the Appeal
description: The fund for The New York Times Neediest Cases was started in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was publisher of The New York Times until his death in 1935. Contributions to the 62d annual appeal can still be sent to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249, until March 1. Money received after that date will be credited in the 63d annual appeal.

title: NEW ORLEANS
description: NEW ORLEANS My wife has not cooked a fish stew for three months because she can no longer buy saltwater redfish and she got tired of substituting freshwater catfish, which she regards as harmful to a stew.

title: Democrats, Independents Favor Kennedy, Poll Shows
description: A Harris poll of Democrats and independents shows Senator Edward M, Kennedy of Massachusetts preferred by most as the 1976 Democratic Presidential nominee, with Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama second, The Associated Press reported.

description: Raymond L. Fitzgerald, who retired in 1956 as editor in chief of the business magazine Boot and Shoe Recorder, died Friday in St. John's Queens Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Canadian Ski Conditions: Bird'sEye View
description: ST. SAVEUR, QuebecAs if being guided by radar, thousands of motoring ski enthusiasts in Canada's Lau. rentians follow the recommendations of Rick Leckner every weekend before setting their targets for that day's sport. Leckner, a staff announcer for radio station CJAD in Montreal, gives onthespot reports on ski conditions.

title: Dratha
Canadiens Keep Spell On Canucks

title: Stefanich Rolls 300; Ritger Wins
description: ALAMEDA, Calif., Jan. (UPI)  In the highest scoring finale in t he 15year history of professional bowling, Dick Ritger of Hartford, Wis., took first place today in the $100,000 Midas open tournament. Ritger's reward was $14,000.

title: Elizabeth J. Coleman Is Betrothed
description: Miss Elizabeth J. Coleman and Robert H. Stroup, who are in their third year at the University of Pennsylvania Law School, plan to marry in March. Their engagement has been announced by Mrs. Joseph A. Coleman of Riverdale, the Bronx, who as Beatrice Coleman is president of Maidenform, makers of undergarments and swimwear.

title: Nixon: The Friday Night Disturbance
description: Despite all the efforts at embellishing the President's image as a man preoccupied with the nation's domestic and foreign concerns, the unremitting pressures of the investigation into his own conduct have produced, if not another Saturday night massacre, then a Friday night disturbance.

title: Vincent Starrett, Author, Dies; Authority on Sherlock Holmes
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP)Vincent Starrett. a newspaperman who became an authority on Sherlock Holmes, died today at the age of 87.

description: JEFFERSON, IowaDurIng the bumpercrop year Max Naylor, like many other grain farmers in this marvelously fertile area, dropped out of the pricesupport program and planted all the corn and soybeans his large acreage could hold.

title: Including a pink Male Chauvinist Pig pillow
description: A WomanMadeBook. Edited by Kirsten Grimstad and Susan Rennie. Illustrated. 223 pp. New York: Coward, McCann & Geoghegan/ Berkley Publishing Corp. Paper, $5.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP)Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that many Americans doubt there is an energy crisis because of constantly changing estimates of fuel shortages. In two months, he said, Covernment estimates of oil shortages have ranged from 1.2 million to 3.5 million barrels a day. In other words, the energy crisis will be anything from had to three times worse than that, Mr. Proxmire said in a statement. He blamed the profusion of estimates on Government reliance on industry sources for information.

title: Rafters Ringing In Nutley Church
description: NUTLEYSunday worship at the handsome, new First Baptist Church here starts in a leisurely way around 11:30 or noon. But once the service gets going, the rafters ring with a particularly joy ful noise.

title: Controls: Prelude to Shortages
description: General merchandisers look to payrolls, and six million more Americans are employed today than just two years ago. Personal disposable income grew in 1973, and even after adjustment for price increases, this pattern will continue in 1974. Employment will remain at record levels, even though unemployment edges upward. This will result in continued growth for the generalmerchandise industry.

title: RHODESIA EXUDES A PROSPEROUS AIR
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 5 (Reuters)  A visitor who did not know that Rhodesia was the target of United Nations economic sanctions would probably never guess.

title: Sally Gabriel Is Wed to John Steinbach
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 5The marriage of Miss Sally Jo Gabriel to John Winthrop Steinbach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop E. Steinbach of Williamson, took place here this evening,

title: Housing Industry Beset With Problems
description: WASHINGTON  Controversy seemed to be as much a commodity as the delivery c.f housing by the Nixon Administration last year beginning with the freeze on subsidies for lowand middleincome housing.

title: A.H. S. A. Meeting Sees Smooth Sailing
description: The 57th annual convention of the American Horse Shows Association opens Thursday for three days at the Sheraton Hotel in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., with no major problems to be solved. We think this con vention will run very smoothly, said Albert E. Hart Jr., president of the A.H.S.A. for the past 16 years. In the past we have had some real knockdowndragout battles, but I don't anticipate anything like that this time.

title: Youth, Once Disaffected, Looks Warily to Business
description: LOS ANGELESWith the exception of engineers and accountants, big business should have little trouble recruiting its next generation of managers.

description: NEWARK  The Passaic Valley Sewerage Commission, operator of the largest sewage collection and treatment system in New Jersey, Is completing the first phase of a massive 10year program to build a $400million sewage treatment complex.

title: 1974 Housing Outlook Dim
description: EAST BRUNSWICKMore than two years ago, Governor Cahill said that New Jersey required at least 100,000 new housing units annually to meet existing needs. Since then, the housing figures have fallen far short of that goal.

title: Brooklyn Fieldhouse Reopened
description: More than 100 people attended the reopening of the Friends Field Park field. house at East Fourth Street and Avenue L in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn recently.

title: REV. GERARD A. LANE
description: The Rev. Gerard A. Lane, retired pastor of St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church in Dover Plains, N. Y., died yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in the Pope Pius VI residence in the Bronx.

description: MASSAPEQUA, L.I.Planers in Washington may be making the strategic decisions about energy policy these days, but it is men like John F. Leahy, who owns the B & J Exxon service station, who must face the crossfire of the front lines.

title: Slalom Won By Tschudi At Mt. Snow
description: MOUNT SNOW, Vt., Jan. 5 (AP)A threetime Norwegian champion, Otto Tschudi, easily won the giant slalom and the $4,000 first prize today in the $30,000 Benson & Hedges Grand Prix ski event.

title: Yes, There Are People Out There Who Believe
description: RLLIGIOUS AMERICA is not about religion in America, and that's why its content is so engrossiug. The 13week PBS series, which starts tonight at 8:30 on WNET/13, deals with religious Americanspeople who have a spiritual center their ,ives. The discovery of that center, and the surprising ways it takes shape, results in a stimulating look into piety in the 20th century.

title: A Case Study in Aid at Xerox
description: Leaving her comfortable office in Webster, N. Y., Mrs. Esther E. Kapuschat moved to Bethlehem, Israel, where she cared for as many as 50 destitute Arab children in one morning under difficult clinical conditions.

title: A.H.French Fiance Of Patricia Carroll

title: Byrne Is Asked to Make Panel on Women More Effective

description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. John Elefante of Hackensack, N. J., on Dec. 22 in the Pascark Valley Hospital in Emerson, N. J. The child is named Daniel Vincent.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE FEDERAL RESERVE Board reduced margin requirements on stock purchases from 65 per cent to 50 per cent. . . . Members of the New York Stock Exchange showed an aggregate loss of 56.9million in November following profits in September and October. ... Farm product prices rose 1.5 per cent in the month to Dec. 15 and were 34 per cent higher than in the corresponding period a year earlier. . . . The Chase Manhattan Bank lowered its prime rate to 934 per cent from 10. per cent.

title: Zero Traffic Growth Threatens Airlines
description: Since the late nineteensixties the cost of inflation to the airline industry has been above the national rate, and indications are that relatively higher costs will continue for the carriers in 1974.

title: The Year They Stopped Fueling Around
description: IN retrospect, the disappo.intments of the 197475 television season can be olamed solely on that medium's earnest but clumsy attempt to support President Nixon's campaign to ameliorate the energy crisis. Television producers, confident of their power to sway and influence, took it upon themselves to change the public's energyguzzling way of life by sneaking the power problem into their story lines whenever possible.

title: Joni's Songs Are For Everyone
description: JONI MITCHELL doesn't write love songs. She writes songs about love. And she is the premier explorer of the terrain. Romance and reality both work within her sensibility so that her songs honestly express the range of feelings involved in love. In Court and Spark (Asylum 5072), her sixth album in as many years, Mitchell continues to probe this vital life force, and as always she couches her keen insights in poetry that moves both the heart and the mind.

title: A RELAXED DYLAN SINGS IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 5The second concert of Bob Dylan's tour last night at the Chicago Stadium was a more relaxed affair than Thursday's opener, for both the performers and the audience. Mr. Dylan and the Band looked and sounded tore comfortable The pressures inherent in the return of a legend had passed for the listeners, making it possible to appreciate better what was actually happening up there on atage.

title: Dance
description: ONE is always cornOpelled to make ritualistic obeisance toward a New Year. It is pattern older than any civilization we have known or even recorded. I have often wondered whoever first made the calendar. The day I can easily understand  that is something within the immediate bounds of perceptionand the season's primitive man Would certainly notice. But the concept of a year always seems extraordinarily sophisticated to me. But that may be simply because I am unsophisticated.

Aftertax profits peaked at an annual yate of $71.6billion in the second quarter of 1973 and were almost unchanged at $71.5billion in the third quarter. But they probably fell in the final quarter and will continue to drop. The decline from 1973 to 1974 is likely to be 6 or cent.

The Poet Laureate is an Officer of the Royal Household ranking immediately above the Royal Bargemaster and the Keeper of the Queen's Swans. Many Englishmen derive a certain quiet satisfaction from this, reckoning that poetry has just about found its place in the order of things. The Laureate also receives a stipend of 70 (about $160) a year plus an allowance of 27 (about $62)

description: THE year now begun brings promise of maximum of travail and a minimum of travel; it bids fair to be a year when collectors, wrapped in greatcoats, will be s'pending more time at home with their collections.
