title: Son to Mrs. Cimmino
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 5A son was born here at the Women's Hospital to Dr. and Mrs. Vincent Cimmino on Dec. 17. The child, the couple's second son, has been named Craig Jason. Dr. Cimmino is a resident in surgery at the University Hospital here.

title: Dance: Hawkins in Greek Dreams
description: The harmonious and ceremonial aspects of Erick Hawkins's dances have been the cause of so much commentary in recent years that it is possible to forget that sheer exhilaration, as in his Cantilever, is also a part of his work.

title: Student Sells His Crosswords
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  Edward Julius, a Rutgers College senior, says that he cannot solve crossword puzzles to save his life. But that does not stop him from making and selling them to college newspapers across the country.

title: Businessmen Feel Ennui Over Nixon
description: WASHINGTONIt does not matter very much American business whether President Nixon goes or stays. Businessmen, even though they gave their votes and money to Mr. Nixon, are more concerned with the energy shortage than with the question of who occupies the White House.

title: What's Doing in Amsterdam
description: WINTER SCENEThe Netherlands and its star attraction, Amsterdam, have traditionally been thought of as spring destinations, but during the winter one actually sees Amsterdam and its residents in their most characteristic light. Though the weather is often gray, cold, misty and drizzly, this is the best time to savor the dramatic cloudfilled Ruysdael skies that silhouette the some 0,000 old gabled houses now protected as monuments in the center of town. Amsterdam is, after all, a northern city at heart and the Amsterdamers seek their traditional jezelligheid (coziness) in the cafes, restaurants, theaters, concert halls, museums and art galleries and at the ballet and opera. The Sunday driving ban in December, now being replaced by rationing, brought a flurry of bicycle buyingand suddenly transformed all of Amsterdam into one great fietspad (bicycle path). Thanks to the oil crisis, hearty Amsterdamers are walking and cycling more than they've done since the automobile took over Amsterdam in the last it.

title: Seton Hall Victor In 4Team Track
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 5 Seton Hall broke four meet records en route to a victory over Princeton, Fordham and New York University tonight in a quadrangular track meet at Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: Oil Shale: Leasing to Begin On Vast Reserves in West
description: DENVER. Jan. 5  For 43 years, the United States has bee sitting on  in its own backyard  the world's largest oilfield. True or false?

title: Former College Teacher Dies in a Brooklyn Blaze
description: A former member of the economics department at Brooklyn College was found dead in his Borough Park apartment yesterday, the police said, apparently as a result of a fire that started in a closet.

title: Nuclear Power Plants: A Struggle to Expand
description: For many years, the rapidly growing United States nuclearpower industry has been beset both by transcendental forecasts of its ultimate contribution to the nation's energy supply and by dark predictions about releases of biologically damaging radiation during normal operations or a catastrophic accident.

title: Retirement Aid: Efforts Beyond the Gold Watch
description: The pensionreform legislation that is expected to emerge from Congress this year after a decade of investigation and debate ought to serve as bonemeal for budding subindustry. Like minority recruitment and equal employment opportunity consulting, preretirement counseling is a new mutation of expertise.

title: CREW CALLS COMET FAINTER THAN FAINT
description: HOUSTON, Jan 5 (UPI)The Comet Kohoutek was reported by the Skylab 3 astronauts today as getting fainter than faint.

title: The New Urban Image? Look Down, Not Up
description: THE First National City Corporation, familiar to many as the First National City Bank, remembered by some as the First National Bank and the National City Bank B.M. (before merger) and referred to by the irreverent as the First National Piggy Bank, now calls itself, in the cryptic spirit of the times, by the breezy acronym of Citicorp.

title: Wood on 29 Acres Offered
description: BILLERICA, Mass., Jan. (AP)The owners of 29 acres of land in Billerica announced Wednesday thai they would allow the public to cut any amount of trees in the area for firewood. The tract is near Route 3 on Rangeway Road.

title: Demand for Oil Tax Challenges Mills
description: WASHINGTON  Widespread pressure for some sort of tax on the windfall profits that oil producers are widely expected to reap from the fuel shortage adds further uncertainties to what was already an unclear outlook for tax legislation in 1974.

title: It Pays to Grow Your Own Vegetables
description: IN these days of food shortages, high prices, and often poor quality store prodace, every homeowner wtih even the smallest spot for gardening should consider growing at least a few vegetables this critical year. Last year, decided to see just what might be done with a small plot, with minimum labor, and what it might save over the purchase of vegetables in our local grocery store. My garden is Martha's Vineyard with sandy soil which has had a minimum of composting, fertilizing or cover crops. The little piece for my experiment is just 35 x 35 feet, around 1,200 square feet.In recording costs of the garden, I did not figure my Own labor, but only the costs of fertilizers, seeds and equipment. Onion sets and seeds cost $17; rototilling the garden after fertilizing $5; a small load of horse manure $15; arbag of commercial fertilizer $10 and miscellany $4. Labor was written off as healthy exercise. No sprays were needed because I depend each year on newly hatched praying mantis to eat the aphids, they and the birds which are attracted to the vegetable plot by bird feeders and a bird bath.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As a Park Slope brownstoner, I heartily disagree with the statement of Bernard Atkins, a broker seeking higher prices for houses he wants to sell in Clinton Hill and other brownstone neighborhoods, that brownstones in Park Slope, Cobble Hill, Carroll Gardens and Boerum Hill are in the $60,000plus price range [Off We Go aBrownstoning in Brooklyn, Nov. 25].

title: U.S. Says a C.1 .A. Agent Sent False Message to Thai Premier
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. (AP)The United States Embassy said today that an agent of the Central Intelligence Agency had sent the Thai Government a false ceasefire offer in the name of a Thai CommuAist insurgent leader.

title: PAKISTANI BANKS ARE NATIONALIZED
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 5 (Reuters)  New measures this week to give the Government control of Pakistan's bank. ing, shipping and oildistribution industries mark a major step toward socialism here.

title: A Status Report on the Watergate Inquiries
description: WASHINGTONLast year was one of exploration and disclosure. In grand jury rooms, courthouses and Congressional chambers, the array of scandals surrounding President Nixon, his aides and his Administration was laid bare. The new year promises to be one of judgmentadding significance to the Friday night reshuffle that placed an experienced trial lawyer, James D. St. Clair, at the head of the White House legal defense staff.

title: Tampa Job Open
description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP) Ben Schwartzwalder, retirine as head football coach at Syracuse University, has applied for the athletic director's job at the University of Tampa, school officials said today.

title: Art
description: IF you want to be fussy about it, the new Boucher exhibition at the National Gallery in Washington would have to be called the last major exhibition of 1973, since it opened Dec. 23. But in effect it is the first of the new year, and you could hardly ask for a better start. This is a beautiful show.

title: Human Eye Flown to Japan Is Successfully Implanted
description: TOKYO, Jan. 5 (AP)A human eye flown from abroad has been transplanted into young student thanks in part to United States Air Force personnel.

title: Thomas Hussey to Wed Ellen McNamara
description: BABYLON, LI., Jan. 5Mr. and Mrs. Daniel McNamara Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Marie McNamara, to Thomas Ward Hussey, son of Mrs. Anne Hutchinson Sharp of Arlington, Va., and Ward McLean Hussey of Alexandria, Va. A Julie wedding is planned.

title: Miss Lauren Sinclair Timberlake to Wed
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Jan. 5Mr. and Mrs. Shelby V. Timberlake Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lauren Sinclair Timberlake, to Thomas Joseph Brady Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brady of Elmsford. The wedding is planned for April 27.

title: Miss Harvey Plans Wedding
description: SEATTLE Jan. 5  Miss Margaret Lee Harvey, a publie schoolteacher here, and William Ward Hates, a law yer with the office of the solicitor, United States Department of Labor here, plan to be married in April.

title: Miss Cheney Fiancee of John McGurk 3d
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 5  Mrs. Constance Bill Cheney of Delray Beach and Alton Austin Cheney of Litchfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deirdre Ann Cheney, to John Joseph McGurk 3d, son of Mrs. McGurk Jr. of Durham, N. C., and the late Mr. McGurk. A spring wedding is planned.

title: $1.2BillionBenefits Arelinked by T.V.A. To Its Dams System
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 5 flood control benefits from the Tennessee Valley Authority system of dams now total more than $1.2billion, nearly five times the total cost of building and operating the system, the T.V.A. said in its annual report.

title: How do you keep the rich from keeping the poor poor?; More Equality; By Herbert Gans. 261 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $7.95.
description: Herbert Gans's new book is a collection of essays, some new, some previously published, containing his ideas about why the United States needs more equality, why it hasn't been achieved up to now, and about how it might be achieved in the near future. He makes it clear from the start that he's not talking about equality of opportunity, which almost nobody seems to be against any more, but about equality of results, what used to be called equality of condition. He is not under, any delusion that absolute equality can be achieved, nor even that it is very desirable. What he cares most about is reducing inequalities of income, wealth and political power, understanding that inequalities of prestige and other differential evaluations of persons and groups on cultural grounds would persist, depending on how they used the wealth and had.

title: T. LESTER KILLOUGH
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Jan. 5T. Lester Killough, a former publishing executive with Cosmopolitan magazine, the Review of Reviews and the Literary Digest, died Tuesday in Elizabeth General Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived here.

title: Boom to Gloom
description: It happened so quIckly. One minute, seemed, there was a worldwide economic boom. The next minute, a world economic recession threatened. The Arabs and their oil cutbacks stand accused in the dock.

title: In Aerospace,Throttling Back
description: WASHINGTONThe aerospace industry which was pulled out of a slow business downturn by an upsurge in the sale of commercial aircraft, is being throttled back once again, this time by the energy shortage.

title: Cooperation on Oil
description: Secretary of State Kissinger's warning that worldwide depression and economic suicide lie ahead if the industrial nations persist in dealing separately and competitively with the energy crisis is blunt talk, but long overdue.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: One of the most striking aspects of the farreaching energy crisis is the reacclamation of the United States as the dominant world economic power. The reason that we are far less dependent upon imported oil than any of our major trading partners (or rivals) except Canada.

title: Watergate Raises New Problems of Giving and Getting for Businessmen
description: For many of the nation's businessmen, the spreading stain of Watergate has created a host of problems that must be resolved in 1974.

title: Who said happiness was Size 6?; FAT and happy
description: Mrs. Henry Meltzer is no sylph and she knows it. But she's an extremely happy young woman.

title: Commuters Switching To Buses and Trains
description: WAYNEThe state's largest bus company, the Penn Central Railroad and the Central Railroad of New Jersey are reporting increased passenger volume because of rising gasoline prices and gasoline shortages.

title: Exxon Wins Laurels in Dog Show
description: Castletop's High Octane, a black cocker spaniel, who won't be a year old until Washington's Birthday, was the futurity winner as the American Spaniel Club opened its twoday specialty at the Statler Hilton Hotel yesterday. It was the 57th show staged by the 82yearold organization and ushered in the dog show season in the East.

title: Lester Maddox And How to Become
description: ATLANTAAt 10 o'clock on steamy Friday night in Underground Atlantathis city's major tourist playground, similar to Times Square but safer and less sleazya middleaged couple and their three children crowd into a tiny souvenir shop filled to capacity with 25 or so anxious visitors out on the town. The bald exuberant storekeeper, a native Atlantan, greets them as though he had unlocked his shop just for them and has been awaiting their arrival since noon. Hi! he barks to the father in a loud, strong voice. Hi! Glad to see ya! He stands behind a glass case filled with souvenirs, autographing a Tshirt for another customer with his felt tip pen and trading hearty jokes with the beaming, adoring customers. To the three children he yelps, Hey, shoog, hey, chief, hey, red, white and blue, then turns to the customer purchasing the skirt. Johnny?

title: And for Detroit: Throw Money Into Small Cars
description: Even before the current energy shortage, auto executives had been saying that future cars would have to be smaller, less powerful and more economical on fuel; a gasoline pinch had been expected for some time. What the Arab boycott did was to force the companies to scrap orderly plans for gradual change and hurry conversion of big car assembly lines into the production of small cars.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: In a renewed effort by the Nixon Administration to end crossownership of mediacontrol by one person or group of radio, television and newspapers in a given areathe Justice Department last week acted to strip the broadcasting interest from newspaper publishers in St. Louis and Des Moines.

title: U.S. Team Victor In Junior Hockey
description: LENINGRAD, Jan. 5 (UPI) The United States beat Czechoslovakia, 32, today for its first victory in the Junior International ice hockey tournament.

title: Boat Show Back NextWeek, Gaudy as Ever
description: Now it's the indoor boat show's turn.

title: DAYAN ENDS TRIP TO U.S. WITH HOPE FOR A PEACE STEP
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5  Defense Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel ended two days of talks with Secretary of State Kissinger today, saying that he hoped his country was now ready to take the first step toward peace with Egypt by reaching an accord on the separation of Israeli and Egyptian forces.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: POINSETTIA

title: CHILDCARE BIAS CONCEDED IN SUIT Placement by Religion Cited in Consent Judgment
description: A major childcare agency has agreed in Federal Court here that the religionbased system of placing children in need of help in New York City and State has the effect of discriminating against black Protestant youngsters.

title: Sadat's Brother Reported Killed During October War
description: CAIRO, Jan. 5 (UPI)Cairo newspapers reported today that President Anwar elSadat's younger brother was killed in combat during the October war.,

title: Disagreeable Squeeze
description: PARISTwo key factors in West Europe's economic boom had been availability of ample cheap supplies of energy and ample cheap supplies of labor. Now, with cheap petroleum finished, the huge work force imported into Common Market countries from less industrialized areaslike Algeria, Morocco, Spain, Portugal, south Italy, Greece, Turkey and Yugoslaviawill find itself progressively more idle.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Not long ago in these pages I was denounced by Alfred G. Haggerty on the ground that a column published here was unfair to the American insurance industry, for which Mr. Haggerty seemed to be the official writer of angry letters.

title: Patricia H. Austin, Nurse, Is Bride of Andrew J. Esser
description: DARIEN. Conn., Jan. 5Miss Patricia Harnish Austin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall McVay Austin, was married here this afternoon to Andrew John Esser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil J. Esser of Setauket, L. 1. The ecumenical ceremony was performed in St. Paul's Episcopal Church by the Rev. H. Arthur Lane, former rector of the church, and the Rev. Americo Said, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Kern Is SkiJump Victor In Torger Tokle Tourney
Canadian Loan for Zaire
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Jan, (Agence FrancePresse)Canada is to give Zaire a $36million longterm loan for construction of a telecommunications network, the Canadian Embassy disclosed here,

title: DETROIT
description: DETROITIt was a lusty, bouncy kind of song. A little long on boosterism, perhaps, but an upbeat spiritlifter, nonetheless. And a minor stroke of genius for the ad agency that created the commercial jingle as a way of harnessing civic pride to the selling of a local product:

title: With a Little Help From Your Friends
description: Neil Simon reads it twice a day with a glass of water. Dan Greenburg felt calmer and peppier after reading it and went out and treated himself to a banana cone with sprinkles. Nora Ephron can't live without it. It changed Rex Reed's life. At a time of trouble and confusion in her life it was a deep breath of mountain air to Berry Berenr son.

title: Miss Downey Sets Nuptials
description: WHITING, N. J., Jan. 5Mr. and Mrs. William Sexton Downey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Jean Downey of Washington, to John Henry Bayly Jr., also of Washington. He is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Bayly of University Park, Md.

title: Cornell Regains Prestige For Eastern College Sixes
description: It may not be Yanks vs. Rebels, but in college hockey, East against West has the same meaning. Intersectional clashes, even before this energyshort era, have remained quite rare. For years, the Western teams dominated the Christmas tournament meetings and the eventual National Collegiate tourney jousts. Recently, the Eastern squads have had a slight edge, but not this time as Eastern College Athletic Conference clubs recorded only 3 victories and 3 ties in 13 EastWest games. Top Eastern outfits were soundly trounced as Boston College fell, 125, to Michigan State, Michigan Tech downed Penn, 62, and Harvard lost twice, 63 to Minnesota and 52 at Notre Dame.

title: DELAYS DEVELOP FOR SMALL CARS
description: DETROIT, Jan. 6Despite the present slumping newcar market, many wouldbe buyers are being told they may have to wait as long as two months for a 1974 model.

title: SUFFOLK TO OFFER A TAXMAP SERIES
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 6Starting this month, Suffolk County will make available to residents of Shelter Island, the Town of Babylon and the Village of Greenport an elaborate series of tax maps.

title: Long Beach Quintet on Probation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. (AP)  Long Beach State was placed on indefinite probation for not less than three years by the National Collegiate Athletic Association today for basketball and football violations.

title: Klammer Takes 2d In Downhill Race
Physicians Are Confident About Humphrey's Tumor
Personal Finance: Giving Via Trust
description: A perplexing problem for those with money is how best. to give it away within the family.

title: Suit Against Baker to Start
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) A Government civil suit to recover $108,968 from a former secretary to Senate Democrats. Robert G. Baker, who was protg of Lyndon B. Johnson, goes to trial tomorrow.

title: FIRE BURNS 4 HOMES; QUEENS MAN KILLED
description: A 60yearold man was killed and three families were made homeless early yesterday when fire swept through four twoandahalfstory homes in the Woodhaven section of Queens.

title: Red Smith This Time Bill Has a Chance to Lose
description: In August Danny Murtaugh made a suggestion to Joe L. Brown, general manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates. Bill Virdon has done a hell of a job for you, Murtaugh said. Why don't you announce right now that he's rehired for next year? They're probably going to win it all anyway, but this might give the club a little something extra.

title: Coal and Oil and Politics and Oligopoly
description: I was born in the mountains of West Virginia, and my views are the views of a coal miner. Coal mining is hard, dirty work, and when you have time to think on the job, you mainly think about your survival. I have spent most of my life just trying to survive, and what free time I had left over I spent on trying to reform the union I belonged to. That is hard work, too. So my views are generally geared to getting from one day to the next.

title: Stage: A Gifted and Exciting Liza
description: She has urchin hair, big gypsy eyes, good legs, lovely expressive hands, and a voice that can purr, whisper, snarl and roar. She is also very sexyin an oldfashioned way that I was beginning to think had. gone out of style.

title: Codd Will Shift 1,000 Officers to Street Patrol
description: Police Commissioner Michael; J. Codd said yesterday that he planned to add 1,000 uniform; officers to street patrol by taking them off clerical details and similar duty.

title: 15,194 at Sunday Racing
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 (AP)Sunday racing in the Philadelphia area made its debut today. The first program drew a crowd of 15,194 to Liberty Bell. There will also be racing next Sunday.

title: About New York Bureaucratic Math: More Is Less
description: A man who has never much trusted the bureaucracy, anyway, lives in a MitchellLama building in the Bronx. He has a onebedroom apartment for which he pays a rent of $228 a month, plus a surcharge of $99 a month for a total of $327. The surcharge is based on his salary, and for the last year he has been unhappy about it, feeling that it adds more to his rent than he can really afford.

title: Gigante, During Service, Takes His Council Oath
description: In an old brick church in the South Bronx parish he has served for more than 12 years, the Rev. Louis R. Gigante celebrated mass yesterday, took an oath of office as the new Councilman from the district and, standing before an altar in white vestments, pledged to remain in the streets to work on local problems.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Jersey Man Slain in Traffic Dispute

title: Surprising Manhattan Has Strong Case for National Ranking
EVELYN BLEWETT
description: Evelyn Blewett, staff manager of the War Advertising Council in World War II who helped recruit 12,000 nurses and was also active in recruiting for the Waves, died Saturday in Atlanta. Friends said she had been living there since retiring from The St. Petersburg (Fla.) Times because of arthritis. She was 58 years old.

title: ROBERT W. NEUMANN
description: Robert W. Neumann, a consultant on the foreign money market, most recently to the Cummins Engine Company of Columbus, Ind., died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 154 West 71st Street.

title: BEAN CLARIFIES PLAN FOR DINKINS
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that he had no recollection of mentioning the job of Deputy Mayor when he disclosed that he wanted David N. Dinkins

title: Notestein Memorial Set
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 6There will be a memorial service for Mrs. Ada Comstock Notestein, president emeritus of Radcliffe College and widow of Prof. Wallace Notestein, at P.M. on Thursday in the Dwight Chapel of Yale University.

title: SIMON URGES CUT IN PRICES OF OIL FROM OVERSEAS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6William E. Simon, the Nixon Administration's energy chief, called today for a rollback of foreign crude oil prices within months.

title: Israel Shapes Military Proposal After Dayan's Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 6  Defense Minister Moshe Dayan delivered a 90minute ,report today to the Israeli Cabinet on his two days of talks in Washington with Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Hot Wire Kills Prize Cattle
description: BRENTWOOD, Tenn., Jan. 6 (UPI)Nineteen head of prize Charolais cattle were fatally shocked yesterday, when thieves, stealing copper wire, released a hot electrical wire on part of the herd. Norman Anderson, operations manager for the Nashville Electric Service, said the thieves released a tension wire, causing a hot wire to fall across five of the cattle, killing them. The other 14 came up out of curiosity and one by one were killed.

title: '72 Statement by Ramsey Clark On F.B.I. and Eagleton Disputed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6The Federal Bureau of Investigation has found Ito evidence in its files to support a statement in 1972 by former Attorney General Ramsey Clark that it possessed information on Senator Thomas F. Eagleton's mental health, according to confidential F.B.I. reports.

title: SALT Bog...
Senate Report Hits Bank Stockholdings
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (Reuters)  Large United States banks are hiding their control of publicly owned corporations by listing their stockholdings in nonexistent companies they have created, according to a Senate report made public today.

title: Soviet Developing Source For Molybdenum in Asia
description: The Soviet Union, in an effort to strengthen its position in the molybdenum field, has begun to develop one of the largest sources of this strategic metal in the heart of Asia.

title: WILSON WILL URGE BUSINESSTAX CUT
description: Governor Wilson will propose that the state double the current tax cuts provided to corporations that invest in plant expansion.

title: SOUTH AFRICA PARTY AND ZULU IN ACCORD
description: CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 6The political leader of the Zulus and a leader of the white Parliamentary Opposition, the United party, have signed a declaration of faith in South Africa's future as peaceful, multiracial society with equal opportunity for all.

title: Derailed Train Hits House
description: LUCAMA, N. C., Jan. 6 (UPI) Fortysix cars of a Seaboard Coast Line freight train derailed today. Several cars crashed into a house beside the tracks and slightly injured a woman, officials said. The cause of the derailment, which started about third of the way back on the train, was undetermined.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: The Forgetting of Things Past
description: SATELLITE BEACH, Fla.  What America needs is a return to the bright and shining Camelot hours of John F. Kennedy and to the equally exciting Great Society era of Lyndon B. Johnson. These were years to warm the heart of every true liberalthe good old days.

title: Dil Flowing to Refineries, But Facts Are Hard to Find
description: LINDEN, N. J., Jan. 6At Exxon's sprawling Bayway refinery here, the energy crisis is a dramatic paradox: crude oil flows in huge quantities, but information about it has been cut to a murky trickle.

title: Vinyl Shortage Slows Record Industry
description: A developing shortage of vinyl, the oilderived synthetic resin from which most ?? are pressed, is causing postponements, cutbacks and uncertainties in the musicrecording industry.

title: Horse Show Results AT MIDDLE ISLAND, L.I. THE CHIEF AWARDS
description: Special Working Hunter ChampionshipChem. pion, Byron Allston's Mac Mar, 7 points; reserve, Elizabeth French's Little Rebel, (championship decided Co hackoff).

title: Stage: McNally's The Tubs at Yale
F.T.C. Studies Ads Disavowing Link of Eggs to Heart Disease
description: The Federal Trade Commis, Ision is investigating a series! of advertisements, sponsored by the egg industry, that disavows a relationship between eating! !eggs and developing heart disease.

title: Finding Someone Responsible to Care for the Children
description: Lucille and Ronald Fields, both teachers in the New York City school system, couldn't find anyone who lived up to their admittedly high standards to take care of their infant son. Just before the Christmas vacation, Mr. Fields began his paternity leave to do so. He had been teaching longer than his wife and had tenure.

title: Chile to Return Banks
description: SANTIAGO, Chile Jan. (Reuters)  Commercial banks nationalized by the toppled leftwing government of the late President Salvador Allende will be returned to their owners, the Production Development Corporation of Chile announced over the weekend.

title: Pittsburgh's Mayor Flaherty, a Source of Alienation and Affection, Entering 2d Term
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 6In his first four years as Mayor of Pennsylvania's second largest city, Peter F. Flaherty has managed to make enemies of, among others, the Democratic party, organized labor, the former Mayor, most of the City Council, the police, the firemen, the business community, the black community and both of the city's major newspapers.

title: New Red Wing Line Sparks 96 Victory
description: DETROIT, Jan. 6 (AP)Pierre Jarry and Bill Hogaboam scored one goal each and assisted on four other today as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Minnesota North Stars, 96, in a National Hockey League game.

title: Sadat Is Believed Planning ShakeUp That Stresses Private Development
description: CAIRO, Jan. 6President Anwar elSadat, clearly confident that Egypt will achieve a settlement with Israel, is believed to be preparing a major shakeup in the countryss political structure and economic policies to open the way for industrial and social development.

title: Erwin Mermelstein Weds Miss Blank
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 6Miss Catherine Ann Blank, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Blank, was married here this afternoon to Erwin Mermelstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Mermelstein of Brooklyn.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: RUTHERFORD, Jan. 6Too often, a football coach has only one concern in life: football, and anything related to the game.

title: The City's Present System
description: The Emergency Medical Service Division of the Health and Hospitals Corporation has 142 ambulances to serve the needs of city residents. But only about 120 are in service at any one time. In addition, the voluntary hospitals have 38 ambulances on duty.

title: Peers Applaud an Econometricist
description: Last month, Franklin M. Fisher heavyset, grayhaired and brilliant  received the economics profession's loudest applause.

title: U. S. Checks on Reports of Illegal Oil Sales
description: The regional unit of the Federal Energy Office here is investigating what its director yesterday termed the suspicious, I sale of millions of gallons of heating oil by wholesalers that he called the dirty dozen.

title: Selena Is Best Spaniel 2d Year in Row
Bucks Bow To Bullets By 9088
description: LARGO, Md., Jan. 6 (UPI) Phil Chenier scored 31 points tonight in leading the Capital Bullets to a 9088 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: North Team 287 Victor Over South
Duryea Aide Has Lost 2 State Jobs He Says
description: Harold J. Relkin a key figure in Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz's inquiry into possible illicit campaign practices by state Republicans, says he had been dropped from the Assembly payroll as a $3,882ayear general clerk in the ofnce of Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea who was indicted last month on charges of violating the election law.

title: AUSTIN HOMER
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 Austin Hamer, retired president of the J. E. Caldwell Company, jewelers, silversmiths and antiquarians here, died Thursday in Coatesville, Pa. His age was 77.

title: Death of Cardiac Victim Raises Dispute On Ambulance Emergency Procedures
description: A young woman died while being taken by ambulance tc Coney Island Hospital last May 30 because, an auxiliary police man asserted, he and two thei members of an emergency squad were not allowed to con. tinue administering cardio. pulmonary resuscitation. Under Police Department regulations a physician must be present to supervise such operations

title: Nets Down Colonels, 103100
3 Public Hearings Called On Texas DeepWater Port
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 6Three public hearings have been called on a recommendation by the Texas Offshore Terminal Commission that the state issue revenue bonds to build a deepwater port facility to handle !tankers off the Gulf Coast Brazoria County.

title: Arab Guerrillas Oppose Nomination Of Godley to Be Envoy to Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 6The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, the Marxist and radical guerrilla organization, has issued a warn ing against the nomination of G. McMurtrie Godley as the new United States Ambassador to Lebanon.

title: D.W. BROGAN DEAD; BRITISH HISTORIAN
description: LONDON, Jan. 6Sir Denis Brogan, whose books, articles and lectures as D. W. Brogan gave two generations of Britons a better understanding of the United States, died last night at a hospital in Cambridge. His age was 73.

title: Horse Show Results
description: Intermediate JumPer ChampionshipChem. pion,. London's Libra, 10 points; reserv, Louis Sava's Ebony Hawk, 5.

title: . . .MIRV Mess
description: The problem now is that President Nixon, on Pentagon urging, refused to settle in SALT I for limitations on defensive antiballistic missile (ABM) systems, although that was the chief American objective initially. To obtain some kind of SALT I accord on offensive missiles during his preelection Moscow visit in 1972, the President signed a fiveyear interim agreement conceding to Moscow a substantial edge in missile launchers and payload to compensate for the American lead at that time in MIRV warhead numbers and some other advantages. The MIRV issue was put off to SALT II on the false assumption that the American lead there served an American advantage. But, if the Soviet Union now places MIRV's atop its giant ICBM's, the asymmetric balance SALT I could turn into Soviet superiority and even Soviet firststrike capability.

title: Dim Daylight Cuts Saving As Time Is Changed Here
description: As the city, along with most of the nation, switched over to Daylight Saving Time yesterday, forbidding skies yielded barely enough light to be worth saving. The sun lined up with the moon and earth in an unusual pattern, modifying the Twelfth Night postholiday return to normalcy on the first Sunday of the new year.

title: Jersey City Plans Broad Renewal
description: JERSEY CITY  There are two grand nineteentwenties movie palaces near Journal Square, the main downtown intersection of this old, riverfront city. Not only are they still standing, they still show movies.

title: Jersey Will Honor Its First Governor
description: TRENTON, Jan. 6As New Jersey prepares to inaugurate Brendan T. Byrne as its 54th Governor, a project aimed at collecting the public and private papers of William Livingston, New Jersey's first Governor who served from 1776 .to 1790, has been announced by the state's American Revolution Bicentennial Celebration Commission.

title: Michael Myerberg Dies at 67; A Stage and Screen Producer
description: Michael Myerberg, a stage and screen producer, who owned the Brooks Atkinson Theater for many years, died yesterday in the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 67 years old and lived in Neponsit, Queens.

title: Reds Gain in Influence in Troubled Italy
description: ROME, Jan. 6The Italian Communist party, the strongesti Marxist organization in the West and this nation's second political force; has recently won new respectability and influence.

title: Midseason TV Overhaul Puts Burden of Success on A.B.C.
description: When the television networks next week begin their second season'  that midseason overhaul of prime time that will bring in 10 new weekly series and two additional moviesthe burden of success will be mainly on the American Broadcasting Company, which so far has made its poorest showing in several years in the nighttime audience sweepstakes.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: COMET CRAZE From 5 to 7 this evening, Kohoutek, the careening comet, will be the talk of Battery Park, at least of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, opposite the park at 15 State Street. Maybe not even the talk of the whole institute, but certainly of its fifth floor, where you are invited to muster, free of charge, to be inundated with comet background.

title: The West German Press: Magazines for Scandal, Newspapers for serious News
description: BONNLike the political life it covers so extensively, the West German press these days is perhaps less lively than it was when Willy Brandt and his Social Democrats were the party of opposition, but it is still just as thorough and serious"earnest would perhaps sum it up in a word.

title: Iran Tries 12 in Death Plot
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 6 (AP) A fourman army court began an open trial today of 12 persons charged with plotting to assassinate the Shah of Iran and kidnap Empress Farah and the 13yearold Crown Prince Reza.

title: Canadian Posts Her First Triumph
description: PFRONTEN, Germany, Jan. 6 (AP)Kathy Kreiner, a 19yearold blonde Canadian, raced to her first World Cup ski victory today. She won the women's giant slalom in a rainstorm, while Annemarie Proell of Austria, the world cup holder, finished a disappointing eighth.

title: CITY HOSPITALS UNIT ACCUSED OF WASTE
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation spent nearly $16million needlessly in 1972 keeping patients who did not require acute care in general hospitals that provide such care.

title: Follow the Rats?
description: WASHINGTONWhen the water reaches the upper levels, F.D.R.'s Navy Secretary Claude Swanson used to say, follow the rats.

title: BERNARD ARON
description: Bernard Aron, general manager of the Career Club Shirt Company division of Publix Shirt Corporation, died of heart attack Saturday at his home, 11 Fifth Avenue, where he had been recuperating from a stroke. He was 64 years old.

title: Lamb Ski Victor After Kern Falls
Brazil's U.S. Jazz Makes Debut
description: SUMMIT, Jan. 6Jazz from New Orleans and from Chicago in the nineteentwenties, played by musicians who have never been to either city, filled the Summit High School auditorium last night as the traditional Jazz Band of Sao Paulo, Brazil. made its NorthAmerican debut.

title: Brooklyn Stage Going British
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music is becoming the British Academy of Theater from B.A.M. to B.A.T.with a threeandahalfmonth British Theater Season unmatched in New York's theatrical history.

title: Still Time to Give
description: Neither the unsteady Dow Jones index of a nervous stock market nor the nation's concern over the energy crisis had the effect of hardening hearts toward the plight of the poor. The recent holiday season's theme of good will was given true meaning by those who sent their gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases before the start of the new year.

title: Mary Lou Williams, on Piano, Tailors Style to Jazz History
description: While Bobby Short is taking] a twomonth leave from his permanent base, the Cafe Carlyle, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, Mary Lou Williams has moved into the room, replacing Mr. Short's ebullient singing with her accomplished jazz piano.

title: Rangers Repel Flames, As Fairbairn Ends His Slump
description: The New York Rangers and the Atlanta Flames came to life last night and played a lively third period of hockey at Madison Square Garden, Each team scored twice in that closing period, but the Rangers had an advantage going in, and they came out with a 52 victory.

title: Irving Has Lounging Day On His Pass From Prison
description: Clifford Irving, the author who was sent to Federal prison in connection with his spurious biography of Howard Hughes, lounged in his lawyer's Manhattan apartment yesterday, read The New York Times and scanned two books.

title: FORD IS HOPEFUL OF COMPROMISE IN TAPE DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON,. Jan. 6Vice President Ford said today that some compromise might be possible between the White House and the Senate Watergate committee following President Nixon's rejection on Friday of committee requests for more than 500 tapes and documents.

title: Nets Down Colonels, 103100
BOOKS IN S.I. SCHOOL BURNED BY VANDALS
description: Vandals broke into Intermediate High School 2 last night in Staten Island and set fire to about 50 books after dumping them into two garbage cans in the school library, authorities reported.

title: CONGRESS FOUND TO ERR IN CLAIMS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6Although Congress claimed to have cut the President's proposed appropriation total by net $3billion in the session just ended, it actually added $4billion to total Government spending, a wellknown budget analyst concluded today.

title: Dolphins Hit Town For the Countdown
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 6 (AP)About 400 cheering, pennantwaving fans greeted the American Football Conference champion Miami Dolphins today when they arrived to begin final drills for next Sunday's Super Bowl game against Minnesota.

title: Beame's Son Blamed for Fiasco on Terry Appointment
description: Mayor Beanie's son Bernard (Buddy) Beanie was given much of the credit for running the Beanie mayoral campaign. Now he is being given much of the blame for the Seymour Terry fiasco. It was Buddy Beame, City Hall informants report, who was Mr. Terry's strongest booster first in Mr. Terry's attempt to become a Deputy Mayor and, when that failed, to become the Mayor's chief troubleshooter, a job especially created so that Mr. Terry would not lose too much face when he did not get the Deputy Mayor's post.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
4Year Oil Broadway Contract Turned Down by Actors Equity
description: Actors Equity Association rejected yesterday a fouryear contract proposed by the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers that would affect performers and stage managers in 57 theaters.

title: Ithaca Coach Honored
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 6 (AP) Carlton Wood, who guided Ithaca to second place in the collegedivision world series, has been named coach of the year by the Association of American College Baseball Coaches.

title: Rangers Repel Flames, As Fairbairn Ends His Slump
U.N Reports a Decline in Fighting on Suez Front
description: CAIRO, Jan. 6  Shooting along the EgyptianIsraeli lines east and west of the Suez Canal was reported by the headquarters of the United Nations Emergency Force here to have dropped off In the last few days, although a threat of serious disruptions was said to persist in one area east of the waterway.

title: Karen Krantzcke Upsets Miss Goolagong in Final
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 6 (AP)Karen Krantczke, the 6footlinch Australian tennis star, upset her compatriot, Evonne Goolagong., 62, 63, today in the woman's singles final of the New South Wales tennis championships.

title: Mrs. Howard Southgate, Literary Agent, Is Dead
description: Mrs. Maeve La Farge Southgate, a literary agent and the widow of Howard Southgate, writer, died here Saturday. She lived at 41 Fifth Avenue.

title: Energy Bill to Test Saxbe Commitment
description: WASHINGTONThe strength or softness of the antitrust view of the new Attorney General, William B. Saxbe, is about to be made clear.

title: The Need for Rationing
description: The Administration is still trying to make up its mind about instituting an orderly system of gasoline rationing.

title: Nuclear Navy Advocates Find Argument Bolstered by Oil Crisisl
A Foil Finds 38% in U.S. Sympathize With Israelis
description: A poll commissioned by C.B.S. News indicates that more Americans sympathize with Israel than with the Arabs and believe that the United States should apply little or no pressure on Israel to relinquish Arab territories taken in the 1967 war.

title: COURT FIGHT WON BY ANIMAL PARK
description: TRENTON, Jan. 6  Great lAdventure, Inc., the New York corporation that plans to build a $104million wildlife park and amusement area in Jackson Township, has won a temporary court battle allowing it to continue construction with the hope of opening the first phase of the project this summer.

title: They Keep Warm With Wood Stoves Throughout House
description: KATONAH, N.Y.  Fuel shortage? The Kiley family isn't going to worry about it.

title: 2 Foundations Say Birth Control Study Needs New Funds
description: Officials of the Ford and Rockefeller foundations asserted yesterday that financial support for research on birth control was entirely inadequate.

title: So Little Time
description: Time is rapidly running out for the protection America's coastal areas. A growing population; increasingly prosperous and leisured, puts the pressure of Intensive recreational use on the thin strips of beach and the adjoining estuarine wetlands.

title: Third Expansion Offers VVa To Unravel San Diego Snafu
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6The San Diego Dilemma, however it is handled on Wednesday when the National League club owners meet in Chicago, may hasten another expansion of the major leagues.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Pace of New Issues Quickens for Bonds
Dayan Flies Back to Israel After Talks With Kissinger on Disengagement
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 Egypt's Ambassadordesignate to the United States said today that if Egypt and Israel reached an agreement in Geneva on the separation of their military forces, then I can say that we are on the right road toward lifting the Arab oil embargo against the United States.

title: Retailers Feel Pressure of Unknowables in Planning
Letters to the Editor
description: Investing the Wealth of Oil

title: Second Suspect Seized In Shooting of Mailman
description: A second suspect was arrested yesterday in the shooting and critical wounding of !a Queens letter carrier on New Year's Eve.

title: Oil Sales Studied
description: The Federal Energy Office is investigating reports that some heating oil wholesalers have been holding back cheaper domestic fuels from regular customers and using it to take business away from independent suppliers. Page 19.

title: Reid and Sher, DuoPianists, Emphasize the Direct Approach
description: Boyce Reid and Daniel Slier, duopianists who studied in New York but now live in Louisiana, came to Tully Hall on Saturday night in a program of Mozart's Sonata in D (K. 448), Stravinsky's Concerto for Two Pianos, Brahms's Variations on a Theme by Haydn, Lutoslawski's Variations on a Theme of Paganini and four of Dvorak's Legends for piano, four hands.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Nuits Concert Canceled
description: Because of the illness of Jean Royer, conductor of the Nuits Musicales concert series at Alice Tully Hail, Thursday night's program has been canceled.

title: Siqueiros, Muralist and Exponent of New World Proletarian Art, Dies at 77
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 6 (AP)The Mexican muralist David Alfaro Siqueiros died today after losing a fight against cancer. He was 77 years old.

title: Sharif Khan Wins Squash Racquets
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Jan. 6  Sharif Khan, a Pakistani now living in Toronto, won the William White Memorial Cup open squash racquets tournament for the second straight time today at the Merlon Cricket Club.

title: Close Watch on Local Governments Grows as Result of Watergate Doubt
description: MINE HILL, Jan. 6A number of watchdog organizations have been formed on the municipal level in New Jersey in the last year to monitor local government. The result, in the wake of the Watergate scandals, has been a heightened interest in what municipal officials are doing or not doing.

title: PERCY WINNER DIES; CORRESPONDENT, 74
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6Percy Winner, a former foreign correspondent who had recently been director of foreignarea studies at American University, died of cancer yesterday in George Washington University Hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: British Soccer
description: FOOTBALL ASSOCIATION CUP THIRD ROUND

title: FILM BY TRUFFAUT NAMED BEST OF 73
description: Day for Night (La Nuit Americaine''), Frangoise Truffaut's French romantic comedydrama about the making of movie, was voted the best film of 1973 in the seventh annual poll of the National Society of Film Critics.

title: Districting Alternatives
description: State officials may not have to redraw Congressional and legislative district lines in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn to conform to last Friday's Federal Court order on racial fairness. Maps showing racial patterns and other details are on Page 35.

title: Soviet Says Vote Proves the Israelis Are Tired of War
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 6The Soviet press has interpreted the results of last week's Israeli elections as proof of widespread war fatigue and disillusionment in Israel.

title: a Levy on the President's Entire Compensation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6An obscure debate in the Senate more than 22 years ago established the basis for the controversial tax treatment of the annual $50,000 expense allowance of President Nixon, according to Arthur Blech, the President's tax accountant.

title: Troops Back at Heathrow Amid Fear of Missile Raid
description: LONDON, Jan. 6  For the second day, troops, tanks and armored cars surrounded Heathrow Airport today in a fullscale alert ordered after reports that Arab terrorists planned to shoot down airliners with Sovietbuilt surfacetoair missiles.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Jan. 7, 1974 ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Meets 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Artist Who Outlived His Movement
description: The death of an artist is to his life what a frame is to a painting. No matter how well known the events of his career may have been, and no matter how familiar his work, suddenly they are enclosed in their entirety, defined once and for all. The death of David Alfaro Siqueiros acts, additionally, as a longdelayed rounding off of the nationalistic art movement called the Mexican Renaissance, an antiesthetic (at least in European terms), aggressively proletarian movement originated by Diego Rivera and Jose Clemente Orozco in the nineteentwenties as a form of visual propaganda for the agrarian revolution and the ,celebration of Mexico's Indian past.

title: COX ITEM DENIED BY WHITE HOUSE
description: SAN OLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 6 (AP)The White House denied last night a published report that a reason for the dismissal of Archibald Cox as special Watergate prosecutor was a fear that President Nixon would be named as an unindicted coconspirator in a Watergate indictment.

title: ANKER PLANNING SPECIAL SCHOOLS
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker has begun plans to create between five and 10 special elementary schools across the city next year each stressing theme decided by the local community and attended by pupils whose parents have chosen to send them there.

title: Los Angeles Drivers Have Little Difficulty Finding Fuel
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6There was a long line here the ;other night. but unlike the situation on the opposite side of the country, it was for a movie, not gasoline.

title: Pope Speaks of Mideast
description: ROME, Jan, 6Pope Paul VI recalled today his pilgrimage to the holy land 10 years ago, the first of his many trips during his pontificate, and urged Christians to pray for the Middle East. While the Pope spoke briefly to a crowd in St. Peter's Square and gave his customary Sunday blessing, youths were distributing leaflets protesting a scheduled showing of the film Jesus Christ Superstar in Rome tomorrow. They denounced it as blasphemous.

title: Appeal Delays Sterilization Of Retarded St. Louis Girl
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 6 (UPI)Sterilization of a 14yearold mentally retarded girl, requested by her parents because she is overly friendly to strangers, was held up yesterday by an appeal filed by the Legal Aid Society.

title: Energy and Food
description: BOSTON, Jan. 6Every once in while a world trend of profound importance gets under way without making headlines. According to authorities on agricultural production, something like that may be happening in their field right now. The chemical fertilizer on which the world increasingly depends for food is in short supply, and getting shorter.

title: Bridge: Miss Kearse Spero Winner, First Woman to Take Trophy
description: The player with the best record in New York team competitions during a year receives the Spero Trophy of the Greater New York Bridge Association. The 1973 winner is Amalya Kearse of New York, the first woman expert to win this major award. Her success was attributable to a rare combination of technical skill, determination, concentration, and being pleasant to partners.

title: FIVE GIVE BACKING TO SOLZHENITSYN
description: MOSCOW, Jan, 6Five Soviet dissident intelleauals came to the defense of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn today, supporting both his right to publish The Gulag Archipelago and the general thrust of the charges made in his new book.

title: 3 City Boroughs May Be Able to Avoid FullScale Redistricting
description: A range of alternatives will be available to New York State to conform to a court order subjecting Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn legislative districts to racial fairness criteria.

title: Brooklyn Mass Honors Nine Slain Policemen
description: Two hundred worshippers, including 100 police officers, attended a high mass in an AfroAmerican Orthodox church in the Bedford Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn yesterday to honor the nine city policemen killed in the line of duty here last year.

title: A Health Problem on the Reservation
description: WHITESBURG, Ky.The elimination of the military draft is considered one of the good things of the Nixon years. But it has also meant the end of a fairly regular flow of draftdetesting young medical school students seeking to do their time in the Public Health Service.

title: WILSON WILL URGE BUSINESSTAX CUT
description: Governor Wilson will propose that the state double the current tax cuts provided to corporations that invest in plant expansion.

title: Advertising: Upbeat Bond Spots
description: In recent years the creative print advertising for Lebenthal & Co., a municipal bond house, has stood out against a background of usually dull (but terribly informative) financial advertising.

title: Discoverer of Cornet Lubas Kohoutek
description: Among the many scientists and amateur astronomers who will be trying to catch evening glimpses of and study the cornet Kohoutek during the next few weeks will be the shy 38yearold, Czechoslovakianborn astronomer who stumbled across the comet while searching for asteroids last March. He is Dr. Lubos Kohoutek (pronounced Loo bosh Kohotek without, accent on any syllable), the man who made the discovery at the Hamburg Observatory in West Germany, where he has been working since 1968.

title: Soviet Spy Thriller Exposes U.S. Plot
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 6  For most Americans, World War II has faded into history, left largely to scholars and retired generals to debate. For Russians, it is kept vivid as a memory and a source of national unity through a flood of books, movies, memoirs, and lectures  but rarely as effectively as in the latest television espionage thriller, Seventeen Instants in Spring.

title: Hearing Delayed on Order Silencing Health Officials
description: TRENTON, Jan. 5  Dr. Oscar Sussman, the feisty consumer health director, and his fellow Health Department employes will have to wait a bit longer for a hearing in their court suit. Dr. Sussman is challenging the policies of Dr. James R. Cowan, Commissioner ofthe Department of Health, who has restricted public statements by employes in his department. The hearing, scheduled for this week, has been .postponed until next month.

title: Title to Miss Zaharko
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 6Wendv Zaharko .defeated Mrs. Leland Moyer, 154, 1512, 1215, 1512, for the New Jersey women's squash racquets championship today at the Pretty Brook Tennis Club.

title: Barker Said to Link Plumbers To Bugging of Soviet Embassy
description: MIAMI, Jan. (AP)Bernard L. Barker, the convicted Watergate conspirator, is quoted in today's editions of The Miami Herald as saying the White House plumbers intercepted and taped radio communications of the Soviet Embassy proving that the Soviets had access to the Pentagon papers.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: In our Dec. 25 issue, which some readers may have neglected in favor of the Christmas goose, we examined the sad state of home economics. We concluded that it was less to blame than the gourmet crowd for the food mess. Before we depart, perhaps we'd better explain.

title: 4TH TV NETWORK SOON IS DOUBTED
description: Prospects for a fourth commercial television network in the United States in the next few years are not very bright despite the impetus given the idea by a recent White House study, according to a Rand Corporation report released here recently.

title: Energy Office Flooded by Suggestions With 90% Preferring Rationing of Fuel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 6Every day more than 2,000 letters and telegrams descend on the Federal Energy Office with ideas on how to solve the energy crisis.

title: REV. JOSEPH FOLEY, LED PAULIST CHOIR
description: The Rev. Joseph R. Foley, director since 1943 of the Paulist Choristers at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue and 60th Street, died Saturday of a heart attack at the rectory, 415 West 59th Street. He was 58 years old.

title: DR. BENJAMIN BARG, U.N.TECHNOLOGYAIDE
description: Dr. Benjamin Barg, chief of new technologies of the United Nations office for science and technology and adjunct professor of management at the New York University Graduate School of Business Administration, died Friday of a heart attack at Kennedy International airport. He was 41 years old and lived at 16 Huguenot Drive, Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Ozmapolitan Leads Readers Down Yellow Brick Road
description: The road to the City of Emerald is paved with yellow brick, said the witch, so you cannot miss it. And so, Dorothy and, To to, Scarecrow, Tin Woodman, and the cowardly Lion bound down the yellow brick road to see the Wizard of Oz.

title: Julius Brauner, 64, Dies; General Attorney of C.B.S.
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 6Julius F. Brauner, secretary and general attorney of Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., and executive director of CBS Foundation, Inc., died yesterday at his home here. He was 64 years old.

title: FORD IS HOPEFUL OF COMPROMISE IN TAPE DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6Vice President Ford said today that some compromise might be possible between the White House and the Senate Watergate committee following President Nixon's rejection on Friday of committee requests for more than 500 tapes and documents.

title: Books of The Times
description: Time and again, one feels one's about to see what Toni Morrison is trying to do in her second novel, Sula (her first was The Bluest Eye). One glimpses for a moment in her artful evocation of the black community of Medallion, Ohio, which at the opening of Sula is about to be obliterated by a suburban golf course: They are going to raze the Time and Half Pool Hall, where feet in long tan shoes once pointed down from chair rungs. A steel ball will knock to dust Irene's Palace of Cosmetology, where women used to lean their heads back on sink trays and doze while .Irene lathered Nu Nile into their hair. Men in khaki work clothes will pry loose the slats of Reba's Grill, where the owner cooked in her hat because she couldn't remember the ingredients without it. One almost glimpses it in the tragicomic family histories of the story's two heroines: of Nell, whose superrespectable mother brought her to Medallion (or the Bottom, as the black section of Medallion is called) from a New Orleans whorehouse; of Sula, whose grandmother is rumored to have stuck her leg under a passing train in order to live off the $10,000 worth of injury compensation she receives.

title: TV: A Stylized Portrait of Fitzgerald
description: F. Scott Fitzgerald and The Last of the Belles', a twohour film being presented by the American Broadcasting Company tonight at 9 arrives laden with promising credits and admirable ambitions. Herbert Brodkin, the executive producer George Schaefer, the director, and James Costigan, the writer, have intertwined Fitzgerald's biography with a piece of Fitzgerald's fiction in an effort, evidently, to distill and illuminate both.

title: Honda Dealer Sees Benefit in the Shortage
description: Things were bad for Honda of New York in 1973. Unlike some other businesses that are affected by the fuel criis, however, this Manhattan motorcycle agency looks forward to a possible record year in 1974. Honda of New York sold about 600 motorcycles in 1973, well below the breakeven point, according to Oded Benary, 38 years old, the corporation's sales vice president.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: 3 TeenAgers Held in Church Vandalism

title: Soviet Spy Thriller Exposes U.S. Plot
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 6  For most Americans, World War II has faded into historY, left largely to scholars and retired generals to debate. For Russians, it is kept vivid as a memory and a source of national unity through a flood of books, movies, memoirs, and lectures  but rarely as effectively as in the latest television espionage thriller, Seventeen Instants in Spring.

title: President Attends Church In Rare Coast Appearance
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Jan. 6  President Nixon attended church services today in what was his second announced departure from the San Clemente compound since his arrival Dec. 26.

title: President Attends Church In Rare Coast Appearance
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Jan. 6  President Nixon attended church services today in what was his second announced departure from the San Clemente compound since his arrival Dec. 26.

title: The Bitter End of Waitress's Dream: Jail in London
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 6Shortly before 18yearold Allison Thompson quit her job as a waitress and flew to London, she said that she would soon be a rich girl, according to other employes of the Santa Barbara restaurant where she worked.

title: SIMON URGES CUT IN PRICES OF OIL FROM OVERSEAS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6Wil11am E. Simon, the Nixon Administration's energy chief, called today for a rollback of foreign crude oil prices within months.

title: Gifts to Neediest Are in 3 Categories
description: Gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund appear to fall into three categoriesonetime or firsttime donations, contributions from regulars and contributions with growth potential.

title: ROSALIE LITT
description: Rosalie Litt, a member of the classified advertising department of The New York Times for 15 years, died Saturday of a heart attack in Roosevelt Hospital. She lived at 165 West End Avenue.

title: A Man in Rome Says He Helped Abduct Getty
description: ROME, Jan. 6 (AP)  A man saying he had been one of the abductors of Paul Getty 3d telephoned a Rome newspaper early today and named another man in Rome as a leader of the kidnappers, the newspaper reported. It did not disclose the name.

title: 11 Dead and 6 Hurt as Turboprop Crashes Near Johnstown Pa.
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Jan. (AP)  Eleven persons were killed and six others critically injured tonight when a twinengine Air East turboprop crashed while landing at the ,JohnstownCambria County Airport, the authorities said.

title: Rockefeller Panel Studying Predecessor's Impact
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3The top echelon of former Gov. Nelson A, Rockfeller's Commission on Critical Choices for America is studying the impact of a forerunner, the Rockefeller Brothers Fund reports of the late nineteenfifties, titled America at MidCentury.

title: Burger Sees High Court Case Load Doubling by 1987 if Appalling Mass of Litigation Persists
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6Chief Justice Warren E. Burger predicted today that the case load of the Supreme Court, now more than 3,000 a year, would double by 1987 if no steps were taken to deal with what he called the appalling mass of litigation inundating the Federal court system.

title: Morton Assistant Named
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) J. David Breslin, 51 years old, has been appointed special assistant to Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton for the 13state Northeast region. Breslin was the director of Massachusetts's Urban Job Incentive Bureau.

title: TV: Upstairs, Downstairs Is Too Good to Miss
description: If you missed Sunday evening's first episode of Upstairs, Downstairs, the new 13part series on Masterpiece Theater, you shouldn't have. The episode and the series are delightful. But, this being public television, you can still catch up with the inevitable repeat, scheduled on Channel 13 for this Friday at 9 P.M.

title: VOTE ON SUBPOENA COULD TEST HOUSE ON IMPEACHMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7The groundwork was laid for an early test of impeachment sentiment among returning Congressmen when the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee said today that a vote of the full House was needed to give subpoena power to the committee's impeachment inquiry staff.

title: Record Low in Britain
Hanoi Bulldozers Drive Road Network Into South
description: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Jan. 5North Vietnamese bulldozers and South Vietnamese fighterbombers are fighting duel in the forested expanses of the Central Highlands. The bulldozers are winning.

title: CALLISTUS SMITH, 70, A FRANCISCAN PRIEST
description: The Rev. Callistus Smith, who taught canon law and moral theology at Christ the King Seminary of. St. Bonaventure University from 1933 to 1964, died Thursday of cancer in St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson, N. J. He was 70 years old and had been living at St. Bonaventure's Monastery, there since his retirement from teaching.

title: YIELD GENEROUS ON UTILITY ISSUE
description: The corporatebond market, embarked on what will be a busy month yesterday with one new offering drawing a generous 8.40 per cent yield and a recently offered issue climbing, from an original 8,05 per cent yield to an 8.30 per cent yield. The newest offering was $75million of San Diego Gas and Electric Company bonds, rated AA by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's, won in competitive bidding by underwriters headed by Blyth Eastman Dillon. Carrying an 8 per cent coupon rate, the bonds were riced at 99.727 per cent of the principal amount to yield 8,40 per cent.

title: Jersey Sues 2 ExCahill Aides Over Kickbacks on State Lease
description: TRENTON, Jan. 7Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr. said today he had filed a civil suit against two former Republican fund raisers who arranged a state lease for office spade in the Arnold Constable Building. here and then received 10 per cent of the rents under a secret agreement with lithe Arnold Constable Corpora;tion.The agreement could have brought them $4million if the lease ran to its maximum possi; ble term.

title: Thai Government's Life Is Short, Its Problems Many
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan.  Thailand's interim Government, at the midpoint between the student uprising that overthrew an authoritarian Government in October and the scheduled establishment of a new Constitution in April, is grappling with political, economic and social problems that writhe and menace like the vipers at the Pasteur Institute's snake farm in downtown Bangkok.

title: France Confirms Negotiations on Oil With Saudi Arabia
description: PARIS, Jan. 7The Government confirmed today that France was negotiating a long. term agreement with Saudi Arabia on oil deliveries.

title: State Addict Aid Proposal Gives Prisoners Priority
description: TRENTON, Jan. 7 (UPI) The New Jersey Health Department proposed a $6million drug treatment plan today that would place priority on rehabilitating imprisoned addicts.

title: Widened Turnpike Between Exits 10 And 9 Now Open
description: A new fivemile stretch of 12lane dualdual highway became fully operational on the New Jersey Turnpike yesterday between Exits 10 (Edison) and 9 (East Brunswick).

title: GIRL FEARED TAKEN FOUND WITH FATHER
description: KINNELON, Jan. 7A 2yearold Kinnelon girl was found in good condition at Kennedy Airport this evening, a few hours after she had taken from her bed in her grandfather's home. According to the police, the girl, Michele Lynn Markoski, had been kidnapped by her father, who is estranged from the child's mother.

title: Schmidt Completes Negotiations to Buy A Rheingold Plant
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 C. Schmidt & Sons, Inc., of Philadelphia has completed negotiations to buy the Rheingold Brewery at Orange, N.J., and continue production of Rheingold beer there.

title: Nuxhall to Cover Reds Another Year
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 7 (AP) Joe Nuxhall, who has spent more than half his life with the Cincinnati organization, was signed today for an eighth season as color commentator with the Reds broadcast team.

title: Making a Decision for America
description: Dear Peter and David,

title: Business Is Own Worst Enemy To Public, May's Chairman Says
description: American business has fallen into wide disrepute mainly because the public has come to distrust the profit motive and business has an almost unbroken record of opposing legislation that the public thinks is good, Stanley J. Goodman, chairman of the May Department Stores Company, St. Louis, told a convention here yesterday.

title: Who Grabs In Brooks? Who Would Dare Try!
description: There were several dozen early arrivals. They were wearing cotton oxford buttondown shirts, unobtrusive ties, threebutton suits, hats and gloves.

title: LEADER OF PARTY IN ULSTER YIELDS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 7Brian Faulkner resigned today as leader of the Unionists, Northern Ireland's biggest Protestant party, but he declared that he would remain as head of the province's new governing executive body.

title: A Nation Of SecretSharers?
description: How is it to be explained that while 79 per cent of the 2,000 persons recently polled by the Roper organization believed Richard Nixon guilty of one or more serious charges against him, only 44 per cent of the same persons favored his impeachment?

title: Sugar Cane Cutter Killed
description: BELLE GLADE, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP)One offshore sugar cane cutter was killed today and 751 were injured when a tractortrailer carrying 130 field laborers overturned along a rainslicked highway, the police said.

title: Cone Mills in Plant Closing
description: The Cone Mills Corporation announced yesterday that it was closing its knit ,plant in Whitmire, S. C., owing to a lack of profitability and extremely competitive conditions in the knitting industry. The company said it would assist the 250 plant workers to obtain other employment.

title: Apple Hill Blends Fluent Musicianship With Stylistic Flair
description: The Apple Hill Chamber Players, composed of faculty members of the Center for Chamber Music in Nelson, N. H., began to extend their activities a couple of seasons ago to neighboring villages in the Monadnock Mountains. Last season this missionary work was enlarged to include this city, with a sevenconcert series that reportedly was wellreceived by the natives.

title: Met Improvises Friday's Tristan
description: The Metropolitan Opera, shaken by casting crises and intramural warfare, pulled itself together yesterday and improvised plans to perform Tristan and Isolde Friday night.

title: Connecticut Unemployment Up by 13,000 in Two Weeks
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 7 (UPI)The State Labor Department says unemployment in Connecticut has increased by about 13,000 over a twoweek period ended Dec. 29. The decrease in employment was attributed to the preChristmas ice storm, problems caused by the energy crisis an dseasonal fluctuations in the job market.

title: Grandmother, 87, Is Killed In Gloucester Gas Blast
description: BLACKWOOD TERRACE, Jan. 7 (UPI)An 87yearold grandmother was killed today when.a gas line leading to her house exploded after it was hit by a contractor digging for a sewer line in the Gloucester County community. The body of Elizabeth Herring, who owned and lived alone in the twostory house, was found under a pile of debris in her neighbor's yard. An adjoining home was destroyed by fire, and another severely damaged.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Slatkin to Bow Here As Muti StandIn

title: DUDLEY J. BACHRACH
description: Dudley J. Bachrach, retired president of the Clifton Chemical Company, died Sunday in University Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in the Bolivar Hotel.

title: Mrs. Weyher, A. K. Gage Wed
description: Mrs. Barbara McCusker Weyher was married here yesterday afternoon to Alan Kenneth Gage, president of Parrish Securities, Inc., members of the New York Stock Exchange. The Rev. James Seth Stewart performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church, where the bridegroom is a deacon.

title: O'Dwyer Vows Not to Accept Proxies In Challenge to Leadership of Council
description: In an implicit challenge to the City Council leadership, Paul O'Dwyer, the newly installed President, has informed Councilmen that he will not accept voting by proxy. said that the committee would meet soon to discuss proxy voting. He predicted that some reform would emerge, such as allowing proxies to be left only on specific bills and only by Councilmen who are physically present on the day of a vote and then called away.

title: Heath Rules Out Yielding to Coal Miners
Presidential Papers...
description: The dispute over President Nixon's large and legally questionable tax deduction for the donation of his VicePresidential papers to the National Archives raises once again the unresolved issue of the ownership of the papers of Presidents and other public servants.

title: Democrats, in State of State, Press Rival Legislative Goals By FRANCIS X. CLINES
Filion and Chapman Receive FiveDay Trot Suspensions
description: In the continuation of a gettougher policy, Herve Filion, the national harness champion, and John Chapman received fiveday suspensions yesterday from the new New York State Racing and Wagering Board for driving viola tions at Roosevelt. Raceway last week. The verdicts were handed down by the presiding judge, Howard C. Dobler, and his associates, Peter A. Avalone and Vincent A. Bergamo. Dobler had promised that the board would be stricter, imposing suspensions rather than fines. In the last two weeks; five drivers have been set down for infractions.

title: Books of The Times
description: According to Nathan A. Scott Jr., apocalypticism, as a distinctive way of managing reality, is, of course, a method which the imagination tends to employ precisely in those moments when the realities of history seem to be quite unmanageable. We fall back on the dramatic ellipses of prophecy and revelation, on cosmic incantation, when we no longer have what Paul Tillich called the courage to be""the kind of courage, Mr. Scott says that permits us to reckon with the conditioned and imperfect reality of ourselves and the world to which we are committed by the logic of our history.

title: CHLOE OWEN GIVES RECITAL OF LIEDER
description: Chloe Owen's recital of German songs late Sunday afternoon at Town Hall had much to recommend it. Miss Owen, who has had an extensive career in Europe and America and who teaches now at Boston University, is obviously at home with the lieder of Brahms, Mozart and Richard Strauss. Her command of the language was secure, and her bright, even soprano was able to encompass most of the technical demands posed by her program.

title: Byrne Scored for Failing To Give Blacks Any Posts
description: TRENTON, Jan, 7  New Jersey's two most prominent black political leaders strongly criticized Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne today for failing to appoint any blacks thus far to top positions in his incoming Democratic state administration.

title: A Brooklyn Man Goes on Trial In 1972 Slaying of 2 Policemen
description: A 26yearold Brooklyn man charged with slaying two policemen in the East Village nearly two years ago went on trial yesterday in State Supreme Court here, and 50 prospective jurors were told that testimony might not be completed until the end of March.

title: Browns Name Gregg
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 7 (UPI) Forrest Gregg, a bulwark of the powerful Green Bay Packer teams as an eighttime allpro offensive right tackle, was named offensive line coach of the Cleveland Browns tonight.

title: 4 Die as Car Hits Lake
description: EUREKA, Calif., Jan. 7 (UN) Four young girls died early yesterday when the automobile in which they were riding skidded off a highway in a sleet storm and plunged into an arm of Humboldt Bay. The bodies of Tanya Moores, years old, Jean Price, 10. Joan Price, 9, and Leah Woods, 11, were recovered four hours later by sheriff's department marine divers.

title: 5 Italians Post Sweep In Slalom

title: LEADER OF PARTY IN ULSTER YIELDS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 7Brian Faulkner resigned today as leader of the Unionists, Northern Ireland's biggest Protestant party, but he declared that he would remain as head of the province's new governing executive body. Mr. Faulkner's resignation came after a vote on Friday in the Unionist ruling council gave a majority to those who opposed his policy of sharing power with Roman Catholics and of participating, together with the Government of the neighboring Irish Republic, in a Council of Ireland.
