title: Graduates of Catholic Schools Found More Hopeful in Study
description: Roman Catholic adults who have attended parochial schools tend to be more hopeful"! about human problems than those who have not, according to two Chicago sociologists. The implication of this finding according to the pair, the Rev. Andrew M. Greeley and William C. McCready, is that Catholic schools, may have worked better than most peopie thought in their goal of equipping students with Christian values. They warned, however, that such news may have come too late to help in the revival of the parochial school system in this country. The deterioration of selfconfidence is such now that it is improbable that any good news can reverse the process, they stated. It is almost as though no one wishes to believe in the possibility of good news about Catholic schools. Father Greeley and Mr. McCready, both members of the staff of the National Opinion Research Center in Chicago, based their findings and conclusions on research conducted for the Henry Luce Foundation that is scheduled to be published soon under the title The Ultimate Values of Americans. Preliminary Report A preliminary report on aspects of the study, based on a subsample of 356 American Catholics, appears under the authors names in the current issue of The National Catholic Reporter, a layedited Catholic weekly newspaper. In the survey, the two scholars asked respondents to indicate how they would react to six."critical life situations. The situations included being told that one's child would be mentally retarded and interpreting the meaning of natural disasters. Men and Women of Hope The respondents were then classified into five groups on a scale ranging from religious optimists who [slide] rather easily over evil, suffering and tragedy to pessimists who are angry at the folly and absurdity of the human condition. Another category is the hopefuls, who take the problem of evil seriously but believe good to be stronger than evil. In their article, the two sociologists, who recently released another study reporting a sharp decline in churchgoing among adult Catholics, found that respondents who had gone to Catholic schools seem to be those who have not to be men and women of hope.

title: Jump in Oil Earnings Seen
description: The oil crisis appears to be bad news for everybody except the oil industry itself. As the data In the accompanying chart show, the major oil companies increased their profits spectacularly during the first nine months of 1973. Exxon's profits were up 59 per cent over the first nine months of 1972; Shell, up 41 per cent; Mobil, up 38 per cent; Texaco, up 35 per cent; Gulf, up 60 per cent; Standard of California, up 40 per centand Occidental Petroleum, up a tidy 417 per cent.

title: A Bachelor, 74, Fights To Keep His 100 Cats

His collection started 15 years ago, five years before his retirement as an inspector at Pratt & Whitney, when he brought home a pregnant stray female. Successive offspring have stabilized at about 100, Mr. Bachman said.

description: A black man will be appointed as a Deputy Mayor today, barring any unforseen situations, Mayor Beame said yesterday during an impromptu news conference in his City Hall office.

title: Spending the Oil Money
description: According to the joke making the rounds of the more cynical international financiers, Arab oil producers should be encouraged to use their windfall revenues to buy up the stock of great American corporations, and then the corporations could simply be nationalized. Beyond this arch suggestion, there is little levity these days about the convulsions threatening the world monetary system, one of the more awesome sideeffects of the energy crisis.

title: Filion and Chapman Receive FiveDay Trot Suspensions
description: In the continuation of a gettougher policy, Herve Filion, the national harness champion, and John Chapman received fiveday suspensions yesterday from the new New York State Racing and Wagering Board for driving viola tions at Roosevelt Raceway last week. The verdicts were handed down by the presiding judge, Howard C. Dobler, and his associates, Peter A. Avalone and Vincent A. Bergamo. Dobler had promised that the board would be stricter, imposing suspensions rather than fines. In the last two weeks, five drivers have been set down for infractions.

title: COLLUSION HINTED KENT SHOOTINGS;Spontaneous Incident Also Possibility, Witness Says
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 7 (AP).A former National Guard officer said he told a grand jury today that shooting by National Guard troops at Kent State University might have been the result of possible coincidence.

title: 73 SALES AT 415,000 FOR POLAROLD SX70
description: The Polaroid Corporation reported yesterday that retail sales of its new SX70 camera totaled 415,000 units in 1973, but the company fell short of its goal of selling one million units. The 1973 sales goal was a secret locked in a sealed envelope in the office of Peat Marwick Mitchell & Co., Polaroid's auditors, and only was made public yesterday.

title: RISE IN MARIJUANA AND HASHISH FOUND
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UPI) Enough marijuana and hashish entered the United States in 1973 to make about five billion cigarettes, according to a Senate report.

title: Byrne Is Criticized For Failing to Give Blacks Any Posts
description: TRENTON, Jan. 7  New Jersey's two most prominent political leaders strongly criticized Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne today for failing to appoint any blacks thus far to top positions in his incoming Democratic state administration.

title: Long Beach Tries To Check Decline
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., Jan. 7 Like natives of some isolated civilization, most residents of Long Beach use the same words to describe Long Island's only citybythesea:

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Portability
description: One happy aspect of saltwater fly fishing its proponents never mention is that one is not overburdened with equipment.

title: Civilians Caught in Phnom Penh Clashes
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 7 (UPI)Scores of civilians were reported killed today in fighting between Govern1ment and Communist troops near Phnom Penh's airport.

title: 6 Jews Deny Guilt In Slaying of Arab Living in Norway
description: OSLO, Norway, Jan. 7 (UPI) Six Jews pleaded not;guilty today to charges of, espionage and conspiracy to , cOmmit murder in the slaying in Norway last summer of a man thought to be a leader of Black September, an Arab terrorist organization.

title: AirShuttle Service Is Ended by Eastern To Conserve Fuel
description: NEWARK, Jan. 7  Under cloudy skies but good flying conditions, a reservedseat, scheduled Eastern Airlines aircraft took off from Newark Airport for Boston at 7 A. M. today, and 20 minutes later similar flight headed for Washington.

title: Army Judge Acquits Sikh Wearing Turban on Duty
description: FORT MONMOUTH, Jan. 7 In a reversal of previous military rulings, an Army judge today acquitted a soldier of all charges pertaining to his practice of the Sikh religion while in uniform and on duty.

title: Tour's Roaring Ovations Leave Dylan Quietly Pleased
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 Bob Dylan, dressed in jeans, a zippered sweatshirt and a fur hat, sat barefooted and crosslegged on the living room couch of a suite in the Sheraton Hotel this afternoon, wiping sleep from his eyes and gradually overcoming a certain frogthroatedness usually associated with the early morning hours.

title: Malaysia to Restrict Size Of OilDrilling Concessions
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Jan. 7 (AP)Malaysia will reduce the size of offshore oil concessions, her Primary Industries Minister, Taib Mahmud, announced today. He said the current concessions are at least 15,000 square miles each. Future concessions will be limited to about 5,000 square miles apiece.

title: SISCO TO REMAIN AS KISSINGER AIDI
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7Sec retary of State Kissinger ha persuaded Joseph J. Sisco, thl State Deparment's top officia for Middle Eastern affairs, to accept a major promotion the department and give ur plans to become president o Hamilton College this spring Administration officials said to. night.

title: New Draft Director
description: TRENTON, Jan. 7 (AP)Edward J. Henderson has been named state director of Selective Service for New Jersey. Mr. Henderson, who lives here, was to be sworn in tomorrow by Maj. Gen. William R. Sharpe, chief of staff of the state department of defense.

title: 3 Americans Win. At S. Africa Net
description: DURBAN, South Africa, Jan. 7 (Reuters)Raz Reid of Greenville, S.C., Dick Dell of Bethesda, Md., and Sharon Walsh of San Rafael, Calif., won first  round matches in a Sugar circuit tennis tournament today.

title: PRODUCERS WEIGH A DIALOGUE ON OIL
description: GENEVA, Jan. 7Oil ministers from the major exporting nations today considered proposals for a dialogue with consumer countries over matters of common concern, such as more stable pricing, conference sources said.

title: Syria Says She Repulsed Advance by Israeli Tanks
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. (Reuters)  A military spokesman said today that Syrian artillery had inflicted casualties and driven back an Israeli armored unit that had moved toward Syrian positions.

title: PROSECUTOR CITES ERROR BY CARPI
description: TRENTON, Jan. 7Richard M. Altman, Mercer County assistant prosecutor, said in an opening statement today at Colin C. Carpi's murder trial that the wealthy businessman thought he had committed the perfect crime but made a single fatal error.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A sevenman, fivewoman Federal jury was chosen in Newark yesterday to hear the cocaine smuggling trial of Peter Richard Campisi, a reputed mobster, and five others. They were among 20 persons named last May a threecount indictment that alleged they had conspired to smuggle in at least five and a half kilos of cocaine from South America. Judge James A. Coo'hail is presiding in District Court.

title: THOMAS J. GILLEN
description: Thomas J. Gillen, a printer at The New York Times from 1946 to his retirement in 1964, died Saturday in Physicians Hospital, Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 79 years old and lived at 4115 Benham Street, Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Dave Anderson Dolphins Better Than the Packers
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 7When the Miami Dolphins won the Super Bowl a year ago, they still had their skeptics. It was almost as if, by streaking through 17 games, they had been too perfect to be accepted for what they werethe best team in National Football League history. But this season they've convinced the skeptics. They've even convinced the oddsmakers.

title: Record Low in Britain
description: LONDON, Jan. 7A massive shift into American dollars swept through the foreignexchange markets of Western Europe today as speculators rushed to sell British pounds, West German marks, Swiss francs and other currencies.

title: Temple Player Barred
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 (AP) Temple goes into the Big 5 basketball game against Pennsylvanii,tomorrow without the services of Joe Anderson. The 6foot4 forward was suspended last night for leaving the Owls lockerroom at halftime Saturday night and not returning. The Owls lost to Manhattan, 6866.

title: PLAN BOARD ACTS NURSING HOMES
description: The City Planning Commission approved a proposal yesterday to extend its control over construction of nursing homes and healthrelated facilities in 24 of the city's 62 community planning districts.

title: A CABINET SHUFFLE EXPECTED IN EGYPT
description: CAIRO, Jan 7Indications that President Anwar elSadat intends to turn over the premiership and shuffle the Cabinet were confirmed today by the authoritative Cairo newspaper Al Ahram.

title: Safety Unit Plans Hearing On an Aerosol Spray Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP)  The Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today that it would hold a public hearing next month on a petition requesting a ban on certain aerosol spray products used in the home.

title: Sugarman Is Taking a Post in Atlanta
description: Jule M. Sugarman, the city's Human Resources Administrator, was named yesterday as chief administrative officer of Atlanta by that Georgia city's first black Mayor, Maynard Jackson. He will take office Jan. 28.

title: DDT Use for Moths Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP)the Agriculture Department said today that it had asked the environmental Protection Agency to approve the possible use of DDT ext summer for control of Tussock moths invading Douglas fir in the Northwest. A similar request to use the banned pesticide for Tussock control was banned by agency last year. In the new request, Agriculture Secretary Earl I.. Butz said it would only be used if other measures failed to curb) the insects.

title: Rangers Need 3Period Stamina for SixGame Trip
description: One of the charms of the New York Rangers is that they are difficult to figure out. On paper they have depth, scoring power, defense, experience  everything. On the ice they are something else. The club that everyone though t back in October was a shooin to win the Stanley Cup is hanging on to a precarious third place in the East Division of the National Hockey League. Lately they have acquired the notion that a hockey game runs only two periods. That was how they lost last Friday to Boston and how they almost gave away a game Sunday to Atlanta.

title: United States Government and Agency Bonds
Judge Defers Ruling on Treaty For First Wounded Knee Trial
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 7  Federal District Judge Fred Nichol said today that he had not decided if he would allow Dennis J. Banks and Russell C. Means, the leaders of last year's insurrection at Wounded Knee, S.D., to use the Indian treaty of 1868 as a defense in their trial.

title: 3 PAPERS SCHEDULE AUTOMATION TALKS

title: Heath Rules Out Yielding to Coal Miners
description: LONDON, Jan. 7  Prime Minister Heath has declared that he is prepared to keep Britain on a threeday week at least until spring rather than yield to the wage demands of the coal miners.

title: Obsolete Status Symbol
description: The order that barred the use of a special aircraft for a European inspection tour by an Air Force general of little consequence in itself; its significance is symbolic. It is futile to ask the American public to conserve fuel by limiting driving, turning down the thermostat and dimming the lights, while the privileged few the military, Government or business and industry continue needlessly and wastefully to exercise their prerogatives as though there were no gasoline shortage at all. Fairness dictates the elimination of a businessasusual resort to such means of transportation when they constitute merely the trappings of executive prestige rather than a necessity for efficient travel of security.

title: Nets Release Rinaldi

title: Heathrow Alert Still On; Continent Tightens Guard

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UPI)  The Consumer Product Safety Commission said today that it had requested the recall of at least 10 brands of a glue, developed originally for surgery, that is so strong it can cement the user's fingers together.

title: Records
description: A good many modern performances of the symphonies of Anton Bruckner sound as if the conductors were just a little ashamed of his music. The broad, expansive gestures are hurried over, the musical expressivity is ignored in favor of a brisk contemporaneity. The result is, paradoxically, to make Buckner sound more empty and boring than he does in more oldfashioned kinds of performances: Those chunky, repetitive motifs have an inevitability to them at a slow tempo that they lose when speeded up.

(UPI)The Chicago Cougars and Cleveland Crusaders skated to a scoreless tie in overtime tonightthe World Hockey Association's first overtime contest to end with a 00 score. title: Screen: 2d Animation Festival Begins
description: The second International Animation Film Festival will open today at 9:30 A.M. at New York University's Loeb Center Auditorium, 566 La-Guardia Place and Washington Square South. As with the first assembly held here in 1972, the public is invited to the four-day conclave of distributors and makers of animated movies. In addition to special and retrospective screenings, the program will include a competition among 200 animated short-subjects from 20 countries.The nonprofit festival is funded in part by a grant from the New York State Council on the Arts, with additional support from N.Y.U. It is one of three international events devoted exclusively to animation, with the other festivals being held in Annecy, France, and Zagreb, Yugoslavia.At a press preview of the program, Fred Mintz, the festival's organizer, said that the program would stress the burgeoning activities and new trends of animation here and abroad."Animation is a thriving business both here and in Europe," said Mr. Mintz, who heads the Cinephile Company, a distribution agency in New York. "The main outlets now in the United States are, of course, television and the 16-mm., non-theatrical circuit of schools, clubs and libraries, which are buying more and more animated shorts as audio-visual aids in the graphic arts."Mr. Mintz estimated that there was a total of 100 animation studios in Europe, most with government subsidies. There are, he said, about 200 studios here. Current trends are toward the mixing of computerization and animation and the production of more theatrical features, such as the French-Czechoslovak "Fantastic Planet" and Ralph Bakshi's "Fritz the Cat" and "Heavy Traffic." (The Bakshi films will be given a double-feature screening at the festival.)Other special events at the festival are screenings of animated works by Bruno Bozzetto (Italy), Yoji Kuri (Japan) and the late Jiri Trnka (Czechoslovakia), a showing of the United Nations Children's Fund movie, "The Selfless Giant," and a computer-animation conference."The wonderful thing about animation as a field," Mr. Mintz said, "is its built-in international language. With minimal, practical adjustments, animated pictures have an audience anywhere. Whereas the two European festivals stress the artistio products, we are also emphasizing new techniques in drawing and showing educational and industrial films and even the longer, made-for-TV specials, unlike Annecy and Zagreb."A two-hour sampling of festival shorts, entered in competition, attested to the program's variety and quality.The National Film Board of Canada's "The Family That Dwelt Apart" is a sprightly fable narrated by the author, E. B. White. "The Maggot" is a striking anti-drug cartoon set in Harlem but made in Britain by George Dunning (of "Yellow Submarine"). Francis Masse's "Evasion Express," from France, is a strong, brooding parable of train passengers, in contrast with a frisky college, "Mini-Mini," from Japan. The Italian-made "Opera" hilariously satirizes operatic performances in terms of social fantasy.Other samplings were Wolfgang Urchs's "Neighbors," a sharp satire within a simple animated frame, and a radiant television commercial linking Eastern Airlines and the Walt Disney World. Two somber, artistic imports from Poland and Belgium, Richard Czekala's "The Son" and Raoul Servais's "Pagasus," were remarkably effective.Festival tickets, excluding some special events, are $2 each, and $1 tickets, for students. They are available at the Loeb Center box office.

description: SPRINGFIELD, III., Tan. 8 (UPI)  Herbert G. Klein, former director of communications for the executive branch, suggested today the television industry should cut back on its broadcasting hours to help save energy.

title: McCord's Bond Reduced From $50,000 to $5,000
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Bond for James W, McCord Jr. was lowered today from $50,000 to $5,000 by United States District Judge John J. Sirica.

title: ExHead of Bolivia Exiled to Paraguay Along With 5 Aides
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 8 (Reuters)Former President Victor Paz Estenssoro and five members of his Nationalist Revolutionary Movement party were deported today to neighboring Paraguay, an official communiqua announced here.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 8 (UPI)A roundtheworld, 100day voyage of the liner Oriental Empress has come to an abrupt end in Hong Kong's harbor: the vessel ran out of fuel. The liner, owned by the C.Y. Tung Group, left Los. Angeles Dec. 7 with 250 passengers, and her scheduled ports of call included places in the Far East, Africa and South and Central America.

title: Nets Score By 109101, Tie for First
Red Smith
description: Henry David Thoreau has warned us to beware of all enterprises that require new clothes, but the hermit Walden has never been Joe Frazier's favorite author. The former heavyweight champion of the world, whose next major enterprise is a 12round match with Muhammad Ali, visited New York this week for a fitting of an anklelength white mink coat (he has a black one back home Philadelphia). He was chic as a fire engine with his widebrimmed hat of red felt, red turtleneck, red shoes with threeinch heels and a suit of blackandwhite plaid. On his left pinky was a cluster 19 modest diamonds, on his right a soliof laire that could once have been the eye a pagan idol. His even teeth gleamed through shrubbery neatly trimmed. Even Solomon In all his glory, according to a reliable source, was not more fetchingly arrayed.

title: Price Runaway
description: With food and fuel prices both racing uphill, the defenses against inflation are fast collapsing. The wholesale price index went up last month at a rate that would cut 25 cents out of the 1974 consumer's dollar if fully translated at the retail level.

title: A Planning Revolution
description: A quiet revolution has taken place in planning in New York. In many parts of this metropolis, the community and City Hall have been working together to preserve and improve neighborhoods according to deeprooted local understanding of the area's character and needssomething the cynics said could never be done.

title: Culture Expands Into Suburbs, Mixed Notices
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 8One day last month at Sardi's, just off Times Square, a group of people interested in various aspects of show business gathered to examine what many felt was the ailing state of Broadway.

title: Peasants Trade Secretly With Vietcong
description: CAM AN, South Vietnam7 If a villager is enterprising and daring, he can buy a bicycle tire for about $1.40 in this tiny hamlet, carry it one mile east of here and sell it for $4.50.

title: HENRY WEITZ
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 8Henry Weitz, former director and senior vice president of Loehmann's, the women's dress store chain, died here today of a heart attack. His age was 72 and he lived in Hollywood.

title: Mother and Two Children Die in Brooklyn Fire
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: FallOff of Gunfire in Mideast Continues
The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: ECONOMIC AND

title: A Town Shows Its Strength By WinningWar of Whistle
description: CANTON, III,, Jan. 8The town whistle blew here today. And that simple, steamy blast brought smiles to the faces of Lee Allaman and Orlene Johnson and Edward Lewis and Florence Thixton and Ray Walker and even old Al Sheets. It was rurther proofif any was needed  that the end had come for the Great Whistle War, a sudden skirmish that taught the state government, a giant corporation and much of a cheering Middle West just how strong an aroused community can be when its institutions appear to be threatened.

title: Bridge: Insoluble Problem Is Posed In Rebidding FourFive Hand
description: A permanent problem in standard bidding methods is the moderate fourfive hand, with a fourcard suit just outranking a fivecard suit.

title: C.M. in Employe Cutbacks
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 8 (AP)Some 350 workers at the General Motors Corporation's Fish er body plant in nearby West Mifflin have been furloughed because of the energy crisis, plant officials said today. Frank Dox, personnel director at the plant, said the layoffs) were for an indefinite period, and noted that decisions on further employe cutbacks will be made on a daytoday basis.

title: ExAstronaut on E. S. P.
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.During the Apollo 14 lunar expedition, I performed an extrasensoryperception experimentthe world's first in space. In it five symbolsa star, cross, circle, wavy line and square were oriented randomly in columns of 25. Four persons in the United States attempted to guess the order of the symbols. They were able to do this with success that could be duplicated by chance in one out of 3,000 experiments. This in parapsychology experiments is considered reasonably successful.

title: TWO STATEMENTS
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Jan. 8President Nixon acknowledged today that he took traditional political considerations into account in ordering a controversial 1971 increase in Federal milk price supports.

title: The Crisis in Britain
description: Prime Minister Heath, in an interview with The New York Times, projected his familiar image of inflexibility in principle and tactics that friends admirebut that many believe has contributed to the crises which have buffeted his Government.

title: WILLIAM HURLEY, 78, FORDHAM PROFESSOR
description: William P. Hurley, who retired in 1963 as professor of physics at Fordham University after 40 years on the faculty, died Monday at Union Hospital in the Bronx. He was 78 years old.

title: Bunker Ends Session
description: PANAMA, Jan. 8 (AP) Ellsworth Bunker, the United States negotiator, left Panama today after three days of talks with Panamanian officials withput announcing any agreement in the controversial Panama anal treaty.

title: An Outspoken Goldwater Shows New Political Life
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Barry Goldwater, like a Republican cloth coat rediscovered in the closet at the end of a fashion era, is back in style.

title: Amateur Sports Shift
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association voted yesterday to permit an athlete who competes in a collegiate sport as an amateur to perform as a professional in another sport. Page 27.

title: Walton Gets Only Bruise From Fall
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 (AP) Bill Walton of U.C.L.A. sustained only a hack bruise after taking a hard fall last night in a game against Washington State at Pullman, a school official said today.

title: Futures for Wheat Climb to a Record
description: March wheat futures prices rose to a record for any month's contract of $5.92 bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade. Yesterday's soaring price erased the former high of $5.78 registered by December wheat in midDecember be:ore it expired.

title: Heath Creates Department of Energy
description: LONDON, Jan. 8Prime Minister Heath moved today to deal with the country's fuel shortage by creating a new department with sweeping powers.

title: Rally for Nixon Set Today
description: CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 8 (AP)  A rally and march through downtown Concord are to be held tomorrow in support of President Nixon, according to spokesman for the Unification Church. We've gotten very good reaction in New Hampshire, better than in any other state, Michael C. Smith of Durham, who has been organizing similar rallies throughout New England, said yesterday.

title: Notes on People
description: Mrs. John L. Loeb, who was Commissioner to the United Nations and the Consular Corps in the Lindsay Administration, will serve in the same capacity for Mayor Beame. Mrs. Loeb, wife of the senior partner of Loeb Rhoades & Co., investment banking concern, is to be sworn in today. Her office serves as intermediary between city agencies and staff members of foreign missions.

title: China Says Soviet Oppresses People With Police and Camps
description: PEKING, Jan. 8China criticized the Soviet Union today for its use of secret police, labor camps and what it called armed oppression against its own people.

title: OSLO WITNESS TELLS OF SPY ROLE IN POOL
description: OSLO, Norway, Jan. (Reuters)A Jewish woman charged here with complicity in the killing of an Arab waiter described today how she had eavesdropped on a conversation in a swimming pool between the victim and his friend.

title: Advertising: Luring Companies
description: If you are not one of those allegedly upscale, wellinformed decisionmakers who read Time, Business Week, U. S. News & World Report or Forbes then, poor soul, you are completely unaware of an ad campaign designed to make believers out of nonbelievers in advertising.

title: PRESIDENT TO ASK WIDE HEALTH PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8President Nixon is expected to propose to Congress this month national health insurance program for all Americans that would cost about $37.5billion next year.

title: U.S. Businessmen Plan Higher Spending for 74
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8Businesses expect to increase their spending on new plants and equipment by 12 per cent this year, according to the latest Government survey, which was made public today.

title: City Forbids Bias in Sales of Gasoline
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs told servicestation owners yesterday that they could no longer withhold gasoline for their regular customers at the expense of other would be buyers and that if gasoline was sold in limited quantities, all customers must get the same amounts.

title: The Spotlight on a Substitute Joseph Lionel Galiber
description: The trim, 6foot, 4inch former basketball player who faced the television lights in the Blue Room at City Hall yesterday appeared only a bit less lithe and adroit than he had been more than two decades ago when he could be seen on winter evenings under the floodlights at the old Madison Square. Garden as a member of the City College Cinderella team  the only team ever to win both the National Collegiate Athletic Association and National Invitation Tournament championships in the same year.

title: Donald I. Ball, 69, Is Dead; Former Announcer on C.B.S.
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 8 Donald I. Ball, a radio announcer in the nineteenthirties and forties for the Columbia Broadcasting System, and later a program director, died yesterdayHis age was 69 and he lived at 13 Ridgecrest East.

title: Students Sample the Workaday Art World
description: Can a cloistered Bryn Mawr woman find happiness or at least a careerin the bustling New York art world? Eighteen students from the still allfemale school (plus one man, a junior. at nearby Haverford College) are in town this week to find out: touring backstage at museums, dipping into community projects, visiting galleries, firing questions at administrators and mixing after hours with artists and collectors.

title: U.S. Prosecutor Says Maryland Has Corrupt Kickback System
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 8  The Federal prosecutor in the trial of N. Dale Anderson, who succeeded Spiro T. Agnew as Baltimore County Executive, said today that many Maryland politicians received kickbacks from engineers and architects doing state business as part of an organized system of corruption.

title: A Town Shows Its Strength By Winning War on Whistle
description: CANTON, Ill., Jan. 8The town whistle blew here today. And that simple, steamy blast brought smiles to the faces of Lee Allaman and Orlene Johnson and Edward Lewis and Flor ence Thixton and Ray Walker and even old Al Sheets. It was further proofif any was needed  that the end had come for the Great Whistle War, a sudden skirmish that taught the state government, a giant corporation and much of a cheering Middle West just how strong an aroused community can be when its institutions appear to be threatened.

title: Woman Slain in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP)  The body of a woman was found this morning in a clump of bushes near the entrance to station WTOP's Broadcast House In northwest Washington. Investigating officers identified the victim as Barbara Lucille Meyersburg, 28 years old, of Washington.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: On Saturday afternoon, 600 children from 16 selected community centers, settlement houses and special schools in the New York area will attend the New York City Ballet by .invitation of the New York City Ballet Guild. The Guild is a sponsoring educational and social group for the New York City Ballet.

title: NEW PRICES OF OIL HELD TEMPORARY
description: GENEVA, Jan. 8  Finance Minister Jamshid Amouzegar of Iran said today the major oil exporting nations considered the newly raised level of prices adequate only for the next1 three months and that further price action depended on measures consumer nations took themselves.

title: Miss Zechmeister, 16, Wins 2d Slalom in Row
TV Review
description: Come back, Eve Ardenthe cool, debonair,wisecracker of yore. Our Miss Brooks is broadly paddling upstream as a wideeyed whiner in Mother of the Bride, an archly comic television exercise running 90 long minutes today at 1:30 as the A.B.C. Afternoon Playbreak.

title: Robert Baker Suit Is Dropped by U.S.; He'll Pay $40,000
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP)  Robert G. Baker agreed today to pay $40,000 into the United States Treasury in return for the dropping of a Federal suit charging him with influence peddling.

title: St. John's Routs Hofstra As Searcy Gets 22 Points
Kissinger Said, to Weigh New Trip to Middle East
MARVIN GLASS, 59, DESIGNER OF TOYS
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 8  Marvin Glass, a wellknown toy designer and the founder of Marvin Glass & Associates here, died last night at his home in suburban Evanston, of complications following a stroke he suffered last summer. He was 59 years old.

title: Concert
description: The New York State Council on the Arts announced. a commissioning program tor composers only last month and already the fruit has started dropping from the tree. At the Whitney Museum of American Art on Monday night, a remarkable young group of modernmusic specialists drawn from the Boston Symphony made its New York debut and gave the performance of Charles Schwartz's Riffs. The group, which calls itself Collage, had commissioned the piece under the council's program.

title: NASSAU TO STUDY ENERGY AND POOR
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 8Plans to help alleviate the impact of the fuel shortage, particularly as it affects almost 200,000 povertylevel residents in 11 areas of Nassau County, were outlined today by the Economic Opportunity Commission of Nassau County.

title: JAWORSKI DROPS ROLE IN 4 CASES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  In four instances in the Watergate investigations, the special prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, has withdrawn from personal involvement in cases because of possible conflicts of interest.

title: Mrs. Albert Schoolman Dies; Hadassah Board Member, 76
description: Mrs. Bertha Singer Schoolman, since 1935 a member of the board of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, died Sunday in Doctors Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived at 415 Central Park West. Her husband, Dr. Albert P. Schoolman, its former director of the Central Jewish Institute and president of the National Council of Jewish Education.

title: New A.B.A.Crisis: BigCity Market
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8  A new battlefield is shaping up in pro basketball now that the American Basketball Association's hopes for prompt merger with the National Basketball Association have died.

title: Nixon Is Reported Willing To Compromise on Tapes
Fire on Tanker Doused
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 8 (UPI) The 29man crew of the Greek oil tanker Atrotos doused a boiler fire today before it could spread to nearby engine fuel supplies or tons of Venezuelan fuel oil filling the cargo tanks. An explosion and fire left the 579foot ship disabled near the center of the Gulf of Mexico in foggy weather for about eight hours. There were no reported injuries.

title: Luvisi Emphasizes Poetic Melancholy In Schubert Pieces
description: It Is hard to believe, that it is 16 years since Lee Luvisi gave his debut recital in Carnegie Hall, making his mark as one of the more talented of Rudolf Serkin's pupils. Now that he is 36, he is a mature artist, very much his own interpreter, as he confirmed in a recital In Tully Hall on Monday night.

title: Blue Cross Bid for Rate Rise Delayed
description: A Blue Cross applicatwn for an average 10 per cent increase in premium rates, which had received the conditional approval of State Health Commissioner Hollis S. Ingraham, is now being held up, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Chinese OilOutput Figures Are a Puzzle
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 7The Chinese, whose increases in oil production are officially attributed to the revolutionary line of Chairman Mao Tsetung, appear to have given out a figure for 1973 that is Notes a staggering 40 on China per cent higher than estimatesbeing used by diplomatic analysts and the representatives of international oil companies here.

title: Peasants Trade Secretly With Vietcong
description: CAM AN, South VietnamIf a villager is enterprising and daring, he can buy a bicycle tire for about $1.40 in this tiny hamlet, carry it one mile east of here and sell it for $4.50.

title: BARON PAUL METHUEN
description: LONDON, Jan. 8 (AP)Paul Methuen, one of the most prolific painters of his generation, died yesterday in a hospital in Bath. He was 87 years old.

title: 5 Injured in Shootout and Fire in Brick Township
description: BRICK TOWNSHIP, Jan. 8 A gun battle between state troopers and local policemen and a gunman here this afternoon for almost an hour resulted in the capture of the badly injured man and injuries to four other persons.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BREWER'S FEAST With Teresa Brewer as the cultural canape, the winterspring season of cocktail concerts at Town Hall begins this evening withwhat else?music, music, music. Although audiences with memories rooted firmly in the fifties remember Miss Brewer primarily for her brassy importuning to put another nickel in, newer fans know her as a more substantial stylist with an expanded repertory that includes jazz and blues.

title: Caliber Named by Beame As Third Deputy Mayor
Cuba Indicates Interest in Talks I f U.S. Ends Economic Blockade
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 8A Cuban diplomat saps that Havana would be willing to hold political talks with Washington if the United States lifted its economic blockade of the island.

title: Market Place: Margin Credit: A Thin Cushion
description: Last week's move by the Federal Reserve to ease borrowing rules for investors at a time when the cushion of margin accounts generally was thin suggests that the Fed may use its influence again to help the ailing stock market.

title: About New York New Chapter in Council's Annals
description: The new City Council meets today for the first time, and the question may be why it bothers. It is at once the best and the worst part of city government, although over the years it has almost certainly gotten better. It now has 48 members, which makes it the largest legislative body New York has had since it was blessed with 73 aldermen in 1901, and among them are 18 Jews, 11 Italians, 7 Irish, 4 blacks, 2 Puerto Ricans and Robert Wagner Jr., who is both Irish and German.

title: Israeli Vote Official, Opening Way for Mrs. Meir
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 8 (Reuters) Official results in the Israeli parliamentary election; made public today, confirmed Premier Golda Meir's Labor group as the biggest party, with 51 of the 120 seats, a loss of five.

title: Colleges Enroll 9, 662, 763, a Rise of 3.9%
description: Women and parttime students are the fastestgrowing segment of higher education, according to a report by the United States Office of Education on enrollment in the country's colleges and universities.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 8 (UPI)A roundtheworld, 100day voyage of the liner Oriental Empress has come to an abrupt end in Hong Kong's harbor:, the vessel ran out of fuel. The liner, owned by the C.Y. Tung Group, left Los Angeles Dec. 7 with 250 passengers, and her scheduled ports of call included places in the Far East, Africa and South and Central America.

title: Title Game Foes Show Mutual Admiration
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 8The most significant matchup in Sunday's Super Bowl game here will be Jake Scott, the free safety for the Miami Dolphins, and Fran Tarkenton, the Minnesota Vikings quarterback. Scott will be deep in the Miami zone defense attempting to think right along with Tarkenton in the latter's play selection. He will try to pick the brains of the hero of his boyhood back in Athens, Ga., in the late nineteenfifties.

title: Court Says Grand Juries May Use Illegal Evidence
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 The Supreme Court ruled today that grand juries may use illegally obtained evidence as a basis for questioning witnesses without violating their constitutional rights.

title: Lines Long as City Welfare Clients Shift to U.S. Program
description: The old, the handicapped and the mentally unstable  the city's tired; its poor, its meek and not so meekhuddled in belowfreezing weather yesterday in lines that stretched as much as a block outside many of the 23 local Social Security Administration offices and wound slowly through corridors and up staircases.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NORTH ARLINGTON, Jan. 8Moses Lajterman could break a long dry spell for Montclair State. The New Jersey school has never produced a featured player in the National Football League. The Argentineborn soccerstyle kicker has been scouted for and kicking and punting abilities by a number of scouts and if the ones who know him don't draft him, Lajterman plans to do what many unemployed people doput an ad in the newspapers.

title: DISMISSAL OF FOUR IN G.S.A. IS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 The Civil Service Commission has called for the dismissal of four high officials of the General Services Administration and the suspension of four others, a commission spokesman announced today.

title: GIFT TO NEEDIEST SAVES POUNDAGE
F.C.C. PETITIONED ON PAYTV MOVIES
description: The National Association of Theater Owners has petitioned the Federal Communications Commission to prohibit Warner Communications, Inc., from showing motion pictures on cable television through pay television programs.

title: Kissinger Said to Weigh New Trip to Middle East
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8State Department officials said today that Secretary of State Kissinger might soon visit the Middle East again to help work out an agreement between Egypt and Israel on separation of their forces along the Suez Canal.

title: Gold Soars Abroad While Dollar Slips
JOSEPH C. MEEHAN
description: PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 8Joseph C. Meehan, for many years a staff member of The New York WorldTelegram and The Sun who had conducted its advertising news column, died here today. He was 69 years old and for the last several years had operated a publicrelations business here as the J. C. Meehan Company.

title: Holyoke Backs Fluoride
description: HOLYOKE, Mass., Jan. (AP)The Board of Health has voted to direct the water department to continue the use of fluoride in the city water supply.

title: Subterranean Politics
description: PARISPossibly the most interest. ing shift in world balances this decade will eventually be seen not as the ending of two dominant military blocs and the start of a vaguely perceived pentagonal grouping  the United States, Russia, the European Community, China and Japanbut as the emergence of the nonaligned underdeveloped lands as an effective global force.

title: Amateur Sports Shift
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association voted yesterday to permit an athlete who competes in a collegiate sport as an amateur to perform as a professional in another sport. Page 27.

title: Inept Islanders Bow to Kings, 31, Before 11,747 Fans
JUDGE'S AIDE FACES PERJURY CHARGES
description: The law secretary of State Supreme Court Justice Albert H. Bosch has been indicted for perjury for denying he had discussed the payment of a $2,500 bribe in return for his $24,000ayear post, the office of Special State Prosecutor Maurice H. Nadjari announced yesterday.

title: Suburban Family Sets Sail for Better Life in the Caribbean
description: COS COB, Conn., Jan. 8Sy and Stephanie Rosenfeld, their daughter and their dog set sail, here today for the Caribbean aboard a 35foot racing sloop they bought with the proceeds from the sale of their suburban home and all its furnishings.

title: SHOP TALK It's Decadence but It Sells
description: That canopied lute player's cage on Bloomingdale's fifth floor is not exactly what everyone craves for the living room. But it is the sort of Britishmade fantasy furnishing from a collection by Antony Redmile that has spelled brisk business at the store.

title: In Croton, the Library Is the Place to Check Before Shopping
description: CROTONONHUDSON, N.Y. For seven years now, Croton's two supermarkets have been eyeing one other across a twolane strip of asphalt like a couple of old gunfighters. &

title: People and Business
description: Morton Siegenfeld, 49, has been named president of the Franklin Simon chain of women's and children's specialty stores, succeeding Mortimer L. Janis, who died Dec. 14.

title: NEWSPAPERS URGING CONTROL EXEMPTION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) The newspaper industry has asked the Cost of Living Council to exempt it completely from Government wageprice controls.

title: First Westchester Merger Is. Cleared
description: The New York State Banking Department announced yesterday it had approved the proposed merger of the First Westchester National Bank of New Rochelle into Barclays Bank of New York.

title: Austrian Editor Denounced By Moscow for Criticisms
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 8The Soviet Union today denounced the editor of the stateowned Austrian radio and television.

title: Excerpts From Statement on the Milk Pricing Case Released by the White House
PERGAMON HOLDERS COMPARE 2 OFFERS
description: LONDON, Jan. 8The battle for control of Pergamon Press,! Ltd., escalated today as the company's institutional shareholders disclosed that they were considering separate pro1 posals from the Reliance Group and Robert Maxwell, Pergamon's former chairman.

title: MURDER TRIAL OF 5 MIGHT BE SHIFTED
description: After a lunch hour of furious !brief and petition writing by defense lawyers, the case of five men accused of killing two police officers at a housing project here nearly three years ago was moved, at least temporarily, from State Supreme Court to Federal Court.

title: Why Not Add Fun to a Child's Winter Sniffles?
description: As the winter days stretch ahead, threaded through with sniffles and ague, and January threatens to last forever, mothers of homebound children might appreciate knowing a few ways to brighten the time. A number of books that have come out recently might do just that.

title: JUDGE ELICITING VIEWS ON INDIANS
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 8Selection of a jury to try the Indian leaders of last year's armed insurrection at Wounded Knee, S.D., began here today with the judge asking prospective jurors such questions as:

title: U.S. JUDGE ORDERS REFORM AT TOMBS
description: Significant changes in. dismal conditions at the Manhattan House of Detention for Men were ordered yesterday by Judge MorrisE. Lasker in Federal District Court here.

title: New Darkness Creates Minicrises in Suburbs
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. L, Jan. 8Bob Fitzpatrick blew his fuse yesterday, a 30 ampere fuse. He did it while saving energy.

title: Unusual High Tides Bring No Floods Here
description: Despite rare astronomical conditions that caused higher than normal tides, no serious flooding was reported yesterday along the New York, New Jersey or Connecticut coasts.

title: Mrs. Thelma Thomas Dies; Survivor of Titanic Sinking
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Jan. 8 (AP)Mrs. Thelma Thomas, a survivor of the 1912 sinking of the Titanic, died Monday at a nursing home. She was 78 years old.

title: Calley and That Old Bitterness
description: When the United. States Court of Military Appeals recently upheld the conviction of William L. Calley Jr. for the murder of at least 22 Vietnamese civilians at My Lai, my old bitterness and disgust were stirred,

title: P.U.C. Is Challenged on Order Letting Bell Pass Costs Along
description: TRENTON, Jan. 8  Lawyers representing the public challenged today the legality of Public Utilities Commission order allowing the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company to pass increased operating costs directly on to consumers without a formal rate hearing.

title: U.S. IS URGING DELAY IN EXPORT OF WHEAT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) Wheat exporters are being quietly urged to delay foreign deliveries wherever possible to conserve the dwindling United States supply of bread grain until a new harvest is ready next summer, the Agriculture Department disclosed today.

title: NEWSMEN'S NOTICE OF A RAID DECRIED
description: A Federal judge issued stern warning yesterday to the United States. Attorney and Federal law enforcement officials here against any repetition of a case last spring in which onthespot news coverage was permitted of a roundup of suspected narcotics dealers.

title: Maskie Sees Chance Of Presidential Race
description: MILLINOCKET, Me., Jan. (AP)  Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, says he is available to run again for the Presidency if somebody wants him.

title: Business Briefs
description: Sohio to Convert Ohio Refinery

title: Contract Awards
description: The Taiwan Railway Administration has awarded contracts to the General Electric Company and to the General Electric Company of England for a fiveyear electrification program. The United States contract would be worth more than $70million and the British more than $81million. Included in the awards are locomotives, rails, substations, communications and overhead power !As.

title: Tanaka Assures Manila on Trade Reins
description: MANILA, Jan. 8Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan told the Philippines today that the Japanese Government would exercise administrative guidance over Japanese businesses here and elsewhere in Southeast Asia to harmonize them with the needs and ways of their, host nations.

title: TWO STATEMENTS
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Jan. 8President Nixon acknowledged today that he took traditional political considerations into account in ordering a controversial 1971 increase in Federal milk price supports.

title: Sally Quinn May Be Out of TV Anchor Role
description: Sally Quinn, who last summer received the greatest publicity buildup for a new television personality,since Batman, is with considerably less ceremony apparently being relieved of her coanchor duties on The C.B.S. Morning News. Her association with the program is expected to continue, but in another capacity.

title: CITY FORBIDS BIAS IN GASOLINE SALES
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs told servicestation owners yesterday that they could no longer withhold gasoline for their regular customers at the expense of other wouldbe buyers and that if gasoline was sold in limited quantities, all customers must get the same amounts.

title: Nixon Is Reported Willing To Compromise on Tapes
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., Jan. 8President Nixon may be willing to accept a limited compromise with the Senate Watergate committee on the release of documents and tape recordings despite the strong position he took last week, against the panel's subpoena, White House officials said today.

title: Mother and Two Children Die in Brooklyn Fire
description: Despite the attempts of three firemen to rescue them, a Brooklyn woman and her two small children died early yesterday after a suspicious twoalarm fire swept the upper three floors of a fourstory tenement at 880 Greene Avenue in the Bushwick section.

title: Bridge: Insoluble Problem Is Posed In Rebidding FourFive Hand
description: A permanent problem in standard bidding methods isthe moderate fourfive hand, with a fourcard suit just outranking a fivecard suit.

title: Cahill Urges State Income Tax In Last Message to Legislature
description: TRENTON, Jan. 8Governor, Cahill urged the new Democratic legislative majority that took office here today to approve a state income tax as part of a sweeping reformation of what he described as New Jersey's unjust and regressive revenue system.

title: Alleghany Widening Scope
description: The Alleghany Corporation is assuming a greater interest in the shoe machinery business through its increased acquisition of stock in the USM Corporation, formerly the United Shoe Machinery corporation, Alleghany acknowledged yesterday that its holdings in USM stock had climbed to 900,500 shares, or about 22 per cent, from about 5 per cent held a year and a half ago.

title: Grant's Stand Draws Rozelle Fine Threat
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 8  Bud Grant, the Minnesota coach, said today he had been threatened with a fine by Commissioner Pete Rozelle should he continue to complain about the inadequacy of the Viking practice facili. ties here.

title: Court Says Grand Juries May Use Illegal Evidence
New Darkness Creates Minicrises in Suburbs
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan, 8Bob Fitzpatrick blewhis fuse yesterday, a 30 ampere fuse. He did it while saving energy.

title: 6 Dolphins, 3 Vikings On AllPro
description: The Miami Dolphins took six places and the Minnesota Vikings three of the 23 positions on the National Football League AllPro squad announced yesterday by The Associated Press.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Excerpts From the White House Statement Involving I.T.T. and the Administration
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  Following are excerpts from a statement concerning the International Telephone and Telegraph Company antitrust case as released today by the White House:

title: Robert Hardy Jr. Weds Anne Bonney
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Jan. 8Miss Anne Elliott Bonney, daughter of Mr.,and Mrs. John Lawrence Vick Bonney Jr. of Columbus, Ohio, was married here at noon today to Robert Lamar Hardy Jr., son of Mr. Hardy of Dallas and Mrs. Fitzgerald Salter Hudson of Durham and Southern Pines, N. C., and Northeast Harbor, Me. The ceremony at the Hillsboro Club was performed by Canon H. Lyttleton Zimmerman of St. MartinintheField Episcopal Church.

title: Two Men Get 25 Years Each In Shooting of a Mail Guard
description: Two Washington, D. C., men who had pleaded guilty to seconddegree murder in the shooting of a United States mail guard were sentenced yesterday to serve 25 years in prison.

title: Laird Says He Favors Some Kind of Amnesty
description: MADISON, Wis., Jan. 8 (UPI)  Former Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird says he favors a limited amnesty for Americans who broke the draft laws during the Vietnam war.

title: President and Rebozo Take 2d Long Drive
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 8 (UPI)For the second time in two days, President Nixon and his friend, Charles G. Rebozo, took to Southern California freeways today for a long drive in the rain.

title: Seoul Imposes Stiff Curbs On Critics of Constitution
CONTINUING FLOAT OF DOLLAR URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8A Congressional subcommittee urged unanimously today that the international exchange rate of the dollar be allowed to continue to float for the foreseeable future.

title: Sweden Rations Gasoline and Cuts Home Heating Oil by 25%
description: STOCKHOLM, Jan. 8 (AP)Sweden today began more than seven weeks of rationing oil and gasoline. Many service sta, tions ran out the first morning.!

title: Reform in Albany?
description: What has been described as the second best legislature in the country convenes in Albany today for a session that has the potential of making it number one.

title: Tax Official Is Silent on Report Of Decision on Nixon's Returns
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8An official of the Internal Revenue Service would not confirm or deny tonight a report that the agency had decided that President Nixon should have paid a capital gains tax on a sale of some land in California in 1970.

title: GERMANS LIFT ORDER TO EXPEL AMERICAN
description: BONN, Jan. 8West German authorities have lifted an expulsion order against an American woman in Heidelberg who had been ordered to leave the country for working on a newspaper opposed to the United States Army.

title: PRIESTS CENSURE AIRED BY VATICAN
description: ROME, Jan. 8A priest who ministers to the shackdwellers of the slum belt that rings Rome has charged in an open letter that Pope Paul VI's own diocese is neglecting its poor.1

title: WrightHargreaves Denies Reactivation of Gold Mines
description: WrightHargreaves Mines, Ltd., said yesterday; that it knew of no basis for reports, published in The New York Times on Tuesday and Wednesday, that it had reactivated and was operating gold mines in the Noranda area of Quebec.

title: Lunch Payments Raised
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz today increased the payments in the National School Lunch program by onehalf cent for each lunch. He also increased the subsidies for free and reduced lunches by 2.25 cents.

title: FOOD PRICES RISE 0.7% IN A WEEK
description: For the second week in a row, record costs were reported yesterday for the 38item Market Basket survey of food for a family of four as monitored by the City Department of Consumer Affairs. rise of

title: New Pro Rule Has Its Cons
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's action permitting a student to turn professional in one sport but retain his amateur status in others could bar many athletes from Olympic and other international amateur competitionand not only the athletes who play professionally.

title: Hopes for National Health Plan Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 Congressional health leaders said today that the Nixon Administration, by broadening its tatIonal health insurance proposal, had enhanced the chances for passage of a nationwide program in the next year or two.

title: FOSTER WHEELER IS SEEKING RAYGO
description: The Foster Wheeler Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire Raygo, Inc., a producer of construction and specialized heavy lift equipment, through an exchange of stock. Terms of the proposed transac tion were not disclosed. The agreement is tentative and subject to approval of the, boards of directors of both companies and Raygo shareholders.

title: Wife Slayer Gets Life
description: MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich., Jan. 9 (UPI)  A father of five was sentenced yesterday to life in prison for beating his wife to death with a baseball bat. The defendant, Jimmy W. McDonald, 36 years old, said that he had attacked his wife, Imogene, 34, and his five children, aged 9 to 17, to save them from Satan.

title: Big Powers Will Seek to Narrow Gap Between Israel and Egypt
description: GENEVA, Jan. 9Israeli and Egyptian generals today suspended their deadlocked military talks for six days to allow time for their Governments to make new political decisions.

title: BONN FINDS A GAIN IN GASOLINE FLOW Rise in Supply Next Month Over Last February Seen Driving Curb Lifted
description: BONN, Jan. 9The Government released figures today indicating that more gasoline would be available in West Germany next month than at the same time last year. It also decided that a weekend driving ban to save gasoline was no longer necessary.

title: ... Illuminating Nothing
description: The considerably shorter statement on the I.T.T. case is even more opaque and incomplete. The President contends that when he instructed Richard Kleindienst, the then Deputy Attorney General, not to appeal the I.T.T. antitrust case to the Supreme Court, he was doing nothing more than establishing a broad general policy that large American companies ought not to be sued simply because of their size.

title: FUEL COSTS RAISE CON ED BILLS $1.A6
description: ALBANY, Jan. 9The Consolidated Edison Company said today it had raised its average electric bill by $1.46 a month since Oct. 1 because of higher fuel costs.

title: Test With Peru
description: By nationalizing the giant Cerro de Pasco Corporation, Peru's military Government has set up a major new test for its relations with the United States, which had improved considerably in recent months. It is a test that will be watched with great interest throughout Latin America and in other areas where governments are acting to take control over basic industries and particularly their natural resources.

title: New Yorker Listed as Dead
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI)  The Defense Department announced today that Maj. Charles C. Winston 3d of Hartsdale, N.Y., was among five servicemen previously listed as missing in Indochina who have now been declared dead as a result of hostile action. The number missing at the time of the ceasefire last January who have since been declared dead is 204.

title: Weisl and 13 Explore City Arts Role
description: A group of prominent people in the arts, most of them officials of major New York foundations, met yesterday with Edwin L. Weisl Jr., the city's Administrator of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, to discuss methods of improving the city's policy toward cultural institutions. Participants emphasized that the meeting was exploratory and preliminary, but might lead to a more formal approach, perhaps to a foundation, financed study of the problems of the arts in the city that could then be presented to Mayor Beame.

title: COURT BACKS SUIT TO VOID TAX SETUP
description: TRENTON, Jan. 9  The Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled today that a challenge to the system of supporting public assistance programs and the court system on a countybycounty basis had merit and should go to trial.

title: Spilling Wine Used to Be Part of the Fun
description: Leonardo Tredanari raised a glass and said: You know, at this moment my mother would tense up, because she knew what was coming. She always set a new tablecloth, and my father would hold up his glass and pour it on the table. He told everybody that eating was for fun, and now they could relax.

title: OREGON TO LIMIT GAS SALE DATES Dealers Back Governor on Schedule for Motorists
description: SALEM, Ore., Jan. 9Service station operators approved a statewide plan last night to limit the days during which gasoline can be sold to motorists, who have formed long lines at gasoline stations in recent weeks.

title: Utica Mayor Limits Use Of City Garages by Aides
description: UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 9 (AP)Mayor Edward A. Hanna had ordered a crackdown on unauthorized use of the public works garages by city em ployes.

title: Milk Price White Paper Seems to Contradict Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  Thela White House explanation dim President Nixon's decision tole raise milk price supports ap parently contradicts a recent declaration by Mr. Nixon that he refused all information about campaign contributions prior to the 1972 election.

title: Court Orders School Plan
description: BOSTON, Jan. 9 (AP)  The Springfield School Committee was ordered today to submit a plan immediately for iinplemen. tation of the state's racial imbalance law, which is scheduled to go into effect by September. The order came at a hearing before Supreme Judicial Court J4dge Francis J. Quirico.

title: Text of Governor Wilson's First State of the State Message to the Legislature
description: ALBANY, lan. 9Following is the text of Governor Wilson's first message to the State Legislature:

title: The Doubts Linger, But the Longhairs Are Being Trimmed
description: They approach the hair stylist's chair with trepidation. Most of them are tired of fussing with long hair, but prefer to have it cut off in easy stages. Once done, they worry about whether they look better or worse, younger or older. And often whether the loves in their lives will approve. Who, women? No, men. In the trendsetting barber shops around town, short hair is back. It's not a return to the bootcamp scalping of the nineteenforties and fifties, but rather like the preBeatles, early sixties. Ironically enough, the short hair movement is being spearheaded by the generation that a few years ago defied teachers and parents to grow flowing locks. Now in their twenties, they pronounce that long hair is for the old, the creeps and the squares.

title: U.S.Women Second, 9th In World Ski
description: LES GETS, France, Jan. 9 UPI)  The United States women's ski team capped twoday show of strength today by taking second and ninth places in the World Cup giant slalom.

title: TEXAS CONSIDERING CHARTER REVISIONS
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 9  If Texas does not get a new, modern and brief constitution from the convention that opened here yesterday, it will not be for lack of all the knowhow that other states have applied to the effort.

title: Cambodia Opens Drive to Avert Insurgent Attach on Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 9 (AP)  Government troops opened a counteroffensive today aimed at trapping rebel forces who were believed to be gathering for an attack on Phnom Penh or its airport, according to reports from the field.

title: Ivies Are Not in League With New N. C. A. A. Rules
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. Recruiting and scholarship regulations adopted by the National Collegiate Athletic Association posed special problems today for the Ivy Leagueapparently.

title: U.S. ACTS TO RESCUE 159 WIRETAP CASES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. (UPI)The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court yesterday to rescue 159 gambling and narcotics cases threatened by administrative procedures used to obtain wiretap evidence.

title: Heath's Energizer
description: LONDON, Jan. 9Although little light is shed on the inner workings of the British Government, the role of Lord Carrington over the last four years has emerged quite clearly. He is per haps the closest and most trusted adviser to Prime Minister Heath, and merely to describe him as the Minister of Defense, the post he has now left, is to suggest that one battleship is the whole navy. For the influence of Lord Carrington, who took up his post today as head of the Department of Energy, extends far beyond any job he holds.

title: TV Review
description: Married Is Better, insisted an hourlong special starring Bill Bixby and Sandy Duncan last night over the National Broadcasting Company. Some viewers, married or single, may have wanted little sturdier, less cute proof.

title: Data Are Questioned
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9The American Petroleum Institute reported today another substantial drop in refineries stocks of crude oil as criticism mounted that the Government was wholly dependent on unverified industry data for information essential to policymaking.

title: People in Sports: Virdon Hires An Old Associate as Coach
description: Bill Virdon, the Yankees newly appointed manager, completed his coaching staff yesterday by naming Mel Wright as bullpen coach. Wright, 45 years old, was pitching coach under Virdon at Pittsburgh last season and had signed to coach next year with the Chicago Cubs, but he was released so he could join Virdon. Along with Emil Tellinger, a Yankee farmhand, and Virdon, a teammate at iBnghamton, Wright was traded by the Yanks to the St. Louis Cardinals for Enos Slaughter in 1953. He had a 24 wonlost record in four seasons as a reliever with the Cardinals and Cubs.

title: Reasons Are a Mystery
description: The New York metropolitan area is undoubtedly the urban center plagued most severely by the national gasoline crisis, but nobody seems to know why.

title: Governor's NonMessage
description: In sharp contrast to his strongwilled predecessor, Governor Wilson presented a State of the State Message the Legislature yesterday that was not only predominantly noncontroversialit was practically a nonmessage.

title: 2 of Governor's Sisters Injured In Car Crash on Way to Albany
description: Two sisters of Governor Wilson traveling to Albany to hear him make his first State of the State address were among at least eight persons injured in a series of vehicular accidents that occurred in a snowstorm on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway near Kingston yesterday.

title: Contract Awards
description: Air Products & Chemicals, Inc., said yesterday it had been awarded multimillion dollar contracts by Pertamina, the Indonesian state oil and gas enterprise. The contracts call for Air Products to supply its patented MCR process and coilwound liquefied natural gas heat exchangers for what is expected to be the largest baseload LNG project ever undertaken at a total cost of more than $3billion.

title: Kissinger Off to Mideast TonightNixon Calls Session on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  Secretary of State Kissinger leaves tomorrow night for talks in Egypt and Israel to hell bring about an agreement for the separation of Israeli and Egyptian forces near the Sues Canal.

title: EXPORTING LANDS FREEZE OIL PRICES
description: GENEVA, Jan. 9Major oil exporting nations, after quadrupling their prices in the last three months, today promised stability over the next quarter but warned that future price decisions hinged on the industrial countries ability to control both inflation and the profits of oil companies.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: A Fish Bounty
description: BUXTON, N. C.  Driving along the edge of the surf from Buxton to Frisco, the fog was so thick one could scarcely see a hundred yards, but our guide, Ken Lauer, found the spot he wanted a channel that cut between the beach and an offshore bar  and in a matter of minutes we were taking summer flounder, or fluke, on nearly every cast.

title: Chesimard Jury Selection Delayed Because of Snow
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Jan. 9 (UPI)  Jury selection in the murder trial of Joanne Chesimard and Clark E. Squire, reputed members of the Black Liberation Army, did not resume as scheduled today. Two prospective jurors failed to reach the courthouse becausel of the snowstorm.

title: WILSON'S SPEECH CALLS MODERATION HIS PRINCIPAL AIM
description: ALBANY, Jan. 9Emphasizing the moderate, middle way, Governor Wilson delivered his first message to the Legislature today and promised there would be no extravagant ventures by the state in this time of inflation and fuel shortage.

title: 23 City Food Spots Listed as Violators Of the Health Code
OneYear Bills Rise At Sale by Treasury
Household Finance Sets $54Million As Unit Writedown
description: The Household Finance Corporation announced yesterday that it would write down a total of about $54million against its 1973 income, representing losses and expenses incurred in the disposition of E Z Haul, a division of National Car Rental System, Inc. In addition, a writedown of $15million will be made for certain other assets.

title: Art Collection Yields $ 1.7Million for Back Taxes
description: Government attorneys obtained more than $1.7million yesterday as payment of 1968 income taxes owed by a Connecticut financier whose art collection was seized to pay tax collectors and creditors.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES BAN ON PATIENTS
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., Jan. 9Two civil liberties groups today challenged the recent Long Beach ordinance banning released state mental patients from this city's adult homes.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 9 (AP)Ann Kiyomura, the junior Wimbledon champion from San Mateo, Calif., was the only American left in the Benson and Hedges open tennis tournament after today's action. Miss Kiyomura beat Lindsay Beaven of England, 76, 63, but Bill Brown, Larry Parker and Kathy Braun were sidelined at the end of the third day of play.

title: Burke Names Deputy
description: Corporation Counsel Adrian P. Burke yesterday announced the appointment of Stanley Buchsbaum, a career civil servant and lawyer, as first deputy corporation counsel. Mr. Buchsbaum, 62 years old, has served as chief of the department's appeals division since 1969.

title: Poll Finds Oil Crisis Laid to Government And Big Companies
description: Public blame for the nation's energy crisis rests largely on the Federal Government and the oil companies, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: FoodPricesHereUp By 0.7% in a Week; 5Week Rise Is 5%
description: For the second week in a row, record costs were reported yesterday for the 38item market basket survey of food for a family of four as monitored by the City Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: U.S. to Continue Search For Missing in Indochina
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)  The Pentagon says the attempt to locate more than 1,100 United States servicemen missing in Indochina will continue, despite a temporary halt after an attack last month on a helicopter engaged in the search.

title: Nets Rout Tams to Be No. 1 Alone
Arnsparger Seems Sure for Giants Job
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 9 More and more it appeared today that Bill Arnsparger would become the next coach of the New York Giants.

title: Drug Charge Suspect Tied To Theft From Faneuil Hall
description: PLYMOUTH, Mass., Jan. (AP)Plymouth County District Attorney Stanley Littlefield says a former steeplejack arrested on drug charges may be able too shed some light on the recent theft of the historic grasshopper weather vane from atop Boston's Faneuil Hall.

title: Founder of Pergamon Offering 25 Cents a Share in Control Bid
description: LONDON, Jan. 9  Robert Maxwell, founder and former chairman of Pergamon Press, Ltd., formally made a bid today to resume control of the publishing company, which has been embroiled in controversy for more than three years.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)  The Cost of Living Council announced today it was approving previously delayed price increases for the tire industry averaging about 3.3 per cent over current prices.

title: Reporter Gains in Fight to Avoid Jail
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9Wil!ment liam Farr, a reporter who was jailed in 1972 for refusing to! identify his news sources, won new hope of eventually avoiding an indefinite sentence for contempt of court.

title: FUEL COSTS RAISE CON ED BILLS $1.46
description: ALBANY, Jan. 9The Consolidated Edison Company said today it had raised its average monthly electric bill by $1.46 since Oct. 1 because of higher fuel costs.

title: Reasons Are a Mystery
description: The New York metropolitan area is undoubtedly the urban center plagued most severely by the national gasoline crisis, but nobody seems to know why.

title: People and Business
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:; President Nixon will not resign from office unless new evidence is uncovered which would prove him guilty. For as it stands now, the evidence held against him is insufficient.

title: Buffalo Patrolman Is Facing Charges of Hitting Civilian
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 9 (UPI)A city patrolman accused of striking a man during an argument last month has had eight departmental charges filed against him.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The power of the civil courts to throw out debtcollection cases en masse when the creditor is shown to be engaging in certain fraudulent practices has been officially confidmed by a state law that went into effect Jan. 1.

title: IRAN, CHARGING PLOT, DOOMS 7, JAILS 5
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 9 (UPI) A military tribunal tonight sentenced seven persons to death for plotting to assassinate Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi and to kidnap three members of the royal family.

title: ESTIMATE BOARD A BEAMS PRIORITY
description: Mayor Beame, in a stand directly opposed to that of his predecessor, said yesterday that he intended to take personal interest in the activities of the Board of Estimate and to attend sessions as frelquently as he can.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
Volkswagen Increases Sales
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany Jan. 9 (AP)  The giant; Volkswagen group. West Germany's largest automobile producer, increased its worldwide sales in 1973 about 5 per cent to some 2.3 million vehicles. a preliminary company report, said today. Sales rose io about, $6.1billion from $5 7billion in 1972, the report said.

title: Trio of Wilson, Duryea and Anderson Expected to Call Tune on Legislation
description: ALBANY, Jan, 9For the first time in 15 years, legislative initiatives will apparently he more in the hands of a troikaGovernor Wilson, Perry B. Duryea, the Assembly Speaker, and Warren M. Anderson, the Senate majority leaderrather than be dominated by the overwhelming power Nelson A. Rockefeller wielded as Governor.

title: U.S.Women Second, 9th In World Ski
description: LES GETS, France, Jan. 9 UPI)  The United States women's ski team capped a twoday show of strength today by taking second and ninth places in the World Cup giant slalom.

title: 29 Are Believed Killed In Colombian Air Crash
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Thursday, Jan. 10 (Reuters)  A Colombian airliner with 29 persons aboard crashed in mountainous jungle territory south of here last night. First reports indicated that all aboard had been killed.

title: Chess:
Dave Anderson
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 9 In the days before the Super Bowl, the game is never the thing. Thankfully. Sunday afternoon is time enough for the blitz and the bomb and the other subtleties of strategy. Until then the subtleties of people are more prevalent. And more fun. Such as the evening when Joe Namath, his right hand holding glass of scotch instead of a football or even a blonde, proclaimed, We're gonna win, I guarantee you. Or When George Allen glared at a multitude of newsmen and sneered, You're making me be late Tor a meeting for the first time in my coaching career. No Sports wonder the Washington Redskins lost last year. But prophecy and distractions, of Allen called them, are no longer popular. The Times In the humidity of Houston this week the important topics are sparrows and mothers. Bud Grant, annoyance defrosting his usual icy manner as the coach of the Minnesota Vikings, displayed two sparrows in the shower as evidence of his team's belowstandard dressing room facilities for practice sessions. Among the Miami Dolphins the bachelors complained why, if the married players wives had been transported and lodged as guests of the front office, their mothers shouldn't deserve similar invitations. As it developed, the sparrows won't have to pay for a Super Bowl ticket, but the mothers will. And Bud Grant may have to pay something else.

title: DR. DAVID M'CABE OF PRINCETON DIES
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 9Dr. David Aloysius McCabe, Joseph D. Green 1895 Professor of Economics Emeritus at Princeton University, died last night at his home here at 371 Franklin Avenue. He was 90 years old.

title: DR. ARNOLD ARBEIT, A C.U.N.Y ARCHITECT
description: Dr. Arnold A. Arbeit, former director of college programing services at the City University of New York and member of the City College architectural faculty, died Tuesday at his home, 116 Fox Meadow Road, in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 62 years old.

title: Jackson Has Two Requests for Finley: Return of Williams, $140,000 Salary
description: The players who won the last two World Series for the Oakland A's want Dick Williams back as manager, and Reggie Jackson said yesterday that he would be their ringleader.

title: Hughes's Blank Checks
description: An agent for Howard R. Hughes gave the Nixon reelection committee signed blank checks, and, Sally Harmony, G. Gordon Liddy's secretary, filled in the amounts, according to her sworn testimony revealed yesterday. Details, Page 22.

title: Swedish Bank Trial Opens
