description: Eleven persons have been indicted in connection with alleged multimilliondollar loansharking ring in Manhattan's garment area whose profits are said to have gone toward the buying and selling of stolen property and smuggled and jacked cigarettes.

title: Lombardi Award Is Given to Hicks
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 10 (AP)Ohio State's offensive tackle, John Hicks, the Heisman Trophy runnerup and the Outland Trophy winner, received the fourth Vince Lombardi award tonight as the top collegiate lineman in the nation.

title: Potluck on Potholes
description: The war against potholes is one the city can't win for losing. Just when officials were congratulating themselves on beginning to catch up with the craters left by last month's disastrous ice storm, two new blankets snow, slush, ice and salt coming in quick succession threaten to leave thousands of new tiretearing, passengerjolting holes in metropolitan streets as their legacy.

title: Manhattan Life Corp. Set
description: The Manhattan Life Insurance Company said yesterday lit was forming a holding company to be known as the Manhattan Life Corporation as the first step in a new acquisition program. Thomas E. Lovejoy, board chairman, said the company was in the market for a new life insurer to offer lowercost coverage. He added that Manhattan Life had no intention of buying anything not related to the life insurance business.

title: At the Furniture Show, There's Little NewExcept the Mood
description: CHICAGO  It seemed that almost, everyone was telling the same joke at the International Home Furnishingg Market here this week. The joke: They've found a great new substitute for plastic  they call it wood.

title: Casserole: An Old Favorite
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: Fire Kills Four Children
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 10 (AP)Flames swept through a housing project town house last night and killed the four children of Mrs. Dale M. Whittemore, 16 months after her only other child was killed by a car. The dead were identified as Earl Whittemore, 4 years old; Terri Ann, 7; Ronald, 10; and Cindy, 13.

title: Probity in City Hall..
description: The problem of probity in politics that has shaken the foundations of government at all levels since the first Watergate disclosures is having jarring repercussions in City Hall and the State Capitol at Albany.

title: Big Snow Has Ski Area Operators Jumping
description: Major snowfalls that lasted for the better part of two days helped put almost the entire Northeast ski country in top condition yesterday. From Jay Peak, at Vermont's rooftop to the Poconos in Pennsylvania, the word from ski operators was at least good to excellent.

title: Notes on People
description: Senator John C. Stennis of Mississippi, who was critically wounded during a robbery outside his Washington home almost a year ago, said yesterday that his health is good with no complications and that he definitely would be a candidate for reelec. tion in 1976.

title: Sabres Trounce Rangers
LIBERTIES UNION TO BACK DURYEA
description: ALBANY, Jan, 10The New York Civil Liberties Union intends to enter the election conspiracy case of Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea and argue that the charges against him should be dismissed because they are unconstitutional.

title: 1974: The Year of the Crossed Fingers
description: The 64th National Boat Show, which opens tomorrow at 10 A.M., has its fingers crossed. So does nearly everybody connected with the annual spectacle at the Coliseum. When livelihood depends on pleasure, as boating normally does, and a national squeeze comes along, such as the shortage of gasoline, the result is almost inevitable: cut pleasure first.

title: Islanders 83 Losers In Montreal
Duryea for Letting a Sleeping Tax Surcharge Lie
description: ALBANY, Jan, 10Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea will introduce on Monday a bill to suspend the state's 2.5 per cent incometax surcharge for another year, his office announced Itoday.

title: Sinatra Tourney Set
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif Jan. 10 (UPI)The third annual Frank Sinatra AllAmericans golf tournament has been scheduled at the Canyon Country Club on Feb. 5. The 18hole event pairs one allAmerica golfer with three amateurs in bestball competition. Last year the tournament netted $30,062 for the Tony Lema scholarship fund.

title: TV:Dirty Sally, New Series by Gunsmoke Team
description: In the same week that British commercial television is supplying American audiences with the remarkably imaginative Upstairs, Downstairs on public TV, the Columbia Broadcasting System. is laying a remarkably unimaginative new series called Dirty Sally on its viewers. The comparison may be invidious, but it is hardly resistible.

title: SIMON WILL AUDIT PRICE AND SUPPLY OF ALL REFINERS
Business Briefs
description: State savings banks reported yesterday that savers 1973 withdrew $619million more than they deposited. The Savings Bank Association of New York State said the amount equaled 1.2 per cent of the total they had in their accounts. The drain, according to Ira 0. Scott Jr., executive vice president of the state group, was not nearly severe as in 1969, when the net outflow reached $924million, or 2.4 per cent of deposits. It reversed, however, the trend of 1971 and 1972 when the savings banks reported net infows of $3billion and $2.7billion.

title: In Iowa, Debate on Impeachment
description: SPIRIT LAKE, Iowa, Jan. 10 Until they prove he's a criminal, I'm going on buying him, said Orren Olson. But they should either impeach him or get off his back, and if Wiley decides, on the evidence, that. he ought to be impeached, then we'll support Wiley in that.

title: Red Smith Fine Irish Hand of Walter O'Malley
description: Eight months after the San Diego Padres were sold for the first time, the brightest minds in the National League have decided for the fourth or fifth time that they can't decide anythingwhether the Padres should play the :374 season, where they should play if at all, what city they should represent if any, who's going to own them if they're owned. It should not be inferred, however, that these men are incapable of making up their minds. They have decided unequivocally that C. Arnholt Smith was mistaken when he advised them recently that he had sold the team to Mrs. Marjorie Lindheimer Everett and friends.

title: Victim in Triple MistakenIdentity Case Absolved After 15 Months
description: A 19yearold high school honor student was officially cleared of robbery yesterday as the story of his nightmarish entanglement in a case of triple mistaken identity was disclosed in court.

title: Reactor Forces Power Cut
description: RICHLAND, Wash.; Jan. 10 (UPI)  Technical problems shut down the Hanford nuclear reactor last night, forcing a cut of 340,000 kilowatts to some industrial customers. Technicians had problems restarting the reactor earlier this week after it had been shut down for refueling and maintenance since Dec. 24.

title: LOEWS NET GAINS 3.5% IN QUARTER
description: An increase of 39 per cent in securities gains enabled the Loews Corporation to show 3.5 per cent gain in net income for the first fiscal quarter{ ended Nov. 30, according to the results reported to stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting here. Directors also voted to raise the quarterly dividend to 30 cents from 29 cents a share, payable Feb. 1 to holders of record Jan. 21.

title: Snowstorm, Rain and Drizzle Leave City Awash With Slush
description: The full spectrum of a bleak, midwinter stormsnow, sleet, freezing rain and a cold, gray drizzlebuffeted the metropolitan area yesterday, delaying rail and masstransit commuters and snarling traffic on icily hazardous highways.

title: Black Group Finds Errors in Displays In History Museum
description: A group of black students and educators has accused the', History of misrepresenting African history and asked that a black curator be hired to supervise all activities and presentations of African history and,. aiture.

title: Colt Industries Shows Record Earnings in Quarter
With Beame Wielding Gavel, Board Disposes of 186 Issues
description: The Board of Estimate, with City Planning Commission will Mayor Beame wielding the be required for any nursing gavel for the first time, dis home. In addition, a special posed of an 186item calendar permit will be required for conin one hour and 12 minutes struction of new nonmedical yesterday, facilities for the elderly any

title: IRAN DUE TO BUY 30 JET FIGHTERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Iran has reportedly accepted a United States offer to sell 30 Grumman F14A fighters at a total cost of $900million, including spare parts.

title: Decade's Warnings Fail to Cut Smoking
description: Ten years ago today, the Surgeon General of the Public Health Service issued a momentous report citing cigarette smoking as a major hazard to life and health. Yet, on the anniversary of that historic, 387page document, cigarette sales are at a record, per capita consumption is increasing and 3,000 teenagers are becoming new smokers each day.

title: FREDERICK QUIN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Frederick Sherman Quin, a foreign service officer for 16 years, died here yesterday after a long !illness. He was 42 years old.

title: Woman Police Officer Is Fired at in Harlem
description: A woman police officer was among a group of police officers that was fired on last night in an East Harlem Street. One of three bullets tore a hole in the right sleeve of her coat before she and two other officers, both males, took cover.

title: Sabres Trounce Rangers
SCHOLARS TO SPUR U.S.INDIA EXCHANGES
description: NEW DELHI, Jan, 10Indian and American scholars announced today a broad effort to spur academic exchanges and research in both countries.

title: What Price, Demand?; Economists Find Gas Cost Rises, Unless Huge, Won't Trim Use by Target Levels
2 Share Phoenix Golf Lead
Tanaka Sees Thai Students Who Denounced His Visit
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan met here today with representatives of students who had been denouncing his visit as symptomatic of economic imperialism.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Boat Show Calendar
description: TODAYNational Marine Distributors Association Industrial Relations Committee breakfast, St. James B, Americana Hotel, 8 A.M.; American Boat and Yacht Council membership meeting, Canada Room, Coliseum, 9:30 A.M.; N.E.S.B.E.C. meeting, Scandinavian Room, Coliseum, 10 A.M. to 2:30 P.M.: N.A.E.B.M. National Conference Committee meeting, Chelsea B, Americana Hotel, 11 A.M.; ChrisCraft Corp. press luncheon, New York Yacht Club, noon; American Boat and Yacht Council board of directors meeting, France Room, Coliseum, 2 P.M.; N.A.E.B.M. show committee meeting, Chelsea A. Americana Hotel, 2 P.M.; N.A.E.B.M. member services committee meeting, Chelsea B. Americana Hotel, 2 P.M.; N.A.E.B;M. annual meeting, Chelsea A, Americana Hotel 5 P.M. (new board of directors meeting immediately following); N.A.E.B.M. exhibitor's party, Georgian Suite, Americana Hotel, 7 P.M.

title: Kissinger Bids Countries Act in Unison on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Secretary of State Kissinger today urged all countriesproducers and consumers of oil aliketo work for longterm multinational agreement to solve the energy shortage, rather than seek shortterm advantages in countrybycountry deals.

title: Market Place: Unkindly Year In ClosedEnds
description: If 1973 was unkind to shareholders in general, it was doubly so to owners of shares of closedend trusts.

title: Timely Cahill Reminder
description: With an eloquent plea for reform of one of the nation's most unjust tax systems and for enactment of a state income tax, Gov. William T. Cahill has delivered a timely and relevant swan song to the New Jersey Legislature. Mr. Cahill's blunt review of the disgraceful facts about the state tax structure must have caused discomfort for both Democratic and Republican legislators who teamed up to kill his longoverdue reform program seventeen months ago.

title: Waterfront OilStorage Depot Argued at Weehawken Hearing
description: WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Jan. Additional pollution of the Hudson River, possible air pollution and heavy truck traffic all came in for discussion tonight as the New Jersey State Environmental Protection Agency opened public hearings into the proposed construction of new heatingoil storage depot on the waterfront here.

title: CANADA WILL EXTEND MOST CUTS IN TARIFFS
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 10 (Canadian Press)Most tariff cuts imposed a year ago to ease consumer price increases will be extended another six months, Canada's Finance Minister, John Turner, announced today.

title: Strike of British Rail Engineers Halts Coal and Jams the Roads
description: LONDON, Jan. 10Railroad engineers walked off their jobs today, halting the movement of badly needed coal and steel, stranding commuters and causing some of the worst automobile traffic jams in British history.

title: The Pop Life Buck Owens Bringing Nashville North by Way of West Coast
description: There's so much prejudice in New York1 think they're afraid of it. The speaker was the country music singer Buck Owens, and the subject was country music.

title: On the Coast: A Land and Sea Operation
description: For the waterborne community along the West Coast, the situation on all levels is basically similar to that of the rest of the country; unclear.

title: When a Crisis Is Not a Crisis
description: VALLEY STREAM, N. Y.Britain's threeday week, although attributed to the fuel shortage, Is really another move in the Conservative Government's long battle with the unions. It is not an energy crisis at all, but lockout, a ploy to pressure the miners into submission.

title: Prank E. McKinney Sr. Is Dead; Headed Democratic Committee
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 10Frank E. McKinney Sr., who served as Democratic National Chairman in 1951 and 1952, died last evening at his home here. He was 69 years old.

title: Purple Prose Makes Page's Mood Indignant
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 10 (AP)Alan Page, Minnesota's AllPro tackle, takes offense at calling the Vikings defensive line the Purple People Eaters.

title: Fuel Oil Shortage Held NearCritical In the Bistate Area
description: New York and New Jersey were reported yesterday to be facing an immediate shortage bordering on the critical of 200,000 barrels of heavy fuel oil a day out of the 600,000 to 700,000 needed daily for utilities to generate electricity, and for schools, hospitals and large apartment houses to heat buildings.

title: Duryea for Letting a Sleeping Tax Surcharge Lie
description: ALBANY, Jan. 10Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea will introduce on Monday a bill to suspend the state's 2.5 per cent incometax surcharge for another year, his office announced today.

title: Super Scalpers Strike Houston
description: HOUSTON,. Jan. 10If you need two Super Bowl tickets, can afford to pay $150 and love dogs, Jack Farr is your man of the hour.

title: Many Blacks Say Beame Uses a Double Standard
description: Responding angrily to Mayor Beame's sudden postponement of the appointment of State Senator Joseph L. Galiber to the last remaining Deputy Mayor's slot, a group of 14 black ministers yesterday sent a telegram to the Mayor charging racism which imputes misbehavior towards black leaders even when there is no basis for the charge.

title: Viewers of Kohoutek in Dark, But Expert Sees Ray of Hope
description: A resident of a Boston suburb looked at the comet Kohoutek through binoculars for the first time Tuesday night, saw a fuzzy blur in the heavens and said, Watergate, then the energy crisis, and now the comet.

title: Dick Williams Takes an Interim Job in Business
description: Dick Williams, the phantom manager of the New York Yankees, retreated from baseball's legal wars yesterday and took a temporaiy job as an assistant to John D. MacArthur, the wealthy Florida businessman and developer.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Narragansett Racing Off
description: PAWTUCKET, R.I., Jan. 10 (UPI)  Racing cards at Narragansett Park for today and tomorrow were canceled today because of poor track conditions and a threat of more snow.

title: Nets Beat Spurs, 10593, To Sweep Road Games
Protestant and Catholic Groups Support Silence by a Clergyman
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 10 Ten Protestant and Roman Catholic organizations and leaders have joined the Minneapolisbased American Lutheran Church in a court test involving clergy confidentiality.

title: U.S. Retargeting Some Missiles Under New. Strategic Concept
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10Sec. retary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that the United States had begun retargeting some of its strategic missiles so they could strike at Soviet military ,installations as well as cities.

title: ANNA M'CRADY
description: RYE, N. Y., Jan. 10Anna Grace McCrady, former director of the Central Club for Nurses and the Presbyterian Hpme for Aged Women in New York, died Jan. 2 at the Miriam Osborn Home here. Her age was 91.

title: A Pacer Who Attacks Owner Out for Bigger Things Tonight
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 10 Derek Heckler has frequently found himself in a spot comparable to that of the youngster who is always told, Get away boy, you bother me. The 6foot1inch Heckler is hardly to be taken for a boy, but his youthful appearance causes many of his associates in harness racing to dismiss him. In a sport where many of the established stars are 40, 50 or 60 years old, Heckler, a native of Frankton, New Zealand, is only 23.

title: Partin Wins And Gains Semifinals
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 10 (AP)  Onny Parun of New Zealand and Ross Case of Australia advanced to the semifinals of an international tennis tournament today.

title: Byrne Appoints Insurance And LaborIndustry Chiefs
description: TRENTON, Jan. 10Governorelect Brendan T. Byrne appointed two more cabinet members of his incoming Democratic administration today, nominating Joseph A. Hoffman to be State Commissioner of Labor and Industry and James J. Sheeran as Commissioner of Insurance.

title: Nadjari Is Denied A Change of Venue For Mackell Trial
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the state's special anticorruption prosecutor, was denied change of venue yesterday in the forthcoming trial of former Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell and two codefendants.

title: State Energy Panel Urges FuelSaving Transit Shifts
description: ALBANY, Jan. 10The Interdepartmental Fuel and Energy Committee, which soon will become Governor Wilson's emergency coordinating group, has urged broad changes in the state's transportation system for the more efficient use of fuel.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 4.2 From WeekAgo Level
Sports News Briefs 3 Dead Horses Entered in Race
description: WINDSOR, Ont., Jan. 10 (AP)Three horses didn't show for the post parade last night at Windsor Raceway. Two of the horses entered last Saturday for last night's card died as a result of separate incidents during last Saturday's racing. The third died Monday, apparently from reaction to drugs administered during treatment for ankle soreness. Odd? Of course it's odd, said Joe DeFrank, director of racing at the track. I can't ever remember happening before.

title: Japan to Hunt Hoarders
description: TOKYO, Jan. 10 (Reuters)The Japanese Government is going to begin a nationwide search next week for hoarders of toilet paper and a number Id other commodities such as sugar and detergents. People have complained that toilet rolls were scarce, and have said that speculators were hoarding such necessities for future profit.

title: MILK PAPER SPURS MORE OUESTIOMS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10A White House explanation that political considerations and Congressional pressures contributed to President Nixon's decision to raise milk price supports in 1971 seemingly conflicts with a sworn statement by the Secretary of Agriculture at the time, Clifford M. Hardin.

title: Morris Named Top Horseman
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 10George Morris, a former United States Equestrian Team rider from Pittstown, N. J., and Carlene Blunt of Delray Beach, Fla., were named today horseman and horsewoman of the year for 1973 by the American Horse Shows Association.

title: People and Business
description: PierrePaul Schweitzer, who retired last September as managing director of the International Monetary Fund, has been appointed chairman of Banque Ameribas, S.A., an investment bank based in both Luxembourg and Paris. Tile bank  established in 1971 and with a current capitalization of $24million is jointly owned by the Bank of America and the Banque de Paris et des Pays Bas.

title: Stock Prices Slide On Recession Fears
No Rubles for Chile Soccer
description: BONN, Jan. 10 (Reuters)The World Cup organizing committee said today there had been no agreement between Chile and the Soviet Union over compensation for the Russians refusal to play a qualifying soccer match in Santiago. Chile demanded that the Soviet Union make up gate losses incurred when the Russian team refused to play a match with Chile on the ground that the detention prisoners in Santiago's stadiumwhere the match was to be playedmade it a concentration camp. A spokesman for the World Cup committee said Chile had received $200,000 from the International Football Federation (FIFA) under FIFA regulations covering unplayed games.

title: BEAK POSTPONES NAMING GALE PENDING INQUIRY
description: Mayor Beame dramatically and abruptly postponed his third effort to appoint the city's first black Deputy Mayor yesterday after being informed that his designee, Joseph L. Galiber, was under challenge for possible improprieties in his handling of campaign contributions.

title: WALLIAM M'CAIN
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Jan. 10William D. McCain, executive, lawyer for the New Jersey Zinc Company, died here yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived here.

title: Federal Aides Assure Beame on HomeHeating Oil
description: Federal energy officials said yesterday that the metropolitan New York area and two other placesOregon and Arizona  had been more severely hit by the gasoline shortage than any other part of the country and that efforts were being made to make sure that these areas are adequately supplied.

title: REV. J. P. M'CORMACK MISSIONER, 80, DEAD
description: MARYKNOLL, N.Y., Jan. 11 The Rev. Joseph P. McCormack, a Maryknoll missioner, died Tuesday of cancer at St. Teresa's Residence. He was 80 years old.

title: Tanaka Discusses Japan's Asian Role In Singapore Talks
description: SINGAPORE, Jan. 11 (Reuters) Premier Kakeui Tanaka of Japan arrived here today for a oneday official visit and began talks with Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Diamond Shamrock Posts Records
Soviet Union Agrees to a Delay In Delivery of American Wheat
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI)  The Soviet Union has agreed to a delay in delivery of 18.4 million bushels of American wheat in a move that officials here said could help ease threats of a bread shortage in the United States this spring, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: KISSINGER HOPING TO SPEED ACCORD
description: ASWAN, Egypt, Jan. 11Secretary of State Kissinger arrived here tonight on his latest mission to the Middle East hoping to persuade Egypt and Israel to agree to some general principles for negotiating an accord on separating their forces near the Suez Canal.

title: SAXBE DRAWS LINE ON IMPEACHMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 Attorney General William B. Saxbe said today that the Justice Department would not help President Nixon fight impeachment by the House of Representatives unless the House was proceeding on obviously political grounds and not on criminal charges.

title: Cambodian Rebel Drive Called Major Effort to Topple Lon Not
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 11Several thousand anti. Government troops have intensified their offensive against this capital in recent days, beginning what Government and Western analysts describe as a maximum effort to force the fall of the Government of President Lon Nol.

title: E.P.A. Drops Plan to Levy Parking Surcharge or Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI)  The Environmental Protection Agency has abandoned plans to encourage public transportation and car pools by imposing parking surcharges or commuter taxes anywhere in the country.

title: People and Business
description: N. J. Nicholas Jr. has been named president and chief executive officer of Sterling Manhattan Cable Television, effective Feb. 1, succeeding Richard M. Galkin. Sterling, which has been completely owned by Time Inc. since last fall, is the nation's largest individual cable television system and says it has 60,000 subscribers.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Several readers have inquired, What's wrong with macaroni and cheese? Nothing, except that the macaroni and the cheese are invariably poor, and even if they weren't, it would be a fairly dull dish.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (Reuters)United Air Lines said today it would have to lay off another 490 employes because of the energy crisis, even though airline fuel restrictions were recently eased. The 490 are ground employes who will be furloughed effective Jan. 26. This will bring to 1,440 the total number of layoffs announced by United as necessary due to operations cutbacks.

title: J. RAY OLIVERA, 69, A NARCOTICS AGENT
description: EDISON, N. J., Jan. 11J. Ray Olivera, who served as an agent of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics from 1928 to his retirement in 1958, died yesterday in John F. Kennedy Hospital here. He was 69 years old and lived here.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED BY PAPERHANDLERS
description: The Paperhandlers Union yesterday reached a tentative twoyear agreement with The New York Times, The Daily News and The New York Post providing for a pay increase of $13.85 a week in each year of the pact.

title: Streaking Nets Down Pacers, 109106
MRS. WILLIAM H. OSBORN
description: Mrs. Katharine Haven Osborn, a welfare leader and the widow of William H. Osborn Sr., a mining engineer, died Thursday at her home, 3 East 77th Street. She was 75 years old and also lived in Garrison and Tivoli, N. Y.

title: Cambodian Rebel Drive Called Major Effort to Topple Lon Nol
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 11Several thousand antiGovernment troops have intensified their offensive against this capital in recent days, beginning what Government and Western analysts describe as a maximum effort to force the fall of the Government of President Lon Nol.

title: Columbia Edged by Cornell Five
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 11Dwight Kiel's 15foot jump shot with two seconds to play gave Cornell a 6463 Ivy League basketball victory over Columbia tonight. For Kiel, a sophomore guard, it was his only shot of the game.

title: A CASTRO OVERTURE IS DENIED BY THE U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11The Mutual Broadcasting System said today that Premier Fidel Castro had sent a cablegram to the United States Government requesting discussions to settle disputes between the United States and Cuba. The report was denied by two State Department officials concerned with Cuban affairs.

title: Veteran Is Charged in Killing of Oakland Educator
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 11A 27yearold veteran of the war in Vietnam who is a political activist was charged today with the murder of Dr. Marcus A. Foster, the Oakland schools superintendent who was shot and killed in an ambush last election night.

title: G.M. Told to Warn Owners of Defect In Aged Cadillacs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11The Government ordered the General Motors Corporation today, to warn the owners of 60,000 aged Cadillacs of a steering defect that could cause the cars to go out of control.

title: General news, P. 37
description: North: Partly sunny, cold today; fair, very cold tonight. Temp. range 2836. South: Partly sunny today; fair, very cold tonight. Temp. range 2832. Additional details on Page 66.

title: Wallich Is Nominated by Nixon To Replace Daane at Reserve
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11President Nixon announced today that he would appoint Henry C. Wallich, a wellknown professor of economics at Yale University, to the Federal Reserve Board.

title: A BANGKOK PAPER NAMES A C.I.A. AIDE
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 11 (Reuters)A Thai newspaper today identified the head of the United States Central Intelligence Agency in Thailand in the latest episode in a student and press campaign against the agency's activities in Thailand.

title: 2 Dairy Officials Plead Guilty In $22,000 Humphrey Donation
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 11 Two former officials of Associated Milk Producers, Inc., pleaded guilty today in Federal District Court here to charges that they conspired to donate illegally $22,000 in corporate funds in 1968 to the Democratic Presidential campaign.

title: Dance: Four Bagatelles
description: As the first of its two new works of the season, the New York City Ballet presented the official local premiere of Jerome Robbins's Four Bagatelles Thursday night at the New York State Theater. A pas de deux set to four of Beethoven's piano pieces known as Bagatelles, the ballet was given a preview performance here last spring by Violette Verdy and JeanPierre Bonnefous before they danced it at Spoleto, Italy. It was performed Thursday by Gelsey Kirkland and Mr. Bonnefous.

title: Burger Birthplace Faces Bulldozer
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 11The birthplace of the American hamburger is in danger. Louis Lunch, a tiny restaurant here wtiere man reputedly first put a chopped steak patty between two pieces of bread, will be replaced within a year or so by a 12story medical complex the city says it needs more urgently.

title: Exxon Raising Prices
description: The oil industry is mounting a counterattack to attempt to halt the growing criticism being directed at it by the Congress, the news media and the public.

title: Sextuplets Born in Capetown; Survival Chances Called Good
description: CAPETOWN, Jan. 11 (AP)A 25yearold South African woman gave birth to sextuplets today after a full nine months of pregnancy, and doctors gave the three boys and three girls a good chance of survival.

title: Liguori Captures Mile; Prefontaine Is Beaten
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 11Marty Liguori, who has not run an indor mile race under 4 minutes, started off with every intention of doing so tonight. But halfway through his first indoor mile of the winter, the former Villanova star decided to settle for just a victory.

title: WINE TALK
description: HEALDSBURG, Calif. Mary Ann Graf is 31 years old and just getting over her first big crush. Of grapes, that is.

title: Impact of Fuel Shortage On JobTotal Is Uncertain
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11Total employment in the nation remained unchanged in December, the Labor Department reported today, adding that part of the failure of jobs to increase could be attributed to the energy shortage.

title: Oil Cooperation...
description: The foreign ministers conference of the chief oilconsuming countries next month is an essential step toward rational solution of the world's energy crisis through international cooperation.

title: Gas Plentiful in OilShort Netherlands
description: GRONINGEN, The Netherlands, Jan. 9The Netherlands with an Arab oil embargo still aimed at her massive oil transport and refining industry, is one of the countries hardest hit by the world oil shortage. Nevertheless, her overall energy situation is one of the bcst in Western Europe.

title: Mallory to Coach Colorado Football
description: OXFORD, Ohio, Jan. 11 (AP)Bill Mallory, the head football coach at Miami University, said tonight he had accepted the head coaching position at the University of Colorado.

title: WIFE OF A DENTIST SLAIN IN LI, HOME
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I., Jan, 11The 31yearold mother of three young children was found slain in her $75,000 home here today.

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, JANUARY 12, 1974
description: International

title: Dolphins to Use Twilley If War field Can't Start
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 11Fate may be moving Howard Twilley back into the Super Bowl limelight,

title: Judge Orders U.S. To Reveal Wiretaps On Antiwar Groups
description: WASHINGTON,.Jan. 11 (AP) The Government must reveal the nature and extent of wiretaps and electronic surveillance of several antiwar leaders and groups, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: ESSO SAID TO AGREE TO PAY TO FREE AIDE
description: BUENOS AIRES. Jan. 11 (UPI)  People's Revolutionary Army guerrillas said today that the Esso Argentina Oil Corporation had agreed to donate $10mil lion worth of food, clothing, tools and medicine to the poor if the guerrillas would free, Victor S. Samuelson, an Esso executive kidnapped Dec. 6.

title: In Montclair, a Car Pool Is a Corporation
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J.  The Rev. J. Martin Bailey braced against the freezing cold at Watchung Plaza the other morning as he checked off the names of friends hurrying into station wagons headed for upper Manhattan.

title: New Steiner Sculptures Have a Precisionist Elan
description: The distinctly precisionist elan of the sculptures of Michael Steiner now on view at the Marlborough Gallery, Inc., 40 West 57th Street, is the most remarkable feature of these recent works by the 29yearold. American artist. _Mr. Steiner's earliest works consisted of sprawling, floorhugging pieces, which maintained a rigorously low prafile and had certain improvisational qualities in their use of irregular formal components. These new works are lifted off the ground by means of struts and platform elements, and the thick plates of Corten steel of which they have been be squared and trued with an almost fanatical exactitude. These are very cleanlined sculptures indeed.

title: On the Long Line
description: The transfer of 200,000 New Yorkers from citystate welfare to Federal Supplemental Security Income payments is part of a program designed to enhance their dignity. But for several, thousand aged, disabled and blind persons, turned into human shuttlecocks and made to stand for hours in the cold and snow, the advent of the new system has proved an inhuman experience that must not be repeated next month when the second round of payments from local Social Security offices falls due.

title: High School Notes
description: George W. Wingate High School in Brooklyn, which had a steady influx of students from Frenchspeaking Haiti, will begin an accelerated program next month to help the youngsters gain proficiency in English.

title: A Method of Doubling Light From Lamps Is Devised
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11Abe Feder, the New York lighting designer who has helped illuminate United Nations headquarters, Kennedy Airport, Philharmonic Hall, the John F. Kennedy Center for Patents the Performing of the Arts and hunWeek dreds of theaters, now offers what he regards as the first basic change in the home lighting field. This week he was granted Patent 3,784,811 for a lamp assembly that includes a reflector bulb and sends indirect light at an angle throughout the room. Much of the shine goes upward and is reflected by the ceiling.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERFanny, beloved mother of Alexander Turner. Cherished grandmother of Ruth, Anita and Mark Services Sunday, January 13, 2:15 P.M. at. The Riverside, 761h St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Black Mayors and Rights Chiefs Find a Sympathetic Ear in Ford
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 11A group of 16 black mayors and civil rights leaders spent two hours with Vice President Ford today, and afterward expressed the guarded hope that they now had a sympathetic ear in the Nixon Administration.

title: Dolphins to Use Twilley If War field Can't Start
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 11Fate may be moving Howard Twilley back into the Super Bowl limelight,

title: PENN CENTRAL LOSES APPEAL ON REALTY
description: TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 11 (UPI) The bankrupt Penn Central Railroad lost an appeal today seeking the increase of an award of $2.million for the sale of property and air rights in Journal Square in Jersey City.

title: Columbia Edged by Cornell Five
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 11 Dwight Kiel's 15foot jump shot with two seconds to play gave Cornell a 6463 Ivy League basketball victory over Columbia tonight. For Kiel, a sophomore guard, it was his only shot of the game.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE

title: Subpoenas Prepared
description: Frustrated by the lack of precise information concerning the supplies and distribution of gasoline and heating fuels, officials of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have begun legal action aimed at wresting such information from the major oil companies,

title: Power Plant Working Again
description: The Consumers Power Company reported yesterday that it had returned its Big Rock Point nuclear power plant to operation. The plant had been closed for repairs since Dec. 8.

title: PENNSY WAGE RISES AND TRUSTEE BACKED
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. II (UPI)A Federal judge permitted the Penn Central Railroad today to comply with 4 per cent wage increases covering 13 national labor unions and to appoint Robert W. Blanchette as a trustee to succeed Jervis Langdon Jr.

title: Planner of FundRaiser Back in Spotlight
description: Arlene Wolff, who went from nightclub singer at the nowdefunct Old Rumanian on Manhattan's Lower East Side to behindthescenes party planner for politicians, is back on center stage.

title: 7 Hurt by Gas Blast In House in Brooklyn
description: Seven persons, including four policemen, suffered minor burns and smoke inhalation yesterday in a gas explosion in the basement of a fourstory apartment house in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn.

title: Murphy Calls Nixon Reluctant To Press War Against Crime
description: Patrick V. Murphy, who resigned last April as Police Commissioner here, charged yesterday that the Nixon Administration had shown reluctance to press the war on crime.

title: GOING OUT Gulde
description: TRIBUTES Had he lived, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. would have observed his 45th birthday next Tuesday. With that day in the offing, this weekend is being marked by a number of memorial tributes in musical form.

title: WITNESSES SCORE CURB ON PARKING
Dr. John Theiss, 77, Dies; OldTime Country Doctor
description: NEW MARTINSVILLE, W. Va., Jan. 11 Dr. John O. Theiss, who was perhaps one of the last of the oldtime physicians who thought nothing of making a house call in the middle of the night, died today. He was 77 years old, and, while his home was in this mountain community, his practice ranged all over the state and beyond its borders.

title: Notes on People
description: The Greek Ambassador to the United States, Ioannis A. Sorokos, who came to Washington in November of 1972, will return to Athens next week for family reasons, and it is believed his successor in the capital will be Constantine Panayiotacos, now Greek representative at the United Nations.

title: White House, Statement
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Jan. 11Following is a statement issued by the President's office on the passing of information from the National Security Council to the Pentagon:

title: DR. DONALD THORBURN
description: REDINGTON BEACH, Fla., Jan. 11Dr. Donald B. Thorburn, an osteopathic physician in New York from 1923 until his retirement in 1971 and a member of the New York State Board of Medical Examiners from 1938 to 195,2, died yesterday. He was 73 years old and lived here.

title: Improbable Probably Won't Set Mark
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 11 (AP)The American yacht Improbable, with a big lead on the rest of the fleet in the HobartAuckland yacht race, appeared tonight to be fighting a losing battle to break the race record. The record of 8 days 2 hours 10 minutes 28 seconds was set 1972 by the American yacht Kialoa II. Improbable was off New Zealand's North Cape late this afternoon with 191 miles to go to the finishing line and less than 24 hours beat the record. If the present weather continues, Improbable is expected here late tomorrow or early Sunday.

title: Ford Motor Is Bringing 3,475 Back to Their Jobs
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Jan, 11 (Reuters)  The Ford Motor Company said today that it would bring 3,475 laidoff employes back to work next week. I Included in the action are I2,300 workers at the Los Angeles assembly plant, 775 at tractor plants in Highland Park and Romeo, Mich., and 400 workers at the Chicago assembly facility.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: ATHENS, Jan, 11Greece's military regime, faced with a $900million bill for oil imports in 1974, tonight imposed strict fuel economy measures, ranging from a 65 per cent price increase on gasoline to alternateweekend motoring. The Ministry of Industry announced an increase to $2.50 a gallon in the price of premium gasoline. Regular gasoline will go up by 75 per cent to $2.05 a gallon. The new restrictions, effective at once, will force Greek motorists off the roads from 7 P.M. Saturday to 4 A.M. Monday, on alternate weekends, based on even or odd license numbers. The top speed limit is now 50 miles an hour. Other restrictions include public street lighting, cut by onehalf, shop signs and windows, to be cut off at 9 P.M., and television stations, to sign off just after 11 P.M. The electricity restrictions may herald the end of the midday nap in Greece, since the authorities are considering a nonstop work schedule and the closing of shops and offices before sunset.

title: GERMANS COMPLETE MRS. RYAN INQUIRY
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, Jan. 11 (AP)  West German authorities announced today completion of a preliminary pretrial investigation of Mrs. Hermine BraunsteinerRyan, a Nazi concentration camp guard who became a United States citizen.

title: Jan Kozak, Czech Writer Who Lectured in U.S., Dies
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 11 (AP)Jan Blahoslav Kozak, a nonMarxist Czechoslovak philosopher who taught in the United States during World War II, has died here, the newspaper Lidova Demokracie announced today. He was 85 years old.

title: Nuclear Plant Shut by Leak
description: LACEY TOWNSHIP, Jan. 11 (AP)The Jersey Central Power & Light Company shut down its Oyster Creek nuclear generating station today to repair a leak that had developed inside the station's containment vessel, which is the housing for the reactor.

title: The Spanked Speak: Awful, but Not Bad
description: When Tony Shorris, a senior at the Collegiate School, was about 8 years old, he would sulk on his bed after he had been punished and wonder how he would discipline his own children.

title: Bridge: Snow and Fuel Pinch Keep Many From Upstate Contest
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., Jan. 11Too much snow and not enough gasoline severely handicapped the start of the Tristate Regional Championships here Thursday. Attendance for the first of the four days of play was about 40 per cent below previous years.

title: Boston's Weather Vane Case Is Ended
description: BOSTON, Jan. 11The case of the copper grasshopper has ended, for the moment anyway, as mysteriously as it began.

title: Kugler Asks Liberalizing Of Right to Know Laws
description: TRENTON, Jan. 11Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr. proposed today a broad liberalization of the state's right to know laws that would make it easier for private citizens to gain access to government information.

title: The Writhes and Falls Of Yepremian, Passer
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 11 (AR)There'll be no passing from Garo Yepremian of the Dolphins in the Super Bowl this time. Miami Coach Don S'nula said today he had put Yepremian through a special drill in summer camp.

title: Argonaut Aide Quits
description: TORONTO, Jan. 11 (AP)Greg Barton resigned his frontoffice job today with the Toronto Argonauts of the Canadian Football League. The Argonauts said Barton, who had been director of Canadian player personnel, was expected to seek a playing job with one of the new World Football League teams.

title: Flyers Top Flames on Flett's Goal
Marines Reprimand the Leader Of Band on Guest Appearances
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) The Marine Corps has reprimanded Lieut. Col. Dale C. Harpham, leader of the Marine band, for allegedly accepting money for appearances as guest conductor for civilian bands.

title: Concert: Leonard Slatkin Conducts
description: Since Leonard Slatkin is said to have begun violin lessoy, at the age of 3, it was probably not rushing matters fir him to guestconduct the New York Philharmonic 27 years later. Mr. Slatkin, substituting at Thursday night's subscription concert for the indisposed Riccardo Muti, seemed quite ready for the itssignment, at any rate. He conducted Mr. Muti's original program with professional aplomb and made a considerable splash at times with Prokofiev's Symphony No. 5.

title: Anne de LapeyrouseVaucresson Married to Franklin R. F. Singer
description: PARIS, Jan. 11The wedding of Miss Anne de LapeyrouseVaucresson and Franklin Reginald Forbes Singer, a greatgrandson of Isaac Merritt Singer, inventor of the Singer sewing machine, took place in the chapel of St. LouisdesInvalides today.

title: 3 I.T.T. SUBSIDIARIES IN ROME ARE BOMBED
description: ROME, Jan. 11 (AP)Three explosions in quick succession early today heavily damaged three buildings in downtown Rome housing offices of companies owned by International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, the police reported.

title: Democrat Bids Tax Agency Act on I.T.T
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 Representative J. J. Pickle urged the Internal Revenue Service today to act soon on a recommendation of its New York district office to revoke a 1969 tax ruling that benefited the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Energy Crisis Hearing Set
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) The House's Permanent Select Committee on Small Business has scheduled a threeday hearing next week in an attempt to determine whether the energy crisis is fact or fiction." A number of industry and government witnesses are schedtiled to testify at the hearing beginning Wednesday.

title: Dr. William Leavitt Dies; Psychiatrist, Teacher, 86
description: Dr. William Leavitt, oldest living member of the American Psychiatric Association, died Thursday at St. Joseph Hospital, Stamford, Conn. He was 86 years old and lived at 145 East 84th Street.

title: MEDIA ARE SCORED BY FRED FRIENDLY
description: News organizations that resort to a Freedom of the Press slogan for every emergency are as guilty of applying stress on the First Amendment as was the Nixon Administration With its antimedia assault, Fred Friendly, broadcast consultant to the Ford Foundation, said Thursday in a speech to the Federal Communications Bar Association in Washington.

title: A.E.C. Is Split in Personality Struggle
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 Internal warfare at the Atomic Energy Commission, gathering in intensity since last summer,has burst to the surface in series of bureaucratic struggles and personality conflicts at the top levels.

title: Blue Cross and Blue Shield Plan to Merge Operations
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield have agreed in principle to merge their operations so that one agency will be able to be more efficient and possibly more economical in providing insurance to help pay hospital and physicians bills.

title: Tony Lama Sr., Founder And Head of Boot Company
description: EL PASO, Tex., Jan. 11Tony Lama Sr., who in 1911 founded the Tony Lama. Company, now a publicly owned manufacturer of Western boots and accessories, died here today at the age of 86.

title: U.S. AUTO MAKERS SEEK CUBAN SALES
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 11American automobile company subsidiaries in Argentina are negotiating with Cuban officials for the sale of thousands of cars and trucks over the next few years. Technically, it would be part of a large trade agreement between the Governments of Argentina and Cuba.

title: Indivillual Investor Backed by Brokers
description: The Securities Industry Association yesterday announced support for a list of aims to encourage more active participation by the individual investor in the stock market.

title: Colombia Leads U.S. In Davis Cup
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 11 (AP)Ivan Molina took commanding lead over Erik Van Dillen of the United States today,i and was on the verge of giVing Colombia a 20 lead in Davis Cup tennis when play was halted by darkness.

title: Art: Cool Luminosity From Ink
description: The 47 Chinese paintings in The Colors of Ink, a new exhibition at Asia House, 112 East 64th Street, are, by literal definition, colorless, since all are in black ,ink with its gray variants. The walls of the galleries, too, have been painted the color of charcoal for the occasion. But the exhibition is anything but somber. The galleries seem, rather, to be shot through with a cool, silvery luminosity that would be vulgarized by the intrusion of any color, and the paintings are infused with the same tonalitywhether or not they are furnished with all five colors by the management of ink alone, as Chinese theorists thought was possible.

title: Alan Hynd, Author, Dies; Wrote Books on Espionage
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 11 Alan Hynd, author of two nonfiction best sellers in 1943 as well as mystery and crime stories in later years, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital. His age was 70 and he lived in Westport.

title: Soviet Aides Losing Chauffeurs
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 11 Russian bureaucrats are dragging their feet on a decree ordering many of them to surrender their most precious status symbolthe chauffeurdriven car.

title: Convention Planners Invite Gibson to Be Favorite Son
description: NEWARK, Jan. 11Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson received public invitation today from the planning committee of the upcoming Citywide Political Convention to represent the gathering as a favorite son in his candidacy for reelection this May.

title: Use of Espionage Denied by Trudeau
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 11 (Canadian Press)Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau said yesterday that while Canada collected intelligence information to protect national security and sometimes shared secrets allies, no agents were sent abroad to spy on other countries.

title: JAPAN CURTAILING INDUSTRIES FUEL
description: TOKYO, Jan. 11The Japanese Government announced a mandatory energysaving program today requiring industry to reduce its use of oil and electricity by 5 to 15 per cent until: the end of February.

title: And While He's Up, Get Me That Giant
description: HOUSTON. Jan. 11 (UPI)Bud Grant places the blame for his stoic reputation along the sidelines on the national television cameras.

title: OIL BLAZE IN TEXAS LINKED TO LIGHTNING
description: PORT NECHES, Tex., Jan, 11 (UPI)A tank of crude oil, apparently ignited by lightning in a thunderstorm, exploded like a volcano today, spreading fire to nearby storage tanks and forcing evacuation of an elementary school.

title: Labor Squeeze
description: Rampaging inflation and the impending demise of statutory wageprice controls have brought mounting indications of trouble on the labor front after a year of remarkable stability.

title: CONNECTICUT EYES RACETRACK VOTE
description: WOLCOTT, Conn., Jan. 11 This town of 13,000 will vote tomorrow on a proposal to build a track for thoroughbred and harness racing on a gently rolling meadow on its northern

title: GRAND JURY GETS CASE ON SCALDING
description: TRENTON, Jan. 11The case of a Trenton State Prison inmate scalded to death in his cell two weeks ago while guards allegedly ignored his screams for help was presented to a grand jury here today by the Mercer County Prosecutor's Office.

title: Weyerhaeuser Deal Set
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company I announced yesterday it had acquired the Scarborough Corporation, one of New Jersey's largest residential construction companies. The transaction involves the exchange of 491,082 shares of Weyerhaeuser common stock for all the outstanding shares of Scarborough. Based on the current price of Weyerhaeuser, common stock, the transaction is valued at approximately $18million.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A mistrial was declared yesterday in the misconductconspiracy trial of former Stafford. Township Mayor Wesley K. Bell, charged with trying to alter drunkendriving charges for an associate. The mistrial was declared by Judge William Huber of Ocean County after the jury failed to reach a verdict on one misconduct count. Earlier in the day, the panel found Mr. Bell not guilty of conspiracy, eliminating that charge.

title: Sony Sets TV Unit Rise
description: TOKYO, Jan. 11 (AP)The Sony Corp. said today it planned to produce about 1.8 million color television receivers this year, up from about 1.5 million units in 1973. Sony officials said one million units would be marketed in the domestic market, and the rest will be sold abroad.

title: ROLE OF 2 INDIANS ELEMENT IN TRIAL
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 11High above the frozen Mississippi River, a courtroom drama is being played out here to determine if the Indians who led the uprising last year at Wounded Knee, S.D., are to be Itreated as common criminals or modern Sitting Bulls.

title: NASA DEFENDS LAG ON WOMEN'S JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 110f ficials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration told a Senate subcommittee today that the agency's shrinking work force and the relatively few available women and minority engineers and scientists were responsible for the agency's selfadmittedly poor record on equal employment.

title: PROTESTS MARK CHESIMARD TRIAL
description: MORRISTOWN, Jan. 11 Forty supporters of Joanne D. Chesimard and Clark E. Squire, who are facing charges of murder, demonstrated in front of the Morris County Courthouse here today while a counterprotest was conducted by two uniformed members of the American Nazi party.

title: British Train Men Call Off Slowdown; Mine Plan Weighed
description: LONDON, Jan. 11 (AP)Locomotive engineers called off a work by the book slowdown today, and rail service was reported up to 80 per cent normal on some lines and 50 per cent on others.

title: Beame Will Help Launch 9Day Boat Show Today
description: Mayor Beame was practicing his French, exhibitors were practicing to look pleased and Coliseum officials practiced to, count to seven million yesterday as the 64th National Boat Show prepared for today's 10 A.M. opening.

title: LEXINGTON, Mass., Jan. 11
description: Miss Hill Leads

title: Beame Meets With Aides Handling Caliber Inquiry
description: Mayor Beame met yesterday with the men investigating the charges that have delayed the k.swearingin. of State Senator Joseph L. Galiber as the city's first black Deputy Mayor, but was unable to resolve the problem.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Custodial employes who work in the city's 900 public schools yesterday authorized a strike for next Wednesday if they do not reach a satisfactory settlement in their pay negotiations with the Board of Education. The most recent bargaining session was held Thursday, and both sides said they were willing to resume negotiations Monday in an effort to head off the walkout.

title: Increased Earnings In Quarter and 73 Estimated by Chase
Sun Oil Increases Prices For Propane 4c a Gallon
description: The Sun Oil Company announced yesterday that it had raised its wholesale and retail prices for propane by 4 cents a gallon.

title: Nader Challenges White House On Nixon Remarks to Dairymen
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  A tape recording of a meeting between President Nixon and dairy industry representatives in 1971 indicates that the White House contention that President Nixon did not mention campaign contributions may have been false and misleading, lawyers for Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, maintained in a brief filed in Federal court today.

title: BUDGET EXPERTS FEAR RISE OF 13% IN PROPERTY TAX
Pro Tour Skiers Seek Fans and More Dollars
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 11Professional ski racers hope to reach a goal tomorrow when they open a twoday stand in the fourth stop of the Benson & Hedges Grand Prix tour. The goal? To stage their programs before sizable crowds that pay to see them perform.

title: On a Clear Day, an Israeli Sees Damascus
description: TEL SHAMS, Israeli occupied Syria, Jan. 9The real winter came to the Golan Heights this week. Not the light, whimsical snow flurries of December, but the hard, cold, lashing rain and hailstorms that begin in January and transform the barren, treeless plain into a vast, bonechilling bog.

title: Rangers Drop Popein After 41 Games; Francis Takes Over Club for 3d Time
description: TORONTO, Jan. 11The New York Rangers, whose abysmal performance has washed out the promise they showed at the start of the season, dismissed today their new coach, Larry Popein, after 41 games of a 79game schedule. The hope is to inject enough life into the fourthplace club to get it into the National Hockey League playoffs in April.

title: Gas Spill at Airport
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11 (UPI)A fuel line ruptured at New Orleans International Airport yesterday, spilling 2,900 barrels of gasoline near the main runway and blocking it for more than seven hours. There were no injuries or damage.

title: Impact of Fuel Shortage On Job Total Is Uncertain
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11Total employment in the nationl remained unchanged in December, the Labor Department reported today, adding that part of the failure of jobs to increase could be attributed to the energy shortage.

title: Geneva Picks Lasse
description: BEAVER FALLS, Pa., Jan. 11 (AP)Dick Lasse, who played end. at Syracuse in the late nineteenfifties, was named head football coach today at Geneva College.

title: Dumpson Reports Beame Withdrew Offer of a Job
description: James R. Dumpson, a former Welfare Commissioner here, said yesterday that he had been scheduled for appointment as IMayor Beame's acting Human Resources Administrator and Commissioner of Social Services until the administration told him there were serious objections from certain sectarian groups against him.

title: Brisk Rally Staged By Stock Market
description: Leading oil issues were notable laggards yesterday as the stock market staged a brisk rally after its pounding earlier in the week.

title: Drug Dealer's Conviction For Murder Is Reversed
description: A convicted narcotics dealer won a reversal yesterday of his conviction on a Federal civilrights charge that he had killed a Manhattan model to prevent her from testifying against him.

title: New Head for Sterling TV
description: N. J. Nicholas Jr. has been appointed president and chief executive officer of Sterling Manhattan Cable Television, effective Feb. 1. Sterling, a wholly owned subsidiary of Time Inc., holds the cable franchise for the southern half of Manhattan. Mr. Nicholas had been an assistant treasurer of Time Inc. He succeeds Richard M. Galkin.

title: AUSTRALIAN SECRETS SAID TO BE LEAKED
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Jan, 11 (Reuters) The Australian Government has begun an intvestigation into the newspaper publication today of communications between the Government and its Embassy in Washington. The communications were described as highly secret.

title: Tax Evasion Charged
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11 (UPI) Benjamin M. Reinhardt, a member of President Nixon's now disbanded Committee on Legal Matters Affecting the Aged, was indicted yesterday on three counts of income tax evasion. Mr. Reinhardt was charged by a Federal grand jury with evading payment of $88,500 in taxes between 1967 and 1969.

title: G.0 P. Delegate Formula for 76 Is Ruled Illegal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 A Federal district judge ruled today that part of the formula that the 1972 Republican National Convention drafted for distributing delegate strength for the party's 1976 convention was unconstitutional.

title: Council Challenge
description: Majority Leader Thomas J. Cuite's dominance of the City Council was never really seriously challenged the other day when a minority coalitionfour blacks, two Puerto Ricans and the lone Liberal party memberupset the usual rubberstamp routine of an opening session by seeking to add three of their number to the important Rules Committee. Mr. Cuite, as usual, clearly had the votes to put the upstarts, led by Councilman Samuel D. Wright of Brooklyn, in their place.

title: Liguori Captures Mile; Prefontaine Is Beaten
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 11Marty Liguori, who has not run an indor mile race under 4 minutes, started off with every intention of doing so tonight. But halfway through his first indoor mile of the winter, the former Villanova star decided to settle for just a victory.

title: New Jersey Sports A Women's Lobber
description: FORT LEE, Jan. 11The brownhaired girl stood the baseline, poised to serve. The ball went up, the racquet flashed andpow! The player at the other end of the court waved futilely. Ace for Barbara Goldman, and another victory for Fort Lee High School's boys tennis team.

title: Dumpson Reports Beame Withdrew Offer of a Job
description: James R. Dumpson, a former Welfare Commissioner here, said yesterday that he had been scheduled for appointment as Mayor Beame's acting Human Resources Administrator and Commissioner of Social Services until the administration

title: Nader Challenges White House On Nixon Remarks to Dairymen
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  A tape recording of a meeting between President Nixon and dairy industry representatives in 1971 indicates that the White House contention that President Nixon did not mention campaign contributions may have been false and misleading, lawyers for Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, maintained in a brief filed in Federal court today.

title: ... Oil Politics
description: The choice of international oil cooperation instead of a goitalone policy in energy confronts the United States with as many problems as it does West Europe and Japan. If more than lip service to cooperation is to be involved in the conferences this country is initiating, an American willingness to face sacrifices will have to be demonstrated.

title: Knicks LineUp
Books of The Times
description: THE AGE OF THE AVANTGARDE: An Art Chronicle of 19561972. By Hilton Kramer. 565 pages, Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.

title: A MILITARY RING LINKED TO SPYING ON WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11The White House investigative unit known as the plumbers uncovered evidence in late 1971 that a ring of military officers was attempting to relay highly classified information on the China talks and other matters to officials in the Pentagon, wellinformed sources report.

title: Exxon Raising Prices
description: The oil industry is mounting a counterattack to attempt to halt the growing criticism being directed at it by the Congress, the news media and the public.

title: WILLIAM T. KIRK, HEADED AID BIT
description: WOODLAND HILLS, Calif., Jan. 11William T. Kirk, who had held the closely related positions of international director of the International Social Service and general director of the organization's American branch, died Monday after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

title: Colombia Leads U.S. In Davis Cup
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 11 (AP)Ivan Molina took commanding lead over Erik Van Dillen of the United States today,i and was on the verge of giVing Colombia a 20 lead in Davis Cup tennis when play was halted by darkness.

title: People in Sports: Colts Inform Schnellenberger He'll Stay On
description: Although his team won only 4 of 14 National Football League games last season, Howard Schnellenberger will return this summer as coach of the Baltimore Colts. Joe Thomas, the Colts genera! manager, announced yesterday that Schnellenberger would he retained for the second year of a threeyear contract.

title: Chilean Deadline Is Worrying Political Refugees
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 11There is a new feeling of insecurity and urgency among political refugees in United Nationssponsored safe havens here as the February deadline for leaving the country draws near.

title: Wynn Takes Lead at 135 In Phoenix
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 11Bob Wynn of Xenia, Ohio, who has been on the pro golf tour for four years, led a tourney for the first time today with a sevenunderpar 36hole total of 135 in the $150,000 Phoenix open. A 67 gave the Ohioan a onestroke edge over Miller Barber, the World open champion, and 12 over Tom Weiskopf, who failed to qualify.

title: Beame Goes It Alone On Taxi Unit Chief; Council Overlooked
description: Already beset by appointment difficulties, the Beame administration discovered yesterday that the Mayor had put another appointee to work without first getting the required confirmation from the City Council.

title: Henry Williams, 79, Dead; Wrote More Than 70 Books
description: SHERMAN, Conn., Jan. 11Henry Lionel Williams, author of more than 70 books covering a wide range of subjects, died Wednesday in New Mil; ford Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived here.

title: HOUSE INQUIRY SEEN ON SUMED BANK LOAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (Reuters)  A Congressional panel will investigate the justification for Government approval of controversial United States financing plan for the 209mile twin oil pipeline in Egypt, sources said today.

title: A Smoking Program Yields Some Encouraging Data
description: In the 10 years since the Surgeon General of the Public Health Service condemned cigarette smoking as a major health hazard, health officials have discovered that this pervasive habit is extremely difficult to control, both on an individual and on a national level.

title: Antiques: Miniature Marvelsof Japanese Sculpture
description: Small enough to disappear in the palm of a clenched fist and light enough to be outweighed by a letter mailed with a few eightcent stamps, netsukes are Lilliputian wonders that the Japanese devised centuries before they produced transistors.

title: A Word to the Arabs Tisk Is Kicking Up a Storm
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9A comment by Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger that there was a risk that military power might be used against the Arabs if oil curbs become really severe has aroused a storm of protest in the Middle East.

title: GLOOM PREVAILS OFF BROADWAY
description: As a Sunday midnight strike deadline approached, both the Actors Equity Association and the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers reported no meaningful progress in talks on the major wagedemand issues yesterday.

title: BUDGET EXPERTS FEAR RISE OF 13% IN PROPERTY TAX
description: An increase in the city's basic realestate tax, possibly as much as 13 per cent, was predicted yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission after Controller Harrison J. Goldin officially cstimated that the cost of debt service to the city in the fiscal year beginning next July 1 would be $1.848billion.

title: A MILITARY RING LINKED TO SPYING ON WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11The White House investigative unit known as the plumbers uncovered evidence in late 1971 that a ring of military officers was attempting to relay highly classified information on the China talks and other matters to officials in the Pentagon, wellinformed sources report.

title: Wilson Names Gulotta Presiding Justice Here
description: ALBANY, Jan. 11  Governor Wilson today designated Justice Frank A. Gulotta, associate justice of State Supreme Court, to succeed Justice Samuel Rabin as presiding justice of the Appellate Division. Second Department.

title: PRAVDA SCORES A PLANNING GROUP
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 11Pravda,In a major commentary urging greater efficiency for the sluggish Soviet economy, took the unusual step today of criticizing the prestigious State Planning Committee and Communist party officials for interfering too much in the daily operations of Soviet industrial enterprises.

title: Romantic Nine Artists/Coenties Slip
description: In the history of art, certain physical locations, acquire an aura Of, romance especially if they are asso ciated with periods of obsecurity and struggle in the lives of artists. who afterward attain a widespread renown It helps, too, if the original buildings occupying the location in question are demolished or otherwise radically altered. Myth flourishes in the absence of mundane physical evidence.

title: The Wrong House Gets A Basement Full of Oil
description: A Bronx resident got some unneeded heating oil yesterday, when 200 gallons were mistakenly dumped in his basement. The resident had converted to gas eight years ago.

title: Blue Cross and Blue Shield Plan to Merge Operations
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield have agreed in principle merge their operations so that one agency will be able be more efficient and possibly more economical in providing insurance to help pay hospital and physicians bills.

title: ExInmate of Soviet Camp Backs Solzhenitsyn's Book
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 11A former inmate of Soviet labor camps today issued an open letter of support for the general theme of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's work. The Gulag Archipelago, 19181956.

title: DuPont Walston Studies Ways to End Its Losses
description: The executive committee of the board of directors of DuPont Walston, Inc., met at length yesterday afternoon to consider what the big securities house might do to end the Josses  estimated at $10.2million  that it has incurred over the last six months.

title: Argonaut Aide Quits
description: TORONTO, Jan. 11 (AP)Greg Barton resigned his frontoffice job today with the Toronto Argonauts of the Canadian Football League. The Argonauts said Barton, who had been director of Canadian player personnel, was expected to seek a playing job with one of the new World Football League teams.

title: U.N.Truce Force Reports 2Day Risein Suez Clashes
description: CAIRO, Jan. 11The United Nations command today reported a marked increase in the military activities of Egyptian. and Israeli forces on the Suez front during the two days preceding Secretary of State Kissinger's arrival on his third visit to Egypt and Israel.

title: Young Americans to Appeal Life Sentences in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 11 (AP)Three young Americans sentenced to life imprisonment on drug charges plan to appeal their cases as soon as the judges make public their explanation of their verdict, according to the Turkish lawyer representing the three.

title: Trenton Grand Jury Hears Evidence On Fatal Scalding of State Prisoner
description: TRENTON, Jan. 11The case of a Trenton State Prison inmate scalded to death in his cell two weeks ago while guards allegedly ignored his screams for help was presented to grand jury here today by the Mercer County Prosecutor's Office.

title: I.B.M. WILL REALIGN COMPUTER DIVISION
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday a corporate realignment that would put under one roof all development, manufacturing, service, and marketing of certain smallsized computers.

title: Schlitz Plans Expansion
description: The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company announced yesterday that Schlitz planned to expand its facilities in WinstonSalem, N. C. Construction is expected to begin shortly, with completion scheduled for late 1975.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $793million, up 17 per cent over la:A year's $678million. Total retail store sales were about $8.456 billion, up 11 per cent over last year's $7.601 billion.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Ehrlichman and Jaworski Deny Any Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 Both the special Watergate prosecutor and an attorney for John D. Ehrlichman denied today that the former Presidential assistant was engaged in pleabargaining.

title: TAY HOHOFF,AUTHOR, LIPPINCOTT OFFICER
description: Mrs. Therese von Hohoff Torrey, author and editor known professionally as Tay Hohoff, who retired last year as a vice president of the J. B. Lippincott Company, died in her sleep last Saturday night at her home, 120 East 34th Street. She was 75 years old and was the widow of Arthur H. Torrey.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
State to Audit Operations Of School District 1 Here
description: The State Controller's office will start an audit next week of the entire financial operations of the controversyridden Community School District 1 on the Lower East Side.

title: CITY IN PAY PACTS WITH POLICE UNITS
description: New oneyear agreements between the city and three police groups were announced yesterday.

title: Legislation to Aid Rail Car Builders
description: One of the prime beneficiaries of the Transportation Improvement Act, proposed Thursday in Washington by Secretary of Transportation Claude S. Brincgar, would be the railroad car builders.

title: KISSINGER HOPING TO SPEED ACCORD
description: ASWAN, Egypt, Jan. 11Secretary of State Kissinger arrived here tonight on his latest mission to the Middle East hoping to persuade Egypt and Israel to agree to some general principles for negotiating an accord on separating their forces near the Suez Canal.

title: Wider Hold Indicated
description: The $1.2billion American International Group of New York received state approval yesterday to increase its holdings to more than 10 per cent of the stock of the $500million American Reinsurance Company. American Reinsurance, the nation's secondlargest reinsurer after the General Reinsurance Company, is already 9.9 per centowned by American International.

title: Ted Poston, Veteran Reporter, Dies
description: Ted Poston, a journalist for more than 40 years whose byline appeared in The New York Post for 33 of those years, died yesterday at his home, 101 Chauncey Street in Brooklyn's BedfordStuyvesant area. He was 67 years old.

title: Subpoenas Prepared
description: Frustrated by the lack of precise information concerning the supplies and distribution of gasoline and heating fuels, officials of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have begun legal action aimed at wresting such information from the major oil companies.

title: Business Records
description: Petition flied by:

title: JAPAN CURTAILING INDUSTRIES FUEL
description: TOKYO, Jan. 11The Japanese Government announced a mandatory energysaving program today requiring industry to reduce its use of Oil and eledtriaity by 5 to 15 per cent until the end of February.

title: Wynn Takes Lead at 135 In Phoenix
Nixon Drafts Messages And Golfs With Rebozo
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 11 (Reuters)  President Nixon played golf and worked on major messages to Congress today.

title: GOLDIN REQUESTS A LARGER STAFF
description: Controller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that he needed an additional 45 accountants to uncover possible fiscal irregularities in city agencies by timely audits and to reduce the backlog of statutory audits.

title: RISE IN PHONE RATE IS STAYED BY COURT
description: TRENTON, Jan. 11The Appellate Division of Superior Court today turned down a request by attorneys representing the public interest to stay $17million New Jersey Bell Telephone Company rate increase that went into effect Jan. 1.

title: ILLEGALITY IS LAID TO COST COUNCIL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  A Federal Court ruled today that the Cost of Living Council had been illegally withholding financial information submitted by the nation's largest corporations to justify price increases.

title: And While He's Up, Get Me That Grant
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 11 (UN)Bud Grant places the blame for his stoic reputation along the sidelines on the national television cameras.

title: Market Place Pension Trusts: A Bleak Qutlook
description: The Wall Street community Is stirring with speculation that the major New York City bank pension trusts will show abysmal performances for 1973 as a result of their commitment to the socalled nifty50 stocks, which have suddenly and dramatically fallen out of favor.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
Delaware to Investigate Release Of Man Who Then Killed Four
description: DOVER, Del., Jan. 11 (UPI) Gov. Sherman W. Tribbitt ordered today an investigation into a court's release last week of a man who yesterday murdered four people and wounded three others before killing himself.

title: PRICES IN REBOUND ON AMEX AB OTC
Mine Journal to Go on Sale
description: BUCKHANNON, W. Va., Jan. 11 (AP)Arnold Miller, president of the United Mine Workers, says the union's UMW Journal will be sold on newsstands so the public can get first hand the union's views on industry problems. He also announced at a seminar on coal at West Virginia Wesleyan College yesterday that the U.M.W. planned a fuel and energy conference in Washington in the I near future.

title: Delay in Expansion Is Seen by Rozelle
description: HOUSTON, Jan, 11Commissioner Pete Rozelle said today that the lifting of the ,local television blackouts last Season, and the resulting increase in numbers of ticketholders who failed to show up for the games, might postpone a proposed expansion of the National Football League from 26 teams to 30.The owners, said Rozelle at his annual preSuper Bowl news conference, are concerned about the 63 per cent increase in noshows and vhat effect the blackout lift will have on the sale of this year's season tickets. They are also concerned about the dilution of television income should more teams be added.

title: Dance: Ballet Theater
ILLEGALITY IS LAID TO COST COUNCIL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  A Federal Court ruled today that the Cost of Living Council had been illegally withholding financial information submitted by the nation's largest corporations to justify price increases.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MORZINE, France, Jan. 11 (UPI)Bob Cochran said today the United States Alpine ski team's steppedup training should start paying off in tomorrow's World Cup downhill race here. Cochran, 21 years old of Richmond, Vt., will be out to match or better his sisters, Lindy, 20, and Barbara, 23, who took runnerup spots in the girl's World Cup races this week at nearby Les Gets. The sevenman United States downhill squad rested as rain and fog prevented the nonstop practice today.

title: Tables to Delight the Young Set
description: Tiffany has turned Its tablesetting attentions to children. The charmer in the group is a setting for a little girls tea party, with organdy napkins and silver appointments and Limoges china, if you please. Next to the bigger table is a tiny one set with a miniature of the larger silver teapot and exquisite Flora Danica cups and saucers. For dolls, of course. Streamers of confetti rippling down over a buffet table lend a festive air to a setting for a birthday party. On the table is an icefilled silver bowl holding bottles of Coke, rows of glasses, a crystal bowl brimming with candy, a pile of party hats and noisemakers, and, of course, a big birthday cake, hidden behind a pile of gaily, wrapped presents. The other settings, ranged along the second and third floors, include dinner at Grandma's, a lunch for boys and aftersehool milk and cookies. They will be on display through Feb. 20.

title: Contract Awards
