description: Alpha Portland Industries, Inc., said yesterday that a subsidiary was successful low bidder as a coventurer in a $54.3million contract to build a portion of the New York subway system. The Grow Tunneling Corporation, a subsidiary of Alpha's Slattery Associates, Inc., is coventurer to build a 1,275foot tunnel through solid rock one hundred feet deep on East 63d Street from Fifth Avenue to Park Avenue.

title: Knicks Win Holzman Ties Club Mark
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 11Forced to struggle during the, last three minutes because a pair of technicals and the ejection of Phil Jackson let the Seattle Sonics rally to within 7 points, the New York Knicks came away. with a 10798 victory, tonight.

title: Percentage Gains
Art Thieves GoBetween Returns Museum's $15,000
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 11 (AP)The intermediary who negotiated the return to the Taft Museum of two Rembrandt paintings valued at $2million refused a $15,000 finder's fee today.

title: BETHLEHEM SETS PRICE INCREASES
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had notified the Cost of Living Council of price increases on tinmill products and galvanized sheet steel beginning Feb. 16. Bethlehem, which Price fell in line with Changes several other large steel producers led by the United States Steel Corporation, said it planned to raise its tin mill prices by an average of about 7.5 per cent, and its galvanized sheet prices by about 4 per cent.

title: Sugar Quota Is Increased To 12.5 MillionTon High
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (Reuters)The United States, in an effort to check another steep rise in domestic sugar prices, raised today the total amount of sugar that may enter the United States market this year from both domestic and foreign supplies  by 500,000 short tons to a record 12.5 million tons.

title: Opera: Met's Tristan und Isolde
description: TRISTAN UND ISOLDE, opera with music and text by Richard Wagner. Metropolitan Opera production with sets, Projections and costumes designed by Guenther SchneidenSiernssen, Staged by August Eventing. Conducted by Erich Leinsdort.

title: 25 on Bus Rescued
description: MILAN, Tenn., Jan. 11 (UPI) The driver and two dozen passengers of a Continental Trailways bus were rescued through the ig vehicle's windows early today when the bus stalled in floodwaters on state road.

title: 22 YOUTHS ARRESTED IN BRONX GANG RAID
description: Twentytwo members of a South Bronx youth gang were arrested last night after policemen raided their headquarters and found a small stockpile of weapons, the police reported.Among the teenagers seized it 8:05 P.M., in a rundown fivestory tenement at 345 East 39th Street wre two youths suspected of having beaten and robbed a schoolboy earlier yesterday in the neighborhood.

title: Crosby to Have Lung Probe
description: BURLINGAME, Calif., Jan. 11 (AP)Bing Crosby will undergo a probe of his diseased left lung to help pin down the cause of a lesion that has failed to respond to normal treatment, his physician said today. The 69yearold entertainer, hospitalized here on New Year's Eve for pleurisy later diagnosed as pneumonia, was cheerful and walking around talking to other patients at Peninsula Hospitalwith his intravenous tubes following on a rolling pole. His condition remains satisfactory.

title: Reform and Conservative Jews In U.S. Assail an Israeli Party
description: American leaders of Reform and Conservative Judaism accused Orthodox officials in Israel yesterday of stipulating irresponsible conditions for their participation in a new coalition government.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD SUGAR UP DRY PRICE LIMIT
description: Nearby deliveries of world sugar futures jumped the daily limit of 50 points yesterday for the third consecutive session on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. A sugar broker called it a runaway market.

title: U.S. Investigation in Nassau Is Termed a WitchHunt
description: MINEOLA, LI., Jan. 11Nassau County District Attorney William Cahn today termed the Federal Investigation of his office a political witchhunt and called on Governor Wilson to request a State Commission of Investigation review of the matter.

title: Dave Anderson
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 11Shortly before Thanksgiving, one of the older players on the Minnesota Vikings approached Chuck Foreman.

title: Polaroid Sets Module Deal
description: The Polaroid Corporation said late yesterday that Texas Instruments, Inc., would become its sole supplier for two control modules that had been partially supplied by the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation and Texas Instruments.

title: STATE G.O.P. PICKS TODD AS CHAIVIAN
description: TRENTON, Jan. 11Webster B. Todd, the 74yearold patriarch of the New Jersey Republican party, was elected state chairman today as the G.O.P. sought to begin rebuilding, following lopsided election losses in November and the death of its former chairman, John Spoltore, last month.

title: Scott Company Rationing Toilet Paper on East Coast
description: CHESTER, Pa., Jan. 12 (UPI) The Scott Paper Company, the nation's largest manufacturer of toilet paper, has begun rationing its product in major East Coast markets.

title: PAUL E. OWENS
description: Paul E. Owens, executive vice president and a director of A Johnson & Company, Inc., which markets petroleum and other products, died Friday in Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He was 55 years old and lived in Irvington, N. Y.

title: World News Briefs
description: Tanaka Arrives In Malaysia

title: Police Seize Man in Midtown In 2 Unsuccessful Holdups
description: uick police action in midtown yesterday afternoon brought about the arrest of a suspect who admitted the unsuccessful holdups of two two cashiers in movie house boxoffices the authorities reported

title: Bilingual Classes for Puerto Ricans Urged
description: TRENTON  Those Puerto Rican children in New Jersey who are expected to speak English and be American at an early age may also be expected to drop out of school at an early age, according to a recently released report entitled The Puerto Rican Experience, An Educational Research Study.

title: Gibson Running Again, but Not as Black
description: NEWARK  Kenneth A. Gibson, the first black mayor of a major East Coast city, has decided to run for a second term, but not as a black man.

title: There Is No Lack of Volunteers
description: Averell Herriman, Robert Morgenthau, Frank O'Connor and Arthur Goldberg: The whateverhappenedto list crowded with the names of Democrats who have marched up the hill against Nelson Rockefeller and marched down again forlorn.

title: Jaraine'sWhere the Hong Kong Action Is
description: HONG KONG  The rep'spected, tradition encrusted Hong Kong trading house of Jardine, Matheson & Co., Ltd., which evolved from successful narcotics smuggling operation, is evolving againthis time into a kind ::of international conglomer ate.

title: Mercy Killing Trial Opens Tomorrow
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Jan 12 Dr. Vincent Montemarano, a mildmannered physician who is highly regarded both professionally and personally by his peers at the Nassau County Medical Center, Is scheduled to go on trial here Monday on a (murder charge stemming from a socalled mercy killing.

title: The Decline and Fall of the Great American Tip
description: PEOPLE all over Europe are talking these days about , another casualty of last year's currency crisis  the onceliberal American tip.

title: Theodore Rousseau, 19121974
description: To The EDTTOR:

title: An Avenue a Serious Artist Has to Follow
description: THE career of the late John Ferren, who was born in Pendleton, Ore., in 1905 and died in East Hampton, L. I., in 1970, is one of those careers that, in its earnestness and perseverance  and ultimately, I think, its lack of proper recognition  make the creative life seem like nothing so much as an accumulation of bad debts. Ferren was affiliatedthough not wholeheartedly associated  with the New York School which rose to international prominence in the late 1940's and 1950's. He was well respected by his colleagues, taught for considerable periods of his life in New York and California and exhibited regularly. Yet he never achieved the rewards and renown that a contemporary like Jackson Pollock commanded.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Encounter Movement, a Fad Last Decade Finds New Shape
description: BERKELEY, CalitThe encounter group movement, which became something of a national fad in the nineteensixties, has evolved into a new, more mature and gentler form:

title: The White House on I.T.T.
description: In addition to the statement on the milk industry, the White House also issued a white paper on the International Telephone and Telegraph Company's antitrust case. Following are excerpts from the paper.

title: Currencies New World Of Turmoil
description: LONDON  Upheaval and turmoil are becoming almost standard conditions in the world's currency markets. Just as security markets tend to react much more sharply and rapidly than ever before, the currency markets have become highly volatile, particularly with today's system of floating exchange rates.

title: Clues Sought to L.I.Woman's Slayer
description: OCEANSIDE, L.I Jan. 12A police van with a loudspeaker soliciting information patrolled the neighborhood in which Mrs. Barbara Waldman was found slain yesterday.

title: AROUND THE
description: INDOOR FRUIT GROWING

title: Ecumenical Knights of Malta Induct 21 Members in Old Rites Here
description: An elegant gentleman with graying temples and a small mustache breezed Into the First Presbyterian Church on Fifth Avenue the other night to help officiate at the Investiture ceremonies of the Ecumenical Knights of Maltaa fouryearold but littlepublicized offshoot of the honorary philanthropic organization whose roots go back to the Crusades and which, until 1970, had been totally sectarian.

title: JOHN R. SALEMBIER
description: John R. Salembier, who retired in 1968 as executive vice president of Bianchini Ferier, Inc., silk importers here, died yesterday in Halifax, Nova Scotia. He was 68 years old and lived in Parrsboro, N.S., and formerly in Englewood, N.J.

title: To The Rescue Of Broken Trees
description: THOUGH the recent ice storm's miseries of no heat, hot water or electric power have faded, the scars left by nature still show. Trees snapped in two or giant branches split off leaving ragged tears high on the trunks. Or some branches split through hang precariously.

title: Bridal Planned By Dana Esman
description: Dr. and Mrs. Aaron H. Esman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susanna Esman, to Peter Singer. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Singer also of New York.

title: Hannibob Returns $6.80
description: PAWTUCKET, R.I., Jan. 12 (AP)  Hannibob. ridden by Norm Mercier, rallied today to win the Barrington Purse by one length at Narragansett Park. Hannibob paid $6.80. $2.80 and $2.20 after covering the 5 furlongs in !:05 15.

title: Stamps
description: THE United States Postal Service, after a period of stewing, has reached a decision to go ahead with its 1974 plans and introduce officially an additional number of higher rate issues. What gave the Postal Service pause was the ruling of the Cost of Living Council that the postal agency hold up on putting into effect its proposed higher rates for several months.

title: LEGISLATORS FIND CITY OFFICE VITAL
description: Jack E. Bronston operates out of his local political club, Manfred Ohrenstein helps maintain a store front office in an abandoned bar and Leonard P. Stavlaky's home is always open to a constituent with a problem.

title: Quits Go on View as Works of Art
description: CLINTON  Interest in quilts has grown so rapidly over the last few years that even small art museums can mount exhibitions of them and expect a substantial turnout.

title: It Is Distorted by a Bitter Past And a Segregated Present
description: JERUSALEMTwo months after the outbreak of the Yom Kippur war, Israel's Defense Minister Moshe Dayan admitted that he had erred in his evaluation of the fighting ability of the Arabs. The Israeli public had been equally unprepared for the force and effectiveness of the Arab attack. A debate began among historians, journalists, sociologists and politicians on the causes of Israel's refusal to face facts, which were all too clear in retrospect.

title: High Price of Dying Is Eased by L.I. Group
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I.Increasing numbers of Long Islanders are arranging their own funerals through memberships in the Memorial Society of Long Island.for a batch of literature on options at death, preplanning forms for the disposition of the physical remains for all family members and a list of six funeral directors with prices of their least expensive funeral arrangements for a variety of options.neral directors are geographically dispersed from Flushing to Bayport, and Mrs. Lippke said she felt they adequately served the society's membership. No ec tion has been taken on requests of the funeral directors who have recently called to be added to the list.want? like a lot of my buddies.service is a service in the presence of the body and a memorial service is one held after the body has been removed.rather than reidirg a pamphlet and filling out a form.

title: Dr. Ann Marie Bajart Will Marry
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Jan. 12Dr. Ann Marie Bajart and Dr. John Anthony Schemmer, physicians in Boston, plan to marry here Feb. 16 in the St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church.

title: Except in East, Fuel Is Plentifull
description: DETROIT, Jan. 12In most of the United States west of the Alleghenies, the fuel shortage is largely something people read about in the newspapers or hear about on television. It has had relatively little direct effect on daily life.

title: Architecture Some Handsome Architectural Mythology
description: I'M not sure if January is the month for reinforcing or dismantling myths in the process of annual stocktaking, but the occasion of the exhibition at the Jewish Museum called Moshe Siddie: For Everyone a Garden is a good thus to examine some particularly attractive architectural mythology.

title: SHOP TALK
description: LIVINGSTONBefore the traffic lights were installed at the Route 10 circle here, by the time you had got safely around it you would have whizzed past five nice shops, never knowing they were there. Now you can take the time to look for the 150yearold house, painted red with white trim, that contains them, and get in the correct lane, ready to pull over. Look for the Wigs Etcetera sign on the side of the building.

title: Dance Keeping the Choreographer's Dances Alive
description: THERE islegendary joy that comes once in, a while, I suppose, to every regular dancegoer tahotigh, possibly, with great r public sophistiAtion and ouch more gen?? to dance evemnts, the joy is becoming More legendary than ever. However it did once happen to Me. In a small English seaside town, in a tiny theater that had seagulls outside and afternoon tea inside, I eavesdropped with barely eonkilned hilarity on two women in satisfyingly oldfashioned hats deciding how clever it was of the dancers to be able to make it all up as they went along.

title: A PURGED CHINESE LISTED IN TOP RANK
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 12 An official who was purged during the Cultural Revolution from his position as General Secretary and fourthranking member of the Chinese Communist party has now been listed in Peking among the. leaders of the party.

title: Godwin, Now a Republican, Is Sworn to a 2d Term as Virginia Governor
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 12 (UPI) The band played Dixie and national guardsmen fired a 19gun salute today as Mills E. Godwin Jr. was inaugurated Governor of Virginia for the second time.

title: Who Gets What, Why and How
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif.Inadvertently, the White House has added to the textbooks on American government chapters and verse on exactly how political considerations influence Federal policy. The intent has been to place the actions of President Nixon in the most defensible light; the accidental result has been to describe the machinery of government as the prize of contending pressure groupsa description not new but newly documented.

title: U.S. Approves Plan To Replace Checks For Social Security
description: The Social Security Administration and the Treasury Department agreed yesterday on new procedures to speed replacement of Federal income payments to the city's aged, blirid and disabled whose checks were not received because of loss or theft.

title: Equestrian Unit to Seek New Riders
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Ha., Jan. 12The United States Equestrian Teamalways on the lookout for new riders and horseswill intensify its scouting efforts this year .by sending its officials to a group of important shows around the country.

title: Ervin Says Receipt of 5 Tapes Might End Inquiry
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Jan. 12 (AP)Senator Sam. J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, said today that if the White House would give the Senate Watergate committee five tapes of Presidential conversations involving John W. Dean 3d the committee might bring its investigation to a speedy end.

title: Wedge of Ice
description: Now ice becomes the wedge that can level the hills. The slow seep of midday melt creeps into the roilts, into those hairline cracks, and when darkness comes with its deep cold, the seep freezes and opens the crack a little wider. Eventually the root of spring will find a place grow there, and another winter will pry again, and again, until a whole ledge totters.

title: TRANSIT SUBSIDY GAINING SUPPORT
description: ALBANY, Jan. 12  The Republican leadership of the Assembly today endorsed proposal by the staff of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee for a major revision in the state's approach to helping ,localities finance mass transit.

title: Edward Weston: The Eye of Eternity
description: THE writing of the hisory of American art in this century is clearly slated for some significant revisions in the coming decade, and none will be more significant, I believe, than the place assigned to the artistic achievement of certain photographers. We were given an interesting hint of the kind of change I have in mind a feW years ago when, in the course of a review of Barbara Rose's American Art Since 1900 in the scholarly Art Quarter, ly, Charles W. Millard offered the following characterization of American art in the period between the two World Wars: A curious lull during which photography rather than painting produced the major creative talents, notably in the persons of [Alfred] Stieglitz and Edward Weston.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Basketball

title: Should All The Action Be Legal?
description: To what extent should government make gambling legal and take a profit from the action? That question has been raised in New York City by police report showing that since offtrack betting on horse races was established here, illegal betting on other sports and the numbers had increased by about 62 per cent.

title: Joyce Nehemiah Wed to S. J. Rosenthal
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Jan. 12At Temple Israel of New Rochelle this evening, Miss Joyce Lee Nehemiah, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Nehemiah, was married to Steven James Rosenthat, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Rosenthal of New York. Rabbi Amiel Wohl performech,the ceremony.

title: PANEL URGED TO ACT ON CAR WARRANTIES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) The Center for Auto Safety urged the Federal Trade Commission today to prevent auto manufacturers from giving what was termed 'underthetable extensions of new car warIranties.

title: O'Neil Play to Open 2d Season for Queensborough Theater
description: The Professional Theater in Rbsidence of Queensborough Community College, the only such operation on a campus in the New York metropolitan area, will open its second treason Thursday with Eugene O'Neill's Desire Under the Elms.

title: New Tack on Police Reform
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 12 (UPI)James F. Ahern, former New Haven police chief, has called for creation of a national organization of police leaders to initiate police reform, We need a group of police leaders who will not shirk from critieizing instead of glorifying police actions, Mr. Ahern told the national symposium on police ethical practice. at John Jay College in Westport on Wednesday. Mr. Ahern is director of the Insurance Crime PrevirttIon Institute.

title: We Found Our Maturity, But Look That We Lost!
description: I'VE been sitting around trying to think of the last time I saw a really good movie that had nothing to do with serious themes or cultural profundities, a movie that was made for no other reason than to give its audience a couple hotirs of fun. And the only thing I've been able to come up with is Holiday, starring Gary Grant and Katharine Hepburn, which was made in 1938 and which I saw recently in San Francisco, along with Vivacious Lady, an old Jimmy StewartGinger Rogers movie that was also pretty good. not important? Whatever happened to intelligent fluff?

title: A Gestural Artist Exhibits in Summit
description: SUMMIT  Mrs. Irene Krugman, whose works are the subject of a onewoman show at the Summit Art Center, is what is known as a

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: WHOLESALE PRICES rose 2.2 per cent in December, bringing the increase for all 1973 to 18.2 per cent. Industrial commodities rose 14.8 per cent in the year, chiefly because of a 65 per centrise for fuel and power, a 32.5 per cent rise for nonferrous metals and a 52.4 per cent rise for cotton products... Commerce Department says business plans invest total of $112.11billion for new plant and equipment in 1974, up 12 per cent from last year. The rise in 1973 was 13.2 per cent.

title: Boston Group Gives Boating to Public
description: Municipal governments always have been willing to sink funds into new public golf courses, tennis courts and community swimming pools. But unlike his favored landlubber neighbors, the sailor has had to fend for himself, buy his own craft and pay for docking facilities at a private club or public dock.

title: Soprano From Brooklyn Triumphs at Met
description: When Klara Barlow was a 17yearold student in Brooklyn, she saw her first opera. It was Wagner's Tristan and Isolde at the Metropolitan Opera House and the Isolde was Astrid Varney, the distinguished SwedishAmerican soprano. In 1967, Miss Barlow herself sang her first Isolde stepping it after Miss Varney had sung the first performances of a new production in Kiel, Germany.

title: Canadiens Triumph, 7.3, End Bruins Home String
description: BOSTON, Jan. 12 (UPI)Frank Mahovlich scored two goals and made two assists today as the Montreal Canadiens beat the Boston Bruins, 7.3, in a nationally televised National Hockey League gante.

title: THEATER OPENINOS
description: FELIX Cherry Lane, 7. A play by Chide. WNW.

title: SANE Unit Still Active Despite Shift In Its Role
description: MONTCLAIR  The visitor to the SANE office was a young black from the slums who had been drafted into the Away, although he had a pregnant commonlaw wife and a child.

title: Victoria Grandchild Dies
description: BAGSHOT, England, Jan. 12 (UPI)Lady Patricia Ramsay, a granddaughter of Queen Victoria, died today at her home after a long illness, a Buckingbam Palace spokesman said. She was 87 years old. Her death left Princess Alice, Countess of Athlone, as the only living grandchild of Victoria.

title: Motor From the Past May Be Key to the Future
description: STRATFORD, Conn.  In the machine shop of the Olsen Marine complex here on the banks of the Housatonic River a line of Bearcat outboard motors Is assembled for winter storage and maintenance. With the shortage of gasoline, which may dramatically change recreational boating habits, these motors take on a special quality on two counts.

title: Fashion: Byebye bikini
description: After many a summer and winter of bikinidotted beaches, there is a hint (it comes from the manufacturers) that the tide is turning back to one pieceswimsuits that are exactly that, suitstoswim in. Onemorehint January is when smart swimmers buy bathing suits because that's when the greatest selection is in the stores.

title: Photography
description: TWO current books Gilles Larrain's Idols and Anne Tucker's The Woman's Eye  explore the relationship of sex and sensibility from almost diametrically opposed standpoints.

title: The Secret Life of Our Times
description: By conventional standards, Gordon Lish's anthology of short stories collected from Esquire takes a great risk: beyond Lish's belief that his writers all went through some bad times to discover something new, it has no unifying theme to connect the disparate imaginative visions it presents. The only organizing principle is Lish's own literary taste:

title: HalfFare Program Here Extended Through June
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday that it was extending its experimental Sunday halffare program through June 30, saying it had been a resounding success and that it had drawn an average of 600,000 extra subway, bus and train riders on each of the four Sundays it had been tried.

title: New Novel
description: Chaim Bermant's family chronicle is as different from the usual familial novel as a chocolate mousse is from a brownie. It has a greater complexity of ambivalences, cunningly blended to achieve a marvelous coherence. The novel commences with the death of a Jewish matriarch, and the traditional seven day wake, held in her conveniently large house in Hampstead (One could manage with a minimum of lebensraum but dying called for space.) Tanya Coggan had four brothers, a sister three sons, a daughter and assorted secondary relations. Each is richly characterized by James, Tanya's 43yearold son a university don in a state of crisis.

title: Doctors Propose Tests to Learn Value of DMSO, a Mystery Drug
description: A hard second look at DMSO, one of the most mysterious and controversial drugs known, has led a group of doctors to urge their colleagues to undertake detailed experiments to determine the full range of its poOctal benefits to patients.

title: Richardson Busy, but Goal Is Unclear
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12Elliot L. Richardson, who held three different seats in the Nixon Cabinet before resigning the Attorney General's office in the Watergate case, now has private law office here and $25,000 fellowship at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars.

title: Times Hard for LongDistance Auto Commuters
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I. Howard Lebwith donned thermal underwear and two pairs of socks before boarding the Long Island Rail Road's 6:16 A.M.'train, Which is diesel powered and reaches. Penn Station at 9:14.

title: Julio Heurtematte Jr. Is Fiance Of Miss Marie Jeanne Connelly
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 12Miss Marie Jeanne Connelly, fashion director of the Hecht Company, department store in Washington, and Julio Ernesto Heurtematte Jr., who is with the projects analysis department of the InterAmerican Development Bank in Washington, will be married in Marca.

title: FUEL IS BECOMING A CAMPAIGN ISSUE
Matheson Is Key to Miami 53 Defense
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 12The secret to the success of the Miami Dolphins defense often has been attributed to its socalled 53 defense.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: The Mayor of Charlotte has an inner glow these days, even though his normally taciturn nature tends to conceal it.

title: MACKELL FACING TRIAL TOMORROW Nadjari in Personal Charge of Prosecution Team
description: Thomas J. Mackell, the former District Attorney of Queens, goes on trial tomorrow for allegedly blocking the prosecution of a $4million getrichquick scheme in which many of his staff had invested money.

title: Marine Wig Ban Upheld
description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 12 (UPI) Federal District Judge W. Terrell Hodges has affirmed the Marine Corps right to ban the wearing of wigs by corps personnel. The order ended court fight that began last August when a suit challenging the constitutionality of the antiwig policy was filed by two Tampa reservists who argued that shorthair wigs satisfied Marine Corps appearance requirements by covering nonregulation haircuts.

title: More Firsts for Kollar
description: MOBILE, Ala. Jan. 12 (UPI) When Bill Kollar of Montana State was named the most valuable player in the Senior Bowl today. he added two more firsts to his lists. He was the first player from his school in the annual game, and became the first defensive lineman to win the award a car which is the first he a. had ever owned.

title: Rich Man In a Poor Community
description: BANGKOK, ThailandWhen the black limousine carrying Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan approached the stately gray Erawan Hotel here last week, it was thronged by Thai students. Bobbing in the crowd of about 3,000 young men and women were placards accusing the Japanese of, among other things, economic imperialism. One placard said: Asia is Japan's slave.

title: DEMOCRATS FEEL GURNEY CAN LOSE
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 12 Leaders of the Florida Democratic party are convinced that Senator Edward J. Gurney, under investigation by two Federal grand juries and the Justice Department in an alleged political extortion racket, has lost stature with the state's voters to the point where he can be beaten this year should he seek reelection.

title: THE DUTCH RATION GASOLINE FOR CARS
description: AMSTERDAM, Jan, 12The Netherlands began rationing gasoline for private use today. Nine weeks ago, when the country became the first in Europe to ban Sunday driving, the Dutch people, angered by the Arab oil boycott, accepted the restriction with a chinup demonstration of national unity. But now, as reports continue to appear that storage tanks in Rotterdam harbor are full of oil, few Dutchmen think that rationing is necessary and most believe it will last no more than a month or two.

title: The N.Y.NonAthletic Club: YoHoHo and HoHoHum
description: The sports coverage of this esteemed journal is, logically enough, estimable. Where else can you keep in touch with 18.2 balkline billiards, sculling on the Henley, or the court tennis career of Pierre Etchebaster? The space gives to less esoteric pastimes, such as bowling, trapshooting and intramural Ivy League football is considerably bigger than a breadbasket. But there one class of readers that is systematically neglected  indeed, ignored  by The Times and other news organs. It comprises a substantial silent minority and deserves better than it gets.

title: A Governor Wins Court Plea
description: PIERRE, S. D., Jan. 12 (AP)The South Dakota Supreme Court has ruled 4 to 1 that Gov. Richard F. Kneip may seek a third term. Mr. Kneip had challenged a state primary election law that prevents a person from being nominated by a political party for a third term as Governor.

title: The St. Louis U. secret in Soccer: Relaxed Talent
description: It was past midnight and the players were still out, most of them at the dog races. Harry Keough, their coach, was sitting in the lobby of the hotel talking about his dog, Barkley, and didn't appear to be concerned about his players or the game his team, St. Louis University, had to play for the National Collegiate Athletic Association title the next evening.

title: Rangers Defeat Canucks In Coach Francis's Return
Cox and his army
description: One muggy midsummer night, Archibald Cox tossed restlessly on his bed in Georgetown, fretting over the mounting confrontation with the President on executive privilege. In the morning he told one of his aides about his insomnia.

title: It's a Rich Play, Richly Performed
description: COLLEEN Dewhurst is a beautiful woman giving a beautiful performance in the newest revival of Eugene O'Neill's A Moon for the Misbegotten (which also just happens to be a beautiful play, possibly O'Neill's best), and I find nothing more fetching about her performance than her witchlike way with an unfinished sentence.

title: Rabbinical Council Deplores Groups'
description: The Rabbinical Council of America, a prominent Orthodox body, scored American leaders of Conservative and Reform Judaism for interfering with Israel's democratic political structure.

title: France I Modified for 2d Attempt at Trophy
description: PARISThe first America's Cup challenge by Baron Marcel Bich ended with the France I lost in a fog four years ago. The second challenge hasn't been doing much better,

title: Alan Linsky Marries Miss Cheryl C. Watt
description: NEW CANAAN Conn., Jan. 12Miss Cheryl Creighton Watt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip C. Watt of New Canaan and Waretown, N. J., and Alan Leonard Linsley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Linsky of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., were married here this afternoon at Waveny House. The Rev. Grant A. Morrill of St. Mark's Episcopal Church performed the ceremony, and Rabbi Samuel Silver of Temple Sinai of Stamford gave a blessing.

title: Notes: Over the Border Gas Pumps Are Fuller
description: WHILE Americans continue to wonder whether the fuel shortage will prevent them from using their automobiles on vacation trips in the United States this year, drivers in Canada and Mexico say that the only thing they have had to worry about is the cost of fuel, not its availability.

title: Queens Five Loses To Chinese Women
description: Tai Yuen, a women's basketball team from China, defeated Queens College, 59.56, in an exhibition game at the Pace University gym last night.

title: ANTHONY F. VACHRIS, LED BUILDING FIRM
description: ROSLYN ESTATES, L.I., Jan. 12Anthony F. Vachris, former president of Charles F. Vachris, Inc., and the Vacar Construction Corporation, died yesterterday of a heart attack at his home here. His age was 61

title: You Simply Can't Do It on Eyebrows Alone
description: WASHINGTON  January started with a trilogy of disappointments. Kohoutek, Secretariat and Sam Ervin all pooped out.

title: Son to Mrs. W. T. Curry
description: A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. William T. Curry of New York on Dec. 20 in the LyingIn Division of the New York Hospital,

title: South Korea Police Detain and Harass Opposition Leaders
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 12 In a harsh crackdown after a month of liberalization, President Park Chung Hee's Government has detained at least half a dozen opposition leaders and assigned the police to accompany more than 20 others on a 24houraday basis.

title: Mt. Vernon Schools Fight Bias Charge
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 12The Mount Vernon school board decided yesterday to challenge a recent ruling that it practices segregation by assigning most of its black teachers to schools in the district with predominantly black students.

title: Cambodian ExPremier Urges Lon Nol to Leave the Country
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 12 (UPI)Former Premier Son Sann, a respected neutralist in the war between the Cambodian Government and Communistled insurgents, urged President Lon Nol today to leave the country so a peace accord can be reached.

title: Joseph Cohen to Wed Ellen Leslie
description: WOODMERE, L. I., Jan, 12 The engagement of Miss Ellen Ann Leslie to Joseph Alan Cohen has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Seymour M. Leslie, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Cohen of Troy, N. Y.

title: How French Women Got That WayAnd How To Handle Them
description: IN FRANCE, the plumber will speak only to monsieur. He has always spoken to monsieur C'est conune ca. Although the French Revolution Was supposed to have liberated all citoyens and citoyennes in 1789, the Napoleonic Code relegated women to the status of minors and convicts, and they are just emerging. French women didn't get the right to vote until 1945the only other European countries, to giant that right later were Italy, Belgium and Switzerland. They then had to wait until 1965 to open bank accounts without their husbands permission and until 1968 to buy contraceptives.

title: Mayor Goes Nautical at the Boat Show
description: With strains of the Marseillaise emanating yesterday morning from the Coliseum, Mayor Beame standing out in the cold talking on a telephone and models in short skirts looking as if they were freezing, one had a right to be confused.

title: 21% IN HOUSE LEAN TOWARD IMPEACHING
description: SILVER SPRING, Md, Jan. 12 (UPI)Twentyone per cent of the members of the House have decided to vote yes or are leaning toward a yes vote if they are presented with the question of impeaching President Nixon, according to a survey released today by the National Observer.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: A collection of critical essays on the works of Claude McKay, Richard Wright, Gwendolyn Brooks, Langston Hughes, James Baldwin, Ralph Ellison and other black writers. George Kent's concern, as his title suggests, is the effect of Western culture on the black sensibilitythe reflection of W. E. B. DuBois's double consciousness in the works of the writers considered and their struggle to maintain black rhythms while acquiring the formal instruments of Western culture. The essays are clearly written, and fully accessible to the general reader. Kent mixes the traditional approaches to literary criticism with interpretation in terms of black folklore, myth and music.

title: Fire Destroys Ohira's Home
description: TOKYO, Jan. 12 (Reuters)Fire destroyed the private onestory wooden residence of Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira of Japan here today. No casualties Were reported. Mr. Ohira was visiting Kagawa Prefecture in western Japan, when the fire broke out this afternoon, the police said. The cause of the fire was not immediately known.

title: Firestorm
Dolphins Choice Over Vikings In Today's Super Showdown
Judith Shaffer Is Bride
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Jan. 12  In the Rooke Chapel at Bucknell University here this afterhoon, Miss Judith Ann Shaffer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Raeford Shaffer of Mifflinburg, was married to Craig Monroe Shoemaker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Perry Monroe Shoemaker of Tampa, Fla., formerly of Westfield, N. J. The Presbyterian ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gordon F. Kurtz. The bridegroom's father retired as president of the Central Railroad Company,of New Jersey.

title: SAMUELS AND REID ASSAIL STATE G.O.P.
description: In speeches critical of the Rockefeller and Wilson state administrations, Howard J. Samuels and Representative Ogden Reid made bids yesterday for support of the New Democratic Coalition in their campaigns for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: Turnpike Phone Numbers
description: BOSTON, Jana 12 (AP)The Massachusetts Turnpike Authority ;announced this week that motorists may call any of four special telephone numbers to find out latest conditions on the highway. The numbers, which will be in operation 24 hours a day, are, in Boston: 2375210; Worcester: 7913316; Chicopee: 593.6648, and Lenox: 6372555.

title: Saudi Warns Against Bloc of Oil Users
description: ROME, Jan. 12  Saudi Arabia's Minister of Petroleum Affairs, Sheik Ahmed Zaki alYemeni, today warned oilconsuming nations against forming a bloc that might clash with producing countries in a headon confrontation.

title: Letters To the
description: Editor

title: OBSTACLES SEEN FOR MERGER PUN
description: MADRID, Jan. 12The announcement today of a union between Tunisia and Libya caused general surprise among specialists in North African politics, who said that the unnatural elements in such a marriage would appear to outweigh the advantages that both sides might draw from it.

title: Miss Tondel Has Nuptials
description: Miss Marcia Jean Tondel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lyman M. Tondel Jr. of Tenafly, N. J., was married in Beckington, England, yesterday to Peter Colin Davis, son of Mr: and Mrs. John Colin Davis of Tilford, England. The ceremony was performed in St, George's Church by the Rev; W. T. H. B. Davis.

title: Nursing Home Curbs Voted
description: Stronger controls on the Construction of new nursing home facilities in the large areas of Brooklyn and Queens were put into effect by New York City last week, But the question of, additional space for, a controversial project on Otean Parkway in the Kensington area was deferred until at least Jan. 24.

title: Romanesques Are Definitely In
description: CALVIN TOMSINS

title: People and Business Voiceprinter Is Made in Princeton
description: A Somerville inventor and a Princeton manufacturing concern have Joined forces to produce what they describe as a new crimefighting tool. The inventor is Lawrence G. Kersta, the company is Base Pen Systems, Inc., and the device is called a voiceprinter.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Protagonist and Talking Picture, respectively the juvenile colt and filly champions of 1973, shared the place honor in the Experimental Free Handicap weights announced yesterday by The Jockey Club. Protagonist was assigned 126 pounds for what once was an actual race but now is used solely as an evaluation of what may be expected of juveniles when they race as 3yearolds.

title: Advertising Regulations Tightened in Nassau
description: MINEOLA, L.I.  The Nassau County Office of Consumer Affairs has adopted four new regulations under Its Home Improvement Licensing law to give the consumer a fighting chance in the purchase of home improvement services, James E. Picken, the Commissioner, Announced last week.

title: Variable Oil Tariff Road to Independence?
description: WASHINGTONGeorge P. Shultz, a man who used wear a jacket and who halt been a free trader in his bones; now sits in a loose sweater by a fire in his lovely old office of the Secretary of the Treasury and talks about the need for variable levies on oil imports for the indefinite future.

title: Plans to Save Energy
description: TRENTONThe new Democratic Legislature will study a package of energyconservation measures this year, including a proposal that would require public utilities to install insulation in the homes their customers.

title: Fuel Shortage May Be The Excuse to Cut Back
description: Allegheny Airlines Flight 695 for years served as a commuter service between steel country and automobile country; it provided a convenient midafternoon link to Detroit for traveling businessmen and residents of Youngstown, Ohio. But last week, Flight 695along with two of the three other daily Allegheny flights that serviced Youngstownvanished from timetables.

title: Budget Proposals Reflect Local Needs
description: Chairmen of community planning boards in Brooklyn and Queens expressed satisfaction last week with the way in which their suggested priority items were included in the capital budget that was presented to Mayor Beanie by the City Planning Commission on Jan. 3.

title: Smaller Than Exxon But Bigger Than Ireland
description: Seven great international companies control most of the world's production and distribution of oil; five of those companies are based in the United States and their games are literally household wordssometimes children can read the word Shell before they can read anything else.

title: Activist Accused in Killing Being Held at San Quentin
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 12 (UPI)An antiwar activist accused of the assassination of School Superintendent Marcus Foster was held today in protective custody At San Quentin Prison.

title: Music; Can Ormandy Tell Boulez What to Play?
description: WRITES a reader: NI gwould like to sugest something. As you have undoubtedly noted, we New Yorkers ,have been drowned the past few years in Mahler and Bruckner. It seems that there is no correlation at all between the various orchestras that visit New York each season. For example, Maazel and Cleveland did the Mahler Sixth, and Solti is doing it this year. Since Szell did it in 1969, I have counted at least 12 performance) of this. Solti, Barenboim have ,done the Seventh the past three years and Maazel is doing it this year. I think a Sunday piece on this would be well received, since many of us attend the concerts by these visiting orchestras. I would personally see that copies got to the appropriate orchestra managers.

title: Miss Cynthia Ramsing Bride Of Charles Robert McGinnes
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 12In the Dingletown Community Church here this afternoon, Miss Cynthia Hartford Ramsing was married to Charles Robert McGinnes by the Rev. Harry Mania.

title: Food: Three times orange equals... By Jean Hewitt
description: Triply orange, this frozen souffl (recipe below) contains orange rind (grated and in the form of candied slivers), that heady essence of orange, Grand Marnier, and fresh orange juice. It is an elegant and easy addition to a host or hostess's repertory. Since it's frozen, this souffl won't fall which means a. dinner party does not have to run on a splitsecond schedule to come out even with the souffl that is rising in the oven. This one can even be made a day or two beforehand and stored in the freezer.

title: Indiana Swim Victor
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Jan. 12 (UPI)  Indiana's swimming team, defending champion of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, posted its 92d straight dual meet triumph tonight, routing Ohio State, 9032.

title: How to Make a Pop Parody
description: TROLLERS down Broadway have to make a conscious effort in order to ignore the photograph of Jobriath plastered across a billboard perched high above Duffy Square. This specterlike trafficstoppera. huge blowup of the record jacket design of the composer's debut album, Jobriath (Elektra EKS75070) pictures the young man as a decaying statue turned over on its side.

title: Feature at Anita To Ancient Title
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP)Ancient Title grabbed the lead at the quarter pole, opened a sixlength margin and then held off a stirring stretch rally by the favorite, Linda's Chief, today to win the $57,300 Malibu Stakes at Santa Anita.

title: Peterson Wins Pole Position
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 12 (AP)  Ronnie Peterson of Sweden captured the pole position today for tomorrow's Argentine Grand Prixthe first race counting toward this year's world drivers championship.

title: Richard Golber to Wed Sandra Scherer
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich., Jan. 12Mr. and Mrs. Martin L. Scherer of Birmingham, formerly of Scarsdale, N. Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra O. Scherer of New Rochelle, N. Y., to Richard Joel Golber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Golber of Short Hills, N. J. A wedding in May is plannned.

title: Opposition to Fuel Projects Is Softening
description: PERTH AMBOYThe critcal shortages of fuel oil and gasoline, coupled with growing unemployment resulting from the energy crisis, appear to be taking the edge off local opposition to the construction of fuel pipelines and oilstorage and refining facilWes in New Jersey communities.

title: JAWORSKI TO DENY PRESIDENT'S DATA TO HOUSE INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12Leon Jaworski, citing legal restrictions, has indicated he will not make the mass of material collected by his office available to the Congressional inquiry into the Impeachment of President Nixon.

title: Westmoreland Faces Decision On Entering Carolina Politics
description: CHARLESTON S.C., Jan 12  Chin in, chest out and standing sentry tall, he still looks like COMUSMACV Coinmander, United States Military Command, Vietnam.

title: Selected Poems 19571967
description: Crow (1971), the most recent volume of the English poet Ted Hughes, was well received here as the ingenious, wacky, raucous, extravagantly bitter, shock minded book that it is Now Hughes has brought forward 67 poems from his first three volumes"The Hawk in the Rain (1957), Lupercal (1960) and Wodwo (1967)as if to remind us that he is more than Ted Crow. Indeed he is, thought the rest too, however feathered, is beaked and grim: a will to outskip a world of buckshot.

title: OneMan Jet Set Swings Around the CanineWorld
description: On the international dog show scene there's a Brazil ian swinger. He swings from country to country, either judging or conferring with canine world notables. He is rotund, agile Dr. Antonino Barone of Forzano. He arrived from Rio de Janeiro to attend the recent Philadelphia show. En route, he judged in Colombia and Chile, attended a demonstration of dogs in Panama, and ruled in four Mexican rings. In between, he made a flight to Ethiopia, where he met with officials in Asmara.

title: MANILA STRESSES COMMUNIST PERIL
description: MANILA, Jan. 12Philippine Communists have regrouped after brief disorganization following the martiallaw crackdown late in 1972 and again pose the main threat to national skupity, according to a report released today by the armed forces.

title: LOBBYING SCORED ON GIFT BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12Reppresentative Hugh L. Carey, Democrat of Brooklyn, charged today that President Nixon had illegally used an individual who was on the Government payroll to ,influence legislation for the President's own personal benefit.

title: L.S.U. Ends Vanderbilt Streak at 11
description: BATON ROUGE, La,, Jan. 12 (AP)  Louisiana State's Glenn Hansen led a secondhalf surge and finished with 23 points to power the Tigers over sixthranked and previously unbeaten Vanderbilt, 84.81, tonight.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: SHOP TALK
description: Things aren't always What they seem at Mark Desio, 130 East 65th Street. Cocktail tables masquerade as layer cakes, ottomans look like marshmallows and sculptured wooden hands turn out to be chairs.

title: Port Conway Lane Wins For $33.80 Bowie Payoff
description: BOWIE, Md., Jan. 12Port Conway Lane, carrying The silks of William T. Stokes, won the $28,800 Bowie Handicap today by a nose over Burning On, who in turn preceded Real Note by a head.

title: Bennie Bonacio, 70, Dies; Composer and Saxophonist
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., Jan. 12 Bernie Bonacio, composer, saxophonist, clarinetist and music publisher, died here Thursday at the age of 70. He moved to Clearwater from Elmhurst, Queens, several months ago.

title: State Calls On Railroad To Explain Freight Din
description: NEWARK  In the first such order of its kind in New Jersey, a railroad has been (greeted to show cause why it should not be compelled to end alleged noise pollution caused by its freight trains in Essex and Hudson Counties.

title: Italian in Coast Track
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 12 (AP)Marcello Fiasconaro of Italy, the world recordholder in the 800meters, today entered the Oregon indoor invitation track meet in Portland on Jan. 26. Fiasconaro ran the 800 in 1:43.7 in Milan last June 27.

title: Braves Top Bullets for 7th in Row
description: LARGO, Md., Jan. 12 (AP)  The streaking Buffalo Braves rallied in the fourth quarter tonight to defeat the Capital Bullets, 97.96, for their seventh straight National Basketball Association victory.

title: Pine Barrens: A Natural Area Now Touched by Man
description: CHATSWORTH  The conflicting goals of environmentalists and housing developers are now coming into focus in this sparsely settled community in the Pine Barrens.

title: Miss Myhrum Has Nuptials
description: The marriage of Miss Margaret Myhrum to Myron Arnold Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Brewster Adams of Guilford, Conn., took place here yesterday afternoon. Howard Box of the Institute of Ethical Culture in Brooklyn performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Myhrum, parents of the bride.

title: A Yachtsman'sEye View of the Sea Birds
description: One of these evenings when the gang is sitting in front of the fire reminiscing and hoisting a tall, cold one, it could just be that someone could come up with a showstopper by saying he had seen a wild pelican on Long Island.

title: New York City Mississippi: Surprising Pair
description: New York is a city that has given time, money, manpower and even blood to help the painful but ultimately successful effort to register blacks to vote in the Deep South.

title: Oil for The Arms Of Europe
description: PARIS  The ninenation European Community has been creaking at the seams ever since the current energy crisis began. The big question raised by President Nixon's proposed oil consumers conference is whether it will manage to close the barn door before the horses have fled into a nationalistic jungle.

title: New Synod In Northeast To Embrace Jerseyans
description: NEWARKDelegated representatives of nearly a halfmillion United Presbyterians in eight states are meeting here this weekend to establish the church's new Synod of the Northeast.

title: Current Best Sellers
description: FICTION

title: The Desert Enchants Kissinger
description: ASWAN, Egypt, Jan, 12Secretary of State Kissinger, standing today in bright sunshine at the Aswan High Dam, looked out at the broad expanse of stone and remarked, I think it is spectacular.

title: Sub Russell Is Christened
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Jan. 12 (UPI)With a swing of champagne bottle, the nation's newest nuclear attack submamine was christened the Richard B. Russell today after the Georgia Democrat who served 38 years in the Senate before his death Jan. 21, 1971.

title: WORLD. OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Thousands of store buyers visited the New York apparel markets last week and indicated they were planning no major cutbacks in their merchandise orders for the spring season.

title: News of the Screen
description: Richard Burton and Lee Marvin who have never been teamed, will costar in The Klansthan, an adaptation of the 1967 novel by William Bradford Huie, that as its title indicates, has a good deal to do with bigotry and clashing ideologies in a troubled Southern community. The drama will be directed by Terence Young (Wait Until Dark, etc.) and produced for Paramount release by William Alexander, a black movie maker who reported from the West Coast that he had been quietly working for more than a year putting this project together.

title: Cries of Doom Sound Out of Tune to Ford
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 12 (UPI)  Vice President Ford said today that the cries of doom heard about the country's problems were badly out of tune with the true American spirit evident in the heartland of America.

title: State Lends Sympathetic Ear to Victims of Violent Crime
description: NEWARK  For Carl J. Jahnke, a member of the state's Violent Crimes Com pensation Board, there are no routine days.

title: Criminals At Large.
description: When Olle Hogstrand's On the Prime Minister's Account was released here in May, 1972 it was highly praised for its realism, tight writing and plot construction. Now the popular Swedish team bf SjowallWahlati would have some real competition. Bit now comes Hogstrand's followup, THE GAMBLER (Pantheon, $4.95) and unfortunately it comes nowhere near its prede cessor.

title: Kerr on Find Your Way Home and More Than You Deserve The Prize Is Not Worth the Taking
description: ACURIOUS fate sometimes overtakes plays and films on homosexual themes. The love object tends to evaporate. Most often the quarrel is between a man and a man, or a man and a woman, over a boy. But even in the otherwise superior Sunday, Bloody Sunday, the bdy was rather a blank, a pretty pawn who didn't seem much of a prize. In John Hopkins's new play at the Brooks Atkinson, Find Your Way Home, the quarrel is between a boy and a woman over the woman's middleaged husband. Presto. The husband turns into a cipher. Why is the battle so often fought over a figure who remains virtually characterless?

title: Hampton to Vote on Land Proposal
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I.An innovative plan that would preserve a minimum of 19 per cent of East Hampton's total area as public open space is before the Town Board.

title: Common Cause Seeks to Subpoena Data From Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 Lawyers for Common Cause are preparing to follow the earlier action of the special prosecutor and the Senate Watergate committee and seek to subpoena documents from President Nixon.

title: Peter Smith Marries Miss Jane L. Borgese
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Jan. 12  Miss Jane Linda Borgese, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Borgese, was married here this afternoon to Peter K. Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Page Smith of Johnston, N. Y. The Rev. Carl Kruger performed the ceremony in Trinity Lutheran Church.

title: Susan West, Bennett Alumna, Is Married to Donald O. Ross
description: Miss Susan Stillman West and Donald O. Ross were married here yesterday in St. James Episcopal Church by the Rev. Frederick Hill. There was a reception at the Colony Club.

title: Opera: Met's Tristan and Isolde
Miss Turrall Sets. FreeStyle Record
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 12 (Reuters)Thirteenyearold Jenny Turrall, who recently set world records for the 800 and 1,500 meters freestyle, won the open 400meter title at the New South Wales swimming championships tonight.

title: Accessory Manufacturers Still Love Great Indoors
description: If there is one advantage an indoor boat show has over an outdoor boat show it'd in the accessory exhibits. For some reason, accessory dealers haven't taken to the tent circuit yet. If you're one of those boat owners who love to browse among the latest in equipment, electronics, specialties and hardware, now is your big chance.

title: Tomatoes Were Not Worth Growing90 Years Ago
description: MY MOTHER, who is well along in her tenth decade, still starts tomato seedlings on a sunny window sill each spring (but lets me set them in the ground). Tomatoes, to her, are the No. 1 crop. By. careful choice of varietiesone is an early, quickgrowing hybridwe get four months of fresh fruit in suburban Boston.

title: Daryl Byrne Wed To Jeffrey Fleuren
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 12Miss Daryl Elizabeth Byrne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur George Byrne of Greenwich and Grande Princesse, St. Croix, V. I., was married here this afternoon to Jeffrey Edward Fleuren. He is the son of Mrs. Alison Sanseigne of New York and the late John Praett Fleuren.

title: OIL INDUSTRY SEES SHORTFALL AVERTED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The Petroleum Institute said today that a 30 per cent rise in oil imports in 1973 and efforts to reduce energy consumption averted what would have been a critical energy shortfall in 1973.

title: Linda Carol Valentine Betrothed
description: CLOSTER, N.J., Jan. 12The engagement of Miss Linda Carol Valentine to Harold Franklin Oberkotter Jr. has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Warren John Valentine. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Mr. Oberkotter, board chairman of the United Parcel Service of America, Inc., and Mrs. Oberkotter of Harrington Park and Palm Desert, Calif. A July wedding is planned.

title: Everyone Came as Someone Else From Henry Kissinger to Fritz the Cat
description: There was Henry Kissinger and Fritz the Cat and fourcount themGroucho Marxes. An elaborate Mexican bull jostled revelers who had borrowed their offsprings Halloween masks or settled for plain black masks from the five and ten.

title: New Church Head Chosen in Greece
description: ATHENS, Jan. 12A World War II resistance comrade of Greece's new military rulers was chosen Archbishop of the Orthodox Church of Greece today, but prelates said that the irregular election procedure used had sown the seeds of dissent in the church.

title: Sudden Death Will Settle Tie
Norwegian Leads Pro Speed Skating
description: RAETTVIK, Sweden, Jan. 12 (AP)  Bjoern Tveter of Norway led allround standing today in the Swedish Professional Grand Prix speed skating competition,

title: Microfilm System Helps Police Find Suspects
description: A computerlike information retrieval system being used by the police in Queens has facilitated the identification of criminal suspects and has, since the inception of the project less than a year ago, iesulted in at least 30 arrests.

title: State Mediation Post Filled
description: Governor Wilson yesterday appointed Daniel R. McGraw of Albany an international retiresentative of the International Union of Operating Engineers, as a member of the State Me diation Board, to fill the unexpired term of Richard H. Nolan.

title: Growing Up at Grossinger's, or, Raised without Reservation
description: MY childhood home was different from yours. I grewlip at the Grossinger Hotel in the years between 1945 and 1960  the era when Grossinger's was in its heyday. My livingroom was a lobby where thousands of strangers congregated. My dining room seated 1,200. I was there for Eddie Fisher's debutthe memorable night in 1949 when he was introduced by Eddie Cantor as the nation's newest singing sensation. I can and sometimes do tell stories about Jan Peerce, Jackie Robinson, Nelson Rockefeller and a host of others. Let me explain right away that this is an affectionate (and eversoslightly irreverent) memoir. I'll tell you about some good times in those good old days, but also recount how we hotel brats, as we called ourselves, used to refer to you guests with lordly superiority as L.P.G.'s. (Lousy Paying Guests) and how we rebelled in sly and occasionally hilarious ways against the prescription of our elders that The Guest Is Always

title: Calendar of Dog Shows
description: Afghan Hound Association of Long Island symposium, Holiday Inn, La Guardia Airport, 100  15 Ditrnars Boulevard, Queens, N.Y.; Fred Alderman, Mrs. Kay Finch. Mrs. Sunny Shay, Lieut. Col. Wally Pede and Dr. Thomas Pescod, panelists; 10 A.M.6 P.M.; $15.

title: Paperbacks Recommended New Titles
description: FICTION

title: A hero cast out, even by tragedy
description: It seems to be true in fictionand it may be in lifethat there are characters so flattened by fate before they crawl into our view that they exist beneath the reach of tragedy. Cormac McCarthy's child of God Lester Ballard, is such a character. Ballard, who seems senile at 27 is a rural squatter living in an abandoned house in the Tennessee hill country. The novelCormac McCarthy's thirdbegins with Ballard's domicile being auctioned out from under him. As he protests, aiming his rifle at the auctioneer someone clubs him from behind with an axe. Lester Ballard never could hold his head right after that.

title: I am not a crook
The Family: Building a Better America
description: SAN DIEGO From early Puritan household to weatherworn pioneer family, from the black/Irish/Chinese immigrant household to the Apache/ Sioux/Navajo family from early log cabin to modern suburbia, the strength of America has always beenand still isthe American family.

title: Hardships? Not the Way Powerboats Are Fitted
description: Even if there isn't any gasoline left for pleasure boating, today's trend toward more convenient and elaborate layouts on power boats may make them a great place to visiteven if they're just tied up to the pier.

title: Why the Devil Do They Dig The Exorcist'?
description: IN addition to making millions of dollars for all concerned, William Friedkin's film version of William Peter Blatty's The Exorcist may help restore the reputation of The Prince of The Power of The Air, which went into a sharp decline after Benjamin Franklin invented the lightning rod. Old Scratch must be pleased this morning, though Franklin, wherever he is, most probably Is suffering from acute shortness of breath.

title: Sunday Observer
description: The energy crisis is bad enough, heaven knows. mean, well, in the first place, there is that awkward question of whether there really is an energy crisis. Government heavyweights talk about it full time but do we really dare believe anything that is said by people like them anymore?

title: A boy's book for the middleaged
description: Malevil is a most pleasant few days reading. Just about the happiest doomsday adventure you'll come across: in aspect rather like one of those cozy, nice Japanese Godzillas who do Jack Benny doubletakes and a shuffle off to Buffalo while under devastating fire from the Yokohama National Guard. Robert Merle author of The Day of the Dolphin, has made a boy's book for the middleaged.. Nothing to be ashamed of there. We are honor ludens: Malevil is a fantasy game with its medieval castle home base and its half dozen loyal musketeers against the trying, postbomb world of rural France. Merle presumably had fun: he has transmitted delight to the reader in an undemanding first person style that fairly hydrofoils over the page:

title: Language Dispute Flaring Around Bombay
description: BOMBAY, India, Jan. 6A violent drama that unfolds continuously across India is being enacted now in the southern Indian restaurants of Bombay and along the border of two states, ,Maharashtra and Karnataka.

title: Friday's Fights
description: MadridJos Antonio Jimenez, Spain, outpointed Daniel Vermandere. France, 15 rounds, featherweights. Jimenez retains European featherweight title.

title: Work Key Ingredient in Marine School Course
description: It's not enough to teach physics, electronics and engine maintenance, Academic success doesn't necessarily turn an exaddict into a marine mechanic, The Pioneer Marine School at the South Street Seaport Museum has discovered the missing ingredient  work.

title: Blackmail Laid to Official In Pentagon spy Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12The White House told the Senate Watergate committee last summer that a Government official who participated in the investigation of the unauthorized passing of National Security Council documents to the Pentagon had, in effect, sought to blackmail his way to a more important job by threatening to make the secret materials public, wellplaced sources said today.

title: Design: Add a greenhouse
description: First came the picture window. Next, sliding glass doors. Then, whole walls of glass. And now, greenhouses. With the vogue for raising plants indoors, the addition of a greenhouse to an apartment or a home is logical, yet indoor gardening alone does not account for the current trend. Some families like the dramatic effect of living out in the open under a glass roof. The owners of the coop apartment shown on this page like the light, airy feeling and the shadow patterns on the walls of their greenhouse dining room. The owners of the home in Bernardsviille, N.J., shown on Page 70, are ardent gardeners who wanted to extend their living quarters out into the surrounding greenery. Living under glass does have disadvantages. Without blinds to filter the glare, the room can be sweltering on sunny days. On sunless days, the temperature will plummet. And gardeners need greenbacks as well as green thumbs to meet even the lowest estimates for

title: Boating Fuel: A Fair Share Is Predicted
description: Boat owners can count on an adequate supply of fuel during the 1974 season. according to the chairman of the industry's Energy Committee.

title: the traveler's world
description: Court Actions Promise More Bon Voyages

title: Nixon Flies East
description: President Nixon left California for Washington last night on a small Government jet, ending an 18day vacation. Details on Page 57.

title: Mrs. Edward Kennedy, 52 Reported on the Far East
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 12 (UPI)Mrs. Dorothy Kennedy, a former Far East correspondent for United Press International, died last night at her home in Euclid. She was 52 years old.

title: Child to the Kobrins
description: ROCHESTER, Jan. 12 A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Kobrin on Dec. 28 at Highland Hospital here. The child has been named Rachel Mara. Her father is a financial analyst with the Xerox Corporation here.

title: Late TV Listings.
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Toughing it
description: The day before Butterfield set off this new phase in the Watergate struggle, Sam Ervin had called the President to request a facetoface meeting on the Presidential papers issue. According to committee sources, the President was in an emotional state during the 14minute conversation. At one point, it was reported, he told the Senator that he would not provide the papers because the committee was out to get him. A few hours later the President entered Bethesda Naval Hospital amid rumors that he was suffering a nervous breakdown.

title: An Impeachment Ball Planned in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI)  An impeachment ball will be held here Jan. 19, with political games and prizes for guests who are dressed as acrobatic secretaries, dancing plumbers and telephoning Martha Mitchells.

title: Miss Ravers Bride of Michael Dumont
description: Miss Belinda Raven, an associate editor of Medical World News, was married in Brooklyn last night to Michael Patrick Dumont, an invertebrate paleontologist at the American Museum of Natural History. The ceremony was performed at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Berson by Cantor Gordon Richards, formerly of the Avenue R. Jewish Center in Brooklyn.

title: YOUTH HOME LEADER GETS NEW TRIAL SITE
description: HAWLEY, Pa., Jan. 12The murder trial of John Reilly, 57yearold former operator of a home for retarded youth has been shifted by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court from Wayne County which embraces this community, to Lebanon County, about 60 miles from here.

title: The Dance
description: What really fantastic dancers New York City Ballet possesses! At the moment one of the most fantastic Patricia McBride is unhappily off  injured, and another of the Balanchine pleiad, Allegra Kent, is also temporarily tindisposed. Yet despite the most regrettable absence of two such dancers; Friday night's performance at the New York State Theater went smoothly enough.

description: UARTERFINAL ROUND

title: THE DAILY WORLD MARKS 50TH YEAR
description: The Daily World, the 12page tabloid that brings the gospel of MarxismLeninism to the faithful has begun celebrating the 50th anniversary of the daily Communist press in America.

title: Four Reforms
description: In his Presidential address a year ago to the American Economic Association, John Kenneth Galbraith, William Buckley's friend, opponent, fellow centurion, and, peripatetic debating partner, spoke of economics as a subject which features defeated expectations. It is well he pronounced in precincts still somewhat off Mr. Buckley's beat, for unavoidably at the conclusion of his address he would have found the editor of National Review rising to inquire: Whose expectations?

description: A 19story apartment house that is to be built largely from the top downward will start going down soon in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Crackdown Under Way
Child to Mrs. Colston
description: MORRISTOWN, N, J., Jan. 12A daughter was born on Dec. 9 to Dr. and Mrs. William Carroll Colstoh at the Morristown Memorial Hospital. where Dr. Colston is a radiologist. The child has been named Katherine Barrett. Mrs. Colston is the former Miss Kathleen Barrett of New York.

title: Epilogue A Glance Back at Some Major Stories
description: A Beneficial Silence

title: Town Drops Coffee Fund
description: TAYLOR, Mich., Jan. 12 (AP) The 327 City Hall employes in this Detroit suhurb will not get free coffee anymore because the City Council has voted to cut off coffee funds. The council acted after City Clerk John Sabo complained about losing his secretary for lack of funds while the city continued to spend $6,580 year on free coffee.

title: Money, money, money
description: Much of the press and public may have been ready to go on to other things, but fresh embarrassments kept cropping up. As the President finished his second response at the Sept. 5 news conferencea long, statesmanlike declaration on Arab oil up popped Ford Rowan, a 30yearold reporter for Television News Inc., a new national television service. Normally the third question goes to a senior network correspondent, but Rowan recalls, The President paused for a moment and I just jumped to my feet. I wanted to ask this one real bad. What he asked was the first question yet at Presidential news conference about the financing of Nixon's realestate purchases.

title: Some Elegant Edwardians Settle In on Public TV
description: THE new tenant at public television's masterpiece Theater, scheduled for a residency of 13 Sunday evenings at 9, is a charmingly seductive concoction called Upstairs, Downstairs.

title: Israeli Marital Disputes Eased by October War
description: HAIFA, Israel, Jan. 12 (Reuters)The October war appears to have healed many marital disputes, according to the records of the rabbinical court that deals with divorces.

title: How a New Concept Grew Around Old Eastside High
description: PATERSONThis city has been urging its business concerns and industries not to leave, even though they may have a need to expand and modernize their facilities.

title: Nassau Goes Underground for Crises
Adelphi U. Opens New Institute Devoted to Study of the Suburbs
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 12 Adelphi University has established what it calls the first research institute in this coun try devoted solely to studying all consequences of the shift of America's population to the suburbs.

title: NorthTeam 1613 Victor
description: MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 12David Jaynes of Kansas fired a 17yard touchdown pass to Lynn Swann of Southern California with 26 seconds remaining today as the North AllStars rallied for a 1613 victory over the South in the silver anniversary Senior Bowl football, game.

title: Wiley Coach Resigns
description: MARSHALL, Tex., Jan. 12 (AP)John Tankersley, athletic director and head baseball coach at Wiley College, resigned today. Tankersley said he was returning to Prairie View A. and M. University to take the head baseball coaching position and also acting as an assistant in football.

title: British Cup Plans Abandoned in Solent Yard
description: LONDON  The uncivalrous way in which Britain conducted her latest challenge for the America's Cup throwing down the gauntlet and then three years later stooping to retrieve ithas left serious doubts here that thin country will ever again mount a credible bid to wrest the elusive symbol of world yachting supremacy from the United States.

title: Marie Powers A Farewell
description: IF I live Just two more years have sung 50 years in opera!!! The exclamation points on the Christmas card's added message were typically effusive, as was the implicit determination to keep at it. Marie Powers didn't quite make the halfcentury mark. She died in New York the last week in December, an extraordinary career behind her, one that included, by her own careful calculation, 2,341 performances as Madame Flora in GianCarlo Menotti's The Medium.

title: Plan to Drill an Oil Well In Florida Forest Battled
description: OCALA, Fla., Jan. 12  Environmentalists and oil officials squared off here this week over a proposal to drill a 4,500footdeep oil well in a national forest that is vital to the state's water supply.

title: Woman Vanishes for 5 Days After Arrest
description: HARTFORD Jan. 12  A woman arrested by the Hartford police last month vanished in a bureaucratic limbo before her family learned from her by phone five days later that she had been committed to a mental institution.

title: The Shift in Commodity Power
description: The industrial nations, which have grown fat largely on huge servings of cheap raw materials such as foodstuffs, fibers, minerals and fuel, are facing an increasingly costly diet.

title: Show Information
description: PUBLIC HOURS  Today and next Sunday, noon to 7 P.M.; Monday through Friday, noon to 10 P.M.; Saturday, 10 A.M. to 10 P.M.

title: Libya Plans Oil Price Rise
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 12 (AP)Libya intends to increase the posted price of her oil from $18.50 a barrel to $20 or $21, Libya's Minister of Petroleum, Izzidin alMabruk, was quoted as saying today. The posted price is a nominnal rate on which taxes and royalties are calculated. It applies only to foreign companies, which normalbr pay taxes and royalties to the country on whose territory they operate oil concessions.

title: City Sniffs Out Problem in Greenpoint
description: Some relief is on the way for residents of the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn who have long complained about the strong and unpleasant odors emanating from many of the area's industrial enterprises, city and state officials say.

title: WILDLIFE IS AIDED IN CONNECTICUT
description: The Connecticut Audubon Society and the Connecticut chapter of the Nature Conservancy have been given two new sites for nature sanctuaries, one in Westport, the other in South Norwalk.

title: RevvedUp Formula 5000 Ready to Hit High Gear
description: Once upon a time, they lived happily ever after. That was before the energy crisis, so the ending to this story about the Formula 5000 series won't be as hapBy as it might have been.

title: Karl Marx
description: The massive head of Karl Marx stares from the dustjacket of this new biography by David McLellan: one eye open and direct, the other slightly hooded; from one angle the shaggy, bearded face reminds us of Santa Claus, from the other Edward G. Robinson. The two profiles, Marx as a bearer of gifts to mankind or as a sinister seer, have tended to define the choices of Marxian biography. The standard 1918 work by Franz Mehring was an affectionate portrait of a selfless genius, cultivated and humane. E. H. Carr chose the second Marx and subtitled his biography, The Mind of a Fanatic.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Troy Says Democrats in Queens Will Keep, Seats in Feb. 14 Vote
description: Matthew J. Troy Jr., the Queens Dmocratic leader, predicted yesterday that his party would retain the Senate seat and the Assembly seat at stake in Feb. 14 special elections in his county.

title: FREEDOM ASKED IN NEW HEBRIDES
description: VILA, New HebridesAn independence movement, fostered by politically conscious Protestant clerics and young graduates returned from universities in independent Fiji and selfgoverning Papua New Guinea, is gaining strength in the islands of New Hebrides.

title: The 64th National Boat Show in Port
description: You've clambered hungrily all over the $162,800 Queen. You've winked longingly at the Hong Kong beauty with her 998 square feet of sail. You've been seduced into a vicarious 90mileanhour joy ride by one of Don Aronow's Cigarettes. With admitted lust you've allowed that luxurious Bertram to lure you deep into her her padded boudoir. And you have stood hallucinated on a new ChrisCraft fisherman hauling in a recordbreaker to the cheers of thousands.
