description: Douglas Newton, curator of the Museum of Primitive Art since 1960, has been named its director, it was announced yesterday by former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, founder and president of the museum. Mr. Newton will fill the vacancy left last March by the death of Dr. Robert Goldwater.

title: Thompson Takes Pro Ski Event
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 13Perry Thompson, the 22yearold blond Californian who scored the first triumph of his pro career early last ,month at Vail, Colo., gained . his second success this afternoon in a $30,000 Benson and Hedges Grand Prix ski event.

title: RATERISE HEARINGS PROLONGED BY P.S.C.
description: ALBANY, Jan. 13The Public Service Commission yielded today to appeals for a longer hearing process on a request by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York for a $272.1million electricrate increase and announced a new timetable to allow interested parties to crossexamine company witnesses and prepare their own cases.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The body of 14yearold Daniel W. Ebersole, who was kidnapped last Tuesday in suburban Lakewood, N.Y., was found yesterday afternoon tied to a pine tree in a wooded area in the Township of Ellicott, just outside Jamestown.

title: MILD SLOWDOWN SEEN BY MOORE
description: The economic outlook may not be that gloomy after all, according to one of the country's leading businesscycle analysts Geoffrey Moore, former commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, sees nothing worse in the wind than a slowdown in the country's growth rate this year. and a mild slowdown at that.

title: New Jersey Briefs State Fears Loss of Sewage Funds
description: President Nixon's decision to impound sewagetreatment construction funds could cost New Jersey nearly $200million, according to George Friedel, director of the, State Division of Water Resources. He says the cut could mean that only about 30 of the watertreatment projects on the state's priority list will be financed next year.

title: ISRAELIS APPROVE PLAN TO DISENGAGE SUEZLINE ARMIES Kissinger Is Authorized to Present Draft to EgyptHe May Visit Syria PHASED PULLOUT SEEN Proposal Said to Include 20Mile Withdrawal and a Buffer Zone in Sinai
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 13The Government of Israel today approved a specific proposal for the separation of Israeli and Egyptian forces along the Suez Canal and authorized Secretary of State Kissinger to present the plan to the Government of Egypt.

title: Boy Waiting for Sled Ride Is Killed by Train on L. I.
description: The Nassau County police reported yesterday that a 12yearold boy was killed by a train Saturday night in Floral Park as he was standing by the railroad track, waiting for his turn to ride a sled down the enbankment.

title: Literary Souls Are Laid Bare In Letter Show
description: Lytton Strachey, the biographer, maintained that lettais undermine the pompousness of Clio, muse of history', revealing her undergarments in the most indecorous manner.

title: The PeoplePlants Love Affair: It's Not Just Bach vs. Rock
description: Hey, Youwiththeleaves. We can talk now.

title: Hulme Captures Argentine Race
GIFTS FROM AFAR AID THE NEEDIEST
description: Gifts from faraway places are no novelty to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Yepremian Gets More Good News
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 13 (UPI) Garo Yepremian got good news when he rushed to the hospital after the game today. His wife. Maritza, who is expecting their first child, did not suffer a miscarriage as he had been told.

title: Principals Face Disciplining Under Grading System
description: The city's school principall will soon join their students in getting report cards that will show how wellor how badlythey are doing in school.

title: Saxbe Says Claim of Privilege Could Stall Impeachment Study
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (UN) The House Judiciary Committee's impeachment investigation could be delayed indefinitely if President Nixon invokes executive privilege and refuses to turn over tapes and documents, Attorney General William B. Saxbe said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Of Impeachable Offenses

title: Red Smith
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 13In the bright, archaic lexicon of Noah Webster, super means higher, greater, more than, above. Employing this prefix, we get superfluous, superficial, supernumerary and supersede, which Webster defined as replace with something better. Here in Rice Stadium, where the professional football championship of all known planets has just been decided in Super Bowl VIII, the question is: What is Pete Rozelle waiting Mr? For the first time in eight confrontations between the champions of the National and American Sports Conferences, the title was decided in a suddendeath periodthe first period. of In the opening 13 minutes and 38 seconds, The Times the Miami Dolphins ran or passed the ball 20 times, gained 120 yards and scored 14 points. The offensive unit did, that is. In the same space, the Miami defensive forces permitted the Minnesota Vikings to run the ball twice and pass it once for 9 yards and nothing else.

title: City to Check on Practices Of FuelOil Distributors
description: Consumer Affairs Commissioner Elinor Gudgenheimer said yesterday that her department would seek. to ascertain this week whether there were abuses in the sale and distribution of fuel oil similar to those reported in connection with gasoline,

title: Cindy Nelson Posts Season's First U.S. Victory in Cup Skiing
description: GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 13 (AP)  Cindy Nelson of Lutsen, Minn., upset Annemarie Proell of Austria today in a World Cup downhill ski race.

title: SYLVAN FREUND
description: Sylvan Freund, president of the Decorative Plant Corp. and former, president of the National Association of Display Industries, died Saturday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 242 East 72d Street.

title: SEX COUNSELING GETS NEW FOCUS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13 A new approach to sex counseling designed to make treatment available to the public on a shortterm, lowcost basis is being conducted at the University of California Medical Center.

title: PopMusic: O'Day,Dearie And Williams Sing Jazz
description: That vague and often mysterious term jazz singer is no closer to definition after a concert at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening that was called The Jazz Singers. The singers involved were Joe Williams, who has developed manner of singing the ruggedest blues with great polish that is very effective; Anita 0Day, who scats and flats her way through familiar songs in such way as to make them utter strangers, and Blossom Dearie, who works in a world of witty and catchy songs, which she enunciates with a small but remarkably flexible voice.

title: U.S. Out of Davis Cup
description: The United.States tennis team was eliminated from the 62d Davis Cup competition by Colombia in Bogota yesterday. It was The earliest defeat for the United States since another firstround loss in 1907. Article, Page 33.

title: DR. MARTIN SCHREIBER
description: Dr. Martin Schreiber, a psychiatrist who had written on the measurement of personality change in people undergoing psychoanalysis, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital, where he had served for many years on the psychiatric staff. He was 75 years old and lived at 135 East 83d Street.

title: PROTEST IS PLANNED ON REINSURANCE BID
description: The $500million American Reinsurance Company will contest the New York State Insurance Department ruling permitting the $1.2billion American International Group of New York to acquire additional shares of American Reinsurance stock.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Study Interviewed 1,341
description: The series of articles starting today in the The New York Times measuring the attitudes and perceptions New Yorkers is based on interviews.by Daniel Yankelovich, Inc., a leading public opinion research organization, with 1,341 residents 18 years or older during the last two weeks of November.

title: Leader in Rent Strike at Stella Wright Houses Named Head of Newark Tenants Organization
description: NEWARK, Jan. 13Toby Henry, president of the Stella Wright Tenants Organization and thus a major voice in the nearly five  year  old strike against the Newark Housing Authority, is the new president of the citywide Newark Tenants Organization, which represents residents of 23 public hous ing projects and some privately owned apartment Notes house groups. The choice of Mr. Henry, who is 27 years old, was praised by Millicent Fenwick, director of the State Division of Consumer Affairs.

title: Democrats Establish Panel to Court Labor
description: ALBANY, Jan. 13  Of all the words of freshly mimeographed praise that followed Governor Wilson's first program message, the ones of greatest interest to rival Democrats came from Raymond R. Corbett, president of the State A. F. L.  C. I. 0, Governor Wilson has certainly started off right to improve the life of the people, said Mr. Corbett in. a news release that reminded readers of the state labor group's claim to speak for the more than twomillionmem. ber organization, a potency that few politicians seem to doubt.

title: Few Still Read to Pass Bar
description: In an age when degrees and diplomas are demanded for even some of the most humdrum jobs, it is yet possible to become a practicing lawyer in New York State without a law degree or, technically, so much as a college education.

title: Title Bout Postponed
description: TOKY0, Jan. 13 (AP)The World B#ing Council's title bout between Rodolfo Gonzales of Mexico, lightweight champion, and Japan's Ishimatsu Suzuki has been postponed indefinitely. It was scheduled for Thursday. The postponement was called when Gonzales was stung in the right leg by a poisonous spider.

title: Horse Show Results AT DARIEN, CONN.
description: Maclay TrophyIrene Jaffee, Weston, Conn. Medal ClassMiss Jaffee. Horsemanship ChamoinnshipChampion, Carolyn Evans, Weston, Connes reserve, Miss Jaffee.

title: Japanese Premier's Daughter Takes a Modern Role
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Jan. 13Makiko Tanaka is not like most Japanese womendemure, retiring, deferential to men. The daughter of Premier Kakuei Tanaka knows her own mind and speaks it oftenand usually a mile a minute, like her father. She is poised, selfassured and frank, qualities that have won her considerable attention from the press and public in the Southeast Asian nations she is currently visiting as her father's official hostess.

title: CutlerHammer Contract
description: The Air Force announced yesterday it has awarded the AIL division of CutlerHammer, Inc. in Deer Park, New York, $31.6million contract to. develop the defensive avionics subsystem for the new B1 strategic bomber.

title: City Aide Under Investigation For Altering His Payroll Sheets
description: The office of Investigation Commissioner Nicholas Scarpetta is reviewing the payroll time sheets filed by Raymond Gerson, director of the city's Noise Abatement Bureau, who also teaches a college chemistry course three mornings week.

title: APPOINTMENTS MADE BY BLOOMINGDALE'S
description: Bloomingdale's, the Manhattanbased departmentstore chain, has named a new executive vice president and two senior vice presidents. The new appointments follow the an. nouncement that Franklin Simon, senior vice president and general merchandise manager for home furnishings, men's wear and fashion accessories, will become executive vice president and general merchandise manager of Burdine's, Miami, on March 1.

title: Back to Poison?
description: Just two years ago, President Nixon signed to the warm praise of conservationists an Executive order that was intended to put an end to the horrid practice poisoning prairie dogs and predatory birds and animals on the public lands. Of all man's intrusions on nature's order, the wholesale use of poison In the United States has been among the most reckless and indefensible.

title: 10 TOP NEWSPAPERS ARE LISTED BY TIME
description: In its current issue, Time magazine lists its choices for the 10 best newspapers in the nation and, comparing the list with one drawn up 10 years ago, points out that half of them are new selections.

title: 2 Huts, I Touchdown
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 13The Miami Dolphins aren't perfect after all. Their quarterback, Bob Griese, and their fullback, Larry Csonka. each forgot the snap count today at the Minnesota Vikings 2yard line in the third quarter.

title: Syrian Leader and Aides Weigh Talks With Israel
description: BEIRUT Lebanon, Jan. 13President Hafez alAssad Syria consulted with his top aides today on proposals for negotiations with Israel separating their forces in the Golan Heights, according to informed travelers from Damascus.

title: Frozen Body of Kidnapped Upstate Boy Is Found Tied to Tree After Phone Tip
description: JAMESTOWN, N. Y. Jan. 13 The frozen body of 14yearold Daniel W. Ebersole, who was kidnapped last Tuesday in suburban Lakewood, was found this afternoon tied to a pine tree in a wooded area of the Township of Ellicott, just west of Jamestown.

title: Personal Finance
description: Ian Fleming immortalized 007. Joe Nemeth made the number 12 a fixture on thousands of Tshirts

title: NEW BAIL SYSTEM UPHELD BY COURT
description: FREEHOLD, Jan. 13A, new bail system that allows defendants in criminal cases to.1 post with the court only as much money as they would normally pay a bail bondsman has passed its first court test.

title: HELEN CLAIRE, 68, ACTRESS, IS DEAD
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 13 (AP)Helen Claire, a stage and radio actress, died here yesterday. She was 68 years old.

title: Capetown Sextuplets Show Progress Against Jaundice
description: CAPETOWN, Jan. 13 (Reuters)Mrs. Susan Rosenkowitz today handled all six 9f her babies in their incubatora, and although all of the sextuplets are still suffering jaundice, a medical bulletin reported that the disease was under control.

title: Ballet: Classic Weekend
description: A weekend of classic dance with two companies in town especially when the two are the American Ballet Theater at the City Center 55th Street Theater and the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater  can hardly fail to be rewarding. Saturday night, for example, we had Ballet Theater's Natalia Makarova and Ivan Nagy in Dimitri Romanov's La Fine Mal Gardee, while yesterday afternoon had Helgi Tomasson, partnering Gelsey Kirkland, appearing for the first time in the new Jerome Robbins duet to Beethoven piano music, Four Bagatelles.

title: First Oil Shipments From Peru's Jungles Going to Brazil Next Month
N.C. State's Thompson Proves One Is Better Than
Food Riots in India Underline An Anger Caused by Inflation
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 13Riots over food scarcity and rising prices have erupted in the Indian state of Gujarat, leaving more than a dozen people dead and underlining the restive and angry mood that grips areas of this nation.

title: Snowmobile Collision Fatal
description: SOUTH BARRE, Vt., Jan. 13 (AP)A 25yearold old Vermont woman died when her snowmobile collided headon with another snowmobile at the crest of a hill early today, the police said. Sandra Lee Perantoni of Graniteville, who was not wearing protective head gear, died of head injuries when the other machine ran over hers, the police said. The driver of the other vehicle, a minor, received cuts in the accident.

title: Land Reform in Vietnam Reversed in Some Areas
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 13The Government has begun to slip back after having reached the brink of success in dissolving large land holdings, distributing them to poor tenant farmers and thus eliminating one of the Vietcong's most potent political issues.

title: Many Arabs. Skeptical of LibyanTunisian Merger
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 13The Arab world reacted with skepticism and some polite official statements to the announcement by Libya and Tunisia yesterday that they plan to merge into one nation.

title: An Impeachment Dilemma
description: BOSTON, Jan. 13By his performance as Special Prosecutor, Leon Jaworski has quieted early questions about his ability to be independent from the President who appointed him. He has held together the staff picked by Archibald Cox; he has pressed the investigations; he has kept his distanceand his freedomfrom the White House.

title: Principals Face Disciplining Under Grading System
description: The city's school principals will soon join their students in getting report cards that will show how wellor how badlythey are doing in school.

title: Wanted: Students
description: After being deluged with students for more than a decade, all but the most prestigious educational institutions suddenly find themselves with an excess of places in their substantially overexpanded facilities. Enrollments in 1973 increased at only half the rate of previous years and the private colleges showed a slight. decline. A shortage of students, at a time of inflationary operating costs and declining Federal support, can place a college's survival in jeopardy or at least endanger its academic quality.

title: A Tough, Sensitive Athlete Larry Richard Csonka
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 13Slowly, the teenage girl approached Larry Csonka for an autograph. Noticing her cautious manner, the 238pound fullback of the Miami Dolphins smiled. I won't bite you, he said, signing her photo of him. On the fields of the National Football League, the 27yearold Csonka (pronounced Zonka) is the essence of the Super Bowl champions, as he was today in smashing for 145 yards in the Dolphins 247 victory. As such, he is thought of as a battering ram or an animal, images that contradict the true personality in repose of this thoughtful, intelligent, sensi

title: FIRM'S REVAMPING ATTACKED IN SUIT
description: The widow of the founder of Walston & Co., has sued duPont Walston, Inc., the New York Stock Evchange, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation and H. Ross Perot and others to undo the realignment of Walston and duPont Glore Forgan, Inc., last July.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Police Seek Boy's Body in Lake

title: STUDY SAYS PRICES OFFSET 73 RAISES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13A Congressional staff study, made public today, concludes that most people are correct in their belief that any increased income they had in 1973 was more than offset by higher prices.

title: Deaths
The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Commission on the Status of Women11 A.M. and P.M.; working group on discrimination3 P.M.

title: Bruins Win As Esposito Gets 2 Goals
Schools Starting Later To Protect the Children
description: The first week of winter Daylight Saving Time has prompted many school districts across the country to delay starting times so children do not travel to class in the dark.

title: Two Men Die in L. I. Fire
description: PORT WASHINGTON, LI., Jan, 13Two men died in a fire that broke out early this morning in the basement of their home at 44 Bayview Avenue. The Nassau County police said the victims were,Howard Georgan, 23 years old, and Gregory McKenna, 22. The cause of the fire, which occurred at 4:30 A.M., is being investigated by the Port Washington Fire Department.

title: M. Z. Rosensaft Weds Jean Bloch
description: Miss Jean Bloch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sam E. Bloch of Rego Park, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Menachem Z. Rosensaft, son of Mr. and Mrs. Josef Rosertsaft. Dr. Gerson D. Cohen, chAncellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, and Rabbi Joseph H. Lookstein, chancellor of the Bar Ilan University in Israel, performed the ceremony at the Rosensaft home.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE

title: Report on Data Leak Said To Have Named Moorer
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13David R. Young Jr., a member of the White House plumbers group, concluded in a report submitted in early 1972 to President Nixon that Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, chairman Of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, had received secret National Security Council documents taken from the office of Henry A. Kissinger, well placed sources said. today.

title: Dolphins Offensive Line in Superb Form Despite Injuries
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 13Bob Kuechenberg of the Miami Dolphins summed up today the basic ingredient in their Super Bowl victory.

title: City Ballet
description: Liebeslieder Walzer is a very special ballet not only on its own terms but also in terms of its place within the Balanchine repertory of the New York City Ballet. At its first performance of the season Saturday night at the State Theater, Susan Hendl and Richard Hoskinson were the new additions to the cast.

title: Accent Is Placed on the Positive As Cahill's Administration Ends
description: TRENTON, Jan. 13  When William T. Cahill took office as Governor here four years ago with an inaugural pledge to search out the corrupters and the corrupt, wherever they exist, he said then that no individual would be sacrosanct, no party would be immune.

title: A Cahill Asseasment
description: William T. Cahill leaves office tomorrow after four years as Governor of New Jersey. A report on how political leaders assess his record appears on Page 31.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
Snow Aids New England's Ski Areas
description: KILLINGTON BASIN, Vt., Jan. 13  The first heavy snow of the season in the New England mountains brought hope this weekend to the region's ski industry, nearly decimated by adverse weather and the fear of gasoline shortages.

title: Recital: The Compelling Artistry of Judith Blegen
description: Judith Blegen did not have to sing at the Hunter College Assembly Hall on Saturday night to prove that she is a major artist. That fact has been well established in her performances with the Metropolitan Opera since her debut there in 1970.

title: Music: Rare Rubinstein
description: Time continues to stand still for Artur Rubinstein. The great pianist strode onstage at Avery Fisher Hall yesterday afternoon for his latest recital here, sat at his instrument as straight  backed as ever and plunged into Chopin's Scherzo in B flat minor, oblivious to the fact that he will be 88 years old on Jan. 28.

title: HELEN FOX DEAD; A GARDEN EXPERT
description: Helen Morgenthau Fox, who wrote and lectured widely on horticulture, died yesterday at her home in Mount Kisco, N.Y. Her age was 89.

title: U.S.INTELLIGENCE SEES HANOI PUSH
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13Fifteen years after the first American. combat troops entered South Vietnam, the American Intelligence community is telling the President that the question is still whennot whether North Vietnam is going to launch a major offensive against the South.

title: Shutdowns of Gasoline Stations in Area on Increase
description: Franchised gasoline station operators here are stepping up complaints of discriminatory allocations and other alleged pressure tactics by the major oil companies, amid accelerated shutdowns of service stations in the tristate metropolitan area.

title: Huge Fish Kill Expected As Atomic Plant Closes
description: LACEY TOWNSHIP, Jan. 13  The closing of an atomic powergenerating plant herea closing that New Jersey officials tried unsuccessfully to forestallcould result in one million dead fish, a state biologist said today.

title: Celtics Subdue Hawks
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 13 (UPI). Dave Cowens scored 29 points and grabbed 22 rebounds and five other Celtics had 16 or more points today as Boston routed the Atlanta Hawks, 128105,

title: Lioness Mauls Florida Boy
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 13 (AP)  A 3yearold boy, Ryan Murphy, was in serious condition today after being mauled by a 350pound lioness. In Tarpon Springs, Leda Brownell, 25, was recovering from wounds she received when la leopard belonging to a friend turned on her.

title: AMNESTY GROUP EXPANDS SESSIONS
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 The Safe Return Amnesty Committee, which seeks exoneration of all war resisters, will hold meetings around the country aimed at. renewing interest in the future of returning exiles, deserters and those already severed from the military with less than honorable discharges.

title: FitzGibbon Team Victor
description: RYE, N. Y., Jan. 13Herb FitzGibbon of the Seventh Regiment and John Beck of the Bedford (N. Y.) Golf and Tennis Club, the defending champions, won the 10th annual Rye pfatform tennis tournament today. They defeated Charles Baird Jr. and Steven Baird, brothers from the Short Mills (N. Y.) Club, 62, 64, 75, at the Manursing Island club.

title: ISRAELIS APPROVE PLAN TO DISENGAGE SUEZLINE ARMIES
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 13The Government of Israel today approved a specific proposal for the separation of Israeli and Egyptian forces along the Suez Canal and authorized Secretary of State Kissinger to present the plan to the Government of Egypt.

title: Crusaders Power Brings 42 Triumph
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 13 (AP) Goals by Paul Shmyr and Russ Walker within two minutes in the second period sparked the Cleveland Crusaders to a 42 victory over the Minnesota Fighting Saints in World Hockey Association play today.

title: HENRY C. M'MULLEN
description: SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Jan. 13  Henry C. McMullen, former president of the Union County Bar Association and municipal magistrate here from 1948 until 1960, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital, Summit. He was 78 years old and lived at 41 Mountain Avenue.

title: Miami Takes Super Bowl Again, 247
description: Football's Super Sunday brought to an end yesterday the National League's championship season amid the sounds of jingling cash registers and the happy wails of football widows who reclaimed their husbands.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: VILLAGE VIBES Now that the Super Bowl has come and gone, and the basketball and and hockey playoffs and the opening of the baseball season remain, like the comet Kohoutek, dim and distant, maybe it's time for all the chairbound to stop watching and start doing. For the footloose, there's something new In town, beginning tonight, to brighten the blue Mondays of the dead of winter. It's a series of dance and variety shows, generally with live music, a weekly event set at the Village Gate, at 160 Bleecker Street. The dancing begins at 8 P.M., and the variety segment starts at 10. Admission, payable at the the door, is $2.50, and all proceeds are for the benefit of radio station WBAIFM

title: Energy, Research Plan
description: The Administration will propose spending about $1.6billion for energy research end development during the aext fiscal year. Page 20.

title: Rockefeller Holdings Studied
description: ALBANY, Jan. 13  A 1959 disclosure by Nelson A. Rockefeller of his holdings in companies regulated by state agencies was left unchanged during 13 years of his tenure as Governor, although his corporate portfolio apparently shifted substantially during that time, according to records on file in the office of the Secretary of State.

title: Super Bowl at a Glance
RothRappaport Team Adds Bridge: Regional. Title to Laurels
description: LIBERTY, N.Y., Jan. 13The country's leading mixed pair added another title a large collection here yesterday in the tristate regional championships. Alvin Roth of New York and Barbara Rappaport of East Orange, N.J., who will be the only mixed pair to represent the United States in the world pair championship in the Canary Islands next May were victorious in the open pairs.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Clovis Ruffin isn't one of your staid, uptight designers. Not by a long shot, But the way the girls came gyrating down the runway of the Gotham Hotel's ballroom the otherafternoon, chiffon flying and all that, you could see that even he had loosened up.

title: Lady Patricia Ramsay Is Dead; Granddaughter of Victoria, 87
description: LONDON, Jan. 13 (AP)Lady Patricia Ramsay, a granddaughter of Queen Victoria who broke several court traditions, died yesterday at her home in Windlesham, Surrey. She was 87 years old.

title: NEW SOVIET SUBS CALLED CHALLENGE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 The Soviet Union is expanding its capacity for building nuclear submarines and starting work on a new, larger Class of missile submarine, according to Pentagon officials.

title: A Warp in the Old Woof
description: INDIAN ROCKS BEACH, Fla.Dogs used to be fine back in the old days, before they took obedience courses and vocational training and learned how to parody human skills in their clumsy way. But they've become pain in the neck.

title: justice Powell's Continued Conservatism Reflected in Two Opinions
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13The liberal lawyers and judges who have been hopefully predicting for the last two years that President Nixon would come to regret his appointment of Lewis F. Powell Jr. to the Supreme Court was strangely silent last week.

title: Van Cliburn's Father Dies
description: SHREVEPORT, La., Jan. 13 (UPI)  Harvey Levan Cliburn, father of the concert pianist Van Cliburn, died yesterday at the age of 75. He was a retired regional executive of the Mobil Oil Company. The elder Cliburn and his wife were given lifetime memberships in the Shreveport Symphony after their son won the Tchaikovsky International Competition in 1958. The Cliburns were also members of the Metropolitan Opera Guild in New York.

title: Colombia Ousts U.S. In Cup Play
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 13 AP)  Colombia eliminated the United States from the Davis Cup competition today when Jairo Velasco beat Erik van Dillen of Aptos, Calif., 60, 75, 46, 63.

title: The winning New, Tersey daily.lottery number yesterday was: 90435
description: Tickets matching The number win 12,500. Tickets, with the five numbers In reverse win $22S. Tickets with the first or test four numbers in order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers th seeuence win S25. Tidasts with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matchine the first and second digits, the second and third, the third 4.51 fowls or the fourth and fifth win $2.

title: Accord Would End Feud and Avert Court Battle
description: The bitter, 18monthlong feud between the National Hockey League and the rival World Association will end within a few days.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 14Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis today called for a Congressional investigation into the pricing and allocation of fuel oils. The Maine Governor was the first witness before Senator Edmund S. Muskie's subcommittee on intergovernmental relations, which conducting a hearing on the impact of the energy crisis in New England. Mr. Curtis decried the layoff of 2,000 Maine workers because of the energy crisis.

title: LOUIS G. WELT, 60, OF YALE MEDICAL
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan, 14Dr. Louis Gordon Welt, medical educator and research scientist, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his office in the Yale New Haven Medical Center. He was 60 years old and lived here.

title: Mr. Shanker's Vendetta
description: The appointment of Dr. Marilyn Gittell as associate provost and assistant vice president of Brooklyn College should have been a matter of academic routine. Dr. Gittell's qualifications as a teacher and administrator are recognized. As a political scientist, it is true, she has always rejected the posture of the uninvolved scholar, her politicoeducational activism often embroiling her in the very issues which also constituted the subject of her research. But it is only under a shaky concept of academic freedom that disagreement over Dr. Gittell's espousal of community control of schools could be turned into a roadblock to career advancement.

title: Madison Fund Seeking Food Shares
description: Madison Fund, Inc., a closedend investment company, with a diversified portfolio of stocks in various concerns, is seeking to increase its ownership in First National Stores, Inc., a leading food chain with some 357 units in the New. England, and New York areas. The fund announced yesterday that it was offering to purchase at least 250,000 shares, or 18.3 per cent, of First National's 1.4, million shares outstanding at $23 a share, or total of $5.75million. First National opened at 22 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and closed at 21, up 2 points.

title: Bridge: No Team Has a 100% Score Up to Last Round of Contest
Detective Tells of Burning Findings in Carpi Murder
description: TRENTON, Dec. 14  Detective Samuel F. Bianco of the Princeton Township Police Department testified under crossexamination today that had burned a 60page investigative report the morning the day he had been subpoenaed to bring in all the records he had on the Carpi murder case for a pretrial hearing.

title: Stennis to Examine Spying by Military
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14Senator John C. Stennis, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said today that he planned to begin an hlfonrial inquiry this week into alleged military spying inside the White House.

title: Briton Will Visit Hungary, Then Rumania and Bulgaria
description: LONDON, Jan, 14 (Reuters) Sir Alec DouglasHome, the Foreign Secretary, will pay official visits to Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria from April 21 to 27 for talks on European economic and security questions and other issues.

title: SILVER FUTURES CLIMB TO RECORD
description: Higher prices for gold traded abroad and for goldcompany stocks here propelled silver futures to record highs yesterday In active trading on the Commodity Exchange. Silver coins traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange also set highs.

title: Soviet Opens a Big Container Terminal
description: A soviet shipping official has announced the opening of a big container terminal at the Pacific port of Nakhodka, formally inaugurating a longplanned container bridge through Siberia between Japan and West

title: SAIGON RETAKING HIGHLANDS BASE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 14 (Reuters)About 30 South Vietnamese soldiers were back today in a remote border base in the Central Highlands nearly four months after the base was overrun by Communist tanks.

title: Strong 74 Business Performance Is Seen
description: A strong business performance for 1974 is widely expected by business and industrial leaders, a survey by The New York Times of dozens of leading companies disclosed, although the energy crisis and continuing questions over the Nixon Administration's economic controls program caused much uncertainty in the forecasting.

title: Citizens Groups Oppose F. C. C. ReRegulation Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 Representatives of 161 citizens groups today challenged members of the Federal Communications Commission to explain how the public interest would be served by the F.C.C.'s efforts to reregulate radio and reexamine the broadcast fairness doctrine for possible modification or even its repeal.

title: Beame to Help Mark Martin L. King Day
description: A memorial service for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. will begin at noon today at the Convent Avenue Baptist Church, 420 West 145th Street, and will be attended by Mayor Beame, who will read a proclamation to commemorate the day.

title: Brady Is Chosen Jockey Club Head
description: Nicholas F. Brady has been named chairman of the Jockey Club.

title: U.S. CONCERN QUITS THAI AIRPORT JOB
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 14 (Reuters) The Northrop Airport Development Corporation and other partners have pulled out of.a project to build a $125million, second international airport for Thailand, it was announced here today.

title: Bradley Married
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 14Bill Bradley used the AllStar break to marry Ernestine Schlant of New York today. They were married at the Royal Poinciana Chapel by the Rev. S. M. Lindsay. Bradley's parents, Mr. and Mrs. W. W. Bradley, came from Crystal City, Mo., to attend the ceremony. A marriage license was issued to the couple on Jan. 9.

title: People and Business
description: Trading was halted briefly yesterday morning on the Midwest Stock Exchange to mark a historic moment: the presence on its trading floor of a woman member.

title: Army Meets Goal Again
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI)  For the second consecutive month the Army met its recruiting goals in December. It attracted 102 per cent of its objective of 12,800 recruits compared with 104 per cent in November.

title: Dayan Says Missile That Started Blaze In Sinai Had Defect
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 14Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said today that a technical shortcoming in an Americanmade Hawk groundtoair missile was responsible for a multimilliondollar blaze in offshore oil wells in the Gulf of Suez.

title: Notes on People
description: Jules Leger, a 60yearold career diplomat, was sworn in yesterday as Canada's 21st GovernorGeneral amid pageantry that included the blaring of trumpet fanfares, the red erminetrimmed robes of Supreme Court justices, and Cabinet members decked out in morning coats.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: Dolphins So Much in Charge Even Blunders Didn't Matter
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 14Don Shula, their coach, said today that the Miami Dolphins played our best football of the season in defeating the Minnesota Vikings, 247, in the Super Bowl game here yesterday. That assessment was understandable, but Shula added depth to the style of the victory by noting that the Dolphins on three occasions made basic blunders but survived them all beautifully,

title: Eight Grandmasters in Hot Pursuit of the King
description: There stands Bobby Fischer,. tall, broad  and invisible. The chess champion of the world has not played in public since winning the title in Reykjavik, Iceland, about 16 months ago. Indeed, he has scercly surfaced and only a few close Mends know where he currently is or, even, where he is living.

title: Books of The Times
description: ROPE ABANDONED, By Nadezhda Mandel. stam. Translated from the Russian by Max Hayward. 687 pages. Atheneum. $13.95.

title: The Cosmic Flopperoo
description: Kohoutek has failed its promoters. It is a nothing act. It is the biggest flopperoo since Kelly hit Broadway at a cost of $700,000 and folded on the first night. It is the Edsel of the firmament.

title: Price Is $6.5Million Local Owner Being Sought
description: Charlie Finley, perhaps the only owner in sports ever denounced on the floor of the United States Senate, will sell his California Golden Seals to the National Hockey League this week for $6,585,000.

title: Venezuela Plans to Adjust Oil Prices
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 14 (UPI)A high official in the Mines Ministry said today that Venezuela would adjust her oil prices Feb. 1 despite a price freeze agreed upon by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (0.P.E.C.) in Geneva.

title: Miss Durr Upset In Coast Tennis
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 14 (AP)Rain plagued the openingday schedule of the $50,000 San Francisco Virginia Slims tennis tournament today and Karen Krantzcke ruined the hopes of sixthseeded Francoise Durr of France.

title: STOCKPILED COPPER UP FOR BIDS FEB. 5
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) The General Services Administration said today that the first in a series of monthly competitive bids for Governmentstockpiled copper would be opened Feb. 5 on an offering of 100 million pounds.

title: Detroit Institute Buys A Lost Caravaggio Oil
description: DETROIT, Jan 11In one of the most significant museum coups of recent decades, the Detroit Institute of Arts has acquired a lost major work, The Conversion of the Magdalene, painted in 1598 by Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio, the great master of Italian baroque art. The purchase price was $1.1million.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI)  The Cost of Living Council exempted today domestically produced ferronickel, a major ingredient of stainless steel, from price controls.

title: NUROCK WORKSHOP: MUSIC A CAPPELLA
description: Kirk Nurock's Natural Sound Workshop, which appeared Saturday night at the WBAI Free Music Store, 359 East 62d Street, is built on an engaging idea. The 20member group makes sound entirely independent of instruments or amplification, mostly vocal and mostly lavoiding fixed pitches and words.

title: Dead Fish Are Sought In Atom Plant Closing
description: LACEY TOWNSHIP, Jan. 14Investigators for the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection today searched the milelong Oyster Creek between the Route 9 bridge and the outlet of the creek in the Barnegat Bay near Waretown for fish reported to have been killed by the shutdown of the atomic power plant here of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company. The shutdown Friday night caused the water temperatures in the creek to drop by 20 degrees.

title: Japanese Premier, Ending Tour, Runs Into Indonesian Protesters
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 14 After quick, quiet stops in Singapore and Malaysia, Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan landed here tonight on the last stop of his Southeast Asian tour and ran immediately into Indonesia's student protesters.

title: ASTRONAUTS SET ENDURANCE MARK
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 14 (AP)The Skylab 3 astronauts set a record today for the longest manned space flight, a world mark that may stand for a decade.

title: Student, 82, Becomes M.A.
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (UPI)George R. Lockhart easily was the oldest of the 115 persons to receive master's degrees yesterday from Chicago State University. He is 82. Mr. Lockhart, a native of the British West Indies and a high school dropout, received his degree in British history.

title: U.S. Davis Cup Defeat Stirs Dissatisfaction
description: How important is the Davis Cup to the United States?

title: AMEX PRICES UP IN DULL TRADING
STEEL PRODUCTION OFF 0.4% FOR WEEK
New Jersey Sports Father Is Upstaged
description: Ed (Buzzy) Fox has built a fine reputation as basketball coach at St. Patrick's in Elizabeth. In his 10year te,nure, his teams have collected three state titles and finished as a state runnerup and semifinalist on two other occasions.

title: Pennsylvania Bell Spending
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 (UPI)The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania said today it would have construction expenditures this year in exxcess of $390million, an increase of nearly $24million over last year. William S. Cashel Jr., Bell president, said in a yearend statement that "this huge investment would come at a time when inflation continues to run rampant and the cost of new capital remains very high. He also noted that a yearold request for badly needed increased revenues was cut more than a third ruled on last month.

title: Black American Held in Berlin As a Spy for the East Germans
description: BERLIN, Jan. 14A 53yearold black American who identified himself as a reporter from New York was arrested Nov. 23 on a charge of espionage for East Germany, West Berlin officials disclosed today.

title: Reserve Unit Voted MoneyMarket Ease
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee sought at its Oct. 16 meeting to make sure that growth resumed in the money supply even if its operations meant some decline in shortterm interest rates, it was disclosed today.

title: First Jersey Inaugural Concert Is Performed in Honor of Byrne
description: TRENTON, Jan. 14 The first inaugural concert in New Jersey's history was staged here this evening for the Gove,:ncrelect, Brendan T. Byrne, members of the state's cultural community and the public.

title: Eight Grandmasters in Hot Pursuit of the King
description: There stands Bobby Fischer, tall, broad  and invisible. The chess champion of the world has not played in public since winning the title in Reykjavik, Iceland, about 16 months ago. Indeed, he has scarcely surfaced and Only a few close friends know where he currently is or, even, where he is living.

title: City Trains Recruits for Sanitation Jobs
description: The city started a training program yesterday aimed at preparing candidates, particularly from minority groups, for the sanitation man examination, which 65,000 applicants have said they want to take.

title: Soviet Assails Book By Solzhenitsyn; Calls Him Traitor
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 14The Soviet Union made a major attack upon Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn today, charging that his new book on the nation's penal system was stuffed with cynical falsifications, concocted to serve the forces of imperialist reaction.

title: Poll Represents Makeup Of City Shown in Census
description: The selection of residents interviewed in The New York Times survey of the city conducted by Daniel Yankelovich, Inc., a leading public opinion research organization, was done in a way that New York's population reproduces as broken down by borough, age, marital status, race, voter registration and other categories in the 1970 census. Nearly all the 1,341 respondents were interviewed by telephone, with names chosen randomly from all the city's telephone directories plus some random digit dialings to account for unlisted telephones.

title: JewishBlack Ties Urged to Improve Lot of Minorities
description: A leader in American Reform Judaism appealed yesterday to the Jewish and black communities of New York to make today, Martin Luther King Day, a time for renewal of their old working coalition aimed at improving the welfare of minority groups.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: RALEIGH, N. C.Having pursued wild quail and woodcock for one clay with Frank Barick, I knew that if I was to get my share of the birds on our next hunt, I would have to move faster.

title: Police Guard Dolphins In Miami After Threat
description: MIAMI, Jan. 14 (AP)Police threw a tight ring of security around Miami Dolphins coaches and players upon their arrival at Miami International Airport today because of telephone threats.

title: Linda Hopkins, in Her Own Way, Sings With Bessie Smith Vitality
description: Bessie Smith has been used as a source of material by several singers in recent years, almost invariably to the contemporary singer's disadvantage. Miss Smith had such a strong personality, even on the 40yearold records that are her basic means of communicating with us today, that the mere memory of her overwhelms most of those who try to follow in her footsteps.

title: Herbert R. Johnson Dies; A Retired Stockbroker, 96
description: TENAFLY, N. J., Jan. 14Herbert R. Johnson, who retired in 1969 as a senior partner in Orvis Brothers, stockbrokers, died Sunday at his home, 137 Engle Street. He was 96 years old.

title: HARRIETTE M'LOUGHLIN
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 14 Harriette Hollis McLoughlin, daughter of John T. McLoughlin of Princeton, president of the Vick Chemical Company, was fatally injured Saturday in a onecar accident near Cambridge, Vt. She was 19 years old and had been employed by the Red Fox Ski Dormitory in Jeffersonville, Vt.

title: State to Call 30 Witnesses To Stand at Mackell Trial
description: Jury selection began yesterday in the misdemeanor trial of former Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell shortly after the prosecution disclOsed it would summon 30 witnesses to testify in the case.

title: Southern Railway Outlay
description: The Southern Railway announced yesterday that its board had authorized capital expenditures of more than $176million, a record for the carrier and one of the largest In the industry. More than half the total will go for diesel locomotives and freight cars.

title: Pentagon Increases Trim Of the Military to 58,000
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP)  The Defense Department announced today plans to cut its manpower over the next six months well beyond reductions imposed by Congress.

title: PATH EXTENSION DRAWS SUPPORT
description: NEWARK, Jan. 14The first public hearing held by the Port AuthoPity of New York and New Jersey ot discuss its $222million Plainfieldcorridor commuter project produced an atmosphere tonight of strong support from business and local govenment officials who testified.

title: Saxbe Asked to Resolve Disputel On F.B.I. Control of Crime Data
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP)  Attorney General William B. Saxbe has been asked to refa dispute over proposed Federal controls on crime records sent to state and local governments.

title: A Midwest District Leans to Impeachment
description: BURLINGTON, Iowa, Jan. 12Outside, the temperature was a bonewarping 20 degrees below zero. Inside a room in the small Federal building in this modest city on the Mississippi River in southeastern Iowa the thermostat was turned up to a defiant 72 degrees. And the mood of the more than 100

title: F.T.C. Law Judge Seeks to Extend I.T.T. Bakery Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 14 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission announced today that an F.T.C. law judge, Alvin L. man, had recommended extension of a legal order barring bakery acquisitions by the I.T.T Continental Baking Company, which markets Wonder Bread and Hostess snack cakes. The finding will be reviewed by the fivemember commission.

title: Phillips Petroleum Expects Turnaround in 73 Earnings
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said yesterday that it expected earnings for 1973 to be substantially improved from unstatisfactory results of the last several years.

title: ASSEMBLY EFFORT AT CHANGE SCORED
description: ALBANY, Jan, 14The Assembly passed rules changes today designed to make the Legislature more effective and open to the public, but the changes were immediately branded as meaningless by the Democrats and as a sham by goodgovernment groups.

title: CITY HEALTH SETUP TO BE REVAMPED
description: A comprehensive reorganization of the city's health services, involving some decentralization of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, more authority for the Health Commissioner and less autonomy for some departments, is quietly being worked out by a special committee that is advising Mayor Beame informally on health problems.

title: Detective Tells of Burning Findings in Carpi Murder
description: TRENTON, Dec. 14  Detective Samuel F. Bianco of the Princetown Township Police Department testified under crossexamination today that he had burned a 60page investigative report the morning of the day he had been subpoenaed to bring in all the records he had on the Carpi murder case for a pretrial hearing.

title: Rebels Said to Cut Phnom Penh's Link To Its Port Again
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan: 14 (UPI)The Cambodian command said that guerrilla forces cut Route 4 about 16 miles southwest of the capital yesterday, severing Phnom, Penh's link to Kompong Somd Cambodia's only deepwater port, again.

title: W.C.T.U. Asks Brewing Halt
description: EVANSTON, III., Jan. 14 (UPI) The president of the Women's Christian Temperance Union said today the Nixon Administration should shut down the nation's breweries and distilleries as a belttightening step ;toward improving the nation's ;economy.

title: Soviet Officials Outfox Crafty Fruit Smugglers
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 14In the farmers markets of Moscow and other central Russian cities a common. lament this winter is that there is almost no succulent fruit from the neartropical orchards around the Black Sea in Soviet Georgia.

title: Peter Pinkernell Dies at 61; Accounting Firm Partner
description: Peter H. Pinkernell, a'senior partner in the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen & Co. and a member since 1966 of the New York State Board of Examiners for certified public accountants, died Sunday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 96 Barkers Point Road, Sands Point, L. I.

title: WOMEN'S REQUEST IS DENIED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission today denied women's rights request for ruling to prohibit sex and race discrimination in the securities industry.

title: High Court to Rule on Space to Reply to Newspapers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether states can require newspapers to provide free space for political candidates to reply to criticism in editorials or news columns.

title: SENATOR ALLEGES SECRET OIL PAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, has alleged in letters sent to Secretary of State Kissinger and Attorney General William B. Saxbe that secret decisions by the Government have shaped the nation's energy policy for 20 years.

title: COURT OVERRULES ARMY DRUG DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 14A United States district judge ruled today that the drugrehabilitation program of the Army's European command was illegal and told the Army to rewrite the program's regulations.

title: Market Place: Inflation Makes Tax Bite Bigger
Nixon's Nuclear Doctrine
description: For some two decades, since the advent of the Soviet Hbomb, the dominant concept in American military planning has been that there could be no winners, only losers, in a strategic nuclear war with the Soviet Union. The central aim of Presidents Eisenhower, Kennedy and Johnson was deterrence.

title: MARYLAND COURT URGED BY PANEL TO DISBAR AGNEW Undivided Recommendation by a 3Judge Unit Terms Him Unfit to Be Lawyer
U.S. BUSINESS UNIT IN FRAUD INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) The Small Business Administration is investigating allegations that three white North Carolina businessmen set up minority employes in spinoff concerns and then milked them profitless with management fees, officials say.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Richard C. Leone, who has been appointed State Treasurer, announced that Clifford A. Goldman of Ewing Township would become deputy state treasurer. Mr. Leone, who takes Ace today, shortly after Brendan T. Byrne is inaugurated as Governor, said Mr. Goldman would have the special responsibility to find a way to meet the requirements a Supreme Court decision ordering a new method of school financing in the state.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Bargaining talks continued yesterday between Actors Equity and the League of Of Broadway Theaters and Producers covering terms of a new labor contract to replace the one that expired Jan. 6.

title: Excerpt From 3Judge Maryland Panel Recommendation for Agnew Disbarment
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 14Fot. lowing is an excerpt front the recommendation by a threejudge panel of Maryland judges that former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew be disbarred:

title: Monika Kaserer First In Swiss Giant Slalom
description: GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 14 (AP)Monika Kaserer of Austria, a 22yearold seasoned skier on the teenagedominated international circuit, won a grueling giant slalom today and surged back into the front ranks of the World Cup standing.

title: Return on Equity 15%
Cod Is Urged as Symbol
description: BOSTON, Jan: 14 (AP) State Sen. William L. Saltonstall, Republican of Manchester, sohught today to remedy an oversightlby our forebears and filed a resolve urging the recognition of the cod as the state symbol. He said he wanted to call attention to the fact that we still care about the codfish, that he's still a part of our history and an important part of our economy, His action followed a discovery that the cod has no official status as a state symbol.

title: Energy Crisis Hogs the Show As Monetary Meeting Opens
description: ROME, Jan. 14Officials and money experts from 20 countries opened weeklong talks today on international monetary reform.

title: STOCK ANALYSTS AGREE ON CAUTION
description: Speakers at an international investment conference yesterday did have some kind words: to say about gold and the potential of the Wall Street stock market, but an air of global caution held sway in, the carpeted grand ballroom of ,the New York Hilton.

title: Ethel Merman's Mother Dies
description: Mrs. Agnes G. Zimmerman, mother of Ethel Merman, the musical comedy actress, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. She was 90 years old and lived at the Berkshire Hotel, 21 East 52d Street. She leaves, besides her daughter, her husband, Edward, a retired accountant.

title: CommodoreLiquidatingUnit
description: The Commodore Corporation, a maker of mobile homes based in Omaha, said yesterday that it was liquidating its Banner Homes Corporation subsidiary that manufactures recreational vehicles. In the fiscal year to June 30, Banner's sales represented 16 per cent of Commodore's $110million annual volume. The energy crisis, the company said has caused sales of motor homes to decline.

title: President Passes Brief Health Test; Fatigue Observed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) President Nixon underwent a brief physical examination today and his personal physician said the President appeared to be in good health.

title: Some City Memories to Go Under Auctioneer's Gavel
description: When the old New York Tribune building near City Hall was dedicated by Horace Greeley's daughter a century ago this month, journalistic mementos of the period were locked into a brass box placed inside the cornerstone. Editorial staff sheets, copies of rival papers, city government reports and autographed manuscripts by Mr. Greeley, The Tribune's founder, were among the things preserved for history on Jan. 24, 1874.

title: GOING OUT
description: AVON CALLING Gone are the days when Brooklyn used to be good for a laugh as the home of Dem Bums. These days, it is the residence of the Royal Shakespeare Company, which has crossed the Gowanus under the auspices of the Brooklyn Academy of Music and Brooklyn College.

title: HARRY T. GHERARDI, ARCHITECT, 67, DIES
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Jan, 14Harry Taylor Gherardi, an ar. chitect who in 1929 joined what was thin the firm of Voorhees, Gmelin & Walker, died today in Princeton Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 37 Snowden Lane.

title: U.S. AIDES HOPEFUL THAT HEATING OIL WILL LAST WED
Simon Hints Relief for City With Gasoline Allocations
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 William E. Simon, the Federal energy administrator, held out hope today to New York City for relief from the long lineups through which gasoline buyers have suffered at service stations.

title: GILBERT M. LANDY
description: YONKERS, Jan. 14Gilbert M. Landy, a city judge here since 1961, died today in Yonkers Professional Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 20 Woodland Terrace.

title: Fraud Is Charged in Offer Of Sports Complex Bonds
description: NEWARK, Jan, 14  The town of East Rutherford and its Mayor asked a Federal Court here today to enjoin the sale of a $295million New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority bond issue on the ground that underwriters had breached antifraud provisions of the securities laws.

title: Lockheed Layoffs Rise
description: BURBANK, Calif., Jan. 14 (AP)Lockheed Aircraft Corporation said today it was laying off an additional 2,500 employes because of the cutback in production of the 1.1011 riStar jumbo jetliner. This will bring layoffs at the Lockheed California division, builder of the TriStar, to about 5,000 since last Nov. 3.

title: 3 Youths Seized as Kidnappers Of Student From Queens Home
description: Detectives captured three kidnapping suspects yesterday and freed a 20yearold student they were said to have seized by taking him from his Elmhurst, Queens, home at the point of a knife.

title: Soviet Assails Book By Solzhenitsyn.; Calls HimTraitor
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 14The Soviet Union made a major attack upon Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn today, charging that his new book on the nation's penal system was stuffed with cynical falsifications, concocted to serve the forces of imperialist reaction.

title: Test Set Of Stars In N.B.A.
description: SEATTLE, Jan. 14  A streamlined format and the absence of some familiar figures will mark tomorrow night's 24th annual EastWest National Basketball Association AllStar game here, to be televised nationally by the Columbia Broadcasting System (Channel 2, 9:30 P.M., in New York).

title: Basketball Ratings WRITERS RATINGS
2 Troupes, 2 Views Same Plath
description: Using much of the identical poetry and prose by Sylvia Plathwho became a literary figure of special inest after her suicide in 1963 at the age of 31the British Royal Shakespeare Company and the American New York Tea Party, a tiny company that began as a feminist consciounessraising group, are presenting separate productions here within a few days of each other.

title: No. 2 Man for the Police
description: At noon yesterday, Police Commissioner Michael J Codd pinned a gold badge on Assistant Chief Inspector James M. Taylor and appointed him first deputy commissioner, the second most important post in the department.

title: 38 Haitian Refugees Seized After Rescue in Atlantic
description: MIAMI, Jan. 14 (UPI) Thirtyeight Haitian refugees, who were rescued from their foundering wooden boat in the Atlantic Thursday, arrived here last night aboard a Coast Guard cutter.

title: Assembly Votes to Drop RapeCorroboration Rule
description: ALBANY, Jan. 14The Assembly today unanimously voted to remove the requirement of corroboration in rape cases from the state's Penal Codea move that for years has been urged by women'sliberation and civilliberties groups and lawenforcement officials.

title: ROBERT MILLER DIES; KODAK EXECUTIVE 56
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 14Robert W. Miller; executive vice president and general manager of the United States aild Canadian Photographic Division of the Eastman Kodak Company of Rochester, N. Y., died here yesterday of a heart attack. His age was 56 and he lived in Brighton, N. Y., near Rochester.

title: L.S.U. Five Shrinks to 4 And Loses
description: STARKVILLE, Miss., Jail 14 (UPI)Larry Fry led secondhalf surge tonight a, Mississippi State downec Louisiana State, 8975, in game that saw the loser: finish with only four players

title: Paine, Webber Expands Profit On Volume From Acquisitions
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14 Bolstered by increased volume from acquisitions, earnings of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, Inc., climbed to 40 cents a share in the quarter ended Dec. 31, the brokerage house reported today. Earnings were equal to 25 cents a share in the corresponding period of 1972.

title: CON ED INCREASES VOLTAGE CUT TO 5%;RoundtheClock Reduction in Power Seeks to Save Dwindling Fuel Supply
description: With only a 10day tui9P1Y residual oil on hand to generate electricity, instead of a normal 25day supply, the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday put into effect a5 per tent roundtheclock, seiendaya week voltage reduction.

title: Acupuncture Center Opens
description: EGREMONT, Mass., Jan. 14 (AP)The Acupuncture Center at the Berkshires, the second such center in western Massachusetts, opened here today. The first is in Springfield.

title: Stage Welcome Revival
description: There is little wrong with the American stagealthough something always seems to be ailing itthat a few more plays like Hugh Wheeler's Look: We've Come Through couldn't cure.

title: Stones Raises Jumping Goals, But Lowers His School Aims
description: Dwight Stones confidently predicted yesterday that he would set a world indoor high jump record of 7 feet 5 inches this winter and a world outdoor mark of 7 feet 7 inches this year, The 20yearold Califor nian who holds the current world outdoor standard of 7 feet 6 inches, isn't going to let such things as college studies interfere with these achievements, Stones, who is in his second year at Glendale Junior College, said, This is it. I've had it in college and I'm finished after this spring. I don't need it. My application of intelligence is

title: Canada Will Curb Tapping But Give Leeway to Police
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 14Canada's Parliament today limited wiretapping and other types of electronic eavesdropping by law enforcement agencies.

title: YONKERS MANAGER WILL RESIGN POST
description: YONKERS, Jan. 14Dr. Seymour Scher, the controversial City Manager of Yonkers, announced today that he would resign in a few weeks at the request of the city's new Republican leadership.

title: Quarter Rise Is Sharp
MARYLAND COURT URGED BY PANEL TO DISBAR AGNEW;
ExCity Aide Guilty In Plot to Distribute Millions in Cocaine
description: Howard Z. Fuchs, a former city welfare investigator who allegedly ran a multhnilliondollar narcotics ring in the metropolitan area, was convicted of Federal drug charges in Brooklyn yesterday.

title: First Inaugural Concert In State Is Held for Byrne
description: TRENTON, Jan. 14The first inaugural concert in New Jersey's history was staged here this evening for the Governorelect, Brendan T. Byrne, members of the state's cultural community and the public.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Sells Bonds at Lower Interest

title: STATE CHALLENGES INVESTMENT SCHEME
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefitowitz said yesterday that the promoters of a German investment scheme involving European houses of prostitution have been directed to produce books and records and to testify in Supreme Court for New York County here on Jan. 28.

title: Judge in California Delays Rearing on Ehrlichman Plea
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 14 (UPI)A county judge delayed today until Feb. 25 a hearing on whether burglary charges should be dropped against John D. Ehrlichman, former chief White House doMostic adviser, and others in connection with the 1971 break in at the office of Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist on the ground that they were acting as Federal police officers.

title: Heath Fails to End Dispute With Miners
description: LONDON, Jan. 14  After five and a half hours of talks, Prime Minister Heath and Britain's union leaders failed tonight to reach an agreement on ending the dispute with the lcoal miners.

title: Clothilde Sakharoff Dies; European Ballet Dancer
description: ROME, Jan. 14tlothilde Sakharoff, formerly one of Europe's bestknown ballet dancers, died here Friday at the age of 80.

title: Myrtle Saxe Jacobson Is Dead; Dean at Brooklyn College, 54
description: Dean Myrtle Saxe Jacobson, director of the Brooklyn College School of General Studies (the evening division), died Sunday at Albert Einstein Hospital. She was 54 years old and lived at 1662 Glenwood Road, Brooklyn.

title: Seoul Reduces Income Tax and Curbs Luxuries
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 14 President Park Chung Hee, in a move to cope with economic difficulties facing South Korea, announced a series of financial measures today to reduce the tax burden on people with low incomes, curb spending for luxuries and conserve gasoline.

title: Basketball, Hockey Standings
Contract Awards
description: The Mitsubishi International Corporation, leading Japanese trading company, announced yesterday a joint venture with Abramson Enterprises and Brisbane Management under which Americana Hotels, Inc., would operate its newly acquired Canyon Hotel and Country Club Estates at Palm Springs, Calif. The $22million agreement marks the initial hotel venture in this country by Mitsubishi. The Canyon Hotel would be the 20th property in the rapidly expanding Americana chain and its second acquisition on the West Coast. Americana Hotels is a subsidiary of the American Airlines.

title: Aspin Asks G.A.O. Inquiry Into Loan to Hotel in Haiti

title: AIRTRAFFICCONTROL BLAMED FOR CRASH!
description: CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 14 (AP)  Delta Air Lines contended today that airtraffic controllers were responsible for the July 31 crash of a Delta jet at Boston's Logan International Airport. All 89 persons aboard died in the crash.

title: Film: 'Sticky My Fingers' and 4 Other Early Works:The Program
description: Graceful as grizzlies, supple as mastodons, the middle-aged men who cherish their games of touch football in Central Park bruise their egos as well as their limbs in John Hancock's delightful short feature, "Sticky My Fingers Fleet My Feet," which is included in "Hollywood's New Directors: Early Works." The program opened Sunday at the Whitney Museum of American Art and will run through Jan. 23. The films are linked by the fact that these young directors developed out of film schools or with grants from the American Film Institute, rather than through years of work in Hollywood.Mr. Hancock's film, with a script by himself and John Lahr, was adapted from a New Yorker short story by Gene Williams, who also plays the lead. It now appears as a dexterous warm-up for Mr. Hancock's "Bang the Drum Slowly." There's the same sensitivity to individuals and their obsessionsas revealed in the context of sports.The happy amateur players of "Sticky My Fingers" are as vulnerable to aging as the doomed professional ball-player of "Bang the Drum" is to death. Although "When the goin" "gets rough, the rough get goin" is gleefully repeated, the amateurs are threatened from the start: They can't even protect their ball from a tiny child whose mother scornfully tells her to return their "toy." Then a teen-age boy joins their game and runs away with it. Stocky and pudgy bodies lurch and surge about, panting and stumbling and collapsing, but they can't catch the adolescent who politely calls them "sir." Equally funny and touching, this small film deserves a long life.Martin Scorsese's "It's Not Just You Murray" focuses on the development of hoods, as does his "Mean Streets." But his early picture is a spoof, centered on an amiable fellow who begins by making gin and ends up as a successful racketeer. What's pleasing throughout is the way that the narration contradicts what's taking place on the screen: A calm, cheerful voice accompanies the beatings and jailings and betrayals that appear as unavoidable hazards of the profession.All of these early works partake of parody, with one exception: George Lucas's "Electronic Labyrinth." Unfortunately, it also seems like a parodyof many other films about the dehumanized future. Actually, it served as a dry run for Mr. Lucas's "THX1138," which concerned programed people with numbers stamped on their foreheads who were forbidden to love their "mates." Here, most of the film shows the man who rebelled against the system running through endless corridorsas though trying to flee from both the future and the past. A sense of panic is conveyed by the numbing whiteness of that labyrinth, but the actor's face can't manage to look frightened, and much of the film is just too clumsy to be chilling.Terrence Malick, who later made "Badlands," is represented by "Lanton Mills." It's intended as a take-off on Westerns, but the acting is languid and stilted, and what comes through is a study in fatigue. Still, there are a couple of nice moments, as when two incompetent stick-up men warn a bankful of people not to "get upset"and the unimpressed crowd isn't even ruffledor when a dying robber chats casually with the repentant cop who shot him. But the movie makes one doubt if there's a market for slow satire.Brian De Palma, whose films include "Greetings" and "Sisters," reveals a rather gentle affection for old-fashioned horror in "Woton's Wake," which parodies the styles of silent films. Woton grins and nods and squints like a number of your favorite monsters, as he chases his victims and sets them afire with a torch, or tries on wigs and fangs and noses with all the concentration of a beauty queen before the mirror. We could do without the shot of a mushroom cloud at the end, but otherwise this little pantomine of destruction works deftly and daftly.

title: Madison Square Garden Shows Profit
Dave Anderson
description: HOUSTON, Jan. I4Treasure the Miami Dolphins now because they won't be quite the same next season. The best team ever to play football succeeded with a formula of human chemistry that already has been diluted. The constant of the defensive unit, Bill Arnsparger, is leaving to become the New York Giants head coach. Several variables on offense, meaning players, are uncomfortable. Jim Kiick hopes Arnsparger will bring him to the Giants where he would be a starting running back. Jim Mandich is looking to the new World Football League after having exercised the option clause in his contract. Earl Morrall probably will retire as the backup quarterback. Larry Csonka and Paul Warfield will demand expensive salaries from Joe Robbie, the owner. If permitted to become bitter, those negotiations would jeopardize the Dolphins opportunity to be the first team to win three consecutive Super Bowl games. Moments after the Dolphins 247 domination of the Minnesota Vikings yesterday, Nick Buoniconti, the middle linebacker, served notice that Joe Robbie's profits are now under seige.

title: New Monetary Design

Since then the October war in the Mideast, the Arab oil embargo, the skyrocketing price of fuel and the impending massive money flows from the nations consuming oil to those producing it have shattered any slight hope for reaching agreement on the complicated design presented at Nairobi.
