title: The Poor Are Educable
description: For the first time since public education became popular enterprise, some of America's intellectual. prophets are trying to persuade the citizenry that their faith in the power of education to raise the spirit, dignity, status and wealth of the individual and community is in opposition to the scientific facts.

title: SYRIANS PRESSED TO ALLY WITH IRAQ
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 15The continued delays in the Middle East negotiations are increasing the pressure on Syria to move away from Egypt and closer to the Arab radical camp led by the Iraqis, who strongly oppose a negotiated settlement with Israel.

title: Defendant Waives Jury Trial on L.I. In Slaying of Coed
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 15Calling prospective jurors these jokers, Samuel H. DeNicola, accused of the slaying of a C. W. Post College coed, suddenly asked today that his right to a jury trial be waived. The court approved the request, and the trial, without a jury, will continue Friday morning.

title: CHARLES W. NORTH
description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 15 Charles W. North, who founded and headed Charles W. North Studios, Inc., at 79 Madison Avenue, one of New York's oldest art studios, died yesterday in Stamford Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived here.

title: Excerpts From Byrne Inaugural Speech
description: Following are excerpts from Governor Byrne's inaugural address yesterday in Trenton, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Industry Report Asserts Nuclear Power Came Into Its Own in 1973
description: A total of 42 nuclear power reactors were classed as operable at the end of 1973, the Atomic Industrial Forum, Inc., said here yesterday.

title: Professors Seen as Beleaguered Group
description: In the late nineteenfifties and early sixties higher education in America was seen as the most likely path to economic opportunity and individual fulfillment. Huge resources insured its expansionboth of the numbers served and of the fields of knowledge covered. The American dream came to include a baccalaureate diploma in every young person's hand.

title: Slide Rule Calculator
description: Texas Instruments, Inc. introduced yesterday an advanced slide rule calculator, designated the SR50, which it is selling initially through direct mail at a price of $169.95, with shipments to begin immediately. This is ,the fifth model in the company's scientific series and features an algebraic keyboard. It is said to be capable of handling such scientific calculations as trigonometric and hyperbolic functions.

title: Teacher Evaluation Gains
description: Interest in performancebased education and certification of elementary and secondary school teachers spread throughout much of the country during 1973 as part of the movement toward ac. countability.

title: Colleges Seeking Liberal Discipline
description: When Daniel Bell spoke recently at Columbia on the reform of general education, he led off with, As I was saying before I was interrupted in 1968.... His reference, of course, was to the disorders of the late sixties that, ironically, drove most serious discussion of educational reform off campus and put it into the hands of foundation and Government officials well insulated from radical activism.

title: TUNIS BACKS OFF FROM LIBYA UNION
description: TUNIS, Jan. 15 (AP)The Tunisian Government backed away today from merger with Libya, delaying a proposed referendum on the union until the Tunisian constitution is re. vised. The process could take months.

title: Villanova Names Aide
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., Jan. 15 (AP)Carl Schaukowitch was named offensive line coach today at Villanova University. Schaukowitch, 23 years old, was an offensive guard at Penn State from 1969 to 72.

title: School Integration Still an Issue Despite Quiet Progress
description: Despite impressive gains in Integration over the last five Years, the overall national picture is marked by racial isolation, Nearly twothirds of all black children attend schools that are majority black. About as many black youngsters go to nearly allblack Schools as attend Integrated ones.

title: To Johnson, It Feels Like Home
description: Philip Johnson never dreamed he would one day occupy the trendsetting East Side guest house he designed and completed to 1950 for Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3d.

title: Protests in Jakarta
description: Many thousands of Indonesians joined in violent demonstrations in Jakarta against the visit of Japan's Premier and what they regard as Japanese economic imperialism. Page 3.

title: TEACHERABSENCES CALLED EXCESSIVE
description: Daniel Klepak the state's education watchdog, charged yesterday that teacher absences in New York City were excessive and cost tens of millions of dollars each year for substitute teachers who were often little more than classroom babysitters.

title: Wilson Sees More Cuts for Some in Auto Insurance
description: ALBANY, insurance law that Jan. 15  Under the nofault insurance law that goes into effect on Feb. 1, motorists in New York State will save $110million in personalinjury automobile insurance premiums at rates in some cases that are even lower than those predicted when the law was passed last year, Governor Wilson said today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Bus Drivers End 15Week Strike

title: Records
description: The thing about legendary ;performers (and in the field of rock n roll, Elvis Presley certainly is a major contender) is that a record company can keep on endlessly mining the same rich vein, repackag in g, digging deep Into the archives. So it is with Elvis:

title: Wings Wary Over Spell Of Francis
Court Blocks Filing of Charges Of Race Bias Against Judges
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15An effort by civil rights advocates to halt an alleged conspiracy against blacks among law enforcement officials in Cairo, Ill., failed in the Supreme Court today.

title: MACHU'S AIDES HELD INCONSISTENT
description: The state's special anticorruption prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, disclosed yesterday that some assistant Queens district attorneys had given contradictory statements to grand jury about their knowledge of a getrichquick scheme and said the truth would have to be wrung out of them at the trial of former Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell.

title: The Football Phenomenon And Its Place on Campus
description: Millions of armchair quarterbacks saw some good college football during the annual New Years Day bowlgame binge, but they probably did not see the best. After all, the University of Oklahoma's Sooners trounced both Cotton Bowl teams  Nebraska and Texasduring the regular season, and tied Southern California, which lost to Ohio State in the Rose Bowl.

title: CHINESE MAY BUY COPTERS FROM U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15The United Aircraft Corpora. tion has received permission from the Government to discuss with Peking representatives the sale of transport helicopters to China, State Department officials said today.

title: A New Team Moves In To Assist Gov. Byrne
description: TRENTON, Jan. 15  The seats of power in state government became occupied by a new group of men, beginning today, when Brendan T. Byrne was inaugurated as New Jersey's 54th Governor.

title: Quiet Trenton Inaugural Has a Souvenir Surplus
description: TRENTON, Jan. 15Norbert Cifelli, the nearly blind proprietor of the snack stand in the State House near the Governor's office, thought the inauguration of Brendan T. Byrne was one of the quietest in memory.

title: Bridge: Doubling for the Lead Can Be Like Spitting Into the Wind
description: A leaddirecting double of an artificial bid is a. twoedged sword. If the doubler's judgment is wrong, he may find that he has simply helped the opposition bring home a shaky contract.

title: HUGHES AIDE SAYS NIXON ASKED GIFT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15An employe of the Howard Hughes organization has told the Senate Watergate committee that President Nixon personally suggested to him before Mr. Nixon's election in 1968 that he should attempt to solicit a campaign contribution from the billionaire industrialist, according to a Senate source.

title: Most Call Crime City's Worst lll
description: An overwhelming majority of New Yorkersrich and poor black and white conservative and liberalregard crime as the worst problem they face personally and the single issue that they would most like Mayor Beame's new administration to tackle.

title: INTEREST LEVELS DRAW INVESTORS;
description: The credit markets which have been sliding since Christmas, reached something of turning point yesterday, Interest rates finally seemed to investors and a mod!attract robust rally got under way. In the money market Treasury bill prices rose enough to lower bill rates as much as 16 basis points, goodsized drop. In the capital !markets, corporate, bond prices !advanced and new bond issues yielding as much as any bonds marketed since last Augustsold quickly after they offerred to investors

title: Iowa Picks Wyatt
description: IOWA CITY, Jan. 15 (AP) Bernie Wyatt, a former Iowa defensive back, was named today to Coach Bob Commings's Hawkeye football staff. Wyatt played for Iowa from 1959 to 1961.

title: Westbury Big Triple Pays Off at $2,968
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Jan. 15  Randy Perry, the tiny driver from Astoria, Queens, broke out of an 10for23 slump at Roosevelt Raceway last night, winning the third race. In the process he triggered the largest bigtriple payoff of the season.

title: Horses &
description: BAY THOROUGHBRED GELDING 162, healthy S sound. Schooted 3rd level dressage. Needs ex, rider. After 6 PM ??

title: Education 74: Sober Realism and Cautious Hope
description: After two decades of alternating elation and depression, education's mood at the beginning of 1974 is one of sober but not despairing realism. The focus is on the sudden recognition that America can no longer buy her way out of her problems. There is no special exemption for Americans frqm the world's dilemmas.

title: Canadiens Beaten, 21, By Kings
New York School Reform: A LongHaul Affair
description: Almost five years have passed since the State Legislature decentralized the New York City public school system, and neither the exaggerated hopes nor the apocalyptic fears of 1969 have yet been realized. The city's transition to decentralization was accomplished with a minimum of disruption or, some might say, a minimum of change.

title: Farah and Union to Meet
description: EL PASO, Tex. Jan. 15 (UPI) Representatives of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and the Farah Manufacturing Company will meet tomorrow for the first time since the beginning of a strike in 1971 that has resulted in a boycott of Farah and cost it, more than $8million.

title: State's New Administrative Judge Richard James Bartlett
description: ALBANY, Jan. 15He'll be worthy of being canonized if he succeeds. The remark from Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel as he created and filled the post of State Admin State's New Administrative Judge Richard James Bartlett istrative Judge was as much a compliment for the new ap pointee, Supreme Court Justice Richard J. Bartlett, as it was an admission that it will take a miracle worker to get the state's huge court system under a single, firm rein.

title: Recrion Stock Tendered
description: The Recrion Corporation announced yesterday that it had received about 1,137,000 shares of common stock in response to its tender offer to exchange one share of common for a new $38 principal amount of a 10 per cerk sinking fund subordinated debenture due 1984. Recrion said it would accept one million shares, representing 88 per cent of the tendered Shares, on a pro rata basis.

title: RALPH W. HALLER, 91, PRINCIPAL IN QUEENS
description: Ralph W. Haller, former principal of the Andrew Jackson High School in Cambria Heights, Queens, and at one time head of the High School Principals Association, died Monday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Avenue. He was 91 years old.

title: Realistic Transit Plan
description: As the State Legislature moves toward probable approval today of a $100million loan to New York City to save the 35cent transit fare for a few more months, the lawmakers have before them a thoughtful proposal for helping to ease the longrange problems of fiscally hardpressed transportation systems throughout the state.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Beame Asked to Back Firemen on Pay

title: Barnard: A Time of SelfAnalysis
description: There have been times in the history of women at Columbia University when Barnard College and Columbia seemed separated by the Great Wall of China instead of by an urban street called ?roadway, times when the act of crossing from one side of the street to the other appeared to require the assistance not of a traffic policeman but of Henry Kissinger and a cadre of diplomats..

title: South Korea Seizes 2 Leaders of Drive To Revise Charter
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 15 The South Korean Army arrested two outspoken critics of President Park Chung Hee today on charges of violating the presidential decree last week that banned criticism of the nation's current constitution.

title: Music: Blissful Firkusny
description: There was quite some entertainment competition on Sunday afternoon (among other things, the Boat Show at the Coliseum, the Super Bowl on TV and a fellow named Artur Rubinstein playing up at Avery Fisher Hall), but those who elected to attend Rudolf Firkusny's recital at Carnegie Hall made a happy choice. The pianist, nearing the end of his 35thanniversary tour, provided an extraordinary display of the finesse, sensitivity and musical authority that have long been his hallmarks.

title: Colleges Vie for Students and Funds
description: American higher education Is a keenly competitive industry.

title: NIXON MD FOR GIFT INV REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15An employe of the Howard Hughes organization has told the Senate Watergate committee that President Nixon personally suggested to him before Mr. Nixon's election in 1968 that he should attempt to solicit a campaign contribution from the billionaire industrialist, according to a Senate source.

title: Tenure Battle Intensifies as Budget Squeeze Grips Schools
description: Through the three decades since World War II, the combination of academic tenure and skyrocketing educational budgets has given university and college faculties a degree of job assurance unmatched by clergymen, bank presidents or truck driVers. Now the financial squeeze on private and public education is causing a reassessment in the nation's institutions of higher learning of the tenure system that has been a foundation stone of academic freedom as well as a guarantee of lifetime economic security for those inside the protected circle.

title: Plane Carrying Marijuana Crashes in Florida, Killing 3
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP)  A twinengine plane loaded with an estimated $1million worth of marijuana crashed and burned at an apartment construction site last night in heavy rain. The plane's three occupants were killed.

title: Josef Smrkovsky Is Dead at 62; Former Czech Reform Leader
description: PRAGUE, Jan. 15 (Reuters)Josef Smrkovsky, righthand man of Alexander Dubcek, the former reformist leader, died of cancer here last night. He was 62 years old.

title: Business Briefs
description: Venezuela in Denial on OilPrice Pact

title: Women on Campus Look to Courts for Equality
description: If the women's movement on campus seemed a little quieter last year, it was because of a fundamental shift in tactics away from a reliance on the Federal Government and toward the use of local courts as weapons in the fight against alleged sex discrimination.

title: German Reds Spur Drive for Ouster of Chinese
description: BERLIN, Jan. 15The East German Communist party has opened a drive among fellow Communists to oust China from the world Communist movement.

title: Red Smith
description: Video Techniques, Inc., which did the closedcircuit television last January when George Foreman swatted Joe Frazier loose from the heavyweight championship the world, expects to announce a title match between Foreman and Ken Norton on Friday at a news conference in Los Angeles. The bout is penciled in for March 25, but the site has not been chosen. Los Angeles was picked for the announcement because Foreman was headed that way from Texas and Norton was just down the coast in San Diego. Last time a ForemanNorton match was in the news, the report was that would be held either in Jamaica, where George won the title, or Rio de Janiero. Now, according to Hank Schwartz of Video Techniques, several locations within the United States are unaer consideration because Foreman is no longer insisting that the fight be held abroad.

title: WORDS ARE LOST
description: WASHINGTON, Jan.. 15A courtappointed panel of six technical experts reported today that the 18 minute gap on a crucial Watergate tape recording was caused by at least five separate erasures and rerecordings, and not by a single accidental pressing of the wrong button on a tape recorder, as the White House has suggested.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE IN SLOW TRADING
7.5% BONDS SLATED ON SPORT COMPLEX
description: NEWARK, Jan. 15  The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, in an apparent effort to overcome investor sales resistance, raised the interest rate it is willing to pay on the bulk of its proposed bond issue from 7 per cent to 7.5.

title: Cellblock Colleges: One Student's View From Auburn, N.Y.
description: Any personal examination of prison education must begin with the period prior to incarceration. It is during the formative years that attitudes toward learning are established, and it is these attitudes that harden the task of instructors and bog potentially great programs in mediocrity.

title: Saxbe Sees Nixon Plea on Crime Files
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15Attorney General William B. Saxbe said today that a proposal to prevent misuse of criminal records would be in the Presiddent's State of the Union Message later this month.

title: WORDS ARE LOST
A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

Breitel as he created and filled the post of State Administrative Judge was as much a compliment for the new ape pointee, Supreme. Court Justice Richard J. Bartlett, as it was an admission that it will take a miracle worker to get the state's huge court system under a single, firm rein.

title: Soviet Meets a Difficult Deadline
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 15Soviet construction teams have reportedly beaten the weather and made their deadline for completing construction, of the outer shells of the huge new facilities for the Kama River truck plant by the end of 1973.

title: CURTIS ASKS DELAY ON SAXBE SUCCESSOR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP)Senator Carl T. Curtis, Republican of Nebraska, asked today that Howard M. Metzenbaum, Cleveland industrialist who was appointed to the Senate from Ohio, not be seated when Congress reconvenes Jan. 21.

title: U. S. AGENCY SUED BY VISTA WORKERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15Action, The Federal agency that encompasses several volunteer service organizations. was charged today by the National VISTA Alliance with imposing arbitrary and selective cutbacks in transportation and supervisory services to VISTA volunteers in the midAtlantic region of Action.

title: OFFICIALS DISPUTE MILITARY SPY PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15High White House officials sought today to minimize the significance of an alleged military spy ring inside the White House and characterized a confidential report on such activities filed by David R. Young Jr. as ludicrous.

title: A.B.C. IS ACCUSED ON 76 OLYMPICS
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 15  A member of the Canadian Parliament said in an interview today that he had received strong indications that the American Broadcasting Company had made a political pay, off here before it was granted coverage rights to the 1976 Olympic Games in Montreal.

title: Options Pilot Plan Submitted to S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP)  The American Stock Exchange has submitted a plan to the Securities and Exchange Commission for trading in stock options on a trial basis, the Securities and Exchange Commis sion said today.

description: An overwhelming majority of New Yorkersrich and poor, black and white, conservative and liberalregard crime as the worst problem they face personally and the single issue that they would most like Mayor Beame's new administration to tackle.

title: MISSISSIPPI RIVER GETS MOPAC STOCK
description: The Mississippi River Corporation announced yesterday that it had received about 88 per cent of the 635,696 shares of new common stoat of its subsidiary, the Missouri Pacific Railroad, tendered in response to its offer to purchase 400,000 shares at $100 a share. Issuance of the new stock and the. tender offer are parts of a courtapproved recapitalization of MOPAC under which each share of class A stock is converted into a new $5 preferred. share and each class B is conyerted into 16 shares of new. common stock plus $850 in cash. Following completion of the recapitalization, Mississippi River will.. own 1,158,395 shares of new preferred, or 62 per tent, and 400,000 shares, or 63 per. cent, of the new common.

title: AARON LEVINE
description: Aaron Levine, a real estate, builder and owner whose properties included 20 Vesey Street where he had his offices, died yesterday in Peninsula General Hospital, Far Rockaway, Queens. He was 77 years old and lived at 48 Lawrence Avenue, Lawrence, L.I.

title: QUEENS WOMAN SHOT RESISTING A GUNMAN
description: A 23yearold Queens woman was shot three times and seriously wounded early this morning when she resisted gunman who forced her into the basement of a house at 4268 Saull Street in Flushing and robbed her of an undetermined amount of money, the police reported.

title: Demographic Changes Exert Impact on Schools, Students and Teachers
description: Reduced enrollment growth In the seventies and eighties will have several economic effects on the nation's schools, some of which are already in evidence. The budgets, of many schools are determined by enrollmentbased formulas, and declining enrollments will mean diminished resources,

title: The Tunnel at the End of the Light
description: SAN FRANCISCOIt appears clear by now that the energy shortage, whatever its causes or consequences, constitutes just one element in the growing national consciousness of limits and in the declining faith in an indefinitely expanding American future.

title: Whole Button Mushrooms Involved in HyTop Recall
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) Only whole button mushrooms in fourounce cans were involved in the Food and Drug Administration's recall of products distributed by HyTop Brands.

title: Notes on People
description: Linwood Holton, former Republican Governor of Virginia, will be appointed to a high Federal position, probably Assistant Secretary of State for Congressional Relations, according to State Department officials.

title: GOING OUT Guide

From that beginning came the impetus for formation of a permanent organization dedicated to the promotion of friendly relations between the two countries and to the fostering here of more accurate knowledge of the people and ways of Japan.

title: Kohoutek Enveloped in Hydrogen Cloud
description: Because of its searing loop around the sun Dec. 28, the comet Kohoutek, now fading from view to the unaided eye, has become enveloped in cloud of hydrogen atoms three million miles wide.

title: Stage: Richardson's Bolingbroke, Pasco's Richard
British Election Risks
description: Prime Minister Heath and leaders of Britain's Trades Union Congress will make one more effort to end the slowdown of 260,000 coal miners. If they fail, Mr. Heath probably will ask Queen Elizabeth to dissolve Parliament and. call a general election for sometime next month.

title: Dyce to Run Here
description: Byron Dyce filed his entry yesterday for the Wanamaker mile, the highlight event of the 67th Millrose Games, which open the Madison Square Garden track season on Friday, Jan. 25.

title: About New York A Slow Night in Night Court
description: It was a quiet Monday in night court. No one knows why, but Mondays in night court are usually quiet. It gets busier during the week, however, and by Thursdays, perhaps 100 cases are heard in night court. It is in the Criminal Court at 100 Centre Street, and on this Monday there were only 40 or 50 defendants. They would all stand before Judge Thomas G. Weaver.

title: Downhill All the Way
description: I am a bit late with my recommendations for 1.974, but I have been building a wheelbarrow and this has taken all my attention. (It is impossible to buy a good wheelbarrow in the storesif you want one that balances well you must go to work and build it.) Here are; my recommendations for.1974:

title: COMMENT PUT OFF BY WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15The White House rerused today to make a premature comment on the technical experts findings on the erased Watergate tape but asserted that conclusions should not be drawn while the matter was still before the court.

title: A Guerrilla Rocket Kills 7, Injures 10 In Phnom Penh Slum
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 15 (AP)  Entrenched insurgents near Phnom Penh fired a rocket into a downtown slum today, killing 7 persons and wounding 10, police officers said.

title: Schooling Has Limits
description: These are hard times for Atherican educators. Money short, public dissatisfaction is widespread, and the sense of manifest destiny that pervaded the profession a decade ago has all but evaporated., One reason for the current crisis in confidence seems to be the widely publicized shift in.opinion among social scientists about the importance of education in shaping American society.

description: BASKETBALL

title: Students Go to Work on Urban Problems
description: Brooklyn College's School of Contemporary Studies, an experiment in liberal arts education, has begun its second year of turning out students who try to practice in the street what they learned in the classroom about pressing social problems.

title: HARRY PEALE HALDT
description: BOONTON, N.J., Jan. 15Harry Peale Haldt, who retired in 1957 as manager of industrial sales for the Franklin Baker division of the General Foods Corporation after 46 years with the concern, died today in Riverside Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived here.

title: Violent Crowds in Jakarta Protest the Visit by Tanaka
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Wednesday, Jan. 16Many thousands of Indonesians took to the streets of Jakarta yesterday in violent demonstrations against the visit of Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan and what they regard as Japanese economic imperialism.

title: U. S. ISSUES RULES ON ALLOTTING FUEL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15The Federal Energy Office released details of a proposed gasoline rationing plan today while making public formal allocations of fuels that favor public services and industrial use at the expense of private automobiles and home heating.

title: EUGENE B.HOTCHKISS, MINING ENGINEER, 66
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 15Eugene Bishop Hotchkiss, a mining engineer, died at his home here today appartently of a heart attack. He was 66 years old and lived at 50 Old Stamford Road.

title: SILVER FUTURES REACH NEW HIGHS
description: Silver, potatoes and sugar set new highs on their respective commodity exchanges yesterday, continuing their strong showing on Monday.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The burden has shifted to the President and his White House aides to explain what went on.

title: British Passenger Trains Halted By OneDay Strike of Engineers
description: LONDON, Jan. 15A oneday strike of railroad engineers stopped all passenger trains in Britain today. Commuters, especially in southeast England, were hit hard. A few freight trains continued to run.

title: Paris Accused of Taps on Mitterrand
description: PARIS, Jan. 15New charges of illegal wiretapping were made against the French Government today by Le Canard Enchain& the masscirculation satirical weekly.

title: 19 Dead, 28 Injured In Bus Crash on Coast
description: BLYTHE, Calif., Jan. 15 (UPI) Nineteen persons were killed and 28 others were injured today when a farm labor bus missed a turn in predawn darkness and plunged into 10 feet of water in an irrigation canal southwest of here.

title: Advertising: SovietBloc Sales
description: They all laughed when Lucien J. Soria sat down to play, but that was over 20 years ago. They're not laughing any more.

title: Indonesians Start to Voice Discontent With Suharto
description: SINGAPORE, Jan. 15President Suharto's government in Indonesia, after seven years of lawandorder stability and controlled political processes following the chaos and decay of the Sukarno ,era, is facing its first eruption of public discontent.

title: BREITEL APPOINTS A MAN TO MANAGE THE STATE COURTS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 15In his first major initiative in office, Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel announced today that he had created a new post of state administrative judge and had consolidated existing courtmanagenent authority in the post to spur statewide improvements in the judicial system.

title: Aussie Gains Lead In 5.5Meter Sail
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 15 (AP)  The Australian champion, Russell Slade, sailing Baragoola, won the fourth race of the 5.5Meter world yatching championship off Palm Beach today and took the lead in the series.

title: New Science Courses Stress Solutions to Practical Problems
description: Armed with test kits, small group of students under Prof. Abe Berlad at the Stony Brook College of Engineering have been traveling from home to home, measuring the efficiency of residential oil burners on Long Island.

title: School Hours Stand
description: WESTFIELD, Mass., Jan. 15 (AP)The School Committee voted unanimously yesterday against changing school hours after officials said parents and teachers overwhelmingly disapproved of the change.

title: Duncan Ring Victor
description: LONDON, Jan. 15 (UPI)Irish Pat Duncan of Las Vegas, Nev., beat Danny McAlinden, the British and Commonwealth Heavyweight champion, on points in a 10round fight tonight at London's Royal Albert Hall. Duncan used his longer reach to punish the Briton with straight lefts and stiff left hooks to the body.

title: SOVIET AIDE BIDS SOLZHENITSYN GO
description: MOSCOW, Jan 15  A ranking official of the Soviet Writers Union proposed tonight that Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn leave the country because of what the Soviet press has called his treasonous writings.

title: Quie Suggests a 25% Share. For U.S. in School Costs
description: The United States now spends nearly $97billion a year on education, more than the entire gross national product in 1926. No nation in the world approaches that figure, and it reflects enormous growth in the last decade or so.

title: 8 Jurors Picked in Trial Of Physician for Murder
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 15 Four men and four women jurors were selected today in the trial of Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano, former chief resident surgeon at the Nassau County Medical Center, who has been charged with murder in the death of a dying cancer pa tient.

title: New Sense of Optimism In City's School System
description: When Harvey B. Scribner left New York City six months ago after three stormy years as the city's School Chancellor, he took with him the goldletteted glass pane from his office door.

title: 2 UNIONS STRIKE THE CITY SCHOOLS; CLASSES PLANNED
description: Twin strikes that could leave the city's 900 schools without heat and cleaning services and force their eventual closing were begun last night and early this morning by 1,000 school engineers and firemen and 4,000 custodial employes.

title: A College Student Makes a Big Decision
description: Back at the Fieldston School in Riverdale, my friends and I used to sit around the lunch table and wonder out lond what college life would be like. We were unsure and a bit scared. Perhaps our biggest fear was that we would be forced to make a decision on what to do for the rest of our lives.

title: BALLET THEATER EYES KIROV DATES
description: The American Ballet Theater, the American company most publicly involved in protests against the appearance of the Kirov Ballet from Leningrad at the New York State Theater, is now free to perform in that theater three weeks earlier than scheduled as a result of the cancellation of the Kirov's tour.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 Albert E. Jenner Jr., the chief Republican counsel on the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment staff, has been rebuked for comments he made Sunday about President Nixon's possible culpability in the Watergate scandals.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Weather: Partly cloudy today; cold tonight. Partly cloudy tomorrow. Temp. range: today 3247; Tuesday 30.43. Additional details on Page 53.

title: South Viewed as Model For School Cooperation
description: ATLANTAFormed 25 years ago to overcome the lag in higher education in the South, the Southern Regional Education Board Is now being examined by educators in other parts of the country as a possible model for regional cooperation at a time when enrollments are sagging and costs are soaring.

title: Books of The Times
description: Elie Wiesel is a survivor of two Nazi concentration camps who is bestknown for his earlier novels dealing with the Holocaust, the systematic extermination of six million Jews during World War II. These works were brilliant artistic successes, yet their creation involved painful ambiguities on the part of the authorthe guilt of the survivor, the literary and moral problems of how to deal with the meaning of a tragedy that in its scope and nature is in the final analysis incomprehensible. Several years ago Mr. Wiesel made it known that he would no longer write explicitly about the Holocaust, and his recent works have followed new lines. Souls on Fire, for instance, was a retelling of Hasidic folk tales.

title: 4 FOUND STRANGLED IN A WICHITA HOUSE
description: WICHITA, Kan., Jan. 15 (UPI)Three teenagers arriving home from school today found the bodies of their parents, a brother and a sister bound, gagged and strangled, each with a hangman's noose around the neck.

title: Changes in W ATS Rate Are Sought by A.T. &
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed yesterday with the Federal Communications Commission for changes in interstate rates fori its Wide Area Telecommunications Service. Weldenbaum, prominent Republican economist and a former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury in the Nixon Administration, warned yesterday that the Administration's budget figures, to be announced later this month, would understate the size of the deficit facing the Federal Government in the fiscal year 1975, which begins next July 1.

title: Panov Case Background
description: Valery Panov, 35yearold Jewish Russian dancer.. first danced with Leningrad's Maly Theater, joining the Kirov Ballet in 1963... won state honors, including the title of Honored Artist of the Soviet Union. seen briefly in the West in 1959, when he performed here once at Madison Square Garden during a Soviet cultural exhibition, before being suddenly ordered to return to Russia best known as a dramatic dancer, with repertory including major roles in Don Quixote, The Sleeping Beauty, Giselle... announced in March, 1972, his decision to emigrate to Israel... dismissed 17 days later from the Kirov and denounced as a traitor to the Soviet Union... his wife, Galina Ragozina, then 23, a Varna Gold Prizewinner who had begun to dance lead roles in the Kirov, was demoted to the, corps de ballet and then resigned in protest at the treatment of her husband... he was imprisoned during President Nixon's visit to the Soviet Union in 1972, prompting protests and petitions abroad to Soviet diplomats... told he could emigrate but without his wife, he refused... he has said he is afraid of further imprisonment on charges of parasitism, since he is now unemployed.

title: 5 Die in Burning Auto
description: SEMINOLE, Okla. Jan. 15 (UPI)A pickup truck rammed the rear of a compact automobile on a foggy highway yesterday causing both vehicles to burst into flames. Five persons died in the car. Killed were Vernon Cole, 23 years old, of Salt Lake City; his stepdaughter, Connie Slane, 3; his stepson, Harold Slane, 5; his motherinlaw, Carol Grogan, 37, of Los Angeles, and another relative, Carol Levan Stephens, 2, Mr. Cole's wife, Donna, the driver survived.

title: Testing Shifts From Which to How
description: Tests and examinations have never stood high in students esteem. But in the last year the examining of examinations was both profound and farreaching throughout education and industry alike. Students parents educators, employers job applicants  all had urgent questions. What do tests really measure? How well do they do their job? Are the scores fair or biased? How should they be used  and how not?

title: U.S. DEFERS TALKS ON BASE IN GREECE

The N.C.A.A. charged Glen McDonald and Roscoe Pondexter had entered school by having proxies take entrance tests for them. Both men have signed statements saying the allegation is untrue.

description: NEWARK, Jan. 15  The New Jersey Sports and Expo sition Authority, in an apparent effort to overcome invesfor sales resistance, raised the interest rate it is willing to pay on the bulk of its proposed bond issue from 7 per cent to 7.5.

description: Negotiators for the city's three major daily newspapers and Typographical Union No. 6 began formal contract baigaining talks on the key automation issue yesterday. title: Fuel Dealer Evaded Taxes
description: BOSTON, Jan. 15 (AP)A Medford fuel dealer pleaded guilty yesterday in United States District Court to a charge of evading more than $24,000 in taxes in 1967. Carl A. Erickson, the owner of the Erickson Fuel Company, was fined $10,000 and sentenced to two months in jail by Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr. He was given a stay of sentence until Jan. 21.

title: Stuttgart Offers Moving Night Of Bach Fugue
description: Bach did not live to finish The Art of Fugue, and his score gives only skimpy and ambiguous indications as to what instrument or instruments he meant it for, if any (there are those who believe he wrote the monumentally scaled work as a theoretical demonstration and never intended it to be performed). So, naturally, musicians and scholars have rushed into the vacuum with performing versions of the score for a great variety of instruments.

description: BOYERTOWN, Pa.There was once a wise, kind and humble man in antiquity who spent his life in search of truth and spreading wisdom among his people. He was a man of peace who loved his state and his community. His method of teaching was to ask thoughtprovoking questions in a pleasant mood to his students and among the citizens. Some of his questions were these: What is truth? What is love? What is honesty? What is justice? His object was to assist people to conquer their own ignorance.

title: Contract Awards
description: The United States Pipe & Foundry Company, subsidiary of the Jim Walter Corporation, announced yesterday the signing of an agreement to sell $750million2million tons of coalto the Alabama Power Company over a 21year period beginning in 1976. Coupled with an earlier $250million contract, the new agreement means that United States Pipe would be selling the Southern Company subsidiary more than $1billion, or 3.25million tons of coal from its more than 300million tons of coal reserves in Alabama.

title: Senate Hearings on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) The Senate Finance subcommittee on energy announced today a series of hearings on hills to tax excess profits of energyoriented companies during the fuel shortage. The hearings are scheduled Jan, 23, 24, 25, 28 and 29.

description: LAFAYETTE, La., Jan. 15 (AP)Larry Zeno was named assistant football coach today at the University of Southwestern Louisiana. Zeno had been an assistant at the University of Nebraska for the last t'o years.

title: New Approaches in Education Wax and Wane
description: A generation ago, a brash, 30yearold lawyer named Robert M. Hutchins took the helm at the University of Chicago and began to make education al waves. Feeling that American colleges had become a colossal housing project for the young, he remade the undergraduate program at Chicago In a new, more humanistic image. Intercollegiate sports were dropped, traditional degree requirements were thrown out, and, most important, a new liberal curriculum was devised to pull teachers out of their narrow disciplinary warrens.

title: G.O.P. CHIEF WINS IN MICHIGAN VOTE

title: George McKenzie Jr. Dies; Engineer Sought Public Office

McKenzie Jr., a retired safety engineer with the Bethlehem Steel Corporation who ran unsuccessfully for the State Assembly, the State Senate and for a seat in the House of Representatives from the 13th District of Brooklyn, died Sunday at the Beekman Downtown Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 1820 Cortelyou Road, Brooklyn.

title: To Charities and Scouts: Halt Pleas to Candidates

title: Can Do Spirit in Schools Wanes as Refuse Mounts

title: WRIT AGAINST SIGNAL REPORTED DISSOLVED

The injunction had been sought by Louis S. Gimbel 3d, a Signal stockholder, in the Court of Chancery of Delaware, which had ordered that a $25million bond be posted by Jan. 15.

description: Nationwide consumption of electricity appears to be running below its normally expected level by as much as 10 per cent, industry figures indicate.

description: Western Union has introduced a service for skiers that provides the latest ski conditions at New England or Colorado resorts. The reports are obtainable by dialing FYI News on Telex 1213 and typing Neski or Colski. Mike Brown, a company spokesman, explained yesterday that the charge was 171/2 cents per minute, which is the regular Telex fee in New York City.

title: Metzenbaum Gives Reply To Plea to Delay Seating

title: Hanoi Sets Terms For Normalization Of Ties With U.S.

title: Italy Arrests 3, Seeks 4th in Getty Kidnapping
description: ROME, Jan. 16 (AP)  The police arrested three men today on charges of having kidnapped J. Paul Getty 3d and said that an underworld gang in the Italian South was involved in the crime.

title: A.K.C. Acts As Breeding Watchdog
description: The work of American Kennel Club executive field agents in dealing with the breeding and selling of dogs for the pet market  was explored by Roy Carlberg, a vice president ofa the AX.C., in aa speech before thea Dog Fanciers Cluba here last week.

title: Solzhenitsyn in Peril
description: The mounting violence and virulence of the official campaign against Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn may wind up doing more damage to the Soviet regime than did the publication in Paris of hi new book on the prison camp system. If the denunciations are followed by arrest, confinement to an insane asylum, internal deportation forcible exile, they will set back a decade of Soviet policy abroad in pursuit of dtente, trade and technological exchange with the West.

title: Fateful Gap
description: The report by the team of courtappointed experts on the cause of the eighteenminute gap in the taped conversation between President Nixon and H. R. Haldeman has shattered all previous White House efforts explain the obliteration of crucial evidence. A record essential to investigation of the Watergate coverup was wiped out by means of at least five separate manual erasures, and not by any terrible accident of the kind reported to the court by Rose Mary Woods, the President's secretary.

title: SIRICA COURT TOLD ERASURES ON TAPE CAME AFTER OCT. 1
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16The search for the person or persons who erased 18 minutes of a key Watergate tape recording was narrowed today when the special Watergate prosecution established in court that the erasure must have been made between last Oct. 1 and midNovember.

title: NEW CHURCH HEAD VOWS GREEK UNITY

On Monday night he began a threeweek engagement at Jimmy's  his first New York club date in five years. Immediately it should be said that in person Mr. Frye is even funnier, more savage and more outspoken. With Swiftian malice, he skewers pomposity and pretension wherever he finds it.

The third victim was identified yesterday as James Ryan Tennant, 30.

Dr. Kepple was Catawba's president from 1942 to 1963, when he left to becomc first director of the Piedmont University Center in Winston. Salem, He retired in 1967.

A 14yearold girl abducted at the same time is still missing, the police said.

title: Dave Anderson
description: They had nothing in common except friendship and skill, which were enough to enable them to enjoy doing things together. Mickey Mantle was a quiet country kid who could hit. Whitey Ford was a tough city kid who could pitch. When they were with the New York Yankees, it seemed as if they were in the World Series every year. It also seemed as if they were in the nightclubs every nigIt. Yesterday they were together in a nightclub again. the morning. The late morning for a change. At the announcement of their entry together into the Baseball Hall of Fame, they were standing on the parquet stage of the Americana Hotel's nightclub, the Royal Box, where Jonah Jones and his trumpet work the evenings. title: Matsumoto's 'Demons' Is a Melodrama of Revenge
description: Because humor is in such short supply at the movies these days, one must be forgiven searching for it in the wrong places, as in a long, seriously intended Japanese samurai film.Toshio Matsumoto's "Demons," based on a Kabuki play, is not, strictly speaking, a samurai film. It is violent but not especially robust. The film is about the revenge wreaked by a shabby, down-at-the-heels samurai warrior on a faithless courtesan and her husband after the couple swindle the warrior out of the 100 ryo with which he was planning to buy back his good name.What makes it rather appealingly comic is not the English translation provided by vapid subtitles, though they are pretty funny, but the borrowed solemnity the director uses to decorate his movie, which looks like an expensive film-school exercise. It wears the furrowed brow of a 10-year-old boy struggling to recite "Thanatopsis" without having the vaguest idea what he's saying.Everything takes place at night, which permits a lot of fancy lighting effects: stark contrasts between light and shadowthat sort of thing. There are occasional confusions between the real and the imagined. Actions are repeated, as if time had gotten stuck in the groove of a record. If a scene doesn't look interesting enough photographed head-on, the director shoots it in slow motion or from above, using the old fly-on-the-ceiling shot.Nothing, however, succeeds in communicating the intensity of the passions of its poor hero. Told in this uninspired fashion, the tale of rage transformed to madness seems closer to farce than tragedy. Not helping much is a heavy emphasis on mistaken identities and curious coincidence. The style is soft, bogus, essentially frivolous, so that by the time a dying husband clasps the severed head of his wife to him for one last kiss, I was ready to say "rats."The film, which was shown at the First Avenue Screening Room Sunday, will be repeated there at noon and midnight today and tomorrow. Mr. Matsumoto, one of Japan's new young directors, was represented here last year by "Funeral Parade of Roses," an equally solemn though even sillier melodrama about Tokyo drug pushers and male prostitutes and their lives of noisy desperation.

description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority announced yesterday that anyone caught carrying an extra supply of gasoline would be put off the highway and be subject to a fine. The ban is being advertised by temporary signs, the authority said, and filling station operators have agreed refuse to fill containers. The authority's concern was heightened by a recent incident on the Pennsylvania Turnpike in which a rear end collision caused a fivegallon can in the back of a car to explode, burning four persons to death. Even though the rearend collision is most common on the turnpike, drivers carry gasoline on roof racks, in plastic containers in the rear passenger compartment and strapped to the rear of motor homes and campers.

title: Advertising: Is It Tea or Coffee?
description: Juan Valdez, the coffeebean picker of advertising fame, and the president of a coffee company, both drinking tea and recommending it to others? Can you believe it?

title: I. R. S. Is Auditing Nixon Foundation; Errors Indicated
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The Internal Revenue Service is auditing the tax returns of the Richard Nixon Foundation in addition to President Nixon's personal tax returns, Arthur Blech, the President's accountant, disclosed today.

title: Beame Inducts Gibson, 1st Black Deputy Mayor
description: At a warm, familystyle ceremony at City Hall, Paul Gibson Jr. was sworn in yesterday as Mayor Beame's third choice to become the city's, first black Deputy Mayor.

title: Wood, Field, Stream: Catboats
A. &
description: DETROIT, Jan. 17 (UPI)The A. &P. food chain has been ordered to. cease sex discrimination against male employes in Detroit, some of whom had been told to cut their hair or give up their jobs.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW INCREASES
Government and Pathet Lao Initial Accord on Capital Forces
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan, 17 (Agence France Presse)Representatives of. the Laotian Government and the Communistled Pathet Lao initialed an agreement today on the organization of their armed forces that would insure the neutralization of the two capitals of Laos.

title: Nixon Assailed on Housing for Elderly
description: TRENTON, Jan. 17  The Nixon Administration was assailed here today for what was described as its failure to support or provide for a compreensive housing program for the elderly.

title: Texas Sets Oil Production At 100% for 23d Month
Psychotic Horse Crazy Over Owner
description: WESTBURY, L. L, Jan. 17  A psychotic, horse with orthopedic shoes is doing quite well for Dean Watson of Beaconsfield, Quebec. Watson has a oq,e;horse stable consisting of a 6yearold trotter named Charon, whom he bought for $1,400 four years ago. It turned out to be a sound investment; Charon has earned more than $93,000 for Watson and is favored to add the winner's share of the $20,000 eighth race at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night.

title: SWINGLINE IS FINED FOR DELAY ON ORDER
description: A Federal District judge in Brooklyn fined the Swingline Corporation $150,000 yesterdny for delay in complying with a Federal Trade Commission diestiture order.

title: U.C.L.A. Wins No. 88, Without Walton
3D MAN CONVICTED IN FAMILY MURDERS
description: DONALSONVILLE, Ga., Jan. 17 (AP)A Superior Court jury convicted Wayne Carl Coleman today on six counts of murder in the slaying of six members of the Alday family last May 14.

title: Simon Sees Record In U.S. Oil Imports After the Embargo
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 William E. Simon, the Federal energy administrator, said tonight that after the embargo United States imports of oil would climb to seven million barrels a day, a new high.

title: Small Stores Feel Pinch Of Strike at Hunts Point
description: Fruit and vegetable stocks began running low at small grocery stores and the outlets of smaller supermarket chains in the metropolitan area yesterday as a wildcat strike that shut down the sprawling Hunts Point produce market in the Bronx went through a second day with no settlemen in sight.

title: Unions Demonstrate Against Phony Fuel Shortage
description: LINDEN, N. J., Jan. 17Members and officers of three.. major New Jersey labor unions demonstrated for alittle more than an hour today in Front of the Exxon Corpora'. Lion's research center on Route I to proteSt what they called a phony fuel Short, age.

title: DEATH OF INMATE SETS OFF INQUIRY
description: TRENTON, Jan. 17The bizarre scalding death of a youthful inmate at Trenton State Prison has touched off a broad investigation into the New Jersey penal system, the Mercer County Prosecutor said today.

title: Cleveland Mayor Asks Ford To Help Reinstate Trains
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI) Mayor Ralph Perk of Cleveland has asked Vice President Ford to help. get Amtrak to reinstate the AlbanyChicago lake shore route through Cleveland.

title: Criminal Cases Against Makers Of Hazardous Products Studied
description: Several criminal cases against the managements of companies that are alleged to be marketing hazardous products knowingly are being developed by the Bureau of Compliance of Product Safety Commission. the eightmonthold Consumer Product Safety Commission

title: The Black ModelsSuccess Is Beautiful
description: When she's in repose, her perfectoval face and long, attenuated body look like a portrait by Modigliani. But Billie Blair is not often in repose.

title: FEDERAL FUNDS ADVANCE IN RATE
Teachers Striving to Cope With Trash and Rowdyism
description: Uncollected trash and unClean lavatories became the chief problems for those city principals and teachers still on the job yesterday, while some student rowdiness added to the difficulties of running a school and teaching classes without custodial help.

title: Chief of Operations Is Appointed by Codd
description: Michael J. Lonergan, a veteran of 27 years in tilt Police Department, became its chief of operations and highestranking officer yesterday when Commissioner Michael J. Codd pinned a.. fourstar shield on the left breast of his uniform.

title: Ford's Home Town Welcomes Him on First Visit Since He Took Office
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Jan. 17  Vice President Ford came back to his home town last night for the first time since being sworn in as Vice President.

title: Off Off Broadway
description: It is advisable to telephone theaters for schedules and prices before going to, the show. Most, if not all, theaters accept Theater Development Fund vouchers.

title: New York Would Get Less Gas Than Others
description: The New York City and Newark metropolitan region would get 20 per cent less gasoline than the nationwide standard under the rationing plan proposed by the Federal Energy Office  possibly 33 gallons a month for each driver, rising to about 40 when supplies ease up.

title: HUMBARD CHURCH BEGINS REFUNDS
description: AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 17The Rev. Rex Humbard's Cathedral of Tomorrow began today to meet the repayment demands of investors who have contributed $12million to his ministry since 1959.

title: Uniting Oil Corisumers
description: Acceptance by the European Common Market of President Nixon's invitation to an ,international energy conference next month is an encouraging step forward, but it leaves still distant the goal of joint action by the leading oilconsuming countries.

title: LANDLORDS SEEK FUELCO ST RELIEF
description: Apartment landlords publicly appealed to the city yesterday for permission to increase rents to cover rising fueloil prices, and at the same time moved to cancel union contracts in the Bronx and to defer maintenance of tax payments elsewhere to get cash for their oil bills.

title: Running the Courts
description: Soon after his election in November as Chief Judge the Court of Appeals, Charles D. Breitel created a committee to help recruit a new administrator for the entire statewide court system. The man has been foundState Supreme Court Justice Richard J. Bartlett, who brings the job a helpful background not only as jurist but as legislator and chairman of the commission that revised the state Penal Code.

title: Prisoner's Scalding Death Stirs Broad Penal Inquiry
description: TRENTON, Jan. 17The bizarre scalding death of a youthful inmate at Trenton State Prison has touched off a broad Investigation into the New Jersey penal system, the Mercer County Prosecutor said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs $500 Fine Levied in Wetlands Case
description: The owner of a boat repair yard in Stony Brook, L. became the first person convicted for violation of the state's new Tidal Wetlands Law, the State Attorney General's office announced yesterday. Thomas,F. Harrison, an assistant Attorney General, said that Arthur A. Barstow, the yard owner, had been fined $500 for filling and dredging a wetlands area by the Sixth District Court in Patchogue. Mr. Barstow had pleaded guilty to the charge.

title: East Bloc Nations Again Bar West's TroopReduction Plan
description: VIENNA, Jan. 17The EastWest negotiations on the reduction of armed forces in Central Europe resumed here today, and the Czechoslovak delegate held a news conference afterward to reiterate Warsaw Pact objections to Western proposals.

title: I .R. S. Is Auditing Nixon Foundation; Errors Indicated
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The Internal Revenue Service is auditing the tax returns of the Richard Nixon Foundation in addition to President Nixon's personal tax returns, Arthur Blech, the President's accountant, disclosed today.

title: Call for Dogs Foils Holdup
description: ALTOONA, Pa., Jan. 17 (UPI) When two robbers entered Mrs. Beatrice Steindel's confectionery store yesterday she shouted: Let the dogs loose! The robbers, unaware Mrs. Steindel had no watchdogs, fled.

title: Career Labor Expert Ida Klaus
description: The Board of Education's chief labor negotiator, Ida Klaus, is a diminutive, darkhaired woman who looks far younger than she is and who talks about her unfinished projects as if she were just starting her career of laborrelations law rather than approaching the completion of 41 years in the field.

title: I.A.T.A. Pushing Fuel Bid
description: LONDON, Jan. 17The world's scheduled airlines announced today they would investigate measures to give civil aviation a bigger share of available oil supplies.

title: People in Sports: Jets Name Fry as Aide; Costello Leaves Ben gals for Dolphin Post
description: After the bowls are over in football, including the Super Bowl, ?? the season to play musical chairs with coaches in earnest. A lively lame was played yesterday by several teams, Including the New York Jets. They named Bob Fry, a Pittsburgh Steeler assistant for the past five years, as offensive line coach to succeed Wimp Hewgley, who has joined the New Orleans Saints.

title: Fordham Routed, 11273, By 4thRated Maryland
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 17 (AP)  John Lucas and Tom McMillen scored 23 points apiece, leading fourthranked Maryland to a 11273 basketball victory over Fordham tonight.

title: Optimism Rides the Ski Slopes
description: HUNTER, NY., Jan. 17Although December proved to be a poor producer of snow in the East and the news from Washington last month about the gasoline crunch had been discouraging, there was little display of concern today as members of the National Ski Areas Association concluded a threeday meeting.

title: JOHN F. ROGGENKAMP
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Jan. 17 John F. Roggenkamp, who retired in 1971 as financial vice president and controller of the. Winthrop Laboratories division of Sterling Drug, Inc., died Monday at his home at 166 Bourndale Road North. He. was 67 years old.

title: Equal Rights Amendment Passed by Maine House
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 17The Maine House of Representatives approved the equal rights amendment today by a vote of 78 to 68. Last year, the House approved the amendment by the same vote, but today's action was necessitated because the Senate disapproved the proposed constitutional amendment by one vote. The Senate is expected to vote again tomorrow.

title: Wood, Field, Stream: Catboats
description: Although I had other craft in mindcanoes and inflateblesas I worked my way through surging crowds at the National Boat Show it the Coliseum, there is no way I could go by her broad beam and classic lines without pausing to look, touch and dream.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Jan. 17 When Drew University and its coach, Dave Harper, take on Fairleigh Dickinson University at Madison tomorrow night in the Rose City Classic, defense will not be the problem. Drew is rather good playing defense. So good actually that the school is ranked fifth nationally in Division III this week.

title: West Virginia: Morning Becomes Electric
description: WASHINGTON Winter daylight saving time has spurred outrage in West Virginia, whose people have tried to develop a protective fatalism in the face of repeated disasters.

title: Car Insurance Rise Barred Until March As Deaths Decline
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI) The Cost of Living Council banned today any increases in automobile insurance premiums for the next two months because of an apparent decline in highway deaths attributed to the energy shortage.

title: Hans Lorentzen Dies at 86; Pioneer in Window Blinds
description: Hans K. Lorentzen, a pioneer in the manufacture of venetian blinds in this country, died yesterday at the Bergen Pines Hospital in Paramus, N.J. He was 86 years old and lived on East Palisades Avenue in Englewood, N. J.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 17The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.5 billion Mnmiles, 7.2 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 492,247 cars, 5,7 er cent above last year.

title: The Pop Life AllStar Jazz Group Set for First Concert
description: In this pop life, where hyperbole is far more common than talent, it's very difficult to distinguish the significant from the flashy event. Yet, it would be hard to overstate the promise inherent in the first concert of the New York Repertory Jazz Company a week from tomorrow at Carnegie Hall.

title: CUT IN OIL PRICES URGED BY SHULTZ
Byrne Plans a Public Defender Office And Intends to Name Van Ness Head
description: TRENTON, Jan. 17  Governor Byrne announced today that he intended to create a new state publicadvocate department and nominate Stanley Van Ness, the State Public Defender, to head it. If nominated and confirmed, Mr. Van Ness would become the first black man in the Byrne cabinet.

title: 294 SCHOOLS CLOSE HERE IN WALKOUT
Phillips Petroleum to Raise EnergySupply Capacity
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company plans to spend $650million this year to increase its capacity to produce 'energy supplies, the company announced yesterday in Bartlesville. Okla.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The Department of Commerce, reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $785million, up 9 per cent over the yearearlier $721million. Total retail store sales were about $8.468billion, an increase of 5 per cent over last year's $8.064 billion.

title: Oil Shale Bid Accepted
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI)  The Interior Department said today that it had accepted a top bid of $210.3million by the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and the Gulf Oil Company for the right to. develop tile first of six oil shale tracts on Federal lands in the Rocky Mountains.

title: Mackell Case Load Called Too Heavy for Close Tabs
description: Prospective jurors were told yesterday that Thomas J. Mackell, accused of blocking the prosecution of a criminal swindle, once headed one of the largest prosecutor's offices in the country and could not possibly have known what was going on in every case.

title: 2 Chinese Gunboats Are Reported Sent To Disputed Isles
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 17 (Reuters)China has sent two gunboats to the disputed Islands in the South China Sea after a shooting incident there involving South I Vietnamese troops, military 'sources here said today.

title: Thailand Officially Chides U.S. Over C.I.A. Interference There
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 17Thailand expressed official dissatisfaction to the United States today over the admitted interference by the Central Intelligence Agency in Thai affairs.

title: Skylab 3 Crew Cleared for Another Week
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 17 (AP) The Skylab 3 crew got a go ahead today to continue its rec ord earthorbiting mission ?? at least another week after experts reviewed the health of the crew and the condition of the spacecraft.

title: Absorbing Recital On Cello Is Played By Victor Cortes
description: Victor Manuel Cortes, young cellist from Mexico who played in Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night, is a musician with unusual but absorbing ideas, even if he will, probably never be compared with Platigorsky. Unlike that paradigm among cellists, Mr. Cortes cares not a whit for a large, rich, pulsating tone, but prefers to make his points with purposefully lean, biting, even astringent sonorities.

title: Attorneys for Mrs. Carpi Recall Two Threats in 71
description: TRENTON, Jan. 17  A Mercer County Superior Court jury heard testimony today that Colin C. Carpi threatened his estranged wife, Laura, twice shortly before she was murdered.

title: Restaurant That's Italian but Feels Exactly Like New York
Of Planners, HeadBopping and Mountain Goats
description: The fastest  growing major city in the United States  the city with the best highway systemthe city with some of the most innovative architecture in the world is Houston. Houston has no zoning laws.

title: Survey Finds Sports No Obsession Here
description: For residents of a city that boasts as many major teams as New York does, adult New Yorkers are apparently not obsessed with sports. Three out of five New Yorkers 18 years of age or older do not follow either basketball or football, according to the TimesYankelovich survey, and 44 per cent don't follow baseball.

description: A woman named Luba Harrington returned from her summer home in Sag Harbor, LI., last fall, and brought with her some flowers from a garden, When she began to arrange the flowers in a bowl in her apartment here, there flew out of them a small fly. I didn't bother killing it, Mrs. Harrington says, Why should I have killed it? It was such a small

title: At Gulfstream . . .
description: Gulfstream Park opened a 40day meeting with its president, James Donn Jr., doing his best to eschew gimmick betting. Donn grudgingly has installed three perfectas (known as the exacta in New York) races on his daily 10race program He would prefer to have none.

title: Cards'
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 17 (AP)Joe Torre, a first baseman who was asked to take a pay cut, was among five players reported today by the St. Louis Cardinals as having signed their 1974 National League contracts.

description: THE LIVING PRESIDENCY. By Emmet John Hughes. Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. 368 pages. $10.50.

description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan, 17 (Reuters)Troops occupied the University of Indonesia campus today shortly after the departure of Premier Kakuel Tanaka of Japan, whose visit here was disrupted by violent demonstrations.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17The first consumer directory of physicians in the nation, containing such information as office hours, fees, willingness to make house calls and medical training, was released today for the Prince Georges County area of Maryland, a suburb of Washington.

title: Crosby Out of Intensive Care
description: BURLINGAME, Calif., Jan. 17 (UPI)  Bing Crosby, the singer who underwent lung surgery last weekend, was transferred today from an intensivecare unit at Peninsula Hospital here to a private room. His spirits are high, he's sitting up and he's on a soft diet now, a hospital spokesman said of the 69yearold entertainer.

title: Notes on People
description: Spiro T. Agnew, the former Vice President, has put his suburban Washington home up for sale for a figure reported to be around $300,000. which is at least $100,000 more than he paid for it a year ago.

title: TV: Eye on New York Jensen Interviews Sgt. David Durk About Knapp Hearings on Police Corruption
description: Channel 2 Eye on . . . is the kind of weekly halfhour that could have given the primetime access rule a good name. The rule took a halfhour away from the networks each night and gave it back to the local station. It was designed to encourage, among other things, more diverse and more adventurous programing. Too much of it, however, was squandered in games shows and various nature expeditions.

Spater, former chairman of the carrier, be punished for his role in an illegal corporate contribution to President Nixon's reelection campaign.

description: OMAHA, Jan. 17 (UPI) Carroll G. Brunthaver, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for International Affairs and Commodity Programs, said last night that he planned to resign at the end of the month.

The Soviet press gency, Tass, said the Cosmos was in orbit with a high point 1,026 kilometers and a low point of 975 kilometers and ircled the earth every 105 minutes.

title: A THIRD THIEU TERM MEETS OPPOSITION
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 17 (AP)Fifty opposition assemblymen said today that the supporters of a proposal to allow President Nguyen Van Thieu to run for a third term were annihilating democracy for a totalitarian regime.

title: Parole Inquiry Is Slated For a Man Jailed in 11
description: The State Senate Committee on Crime and Correction announced yesterday that it would conduct an inquiry into the denial of parole to a 79yearold inmate who has been in prison for murder since 1911.

title: DANFORTH STARR OF CERRO CORP, 68
description: H. Danforth Starr, board chairman of the Cerro Corporation, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, while on an airplane en route to Florida, where he bad planned to attend a meeting of a company of which he was a director. He Was 68 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Being on Time for Job Seems No Big Problem
description: Getting to work on time is not an overwhelming problem for New Yorkers, according to the results of the survey. More than threequarters of them said they felt relatively confident they could get to work on time if they left on time.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 17 (UPI) The chairman of an energy policy group in the Consumer Federation of America contended today that the Nixon Administration had failed to solve energy problems but ,had let energy companies profits run wild.

description: LONDON, Jan. 17 (UPI)The price of gold jumped an alltime high of $132.30 an ounce in Paris today. The dollar made unsteady progress in European exchanges.

description: Marc Neikrug, the pianistomposer who is the son of George Neikrug, cellist, has een creating a body of music or his father that is of more han passing value and should expand the relatively small cel?? repertory. description: LONDON, Jan. 17The British Government tonight eased the curbs on power for the steel industry and said it would consider extending the threeday I work week to four days.

description: ALBANY, Jan. 17State Cerritoller Arthur Levitt asserted today that physician factqty members at the state's four medical schools were regularly earning more outside income than perniitted under the State University's rules and that the medical schools generally made little effort to enforce the state regulations.

description: SEAL BEACH, Calif., Jan. 17 (AP)Rain caused postponement today of the Virginia Slims women's tennis tournament.

description: Mayor Beanie is considering appointing Irving Goldman, who is now a major power in the Shubert theatrical enterprises, as Commissioner of Cultural Affairs.

description: HOUSTON, Jan. 17 Bill (the Bridegroom) Bradley rejoined his New York Knick teammates today after a 48hour honeymoon and, everything considered, was treated gently by a group whose teasing capability is enorMOUS.

At 23 pounds ringside, 33 inches tall and 34 years old, Michu was giving the former heavyweight champion almost 200 pounds, three and a half feet in height and two years in age. He had come north from the winter quarters Ringling Bros.Barnum & Bailey for the match, which was staged for a sellout crowd of photographers on the East 60th Street sidewalk outside the Wig and Pen Restaurant. The encounter with Frazier took place inside the pub at a joint birthday party; All turned 32 yesterday, Frazier reached 30 last Saturday.

title: Screen:Shorts by Vlatko Gilic, Yugoslav, at Forum
description: Moisture makes dried blood flow again: there's a shock in that discovery as a hand scrubs the stained walls of a slaughterhouse, where men in white aprons prepare for the day's killing. "In Continuo" is one of four recent documentaries by the Yugoslav film maker Vlatko Gilic, who has won five prizes in his own country, several in Germany and deserves many more. His work can be seen at the Film Forum, at 256 West 88th Street, through Sunday and Jan. 24-27. Don't miss it.Within the slaughterhouse, the preparations are quite ritualistic, as the men carefully wash the floor and sharpen knives that aren't intended for carving cooked meatbut for cutting into live flesh. Suspense builds up to the carnage that we know will come. The animals' slaughter isn't shown; instead, thick blood oozes and swirls toward the gutters, and the evocation is more powerful than seeing the act itself. The men's serious, intent faces imply that there are no jokes on this job. At first, they seem like soldiers getting ready for battle  later, as though they're in the middle of a war."One Day More" centers on a murky stream outside a small Yugoslav town, where the mudbaths are said to cure even deadly diseases. Old and young sink to their chins in the dark liquid, some rub parts of their bodies with jetty slime. Heads seem to float on the water, while mist rises in a shot that Fellini might envy. The atmosphere is dense with concentration and bleak hope. You feel that these people are terribly worried and fearful about their bodies. They wait as though for a miracle. Finally, they shower, cheer up and chat noisilyin contrast to the anguished hush that held while they were in the stream.Deep concentration and preparation  while waiting for something to happen  are themes that recur in Mr. Gilic's work, whether his subjects are profoundly absorbed in butchery or in trying to regain lost health oras in "'To Love"in one another. This film begins with a piece of machinery slowly moving in space: You can't tell what it is, but it's fascinating to watch it reach its destination. Again, there's suspense, which mounts to the satisfaction of seeing something accomplished. Eventually, we learn that two sides of a bridge are meeting in mid-air, and that we've been watching the key piece going into place. The mystery is solved in one shot, which also suggests the peril of working at great heights.One of the construction workers climbs to the ground, where his wife waits with a picnic. All their feelings are conveyed through their expressions; there are almost no words. While waiting, she looks both eager and apprehensive: Clearly, she's anxious about his safety. She spreads a white cloth in the wilderness and sets forth a feast with as much care and deliberation as the men give to working on the bridge. Affection surges through brief gestures: She pats his knee, he pushes a strand of hair out of her eyes while she beams at him. Mainly, they gaze at each other and eat, and that simple act reveals an extraordinary sense of intimacy."Power" shows a hypnotist giving his disciples  six young men with ultra-white skin and dead black hair  a lesson in dominating the will of others. They follow the master's wordless instructions like zombies, repeating many of his actions. They also direct one another's behavior. He slides a giant black needle through both his cheeks without apparent pain; they do the same, but some can't help wincing. A hand moves in front of eyes that look momentarily terrified  as though watching something hideous that we can't see. There's some groveling and hand-kissing and also some ecstasy afoot. The portrayal of the master's control of his followers is repellent  as it's obviously meant to be. But "Power" hasn't the same brilliance as the first three films, partly because the subjects seem self-conscious.Mr. Gilic's films are called documentaries. But he's superb at finding the astonishing images that lurk in the ordinary world. It's as if he'd nabbed some magic from the air and wedded it to facts. And it's a privilege to see through his eyes: Whatever interests him assumes a contagious excitement for us. It's evident that a major talent is already well developed, and since Mr. Gilic is in his mid-30's, we have a lot to look forward to.

title: Officer Tells Panel of His Oil Protest
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 A Navy officer who has submitted his resignation in protest against Administration policy told Congress today that new wells drilled by the Standard Oil Company of California may be draining oil from the Elk Hills Petroleum Reserve.

title: Making A Better Market
description: Stockmarket reform has proved to be a frustrating experience to all hands. The many moving parts that make up the stock market will not sit still long enough for anyone to figure out what the problem is, or was, much less how to make repairs. And it seems that whether the market is up or down it is making someone important unhappy.

McCormack, president of the fire officers, announced yesterday. The pact, which is retroactive to July 1, 1973, and is subject to a review by the Cost of Living Council, increases salaries of fire lieutenants from $18,590 to $19,825, and of fire captains, from $21,450 to $22,875.

title: Art: Delight of Kandinsky Prints
description: Habitues of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum could be forgiven for feeling that the very last thing this museum needed was another exhibition of the work of Vasily Kandinsky. The museum was more or less founded as a shrine to Kandinsky's art, and its permanent collection even today contains the single most comprehensive collection of Kandinsky'S work in existence. Indeed, though the museum has long since taken a more eclectic and openminded view of the history of modern art, there is still a sizable part of the art public (at least In the older generation) that identifies its outlook with Kandinsky's career and accomplishments.

title: Famous Kenya Elephant Dies in Drought
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Jan l8Ahmed, a massively tusked elephant that had become a major tourist attaction, died, yesterday, a notable victim of an increasingly severe drought, in this East African nation.

However, he is sharing the repeat concerts with Morton Gould, who will be conducting this evening.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19Vice President Ford made a news splash the other day by stepping out of character. He has always been good stolid old Jerry, regular guy, who makes a virtue of having neither bark nor bite, and when he suddenly appeared in Atlantic City Tuesday sounding faintly like the Spiro Agnew of old the press naturally took notice.

description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 18The coalition Government of Belgium collapsed today after the National Iranian Oil Company announced that it was pulling out of a joint project to build &refinery near Liege.

Schiffman, an electronics engineer and inventor, was granted Patent 3,786,195.
