description: World Team Tennis, which has yet to swing a racquet, scored its biggest victory yesterday when Walter Elcock, United States Lawn Tennis Association president, announced the U.S.L.T.A. was prepared to sanction the new league for five years.

title: Solzhenitsyn Replies
description: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn charged that the campaign by Soviet authorities against his new book revealed their animal fear of exposure. The dissident writer predicted that the time would soon come when his book would be widely read, even in the Soviet Union. Page 4.

title: Sullivan Quits as Environment Chief, Stirring Ecologists Criticism of Byrne
description: TRENTON, Jan. 18Commissioner Richard J. Sullivan of the State Department of Environmental Protection, submitted his resignation to Governor Byrne reluctantly today, provoking a storm of criticism among environmentalists and Republican legislative leaders who charged that the new Democratic Governor had forced the Commissioner out.

title: Missed Opportunity
description: Developing shortages of oil and other vital resources add a new dimension of urgency to worldwide efforts to curb population growth. Because of recent advances birth control techniques and a marked decline in fertility In this country in recent years many Americans tend to believe that the population problem is well on the way solution. That unfortunately is not the case.

title: Cougar Pilot Fined In Shoving Incident
description: GREENSBORO, N.C. Jan. 18 (AP)Coach Larry Brown of the Carolina Cougars reportedly has been fined $1,300 by the American BaS.: ketball Association for shoving an official at halftime of  the Virginia SquiresCarolina Cougars game her Dec. 30.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: SHORT HILLS, Jan. 18Team handball may he a sport with an identity crisis, but not in the home of Dr. Peter Buehning, which has become a sort of headquarters for the game in this country.

title: Scratches Set Up Five Daily Doubles
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 (AP)Frozen track conditions set up an unusual daily double payoff at Liberty Bell Race Track today. After some trainers refused to run their horses over the frozen strip, there were five late scratches in the first race and four late withdrawals in the second. This set up a fiveway payoff on the doubles.

title: Nixon's Budget to Go To Congress Feb. 4
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)President Nixon's budget for the fiscal year 1975, starting July 1, now reported be in the area of $305billion, will go to Congress Feb. 4, sources here said today.

title: Mosconi Increases Lead Over Briton
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 DPI) Willie Mosconi continued his mastery over Rex Williams of Britain in their $20,000 Black Velvet bildardssnooker competition.

title: Costly Sidestep
description: Controller Goldin has just given the city's taxpayers and, we hope, his colleagues in the Board of Estimate and City Councila useful reminder of the high cost of economizing on the municipal operating budget by borrowing to pay for daytoday expenses that should be financed out of current revenues.

title: City Hall Follies of 1974
description: (To the tune of Mr. Gallagher and Mr. Shean)

title: Lockheed Chief Expects Arrival of Needed Cash
description: The maximum amount of added financing the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation will need to overeome the threat that it will soon run out of cash is $75million, the company's chairman, Daniel J. Haughton, said yesterday

title: Military Gains of the Pullback Agreement Appear to Be Cairo's
description: However the Israelis may assess the disengagement from a diplomatic and political point of view, from a military point of view Israel's withdrawal from her major bridgehead west of the Suez Canal, and Egypt's retention of positions on the eastern bank and of bridges across the canal, appear to shift the strategic balance in Cairo's favor.

title: RaceRigging Case Inches Out of Gate
description: Thirteen harness drivers Indicted four weeks ago on charges of racefixing learned yesterday what races they were supposed to have fixed.

title: ANN SUMMERS
description: Mrs. Grace Rifbjerg Mann, theater, movie and television actress under the name of Ann Summers, died Tuesday in Hollywood after a short illness. She was 54 years old and lived there.

title: SILVER FUTURES CLIMB TO PEAKS
description: Record gold prices abroad attracted heavy buying of silver futures here. Prices of silver on the Commodity Exchange once again set record highs, with the March delivery moving up to $3.80 6/10 an ounce and closing at that level, about 8 cents higher than the former high on Thursday.

title: ExBrooklyn Man Gets Quaker Executive Post
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18Louis W. Schneider, staff director of the worldwide program operations of the American Friends Service Committee for 14 years, today was named the national executive secretary of the American Quaker organization.

title: Pleasant Pianism From Zola Shaulis
description: The technical facility and fastidious musicianship that Zola Shaulis demonstrated at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night made listening to her piano recital a generally pleasant,,though not very stimulating, experience. Miss Shaulis who tied for first prize in the 1971 Naumburg Award competition here, still plays, like a contest winner, in that she gives each piece a smoothly machined finish. ?? often lacking in this program however, was evidence that she had felt ?? deeply enough. She did not get much past a kind of small scated elegance in Bach's Goldberg Variations and a selection of Chopin Etudes.

title: Radiation Therapy Interrupted By a Cutback in Voltage Here
description: A 5 per cent cutback in voltage by Consolidated Edison has led to a week's interruption of radiation therapy for patients at the MemorialSloane Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan, a spokesman said Yesterday.

title: Market Place: Fund Manager Turns a Corner
description: When John Smith set up business as a money manager two years ago he had the usual struggle to get accounts. In fact, he was only able to get one by May, 1972. He still has just the one account, pensionfund money, and he is by no means assured that he will be able to continue in the business even to this day.

title: Most Have Confidence in City's Schools
description: Although New Yorkers are strongly divided about the merits of school decentralization, an overwhelming majority are optimistic that their children can get a good education in the public schools here.

title: Pajama Game Closing
description: The Pajama Game, the musical costarring Barbara Mc. Nair, Cab Calloway and Hal Linden, will end its run at the LuntFontanne Theater after tomorrow's matinee. It will have played 49 performances. The show by George Abbott, Richard Bissell, Richard Adler and Jerry Ross was produced by,Mr. Adler and Bert Wood in association with Nelson Peitz.

description: The Grand National Team Championship, introduced last season, has become a highly popular event. It gives many tournament players their only opportunity to compete in a major national championship in their own area. About 25,000 players are expected to compete this year, including some 1,500 from a Western area that mustered only eight teams last year.

title: 13% Cut by Phelps Dodge
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation announced yesterday the imposition of a 13 per cent force majeure reduction of refinery shapes, copper rod and bare wire deliveries for February due to continued reduced production at its smelters resuiting from equipment outages and construction required to satisfy applicable environmental regulations.

For his latest work, given its premiere by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater On Thursday night, George Balanchine is using musique eonorete. The ballet is called Variations Pour une Porte et un Soupir.

title: Celtics Win; White Keys Late Spree
description: BOSTON, Jan. 18 (AP) Jo Jo White sparked a 10point Boston burst at the start of the fourth period to help the Boston Qeltics record a 9894 National Basketball Association victory over the Atlanta Hawks tonight.

title: SATELLITE MISSES ORBIT IN MISFIRING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) The second stage of a Delta rocket misfired tonight, apparently scrubbing an attempt to put a British military communications satellite into orbit, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said.

title: The Fabric Isn't FuturisticJust Very Modern
description: Girdles stretch, of course. So do ski pants, a lot of panty hose and some swimsuits and bras. But evening dresses? An increasing number of those that fit like paper on the wall do so because they're made, of elastic. Not the old fashioned elastic made of rubber, but an expandable synthetic fiber called Lycra. It's mixed with all kinds of other fibers, synthetic as well as natural ones, to produce those evening dresses that stretch. Along with day dresses, skirts, pants, even play clothes.

title: SAIGON REPORTS CLASH WITH CHINA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Jan. 19The Saigon military command reported this morning that fighting had broken out between South Vietnamese and Chinese naval and ground forces in a disputed archipelago in the South China Sea.

title: Levin Enters Guilty Plea In the Equity Funding Case
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 18 (UPI)  Fred Levin, a former executive president of the Equity Funding Corporation of America, today changed his plea to guilty on charges of conspiracy, mail fraud and illegal wiretapping.

description: LONDON, Jan. 18 (UPI Gold leaped today to its high. est price on record while the dollar lost value in major European markets.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 18 (AP)An American woman drove her car through a crowd of angry demonstrators outside the United States commissary today, killing a Vietnamese man and injuring a Vietnamese woman. United States Embassy officials said

title: City's OutofClass Pupils Drift or Get Time to Play
description: For the city's more than 880,000 liberated pupils, yesterday represented a release from cold and littered schools, the start of a welcome threeday weekend.

title: SIRICA REQUESTS GRAND JURY LOOK AT TAPE ERASURE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18Judge John J. Sirica asked the special Watergate prosecutor tonight to give immediate and serious consideration to a grand jury investigation of the erasure of 18 minutes of a crucial Watergate tape recording and the alleged nonexistence of two other subpoenaed tapes.

title: School Peonage
description: Thanks to intervention by Chairman Vincent McDonnell of the State Mediation Board, onehalf of the crippling strike by school furnace and maintenance workers is over and the other half seems likely to end in time for reopening of classes Monday. But these welcome developments do not remove the need for a change in the degrading system of employment highlighted by the twin walkouts.

title: Tentative Accord Reached In One of School Walkouts
Knee Injury to Keep Fairbairn Out of Rangers'
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 18The Rangers, having shown last night that they could lose even with Emile Francis coaching, found themselves another man short today as they practiced for tomorrow afternoon's encounter with the Black Hawks at Chicago.

title: BYRNE AND SPASSKY ADJOURN 3D GAME
description: Robert Byrne, the United States chess champion, and Boris Spassky, the former world champion, adjourned the third game in their quarterfinals Candidates Match after 41 moves last night in San Juan, P. R.

title: No Voting in Tripoli
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Jan. 18 (AP)Libya appeared to have shelved her planned referendum, set for today, on the merger. Until Wednesday the statecontrolled press had announced that the vote would be taken today, Fridaythen, yesterday, the press made no mention of it. Today, there was no ,voting here, nor was there any indication if or when a new date would be set.

title: PRISON OUSTS TWO IN SCALDING DEATH
description: TRENTON, Jan. 18Two correction oficers at the Trenton State Prison were dismissed today for neglect to duty in the Scalding death of a 21yearOld inmate in his preCivil War cell three weeks ago.

title: WILLIAM B. BAILEY
description: William Bancker Bailey, retired New York lawyer, died Thursday in Midtown Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 511 East 20th Street.

title: Moroccan Court Dooms 6 For Roles in 73 Uprising
description: KENITRA, MOROCCO, Jan. 18 (Peuters)  A military tribunal here sentenced six Moroccans to death today for their part In a leftwing uprising against the regime of King Hassan II last March. Three others were given life imprisonment, and four drew 30 years

title: SPORTS COMPLEX: A MUTED VICTORY
description: NEWARK, Jan. 18 Triumphantly flourishing a $3.02million certified checka good faith deposit on the $302milion bond underwriting agreement the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority signed todayDavid A. Werblin, the authority's chairman, pointedly kept the name of the bank which the check was drawn covered with his fingers.

title: Antiques: Winter Show at the Armory

title: Rockets Kill One and Wound Four in Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 18 (AP)Communistled insurgents fired two rockets into the center of Phnom Penh this morning, killing one person and wounding four, police officials reported.

title: Eastern Air Asks 6% Fare Rise; Cites Increases in Cost of Fuel
description: Eastern Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday to authorize a 6 per cent increase in domestic air fares on March 1 to help the airlines meet rising jet fuel bills.

title: GOVERNOR RESIGNS IN GRENADA CLASE
MRS. J. S. SHANLEY
description: Mrs. Agnes O'Gorman Shanley, widow of J. Sanford Shanley, an architect who died in 1969, died Thursday at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Rodney F. Joselyn, in Bucks County, Pennsylvania. She was 78 years old and lived at Sniffen Court in this city and in West Cornwall, Conn.

title: LANDLORDS MEET OVER FUEL COSTS
Books of The Times
description: In the hotstove league of birdwatcherdom, this is the season of discontent. Oh, the brightred cardinals are at the feeder all day, of course, and the slatecolored junco merrily flashes its white tail feathers and the blue jays call raucously. But mostly it's a season of waiting, waiting for spring and the rush of glorious color and sweet songs of the migrants and nesters. It's a season when the exciting discoveries of the fall are discussed and rehashed, and when hopes for finding a new rarity or two in the coming season are highest. Maybe this year a bluebird will miraculously appear; maybe this year a blackcapped chickadee will take up residence in the bird box; maybe this year you'll see that warbler you've been looking for all these years.

title: OIL COOPERATION STRESSED IN I.M.F.
description: ROME, Jan. 18Major developed and developing countries agreed here today to cooperate to ease the impact of sharply higher oil prices on their economies.

title: Allegheny Airlines Said to Give C.A.B. Special Treatment
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 18A consumer group under Ralph Nader's direction asked the five members of the Civil Aeronautics Board today to order Allegheny Airlines to stop giving special treatment to the five members of the board.

title: LINTON D. WEIL
description: Linton D. Weil, a registered representative with Bache & Co., Inc., for more than 16 years, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, in Roosevelt Hospital he was 67 years old and lived in Wingdale, N.Y.

title: Still Waiting for Welfare Reform
description: The President's newest proposals for welfare reform, promised for last spring and then for fall, have not yet been disclosed. Apparently, James T. Lynn, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, wants a program of housing allowances for poor people but Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, thinks that that may preempt his department's position. Still, it is said that Mr. Weinberger is not sure what he favors. A Presidential decision is required but Mr. Nixon has been otherwise occupied.

title: Maine 31st State to Ratify Equal Rights Amendment
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 18Maine today became the 31st state to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment to the United States Constitution when the State Senate voted 19 to 11 in favor of the measure.

title: MAKEUP OF JURY BRINGS DISMISSAL
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Jan. 18 Murder indictments against six convicts accused of killing three prison guards were dismissed here today by a judge who ruled that the indictments were invalid because they had come from a grand jury that had too raw members of racial minorities, bluecollar workers and the young.

title: Defendant Tells LI Court He Killed C. W. Post Coed
description: At times silent, at other times laughing or shouting obscenities, the defendant detailed his actions of last June 15, the day of the murder, until Supreme Court Justice David T. Gibbons asked: Did you kill Patricia Ann Sullivan?

title: Con Ed Gets Steam, Gas Rises As P.S.C. Overrules Examiners
description: ALBANY, Jan. 18  The Public Service Commission today overruled two examiners recommendations and authorized the Consolidated Edison Company of New York to increase gas and steam rates by 4.6 per cent and 7.8 per cent, respectively.

title: David Crawford, ExHead Of U of Hawaii, Dies at 84
description: MOORESTOWN, N. J. Jan. 18 (UPI)David L. Crawford, who served as president of the University of Hawaii for 25 years and wrote three books on the Hawaiian Islands, died in a nursing home here yesterday of Parkinson's disease. He was 84 years old.

title: Voters May Be Ms.
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif, Jan. 18 (UPI) A bill permitting wonmen to designate themselves as Ms. when they register to vote has won final legislative approval from the allmale California Senate.

title: Jaworski May File Criminal Charges InI.T.T.Settlement
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI) The special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, said today that his office was considering filing criminal charges in connection with the Government's settlement of International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation antitrust cases and a broad range of related matters.

title: U.S. Awards a Contract For Research Safety Car
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UFOThe Government awarded a $2.1million contract today to several manufacturers, including the Ford Motor Company and Volkswagen, to make a research safety vehicle.

title: People in Sports: Howard Will Swing Bat in Japanese Parks This Summer
description: Frank Howard, the 6foot8inch 275pound slugger, who signed for a reported $108,000 bonus with Los Angeles in 1958 and led the majors in home runs at Washington in 1968, has decided to move on to greener, and smaller, pastures. He was signed earlier this week by the Taiheiyo Lions of the Japan baseball league. He was released after last season by the Detroit Tigers.

title: Suffolk Opens Today
description: BOSTON, Jan. 18 (UPI)The $9,000 Bostonian Handicap will highlight the opening day of racing tomorrow as Suffolk Downs starts its 40th thoroughbred meeting.

title: Woman, 41, Found Slain Outside Home in Suburbs
description: IRVINGTON  ONHUDSON, N. Y. Jan. 18A 41yearold woman was found stabbed to death in the driveway of her $150,000 house here last night.

title: Bill Shakespeare, Star Halfback At Notre Dame in 1930's, Dies
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 18 (AP)William V. Shakespeare, star halfback for the University of Notre Dame in the nineteenthirties, died last night at Good Samaritan Hospital at the age of 61.

description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 18 Peter M. Mocco, the Mayor of North Bergen, was indicted by a Hudson County grand jury on charges of criminal conflict of interest and conspiracy.

description: TRENTON, Jan. 18  The state rested its murder case against Colin C. Carpi today after presenting 36 witnesses and introducing into evidence 67 exhibits during two weeks of testimony.

description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 18 (AP)Charlie Mahoney's two foul shots with 41 seconds left to play clinched a 7367 victory for Manhattan College over Seton Hall tonight in the Miami Beach Basketball tournament. Biscayne College defeated Fairfield College, 6758, in the second game. Tonight winners meet for the championship tomorrow night.

title: Simon Hopes for Rollback In the World Price of Oil
description: William E. Simon, head of the Federal Energy Office, expressed optimism, yesterday that gasoline rationing could be averted this year and that world oil prices could be rolled back to more reasonable levels.

title: Narragansett Racing Off
description: PAWTUCKET, R.I., Jan. 18(UPI) Narragansett Park was closed today because of a frozen track. Thoroughbred racing, canceled after, the fifth race yesterday because of track conditions, was to resume tomorrow.

title: Celluloid Menace
description: The specter of Cuba as a threat to this nation's security would seem to have been largely eliminated with the dismantling of the Soviet missiles in 1962. Is therefore puzzling in the extreme why the State Department has considered it necessary or proper deny entry visas to two Cuban film representatives who were invited to the United States in order to accept an award for artistic excellence from the National Society of Film Critics.

title: Fifth Graders Refuse to Permit Strike To Stop Surprise Party for Teacher
description: It was Mrs. Sherman's birthday, this week and the fifthgraders at Public School 96 on East 120th Street had painstakingly plotted how they could give her a surprise birthday party yesterday.

title: New Bill to Aid Homosexuals Offered in Council
description: A civilrights bill for homosexuals, defeated for the fourth time last year by the City Council, has been quietly reintroduced by 19 of the 43 members.

description: News Summary and Index, Page 33

title: Shipping/Mails AllHours Given in Daylight Saving Time
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: 50 Persons Routed By Tenement Fire; 2 Firemen Injured
description: A smoky fire burned through the upper portions of a row of 10 wooden tenements in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn last night, leaving at least 50 persons homeless on one of the winter's coldest nights.

title: Egyptian and Israeli Chiefs of Staff Sign Suez Accord
description: ON THE CAIROSUEZ ROAD, Egypt, Jan. 18The chiefs of staff of the Egyptian and Israeli armies, flanked by a United Nations general and two American diplomats, today signed an agreement to disengage their military forces along the Suez Canal.

description: Eximbank Grants Credits to Soviet

title: BAIL OF $2.3MILLION IS SET FOR CORNFELD
description: GENEVA, Jan. 18A Geneva court fixed bail tonight for Bernard Comteld, deposed founder of the now distil. tegrated Investors Overseas Services mutual fund empire, at a record of 8 million franca (about $2.34million),

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Cornerstone Items Sold for $725

title: MRS. CLARA EDWARDS
description: Mrs. Clara Edwards, a song writer who was a member of the American Society of Corn. posers, Authors and Publishers since 1925, died Thursday at her home, 29 East 64th Street. Her age was 95.

title: Tunisian Premier Says Talks Are Set With Libya on Snags
description: TUNIS, Jan. 18  Premier! Hedi Nouira of Tunisia said today in an interview that negotiations with Libya would be undertaken to settle the difficulties in the way of union between the two countries.

title: PRESTON A. CHAMPNEY
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., Jan. 18 Preston A. Champney, who retired in 1940 as traffic manager of the American Can Company after having served it since March, 1901, a month after its organization, died today. He was 96 years old and formerly lived in Upper Nyack, N.Y.

title: Leftists in.Spain Giving Little Support to the Basque Terrorists
description: BILBAO, Spain, Jan. 11 The Basque terrorists who as sassinated the Spanish Premier last month are getting little support here from other leftist groups that are equally opposed to Generalissimo Francisco Franco's Government but which disapprove of the Basques methods.

title: Engineers Threaten Strike On the Long Island Monday
description: The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers announced yesterday that it planned to strike the Long Island Rail Road at 5 A.M. Monday because of the railroad's elimination of the second man in the cab of passenger diesels.

title: Equity Disputed on Concession to the Roundabout
description: Paul Libin, president of the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers, disputed yesterday a statement by Actors Equity that the Roundabout Theater was operating under the current Off Broadway contract.

title: THOUSAND IN PRAGUE AT SMRKOVSKY RITES
description: PRAGUE. Jan. 18 (Reuters)About a thousand Czechoslovaks today attended the funeral here of Josef Smrkovsky the former reformist leader who died of cancer Monday at the age of 62.

title: A Corps of Chefs Toasts the Bride
description: LIVINGSTONWhen the daughter of the board chairman of Restaurant Associates is the bride, there are many cooks in the kitchen, And when the cooks are the chefs at The Four Seasons and The Forum of the Twelve Caesars, two top New York restaurants, there are never too many.

title: AirTest Center Fate in Doubt
description: ATLANTIC CITYFor 16 years, the whining of airplane engines at the huge Federal test center in nearby Poniona has been a sweet sound to the people of Atlantic County.

title: Transcript of Nixon's Speech on Energy Situation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19Following is the White House transcript of President Nixon's nationwide radio address today on the national energy situation:

title: Purdue Triumphs, 8976
description: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind., Jan. 19 (UPI)  Purdue beat Northwestern, 8976, today and maintained its perfect mark in Big Ten Conference basketball. Purdue now has a 40 wonlost record in the league and is 114 overall.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor. Beanie made it official yesterday, confirming reports that he would appoint James. R. Dumpson Commissioner of Social Services and that he intended to dismantle. the Human Resources Administration. Mr. Dump. son, 64 years old, will take a leave of absence is dean of Fordham University's Graduate School of Social Service. He served as the City's Welfare Commissioner for six years under Mayor Robert P. Wagner. He will be acting Administrator of Human Resources until Mr. Beame breaks up the superagency, one of three established by his predecessor, John V. Lindsay, that the new Mayor intends to do away with. Mr. Dumpson's salary will be $43,255 a year.

title: Discount for Aged At Flower Show
description: OAKLANDNew Jersey's elderly residents will receive special groupdiscount rates for admission to the 1974 New Jersey Flower and Garden Show.

title: OIL PRICES CITED IN MOVE ON FRANC Experts Also See Setback to Hopes of Monetary Union
description: ROME, Jan. 19 European Common Market sources said today that the French decision to free the franc from currency ties inside the Common Market was a sign of dislocation caused by the recent fourfold increases in oil prices and represented a setback for hopes of European monetary union by the end of this decade.

title: Bill Seeks To Combine Registration For Voting
description: ALBANYThe second bill passed by the Assembly in the 1974 session, which opened its business year last week, was a sleeper  a holdover filed nearly a year ago that is expected to have a major, quiet impact on the elections for school, fire and water districts throughout Long Island this year and in the years to come.

title: PATH Will Speed Union County Rider
description: The Port Authority predicted yesterday that it will take Union County commuters only 4 to 22 minutes to reach a projected PATH rail station serving Newark Airport.

title: Common Cod and Lowly Vegetables Are Uncommon Treat
description: When tomatoes and herbs can be gathered from the garden to sauce a fresh striper, it is easy. With a bluefish out of the water just long enough for the barbecue to be lighted and the water to be boiled for the corn, it is fun.

title: Jolas Premiere By Miss Bucquet
description: In each of the four programs of 20thcentury piano music that MarieFrancoise Bucquet is giving in Tully Hall this season, she has scheduled a work commissioned by her for the series. On Tuesday night, In the third of the series, the premiere was of Betsy Jolas's B for Sonata.

title: Ali's Hand Treatments Stir a Mystery in Camp
description: DEER LAKE, PaEvery day since last October, oversized jar of Theraffin opened and its contents smeared over Muhammad kli's right hand.

title: ZANZIBAR ORDERS STRICT SCHOOLING 18to20YearOlds Now To Get Training in Discipline
description: ZANZIBAR, Jan. 15 (Reuters)  All young people on Zanzibar aged 18 to 20 will have to go to boarding school to learn discipline, the island's President has announced.

title: Interunion Battle Rages Over 10,000 School Aides
description: A bitter interunion battle over the right to represent 10,000 school aides in the city heated up last week.

title: CHINA TIGHTENS CURBS ON CULTURE
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 19Permissiveness in the field of culture is under attack in China, where the relaxed atmosphere of last year is giving way to demands for stricter censorship and more intensive propaganda.

title: 2 Utilities Expect To Meet Demands
description: Two utilities serving thousands in Brooklyn. Queens and Long Island said last week that they were optimistic about meeting all energy requireMents for the remainder of the year.

title: Michigan Wins, 8482
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 19 (AP)C. J. Kupec's basket with one second left gave the University of Michigan an 8482 Big Ten Conference basketball victory today over Michigan State. The Wolverines are unbeaten in three conference games with an 113 overall wonloss record.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
TunisianLibyan Move: A Key to Arab Politics
description: CAMBRIDGE, MassIt is as Certain as can be that the Tunisian Libyan agreement to merge into. a new republic Will not SUrviVe the infancy stage if, indeed, it should see the light of day. Yet the fact that it was even conceived, and the difficulties. it immediately faced, shed an interesting light on contemporary interArab. polltics and ,highlighted certain crucial features of panArab nationalism.

title: Saigon Says China Bombs 3 Isles and Lands Troops
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Jan. 20  Chinese MIG's bombed a chain of three islands in the Paracel group today and followed up by landing an amphibious force there, the Saigon Government said.

title: SPASSKY DEFEATS BYRNE IN 3D GAME
description: Boris Spassky, the former world chess champion, defeated Robert Byrne, the American grandmaster, yesterday in the third game of their world championship quarterfinals match in San Juan, P.R.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: There are probably few corporate executives who decide, while standing on a bathroom scale each morning, ,whether they will allow themselves the luxury of breakfast.

title: Fashion: The cut's the thing
description: Liza Minnelli doesn't carry a comb. Mallory Tone who works one floor above her hairdresser, sees him only four times a year. That says it about hair today. Whether it's cropped short like Liza's or worn to the shoulder like Mallorys,it has to be easy to take care of.

title: Movies
description: Is Lumet excited about the success of Serpico'? I'Mnot one to be cool about a hit, having had so many flops.

title: Saigon Amends Constitution to Let Thieu Run Again
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 19A special joint session of the National Assembly voted today to amend the Constitution so that President Nguyen Van Thieu can run for a third term in 1975. The amendments also extend the term from four years to five.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Olympia and York Developments, Ltd., of Toronto has purchased 2,000 acres of Wooded hind at the intersection of Routes 9 and 18 in Madison Township, N.J.

title: Kirsten's Title Role In Manon Lescaut'
description: Aside from the fact that there were five changes NI cast, the Metropolitan Opera's performance of Manon Lescaut on Friday night had two handicaps. Harry Theyard, who was to have made his debut with the company as Des Grieux, had substituted the previous evening at the house in the strenuous role of Hoffmann in Offenbach's Les Contes. d'Hoffmann. Dorothy Kirsten, appearing for the first time this season in the title role, MS singing against orders of her doctor, who felt she was going Onstage too soon after an operation.

title: Beckwith Is Cleared of Carrying Bomb
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 19 (UPIByron De La Beckwith was found not guilty today. of carrying it live time bomb and a pistol on a midnight drive into New Orleans from Miasis

title: Bond Fees Collected By Lawyers May Be Cut
description: TRENTON  A threeyearold report that accused lawyers of earning excessive fees from bondcounseling work and recommended sweeping reforms may soon lead to tighter controls on such fees.

title: GEORGE RUNS, REALTY MAN, DIES
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 19 George H. Fearons Jr., a socially prominent Roman Catholic layman in New York died today of a heart attack at his home here. He was 74 years old and lived at 35 East 75th Street n.Nelvf York and in Stony Brook, LI., and North Lovell, Maine..

title: Susan Salm Bows In Cello Recital
description: There was very little wrong with Susan Salm's playing in her local debut recital on Jan. 10 in Carnegie Recital Hall. The Chicagoborn, Juilliardtrained cellist was being presented as an auditions winner by the Concert Artists Guild, and she was quite obviously a talented artist, wellschooled and with sound musical instincts. All that she needs would seem to be growth in her musical personality.

title: Honey Jay Takes Dash
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 19 (AP)Honey Jay raced to a threequarterlength victory today in the $17,500 BlackGold Handicap at the Fair Grounds. Honey Jay covered the six furlongs in 1:11 25 and paid $12 for $2 to win.

title: The Craziest Shop in All of London
description: LONDONIf you have been search, ing all your life for some particular weird item of decoration '., or apparel but could never find It, Maybe your quest will at last be taped at the Prop Shop in the Chelset section of London. Who knows, maybe you have always needed a pair of goldpainted rubber griffons. to embellish the legs of a bench, going at $200 the pair, or a mummy case for $675 (oops, just sold) or a few brass apples at $7.50. If your fancy runs to more droll array, such as a white cotton Victorian servant's chemise ?? $25 or a nineteenthirties ostrich leather cape at $23.75 or a Cleopatra headdress, complete with serpent, at $62.50, you will probably fall upon this minuscule store with the avid, gluttonous relief known only to the shopping nut victorious.

title: SADAT, ON TOUR, ASKS ARAB UNITY
description: CAIRO, Jan. 19  President Anwar elSadat,of Egypt toured Arab capitals today in an attempt to get the most important Arab leaders to underwrite the agreement signed by Egypt and Israel yesterday on the disengagement Of their forces along the Suez Canal.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: TV Mailbag
description: I WAS frankly appalled at the incredible lack of good taste displayed in the choice of subject matter in a recent All in the Family episode. I am referring specifically to the threat of breast cancer and possible mastectomy for Edith Bunker. Surely there must be less painful and traumatic aspects of the human condition from which one can draw humor.

title: R. F. Alvaro Jr. Weds Sara Cole
description: SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 19Miss Sara Cole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Ashley Cole, was married here this afternoon to Raul F. Alvaro Jr., son of Mr. Alvaro of Elizabeth and the late Mrs. Doris Alvaro.. Msg. John Ryan performed the ceremony in the St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church.

title: Mary Barbara Ludi Engaged To Edward Wyllis Scripps 3d
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Jan. 19Mr. and Mrs. William C. Ludi have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Barbara Ludi of Mountain View, Calif., to Edward Wyllie Scripps 3d, also of Mountain View. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Scripps of Hillsborough, Calif. and Lyford Cay, Nassau, ills Bahamas.

title: Connors in Net Final
description: ROANOKE, Va., Jan. 19 (AP)  Jimmy Connors of Belleville, Ill., and Karl Meiler of Germany, advanced today to the final of the Roanoke tennis tournament. Connors beat Vitas Gerulaitas of New York, 64, 63, after Meiler defeated Vijay Amritraj of India, 61, 76.

title: Device of Impounding Program Moneys to Be Dropped
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 President Nixon's new budget will all but abandon last year's highly controversial device of impounding funds for programs approved by Congress.

title: A Frontier Town With Echoes Of San Clemente
description: IT was after his sweeping reelection triumph against an Ineffectual opponent that his troubles really begen. One scandal after another erupted. Harassed businessmen had been forced to make illegal contributions to his campaign. The Democrats discovered that their campaign had been sabotaged. The President's chief administrative officer and other trusted aides were implicated in skulduggery. And then, instead of casting out the lot of them, the President defended these people, claiming new constitutional powers and invoking executive privilege to protect them. On the eve of the anniversary of the American Revolution, the Federal Government was paralyzed. There were demands for impeachment. Only his exemplary record in foreign affairs saved the Administration from

title: Briefs on Energy
description: THE HAGUE, Jan. 19 (Reuters)The Netherlands has accepted President Nixon's invitation to attend a conference of oilconsuming countries in Washington Feb. 11, the Dutch foreign ministry said here today. The ministry said

title: Change Bends a Spine in Brooklyn
description: Ocean Parkway cuts, a wide, treelined swath from Prospect Park at Brooklyn's midsection due south to the Atlantic Ocean. For thousands of drivers plying its six lanes, it's merely a fivemile thoroughfare feeding the Prospect Expressway on one end, or the Belt Parkway on the other. For others, Mention of the parkway conjures up a summer's day at Brighton Beach or Coney Island, a hot dog at the original Nathan's, all of which are at its southermost end. But for still othersold men looking up from their chess games to watch the endless vehicular stream, middleaged householders raking their front yards, orthodox Jews walking to the synagogue on the SabbathOcean Parkway is home.

title: Leonard Shecter, Sportswriter, Ball Four CoAuthor, Is Dead
description: Leonard Shecter, a writer whose toughminded approach to sports challenged the re whiz school of reporting, died yesterday of leukemia at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 47years old and lived at 200 Ella 16th Street.

title: 5 Russians Ousted By China on Charge Of Spy Activities
More Women Advancing Into Key Business Posts
description: Women are Sat last moving into the PiPeline of Aniefican business. Though not all of them care to acknowledge it, their presence is largely a result of government pressure and militant feminism.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A major and most egregious omission in the article Lower East Side Tests HomeoWners [Jan. 6] must be noted. I refer to the failure to mention the recent highly successful efforts of New York City's Cooperative Conversion Program to assist in the acquisition of older tenement buildings and their rehabilitation and conversion to cooperative ownerships by their tenants. While this is a program of citywide application, it has already had a considerable impact on the East Side.

title: News Of the Stage
description: Lynn Redgrave, the youngest member of the theatrical Redgraves, who was thrust into stardom by her performance in the 1966 film Georgy Girl, has been signed to star on Broadway this season in the Charles Laurence comedy My Fat Friend.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
QUESTIONS
description: UNWANTED TREES

title: Emilio Gautier Weds Miss Mercurio
description: The Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd in Brooklyn was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Agnes Mercurio, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Mercurio of Brooklyn, to Emilio P. Gautier, also of Brooklyn. The Rev. Peter J. Dexnis performed the ceremony.

title: Closing In
description: The yearlong debate over the nature and extent of President Nixon's personal responsibility for the abuses known as Watergate has, at least for now, been placed in an extraordinary context. A major crime has apparently been committedthe deliberate erasure of a vital White House tapethe F.B.I. is trying to find out who did it, and one of a small group of people they must consider suspects is the President of the United States.

title: ELWIN B. DIXON
description: Elwin B. Dixon, assistant foreman of the delivery department of The New York Times since 1954, died early yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, on his arrival home from work. He was 56 years old and lived at 8064 258th Street, floral Park, Queens.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Doug Swift, linebacker and playerrepresentative of the Miami Dolphins, has misgivings about the future of the Super Bowl champions: You can expect to see a lot of new faces on next year's team. A lot of important contracts come up for renewal and you can bet the guys will be asking more than the management wants to pay.

title: Jazz Buff Realizes a Dream
description: KENDALL PARKIthssell Chase has realized one of the wilder, Walter Mittytype dreams that haunts any collector of jazz records. He has started his own record company, issuing such celebrated jazz names as Dizzy Gillespie, Charlie Parker, Coleman Hawkins and Roy Eldridge.

title: What's Opened At the Movies?
description: THE EXORCIST, directed by William Friedkin, written by William Peter Blatty and starring Ellen Burstyn, Max von Sydow, Lee J. Cobb, Jack MacGowran and Jason Miller, got 8 favorable reviews (Kathleen Carroll, News; Archer Winsten, Post; Rex Reed, News; Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; Joseph Gelmis, Newsday; Jeffrey Lyons, WPIXTV; William Wolf, Cue; Hollis Alpert, Saturday Review/World), 4 mixed (Howard Kissel, Women's Wear; Leonard Harris, WCBSTV; Andrew Sarris, Village Voice; Judith Crist, New York) and 7 negative (Vincent Canby, Times; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Gene Shalit, NBCTV; Jay Cocks, Time; Paul D. Zimmerman, Newsweek; Frank Rich, New Times; Pauline Keel, New Yorker). At the Cinema I, Beekman, Paramount and paris

title: Some Good News and Some Bad News
description: WASHINGTONPredicting the future of the American economy, always a difficult exercise, has become almost impossible. As 1973 ended, the economic indicators were flashing a bewildering variety of signals, quite apart from the uncertain impact of the oil shortage. There was an abundance of both good news and bad news

title: France Asks a U.N. Parley On World Energy Resources
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 19France has proposed world conference on energy resources to be held under United Nations auspices.

title: An emerging reputation comparable to Pushkin's
Houston Gunman Captured With Three Hostages
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 19 (AP)A gunman who held 13 hostages in a supermarket for 10 hours was captured tonight shortly after he made his escape, the police said.

title: Cyr A. Ryan Is Fiance Of Miss Mary O'Hara
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 6The engagement of Miss Mary Frances O'Hara to Cyr Annan Ryan has been ananunnsd by Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Patrick O'Hara, perants of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mn. William Shields Jr. of New York and Allamuchy, N. J., and the late Clendenin James and a greatgrandson Ryan, Fortune Ryan, the financier.

title: Idaho Net Coach to Quit
description: MOSCOW Idaho, Jan. 19 (AP)  Jeff Williams, who coached the University of Idaho's tennis teams to Big Sky Conference titles the last three years, resigned today, effective July 1.

title: Gardens
description: WHEN we were young and had little Aims for the pleasures of nature, my wife and I enjoyed the companionship of an older couple who lived a short distance from our home. Rarely did we visit them without having to listen to long, detailed report on how a persistent, conscienceless squirrel got into their bird feeder and wreaked havoc.

title: Judy Ann Darr Plans Wedding
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 19 Mr. and Mrs. James F. Darr have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judy Ann Darr of New York, to Charles Paterson Eaton, an institutional salesman with the New York brokerage firm of H. C. Wainwright & Co. He is the son at Hugh M. Eaton Jr. of Akron, Ohio, and Dublin, N. H., and the late Mrs. Anne P. Eaton.

title: Karen Murphy Engaged
description: Mrs. John E. B. Murphy of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Karen Bourke Murphy, to Brian Wray Goesl, son of Dr. and Mrs. Andrew G. Goesl of Texarkana, Tex. The future bride is the daughter also of the late Mr. Murphy.

title: It's hard to prove that something, even a monster, doesn't exist
description: The year was 1924, and the place, according to the now legendary story, was Toba Inlet, located on the coast of British Columbia opposite Vancouver Island. For three mornings in a row, Albert Ostman, a lumberman on a vacation camping trip, had awakened to find that his campsite had been disturbed by a nocturnal visitor from the woods. Now as night fell on the fourth evening, he crawled into his sleeping bag fully clothed, intending to feign sleep and surprise the animal that had come to rummage through his knapsack and make off with his food. But after few hours, sleep overcame him.

title: FRANCE TO FLOAT FRANC 6 MONTHS,
description: PARIS, Jan. 19France said today that she would float the franc for six months, setting it free of fixed rates by ending Support for it on the exchange markets.

title: Dane Wins Dinghy Title
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 19 (UPI)Torben Andrup of Denmark won the world OK Class dinghy championship from a fellow Dane, Jorgen Lindhardsten, by 10 points today. Kjell Axerot of Sweden placed third. The seventh and last heat of the series was won by Lars.Fagerberg of Sweden.

title: Racial Issues Split City Deeply
description: New York's major ethnic groupings  blacks, whites and Puerto Ricansare in striking unity in their feelings about such problems as the need to deal with crime, welfare and inflation, but they are seriously divided on issues often rooted in race.

title: Staff of 57 Helps Ellis Give Skiers the Cold Facts
description: TORRINGTON, Conn., Jan'18 Frank Ellis, who provides toll free telephone ski information service for enthusiasts from Maine to California had two visitors yesterday afternoon. They were from the Southof ern New England Telephone Company. When they left, they carried with them a check for $15,974.44. On the bottom of it was Ellis's signature.

title: MacaroniCheese Dinners Recalled by Kraft Foods
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) Kraft Foods said today it had recalled 2.2 million packages of Kraft Macaroni and Cheese Dinners that the Food and Drug Administration had said might contain foodpoisoning bacteria.

title: SYMPTOMS MISSING IN GONORRHEA RISE
description: A team of University of Washington doctors has found irons a study of civilians and soldiers that many more men than previously believed are unknown carriers of gonorrhea. Public health officials say that this venereal disuse has reached epidemic proportions in many countries.

title: Mediator Says Pact is Agreed On to End Hunts Point Strike
description: A Federal mediator announced A new agreement yesterday to end the wildcat strike by warehousemen at the Hunts Point Produce Market, raising hope that the flow of fruits and vegetables into the city's depleted grocery stores might resume sometime today.

title: BEEF SUPPLY OFF AND PRICES CLIMB
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 19With the beef cattle that were held back during last summer's price freeze now sold and eaten, the supply of beef was dropping once again this week and prices were starting to climb again as a result.

title: Alice Fisher Engaged
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 19The engagement of Miss Alice A. Fisher to Barry R. Hansen, son of.Mr. and Mrs. Ewald Hansen of White Plains, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bennett Fisher.

title: Eins, Zwei, Drei, Vier Hans und Fritz Are Coming Here
description: WE are expecting a task force of about 2,000 to land in Hawall next summer, says HansJuergen Kaul, a spokeman for one of West Germany's leading travel agencies. The. members of this task force are/ unlikely to indulge in anything more bellicose than shooting barracuda with a speargun, and yet, ,Heir ICaul's lapse into military Jargon, common lapse among West German purveyors of holiday travel these days, is rather fitting. Tourists from the Federal German Republic, aimed with their hard Deutsche marks, are embarked on worldwide conquest, adding to their holiday dominions at a rate that astonishes their folio* Europeans.

description: TODAY

title: Rome Report Traces Moves Of Five Airport Terrorists
description: ROME, Jan. 19A Government report on the massacre at Fiumicino international airport on. Dec. 17 stated today that it was carried out by five Arabs who had arrived shortly before from Tripoli, Libya, by way of Madrid.

title: The Past Is Only a Partial Guide to the Present
description: WASHINGTONTo his regret, nothing Vice President Gerald Ford said during his 25 years in Congress has been repeated as often, both with scorn and approval, as his description of what constitutes an impeachable,offense.

title: Fuel Crisis Spurs Pleas For Expanded Bus Lines
description: TRENTONPeople throughout the state are urging officials to develop and expand local bus service, in part because of the shortage of gasoline caused by the energy crisis.

title: E.P.A. CHIEF VOICES ENERGY WARNING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 19The nation's top environmental official says the dimensions of the energy crisis are far bigger than is generally appreciate and call for both altered national lifestyles and new governmental mechanisms.

title: Pension Plan Wins As Suffolk Opens
description: BOSTON, Jan. 19 (AP) Favored Pension Plan easily won the $9,000 Boston Handicap before a crowd of 9,104 today as Suffolk Downs opened its 40th year of thoroughbred racing.

title: Cape Cod Arena Is For Sale
description: HYANNIS, Mass., Jan. 19 (AP)The Cape Cod Coilsewn is for sale for $2.5million.

title: Harry Long Fiance Of Janice L. Jeffers
description: Miss Janice Lynn Jeffers, a senior at Smith College, and Harry Winston Long, secondyear student at Harvard Law School, plan to be married. Mr. and ,Mrs. Nathaniel Jeffers of South Ozone Park, Queens, Miss Jeffers parents, have an nounced the engagement.

title: The High cost of Energy Is Affecting Politics as Well as Economies
The Vassals Are Restless
description: Something decidedly like a revolution is brewing down in the slave quarters where the menials of the baseball establishment are loading up for the industry's first round of contract negotiations involving impartial arbitration of salary disputes. Though their owners don't know. it, the peons have already got together and armed themselves with a weapon the owners hoped to keep out of their handsel exact knowledge of how much money other players With comparable ability and experience are getting from other employers. Thus informed, a shortstop batting.275 will have for the first time a reliable guide as to how much he ought to get, and can decide whether to take his case to arbitration.

title: America's Corporate Sweethearts
description: They're the sweethearts of American business, the Mary Pickford and Douglas Fairbanks of the corporate realm. Mr. and Mrs. Harding L. Lawrence are probably the only two chief executives of Big Board companies who would dare suggest that love between corporate officers is a sound management strategy.

title: A Woman Waits 8 Hours to Get Some Food
description: The line of old, blind, and disabled stretched a block outside the entrance of the Brooklyn Borough Hall Social Security district office and into the two heated buses, motors constantly. running, that Social Security has provided.

title: Architecture
description: BEFORE the assessments of the Lindsay Administration have all been used to wrap yesterday's fish, one part of the score that has been conspicubus by omission should be added to it. The subject is urban design, or as correctly stated in the title of a new book by Jonathan Barnett, Urban Design as Public Policy (Architectural Record Books, McGrawHill). Mr. Barnett Is one of a group of able young people who worked in government to help establish this virtually new field as an integral part of city procedure, and Mr. Lindsay was the Mayor who put his weight behind it.

title: I Took to TV Like an Alcoholic to Demon Rum
description: IT is sobering to reflect that while 92 per cent of the households in this country have television, only.86 per cent have indoor plumbing. I read somewhere that TV is now regarded as a necessity for families on welfare and no doubt it is. Yet, since I do not own a television set, such facts leave me feeling a bit isolated to say the least. It is more than the minor embarrassment of missing references to popular shows and commercials at cocktail parties and the like. Rather, it is missing out on part of the collective unconscious of America. Sort of like never having visited Disneyland or Yellowstone, I imagine.

title: The complete Truth Is Global
description: JUST a year ago was in the middle of Africa. Thirty of us had crossed the Sahara and were driving into villages, unrolling a carpet, making music, dancing or playing stories for anybody who cared to watch. In a matter of moments, we would be surrounded by old people, young people, tiny children all giving our work immediate, untroubled attention. When we met the village chief, we would explain that we were traveling to see if communication was possible between, people who had no common language. This simple explanation was always completely satisfactory.

title: Oil Energy Role for Businessmen

title: A room to live in
description: Our kitchen is the heart of the house, says Hungarianborn George Lang, writer, cook and adviser to hotels, restaurants and shipping lines on the planning of their fond. preparation centers. And it really is where the pulsing life of the Lang household is centered. It's where George and his wife Karen cook, eat, write (he is the author of The Cuisine of Hungary), sew, watch television, entertain, hold cooking and baking classes, store a ton (literally) of dishes, cooking utensils, food and wineand just plain live. When the Langs were ready to build their dream kitchen last year, they w...!re able to tell architect Donald Mallow just what the 17by35foot space should contain and how Should be laid out. It is essentially professional, with a whiteenameled restaurant range topped by a huge brass hood, a double, glassdoored refrigerator, a commercial dishwasher that is noiseless and almost instant (it has a fourminute wash cycle) and a marvelous device that stores and lifts warmed plates for service one at a time. They avoided all fads and fashions and let utility and their own needs and taste govern the appearance of the kitchen. The result is a gleaming stretch of space that is all light and white with accents of wood and brass.

title: After the appeasernent of the sheiksThe idea of Europe runs out of gas
description: The impending collapse of Europe has been announced by a great many thinkers in our time from Spengler to Sartre and beyond. But none of the prophets of doom had sufficient imagination to envitage that the fatal crisis could be triggered by the Emir of Kuwait and the Sheik of Abu Dhabi. The economic consequences of the oil crisis had a limited effect, but the political impact was shattering, a turning point in the history of contemporary Europe. True, there was a rush to the pumps; illuminations and street lighting went out all over Europe; speed limits were imposed, and Sunday driving was banned. There were dire predictions for the economic outlook in the next few years. But the oil restrictions will not last forever and in the long run they will have the salutary effect of forcing the industrial world to face problem neglected far too long. World oil resources are likely to last only for another two or three decades, and, since the days of cheap oil are over anyway, alternative sources ofenergy are urgently needed. To this extent the Arab diplomats were right when they told their American colleagues that for the West the interruption of the flow of oil was a blessing in disguise. Western nations and Governments needed a sudden shock to galvanize them into action.

title: A Jazz Fantasy Come True

Musicians dream of autonomy so that they can be in complete charge of the label's finances as well as of its music policy. Jazz performers have long, and often justifiedly, complained of being ripped off by record companies. Get as much bread as you can in front, I have heard older players counseling newcomers, because you'll never see any royalties.

title: Food
description: What would you command if you were allowed one last great meal on this earth? I have my answer. The menu would move blissfully from caviar with vodka (Stolichnaya, by choice) to, in due course, a fine fat squab stuffed with truffles and foie gras. It would end with an elegant ice. Now, preferences in food are highly subjective and there may be those who would question my choice, of squab. But to my mind squab is one of the most sumptuous of birds and for that last go. round at table, I would not willingly accept a substitute. Except, just possibly, quail. I did not choose filet mignon as a principal dish, a fact that may astonish beef lovers, but as I have noted many times, I find it monotonous. I prefer hamburger. And what kind of cheese would there be for one's last meal? I choose Brie because to me it is the king of French cheeses.

title: The Shea Syndrome

Casey Stengel, drinking bourbon often to ease his penance as the manager of the Mets, was asking, Can't anybody here play this game? The Jets were escaping from the Polo Grounds before the empty seats collapsed around them. At the same time, the Yankees were about to win their 15th pennant In 18 years and the Giants had won a National Football League division title in five of the six previous seasons. Clearly, the Yankees and the Giants were in command of their constituents. But the world turns. Now the Mets and the Jets of Shea Stadium dominate the town, according to a survey conducted for The New York Times by Daniel Yankelovich Inc., the public opinion and research firm.

title: What the Neighbors Did; And Other Stories. By Pearce Pearce. Illustrated by Faith Jaques. 130 pp. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell Company. $4.50. (Ages 9 to 13)
description: In the Middle of the Night, the best story here in Philippa Pearce's collection, is very funny. It's about children illicitly cooking potato cakes and is as finely structured as music; at the last note, sighing pleasurably, you wish for nothing more: a distinct achievement. On the other hand, some of these stories are often oddly unsatisfactory. The tone varies, of course. Two are first person, some slangy, others formal or detached or both. But all have Miss Pearce's strong sense of place, her wit and slyness of observation (adding, incidentally, to her special gallery of obstinate old men). Some may not be children's stories at all. The title one, for instance, shows a small, awful, adult wasteland. The best are too good to be confined to children anyway.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 19 (UPI)  Wolfgang Zimmerer and Peter Utzschneider of West Germany held a comfortable lead at the halfway stage of the world twoman bobsled championships today and seem well on the way to winning the title for the third consecutive year. In today's two runs Zimmerer piloted his sled in the fastest times down the..icy 1,722yard course, leading from St. Moritz down to Celerina. The final two runs will be held tomorrow, the winner to be decided by the best aggregate time over the four runs.

title: World Cup Pairings Produce Predictable Reaction

description: Jessie Bollier is a 13yearold white youth who lives in New Orleans early in the 1840's. He likes to sit on the docks and play his fife, and one day he is overheard by two men. That night he is captured by them and taken aboard a slave ship bound for West Africa. Jessie soon learns that he will be the slavedancer, playing his fife for the captured Africans on the return voyage, inducing them to macabre dances as a means of pacification.

He starts talking in an intense waterfall of nasal, New Yorkaccented hard consonants and somehow, within two sentences, he looks handsome and dashing. He picks a few runs on his guitar and he seems 10 erect feet tall. A group of musicians assembles around him and, as they develop a hootchykootchy, theme with a heavy backbeat, Bromberg is suddenly shouting in a raw, rusty voice

title: Unhappy childhood

title: Recordings: A Tip of the Hat to Verdi's Vespers
description: OF all Verdi's mature operas (that is, from Rigoletto of 1851 to Falstaff of 1893), Vespri Sicilian is the biggest question mark for most operagoers. The composer's other 11 stage works written during this period are now familiar repertory pieces in major opera houses (save for the 1857 Aroldo, an uneven revision of an early score), but Vespri turns up very infrequently. Whether we've been overlooking some vintage Verdi or not will shortly be resolved for New Yorkers when the Met stages its firstever production on Jan. 31 meanwhile RCA's new recording of the opera should provide an instructive preview of what to expect (ARL 4four disks).

I always need a lot of paint to cover my work. I just placed a bigger order than I normally would, figuring prices would be higher next spring."

title: The Protestant Ethic gets it again
description: It's not easy to spin a lot of familiar disaffection into an interesting book, but Philip Slaterformer chairman of the Department of Sociology at Brandeis and author of the widely praised social critique The Pursuit of Loneliness: American Culture at the Breaking Point (1970)almost pulls it off. The substance tends to dissolve itself as you go, in contradictions, provisos and explanations of foregoing explanations. It all comes down to a few hard grains, but has a lot of flavor while it lasts.

title: All men heroic, all women beautiful, all beasts friendly; Indian Paintings From the Punjab Hills; A Survey and History of Pahari Miniature Painting. By W. G. Archer. Two volumes. 783 pp. London and New York: Sotheby Parke Bernet. (81 Adams Drive, Totowa, N. J. 07512.) $84.
description: To the traveler looking north from the Punjab plain in India, the Himalayas rise seemingly as a great, sudden, impermeable wall. But this is an illusion. Before the mountains begin, there are foothills with valleys behind or between. Other valleys, some wide, some mere clefts in the wall, run deep into the mountains. The most famous of these, the Kashmir Valley, lies deep behind the first mountain range. To this day these valleys, that of Kashmir apart, are little visited and not much known. But on those who do know them they exert a compelling fascination. Partly this is the contrast with the plains. Unlike the latterKipling's sand under a burning glassthe valleys are cool and green with fresh, fast streams. Partly it is the women, who are tall, clearskinned, erect and, one senses, confidently aware of their reputation for beauty. Partly it is the mountains. All other mountains the eye associates with the earth; these belong to another, more remote world related

title: When the court made a spectacle of itself
description: Aside from students possible passing acquaintance with Milton's Comus, the court masque is probably the least known of Renaissance art forms. The masque in Stuart England was a strange mixture of mythological poetry, political theory and polemic, opera, aweprovoking spectacle, amateur ballet, fancydress ball and formal party. Members of a tiny but centrally important audience would themselves participate, as allegorical and symbolic personages, acting out in formal patterned dances, done in spectacular but iconographic settings, a moral emblem whose meaning was revealed to, and whose results devolved upon, them all as princes and nobles of a great culture. A satiric anti(or antic) masque might also occur, but its disorder would usually be resolved in the central fable of fiction, at the end of which masquers and audience would join in the dances of the closing revels. The masque is lost to us not only in the way that Ben Jonson himself despaired of recovery by imagination, much less by description, a part of that spirit it had in the gliding by. For although taste and scholarship may allow us to simulate for ourselves the learning of James I, or the artistic connoisseurship of his son Charles, we can never be kings or princes, strongly affirming our role as moral and even metaphysical center or soul of the body politic, even at the moment as that body was beginning to declare the independence of its members, and

description: TRENTON  New Jersey's Green Acres Preservation Program, looked upon as the ideal way to protect open space when it was started in 1961, has run into an increasingly familiar problem: How to guard parkland and recreation areas while municipalities struggle for added sources of tax revenue.

title: 14 Reported Missing After 2Ship Crash Near New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 19 (AP) Search operations for 14 persons still missing in the collision of a freighter and a tanker were hampered by fog today.

title: Dance: Ballet Theater as a Museum
description: American Ballet Theater is our national gallery of the danceand also, in the nicest and least mustiest way, our museum of record. At a couple of performances, Wednesday and Friday nights, the company gave only one ballet, Eliot Feld's Intermezzo, which dated from the seventies. The next youngest ballet was Antony Tudor's Undertow, which dates from 1945.

title: Collombin Takes Cup Skiing Title
description: WENGEN, Switzerland, Jan. 19 (AP)Roland Collombin, a 23yearold, won the Lauberhorn downhill classic today, becoming the first Swiss skier to post a victory on this famous track since 1950, and clinched the World Cup downhill title.

title: ChaplinOnce a King, AlWays a King
description: CHARLIE CHAPLIN's A King in C New York is like a letter written but unsentuntil nowfrom a faroff time and place of great bitterriess. It is quarrelsome, hardheaded, egomaniacal. Although it was produced in 1957, it looks very much like a movie made by a man who acted In his first films in 1913. When the camera moves, it has a way of making everything else seem static. It's Movie with absolutely no gift for small talk, the sort of tricks or narrative bridges that get the story from the climax of one sequence into the start of the next. People always seem to be walking across rooms, opening doors, letting other people in, and walking back again. Nothing seems to happen far great stretches. A lot of scenes look as if they'd been lifted, from plays that were being acted befOre any scripts had been written.

title: Disengagement
description: The military disengagement between Egypt and Israel may be, as the text of the agreement. says,. only a first step toward peace in the Middle East; but it is a first step of fundamental importance and is the most hopeful development to have taken place in ArabIsraeli relationships in many years. It is also a genuine triumphto use a much misused wordfor the diplomatic skill of Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, without whose extraordinary negotiating efforts the agreement could never have been attained.

title: Dora Short Plays FirstRate Violin
description: Dora Short, a violinist from Virginia with a good deal of performing experience behind her, made her New York debut a year ago. The recital was well received, and on Monday night she returned for a second concert, in Town Hall. If she wanted to confirm locally that she is a firstrate violinist, she did exactly that.

title: Antioch, a. Symbol of Quality, Struggling to Survive
description: YELLOW SPRINGS. Ohio, Jan. 15Antioch College, a venerable symbol of innovation and quality in American higher education, is struggling to survive.

title: An Ex Addict Declares War on Drugs
description: NEWARKIt was Christmas Eve, 1950, when George C. Richardson received a present that he has never forgotten. It was a small amount of light powder (heroin).

title: Program Fighting Segregation In Housing
description: The City Commission on Human Rights and local civic organizations in eastern communities of Brooklyn and Queens are collaborating on a pilot program designed to keep speculators and unethical real estate dealers from bringing about the deterioration of neighborhoods as a device to spur real estate activity.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The time has come when people should begin thinking seriously about the problem of inflation and begin to realize what it already has done to us, where we now stand and where we are heading. Corrective measures should no longer be delayed.

title: State Offers Little Trees For Sale
description: MILLBROOK, N.Y.  The State Department of Environmental Conservation announced last week that nine varieties of evergreen seedlings were available at a minimum cost for spring planting.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: GROSS NATIONAL PRODUCT, in real terms, grew 1.3 per cent in the final quarter of 1973, to a total of $1,334 billion [annual rate]. It was the smallest gain since the last quarter of 1970.... Industrial production dropped 0.5 per cent in December, the deepest decline in two years, automobile output fell... Consumption of electricity declined 4.1 per cent in the first week of daylight saving.

title: Whole New Game for Giants
description: The assistant equipment manager, black youth in his early 20's, spotted Bill Arnsparger seated at a table with Don Shula and several friends at the Miami Dolphins Super Bowl victory party last Sunday night in Houston.

title: James, at 72 M.P.H., Wins Ocean Race
description: MIAMI, Jan. 19 (AP)Sammy.James of Miami won the 200mile Jockey Club Sea Talk national ocean race today, averaging 72 miles an hour in a 38foot BertramWhittaker Moppie.

title: Oil and Pipeline Concerns Lose Suit Opposing Alaska Borough
description: BARROW, Alaska, Jan. 19More than 3,800 Eskimos and other Alaskan natives had good reason to celebrate this week as the Alaska Supreme Court dismissed a case by 12 oil and pipeline related plaintiffs that had fought the incorporation of the North Slope Borough.

title: They Really Do Have Everything, but They Want to Work, Too
description: CHICAGOHe is tall, fair, blueeyed and Nordic looking. She is tall, dark, brown eyed and exotic looking. They call each other Bubbles. They are currently Chicago's No, 1 youngcoupleabouttown, and the fact that she is Rockefeller and recently came into an estimated $35million obviously doesn't hurt any.

title: DR. ROBERT STEELE, BIOCHEMIST, 58, DIES
description: UPTON, L. I., Jan. 19Dr. Robert Steele, biochemst of the Brookhaven National Laboratories here and a former member of Brookhaven's council, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home at Arthur Avenue in Blue Point. He wag. 58 years old.

title: Art, The Recovery of a Masterpiece
description: IN his Journal for Feb. 22, 1860, Delacroix wrote: Realism is the great resource of the innovators at those periods when the schools are becoming languid and turning to mannerism; through it they awaken once more the blase taste of the public, while tha schools turn in the circle, of the same conventions.

title: Mrs. Curry Has Son
description: KINGS POINT, L. L, Jan. I9A ton was born on Dec. 29 to Dr. and Mrs. Charles MacNeil Curry Jr. at the North ShoreCornell.Medical Center in Manhasset Dr. Curry is director of emergency medicine at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip. His wife, the former Miss Susanne McGuire, is a vice president with C. Moberg, Inc., consumer public relations agency in New York. The child, who has been named C. MacNeil 3d, will be known as MacNeil.

title: Suns Rout Knicks by 112 to 89
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 19Having scored something of a victory merely by reaching Phoenix, after three, plane cancellations, an unscheduled sleepover in the Houston Airport's luxurious hotel and route through San Antonio, the New York Knicks faced the Phoenix Suns tonight in the last game of a twoweek road trip.

title: Coping With School Strike
description: Your school is hurt if you disrupt the routine. Normal is the standard, said Martin Ulivicky, principal of William Cullen Bryant High School in Long Island City, Queens, last Thursday. Meanwhile, I'll just play it by ear.

title: Merchants in Lodi Upset by Renewal
description: LODI  An urbanrenewal project is jeopardizing the future of the small lousiness district on Main Street, at one time the hub of this.Bergen County borough of 28,000 people. We once had 120 businesses here, said Vincent Sorbello, whose drugstore has been a fixture in Lodi for 40 years. Now there are only 12 of us left, and 300 families have lost their homes and moved away as well.

title: 2 Defenders Retain A.A.U. Luge Titles.
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Jan. 19 (AP)Terry O'Brien and Katie Homstad successfully defended their titles today in the Amateur Athletic Union national senior luge championships on the Olympic bobsled run.

title: The World
description: Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan has returned to Tokyo after 10 turbulent days of touring five nations of Southeast Asia, and at his final stop in Indonesia, he found the most violent demonstrations of all. But it was clear in Jakarta that more than antiJapanese feelings had brought thousands of demonstrators into the streets: They were also protesting the policies of their own government, and Mr. Tanaka's visit gave them the excuse to do so.

title: Gasoline Crisis Hard on Handicapped
description: Barbiara Tappet. of the Bronx, a 32yearold librarian at Baruch College in Manhattan, uses crutches because of arthritis and the weakening sideeffects of nearly four years of blooddialysis treatments for kidney disease.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Millions of Dollars Washed Out to Sea in Efforts to Curb Beach Erosion
description: The National Park Service's desire, which was made public late last summer, to stop spending millions of dollars in essentially ineffective beach erosion control is praised by Gary Soucie in the January issue of Audubon magazine.

title: Some Irked by $3 BoatShow Charge
description: The $3 admission to the National Boat Show irks some ticketholders as much as it might if admission were charged to enter the A & P.

title: Elaine Hamrick Will Be Bride Of Day R. Shields on April 20
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Hamrick of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marguerite Elaine Hamrick, to Day R. Shields, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Shields of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: FREDERICK GUYOTT JR.
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Jan, 19 Frederick F. Guyott Jr., New England sales manager of architectural construction systems for the Johns Manville Corpora tion, died yesterday in Norwalk Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at West Branch Road here.

description: Announcement has been made by the Rev. and Mrs. John B. Coburn of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Eugenia Coburn, to Steven Earl Borgeson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl C. Borgeson of Palo Alto, Calif.
