description: WOODBURY, L. I.Registration for cultural arts workshops conducted in Woodbury, Jericho and Syosset will be held at the SyossetWoodbury Park Community Center on Jericho Turnpike here on Jan. 28 through Jan. 31 from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. Registration forms may be obtained by calling Lois Manning at 9215944, Fact. 5875.

title: SplitLevels Giving Way To Apartments In the Suburbs
description: Whether it's three rooms over the delicatessen, a luxury highrise, a gardenapartment complex or a condominium development with its own golf course and bridle path, the apartment, by whatever name, is coming to suburbia.

title: People and Business
A Journey Well Worth Making
description: THE 30 or so art galleries of SoHo, increasingly interspersed with boutiques these days, are an odd lot. Ranging from vast, glossy showrooms to dusky little storefronts, they Carve up a territory as much psychological as esthetic. Each gallery has its own constituency of artists and audience and its own complex ambience. Some are brazenlit involved in selling; others have discreet, uptown manners, and still others seem almost to suggest, by their hairshirt funkiness, that any mention of money would draw frown.

title: The new Americanborn musicians: tired of playing second fiddle
Narragansett Off Again
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., Jan. 19 (AP)Today's racing at Narragansett was called off because of dangerous track conditions, officials said. An early morning ice storm melted by post time, making the track slushy and wet. It was the sixth cancellation of the track this season.

title: Tureck Song Recital Today
description: In the Who Makes Music and Where listings in today's Arts and Leisure Section, notice of Jerome Tureck's recital today was inadvertently left out. Mr. Tureck, a bassbaritone, will appear at Carnegie Recital Hall this afternoon at 5:30 and, with Stanton Carter as accompanist, will offer songs and arias by Handel, Schunann, Verdi, Strauss, Ravel and Hoist.

title: Divisi Of Property In Divorces Is Appealed
description: TRENTON  In 1971,when New Jersey revised its divorce laws for the first time in 50 years, the legislation included a littlenoticed provision that is currently musing shock waves in the state's system of dividing marital property.

title: Playing O'Neill, in life and on stage
Pop&
description: ANOTHER generation's ol blue eyes is back. Bob Dylan, like Frank Sinatra, has emerged from a state of semiretirement with a brand new batch of songs on a new album release called Planet Waves (Asylum 7E1003) that coincides with his first fullscale tour in eight years. And the original Dylan audiente, who are the children of the Sinatra generation, is treating the event with all the reverence of a Second Coming.

title: Headliners
description: For 25 years H. L Gross, the Iowa Republican, has been the fiscal gadfly of the House of Representatives. Mr. Gross made a practice of reading every report and bill, being present for almost every session and interrogating the manager of each bill, usually beginning with the question: How much will this boondoggle cost? Last week he announced his retirement at the age of 74. Typically, the announcement was handtyped, with carbon copies to save the pennies costs to run a copying machine.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES INSURANCE LIMIT State Asked to Alter Rule on SavingsBank Policies
description: The New York State Law that prohibits individuals from buying more than $30,000 in savingsbank life insurance and that restricts purchases to people who live or work in the state has been challenged in a court suit by Consumers Union.

title: 5th Charged in Getty Case
description: ROME, Jan. 19 (UPI)A fifth southern Italian was charged today with involvement in the kidnapping of J. Paul Getty III, who was held for five months. A warrant charged Giuseppe Lamanna, 49 years old, with abduction, inflicting serious wounds and criminal associa??

The Lawrences Contracts
description: For several years, Harding and Mary Lawrence were. tile highest paid executives In their industries;: and and that's more than a slight coincidence.

description: To the Editor:

title: At the Heckscher Detective Story.
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I,  The Heckscher Museum, which has five Ralph Blakelock canvases of its own, has turned over a good part of its exhibition space for a show of the 19thcentury romantic artist and for a special seminar on his work.

title: Free Boat Instruction Is Offered
Pro Bowl Bids Adieu To Season
description: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 19 (UPI) Tomorrow will present the last call for the 197374 football season with the Pro Bowl game in Arrowhead Stadium.

description: TRENTON  New Jersey homeowners are expected to be able to obtain adequate supplies of heating oil for the remainder of this winter. And the gasoline shortage, acute during the recent holiday season, is expected to ease, at least for the next several weeks.

title: Merchants Blow the Whistle on Defective Goods
Brazil New Industrial Powerhouse
description: RIO DE JANEIROAt a time when many of the world's leaders are fearful about Industrial downturns, Brazil's military leaders are atruggling to keep their soaring economy from smashing through the roof.

title: Henry Levine Fiance Of Brenda L. Kaplan
description: LONG BEACH, L.I., Jan. 19 Miss Brenda Lynn Kaplan and Henry Levine, graduates of Union College, plan to marry next year. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Irving Kaplan, parents of the bridetobe, whose fiance is the son of Mrs. Sidney Levine of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Levine.

title: Chinese Girls Oppose Presents for Weddings
description: PEKING, Jan. 19 (Agence FrancePresse)The Chinese press has reported the creation of a girls association opposed to traditional Chinese marriage customs in Hupeh Province, thus indirectly pointing to the persistence of the old traditions in rural areas.

title: CYANIDE GUN DUE FOR COYOTE TEST
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 19The Environmental Protection Agency and the Texas Department of Agriculture reached agreement here this week to start an experimental predator control program permitting the use of the previously banned M44 cyanide gun in combating coyotes,

title: May the World Rest in Peace
description: SAN FRANCISCOSoaked with gasoline, the young Czechoslovak struck a match. Jan Palach became a torch that day, a frail figure of burning flesh in Wenceslaus Square. He had written that he would die to move his conquered countrymen from the edge of hopelessness. The hope sparked by his protest flashed through Russianoccupied Czechoslovakia. His funeral procession would bring half a million resolute citizens into the streets of Prague. On Jan. 20, 1969, three excruciating days after the immolation in Wenceslaus Square, Jan Palach died.

title: W.F.L. Mobilizes for Contract War With College Draft Tuesday
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19The fledgling World Football League will begin building its 12 club rosters Tuesday in New York with its first collegiate player draft, beating the established National Foot ball League by nearly a week.

title: The Suez Pact: Where They're Going to Move
The Backbone Of Bolivia: The Cholas Who Mind The Store
description: YOU see them everywhere in La Paz, their jaunty bowler hats with brims upturned and their cheeks burned, a reddish gold by the sun of: the Andes. You see them scampering nimbly through the crowded streets of the Bolivian capital, bowed double by the weight of their merchandise or bouncing their blanketswaddled babies on their backs. You see them seated on the pavement selling candy and Chiclets or eternally embroidering  stitch, stitch, stitch. You see them in the markets of the town, vending meat, fruit and vegetables or sweaters and ponchos of tine llama and alpaca.

title: Hamilton Six Wins, 32
description: CLINTON, N. Y., Jan. 19 (AP)Keith O'Brien picked up a loose puck and scored the deciding goal today as Hamilton defeated Colby, 32, In hockey.

title: Johnny Miller's Lead Falls to 2 Shots
Notre Dame Beats U.C.L.A. in Last 29 Seconds, Ending Streak at 88 Clay's Shot Wins, 7170, as Irish Rally From 11 Point Deficit With 3 :32 to Go
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 19U.C.L.A.'s record 88game basketball winning streak came to an end today on the same court where the Bruins had last lost three years ago.

title: A Richard Etched In Steel, and Just as Cold
description: FROM Britain to Brooklyn has come the Royal Shakespeare Company, opening a substantial visiting season with John Barton's staging of Richard II. Mr. Barton's production is a scholar's dream. Unfortunately, a scholar's dream can become an audience's slumber.

title: Renting Starts After Uproar on Height
description: The rental program began this weekend for a luxury apartment ,house that was built.to the anger of many in the community and to the subsequent grief of the builderthree stories higher than it was entitled to go.

title: The First Step is Taken in Mideast, But Now What?
description: Either because they wanted and needed to separate their forces, or because they were pressured to do so by the superpowers, Egypt and Israel have agreed to disengage their tangled troops along the Suez Canal.

title: Morris Park Unit Offering Firewood
description: MORRISTOWNUntil further notice, the Morris County Park Commission is offering free firewood every third Saturday of the month. The first pickup day was yesterday.

title: Cathy Anne Stuckey, Mark Johnson Wed
description: LIVINGSTON, N.J., Jan. 19  Cathy Anne Stuckey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Stuckey Jr. of Dallas, was married here this afternoon to Mark Edward Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Johnson of Larchmont, N. Y. The Rev. William Kennedy performed the ceremony in St. Philomena's Roman Catholic Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Charles Dietz, a Lutheran minister.

title: Grandmasters Of Chess By Harold C. Schonberg. Illustrated. 317 pp. Philadelphia and New York: J. B. Lippincott Company $10.
description: In the months since the impalpable Fischer Spassky match for the chess championship of the world, which took place in the stark and woodless city of Reykjavik, there has been a torrent of articles, essays and books published about chess. Not since Edgar Allan Poe debunked Maelzel's chess automaton in the Southern Literary Messenger of April, 1836, however, has the game attracted such literary figures.

title: Evelyn Silver Plans June Wedding
description: LONG BEACH, L.I., Jan. 19 Miss Evelyn M. Silver, a premedical student at the Yeshiva University Stern College for Women, and Lawrence Kraut, a premedical student at Yeshiva, plan to be married inlune.

title: Tales of two cities
description: One brilliant, one dull, both fascinating. Fascinating because FlorenCe and Venice are among the great cities of the world, not merely physically, beautiful as they both are, but because for century after century their contribution to the arts and sciences of life has been quite remarkable. They were also creative cities in politics. Florence was far more experimental than Venice, forced as she was to adapt to those powerful external political forcesempire and papacy  which Venice managed to keep just at arm's length and so preserve for century after century a most remarkable oligarchy: remarkable because of the intricate checks and balances which preserved some liberty, allowed considerable participation in politics, kept corrupton within tolerable limits and created stability.Fascinating and spectacular as the story of Venice is, it has not been well served by its historians. Certainly aspects of Venetian historyits economic growth, its diplomatic skill, its involvement in the Crusades, its wars against the Turks, its treatment of poverty and certainly its architecture and artistic contribution have fascinated great scholars and produced exciting monographs, but there are scarcely any good onevolume histories of Venice. Frederic Lane's book will help to fill that gap.Prof. Lane is a careful scholar, deeply versed in Venetian history. He covers most comprehensively the story of Venice's rise from the mud flats and timber bUildings in the Lagoon to imperial greatness. He mentions Bellini, Carpaccio, Giorgione, Titian, Aretino. Guardi, Canaletto and the rest in a brief informative sentence or two. But, frankly, it is all very dull; a factually informative textbook which never bursts into life, never conjure; out of the past the flavor of Venetian life and culture.

title: The World/continued In Summary
description: Why they announced a merger in the first place is a mystery; Libya and Tunisia had little in common and the obstacles appeared formidable. Now, just as mysteriously, formation of the Islamic Arab Republic has been put off indefinitely.

title: AMERICANS ABROAD GET SECURITY DATA
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 19 (Al')  American businessmen in foreign countries are getting instructions on how to protect themselves and their families from terrorists and how to behave if kidnapped.

title: 2 Australians Pace State Indoor Tennis
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 19 John James and Mike Phillips, touring Australians, led the field into the third round of the New York State men's indoor tennis championship today at the Cove Racquet Club.

title: January Wind
description: There are a hundred different voices in the January wind. It can bellow, it can shout, it can scream, it can whisper. It can rip and tear and with one scream darken a thousand homes. You hear it roaring through the leafless maples, murmuring through the pines on a hillside. Of an evening, you may hear it whistling down the chimney, to set the hearthfire to dancing. On a mild and sunny day you may even find it dawdling in a sheltered spot at the foot of a hill, gentle as April. More often it prowls the lonely darkness of night and mutters of ice and snow and deepfrozen ponds.

title: The discovery of America
Congress Wilt Face 2 Key Issues Today
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20The 93d Congress begins its second session tomorrow beset by two problems left over from its last one  the possible impeachment of president NiXon and the energy shortage.

title: The Taxes on Oil
description: In his radio address on the oil shortage, President Nixon pledged to do everything in my power to prevent the big oil companies and other major energy producers from making an unconscionable profit out of this crisis. But the steps he is proposing are more in the nature window dressing than the longoverdue reform of the taxation of the oil industry's domestic and foreign earnings.

title: Bel Canto's Pure Sound By Caballe
description: Montserrat Caballe's virtues are so palpable that one almost hates to hint at her faults. Her soprano, heard in recital at Carnegie Hall yesterday, is distinguished above all by its simple beauty of sound, delicately veiled with a vaguely chesty color but always clear and pure, at least in the tessitura and dynamic range to which she normally confines herself. It is also spectacularly even from register to register. For sheer sound, her rice would be hard to surpass in the world today.

title: 7 Correction Appointees Face Albany Questioning
description: ALBANY, Jan. 20State Senator John J. Marchi, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, will ask the seven appointees to the State Correction Commission to appear before the committee before their appointments are confirmed.

title: SCOTT DECLARES WATERGATE DATA CAN CLEAR NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20Senator Hugh Scott said today that he had information that would clear President Nixon of any wrongdoing in some aspects of the Watergate scandals.

title: STADIUM'S FUTURE APPEARS BRIGHTER
description: ALBANY, Jan. 20State officials insisted today that New Jersey's successful sale of bonds to finance the Meadowlands sports complex would not jeopardize former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's threemonth, old plan to build an 80,000seat stadium and two race tracks on a 300acre site in Sunnyside,, Queens.

title: Democrats Elbowing For No. 2 State Post
description: While most of the attention has been focused on the Democratic gubernatorial and Senate candidates, a half dozen or more Democrats have been playing host at receptions for politicians around the state, sending favorable newspaper clippings to county leaders and making it clear that they are interested in running for Lieutenant Governor or Attorney General. Controller Arthur Levitt, the only Democrat in the state administration now, is unchalleneged for renomination to the remaining spot on the Democratic ticket.

title: Hayes Sparks Bullet Victory
Pop Music: A Medallion, Too, for Ella Fitzgerald
description: Ella Fitzgerald had quite an evening Friday at Avery Fisher Hall. She was greeted by an audience that filled both the hall and all available Space on the stage. When her drummer was delayed getting to the hall, an emergency call went out for a substitute, and she wound up with two drummers. And, to cap the affair, she was given the Lincoln Center Medallion, the first pop singer and the first woman to receive the award, which had previously been bestowed on Dmitri Shostakovich and Andres Segovia.

title: Soviet Claims Lead Over U.S. in Output
description: The Soviet Union has announced that. in 1973 it became world's leading producer of chemical fertilizer, surpassing the United States for the first time.

title: William Brayer, Executive Of Cone Mills, Dies at 74
description: William H. Brayer, who re tired in 1964 as executive vice president of Cone Mills, textile manufacturer, died Friday in Clearwater, Fla. He was 74 years old and lived at 70 East 10th Street.

description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on the Status of Women  10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Reform in Albany...
description: The pressure for reform at all levels of government that has been mounting throughout the country in the wake of Watergate has had some impact on the State Legislature in Albany this yearbut not much. Despite Assembly Speaker Perry Duryea's warning that we are learning the bitter lessons of government too closely held, New York legislators have shown a persisting reluctance to open up their proceedings to public scrutiny, especially in the Assembly.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Jan. 21In a final devastating attack with MIG's and ground troops, the Chinese apparently wrested complete control of the disputed Paracel Islands from a small and lightly armed South Vietnamese force yesterday, according to reports from the Saigon military command.

description: uick thinking and total professionalism were responsible for an unscheduled debut in American. Ballet Theater's production of Divertissements From Napoli on Saturday afternoon at the City Center.

title: Stage of Music Hall Is Turned Into Rink For Festival on Ice
description: Like a dream of Music Hall stage shows, the International Ice Revue Festival on Ice swept into town Friday at the Radio City Music Hall. Under a new policy of special attractions during certain periods of each year, selecting Festival on Ice as the first event was a stroke of genius. The stage has been turned into a vast rink, and the grand old Music Hall is the perfect setting for this spectacle, the handclapping, singalong happiest ice show

title: Skylab Stabilizing Device Continues to Slow Down
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) Flight controllers puzzled over a continually faltering stabilization device aboard Skylab 3 today.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: Residents Say No to Idea Of Breaking Up the City
description: New Yorkers overwhelmingly reject the idea that their city is ungovernable and should be broken up, although those who live in the four outer boroughs very much resent what they believe to be the domination of Manhattan.

title: Halfway Houses for Former Mental Patients Create Serious Problems for City's Residential Communities
description: Halfway houses for discharged mental patients have become serious threats to residential communities in the city, and some officials say they are More menacing than the welfare hotels.

title: New Oil Refineries Sought
description: BOSTON, Jan. 20 (AP)Representative Michael J. Harrington, Democrat of Massachusetts, said today that he would introduce a bill tomorrow to finance publicly the construction of at least seven oil refineries.

title: Boat Show Figures Sink, Spirits Buoyant
description: Both attendance and sales dropped this year at the 64th National Boat Show. The show closed yesterday at the New York Coliseum after nineday run for the public and two days for the trade.

title: M. L. Edelman Weds Alice Chasan
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 20 Miss Alice G. Chasan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Chasan of Jersey City and Deal, was married here at noon today to Matthew L. Edelman. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham H. Edelman of New York and Newtown, Conn.

title: Personal Finance: Joint Return Tax Liability
description: A Federal Court judge in Alabama, in a landmark decision that may help American women everywhere, has ruled that a housewife is not automatically liable for Federal income taxes simply be cause she signs a joint tax return.

title: About Cleaning Ladies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20A clean ing lady comes into my office every evening, empties the wastebasket, wipes out an ashtray, makes a pass at some dust with a rag and is gone.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Centenary defeated Lamar Tech, 8365, Saturday night in Beaumont, Tex. There were about 3,000 people at the game, no national television or publicity. Hardly anyone cared about the outcome except for the student bodies of the schools and some people in Shreveport, La., and Beaumont.

title: Needed: A National Food Policy
description: Our country desperately needs national food policy. The United States today is dangerously short of food. What is worse, we are dangerously short even of farmers. We are dangerously short of farming capacityof machinery and breeding stock and production supplies. We are dangerously short, above all, of morale among our farm people. All this portends that our danger will grow worse unless we correct its cause.

title: RESPONSE FOUND TO CONSUMERISM
description: A study of 149 major American companies with fulltime consumer affairs departments concludes that these departments represent a positive approach to the same forces giving rise to the consumerism movement.

title: About New York
description: The actor on the platform was talking about himself, and saying yes, there was some problem with the movie, and that it had been bind on one book, and that other books, of course, would tell it differently. I think the movie is slanted for the,purpose of being dramatic, the actor said.

title: Sandman Debt at Issue
description: New Jersey Republican officials said there was no Agreement for the party to assume the $316,000 debt of last year's unsuccessful gubernatorial campaign of Representative Charles W. sandman Jr. Details, Page 31.

title: ISRAEL Will BEGIN PULLBACK FRIDAY
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 20Israel will start to pull back her troops from the western bank of the Suez Canal on Friday, It was announced today by Lieut. Gen. David Elazar, the Israeli chief of staff,

title: Article 3  No Title
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 20Notre Dame's basketball team had an unusally strong belief in its ability to beat the University of California, Los Angeles, yesterday. It carried the Irish to the stunning 7170 victory over the Bruins and snapped their record 88game, threeyear winning streak.

title: Books of The Times
description: PLAIN SPEAKING An Oral Biography of Marry S. Truman. By Merle Miller. 448 pages. Berkley/Putnam. $8.95.

title: Shanker Drops Bid to Bargain For 10,000 City School Aides
description: Albert Shanker, the head of the United Federation of Teachers, abandoned yesterday an effort to have his union represent the 10,000 New York publicschool aides now represented by a rival union.

title: Residents Say No to Idea Of Breaking Up the City
description: New Yorkers overwhelmingly reject the idea that their city is ungovernable and should be broken up, although those who live in the four outer boroughs very much resent what they believe to be the domination of Manhattan. Island, called the statement fair.

title: BOTH SIDES GIVEN U. S. ASSURANCES
description: LONDON, Jan. 20  The United States has given Israel and Egypt eight or nine unpublished statements amplifying the separation of forces agreement and the arms limitation accord already made known, a senior American official said tonight.

title: Nearby Horse Shows AT WESTON, CONN,
description: Children's Hunter ChampionshipChampion, Amy Weiss's Glinockvs Britas Bay, Points; reserve, the between Hans Richter's Gwyredd Ask Mt and Marie Debaney's Billy Blastoff, 6 each.

title: St. Peter's Bows, 9685
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 20 (AP)  Oscar Jackson scored 22 points to pace Duquesne to a 9685 basketball victory over St. Peter's of New Jersey today. Ken Markowski of St. Peter's led all scorers with 28.

title: John P. Shaw, Diplomat, Dead; Wrote a Basic SALT Document
description: BETHESDA, Md., Jan. 20 John P. Shaw, a diplomat who was a specialist on Soviet affairs and divisions in the international Communist movement, died today of a heart attack at his home here. He was 50 years old.

title: SCOTT DECLARES WATERGATE DATA CAN CLEAR NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20Senator Hugh Scott said today that he had information that would clear President Nixon of any wrongdoing in some aspects of the Watergate scaridals.

title: Cardinal Dedicates Ecumenic Window In Episcopal Church
description: Cardinal Cooke, making his first appearance in the pulpit of St. Thomas Episcopal Church as Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, blessed and dedicated yesterday a new stainedglass window containing a portrait of the late Pope John XXIII.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: After reading your Jan. 10 editorial Governor's NonMessage, I turned to another page for the complete text. This is a much appreciated luxury frequently available to your readers. Then, staying with the same issue read the Albany dispatch by Francis X. Clines and the comments entitled Birth of a Campaign, by Frank Lynn. These are good pieces and furnish picture substantially at variance with the editorial.

title: Slavery Just One Threat Facing Paraguay Tribe
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, Jan. 11In the jungles of eastern Paraguay a small Stone Age hunting tribe of Indians is facing a losing battle to preserve a primitive culture and way of life from the onslaught of the white man.

title: Bringing Peace to the Mideast
description: The defeatists position toward Israel that has been preached since 1967 by some radical elements is now, after the 1973 war, being defended in defiance of all logic. As one member of this group recently put it, Now, like Jeremiah, we can only mourn at how correct we were.

title: Hometown Hails Phelps
description: BEACON, N. Y., Jan. 20Mayor Robert Cahill will ask the city council tomorrow night for a resolution proclaiming Digger Phelps Week.

title: Nixon May Change Date Of Address to Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) President Nixon is expected to change the Jan. 29 date for his State of the Union Address to Congress because of a conflict with a Washington dinner honoring the returning members of Congress.

title: How Beckwith Was Cleared in Bomb Case
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan.Byron De La Beckwith's ideal Christian republic would have no Jews, Orientals or Negroes and would place very little trust in Roman Catholics.

title: FATAL KNIFING ON IRT IS LAID TO 3 YOUTHS
description: A 13yearold boy and two 15yearolds were arrested yesterday and charged with stabbing a 17yearold subway passenger to death Friday afternoon.

title: Fire Subdued in Oil Tanker Collision in Mississippi
description: PILOTTOWN, La., Jan. 20 (UPI)Firemen, using thousands of gallons of foam flown in from six states, subdued today a blaze on a wrecked oil tanker that blocked shipping near the mouth of the Mississippi River.

title: Mail Employes Plan To Protest Change In Work Schedules
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 20 (UPI)  Postal workers at the Jersey. City bulkmail facility, which sorts all incoming mail for New York City and parts of New. Jersey, plan to protest a planned change in their work schedule$ tomorrow.

title: Protesting Truckers Meet For a Drive to Washington
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 20 (AP)An estimated 75 independent truckers gathered tonight at two truck stops north of here and. prepared to drive into Washington tomorrow to protest fuel prices.

title: Energy Pinch Altering Families LifeStyles in City and Suburbs
description: Representative Peter A. Peyser's district runs along the Hudson River from the Bronx to MidWestchester, neatly spanning the gap between city and suburb.

title: 37 Gallons Possible as Monthly Gas Ration
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Eligible drivers in New York City and most of its nearby suburbs would probably receive about 37 gallons of gasoline a month, under present projections, if a contingency rationing plan is put into effect this summer, according to an official of the Federal Energy Office. Rations could vary from month to month, however, according to available supplies.

title: KISSINGER IS GIVEN SYRIAN PROPOSALS ON OPENING TALKS
Reprieved State Aide Pursues Consumer Justice
Essex Scores, 21067, National Junior College Record
description: Scoring over 100 points a game has been the rule this season for Essex County College. But the Newark, N. J., school reached that total in just the first half Saturday night in Newark, then outdid itself in the second half.

title: THEODORE B. RICHTER
description: Theodore B. Richter, an Assistant Commissioner of Public Works in the midforties and one of the oldest practicing lawyers here, died Friday in Doctors Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived at 2 East 86th Street. His office was at 100 West 72d Street.

title: A Director of Lane Bryant
description: George T. Palley, a corporate vice president and director of Lane Bryant, Inc., the diversified retail apparel and shoe chain, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 45 East 72d Street. He was 65 years old.

title: Off Broadway Is Struck By Equity Over Wages
description: The Actors Equity Association called a strike last night against the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers.

title: Speaking in Tongues Is Viewed By Psychologist as Learned
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19John P. Kildahl, a clinical psychologist and professor at New York Theological Seminary, said here today that the Pentecostal practice of speaking in tongues constituted learned behavior.

title: Mrs. King Wins From Chris Evert
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20 (AP)  The sellout crowd of 6,500 was half the story at the $50,000 San Francisco Virginia Slims tennis tournament, won by Mrs. Billie Jean King last night. More than 2,000 fans were turned away. I've waited 20 years to see crowds like this, Mrs. King said before Tier 76, 62 victory over Chris Evert in the final. It's all too beautiful.

title: Paris: First Retrospective for Wals
description: PARISI don't care hoot about the quarreling of the experts. I remain very small, wrote Wolfgang Schulze  better known as Wolssome 30 years ago. Smallness, as the retrospective (his first) devoted to Wols by the Paris Musee d'Art Moderne demonstrates, was to be his key to greatness.

title: Mental Effect of Abortion Called Mild
description: A study of the psychological effects of abortion, in which women undergoing abortions were compared before and after with women having babies, has shown that abortion is no more traumatic  and may be less so  than giving birth.

title: U.S.Thai Relations Expected to Survive C.I.A. Blow
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 20 The admitted interference of the Central Intelligence Agency in an internal Thai affair does not mean in the view of knowledgeable Western diplomats, that the C.I.A. has garroted itself with its own cloak in this country, but that it has at least pinked itself with its own dagger.

title: Nixon's New Majority Seems Shattered for Him and the G.O.P
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20At his second inauguration a year ago, President Nixon still enjoyed being compared with Franklin Delano Roosevelt as coalition builder, an architect of realignment in American politics.

title: Chesimard Jury Selection Evokes Varied Reactions
description: Mrs. Chesimard and Mr. Squire, who the police believe are members of the Black Liberation Army, will be tried in New Brunswick. Jury selection was switched to Morristown after efforts failed to empanel a jury in New Brunswick, the Middlesex County seat.

title: STUDY ASKS  CUT IN RESERVE FORCE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20The military Reserves could be trimmed by about onethird and still meet essential commitments, according to a study made public today by the Brookings. Institution.

title: Howard Ferguson, 78, Dies; Led Dance Masters Group
description: HORSEHEADS, N.Y., Jan. 20J. Howard Ferguson, national executive secretary of Dance Masters of America, Inc., died Friday in the Statler Hilton Hotel in New York where he was attending a meeting of the organization's advisory board. He was 78 years old and lived here.

title: SCHOOLS'
description: All of the city's 947 schools were scheduled to open this morningsome buildings still dirty, but most now warm enoughafter members of two custodial unions voted overwhelmingly yesterday to end the strikes that had virtually shut down the school system last week.

title: PANEL WILL STUDY HIGHER EDUCATION
description: The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching announced yesterday the formation of a permanent panel to examine higher education in the nation and help develop policies in the field.

title: West German Team Wins 3d Straight Bobsled Title
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 20 (AP)Wolfgang Zimmerer and Peter Utzschneider, two cool Bavarians who race with precision, led a West German sweep of the gold and silver medals today in the World TwoMan Bobsled Championships. They won their third straight title.

title: Music: New Ginastera
description: Although Alberto Ginastera is known here chiefly as a composer of three flashy operasDon Rodrigo, Bomarzo and Beatrix Cenci he also writes other kinds of music, and at Tully Hall on Friday night the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center offered the premiere of a new nonoperatic work.

title: Taiwan Warns Japan on Breaking Airline Accord
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 20Two years ago the Chinese Nationalist Government attempted to forestall Japanese recq nition of Peking by hinting that economic and cultural relations, could not be retained In the absence of diplomatic ties. The move was a rather transparent bluff, considering the intricate economic network binding Taiwan and Japan.

title: France Floats
description: In permitting the franc to float downward in foreignexchange markets, France has delivered what may prove to be a mortal wound to the snakethe band of European currencies joined together by governmentsupported exchange rates. Britain, Ireland and Italy had already dropped out of the snake, which required countries to hold their exchange rates within 2 per cent of agreed central rates. But the action of France, as Common Market monetary leader, is a far more devastating blow.

title: Better Trial Lawyers
description: Chief Justice Burger believes that at least onethird of the 375,000 lawyers in the country are not competent to argue a case in court. He urges basic revision in legal education and certification to establish more exacting standards for trial practice. A similarly low estimate of the caliber of many practitioners comes from Chief Judge Kaufman of the United States Court of Appeals for this busy circuit. He has appointed a committee of lawyers to examine the quality of representation in the Federal courts here and to recommend how to achieve greater effectiveness.

title: 2 Youths Rob Woman of $9 At Knifepoint in Depot
description: Two young men suspected of robbing a woman of $9 at knifepoint in the Port Authority Bus Terminal at 178th Street near the George Washington Bridge were quickly apprehended last night by two police officers, after a threeblock chase.

title: Sandman's Campaign Debt Still an Issue Within Party
China Controls Isles
description: Chinese jets and ground troops, in a powerful attack yesterday, apparently wrested control. of a small group of islands in the South China Sea from a lightly armed South Vietnamese force. Details, Page 2.

title: Catholic Bishops Bid Rhodesia Change Her Racist Policies
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 20 (Reuters)  Rhodesia's six Roman Catholic bishops as serted today that the Governtent must change its racist policies radically if there were to be any hope of permanent peace in the country.

title: Advertising: New Unit at Y.&.R.
description: All of you who were becoming concerned about Young & Rubicam because you haven't read a single important announcement from them for a full 11 days, can take heartconununiques are still being issued, and press briefings held, at 285 Madison Avenue.

title: Obsolete Divorce Laws Assailed at N.O.W. Conference Here
description: The women were mostly middleaged and middleclass, and they came to the Commodore Hotel over the weekend to talk about marriage and divorce. After two days of drama, debate and tears, it appeared that marriage had emerged as the loser.

title: NIXON BACKDATING ON PAPERS ALLEGED
description: Government investigators have been told by two lawyers for President Nixon that the lawyers backdated his VicePresidential papers to the National Archives in 1969, according to the current issue of Newsweek.

title: Program Is Set Up To Assist Victims Of Crimes in Bronx
description: A pilot program that seeks out victims of violent crime in the Bronx and assumes responsibility for getting them medical, financial and social aid has opened at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

title: Skeletons Still Rattling in Old State Capitol
description: ALBANY, Jan. 10To most people who see it for the first time, the State Capitol here is a gloomy, fortresslike building whose time has long since past  a little bizarre, certainly, but hardly the stuff of architectural controversy. The controversy is all across the street, at the South Mall.

title: Villeneuve Captures Snowmobile Title Race in Rain
description: EAGLE RIVER, Wis., Jan. 20Gilles Villeneuve, a professional racer who has no time now for recreational snowmobiling, won this sport's world championship today as soon as his engine began operating on all cylinders.

title: VANDALS DAMAGE BROOKLYN SCHOOL
description: A Brooklyn elementary school was heavily damaged over the weekend by vandalism that the police and Board of Education officials suggested was linked to the labor disputes that crippled the school system last week.

title: SIOUX IN DAKOTA VOTE TOMORROW
description: WOUNDED KNEE, S.D., Jan. 15  Before the midJanttary thaw this week, a foot of snow and belowzero temperatures covered the undulating prairies of the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, giving the traditional home of the Oglala Sioux a remarkable resemblance to Arctic tundra.

title: Pacific Northwest Mops Up
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 20 (UPI)Residents of the soggy Pacific Northwest mopped up today after almost a week of storms that took 15 lives and caused. more than $135million damage.

title: T.W.A., Yielding to State, Will Alter Misleading Ads
description: Trans World Airlines will revise its advertising about free movies, music and cocktails for coach passengers, among other things, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkovvitz said yesterday.

title: Warriors Give Celtics 10th Defeat
Tanaka's Explosive Trip
description: TOKYO, Jan. 20When Preon: Let me venture to say mier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan and his entourage left Jakarta for Tokyo Thursday morning, they had to slip away like cowboys who have been told by the sheriff to get out of town before sunup. With the city still dark, Mr. Tanaka's staff and accompanying Japanese newsmen were hustled from downtown Jakarta to the airport before the overnight curfew ended at 6 A.M. A little later, the Premier and his daughter, Makiko, were taken by helicopter to the airport from the Indonesian President's guesthouse, where they had teen kept while antiJapanese riots exploded across the Indonesian capital. News Analysis

title: Nindl Posts Sweep In 2Day Ski Meet
description: BURNSVILLE, Minn., Jan. 20 (AP)Hugo Nindl of.Austria won the slalom today completing a twoday sweep of the McDonald Cup at Buck Hill and moving into a commanding lead in the overall standing of the professional ski circuit. He has 145 points.

title: Mexican Copper Project Begins After Long Delay
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 20After three years of delays, work has at last begun on massive coppermining project at La Caridad in northern Mexico.

title: Russians in Peking Dispute China's Charge on Spies
description: PEKING, Jan. 20The five members of the Soviet Embassy who were expelled from China yesterday on charges of spying had been held incommunicado for four days, according to Soviet sources here.

title: Renee J. Brody Laurence Kahn Marry in Jersey
description: LIVINGSTON, N. J., Jan. 20Miss Renee Jan Brody, a candidate for a master's degree in fine arts at Columbia University, and Laurence Howard Kahn, a student at the Columbia Law School, were married here this afternoon.

title: 24 Die in Karachi Fire
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 20 (Reuters)At least 24 people were killed and 40 injured last night after a gasoline tanker truck collided with a bus and leaking fuel set fire to buildings nearby.

title: Executives Group Bids Nixon Work For Voting Reform
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20The Committee for Economic Development, expressing its deep concern about the erosion of public confidence in the democratic process, urged President Nixon today to reestablish the integrity of the PresidenItial office.

title: TAXEXEMPT LIST IS LONG THIS WEEK
London Housing Protest
description: LONDON, Jan. 20 (UPI)The police arrested 18 people today at a demonstration protesting London's housing shortage. The demonstration marked the end of a twoday occupation of Center Point, a 32story office building that has been empty since it was built in 1963.

title: BURNS BENNETT, 60, ALABAMA OFFICIAL
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 20 Burns Bennett, a newspaperman and public official, died early today of.a stroke. He was 60 years old.

title: French Floated the Franc to Save Gold
Educator and Catholic Activist Detained by the Brazilian Police
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Jan. 20 The political police have arrested a prominent Brazilian educator and Roman Catholic lay leader, church sources said today.

title: Kennecott Shows Sharp Profit Rise In Fourth Quarter
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation, the first major copper company to report on its performance in 1973, announced yesterday sharply higher income for the fourth quarter and the year.

title: Knicks Limp Back From Road Still Battling Injury Problems
Stage: Removalists From Australia

title: Jackson to GetJewish Award
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) The American Jewish Committee announced today that Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, would receive its Isaiah Award for Pursuit of Justice at a luncheon here Jan. 28. Mr. Jackson has been a leader in efforts on behalf of Soviet Jews and has been a strong supporter of Israel.

title: China Controls Isles
description: Chinese jets and ground troops, in a powerful attack yesterday, apparently wrested control of a small group of islands in the South China Sea from a lightly armed South Vietnamese force. Details, Page 2.

title: FASHION TALK
description: When the models came skipping down the runway in Geoffrey Beene's showroom the other day in sheer voile shirts with nothnig underneath, there weren't any audible gasps because, you know, fashion people are used to this sort of thing.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Beame yesterday appointed Robert A. Lowa Councilman from 1961 to 1969 and author of the city's airpolutioncontrol lawas Environmental Protection Administrator.

title: CHARLES B. FOELSCH, LUTHERAN PASTOR,82
description: The Rev. Dr. Charles B. Foelsch, pastor of Christ Luthem Church, 355 East 19th Street, since 1966, and earlier of Holy Trinity Church, Central Park West and 65th Street, died Saturday at the Cabrini Health Care Center. He was 82 years old and lived at 450 East 20th Street.

title: The Average American Househusband
description: What started the whole thing was my wife's orthopedic surgery. The result for her: seven weeks of plaster and crutches. For me: seven weeks in whichwith a little help from our friendsI kept house.

title: Slavery Just One Threat Facing Paraguay Tribe
Tokle Wins Ski Jumping At Bear Mt.
New Jersey Sports
description: HACKENSACK, Jan. 20You wouldn't believe the people who know about this school now, said Bob Fazio, a basketball star at Edward Williams College, a junior college affiliate of Fairleigh Dickinson University. They used to say, Edward what?'

title: U.S. Not Acting on Idea of Reprisals on Arabs
SHOP TALK
description: Gorgeous may be the word that best describes the jects in the new show at the Museum of Contemporary Craftsin the way that a circus can be gorgeous or panoplied procession or a box full of jewels.

title: Rzewski, Pianist,. Plays New Music By Tom Johnson
description: Tom Johnson is probably best known as the newmusic critic for The Village Voice. But he is also a composer, and he is nextbest known for a series of concerts over the last year devoted to his theatrical music either quietly theatrical, as in his Four Note Opera, or slyly I theatrical, as in his various efforts that involve theatrics in their performance.

title: Sales Up 60% Last Year At Sotheby ParkeBernet
description: Worldwide sales of Sotheby ParkeBernet in 1973 totaled $206.5million, the company has announced. This was a 60.3 per cent gain over 1972 sales, which totaled $128.8million.

title: Iraqi Press Unit Sees End to Embargo on Oil
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 20 (UPI)The Iraqi press agency said today that Arab oilproducing countries were expected to resume normal production of petroleum and to cancel their embargo on shipments to the United States in view of the EgyptianIsraeli disengagement accord.

title: LAURENCE E. YOUNG
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 20 Laurence E. Young, a retired hat buyer for R. H. Macy & Co. and a former treasurer of Young's Hat Company, died today in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 76 Years old and lived at 36 Iselin Terrace.

title: Music: Schoenberg, Ives Challenge
description: Arnold Schoenberg and Charles Ives, two of the greatest creators in modern music, were born in 1874, and Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, the Gregg Smith Singers gave the first concert we have had celebrating their centenary.

title: Patients a Problem
description: Halfway houses for discharged mental patients have become threats to some residential neighborhoods in the citymore menacing, some officials say, than welfare hotels. Details, Page 31.

title: The Daily News to Install SixPageWide Presses
description: The Daily News announced yesterday that it would install the country's first sixpagewide printing presses, in a prototype experiment designed to increase production by 50 per cent.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Centenary defeated Lamar Tech, 8365, Saturday night in Beaumont, Tex. There were about 3,000 people at the game, no national television or publicity. Hardly anyone cared about the outcome except for the student bodies of the schools and some people in Shreveport, La., and Beaumont.

title: The Children's Circus Warms Moscow Winter
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 20On gray winter weekends here when temperatures are well below freezing, the snow becomes too hard for a decent sled ride and the neighborhood ice patches are used for pickup hockey games by the bigger childrenthe best recourse for the small children of Moscow is an afternoon excursion to the circus.

title: France's Monetary Allies Will Not Float Currency
description: BRUSSELS, Jan, 20The European nations which had taken part in a joint float of their currencies along with France appeared determined to maintain their monetary ties despite the French decision yesterday to float the franc and drop out of tthe European Economic Community's monetary system.

title: 62 Freight Cars Derailed
description: CHILDRESS, Tex., Jan. 20 (AP)Sixtytwo cars of a BurlingtonNorthern freight train derailed near this northwest Texas town today and burned, the authorities said. No injuries I were reported.

title: STUDY ASKS  CUT IN RESERVE FORCE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20The military Reserves could be trimmed by about onethird and still meet essential commitments, according to a study made public today by the Brookings Institution.

title: Brazilian Scores State Tennis Upset
description: GLEN COVE, LI., Jan. 20 Roger Guedes, a 20yearold Brazilian studying engineering at Hampton Institute, upset firstseeded John James of Australia, 26, 63, 64, in the fourth round of the New York State men's indoor tennis championship today at the Cove Racquet Club.

title: Breitel's Move for Efficiency Is Praised
description: In what many court observers regard as a display of political acumen, Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel last week reached back to a proposal advanced 12 months ago and set up the post of state administrative judge. The Temporary commission on the New York State Court System had urged that an office of chief administrative judge be created by statute. It declared: There is no top in the New York judicial system from an administrative, management or leadership standpoint.

title: Hayes Sparks Bullet Victory
New Jersey Briefs
description: Fourteen members of the Safe Return Amnesty Committee were given summonses at Fort Dix after they entered the Army base to distribute leaflets asking exoneration of military deserters and resisters.

title: FOREIGN INVESTING HELD STRAIN ON U.S.
description: Foreign holdings in this country, Senator Stevenson reported, now stand at $15billion and care likely to double in the next 10 years. Japanese investors have acquired coal mines in West Virginia and have purchased a site for a steel mill in New York, he noted.

title: SCHOOLS, OPENING SCHEDULED TODAY AS 2 STRIKES END
description: All of the city's 947 schools were scheduled to open this morningsome buildings still dirty, but most now warm enoughafter members of two custodial unions voted overwhelmingly yesterday to end the strikes that had virtually shut down the school system last week.

title: GOING OUT Giude
description: PROPHETS AND LOSSES The loss of innocence in our time and in our country is the tie that binds the three next plays of Theater at St. Clement's into a cycle. Tonight at 7, the theater in the church of the same name at 423 West 46th Street (CI 67277) starts it off with a revival of Robert Sherwood's nineteenthirties drama The Petrified Forest, directed by Len Cariou, star of A Little Night Music. Although Petrified Forest has apparently been played often over the years, it does not seem to have been done in town by a professional group for some time, if you don't count the TV reruns of the Bette DavisHumphrey Bogart Leslie

title: Red Smith
description: When a white paper prepared by the police showed that in the lifetime of New York's Offtrack Betting Corporation there had been a 62 per cent increase in business for the illegal bookmakers that OTB was going to starve out, Hot Horse Howie Samuels's first reaction was to reject the whole report. Then he explained it his way. Then he seized upon one aspect of the report as proof that instead of helping the books, OTB had actually halved their business on horse racing, the only field where the two compete.

title: Ardsley Downs Ardsley
description: ARDSLEY ON HUDSON, N. Y., Jan. 20The Ardsley Curling Club No. 1 rink, skipped by Edward A. Brandt, won the fourth annual mixed bonspiei today at the Ardsley Country Club. The victors defeated Ardsley No. 2, skipped by Edward Doonan, 106.

title: Rebozo Bank and Gambling in Bahamas Attract Election Spending Investigators
ExClerk in Saigon Says Joint Chiefs Got Secret Reports
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif Jan. 20 (AP)Topsecret messages intended for Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker or other high civilian officials in Saigon were routinely passed on to the Joint Chiefs of Staff, says a man who worked as a document coordinator in South Vietnam.

title: Gunman at Delmonico's Shoots i And Robs Charity Aide at Dinner
description: A gunman invaded Delmonico's Hotel in midtown last night and robbed and shot the vice president of a philanthropic group that had just concluded its annual charity dinner.

title: Neureuther Triumphs in Cup Slalom
City Overcomes Queens
description: Greg McGill scored 15 points in the second half and led City College to a 7665 victory over Queens College yesterday at City's Mahoney Gymnasium. Eric Wray was high scorer for City with 17 points.

title: Bridge: Nancy Weichsers Team Leads In Grand National Qualifying
description: A famous name headed the standings after Saturday's play in the Grand National qualifying competition here, but appearances were deceptive. At the halfway mark, a Weichsel team topped 56 teams with a score of 91 victory points of a possible 120, but it was not led by Peter Weichsel, one of the country's finest players. On this occasion he was outdistanced by his talented wife, Nancy, who was teamed with Richard Khautin, Carl Lindenman and Keith Garber.

title: Concert
description: The Beethoven that Washington's National Symphony Orchestra emphasized in a program given over to that composer's music yesterday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall was the monumental sculptor, not the Romantic tone painter. In the Piano Concerto No. 3 in C minor, splendidly played by the soloist, Peter Frank!, the orchestra under Antal Dorati set the basic style and the pianist contributed graceful variations.

title: President of Broadcasters Opposes a Cut in Air Time
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP)  The National Association of Broadcasters has said that suggestion for broadcast stations to reduce their hours on the air to conserve energy would not be in the national interest.

title: Senate Report Urges U.S. to Spend More to Curb Malnutrition
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20The United States should spend far more than at present to prevent malnutrition in infants mothers, according to a Senate committee staff report published today. and

title: Whitehead and the CableTV Proposals
description: The White Housesponsored proposals for a new national cable television policy that were released last Wednesday were notable, if not remarkable, for the lack of political mischief, in the view of many concerned with the development of cable TV. The report, which advocated almost total freedom from Government control for television. by. wire, was product of an Administration that has been openly hostile to the news media and. that had organized strategies to intimidate the television networks and bring them into line.

title: TV: Moyers Examines Question of Impeachment
description: Bill Moyers Journal, switching this week to Tuesday evenings at 8 on the Public Broadcasting Service, has been expanded to an hour tonight as a special for a broad examination of The Question of Impeachment. Mr. Moyers, calmly but crisply, considers three questions: What is impeachment? What constitutes an impeachable offense? And is the 37th President of the United States a proper target for impeachment proceedings?

title: BYRNE RAISE GAINS APPROVAL IN 3 STEPS
description: TRENTON, Jan. 21 (AP) Governor Byrne said today that the Cost of Living Council had ruled that he could take the $15,000 raise voted him by the Legislature in three annual steps. The increases would still be well above Federal wage guidelines.

title: AN ISRAELI HERO ASSAILS SUPERIOR
description: TEV AVIV, Jan. 21The commander of the Israeli forces In the October war traded charges publicly today with the war's most popular hero.

title: EARNINGS DIP 15% At NORFOLK ROAD;N.&
Contractual Coexistence
description: The importance of these days to the peoples of the Middle East is not found in the details of military disengagement now taking place on the banks of the Suez Canal. What is significant is that Israel and its most powerful Arab neighbor have, for the first time, entered into a contract to coexist.

title: Big Board's Talks on Pacific Exchange Ties Fade
description: Talks between the New York Stock Exchange and the Pacific Stock Exchange on merging some of their facilities, initiated with high hopes nearly a year ago, have apparently faded away.

title: Lewis Strauss Dies; ExHead of A.E.C.
description: Rear Adm. Lewis L. Strauss U.S.N., retired, former chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, died yesterday of cancer at his home, Brandy Rock Farm, in Brandy Station, Va. He was 77 years old.

title: PROGRAM OF ARIAS BY JEROME TURECK
description: Jerome Tureck is a bassbaritone from Montana whose notquitefinished vocal technique suggests something caught uneasily between bass and baritone, rather than extending to include them both. His recital Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall did reveal an instrument that at its best (when he had time to set himself andconcentrate on the tone) sounded reasonably well focused and strong. But both the bottom and the top are still weak, and at less than full strength the voice can turn woolly and hollow.

title: Yonkers Target of Registration Drive
description: YONKERS, Jan. 21The National Urban League today announced that it would begin a voterregistration drive in Yonkers as part of a twoyear nationwide effort to encourage minority participation in elections.

title: MARINE MIDLAND CITES DROP IN NET
SEMINARY STRUCK OVER SUSPENSION
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 21All academic activity at Concordia Seminary of St. Louis was halted today by a student strike in protest over the suspension of the school's president, the Rev. Dr. John ff. Tietjen.

title: HEALTHAID BILLS PASSED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) Four health bills, including three authorizing a total of $533.2million, were overwhelmingly approved by the House today despite some objections by the Nixon Administration.

title: SQUABBLE OPENS SENATE SESSION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Twentysix minutes after the second session of the 93d Congress convened today with its members shaking hands and wishing each other a belated happy new year, the Senate began a partisan squabble over whether a committee should investigate a tax dispute that its newest member is having with the Internal Revenue Service.

title: CHILDREN'S SEATS IN CARS ASSAILED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Many car seats designed for young children are dangerously inadequate though they pass the Federal Government's safety standard, Consumers Union charged today.

title: Anesthesia in Infants Linked to Allergy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21Receiving general anesthesia during the first two of lifeing the first two years of life may be a factor in predisposing children to develop asthma or hay fever, a team of specialists told a medical meeting today.

title: 5 School Officials and Teacher Accused Here of Fund Misuse
description: Six men, including three who have served on Community School Board 5 in Harlem, were charged yesterday with using and attempting to use public funds in the schoolboard election campaign of three of the men.

title: Market Place: SIPC Study :Report Report Awaited
description: The word that troubled duPont Walston, Inc., was seeking to sell its assets to two or more stronger firms adds emphasis to the efforts of a task force that will suggest amendments to the Federal Securities Investor Protection Act.

title: 2 Inmates Who Told Story Of Scalding Put in Solitary
description: TRENTON, Jan. 21Two inmates at the Trenton State Prison who disclosed details of the scalding death of another prisoner were placed in solitary confinement today for violation of prison rules and regulations.

title: No ChildProof Packaging For Birth Control Pills
description: WASHINGTON,Jan. 21 (AP) The Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today that it had decided to exempt most manufacturers of birth control pills from putting their pills in childproof packages.

title: Rangers'
description: When the New York Rangers acquired Real Lemieux, a 29yearold forward, from the Los Angeles Kings on Nov. 20 along with Gilles Marotte, a defenseman, It was commonly understood that the Rangers were taking him on as trading bait. That's the way it turned out yesterday as Lemieux, scoreless this season, was traded again, this time to the Buffalo Sabres. Lemieux, whose strongest talent is in killing penalties, played 20 games for the Kings and eight for the Rangers. Assuming he sees active service with the Sabres, Lemieux becomes the first player in the National Hockey League this season to work for three teams.

title: 48% in Poll for lmpeachment If Nixon Is at Fault on Tapes
description: Close to a majority of Americans believe President Nixon should be impeached if he is found to have been negligent in taking care of the Watergate tapes, the Harris Survey reported yesterday, according to United Press International.

title: Greece Said to Arrest 10, Charging a Plot on Regime
description: ATHENS, Jan. 21Reliable sources said today that military authorities had rounded up 10 persons and accused them of trying to restore the deposed President George Papadopoulos.

title: Even When in a Hit, the Actor Usually Must Moonlight
description: Like most employed Off Broadway actors, Antony Tenuta was not happy about the Actors Equity strike against the producers but supported his union's demand for higher salaries. If only, he sighed wistfully during an interview yesterday before the new agreement was reached, some other solution could be found.

title: Rebel Students the Key to Thai Future
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 20 Are we choking on democracy? asked a lecturer at prestigious Chulalongkorn University recently. His answer was a qualified Yes and an appeal for moderation in student activism in Thailand.

title: GOAL OF MONOPOLY LAID TO MILK COOP
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) A court deposition from former official of the nation's largest dairy cooperative indicates that the concern sought to gain control of all milk supplies in the United States.

title: Showdown in Congress
description: The 93d Congress returns for its second session to face a more distasteful task than any Congress has confronted since the 40th wrestled with the fate of Andrew Johnson. The question of whether or not to oust the President of United States is bound to fix the climate on Capitol Hill for months to comeunless Mr. Nixon should suddenly decide to make his whole Administration inoperative. If the House Judiciry Committee votes out a bill of impeachmenta stronger probability with every unexplained minute of erased White House tapethat grim subject will dominate the session's agenda even though the legislative list includes major bills on energy, national health insurance, land use and the public financing of political campaigns.

title: Interest Rate Cat On Loans Insured By F.H.A. and V.A.
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 21The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, James T, Lynn, announced today steps by the Administration to enable more families to qualify for home ownership and to stimulate ho building.

title: McGuire Back With Recruiting Lesson
description: The official line was that Frank McGuire, the South Carolina coach, came to New York yesterday to help promote the ticket sales for his nationally ranked team's appearance in Thursday and Saturday night college basketball doubleheaders at Madison Square Garden. Southern California, also nationally ranked, Fordham, and Seton Hall are the other teams on the programs.

title: Levitt Assails Costs and Figures of State Job Unit and Asks New Loan Plan
description: ALBANY, Jan. 21A lengthy criticism of the state's Job Development Authority as an agency that overstated its accomplishments while incurring excessive costs in making loans to industry was issued today by State Controller Arthur Levitt.

title: KerrMcGee Bid Denied
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that it had denied authorization to the KerrMcGee Corporation for the deepwell disposal of radioactive wastes at its. Sequoyan Uranium Plant in Oklahoma.

title: 2 Trenton Prisoners Who Told Of Scalding Placed in Solitary
description: TRENTON, Jan. 21Two inmates at the Trenton State Prison who disclosed details of the scalding death of another prisoner were placed in solitary confinement today for violation of prison rules and regulations.

title: SILVER FUTURES
description: Following the rise in gold prices to a record high in London, the price of nearby March silver futures on the Commodity Exchange here jumped to a record of $3.90 6/10. The price was 10 cents an ounce above Friday's high point. The more distant contracts were even higher because of the carrying charges involved for the silver.

title: Cleanup Is a Main Subject As City's Schools Reopen
Business and Politics
description: In the matter of corrupt election practices, an attitude of everybody does it is as unacceptable an excuse for corporations as for politicians. That is the heart of report just issued by the Committee for Economic Development, which makes it clear that the system representative government as well as of free enterprise Is indeed being jeopardized by prostitution of the political process.

title: Bar Car for New Haven Line Is Shown
description: The first of 20 new bar cars for the New Haven division of the Penn Central was unveiled yesterday on a brief wellstocked run to New Rochelle, One or two of the cars, called cafe cars by the railroad, are expected to be in service by Feb. 1, and the rest by next spring.

title: Rating the Principals
description: Among the few educational issues on which there substantial agreement is the role of the principal in determining a school's quality. The proposal to evaluate the individual effectiveness of New York City's principals ought to receive wide support.

title: Solzhenitsyn Calls on Russians to Reject the Lie
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 21  Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn has asserted that the Soviet Union would benefit by allowing free discussion of the penal system abuses detailed in his controversial new book, The Gulag Archipelago, 19181956.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Striking warehousemen and porters ratified a new threeyear contract yesterday and ended their fiveday wildcat walkout at the Hunts Point Produce Market in the Bronx. The 1,600 members of Local 202 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters began returning to work noon. Supplies of fruit and vegetables began leaving the market by nightfall.

title: '73 ALCOA NET UP; QUARTER OFF 21%
description: The three leading aluminum companies had good news for their stockholders yesterday as each reported major gains in net income for 1973.

title: Restive Chinatown Ready for Its New Year
Byrne Is Defeated By Spassky Again; Trails by 2 Games
description: Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union took a twogame lead over Robert Byrne of the United States yesterday by winning the fourth game of their quarterfinals chess match in San Juan, P.R., one of four matches under way to determine who will challenge Bobby Fischer for the world championship next year.

title: FreightTrain, Fire Ruins Cotton Worth $1.7Million
description: CHILDRESS, Tex., Jan. 21 (UPI)Officials said today that 1$1.7million worth of cotton was destroyed by fire that swept through 62 cars of freight train that derailed on a curve in a canyon before dawn yesterday. There were no injuries to the fiveman crew.

title: Can you make money collecting rare plates?; Art Expert Reveals 8 Easy Secrets
description: NORTHBROOK litA successful art dealer in this Chicago suburb has announced a new, 8point way to start collecting rare porcelain plates with the potential of becoming heirlooms of the future with exceptionally high resale value.

title: Colt Feud On Aides Develops
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 21 (AP) Joe Thomas, general manager of the Baltimore Colts, dismissed two assistant coaches today and incurred the wrath of his head coach, Howard Schnellenberger.

title: Liguori Won't Chase Rabbits Again
description: Marty Liquori won't put his trust in rabbits this week, even if it means missing the first subfourminute Wanamaker Mile Friday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: They Find Children in Need And Ask Them to Join the Family
description: PIEDMONT, Calif. By 10:30 or 11 o'clock at night the house quiets down and, as the wind blows through the towering redwoods that shade the big Spanish house, Dorothy and Robert DeBolt ease finally into the peace and silence of being alone.

title: Supreme Court Rules Pregnant Teachers Cannot Be Forced to Take Long Leaves
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Public school systems cannot force female teachers to take maternity leave months before they expect to give birth, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: F.C.C. Satellite Ruling Is Challenged in Court
description: The Network Project, New Yorkbased watchdog organization, brought suit in Washington yesterday against the Federal Communications Commission, challenging its decision to permit construction of domestic communications satellite systems by some of the nation's largest communications and aerospace corporations.

title: Military Watergate?
description: The strange case of the admirals, the yeoman and the Kissinger files is beginning to appear as silly as the Watergate caperand perhaps as serious.

title: Bridge: Two Teams Tied for First In Grand National Qualifier
description: Two teams of topranked experts tied for first place in the Grand National qualifying contest played in Flushing, Queens, during the weekend. More important than winning, however, was qualifying for the knockout stages, which begin here Feb. 23.

title: SHORT INTEREST FALLS IN MONTH
SIMILARITY SEEN IN TWO DISEASES
description: MARCO ISLAND, Fla., Jan. 21A Seattle pathologist proposed today that hardening of the arteries might start in a manner similar to cancer, with a change in cells that causes them to grow into tumors.

title: EDMUND BLUNDEN, BRITISH POET, DIES
description: LONDON, Jan. 21Edmund Blunden, the poet and writer, died last night at his home near Sudbury, Suffolk. He was 77 years old.

title: DuPont Walston Failure
description: H. Ross Perot, the wiry Texas millionaire who has pumped almost $100million into Wall Street, apparently in a losing cause, was remonstrating with a visitor last March about his critics in the financial community.

title: State Banking Head Criticizes Bills That Patman Proposed
description: Harry W. Albright Jr.. New York State's Superintendent of Banks, in a major policy statement yesterday on the problems resulting from the growth of bank holding companies in New York and the rapid expansion of foreign banking in the United States criticized the bills on the subject now before Congress.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was
L, I. DEATH LAID TO CONVENIENCE
description: MINEOLA, LI., Jan. 21 The state said today it would prove that the alleged slaying of a terminally ill cancer patient by Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano at the Nassau County Medical Center was a murder of convenience.

title: New Jersey Sports,
description: Reggie Miller, a 6foot6inch forward for Pleasantville High School, is only a sophomore, but already is drawing the attention of college basketball coaches. He is part of young team with visions of capturing the first state championship for the school. Last season Pleasantville reached the Group 2 finals in the southern section.

title: Marathon Raises Outlays
description: The Marathon Oil Company expects to spend $265million this year for exploration and capital expansion, a 60 per cent increase in capital outlays compared with 1973, according to 1. C. Donnell 2d, chairman. The company will pursue new gas and oil reserves mostly in North America, Mr. Donnell said yesterday, but nearly $90million of the funds will be spent to modernize and expand refining facilities and crude oil and product transportation systems.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: Albert: A Biography of the Prince Consort, by Reginald Pound (Simon k Schuster, $10).

title: Superhenry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21Is there anything Henry Kissinger cannot do? Several things, according to his agent, Rollo Whipple, who is in charge of booking Mr. Kissinger around the world.

title: Lewis Strauss Dies; ExHead of A.E.C.
description: Rear Adm. Lewis L. Strauss, U.S.N., retired, former chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, died yesterday of cancer at his home, Brandy Rock Farm, in Brandy Station, Va. He was 77 years old.

title: TOP OILMEN TERM FUEL CRISIS REAL; SENATORS DUBIOUS
MOUNTAIN LION KILLS BOY, 8, ON A HIKE
description: ESPANOLA, N. M., Jan. 21 (UPI)A 50pound mountain lion killed and partly devoured an 8yearold boy yesterday on a hike with his younger stepbrother, the state police reported.

title: Six Hurt in Gas Explosion
description: WINDSOR, N. C., Jan. 21 (UPI)Six persons were hurt yesterday when a rural Pentecostal church was blown apart by an explosion of butane gas fumes, sheriff's officers reported.

title: Shultz Does Net Object to Paris Move, Noting Higher Oil Prices
Well, It Might Snow
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (UPI)The Montreal Expos have notified the Chicago Cubs that their scheduled 1974 National League opener has been postponed a day to Saturday, April 6 in Montreal, the Cubs announced today. The Expos gave no reason for the change, a Cub spokesman said. The game will be played on an open date later in the season.

title: Chess: A PreFischer Spassky Uses Fireworks to Pull Ahead
JAPANESE PREDICT ECONOMIC ORDEAL
description: TOKYO, Jan. 21  Finance Minister Takeo Fukuda warned Japan today to brace for year of ordeal in fighting Inflation and trying to reverse deep deficits in the balance of payments.

title: State of the Union Talk Is Pat Back to Jan. 30
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI)  President Nixon will deliver his State of the Union message to Congress the night of Jan. 30, the White House announced today.

title: Film: Absurdity of Ionesco's 'Rhinoceros' Is Reduced in Transition to Screen
description: "People who try to hang onto their individuality always come to a bad end," says Stanley (Gene Wilder) in the last act of "Rhinoceros," the American Film Theater's screen version of the Eugene Ionesco play that opened at selected theaters here yesterday.But do they always come to a bad end? Stanley, the hero of "Rhinoceros," is an unreliable mouthpiece in an unreliable metaphor so grossly overdirected by Tom O'Horgan that you might get the idea Mr. O'Horgan thought he was making a movie for an audience made up entirely of rhinoceroses instead of people.Stanley, the mild-mannered, virtually identity-less office clerk, has admittedly had a terrifying time. He finds himself the only human being in a world where everyone else, for various reasons, is electing to turn into a rhinoceros.His best friend John (Zero Mostel), a fastidious, prissy man who always carries a pocket mirror and an extra necktie, has transformed himself right in front of Stanley's eyes. At first it seemed only that John had a pesky virus. His voice sounded hoarse and he was irritable. Later there was no doubt what was happening when, between whimpers, John began to paw the floor, snort angrily and exclaim that he really didn't hate people, he was simply indifferent to them.Daisy (Karen Black), Stanley's girl, tries to hold out but she too eventually gives in to the call of the wild: she can't resist the tremendous energy emanating from all the rhinoceroses now charging through the streets of the town that, in Julian Barry's adaptation of Ionesco, is situated not in France but in "Anywhere, U.S.A." "Rhinoceros," which had a middling run on Broadway in 1961, is not ideal film material, being an example of the kind of theater of the absurd that should be played like old-time farce within a stylized, three-sided set or, perhaps, within no set at all. Even though the film never shows us any real rhinoceroses, the realism of the movie camera is undeniable. It reduces things absurd to the status of the merely silly.Mr. O'Horgan's direction has the effect of exposing all of the play's weaknesses and none of its merits. It is clumsily inventive and obtrusive. The same was true of his only other film, "Futz," though it was probably responsible for his huge stage successes, "Hair" and "Jesus Christ Superstar."Mr. Ionesco apparently wants us to see "Rhinoceros" as a parable about conformity and the contagion that could convert supposedly moral, rational people into the ecstatically mindless mobs that idolized Hitler as the last word in authority figures.The lesson is both very small and very fuzzy. It is so determinedly out of focus that one begins to wonder whether the playwright had any ideas in mind at all and, if he did, whether they work out the way he intended. Stanley talks in clichs about "humanity" and "standards" and is, at heart, quite as ignorant as the rhinoceros he disdains. He also has a lot less fun than they do. All of which adds up to a philosophical so-what.Mr. O'Horgan attempts to jazz up the film with music by Galt MacDermot ("Hair"), which is nice but superfluous, and with low comedy routines that he photographs in ways guaranteed to make them unfunny. The grace and continuity of a series of pratfalls are broken up into a lot of different, isolated shots. His feel for slapstick is as solemn as that of an archeologist photographing the individual bones of a dinosaur. For reasons best kept to himself the director also introduces into Ionesco a comparatively lyric dream sequence.Considering the material, and considering the obstacles they had to act around, through and over, the performers come off very well. Mr. Mostel, comparatively subdued, is extremely funny, whether he is outlining the regime Stanley is to follow to become a cultivated man, or whether he is slipping unaware into the early stages of rhinoceritis, munching the leaves of a potted plant.Mr. Wilder has an innate sweetness that neutralizes a lot of the dumbness of Stanley, a character called Berenger in the play but renamed in the movie, I suspect, to evoke unfairly the shade of the late great Stan Laurel. Miss Black, like Mr. Mostel, succesfully created a cartoon character out of pure flesh and blood, hers being a variation on Little Orphan Annie, though not so articulate."Rhinoceros" is the fourth in the American Film Theater's series of eight films based on stage plays. It may well be the least interesting.

title: Consumerism: Bailing by Cupful
description: Life as seen from the vantage point of a consumer protection official in the metropolitan region is a series of shady deals, cornercutting and downright illegality.
