And more and more, the state, city or county consumer offices  relatively recent arrivals on the governmental scene  as well as some Federal offices, are the places where putupon and frustrated consumers are finding a sympathetic ear and a willingness to act in their behalf.

title: Jersey Insurance Chief Orders Rate Cut for Autos in Car Pools
description: TRENTON, Jan. 21Commissioner James J. Sheeran of the State Department of Insurance ordered all automobile insurance companies in New Jersey today to reduce their rates by as much as 20 per cent for vehicles participating in car pools.

title: Plan for Oil Windfall Tax Seen Stirring Senate Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 The fight in the new session of Congress over taxing the prospective windfall profits of oil comnanies will get under way formally tomorrow with a Senate committee hearing aimed solely at discrediting legislation that is before both houses of Congress.

title: White House Staff Is Ordered To Report All Media Contacts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21The White Houte acknowledged today that all members of the White House staff had been told to report all contacts with the news media to the press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler.

title: BUS Strike in 43d Day
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 21 (UPI)  A strike by 350 drivers against Carolina Trailways entered its 43d day today, becoming the longest in the company's history. The drivers will vote this week on a new contract offer, but union leaders have recommended that the proposal be rejected.

title: The Press: Who Shall Edit It?
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21In the fall of 1972 The Miami Herald editorially criticized Pat L. Tornillo, the executive director of the Florida Classroom Teachers Association and a candidate for the State Legislature. Under date of Sept. 30, 1972, Mr. Tornillo wrote The Herald:

title: Books of The Times
description: When Timothy Crouse first rode on a Presidential campaign press bus, in New Hampshire in February, 1972, his assignment from his editors on Rolling Stone was to try to keep Hunter Thompson, the staff holy madman and the author of the bizarre Fear and Loathing on the Campaign Trail, out of trouble and to have bail money handy if he failed. Well, as we know by now, most of Mr. Thompson's delinquencies, as well as his reporting, take place inside his head, where they are readily accessible to his typewriter.

title: High Court Will Hear FreeSpeech Case Involving Kunstler
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21The Supreme Court agreed today to hear a free speech case involving pretrial publicity by a controversial lawyer but refused to review another in which a protest administrator was Onvicted for disturbing a Billy Graham rally.

title: AMERICANS REPORT, ON VIETNAM JAILS
description: Four Americans returning from a twoweek trip of inquiry to South Vietnam said here yesterday that contrary to what they had been told by the United States Ambassador in Saigon, South Vietnamese jails were full of political prisoners.

title: AllMale Jury Selected for Mackell Trial
description: An allmale jury was completed yesterday to decide the state's conspiracyandofficialmisconduct case against former District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens.

title: Transit Agency Asks Data On Tire Safety Defects
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) The Department of Transportation has proposed that tire and Motor vehicle equipment manufacturers should have to file reports of safety defects in their products.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP)The Interstate Commerce Commission today gave the nation's railroads permission to file for a 10 per cent Increase in the export rate for grain and grain products. The increase is subject to protest and to possible suspension. It would be effective Feb. 22 and would remain in effect for one year.

title: DuPont Walston Quitting The Securities Business
C.B.S. Junkets Program Stirs Industry
description: C.B.S. News did some muckraking in its own backyard on Sunday night's 60 Minutes program. Mike Wallace's report on press junketswhich named his own network, the Columbia Broadcasting System, as a giver of free trips to the press, and its leading anchorman, Walter Cronkite, as one who has accepted junkets in the pastreverberated within the company yesterday.

title: MOSCOW EJECTS A CHINESE ENVOY
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 21 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union, in apparent retaliation against China, today expelled a young Chinese diplomat accused of spying, foreign Communist sources said here.

title: Thoeni Finishes First in Giant Slalom
Going out Guide
description: VERSE Times change, forms change, outlooks change but change, and constancy, are old themes for poets, and youngsters in our city's high schools are still writing poetry.

title: Rockets Tomjanovich Keeps Knicks Alert
description: The Houston Rockets are still trying to sell pro basketball in football country and not having much success. They are the worst draw in the National Basketball Association with an average home attendance of 4,100.

title: Corporate Bond Prices Show Decline
Calloway Aids Pajama Game
description: The Pajama Game, which was scheduled to close after Sunday's matinee at the LuntFontanne Theater, will continue an indefinite run because of a $50,000 gift by Cab Calloway, the musician, who is one of the show's principals. The announcement was made Sunday by Richard Adler, the show's producer who wrote the music and lyrics.

title: Soviet Denounces China's Effort To Lure Tokyo as Oil Customer
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 21  Oil is the latest point of contention in the rivalry between the Soviet Union and China.

title: One Man Dead in Grenada A Demonstrations Intensify
description: ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, Jan. 21 (Reuters)One man died and several were injured as supporters of the government of Grenada clashed with antigovernment demonstrators in the dockside area of St. George's today.

title: MRS. MILDRED KURTZ
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 121Mrs. Mildred Kurtz, chairman of the Citizens League for Education About Nuclear Energy (CLEAN), died Saturday at Memorial Hospital in New York. She was 48 years old.

title: He Loved Action
description: WASHINGTONA year ago today Americans watching the nightly news broadcasts saw television commentators pick up the red emergency telephones and repeat the bulletin from Texas: Lyndon Baines Johnson, 36th President of the United States, was dead.

title: Prosecutor Is a Star in Trial of Doctor
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 21The spectators crowd into the Nassau County Courthouse for the rare case of a doctor accused of murdering a patient. And the drama is intensified because the District Attorney is trying his first case in 12 years.

title: Dartmouth to Try New Student Aid Plan
description: Dartmouth College announced yesterday a new approach to student loans designed to ease the increasingly heavy borrowing burden on students, especially those from middleincome families who rarely qualify for existing forms of financial aid.

title: Ross Corbit, ExPresident Of Hiram Walker, Dies at 74
description: DETROIT, Jan. 21Ross Corbit, president of Hiram Walker, Inc., from 1948 until his retirement in 1964, and a former vice president and director of the parent distilling organization, Hiram WalkerGooderham & Worts, Ltd., of Walkerville, Ontario, died here Saturday at the age of 74.

title: MOPAC COMPLETING A RECAPITALIZATION
description: Recapitalization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad has been completed with the issuance of new preferred and common stock, the Alleghany Corporation, the Missouri Pacific Railroad and the Mississippi River Corporation of St. Louis announced jointly yesterday.

title: Subway's Family Plan Has Delivery in Station
description: A pregnant young mother, her husband and their 2yearold son, struggled with the Brooklyn and Queens subway lines last night trying to get to a hospital in time, but they did not make it.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MIAMI, Jan. 21Whittaker Moppie, a 38foot Bertram, took first place in Saturday's Jockey ClubSea Talk ocean race. Sammy James, the driver, and Jack Stuteville, copilot, covered the 200mile course from Miami to the Florida Keys at an average speed of 72 miles an hour, beating Billy Martin of Clark Township, N. J., by 30 seconds.

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY
DuPont Walston Quitting The Securities Business
description: DuPont Walston, Inc., the Wall Street concern that operates the nation's second largest network of stockbrokerage offices, announced yesterday that it plans to quit the securities business.

title: Italians Campaign on Repeal of Divorce
description: ROME, Jan. 21Campaigning has begun for Italy's referendum on repeal of the threeyearold law permitting divorce.

title: I.Q. SCORES LINKED TO ENVIRONMENT
description: Findings in a study conducted by a University of Pennsylvania anthropologist indicate that United States white students score higher on intelligence tests than nonwhites because of environmental factors rather than genetics.

title: FINCH RULES OUT BID FOR OFFICE ON COAST
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 21 (UPI)Robert H. Finch, a former White House adviser, saying the Watergate scandal would obscure the issues, decided today against running for Governor or the United States, Senate. this year in California.

title: CARPI DENIES ALL; SAYS WITNESS LIED
description: TRENTON, Jan. 21  Colin C. Carpi, taking the witness stand in his own defense, testified in a crowded courtroom today that he had abolutely nothing to do with the murder of his estranged wife, Laura.

title: Help for Rape Victims
description: If you rape a woman and steal her television in New York, a writer in The Times Magazine observed two years ago, you may be punishedfor stealing the television set.

title: Radio
8 Quit Philadelphia Tennis. Angering Tourney Director
Adoptions of Vietnamese Children Can Be More Rapid Now
description: The adoption of Vietnamese childrena frustrating and tortuous process In the past is getting easier for Americans. Still far from simple, but easier.

title: UNIT OF GULF OIL
description: Venture Out in America, Inc., a subsidiary of the Gulf Oil Corporation, was disclosed yesterday as the purchaser of Ringling BrosBarnum and Bailey Combined Shows, Inc., from Mattel, Inc., of Hawthorne, Calif. News of the purchase was released on Dec. 18, 1973, and said the property, including Circus World Park in Orlando, Fla., ad been bought by a major unidentified United Stites industrial corporation.

title: Tanaka Bids Japan Learn From Criticism
description: TOKYO, Jan, 21  Premier Kakuei Tanaka, just back from a tumultuous tour through Southeast Asia, said today that he and his compatriots should give ear humbly to reasonable criticisms against Japan, correct what we should correct and improve our mutual relationships with a longrange perspective.

title: SUIT THREATENED ON SUBWAY NOISE
description: The transit police and Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx accused the Transit Authority yesterday of permitting an illegal din in the subways that matched the clamor of a closeup jackhammer. They announced a plan to file suit to compel reduction of the excessive noise if the authority has not started action to curb the racket and roar within 30 days.

title: Baboon Experiment Shows Alcohol Damages Liver, Even With Good Diet
ExAgnew Adviser Testifies He Made Anderson Payoffs
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 21 (AP)Jerome B. Wolff, onetime close associate of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, testified today that he had made cash kickbacks to Baltimore County's Executive, N. Dale Anderson, through an intermediary.

title: Wall St. Suffers a Blow but Not a Crisis
description: Rainswept Wall Street was trying yesterday to digest the news that mammoth (Wont Walston, Inc., an amalgam among amalgams, is seeking to get out of the securities business after having suffered losses of more than $10million in the last six months. At the very least, this represents a psychological blow to an industry that has been battered by a bear market, Congressional pressures for reform, rising costs and plummeting morale.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Florida Mining & Materials Corporation said yesterday it had signed a contract with the I. A. Jones Construction Company for construction of a 3million barrel cement mill representing total investment of approximately $35million. would be located near Brookville, Fla., on a company site and is expected to be operating in the latter part of 1075.

title: College Dormitory Burns
description: BOSTON, Jan. 21 (AP)A twoalarm fire in a dormitory of Chamberlayn Junior College forced 24 students to flee the building shortly after noon yesterday.

title: Notes on People
description: Adm. Hyman G. Rickover has married a Navy commander he met some months ago when he was a patient at Bethesda Naval Hospital and she was his nurse. The marriage, revealed yesterday by the bride's father, took place Saturday in a Chicago suburb. Twentyone of the couple's relatives were present for the ceremony in which Admiral Rickover, who Is 73 years old, married Comdr. Eleonore A. Bednowicz, who is 43.

title: XEROX EARNINGS CLIMB TO PEAKS
PRICE DROP SLIGHT
description: With investors apparently concerned about the state of the economy, prices dropped slightly on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market yesterday.

title: Rockets Hit Phnom Penh Again, Killing 2
Value of Dollar Climbs Deficit in Britain's Trade Is Massive
Sullivan Is Victor In Debut at Forum
description: John L. Sullivan of Olympia, Wash., kept his undefeated record intact tonight, stopping Dino Del Cid of Panama in the fifth round of a scheduled 10round middleweight fight at the Felt Forum.

title: Advertising: Help Not Wanted
description: Personnel agencies specializing in advertising people may not be all that pessimistic, but a check with major ad agencies makes it plain enough that this is no time for jobhunting.

title: Litsky Retains Post
description: Frank Litsky, an assistant sports editor of The New York Times, was reelected president of the Metropolitan Track and Field Writers Association yesterday. Also reelected was Jimmy Dunaway, the senior editor of Track and Field News, as secretarytreasurer.

title: NEW LINES URGED FOR CITY SERVICES
description: A suggestion for simplifying the maze of servicedistrict lines that confronts New Yorkersfor city departments such as police, sanitation, hospitals was offered yesterday by the State Charter Study Commission.

title: Carpi Denies Killing Wife; Accuses Witness of Lying
description: TRENTON, Jan. 21  Colin C. Carpi, taking the witness stand in his own defense, testified in a crowded courtroom today that he had abolutely nothing to do with the murder of his estranged wife, Laura.

title: Music: Flute and Harp Compatibility
description: The flute and the harp mix so congenially that the relative scarcity of concerts exploiting this combination seems curious, even granting that the repertory is not overloaded with substantial pieces. In their duo recital on Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall, Ingrid Dingfelder and Martine Geliot pointed up the essential compatibility of their instruments, though there were times when the compatibility of the instrumentalists was not quite so clear.

title: Islanders Glad to See Seals Again
Giants Are Seeking New Training Base
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 21 (AP)The New York Giants are tired of Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City and they're looking for another inseason training facility, General manager Andy Robustelli said today.

title: Beame Appoints 16 to Help In Keeping Businesses in City
description: Amid expressions of optimism over the city's economic future, a new administrationsponsored coalition of business, labor and civic leaders was formed by Mayor Beanie yesterday and charged with the task of keeping established businesses in, and attracting new business to, the city.

title: People in Sports: Parilli Hired To Coach Boston Club in W.F.L.
description: Vito (Babe) Parilli and Mike Giddings were named yesterday to head coaching jobs in the new World Football League. The 43yearold Panil, a pro quarterback for 16 years and assistant coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers for the last three seasons, will be the head coach of the Boston Bulls.

title: BRITAIN REPORTS BIG TRADE DEFICIT
description: LONDON, Jan. 21  Britain announced today another massive trade deficit for December and indicated that the sharply higher oil prices posted by the producer nations during and after the Middle East war were partly to blame.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In the downstairs room at Jimmy's restaurant yesterday, Henry Aaron sat at a small table with his bride, Billye, as the man from Magnavox addressed the news conference. We're happy to announce, the man said, a longterm, comprehensive association with Henry Aaron that will mean $1million to him over a period of the next five years.

title: Vanderbilt Trounces Tennessee
Wood, Field and Stream: On the Beach
description: Those who enjoy walking ocean beaches in winter may, says the American Littoral Society, add a new dimension to their pleasure.

title: HIGH COURT TO RULE IN CLAIMS ON PENNSY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan.21 (UPI) The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad must pay set off claims when it sues to collect back debts outside the bankruptcy court in Philadelphia.

title: Stars Top Cougars On Wise's Basket
City Taxi Panel Chief Sworn on 2d Attempt
description: In a private ceremony in his City Hall office, Mayor Beame yesterday swore in Moses L. Kove as chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commissionfor the second time. The first time, on New Year's Day, proved not to be legal.

title: Pentagon Halts Inquiry Into Military Spying
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (Reuters)The Pentagon said today it had temporarily halted its investigation of alleged military spying on the White House office of Henry A. Kissinger In 1971.

title: Experts Press for Solar Heating
description: The use of solar energy to heat and cool homes is much closer to reality than most people believe, a group of experts agreed here yesterday. But the development of large power stations that will distribute electricity generated directly from sunlight is decades away, they said.

title: SOUTUERN CO. PLANS $1.1BILLION OUTLAY
description: The Southern Company announced yesterday tentative approval for 1974 system construction budgets totaling more than $1.1billion. Directors also approved an increase of 1centashare in the quarterly dividend, lifting it from 33 cents a share each quarter over the last four quarters to 34 cents. The new dividend will be paid on March 6 to holders of record Feb. 4.

title: Rep. Bolling Faces Reform Plan Test
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Richard Walker Bolling once wrote that a political leader must be willing to accept less than 100 per cent, but if he is convinced 50 per cent will not solve the problem, he must have the courage to say so and to see his carefully nurtured legislative effort temporarily fail.

title: JAPANSES PREDICT ECONOMIC ORDEAL
description: TOKYO Jan. 21  Finance Minister Takeo Fukuda warned Japan today to brace for year of ordeal in fighting Inflation and trying to reverse deep deficits in the balance of payments.

title: Equity and Producers Agree to Submit Pay Dispute to Binding Arbitration
description: The dayold Off Broadway theater strike ended yesterday as Actors Equity Association and the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers agreed to submit their salary difference to binding arbitration.

title: TOP OILMEN TERM FUEL CRISIS REAL; SENATORS DUBIOUS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21Executives of the seven largest oil companies, representing half the sales of the United States petroleum industry, strove today to convince skeptical Senate investigators that the energy crisis is real and that they did not contrive it.

title: Shultz Does Not Object to Paris Moue, Noting Higher Oil Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz raised no objection today to France's decision to float the franc and let her exchange rate decline.

title: U.S. Weighs Establishing Indian Ocean Naval Base
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21The Defense Department is considering establishing a naval base in the Indian Ocean on the Britishheld island of Diego Garcia.

title: Resignation Talk Spreads As Congress Reconvenes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21The House Democratic leader, Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts, said today that President Nixon's resignation would be in the best interest of the nation economically.

title: A Silly Libretto but Noble Duets
description: One wonders ether Bizet's Pecheurs perles could hold the stage any more. Its silly libretto alone would throw an audience into convulsions. And there is a lot of inferior writing in the opera; the composer still was young and had not found himself. But there are some noble duets, and there is the Se crois entendre aria, familiar to so many of a certain generation through the Caruso recording.

title: About the Knicks:
description: Walt Frazier went from Phoenix, Ariz., where the team played Saturday night, to Southern Illinois University, where his college uniform number (52) was retired in ceremonies between halves of the game against Florida State last night. Frazier played on the 1967 Saluki team that won the National Invitation Tournament. After he had been selected as the N.I.T.'s most valuable player, he was signed by the Knicks as their No. 1 draft choice... Dick Barnett, the assistant coach, conducted practice yesterday in place of Red Holzman, who stayed home to nurse a cold... Henry Bibby, who missed four games with an ankle injury, should be ready to play against the Houston Rockets tonight.... Dean Meminger's thigh injury was still painful and he might not play... Willis Reed has an appointment tomorrow in Oklahoma City with Dr. Donald O'Donoghue, who performed surgery on his knee. Reed has been conditioning the knee at Grambling College.... Interest is mounting for a Dave DeBusschere Night here. The forward, who retires after this season, will be honored Feb. 1 in Detroit, his home town.

title: Brady's Maxim at Jockey Club: Study First, Change Cautiously
description: Nicholas Brady has been chairman of the Jockey Club for a week now, and no changes have been made in thoroughbred racing by that distinguished group. And the chances are that any change, when it does come, will be after much consideration on the part of the new chairman.

title: Baboon Experiment Shows Alcohol Damages Liver, Even With Good Diet
description: Two Mount Sinai Hospital doctors who fed baboons the equivalent of a fifth of liquor every day for up to four years have shown that cirrhosis and other liver damage results directly from the toxic effects of alcohol, not from a concurrent poor diet, as generations of medical students have been taught.

title: U.S. TO SHIFT RULES ON STERILIZATION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 The Government is about to publish regulations that would leave local officials with considerable latitude in decding to use Federal money to pay for sterilization operations in public clinics.

title: Gas Use Drops in Bay State
description: BOSTON, Jan. 21 (AP)Consumption of natural gas in Massachusetts has dropped 7 per cent so far this winter as a result of conservation efforts, the Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities reported today. Among conservation measures taken by gas companies are checklists for fuel saving mailed to customers and formulation of a statewide contingency plan for pooling of supplies.

title: ASSEMBLY PASSES AUTOAIRBAG BILL
description: ALBANY, Jan. 21The Assembly today passed and sent to the Senate a bill that would automatically reduce automobileinsurance premiums for cars equipped with air bags as soon as statistics show that the bags actually reduce passenger injuries.

title: Europeans Weigh Fate Of 7Nation Joint Float
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 21The finance ministers of five members of the European Economic Community decided tonight to keep their currencies in a joint float and improve consultations on monetary and economic policy.

title: Soccer Loop Puts Club in Washington
description: There will be more Diplomats in the nation's capital in 1974 and they will all operate out of Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION ROSE 1.8% IN WEEK
Resignation Talk Spreads As Congress Reconvenes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21The House Democratic leader, Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts, said today that President Nixon's resignation would be in the best interest of the nation economically.

title: Soccer Loop Puts Club in Washington
description: There will be more Diplomats in the ration's capital in 1974 and they will all operate out of Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.

title: Eli Goldston, Lawyer, Is Dead; Headed Eastern Gas and Fuel
description: BOSTON, Jan. 21Eli Goldston, chairman and chief executive officer of Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates, who was leading proponent of corporate responsibility for social welfare, died today, apparently of heart attack, at his Cambridge home. His age was 53.

title: 9 Seized in Oregon County
description: COQUILLE, Ore., Jan. 21 (UPI)Nine persons were arrested in this area within the last 48 hours and a large amount Of stolen guns and drugmaking factory were seized. Sheriff's deputies in Coos County said most of those arrested had been taken into custody on Federal warrants issued in other areas of the nation. Two dozen guns, most of them stolen, were confiscated, the sheriff's department announced.

title: Mrs. James Maher, 76, Sold O'Neill Letters for $16,000
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 21  Mrs. Beatrice Ashe Maher, widow of Vice Admiral James Maher, died yesterday in the Camelot convalescent home. She was 76 years old.

title: Senate Unit Bars Ann Klein Nomination By Governor Pending Full Finance Data
description: TRENTON, Jan. 21  Mrs. Ann Klein, Governor Byrne's nominee to be State Commissioner of Institutions and Agencies, missed her scheduled confirmation by the Senate today because she had not yet filed the complete financial disclosure required by the new administration.

title: EXCAMPAIGN AIDE MAY ADMIT GUILT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Herbert L. Porter, former scheduling director for the Committee for the Reelection of the President, waived today a formal indictment on a charge of lying to the F.B.I. and is apparently prepared to admit his guilt.

title: Beame Appoints 16 To Help Him Retain Businesses in City
description: Amid expressions of optimism over the city's economic future, a new administrationsponsored coalition of business, labor and civic leaders was formed by Mayor Beame yesterday and charged with the task of keeping established businesses in, and attracting new business to, the city.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An educational reform project to determine the necessary characteristics of an effective educational system from the perspective of New Jersey black, Spanish and white urban residents has been announced by Gustav Heningburg, president of the Greater Newark Urban Coalition. The project is being undertaken to assure an effective input into the courtordered process of determining what a thorough and efficient education means to urban youngsters and the most equitable means for financing it.

title: CONGRESSMEN GET MIDEAST BRIEFING
Sports News Briefs
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 21 (UPI)Johnny Miller, winner of the first three 1974 Professional Golfers Association tournaments, said he would pass up the Andy Williams tourney in San Diego this week and try to get rid of cold. Four in a row is nice and everything, he said yesterday after his victory in the Tucson open. But just like they say, if you don't have your health you don't have anything. Miller said he has now set his sights on the Masters.

title: EXCAMPAIGN AIDE MAY ADMIT GUILT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Herbert L. Porter, former scheduling director for the Committee for the Reelection of the President, waived today a formal indictment on charge of lying to the F.B.I. and is apparently prepared to admit his guilt.

title: CONGRESSMEN GET MIDEAST BRIEFING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 21 President Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger briefed congressional leaders today on Mr. Kissinger's 10day Middle East trip, including unpublished details that helped produce the EgyptianIgraeli agreement on separation of troops along the Suez Canal.

title: E. I. du Pont Expanding
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday that it would establish an energy and materials department. The new unit, to be headed by David K. Barnes as general manager, would be responsible for purchasing all raw materials, supplies, equipment and energy for the company worldwide, and for planning longterm procurement of energy and key raw materials.

title: Lively Partnership Of St. Louis Quartet Displayed in Debut
description: Taking advantage of the St. Louis Symphony's visit to New York, the St. Louis Quartet, staffed by the orchestra's principal string players, made its local debut late Sunday afternoon at the New School. It was an impressive introduction to the violinists Max Rabinovitsj and John Korman (concertmaster and associate concertmaster, respectively), Darrel Barnes, violist and John Sant'Ambrogio, cellist, and, more importantly, to the suberb ensemble they have forged in only three years together.

title: Mayor Names Kheel As Unpaid Adviser On Labor Relations
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday that Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator, would serve in a new unsalaried post as special adviser on labor relations.

title: Corruption at the Top Angers Indonesian Students
Consumerism: Bailing by Cupful
description: Life as seen from the vantage point of a consumer protection official in the metropolitan region is a series of shady deals, cornercutting and downright illegality. And more and more, the state, city or county consumer offices  relatively recent arrivals on the governmental scene  as well as some Federal offices, are the places where putupon and frustrated consumers are finding a sympathetic ear and a willingness to act in their behalf.

title: Blast Laid to Propane Tank
description: BOWIE, Md., Jan. 21 (AP)A leaky propane gas tank was blamed for an explosion yesterday that leveled a twostory house, caused an estimated $110,000 damage to surrounding houses and injured eight persons, the authorities said today.

title: Recalled Macaroni Dinners Are Traced to Eight States
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP)All Kraft macaroni and cheese dinners suspected of being tainted with food poisoning have been traced to eight states, the manufacturer and the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: Sale of Sports Complex Bonds Generating Moderate Interest
description: A spot check of brokers yesterday suggested that only Imoderate public interest had materialized for the bonds of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority in the wake of an underwriting agreement signed last Friday.

title: Carpi Denies Killing Wife; Accuses Witness of Lying
description: TRENTON, Jan. 21  Colin C. Carpi, taking the witness stand in his own defense, testified in a crowded courtroom today that he had abolutely nothing to do with the murder of his estranged wife, Laura.

title: City and Union Committee Accept Terms for 130,000
description: The city and the negotiating committee of the largest municipal union here accepted the recommendations yesterday or an impasse panel for a new threeyear contract covering employment conditions for 130,000 city employes.

title: RABBIT DEATHS STIR INQUIRY IN GEORGIA
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 21 (UPI)The Georgia Society for the prevention of Cruelty to Animals is investigating the deaths of 70 cottontail rabbits, found dead in their shipping crates at the Atlanta airport this weekend.

title: Bache &
description: Frank A. Digaetano, 52yearold vice chairman and chief financial and operations officer for Bache & Co., Inc., was named yesterday to additional responsibilities in a broadening of the brokerage house's top management structure.

title: People and Business
description: The energy crisis has brought no shortage of suggestions for the Middle East oil producers about how they should handle their wealth. Yesterday, David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, proposed that they might use a sizable part of the dollar funds they were now accumulating for development projects in their own areas.

title: Treasury Bills Rose At the Weekly Sale
DR. ANDREA. BEAUMONT
description: Dr. Andre A. Beaumont, professor emeritus of history at New York University, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 1075 Park Avenue and in Wilton, Conn.

title: Debate Over Change on Nuclear Strategy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Should the United States be able to fight a nuclear war as well as deter one? That question has been raised by Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger, as he tries to stir up a national debate on future American nuclear strategy.

title: Mrs. Bernard Musnik Dies; Headed Hunter Alumni Fund
description: Mrs. Edna Robinson Musnik, for many years vice president and director of the scholarship and welfare fund of the Hunter College Alumni Association, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. In 1928 she was married to Bernard Musnik, who is now president of Publicis Corporation, the New York branch of a leading French advertising agency, and of Regie International, Inc., another international advertising company. She lived at 103 East 84th Street.

title: U.S. Bids Court Fine Gasoline Stations Up to $15,000 a Day for Overcharges
description: Federal civil complaints were filed here yesterday seeking court injunctions and financial penalties against five gasoline stations accused of charging excessive prices.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am somewhat dismayed to read that many Americans are reluctant to accept the idea of impeachment because of its possible traumatic effect on the country. This seems to me shortsighted and potentially dangerous attitude.

title: NO SHORTAGE SEEN FOR 8CENT STAMPS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Post offices across the country are adequately stocked with 8cent stamps to meet customer needs during the twomonth delay in implementing the 10cent, firstclass letter rate, according to a spokesman for the United States Postal Service.

title: Summary of Actions Taken by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: PHOTOS OF COTTON TAKEN BY SKYLAB
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) The Skylab 3 astronauts photographed a Mississippi cotton patch today in an experimental effort to give farmers a better yield from each acre they plant.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Association of American Publishers has called upon the United States Government to voice its concern for the safety of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the dissident Soviet author, and to take all steps possible to obtain assurances from the Soviet Government that his freedom and personal safety, will be protected.

title: Snowstorm in Egypt
description: CAIRO, Jan. 21 (AP)The first snowstorm in Egypt in recent memory fell on Alexandria all day yesterday. The port was I closed to shipping by 45mileanhour winds and waves as high as 18 feet. MEMO

title: Jersey Mail Facility Disrupted in Dispute Over New Hours
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 21Activity at the giant Jersey City bulkmail facility virtually came to a halt here today amid a bitter dispute between United States Postal Service officials and the Metro Area Postal Union over changes in employe work schedules due to be implemented this week.

title: Tax Experts Call An Oil Profits Levy Unworkable Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22A bipartisan panel of tax experts told the Senate Finance Committee today that the plan to tax windfall profits of oil companies that is contained in the emergency energy bill is unworkable.

title: PROGRAM ON ADS REVISED BY F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission revamped today the program under which it makes big advertisers back up their claims, cutting down on the number of ads that will be questioned and reducing the amount of unfavorable publicity to which some companies have been subjected.

title: OIL PROFITS UP 46% ON 6% VOLUME RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22The seven largest oil companies operating in the United States increases their profits 46 per cent in the first nine months of 1973, at a time when their prices were rising sharply, although they sold only 6 per cent more of their products than the year before, a Senate hearing was told today.

title: RISE IN COSTS SEEN IN MORTGAGE MONEY
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 22  The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, Thomas R. Bomar, predicted today that there would be an adequate supply of mortgage money during 1974 but that it would be more expensive than in previous periods of adequate supply.

title: PREDICTION ON NIXON DENIED BY KISSINGER
description: The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday it had learned that Secretary of State Kissinger had told two highranking Israeli ministers he believed President Nixon would leave office within six months.

title: Repairs Will Close 72d79th St. Link Of Hodson Parkway
description: The Henry Hudson Parkway will be closed in both directions between 72d and 79th Streets for an indefinite period beginning at 10 A.M. today to permit experts to examine and correct newly discovered deterioration.

title: KISSINGER THINKS ARABS WILL LIFT OIL EMBARGO SOON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Secretary of State Kissinger said today that he expected an early end to the Arab oil embargo against the United States to result from his role in bringing about the agreement between Egypt and Israel on separating their forces near the Suez Canal.

title: AIDE SAYS NIXON IGNORES DEMANDS FOR RESIGNATION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22President Nixon is ignoring rising demands that he resign, is determined not to be consumed for another year by Watergate and fully intends to serve out the three years remaining in his term, Ronald L. Ziegler, his press secretary, said today.

title: SYRIA RELEASING JAILED AMERICAN
description: Secretary of State Kissinger announced in Washington yesterday that he had secured the release of Jonathan Bates, a 32yearold New York City resident who has been held in Syria for nearly two years on espionage charges.day as a gesture of good faith and that the action was welcomed by the United States.

title: Port City Is Model for Chilean Junta's Strict Society
Oil Crisis and Effort to Cut Rising Cost Among Factors
description: More than 80 airliners word more than $500million have been grounded by the na tion's airlines since the oil em ergency erupted according to survey by The New York Times

title: Island in Hudson Now a State Park
description: WATERFORD, N. Y., Jan. 22The state today officially took possession of Peobles Island, one of the largest islands in the Hudson River, as part of a longrange program to develop the islands and parts of the Hudson River line into a park system.

title: Books of The Times
description: FRAGMENTS OF THE CENTURY. A Social Autobiography, by Michael Harrington. 246 pages. Saturday Review PresalE.P. Dutton. $7.95.

title: D.A. Checking Creedmoor And Its Release of Patients
description: District Attorney Nicholas Ferraro of Queens has started an investigation of Creedmoor State Hospital and of the Queens residences in which mental patients are placed after being released from state

title: Indemnity On Padres Arranged
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (UPI)  The Washington group seeking to purchase the San Diego Padres National League franchise said today that it had arranged for indemnity against lawsuits arising from the proposed transfer.

title: Braves Top 76ers for 10 Out of 13
description: BUFFALO, Jan, 22 (UPI)Jim McMillian scored 16 of his gamehigh 32 points in the third quarter in leading the Buffalo Braves to a 119109 National Basketball Association victory over, the Philadelphia 76ers tonight.

title: Wilbur M. McFeely Dies at 64; Ex. Head of National Y.M.C.A.
description: JAMESBURG, N. J., Jan. 22 Wilbur M. McFeely, former chairman of the national board of the Young Men's Christian Associations, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home here. He was 64 years old.

title: 10% Increase in Corti Plantinffs Is Announced for Current rear
Advertising: AntiMemo Drive
Racing Chief's Salary Is Placed at $75,000
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22Among the many things accomplished in the 931page budget is the correction of what state officals say was a typographical error in a press release last summer that announced the salary of the chairman of the state's new Racing add Wagering Board as $65,000 a year.

title: Do Not Fold or Spindle
description: Following are excerpts from an exchange of correspondence between Caryl Louise Ambrose, who commutes between Mahopac, N. Y., and New York City, and officials in Washington.

title: BeameFindsImportant Strides in Alleviating Municipal Fiscal Ills
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22  Governor Wilson's 197475 budget, which offers New York City the promise of state masstransit subsidies but contains no unexpected giftsand in some cases actually costs the city moneyreceived an enthusiastic response today from Mayor Beame and his chief fiscal adviser.

title: Cedeno Expects Reaction
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 22 (AP)Cesar Cedeno said today he expected varied reaction from fans and players concerning his recent conviction on a charge of involuntary homicide in the shooting death of a young woman in the Dominican Republic.

title: Witness in Carpi Case Changes Testimony About Phone Calls
description: TRENTON, Jan. 22A witness who had testified for the state in the Colin C. Carpi murder trial changed her testimoney today when recalled by the defense.

title: Main Points of Governor Wilson's Proposed Budget
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22Following are the major parts of Governor Wilson's proposed budget for the fiscal year beginning April 1st

title: New York Chooses Boryla in First W.F.L. Draft
description: The ambitious World Football League held its first draft of college players here yesterday and the Memphis team, which lacks a name, made David Jaynes, the Kansas quarterback, the No. 1 selection.

title: Music: Bachauer Dazzle
description: When Gina Bachauer is playing at her best level, as she was on Monday night in Carnegie Hall as solist with the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, she can transform a routine concert into a stirring musical event. And when her performance happens to come, as it did on this occasion, at the conclusion of an already excellent program, the pianist can generate enough electricity to heat the hall for a week.

title: SULLIVAN REVIEWS RECORD IN OFFICE
description: TRENTON, Jan. 22  Describing himself as an available, unemployed bureaucrat without a job prospect, Richard J. Sullivan, the outgoing State Commissioner of Environmental Protection, listed today some of the key programs for which his administration could claim credit by the time he leaves office Feb. 1.

title: RODINO FEARS LAG OF YEAR IN INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee warned today that the inquiry into the impeachment of President Nixon could be delayed into 1975 if the Watergate special prosecutor did not turn over relevant grand jury evidence to the committee.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Donovan Construction Company, a subsidiary of Donovan Cos., Inc., said it had received a $23.8million contract from the Department of Defense to resume manufacture of 155 millimeter projectiles at the Twin Cities, Minn., Army Ammunition plant near New Brighton, Minn. Initial deliveries are scheduled for April.

title: Lover in Home Held No Bar to Welfare
description: TRENTON, Jan. 22The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the state could not reduce welfare payments to a mother and her child merely because the woman's household included her lover.

title: 6Million in Bids Made For Geothermal Tracts
Diabetic Girl, 10, Fails To Return to Her Home
description: A 10yearold, Bronx girl, described as a latent diabetic requiring a strict diet, was reported missing yes terday afternoon when she failed to return home from school.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: PROFIT SOARS 50% AT CITIES SERVICE
description: The Cities Service Company, the first large oil company to report 1973 profits, announced yesterday a 50 per cent leap in fourth quarterthe quarter in which the Arab oil embargo was declared and that prices rime sharply. Cities Service's gain was significantly larger than expected in the financial community.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Evelyn Lear Gets Marschallin Role

title: Briefs on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP)Retail gasoline prices rose an average of 4.4 per cent in Decdmber, the Bureau Labor Statistics reported today. The average price for regular jumped 4.6 per cent to 43.7 cents a gallon in December, while premium rose 4.1 per cent t6 47.3 cents. The Government said price increases of regular gasoline ranged from 2.6 per cent in Honoluluwhere the price was higher than in any of the nation's other 22 metropolitan areasto 6.7 per cent in Philadelphia. The rise in premium prices was smaller than for regular in most cities, with the increases ranging from 2.7 per cent in Cleveland and Honolulu to 5.9 per cent in Atlanta.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: CERAMICS Indians of the Americas have been working in ceramics for imply centuries, and much of what they have made is called blackware, logically enough because the items range in color from black through gray. They are bowls, jars, lamps, figures, miniatures, and they are being made down to this day, retaining much that is traditional yet giving evidence that what is old can also be modern.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP)  The United States enjoyed a $1.4billion surplus in its trade with Communist countries during the first nine months of 1973, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Eastern Airlines Reports Loss for 1973; Industry Grounds More Than 80 Planes
Leon Volkov of Newsweek Dies; Soviet Expert Defected in 1945
description: Leon Volkov, a Soviet Air Force pilot who defected in 1945 and for the last 20 years was Newsweek magazine's Soviet affairs specialist, died Monday at Suburban Hospital in Bethdesda, Md., after a heart attack. tie was 59 years old and resided in Bethesda.

title: Suburban Leaders See $100Million Deficit Forced on Them
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22  Representatives of the state's suburban counties and large upstate cities expressed varying degrees of disappointment, even condemnation, of the first budget of Governor Wilson.

title: Trading of Stock Resumed
description: The New York Stock Ex. change said yesterday that trading in common stock and Series A $1.70 cumulative convertible preferred stock of In terational Industries, Inc. would temporarily be resumed on a regular way basis to day. and would continue to hr traded on the exchange through March 15, 1974.

title: NAVY TAKES STEP ON ELK HILLS AREA
description: WANAINGTON, Jan. 22The Navy moved today to prevent the Standard Oil Company of California from draining oil from the onebillionbarrel Naval Petroleum Reserve in Elk Hills, Calif.

title: City Praises State Budget, County Chiefs Deplore It
Kent State Jury Sees Guard
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 22 (AP)Federal grand jurors talked today with members of an Ohio National Guard unit from which gunfire erupted when four Kent State University students were shot to death in 1970. It was not known whether any of the witnesses were among those who fired.

title: Soviet Says Peking And the West Unite To Exploit Gulag
description: MOSCOW, Wednesday Jan. 23The Soviet Writers Union charged today that Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's new book, The Gulag Archipelago, 19181956, had become a rallying point for China as well as neoFascist centers in the West.

title: Montemarano Plea For Autopsy Denied, Doctor's Trial Told
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 22  Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano requested an autopsy on the body of Eugene Bauer shortly after his death and was refused permission by the family, according to testimony elicited today at the murder trial of Dr. Montemarano.

title: SUEZ PACT SPLITS ARAB GUERRILLAS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 22The EgyptianIsraeli agreement on the separation of forces on the Suez front has. split the Palestinian guerrilla movement and led to a challenge to Yasir Arafat's leadership.According to Arab sources here, Mr. Arafat, who heads the Palestine Liberation Organization the overall guerrilla group, as well as Al Fatah, the largest commando organization, is trying to stop the growing hostility toward the accord from turning into a conflict between the Palestinians and the Egyptian Government.

title: Notre Dame Edges Kansas, 76 to 74
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Jan. 22 (UPI)  Notre Dame, rated No. 1 in college basketball, blew most of a 14point halftime lead tonight before holding on for a 7674 victcry over Kansas before a sellout crowd of 17,100.

title: A Fair Deal for Vietnam Veterans
description: WASHINGTONOne year ago today, President Nixon announced we had achieved peace with honor in Vietnam as a ceasefire agreement was reached. He called on us to be proud of the two and a half million young Americans who served in Vietnam. Later in his State of the Union message the President asserted: A grateful nation owes its servicemen and women every opportunity it can open to them when they return to civilian life. The nation may be weary of war, but we dare not grow weary of doing right by those who have borne its heaviest burdens.

title: Lawyers for Hughes Ask Court to Dismiss Charges
description: RENO, Nev., Jan. 22 (AP)Attorneys for Howard R. Hughes and two other men indicted in the Air West stock manipulation case filed a motion for dismissal of the charges today in Federal District Court.

title: KISSINGER THINKS ARABS WILL LIFT OIL EMBARGO SOON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Secretary of State Kissinger said today that he expected an early end to the Arab oil embargo against the United States to result from his role in bringing about the agreement between Egypt and Israel on separating their forces near the Suez Canal.

title: People in Sports: Phil Jackson's Push Is Costly ($1,000)
description: Phil Jackson, the 6foot8inch Knicks forward who pushed Earl Strom, a referee, after having been ejected from a game at Seattle on Jan. 11, was fined $1,000 yes. terday by Walter Kennedy, commissioner of the National Basketball Association.

title: 15c to 20c Increase Sought in Cab Fare
description: The city's licensed taxicab industry said yesterday that it was applying immediately for an interim increase of 15 or 20 cents a ride to offset a doubling in gasoline costs since March.

title: Consolidated Foods To Sell Subsidiary To CurticeBurns
description: The Consolidated Foods Corporation reached an agreement yesterday to sell its Michigan Fruit Canners, Inc., subsidiary to CurticeBurns, Inc., a Rochester food processor and canner. The transaction involves about $21.4million, of which $20.9million will be paid in cash with 42,000 shares of CurticeBurns class A common stock.

title: About New York
description: The antiques dealers are on Park Avenue, displaying antiques in the 20th annual show at the Seventh Regiment Armory. This year there are 59 dealers, and in a way they are more interesting than their antiques.

title: Ernest L. Nye, Trust Expert In RailEquipment Finance
description: RUMSON, N. J., Jan. 22Ernest Lewis Nye, a specialist in railroadequipment trust financing, died Saturday In Red Bank. He was 85 years old and lived here.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: The winning. New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Firecrackers Bring In The Year of the Tiger
description: Residents of Chinatown last night welcomed the Year of the Tiger, 4672, with at least as many firecrackers tossed by scores of youngsters who gathered in groups along Mott Street.

title: KungFu Boxers Beaten by Thais
description: BANGKOK, Thailand Jan. 22 (UPI)Thailand's kicking boxers knocked down Taiwan's kungfu boxers one by one in little more than five minutes last night to the dismay of 14,000 fans who packed the Hua Mark indoor stadium to witness the fights to the death.

title: City Pressing Its Inquiry On Caliber's Financing
description: The city's Department of Investigation is continuing an inquiry into possible campaignfund irregularities of State Senator Joseph L. Galiber despite the withdrawal of his pending appointment as Deputy Mayor nearly two weeks ago.

title: AIDE SAYS NIXON IGNORES DEMANDS FOR RESIGNATION
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22President Nixon is ignoring rising demands that he resign, is determined not to be consumed for another year by Watergate and fully intends to serve out the three years remaining in his term, Ronald L. Ziegler, his press secretary, said today.

title: New Methods Cut Risks in Heart Surgery for Babies
description: MARCO ISLAND, Fta., Jan. 22New methods of diagnosing and treating infants born with lifethreatening heart defects are saving babies who might otherwise have succumbed to the traumas of open heart surgery.

title: Fewer Veterans Jobless
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) The unemployment rate of Vietnam veterans declined in the fourth quarter of 1973 to its lowest level in three years, from. 5.1 per cent to 4.1 per cent, the Government reported today.

title: Notes on People
description: John H. Powell Jr., with President Nixon at his side, was sworn in yesterday as chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, succeeding William H. Brown 3d, whose term as a member and chairman expired last summer. The 42yearold Mr. Powell, whose term expires in 1978, had been general counsel of the Civil Rights Commission since 1970. He had been associated with civil rights organizations since the early nineteensixties.

title: Hijacked Colombian Airliner Lands in Cuba
description: HAVANA, Jan. 22 (Reuters) A Colombian domestic airliner, hijacked over Colombia yesteiday by a 25yearold leftist, landed here early today.

title: MESSAGE REROUTING DENIED BY PENTAGON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) Allegations that top secret messages to American officials in Saigon were improperly routed to the Joint Chiefs of Staff in Washington were de nied today by the Pentagon.

title: In Which the Loser Pays
description: PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 22 (AP) A total of $10 was spent by the five City Council candidates in last month's municipal election, according to campaign reports filed at City Hall. The money was all spent for printing costs by Popkins Aakarian, who lost.

title: Kawasaki Planning Production in U.S. Of Motorcycle Line
description: The Kawasaki Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it would go into the production and assembly of motorcycles in the United States, the first foreign manufacturer to do so.

title: Killebrew Signs At a Cut in Pay
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 22 (AP)Harmon Killebrew, fifth leading home run hitter in major league history, signed his 1974 contract with the Minnesota Twins today but took a reduction that will drop his salary below $100,000

title: California Officials Accused of Giving Nixon Favored Treatment on State Income Taxes
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22  California tax authorities were accused today by one of their own number of giving President Nixon favored treatment and of making no proper effort to collect state income Imes from the President.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: JAMES COLLIGAN, 70, TV PRODUCER, DEAD
description: James J. Colligan, a television producer, died Monday at his home, 509 East 85th Street. His age was 70.

title: ARTHUR PECK DIES
description: MANHASSET, LI., Jan. 22  Arthur Peck, who retired as director of the Columbia Broadcasting System's radio broadcasting operations in 1972, died yesterday at St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn. He was 66 years old and lived at 38 Beechwood Avenue here.

title: WILSON'S BUDGET OF $9.38BILLION STRESSES ECONOMY
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22Governor Wilson sent to the Legislature today an electionyear budget of $9.38billion that offered few major spending initiatives, provided little in additional tax relief and devoted most of a proposed $772million increase in spending to maintaining existing programs.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: FICTION

title: Suburban Leaders See $1 00Million Deficit Forced on Them
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22  Representatives of the state's suburban counties and large upstate cities expressed varying degrees of disappointment, even condemnation, of the first budget of Governor Wilson.

title: WAYNE D. M'MURRAY, ASBURY PARK EDITOR,
description: ASBURY PARK, N.J., Jan. 22Wayne D. McMurray, president and editor of The Asbury Park Press and also president of WJLK Radio, died today in Jersey Shore Medical Center, Neptune. He was 76 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Eleven of 13 harness drivers indicted on racefixing charges have appealed to the State Racing and Wagering Board for reinstatement pending the outcome of their trial. A spokesman for the Board said yesterday hearings would be held as soon as possible for the drivers, who have been suspended from all direct and indirect harnessracing activity.

title: Yonkers Council Rejects An Effort to Retain Scher
description: YONKERS, Jan. 22The Republican dominated City Council rejected a Democratic bid tonight to retain Dr. Seymour Scher as City Manager.

title: Energy Bill?...
description: The emergency energy bill, stalemated in Congress last month just before the adjournment of the first session and now pending in the Senate, reflects neither a coherent Administration strategy nor careful consideration by committees of the House and Senate.

title: News Summary and Index
Mail Union Defies Writ In Jersey City Walkout
description: JERSEY CITY Jan. 22The impasse between the United States Postal Service and the Metro Area Postal Union intensified today at the New York Bulk.and Foreign Mail Center here. as hundreds of workers, defying a Federal Court order, stayed away from their jobs to protest changes in their work schedules.

title: Time to Spook the Spooks?
description: MILAN, ItalyThe role of intelligence in modern societies is now increasingly questioned as the result of scandals, wiretappings, failures to evaluate correctly what special services report, or inexcusable political interventions like the recent C.I.A. case in Thailand.

title: Thais Fighting Insurgents At Point Near Laos Border
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 22 (AP)  Troops and policemen are fighting Communistled insurgents for control of a district in northeastern Thailand near the Laotian border, the Government Defense Minister said today

title: The History Lesson
description: LOCUST VALLEY, N. Y.The new boy did his best to avoid attention, as new boys generally do. He arrived one day at my sixthgrade classroom in the Green Street School in Brattleboro, Vt., and silently took a seat in the very back row, in the corner next to the window.

title: ... or Dirty Air Bill?
description: The pending energy bill permits the postponement of strict auto emission standards for yet another year. Because of the controversy among Detroit's big three automobile manufacturers about catalytic converters to control those emissions, much publicity has naturally focused on this part of the bill.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Commission on the Status of Women A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Cost Crisis in Oil Developing in Japan
KICKBACK DESCRIBED AT BALTIMORE TRIAL
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 22 (AP)Jerome B. Wolff testified today that N. Dale Anderson, the Baltimore County Executive, told him he would have to kick back money for county contracts in advance or not get the work.

title: Southern Line Gains
description: The Southern Railway, which in 1972 was the second most profitable railroad system in the country  after the Union Pacific  reported yesterday that its net income in 1973 increased 13.1 per cent, setting a record for the eighth consecutive year. Fourthquarter net income climbed 13.7 per cent on a 10 percent rise in operating revenues.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Eleven of 13 harness drivers indicted on racefixing charges have appealed to the State Racing and Wagering Board for reinstatement pending the outcome of their trial. A spokesman for the Board said yesterday hearings would be held as soon as possible for the drivers, who have been suspended from all direct and indirect harnessracing activity.

title: New Orders Off for December; Much of Decline Tied to Autos
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22New orders flowing to manufacturers of durable goods fell sharply in December, but much of the drop was in the automobile sector, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Beame Finds Important Strides in Alleviating Municipal Fiscal llls
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22  Governor Wilson's 1974.75 budget, which offers New York City the promise of state masstransit subsidies but contains no unexpected giftsand in some cases actually costs the city moneyreceived an enthusiastic response today from Mayor Beame and his chief fiscal adviser.

title: Goldwater Says Watergate Will Slash G.O.P.'s Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 Senator Barry Goldwater said today that Watergate would cost every Republican candidate a disastrous 10 per cent of the total vote this year. The only way President Nixon can help the situation, the Arizona Republican hinted, is by resigning.

title: Harold A. Loeb Is Dead at 82; Lost Generation Figure in Paris
3 Gunmen Get $27,000 In a Holdup, but Briefly
description: Three gunmen held up a Bronx financial institution getting away with $27,000 but minutes later the police recovered the money although the robbers escaped.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Emergency Relief Funds in Nassau

title: Ford Sets Price Increase
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it would increase the price of its Courier compact pickup truck by $205. or 7.8 per cent, to $2,844, beginning today. Ford said that the increase was in conformit with government regulations applying to imported vehicles. The Courier is imported by Ford from Japan.

title: MIDDLETOWN LOSES A ROUND ON ZONING
description: TRENTON, Jan. 22 (AP)A lstate appeals court ruled today that Middletown Township could not automatically prohibit garden apartments in the community.

title: E.P.A. Warns Power Plants on Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 The Environmental Protection Agency said today it was going to start cracking down on power plants that have been stalling on putting in equipment to control sulphur dioxide fumes.

title: Upstairs at Downstairs Ends Its 30 Yeats of Fun
description: Upstairs at the Downstairs, for the last 30 years a theatrical breeding ground for some of the country's best comedy and musical talents, closed its doors yesterday for the last time.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: ERVIN REPORTED TO BACK HEARINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chairman of the Senate Watergate committee, has told committee staff members that he is willing to resume public hearings and continue them for several weeks, according to persons who have met with him.

title: RODINO FEARS LAG OYEARININUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee warned today that the inquiry into the impeachment of President Nixon could be delayed into 1975 if the Watergate special prosecutor did not turn over relevant grand jury evidence to the committee.

title: Islanders Set Back Seals, 43
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Jan. 22  The New York Islanders beat their favorite opponent, the California Golden Seals, 43, tonight and tied a club recorclt for going undefeated in fout straight games.

title: BUNKER, IN GENEVA, BRIEFS CONFEREES
description: GENEVA, Jan. 22Delegations to the Middle East peace conference here have received a firsthand report of Secretary of State Kissinger's latest round of mediation efforts.

title: UPROAR DISRUPTS ULSTER SESSION
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 22Violence erupted in Northern Ireland's provincial assembly today as militant Protestants demonstrated at the first session attended by the new ProtestantCatholic coalition.

title: Pro Transactions
description: CHICAGO (NL)Signed Jim Kremme!, lefthanded pitcher, and Chris Ward, outfielder. CINCINNATI (NL)Signed, Johnny Bench, catcher.

title: New York's Economy
description: There are signS that New York's long downhill slide in private employment may be leveling off, despite the generally pessimistic outlook for jobs created nationally by the energy crisis. Indeed, the shortage of oil adds to the attractiveness of the central city as a headquarters location. Low cost, speedy mass transit to the outer reaches of Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens helps promote fresh interest in industrial parks within the city limits.

title: Libya and Tunisia, Planning Union, Share Border but Little Else
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Jan. 22To a Western traveler, going from Tunis to Tripoli by road, a custom man's questionDo you have any drink?"makes it clear that the frontier separates not only two countries but two ways of life.

title: Caretaker Budget
description: With two notable exceptions that have brought cheer to City Hall, Governor Wilson's 19743201375 budget is basically a caretaker document, reflecting commitments inherited from the Rockefeller administration. It is disappointingly shy of the initiative that might have been expected from a successor administration determined demonstrate its capacity to cope with new challenges and unresolved old problems.

title: Notre Dame No. 1 Team In 2d Poll
Market Place: 3 Year Results At Banks Cited
Nixon Names Link to Post
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) Edwin A. Link, designer of flight training and submarine research craft, was appointed to the National Advisory Committee on Oceans and Atmosphere today by President Nixon.

title: BOTH SIDES PRESS ABORTION VIEWS
description: The first anniversary of the Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion on demand was marked yesterday by demonstrations for both sides of the dispute.

title: FORD SAYS DATA CAN CLEAR NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Vice President Ford said today that the White House had information that would clear President Nixon of wrongdoing in the Watergate affair or its subsequent coverup.

title: Through a Glass Brightly, And Other Intelligent Ideas
description: Anyone who has ever dreamed of seeing her name in lights can awaken, amble over to 7 West 57th Street and, abracadabra, with a modest amount of money and a little patience, the dream will come true.

title: JAWORSKI MOVES TO HELP THE I.R.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Spectal Prosecutor Leon Jaworski asked permission today from theUnited States District Court to turn over to the Internal Revenue Service information on possible illegal corporate campaign contributions.

title: WILSON'S BUDGET OF $9.38BILLION STRESSES ECONOMY
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22Governor Wilson sent to the Legislature today an electionyear budget of $9.38billion that offered few major spending initiatives, provided little in additional tax relief and devoted most of proposed $772million increase in spending to maintaining existing programs.

title: WHEAT, SOYBEANS AND CORN DECLINE
description: Traders took profits and evened up their positions yes terday pending the Government's report on acreage estimates for the wheat, corn and soybean crops, which were due for release after the close of trading, causing some sharp declines in the commodities on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Red Smith
description: Around the time of World War II the Pittsburgh sports editor, Chet Smith, was in Urbana, Ill., for a football game. on., the eve of the game several other reporters gathered in his room for Attitude Adjustment Hour and with them was a brash young man from radio whose job was assembiling names, numbers and vital statistics for Bill Stern, the broadcaster. The young man tended to take charge.

title: RUFUS M. HARTEL, EDUCATOR, 82, DIES
description: Dr. Rufus M. Hartill, who was president of the Protestant Teachers Association in the nineteenthirties and of the As sociation of Assistant Superin. tendents in the fifties, died Monday in the Amsterdam House, 1060 Amsterdam Avenue. He was 82 years old.

title: Mrs. Joseph Klingenstein, Aided Mount Sinai Hospital
description: Mrs. Esther Adler Klingenstein, wife of Joseph Klingenstein, a senior partner in the investment banking firm of Wertheim & Co. and chairman emeritus of the Mount Sinai Medical Center, died in the hospital there on Monday. She was 74 years old and lived at 1120 Park Avenue.

title: Ballet: Colleen Neary as the Firebird
description: Two matinees on the weekend brought two Balanchine programs for the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater. They showed the vast range of the master, from the conventional La Source to the slinkily experimental Variations Pour Une Porte et Un Soupir.

title: Miller Is Planning to Build A Brewery in the East
description: The Miller Brewing Company, a subsidiary of Philip Morris, Inc., will build an Eastern brewery within 200 miles of New York on one of several sites under consideration, a spokesman announced yesterday.

title: BreakIn at Envoy's Home Protested by Soviet Union
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 22The Soviet Union protested at a meeting here today that burglars armed with a knife broke into the apartment of Gleb Smirnov, a Russian representative, last night and threatened his 13yearold son, Aleksandre. The boy's arm was twisted by one of the intruders, who left without taking anything. The apartment is at 353 East 83d Street.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK; Jan. 22John Sabo of South Orange, is a handball player and the recipient of the Newark Boys Club's New Jersey amateur athlete of the year award. He was a star football player at Rutgers in the late 1940's and is now finding success in fourwall handball.

title: MANILA LISTS CASE AGAINST U.S. PRIEST
description: MANILA, Jan. 22Government lawyers today completed the presentation of their case for deporting an American missionary. An official testified that the American participated In, a protest march on behalf of some southern Philippine farmers in 1971, and the lawyers cited this as evidence of lull undesirability as an alien here.

title: People and Business
The Nixon Inquiry: Exceptions to Grand Jury Secrecy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22It looks like yet another Watergate impasse: The special Watergate prosecutor sits in his closely guarded office on K Street, saying he does not see how he can legally turn over to the House Judiciary Committee the information that his grand juries have developed about President Nixon; the chairman of the committee sits in his office on Capitol Hill, saying that unless he gets the special prosecutor's information, the impeachment inquiry will go 12 months more than already expected, pushing it into the spring of 1975.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP)Retail gasoline prices rose an average of 4.4 per cent in December, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The average price for regular jumped 4.6 per cent to 43.7 cents a gallon in December, while premium rose 4.1 per cent to 47.3 cents. The Government said price increases of regular gasoline ranged from 2.6 per cent in Honoluluwhere the price was higher than in any of the nation's other 22 metropolitan areasto 6.7 per cent in Philadelphia. The rise In premium prices was smaller than for regular in most cities, with the increases ranging from 2.7 per cent in Cleveland and Honolulu to 5.9 per cent in Atlanta.

title: A Blow to Europe
description: What does the French decision to float the franc independently mean for the future of the European Economic Community? And what impact will it have on the world monetary system? France's Economic action was unAnalysis questionably a severe blow to the Common Market because it unilaterally broke the European monetary agreement solemnly entered into by heads of government at the Hague summit conference of December,; 1969, and reaffirmed at the Paris summit of October, 1972, called by. France's President Pompidou himself.

title: Hutton Data Mixed
description: E. F. Hutton & Co., Inc., reported yesterday a sharp improvement in Decemberquarter profits, but showed lower earnings for all of 1973. The major brokerage firm has been profitable every year since its founding in 1904.

title: OffForm Knicks Defeated By Rockets, 10893, Here
State Budget, a Rockefeller Echo
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22Carried along by the fiscal momentum of the Rockefeller years, Governor Wilson's first budget breaks the $9billion mark. But like a man in businesssuit gray who knows he must don the emperor's clothes if he is to bear the scepter, Mr. Wilson is trying not to seem too flashy about it. Mr. Wilson's aides are emphasizing that his initiatives are responsible for less than per cent, or $255million, of the $9.38billion spending and taxing plan, and a good chunk of this is the $100million transit proposal worked out in the final Rockefeller days.

title: Records: Philadelphians China Tour
description: The first recorded documentation of Eugene Ormandy's and the Philadelphia Orchestra's tour of China last Septemberthe first by an American orchestrahas now arrived (RCA ARLI0415, $5.98). The disk, devoted entirely to pieces played on the tour, was recorded in this country, which is fine for sonic quality, although one regrets that something of the atmosphere of a live concert wasn't included. But the main news on it is the first Western recording of The Yellow River Concerto.

title: Justice Ross Named Overseer Of State and City Courts Here
description: Justice David Ross of State Supreme Court was named yesterday as citywide court administrator in a move designed to speed up the processing of cases by placing all city and state courts here under a single management.

title: ISRAEL VOTES PACT IN AN ACID DEBATE
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 22Rejecting the Opposition's angry charge of onesided Israeli withdrawal, Parliament today approved the new trooppullback agreement signed with Egypt last week.

title: French Franc Floats Steadily While Gold Price Slips Abroad
description: PARIS, Jan. 22  The newly floated French franc held steady today, settling at an effective 4 per cent devaluation against the dollar, and a little of the heat went out of the gold market in Europe's latest financial crisis.

title: PUBLIC AND COMMERCIAL NOTICES 51005102
description: Public Notices 5100

title: Brazil's Destiny
description: Whenever Brazil's armed forces arrange the election of a new President, hopes invariably are expressed that he will prove less authoritarian than his predecessor and will start the country back toward government by consent. On two occasions, the incoming chief. executive has deliberately kindled such hopesonly to end up imposing harsher controls than ever.

title: Gambling Indictments Expected Against Top City Mafia Figures
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn has for weeks been hearing evidence collected during the most extensive investigation of organizedcrime gambling operations ever conducted in the metropolitan area by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Cambodia Knows the Value of Boy Soldiers
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 11 Private Leng is one of thousands of boys between the ages of 12 and 17 who serve as regular soldiers in the Cambodian Government's Army.

title: NADJARI OUTLINES HURL CHARGE
description: The special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, said yester, day that the state would prove, that three days after the arrest of Joseph Ferdinando, a convicted swindler, Thomas J. Mackell, the former District Attorney of Queens, admitted to his thenchief prosecutor that people in our office are involved and I don't want any problems for them.

title: Kissinger Says He Heard Tape of Plumbers Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22  In what seemed to be a direct contradiction of his sworn testimony, Secretary of State Kissinger acknowledged today that he had listened to a tape recording of an interrogation conducted by David R. Young Jr., a White House aide, shortly after publication of the secret IndiaPakistan papers in December, 1971.

title: Zarzuela Is Tuneful Example Of Rich Repertory
description: The Spanish zarzuelathat country's national form of opera and operettahas a rich repertory, and one not heard extensively enough in New York. Sunday evening, at Carnegie Recital Hall, members of this city's Spanishspeaking community tried to, rectify that lack with a concert performance of one. of the most popular zarzuelas. Whatever the weaknesses of the performance, one hopes there will be more, and preferably staged.

title: Chapman to Miss U.S.C. Trip Here
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22 (AP)Coach Bob Boyd said today that Clint Chapman, suffering a bruised ligament in his left knee, would not accompany the Southern California basketball team to New York for games Thursday night against Seton Hall and Saturday night against Fordham.

title: OIL PROFITS UP 46% ON 6% VOLUME RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22The seven largest oil companies operating in the United States increased their profits 46 per cent in the first nine months of 1973, at a time when their prices were rising sharply, although they sold only 6 per cent more of their products than the year before, a Senate hearing was told today.

title: U.S. FINANCIAL FILES FOR REORGANIZATION
description: U.S. Financial, Inc., yesterday filed a 340page reorganization plan in Federal Bankruptcy Court in San Diego, Calif., requesting that it be allowed to remain in Chapter 11 proceedings with its current management. It asked for relief from a previous stipulation that would move it into Chapter X proceedings with a trustee at its head.

title: AMIABILITY MARKS PAUK'S VIOLIN MUSIC
description: Gyorgy Pauk played a sweettempered program of violin staples Sunday afternoon at Hunter College, and his performances were as amiable as the music itself. Even within this somewhat limited emotional framework, Mr. Pauk found something personal to say about each piece.

title: People in Sports: Phil Jackson's Push Is Costly ($1,000)
description: Phil Jackson, the 6foot8 inch Knicks forward who pushed Earl Strom, a referee, after having been ejected from a game at Seattle on Jan. 11, was fined $1,000 yesterday by Walter Kennedy, commissioner of the National Basketball Association.with what I've learned about the man.
