He seems very clearheaded now and is going in the right direction.

title: Goldwater Says Watergate Will Slash G.O.P.'s Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 22 Senator Barry Goldwater said today that Watergate would cost every Republican candidate a disastrous 10 per cent of the total vote this year. The only way President Nixon can help the situation, the Arizona Republican hinted, is by resigning.

title: U.S. Judge Fines Greyhound $600,000 in a Court Case
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (UPI)A Federal judge today fined greyhound Lines, Inc., and its parent concern, the Greyhound Corporation, $600,000 on charge of anticompetitive and discriminatory treatment of its chief competitor in the pacific northwest.

title: G.M. Cuts Production By 20,000 More Cars
description: DETROIT, Jan. 22 (AP)The General Motors Corporation has cut back its auto, production by an additional 20,000 cars by extending the temporary layoffs of 37,000 workers this week, the company said today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: Design Prize Reflects Resource Crisis
description: The Progressive Architecture magazine design awards, one of the country's most Important architectural competitions, were marked this year by a consciousness of limited resources for building. The design competition showed a trend toward energysaving buildings, buildings planned for modest budgets, and also toward What architects and critics have come to call recycling the ,conversion of older buildings, not necessarily those of architectural distinction, into new functions as a way of avoiding new construction altogether.

title: Friend of Houston Suspect Describes Night of Killing
UPGRADED IMAGE FOR GIRLS URGED
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Jan. 22 Urging a group of 350 educators to help female students Upgrade their image, Mrs. Ann Klein, former. Democratic Asseblyman from Morris County, said that unless girls saw women run for office they would never think of running for office themselves.

title: NAVY TAKES STEP ON ELK HILLS AREA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22The Navy moved today to prevent the Standard Oil Company of California from draining oil from the onebillionbarrel Naval Petroleum Reserve in Elk Hills, Calif.

title: Don't Count Nixon Out
description: WASHINGTON

title: New Methods Cut Risks in Heart Surgery for Babies
description: MARCO ISLAND, Fla., Jan. 22New methods of diagnosing and treating infants born with lifethreatening heart defects are saving babies who might otherwise have succumbed to the traumas of open heart surgery.

title: Giants Add Peters and Baughan
description: Bill Arnsparger, the Giants new coach, completed the defensive half of his coaching staff with the appointment yesterday of Maxie Baughan and Floyd Peters, two old pros. John Symank, another seasoned pro of the N.F.L. wars, had been named yesterday.

title: Chemical Maker Strong
ATLANTIC RICHFIELD GIVES FUEL REPORT
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company reported yesterday that its stocks of gasoline were down from a year ago, but that middle distillates, including home heating oil, were up. Crude oil inventories were substantially higher.

title: Mexico Uncertain on Oil Crisis
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 22The exhaust fumes of a million vehicles still hang over Mexico City every morning, but bulky policemen are now squeezing into small European automobiles to o on patrol. Government buildings are still bathed in light every evening, but there is talk of putting the clock forward by one hour.

title: Excerpts From Governor Wilson's State Budget Message Sent to the Legislature
TV: Gorky's Enemies Opens WNET Series
description: Theater in America, a series of plays produced for public television by WNET/ 13, begins tonight at 8:30 with Maxim Gorky's Enemies. The production, codirected by Ellis Raab and Kirk Browning, was originally mounted by the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center in 1972, before the installment of Joseph Papp at Lincoln Center.

title: GIBSON IS THRUST INTO HIS NEW JOB
description: In the first hours of his new job as Deputy Mayor for Planning this week, Paul Gibson Jr. learned what one of his areas of responsibility will be in the administration of Mayor Beanie.

title: William Grime, ExRector Of St. Paul's in Great Neck
description: ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt., Jan 22 The Rev. Dr. William Grime, former rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Great Neck, L. I., where he served for 35 years, died Sunday at his home here. He was 81 years old.

title: Rockefeller's ModernArt Is Going Home, Too
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22  The modern art collection that former Gov. Nelson Rockefeller assembled over the last 15 years for the vast interiors of the Executive Mansion here was removed today in less than 15 hours.

title: MEDICAL CENTER GETS AN ADDITION
description: JERSEY. CITY, Jan. 22The Jersey City Medical Center, whose history mirrors the turbulent political and social history of the city, today dedicated a 168bed addition that officials described as a signal of a longterm renovation designed to revitalize the hospital.

title: Taxi Industry Asks Rise of 15 or 20c to Offset Doubled Fuel Cost
description: The city's licensed taxicab industry said yesterday that it was applying immediately for an interim increase of 15 or 20 cents a ride to offset a doubling in gasoline costs since March.

title: Kissinger Says He Heard Tape of Plumbers Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22  In what seemed to be a direct contradiction of his sworn testimony, Secretary of State Kissinger acknowledged today that he had listened to a tape recording of an interrogation conducted by David R. Young Jr., a White House aide, shortly after publication of the secret IndiaPakistan papers in December, 1971.

title: Eased Church Stand on Birth Curb Hinted, but Vatican Denies Iy
description: ROME, Jan. 22Reports of a confidential Vatican circular to bishops, along with a Vatican statement last week on confession, have caused speculation here that the Roman Catholic Church may be planning to ease its opposition to birth control,

title: Gross Rebuffed in Move To Void Tax Indictment
description: NEWARK, Jan. 22Nelson G. Gross, the former state Republican chairman, lost his bid today to quash a Federal indictment charging him with inducing a client to violate Federal income tax laws and later with influencing the client to lie about the matter to a Federal grand jury.

title: Students in Athens Vow New Protests; Classes Boycotted
description: ATHENS, Jan. 22 (UPI) Greek university students boycotted classes today to press demands for political and academic freedom. They also demanded an end to what they called the sale of Greece to the Americans.

title: Cambodians Report A Rebel Pullback Near Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 22 (AP)  An insurgent force estimated to number 2,000 men reportedly withdrew from positions eight miles northwest of Phnom Penh today as Government troops advanced on them from four directions.

title: Bridge: Use of the Marmic System Brings Surprising Results
description: The mostremarkable system ever seen in world championship play, and perhaps in any tournament anywhere, was Marmic. This Italian method, now long abandoned, required a player to pass a balanced hand with about 18 points as dealer, or in second seat, or after an opening to his right. Consequently, his partner was expected to keep the auction alive with very sketchy values.

title: Inouye Is Disturbed by Increase In Criticism of Watergate Panel
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 22Senator Daniel K. Inouye, a member of the Senate Watergate committee, said here tonight that he was disturbed by increasing criticism of the committee.

title: Postal Union Defies Court In Walkout in Jersey. City
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 22The ithpasse between the United States Postal Service and the Metro Area Postal Union intensified today at the New York Bulk and Foreign Mail Center hare as hundreds of workers, defying a Federal Court order, stayed away from their jobs to protest changes in their work schedules.

title: ESCROW INTEREST PASSED BY SENATE
description: ALBANY, Jan. 22The Senate unanimously passed today a bill that for the first time would require banks and livings and loan institutions to pay interest on money held in mortgage escrow account.

title: Carrier Blames Jet Woes and Surging Prices of Fuel
WOMAN, 21, BEATEN, RAPED IN WOODSIDE
description: A 21yearold Queens woman was beaten and raped last night in the Woodside section after she emerged from the subway.

title: Eastern Air in Red
description: Eastern Airlines cited jetengine problems and fuelprice increases as it reported yesterday a net loss of $51.3million for 1973. Meanwhile, a survey showed that more than 80 airliners had been grounded by the nation's airlines since the oil emergency began. Page 50.

title: German Is Chosen to Head Strategic Studies Institute
description: LONDON, Jan. 22Dr. Christoph Bertram, a young West German lawyer and defense expert, was appointed today as director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies.

title: 23 Vietnamese Survivors Of Sea Battle Are Found
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 23 (AP)A Dutch tanker rescued 23 South Vietnamese crewmen whose patrol boat was sunk last Saturday in a sea battle with a Chinese task force over the disputed Paracel Islands, the Saigon military command announced today.

title: Old Agd: A Case of Spirit, Not Chronology
description: This is about five women, all of them past 75, But they are not old.

title: TRENTON TURNS KEY FOR 2 IN SOLITARY
description: Two inmates at the Trenton State Prison who disclosed details of the scalding death of another prisoner have been released from solitary confinement pending their appeals to charges of having violated prison regulations.

title: Skylab's Gyroscope Has Worst Seizure; Breakdown Feared
description: SPACE CENTER, Houston, Jan. 22 (AP)A faulty gyroscope aboard the Skylab space station experienced its worst spell of distress today, and officials feared that the instrument might be on its way to total breakdown.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Federal Aviation Administration ordered the reopening of a costcutting study of its National Aviation Facilities Experimental Center in Pomona. The order, from F.A.A. Administrator Alexander P. Butterfield, signaled at least a temporary victory for politicians and business leaders from New Jersey who had lobbied intensively against closing the facility 10 miles northwest of Atlantic City.

title: CON ED EARNINGS ADVANCED IN 1973
description: The Consolidated Edison Company of New York reported yesterday net income of $207,706,754 for 1973, compared with $148,127,302 for 1972.

title: 11 Hurt as Fire Truck Crashes on Futile Call
description: Seven firemen and four civilians were injured slightly yesterday morning when a fire truck responding to what proved to be a false alarm collided with a taxi at Prospect Avenue and East 156th Street in the Bronx, then struck several parked cars and mounted a sidewalk.

title: AX, PIANIST, WINS HUNTER OVATION
description: If Emanuel Ax has not yet made his name thoroughly known to the general public, his work has attracted much attention among his professional colleagues, dozens of whom attended the 24yearold pianist's Hunter College recital Monday night.

title: ISRAEL VOTES PACT IN AN ACID DEBATE
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 22Rejecting the Opposition's angry charge of onesided Israeli withdrawal, Parliament today approved the new trooppullback agreement signed with Egypt last week.

title: 1973 PRICE GAINS HIGHEST SINCE 47
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22Consumer prices continued to rise strongly in December and finished the year with. the largest annual increase since the immediate aftermath of World War II, the Labor DeIpartment said today.

title: Quake in Uzbekistan
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 22 (UP) An earthquake rocked the Fergana Valley in the Central Asian Soviet Republic of Uzbekistan today, the Tass press agency said. It made no mention of damage or injuries.

title: Helen Walbridge, 94, Dies; Early Industrial Physician
description: Dr. Helen I. Walbridge, the first woman interne in the old New York Hospital on West 16th Street, in 1918, died Monday in the Bayview Nursing Home in Babylon, L. I. She was 94 years old.

title: BONUS TO OBTAIN VARIANCE DECRIED
description: Members of the city's Board of Standards and Appeals said yesterday that they would not be a party to a financial ar. rangement in which Community Board 7 has endorsed an additional story for a 28floor Upper West Side apartment build. ing, provided the builder con. tributes $54,000 for a nearby playground and other community improvements.

title: Proceeds of Burnup Offering Will Pay LongTerm Debt
description: Jerry Finkelstein, chairman of the Struthers Wells Corpora:, tion, announced yesterday that the proceeds anticipated from the sale of 400,000 shares of Burnup & Sims common stock sold by Struthers Wells in a registered public offering would be used, after estimated expenses, to prepay existing longterm debt of $7million.

title: Buerkle Running Like Ringing a Bell
description: Dick Buerkle has been hearing bells lately, and not just because he suddenly has emerged as one of this country's top distance runners.

title: Nixon Accepts Resignation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP)The resignation of John H. Ryther as a member of the Marine Mammal Commission was accepted today by President Nixon with deep regret. Mr. Ryther is chairman of the Department of Biology at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution at Falmouth, Mass.

title: Nixon Address Is Slated For 9 P.M. Wednesday
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP)President Nixon will deliver his State of the Union message next Wednesday at 9 P.M. before a joint session of Congress, the White House announced today.

title: Wallace H. Fulton Dies at 77; Led Securities Dealers Group
description: NAPA, Calif., Jan. 23Wallace H. Fulton, who helped to found and for 25 years was executive director of the National Association of Securities Dealers, died here last Wednesday at the age of 77.

title: Chief Not Embarrassed
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company reported yesterday profits for the 1973 fourth quarter, wher the Arabs imposed an oil embargo against the United States, that ran 59 per cen ahead of the same period of 1972. The company also re. ported that earnings for 1973 set a record and were also ur 59 per cent.

title: Theater: Good Seagull
A Question of Trust
description: BOSTON, Jan. 23Forty years ago a Senate investigating committee subpoenaed documents from William P. MacCracken Jr., a Washington lawyer. He said they were protected by the lawyerclient privilege. While that claim was pending, one of his clients without Mr. MacCracken's knowledgegot into his files, removed material and destroyed it.

title: Tensions Spread as Yen And Franc Remain Weak
description: PARIS, Jan. 23There were further tensions in currency markets today as the Japanese yen and the French franc came under pressure, heightening fears that a period of competitive devaluations may already have begun.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Boeing Company announced yesterday that Air Algerie, the Algerian national airline, had purchased five new aircraft at a cost of $40million. The order includes three advanced 7373's and two advanced 727 Trjets.

title: FOOD SPOT PLANNED AT SITE OF M'GINNIS
description: McGinnis, a popular testaurant in Sheepshead Bay at the turn of the century and Which became a landmark at Broadway and 48th Street ??? it closed last November, will be replaced by another eating establishment.

title: Brookings Scholars Reflect On Politics of Political Study
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Fred D. Thompson, Republican counsel to the Senate Watergate committee, had been on the capital scene only a short time when he startled older Washington ,hands during a staff interview of a witness.

title: Low Reserves of Wheat By Spring Are Foreseen
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 23Supplies of wheat now held in American elevators will be drawn down to dangerously low levels before the harvest of the 1974 crop begins in midMay.

title: State Witness Is Contradicted About Scratches on Carpi's Face
description: TRENTON, Jan. 23  A forI mer schoolmate of Colin C. Carpi testified today that Mr. Carpi had no scratches on his face the day his estranged wife, Laura, was murdered. Mr. Carpi, a 42yearold Princeton businessman is charged with killing his wife at her Princeton home on Feb. 8, 1971.

title: 5 FIRMS SEEKING WALSTON OFFICES
description: At least five major Wall Street brokerage houses were reported yesterday to be actively negotiating to take over branch offices and personnel from the financially ailailing duPont Walston, Inc., system.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MONTAGUE, Jan. 23Bernard Oesen is a specialist in icings  the kinds that cover mountaintops and go on pastries.

title: Truth in Labeling
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23One of Fred Allen's radio characters was an amnesiac who kept trying to remember who he was by the process of elimination. Bduh, I don't carry an umbrella, he would muse, so I can't be Neville Chamberlain.

title: 20 AntiCoalition Protestants Walk Out of Ulster's Assembly
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 23Hardline Protestants walked out of Northern Ireland's Assembly today to protest again against Ulster's new coalition government of moderate Protestants and Roman Catholics.

title: College Tax Credit Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI) Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, submitted legislation today to give middleincome families a tax credit for higher education ex penses. The bill offers a maximum tax credit of $325 for each student. The credit would be computed on the basis of 100 per cent of the first $200 in expenses for tuition, fees and books, 25 per cent of the next $300, and 5 per cent of the next $1,000.

title: Laver Sharp, Ousts Drysdale, 64, 64
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 (AP)Rod Laver of Australia unleashed a powerful attack today in gaining the fourth round of the $100,000 United States professional indoor tennis championship. He scored a 64, 64 triumph over Cliff Drysdale of South Africa.

title: Ervin Unit, on Party Vote, Decides on New Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23On a straight partyline vote, the Senate Watergate committee, which has been in recess since before Thanksgiving, decided today to resume public hearings next week.

title: U.S.Soviet Track Set for Moscow
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 23 (AP)This year's United StatesSoviet Union indoor track meet will be held in Moscow on March 2, the Amateur Athletic Union said today. The announcement by the A.A.U.'s executive director, Ollan Cassell, reflected a change of, mind by the Russians, who earlier had indioated they would prefer to hold the meet at Richmond Coliseum for a third straight year.

title: Prof. James Charlesworth Dies; Political Scientist at Penn, 74
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23Dr. James C. Charlesworth, president of the American Academy of Political and Social Science from 1953 to 1971, died Monday in a Lancaster, Pa., convalescent home. He was 73 years old and lived in Upper Darby, Pa.

title: Jakarta Adopts Stiff Measures To Curb Chinese Businessmen
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 23 (UPI)The Indonesian Government today announced a series of tough new measures designed to curtail the assets of the resident Chinese business community and eliminate corruption in Government.

title: BERLIN OFFICE SET BY WEST GERMANY
description: BERLIN, Jan. 23West Germany decided today to strengthen ties with West Berlin by setting up a new federal office in the city, despite strong criticism by the Soviet Union and East Germany.

title: Christmas Tree Bill Gains in Senate
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 23The Senate voted today to give tax relief to flood victims in West Virginia, to the producers of an ore called trona and to half a dozen other groups of individuals, organizations and businesses, some of which no Senator would identify.

title: AMEX STOCKS UP FOR SECOND DAY
Agency Says Nixon May Have to Drop Wheat Import Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) The Agriculture Department said today that the prospect of dangerously low wheat upplies might force President Nixon to suspend import quotas so that United States bakers can get grain and flour from Canada.

title: Train Kills 8 French Soldiers
description: CHATEAUTHIERRY, France, Jan. 23 (AP)  Eight soldiers were killed and three seriously injured today when a train plowed into a 16man army patrol on a commando exercise in a tunnel.

title: Wilson Visits White House In Quest for Transit Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Governor Wilson went to the White House today in search of $200million for masstransit operating subsidies to extend beyond May 1 the 35cent fare in New York City, but the visit appeared inconclusive, at best.

title: BRITAIN'S MINERS WEIGH FULL HALT
description: LONDON, Jan. 23Leaders of the nation's miners decided today on a course of tougher action In support of their pay struggle with the British Government.

title: DR. JOHN BOWLER OF DARTMOUTH, 79
description: HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 23Dr. John P. Bowler, cofounder and former president of the Hitchcock Clinic and former dean of the Dartmouth Medical School, died yesterday at the Hanover Convalescent Center. He was 79 years old.

title: Rahv Memorial Feb.1
description: There will be a memorial meeting on a 2 P.M. Feb. 1 for Philip Rahv, the literary critic and editor who died Dec. 22, in the memorial chapel at Brandeis University. He had been professor of English at Brandeis.

title: Sales of 1974 Autos Drop at Twice Predicted Rate
People and Business
description: The Executive Woman, a newsletter for businesswomen, held the first of what it hopes will be annual national business dinners here earlier this week. One of the speakers was Muriel F. Siebert, the first woman member of the New York Stock Exchange and head of a securities concern bearing her name,

title: New Orleans Editor Named
description: NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 23 (AP)Ed Tunstall has been named editor of the Times Picayune. He succeeds Arthur F. Felt Jr., who is retiring.

title: SADAT FINDS SYRIA WILLING TO TALK
description: RABAT. Morocco, Jan. 23President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said here today that Syria was willing to talk with Israel about the separation of troops oh the Golan Heights front.

title: U.S. TO WELCOME ARAB INVESTMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (Reuters)  The United States would welcome and could easily absorb investments by Arab and other oikproducing countries, Presidential assistant Peter Flanigan said today.

title: OIL INQUIRY BEGUN BY D.A'S IN NATION
description: The National District Attorneys Association has begun a broad investigation of possible economic crimes of oil companies in the fuel crisis.

title: Rangers Win, 44; Ratelle: 2
description: A new team with an old namethe New York Rangersreturned to home ice at Madison Square Garden last night and beat the Atlanta Flames decisively, 41.

title: People in Sports: Tributes to Paterno
description: The two things probably had nothing to do with each other, but Milton Shapp, Pennsylvania's Governor, a Democrat, showed up at Penn State's annual awards dinner Tuesday night and gave Joe Paterno, the Nittany Lions football coach, a special Wiseman Trophy for turning down a $1million offer to coach the New England Patriots last spring, plus the newly established Governor's Cup as winner of the Penn StatePittsburgh game. Then yesterday Andrew J. Lewis, Republican gubernatorial hopeful, said Paterno had turned thumbs down on his offer to put the coach on his ticket.

title: Nurse Says She Saw Montemarano Give Patient Fatal Injection
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 23  A nurse testified today that she had ;een Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano inject a fatal dose of potassium chloride into a terminally ill patient.

title: SADAT FINDS SYRIA WILLING TO TALK
description: RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 23President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said here today that Syria was willing to talk with Israel about the separation of troops on the Golan Heights front

title: Michigan Congressmen Testify On Quello Nomination to F.C.C
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 President Nixon's nomination of James H. Quello, a retired Detroit broadcasting executive, to the Federal Communications Commission was strongly supported today by a bipartisan group of Michigan Congressmen but opposed bytwo black Representatives who questioned whether the nominee would be sensitive to the needs of consumers and blacks.

title: Peace in City Labor
description: In June, 1971, a strike by a comparative handful of municipal civil service employes sent 700 million gallons of raw sewage spewing into metropolitan waterways, locked Harlem River bridges in uncrossable positions, snarled traffic and cut off school lunches. The aim of that strikenever successfulwas to coerce the State Legislature into approving an overgenerous pension plan the city had agreed to establish for 130,000 clerical, administrative and maintenance workers.

title: Nisbet Succeeds Barbara Ward In Columbia's Schweitzer Chair
description: ALBANY, Jan. 23  The State Board of Regents today approved the appointment of Robert A. Nisbet, a leading scholar in the history and philosophy of social and political thought, to the Albert Schweitzer Chair in the Humanities at Columbia University.

title: Anker Orders Cuts in Some Districts
description: Chancellor Irving Anker said yesterday that local school districts would have to find areas, including teaching positions, in which economies could be made to avoid anticipated budget deficits in elementary and junior high schools throughout the city.

title: On Formulating an Approach to Impeachment
description: The impeachment process now under way poses novel and unusually difficult challenges to lawyers, to men in government and other forms of public life, indeed to all of us. We write upon an almost clean slate. Little law or political precedent is avahable to guide the hard decisions. Yet, regardless of the outcome, the value of the proceeding will depend on whether the process is so conducted that the country perceives it as a fair and legitimate measure for restoring integrity to government.

title: Nuns and Priests Take Cue From Business Recruiters
description: Sister Julienne Howell squirmed with feigned nervousness as she pretended to be a girl who had doubts about entering a novitiate.

title: San Miguel Taken By Money Lender
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 23 (AP) Mrs. John Longden's Money Lender beat Triple Crown and El Espanoleto today in a photo finish in the $34,100 San Miguel Stakes at Santa Anita.

title: Notes on People
description: The 124th president of the American Association for the Advancement of Scierice will be Dr. Margaret Mead, the 72yearold anthropologist. Dr. Mead, curator emeritus of ethnology at the American Museum of Natural History, will assume office next Jan. 1. She is the second woman to be elected president of the association; the first was Dr. Mina Rees, who was elected in 1971.

title: SCHUMAN IS NAMED TO M'DOWELL POST
description: William Schuman, the composer, has been named chairman of the board of the MacDowell Colony, the work retreat for artists in Peterborough, N. H. In this newly created post, Mr. Schuman will share leadership resonsibilities of the colony with its new president, Arthur Levitt. Mr. Levitt succeeds Russell Lynes, who served as president for five years.

title: Jazz Makes a Comeback With Broadest Range Yet
description: Down in the murky depths of the Village Vanguard, where the concentrations per square centimeter of people, smoke and sound were more or less equal the other night as the big Thad JonesMel Lewis jazz band was blowing full blast, some people, looking around the packed room, were saying that jazz was obviously coming back. Hopeful enthusiasts have been saying that for years, never more wistfully than during the nineteensixties, when rock knocked the basic pins out of jazzstealing the interest of the fledgling musicians who had been a wellspring for jazz from decade to decade.

title: Ottawa's Brusque Energy Chief Donald Stovel Macdonald
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 23  Last night, between sessions of the Canadian provincial premiers conference on national energy policy, Donald Macdonald was asked how he could hope to persuade the provinces that are rich in oil to share with the poor ones, while at the same time convincing the poor ones that they were getting enough of the wealth.

title: In Rome, Shows Are Off to a Cautious Start
description: ROME, Jan. 23No selfrespecting fashion follower is showing her knees these days. In fact, as the spring couture showings unfold, some are covering up much more than knees.

title: Nets Defeated, 118110; Paultz Hurts Left Ankle
MOORER AND STENNIS HOLD PRIVATE TALK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, chairnan of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, met privately this week with Senator John C. Stennis, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, to discuss the recent allegations of military snooping on the White House, sources said today.

title: MAJOR PARTIES JOIN IN FUNDRAISING PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI)  Democratic and Republican party leaders have started working jointly in an effort to find different ways of financing their Presidential nominating conventions.

title: City Sells Bonds Worth $349Million, First of New Rating
description: The city sold $349,130,000 worth of bonds yesterday, the first such sale of the Beanie administration and the first since New York City's credit rating was raised by the Standard & Poor Corporation.

title: STRIKE INSURANCE PARES T.W.A. LOSS
GOING OUT Guide
description: NEW BOUNDS The surge of Chinatown to the north continues both on the Italian aide, west of the Bowery, and on the Jewish side, east of the Bowery (Of course, many Puerto Ricans and others already live on both sides).

title: Italy Suspects a Rightist Plot Involving Top Army Officers
description: ROME, Jan. 23Several high army officers are embroiled in a broadening inquiry into charges that a secret neoFascist network has been conspiring to overthrow Italy's democratic institutions.

title: The Hope for Ulster
description: When the Rev. Ian Paisley was forcibly removed by police after he and fellow Protestant extremists deliberately disrupted the Northern Ireland Assembly earlier this week, he railed against jackboot fascism. But it is his own group of Loyalists, with their fanatic hatred of Ulster's longoppressed Catholic minority, their bullying tactics and their support of mindless violence who recall the European fascists of forty years ago.

title: STAFF FILESTAKEN TO MACKELL JURY

title: Winter Birds
description: Winter is a difficult time for wild life, but perhaps the hazards are not as serious for the birds, for instance, as we sometimes think. Normally migratory birds that fail to go south have trouble every winter. Theirs is a marginal existence. But this does not apply to most winter robins. Many of them migrate to this area from New Brunswick and Nova Scotia and are a hardy breed. So are most of the birds that live here the year around. They are well feathered, with as much as a third again as many feathers in winter as in summer. They can live well on a wild diet. They know how to cohserve energy in prolonged cold spells.

title: Film: Wildlife in Peril
description: Welcomeeven thanksto "Vanishing Wilderness," a fine new film for the entire family that opened here yesterday in a mass showcase booking. This nature documentary reportedly has been mopping up financially in previous showings across the country and Canada, and no wonder.The feature is a documentary of wildlife, primarily in Alaska, the American North-west and the Florida Everglades. Photographed in beautiful color, with a splendid sweep of seasonal settings, it closes in marvelously on a richly varied assortment of beasts and birds, many of them threatened with extinction.The narration is easy, comfortable and interesting, rarely folksy, and, wonder of wonders, the plea for wildlife protection is made pointedly but casually. The camera, manned by a German photographer, Heinz Seilmann, says it all, hovering intimately over an extraordinary, untamed cavalcade, large to tiny.The picture swarms with wildlifeantelopes, mustangs, buffalo ("whose sad eyes tell their story"), geese, whooping cranes, pelicans, herons, alligators, caribou, big horn sheep, bears, water moose and many other species. The most beguiling scenes were those of a frisky little sea otter, beaver dam-builders and a spectacle of swarming fur-seals on the Pribilof Islands off Alaska, magnificently presented.A charmingly informal prelude shows the family of Arthur Dubs, who co-produced with Mr. Seilmann, riding the rapids in a boat on the Rogue River in Oregon.
