title: The Screen: Willie Dynamite' Tells Story of a Pimp
description: "Willie Dynamite," which opened yesterday at the Demille, is another rip-off on the black exploitation film for which, I suppose, all sorts of sociological rationales are possible, though, in this case, I don't feel like making them.The movie, about the decline and fall of a black New York superpimp nicknamed Willie Dynamite, has a promising beginning. The costumes, language, melodrama, performances and even the soundtrack music are so outrageously broad it seems as if the film were putting itself on, parodying such earlier live-action black cartoons as "The Mack" and "Cleopatra Jones," Not at all. It wants a piece of the same action.Willie Dynamite (Roscoe Orman), who dresses every morning as if he were going to a Mardi Gras ball before lunch, may not have happiness but he has everything else: a lavender-and-gold, supercharged Lincoln, a magnificent pad that looks like the Castro showroom on Duffy Square, a nice middle-class mother who lives in New Jersey and thinks he is some sort of artists' agent, and a stable of six super-women who have free run of what could be the New York Hilton.When the cops put the heat on whoring, Willie, idealistic loner that he is, refuses to join the city's other major pimps in a mutual-protection agency.The proud Willie is punished not by the gods but by the Internal Revenue Service, by the other pimps, by the cops and mostly by a former prostitute, played wanly by the late Diana Sands in her last film appearance, a character who, having gone straight, describes herself as "a sort of Ralph Nader for hookers." The film is under the peculiar impression that Mr. Nader operates on behalf of the retailer rather than the consumer.Before Willie meets his comeuppance, the movie indulges itself and us in a lot of dumb fantasies about how great it would be to be at the top of pimpdom, even if only for a little while. It talks pseudo hip, and it introduces (but never develops) an interesting character in the person of a black cop (played by Al Hall), who wears button-down shirts and Brooks Brothers suits and is, apparently, a Black Muslim.The film spends a good deal of its time ogling Willie's women, who are black, white, oriental and beautiful, but its menage is stupifying sentimental. The thing that convinces Willie to go straight is the death of his mink-stole-wearing mom, who has a heart attack when she learns where Willie's money really comes from. Says Willie through his tears: "I did it all for her," or some such baloney.The movie was directed by Gilbert Moses, who has some good stage credits, including Melvin Van Peebles's "Ain't Supposed to Die a Natural Death." As the beginning of the film shows, Mr. Moses may be a director with a true sense of comedy and parody, but one can't be sure. The screenplay, by Ron Cutler is so awful.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In retrospect, it was all Howard Cosell's fault. Instead of sitting in the middle chair, where he might have been a persuasive referee, he sat on the left. At the right was Muhammad Ali, in a vested brown pinstriped suit, and when Joe Frazier appeared in a suede jump suit, he sat down in the empty chair between them, only inches away from the voice he hates to hear. They were in an Anierican Broadcasting Company studio on West 66th Street yesterday to tape the Wide World. of Sports show that will appear Saturday afternoon. The plot was for them to view, for the first time together, the film of their $20million extravaganza, now known as The Fight I, in anticipation and promotion of The Fight II at Madison Square Garden on Monday night. For nearly an hour, as the two gladiators watched and mildly insulted each other, the atmosphere was tense but somewhat playful. Suddenly, as they were watching the 10th round, the mood changed. They were discussing how the right side of Ali's jaw had swollen. Sports of The Times

title: STATE MAY ALTER SCHOOL FINANCING
description: ALBANY, Jan. 23  A special state education task force is considering a revision of the financing of primary and secondary education in the state at a possible cost of up to $200million more a year than the state is now spending.

title: FINGERPRINT PLAN BACKED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Jan, 23The Senate, after a heated debate, adopted a resolution today that would allow the Federal Bureau of Investigation to fingerprint all prospective employes of the New York City Board of Education, including teachers and nonprofessional personnel.

title: Low Reserves of Wheat By Spring Are Foreseen
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 23Supplies of wheat now held in American elevators will be drawn down to dangerously low levels before the harvest of the 1974 crop begins in midMay.

title: CARPI SUPPORTED BY SCHOOL FRIEND
description: TRENTON, Jan. 23  A former schoolmate of Colin C. Carpi testified today that Mr. Carpi had no scratches on his face the day his estranged wife, Laura, was murdered. Mr. Carpi, a 42yearold Princeton businessman is charged with killing his wife at her Princeton home on Feb 8, 1971.

title: Montgomery C. Eilbeck, 79, Chairman of Flint &
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 23  Montgomery Cowperthwaite Eilbeck, chairman of the board, of Flint & Horner Company, Inc., a threeunit furniture chain on Long Island that was lin his family for three generations, died yesterday at his home here. He was 79 years old and lived_ in Greenwich, Conn., an Centerport, L. I.

title: Market Place: A 1930's View Of Bank Action
description: If you ask an oldtimer like Bradford F. Story where the major New York City banks went wrong in their investment policies for pension fund money in 1973, his answer will be framed in the context of a career that stretches back to before the Great Depression.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Byrne announced yesterday that the. State Attorney General was investigating evidence that the state had been defrauded of thousands of dollars in receipts from New Jersey's daily and weekly lotteries. The Governor and William F. Hyland, the Attorney General, emphasized at a news conference, however, their confidence that ticketholders had not been cheated of any winnings. It was the State Treasury, they said, that had been bilked by some dishonest lottery agents.

title: Peron Widens Purge of Leftists And Crackdown on Guerrillas
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 23In the wake of the Marxist guerrilla attack on an army garrison last weekend, President Juan D. Perlin has extended his purge of leftists in his movement and is pressing for strict antiterrorist legislation.

title: New Deal Reported On Sale of Padres
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 23 (AP) A hamburger millionaire, Ray Kroc, has reached a handshake agreement to buy the San Diego Padres baseball club, The San Diego Union reported tonight.

title: Long Predicts that President Will Be Asked to Pay Back Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI)Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, said today that President Nixon would almost certainly be asked to pay back taxes because he was not entitled to the $576,000 deduction he claimed on the gift of his VicePresidential papers.

title: Stage: 2 New Musicals
description: Of two current Off Off Broadway musical packages, one is a frantic, contagious mischief, by the name of Pigjazz. It features a galvanic quartet of youngsters, who call themselves the Decadent Poor, babbling a 70minute stream of farcical gibberish, songflavored and loosely spiked with social commentary.

title: Swidler Proposes a Curb on Cutoffs by Utilities
description: ALBANY, Jan. 23Joseph C. Swidler, State Public Service Commissioner, today proposed a change in regulations to prevent the cutoff of utility service such as what allegedly caused the death of an elderly Schenectady couple last month.

title: Burroughs Sets 2.1 Split And Increase in Dividend
description: The Burroughs Corporation, which recently reported record earnings for the quarter and year ended Dc. 31, announced yesterday that directors proposed a 2for1 stock split and an increased, quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share. The split is subject to shareholder approval of an increase in the authorized shares to 60 million from 30 million at the annual meeting on March 27 in Detroit. The dividend, payable April 20 on presplit shares to record on March 29, compares with 20 cents paid in former quarters.

title: Closer U.S.Allied Consultation Urged by British U .N . Delegate
description: Sir Donald Maitland, Britain's chief delegate to the United Nations, called yesterday for closer consultation between the United States and its European allies but insisted that anxiety over the alliance was ill founded and ill judged.

title: Temple Five Bows, 6449, To St. John's
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 (AP)Mel Utley's 22 points sparked St. John's to a 6449 victory over Temple in a college basketball game tonight at the Palestra.

title: Consumer Notes
description: As everyone knows, dealing with the telephone cornpany has its pitfalls, although the phone company would arguewith justicethat it has filled in a lot of the potholes.

title: ATLANTIC RICHFIELD GIVES FUEL REPORT
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company has reported that its stocks of gasoline are down from a year ago, but that stocks of middle distillates, including home heating oil, are up. Crude oil inventories were substantially lower.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: Irresponsible Games
description: The White House continues to devise game plans which are an affront to the intelligence of the American people. The latest examples are the White Houseinspired statements by Vice President Ford and Senator Hugh Scott to the effect that they have seen the President and, have come away, confident that, if only the public knew what they know, Mr. Nixon would be in the clear.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: Arabs to Study Embargo Leaks

title: Hannes Schneider Skis Again, That Is, the Master's Grandson
description: NORTH CONWAY, N. H., Jan. 23  There's another Hannes Schneider skiing on Mount Cranmore. He's the 6yearold grandson of the late Schneider, who was America's first recognized ski meister. The youngster has just mastered the stem christie and is learning the parallel turn. News of Skiing

title: EVERETT COOK DIES; COTTON SHIPPER, 79
description: MEMPHIS, Jan. 23Everett R. Cook, chairman of Cook Industries, Inc., which he founded in 1916 as Cook & Co., cotton shippers, died here Monday. He was 79 years old.

title: FREER TRADE SOUGHT FOR E.E.C. AND U.S.
description: GENEVA, Jan. 23The way has been cleared for mounting a new assault on barriers to the free flow of world trade with removal or a procedural deadlock that opposed the United States to the European Economic Community.

title: BYRNE, ILL, GRANTED A DAY OFF IN MATCH
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 23Robert Byrne, the only United States player in contention for the right to challenge Bobby Fischer for the world chess championship, sought and received permission today to postpone his fifth game with Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union.

title: Nuns and Priests Take Cue From Business Recruiters
description: Sister Julienne Howell squirmed with feigned nervousness as she pretended to be a girl who had doubts about entering a novitiate.

title: Witness Says Agnew Got Road Contract Kickbacks
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 23  A former Maryland Roads Commission chairman testified in Federal Court here today that he was involved in the extortion of cash kickbacks from 1967 to 1969 with former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew and a Baltimore mortgage banker.

title: Chief Not Embarrassed
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, reported yesterday profits for the 1973 fourth quarter, when the Arabs imposed an oil embargo against the United States, that ran 59 per cent ahead of the same period of 1972. The company also reported that earnings for 1973 set a record and were also up 59 per cent.

title: Judge Rules Boys Eligible To Take Hunter High Test
description: Judge Inzer B. Wyatt ruled in Federal District Court here yesterday that 24 boys should be permitted to take an entrance examination tomorrow for the allgirl Hunter High School. The boys had filed a lawsuit seeking to compel the school to accept qualified boy students.

title: Sheila Young Wins Skate Series Title
description: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 23 (AP)Sheila Young of Detroit won the fourevent series and Monika Pflug of West Germany took the sprints in the multiple speedskating competition that ended today.

title: Cut to Military Charged
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today that he had documentary proof that at least one major American oil company had cut supplies to United States military forces around the world during the Middle East crisis ion orders from Saudi Arabia.

title: Personal Finance: Tax Appeal Shifts
description: The Internal Revenue Service, in a major effort to make it easier and less expensive for the taxpayer to defend his tax deductions, is quietly revamping its taxappeals system.

title: Shane and Sirkin,  Comic and Writer, Die in Auto Crash
description: Jerry Shane, a nightclub comedian, and Stephen Sirkin, a writer for comedians, were killed on Saturday when their car, driven by Mr. Shane, was in collision with a tractortrail. er after a skid near Downingtown, Pa. They were returning to their homes on Long Island from Mr. Shane's engagement in Lancaster.

title: SKYLAB GYROSCOPE IS EXPECTED TO FAIL
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 23 (UPI)Space agency officials said today that they believed Skylab's controlling gyroscope was "slowly but surely caving in during the final days of the earthorbiting mission that first began last May.

title: Richardson Dilworth, 75, Dies; Twice Mayor of Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 (AP) Richarason K. Dilworth, a former twoterm Mayor of Philadelphia, died tonight of a malignant brain tumor at Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 75 years old.

title: City Ballet
description: La Valse presented Tuesday bight at the State Theater by the New York City Ballet, is not usually considered a typical Balanchine ballet. Yet like all ballets by George Balanchine, the company's artistic mentor, it makes its public work a little harder than elsewhere, and it is closely related to the structure of its music.

title: A.M.C. and Volkswagen Deny a LinkUp
description: Rumors of a possible link between the American Motors Corporation and Volkswagen of West Germany helped propel A.M.C. shares on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to a new 1973.74 high for the second consecutive day.

title: 3 in an Alleged Plot To Free 6 at Tombs Released by Judge
description: Charges have been dropped for lack of evidence against three persons who had been accused of plotting the escape of six alleged members of the Black Liberation Army from the Manhattan House of Detention.

title: Interior Department Issues Permit for the Building Of Alaskan Oil Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23After four years of intense controversy, the Department of the Interior issued a permit today for the building of a 789mile pipeline to take oil from Alaska's North Coast to the icefree port of Valdez.

title: Berlinger Contends That City Misspent Millions in Medicaid
description: George F. Berlinger, the State Welfare Inspector General, charged yesterday, that the city had paid out more than $1billion in Medicaid claims in the last eight years with little or no verification of whether the claims were legitimate.

title: OILDEALER RAIDS PROTESTED HERE
description: Leaders of independent heatingoil dealers protested to the regional Federal Energy Office here yesterday that they had lost thousands of homeowner customers in the last few months to raiding by major oil companies and their wholesalers.

title: Motorists in Manhattan, Take Heed
description: Closedoff expressway sections along both the Hudson and East Rivers turned the usual rush traffic yesterday morning into a caravan of creepers and caterwaulers.

title: Bond Prices Steady in Quiet Trading
CATHARINE OZBIRN, LED WOMEN'S CLUBS
description: FORT WORTH, Jan. 24 (AP) Mrs. Catharine Freeman Ozbirn, nationally known promoter of scholarship and the interests of women, died Thursday in her home.

title: SHELLING KILLS 35 IN CAMBODIA CAPITAL
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Friday, Jan. 24 (AP)The biggest rebel artillery barrage to hit Phnom Penh since the Cambodian war began killed at least 35 persons last night and wounded more than 80, police sources said. The shells struck within a quartermile of the presidential palace.

title: Increases in Wages Fell as Living Costs Rose Sharply in 73
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 While the cost of living was rising steeply last year, the size of wage increases paid to workers covered by major colllective bargaining settlements fell off sharply, a report by the Department of Labor disclosed today.

title: Pop Music: Jim Stafford Skips That Serious Stuff
description: The rockpop club scene in Manhattan tends to take itself very seriously. Ponderous pronouncements are made about what group or what artist has, in personal possession, the tablets upon which is written, in holy script, the next direction the music will take.

title: House Republican to Run
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)  Representative William S. Cohen, 33yearold firstterm Republican of Maine, announced today that he would run for reelection.

title: Nixon at Camp David For Work on Message
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24(AP)President Nixon drove tonight to his favorite decisionmaking retreat at Camp David, Md., where he was expected to work on his forthcoming State of the Union Message.

title: Friends of Duryea Cheer Our Perry's Vindication
description: SOUTHOLD, L. I., Jan. 24 At 12:55 P.M. today, as Perry Belmont Duryea Jr. was digging into a beef pie at the Shelter Island Pub, the telephone rang and the 96th Speaker of the State Assembly was summoned to receive a call from his New York office.

title: U.S. SAID TO BACK TALKS ON ARAB OIL
description: LONDON, Jan. 24 (UPI)The British Petroleum Company said today the Nixon Administration sanctioned meetings of top Western oil executives to map a common stand toward Arab oilprice increases.

title: Walston Sells 40 Of Its 143 Offices; Litigation a Factor
Oil Industry and Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Some of the most popular proposals for changing the way the tax, laws apply to the oil industry would not cost most oil companies a single penny in additional Federal income taxes. This is true of at least two ideas put forth by the Nixon Administration, and is also true of other ideas being supported by such liberal (and presumably antioil company) politicians as Senator GeOrge McGovern of South Dakota.

title: U.S. WON'T APPEAL LOYALTY OATH BAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The Justice Department announced today that the Government would not appeal a court decision prohibiting the State Department from requiring applicants for passports to take loyalty oaths.

title: TAX BILL KILLED AT SPONSOR'S BID
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Senate liberals attached so many amendments today to a Christmas tree tax bill that the bill's main sponsor asked the Senate to kill the measure, which the Senate did.

title: How Far Is Your Weekend Home? Oh, About One Tankful of Gas
description: They rattle off miles per gallon and tank capacity the way a stockbroker quotes the Dow Jones averages. They have scouted all the offthebeatenhighway service stations en route to Stowe, Vt., Great Barrington, Mass., and East Hampton, L. I. They keep their automobiles parked during the week, conserving their gasoline bounty the way a squirrel hoards nuts. And they have committed to memory which city stations open 5:30 A.M.

title: SILVER RESPONDS TO RISES ABROAD
POSTAL EMPLOYES RETURN TO WORK
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 24Both sides in the labor dispute at the New York Bulk and Foreign Mail Center here agreed today to a temporary settlement in the fourdayold work stoppage that followed management attempts to alter workshift hours

title: Greece Sentences Two Arabs To Death for Killings at Airport
description: ATHENS, Jan. 24Two Arabs who killed five persons and injured 55 in a grenade attack at the Athens airport last August were sentenced to death tonight after a oneday trial.

title: Natural Gas Ruling
description: A ruling by the New Jersey Public Utilities Commission enables the Elizabethtown Gas Company to become the country's first utility to sell natural gas that it has found and produced. Page 37.

title: State Plans to Aid Students Attending Private Colleges
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24A joint higher education committee of State Legislature is expected to present a major program next week to subsidize students attending private colleges and universities throughout the state.

title: ROBBER GETS $580 AT DOCTOR'S OFFICE
description: A gunman terrorized the offices of a physician on the upper West Side last night and fled with an estimated $580 in cash as the police, alerted by a nurse, arrived at the scene, at 415 Central Park West, near 101st Street.

title: ANGERED OIL MEN DISPUTE CHARGES OF SENATE CRITICS
description: The oil industry responded angrily yesterday to criticism and charges leveled at it by Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, and his Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, which is holding hearings on the nation's energy problems.

title: EDWARD F. MURPHY
description: EAST MEADOW, L.I., Jane 24Edward F. Murphy, who retired eight years ago as teaching golf professional at the Glen Oaks Club of Old Westbury, died today of stroke at the Nassau County Medical Center. He was 72 years old and lived at 11 Elm Drive, New Hyde Park.

title: Heath Is Taking a New Tack in a RoughSea
description: LONDON, Jan. 24  Those who have watched Prime Minister Heath handle his yacht report that he often wins sailing races by taking chances that others would not dare. In his dealings with the miners, he is also taking serious risks with his political life. His first tack, intended to end the slowdown by the miners, has now failed and he has decided on a second. So far he has managed to trade one uncertainty for another in a struggle that has left the British wondering where the voyage will end.

title: Advertising: A Buttenheim Deal
description: The 63yearold, familyowned Buttenheim Publishing Corporation, which for years has withstood the offers of acquisitive companies, has been purchased by MorganGrampian, Inc., a fairly new United States subsidiary of a young British publishing company.

title: ExPublicist Reportedly Weighed for a City Post
description: Henry O. Dormann, a former publicity man, is under considerotica for a post in the Beame administration according to sources at City Hall.

title: Union Carbide Paces Gains
Sports News Briefs
description: The 17th annual Louisville Sport, Boat and Vacation Show will open tomorrow at the Kentucky Fair and Exposition Center, running for nine days. Last year, more than 167,000 visitors attended the show, the sixth largest in the country.

title: Notes on People
description: The Mayor, of Cleveland, Ralph J. Perk, announced yesterday that he would seek the Republican nomination for the United States Senate. State party leaders indicated they expected Mr. Perk to have little or no opposition.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GOOD HEAVENS After regular office hours, when the stars are the star of the show, the Hayden Planetarium is going to become a concert hall, at least for the next three Fridays and Saturdays, starting tonight: Sharing the dim light with the firmament will be Robert Mason and his band, Stardrive, and the electronic synthesizer the composerperformer built himself.

title: Zellerbach Earnings at Peak
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation, one of the nation's largest paper producers, reported yesterday, the highest sales and earnings for a fourth quarter and any year in its 103year history.

title: People in Sports: Lions'
description: Mike Lucci, a 12year middle linebacker in the National Football Leaguenine with Detroit  retired yesterday and in passing, leveled a blast at Coach Don McCafferty.

title: Colleg'e vs. Business The Versus Declines
description: ST. LOUISHigher education's distrust of the business world, a feeling that has sometimes bordered on hostility, seems to be giving way to mood of accommodation.

title: MINORITY BUDGET STIRS COMPLAINTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Funds for the Office of Minority Business Enterprise, the agency that coordinates the Administration's minority capitalism program, will remain at $52million in the new budget, according to Department of Commerce sources.

title: Utility to Sell Natural Gas It Found and Produced
description: NEWARK, Jan. 24  Elizabethtown Gas Company will become the first utility in the country to begin selling natural gas that it has discovered and produced on its own. This became possible under a ruling handed down by the state Public Utilities Commission today. The order enables the utility, starting next Tuesday, to take on new residential customers for the first time in 18 months, and limiteduse industrial customers for the first time since May, 1970.

title: Bridge: Indonesians Qualify Again For Bermuda Bowl Tourney
Impeachment Panel Seeks House Mandate for Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Senior members of the House JUdiciary Committee agreed today to ask the full House Representatives to ratify formally the committee's investigation of President Nixon's conduct in office.

title: MONTHLY DAIRY GIFT TO NIXON DISCLOSED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) Three White House reports filed in connection with consumer advocate Ralph Nader's suit to roll back milk support prices revealed today that milk producers had promised $90,000 a month to President Nixon's 1972campaign.

title: Down by the Depot
description: This is the country of the throwaway civilization. Most conspicuously expendable have been the artifacts of the railroad age, that period of slightly more than half a century that opened the continent, shaped the environment, set the pattern of cities and built a series of monuments of notable esthetic ambition and engineering ingenuity.

title: People's Democratic Republic of Letters
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.Writers often unjustly accuse my colleagues and me of opposing their humanitarian schemes for nationalizing the medical profession in America. On the contrary, we deem it a great honor to have our property, education and skillacquired at much personal effort and expensedeclared important enough to'be confiscated for public use.

title: 13 Are Indicted in Illinois For HarnessRacing Fix
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (UPI)A grand jury indicted 13 men today on charges of conspiracy to fix three harness races in 1972 at two Cook County race tracks.

title: Standards on College Costs Are Asked
No Aid, No Trade
description: The House of Representatives threw much more into jeopardy than its members may have realized when refused to authorize funds for an enlarged development loan pool to be operated by the World Bank for the poorest nations of the world. Several reasons for defeat of the Administration's proposal are obvious; there are many more reasons why this unthinking action should be quickly reversed, if it is not too late.

title: Market Moves Downward On Investor Uncertainty
BIAS IS CHARGED IN JOBLESS PAY
description: TRENTON, Jan. 24New Jersey has been charged with discrimination in denying unemployment compensation benefits to Puerto Ricans who, after losing their jobs in New Jersey go to Puerto Rico to seek employment.

title: GRADUATE STUDENT TELLS OF SYRIA JAIL
description: LONDON, Jan. 24 (UPI)A New York student freed after two years in a Syrian prison passed through London today on his way home.

title: 2 Officers Die in Jet Crash
description: GILA BEND, Ariz., Jan. 24 (AP)  Two Air Force officers were killed last night when their F4C jet fighter crashed on the Gila Bend Gunnery Range. They were identified by Luke Air Force Base officials as Maj. Jerry D. Whitlock, 34 years old, of Dallas, and Second Lieut. Jerry W. Smith, 23. of Oxon Hill. Md.

title: IRISH FOOTBALL
description: LEAGUE MATCH

title: 8 Dad in Liberty. Blaze; 1 1 Are Taken to Hospital
description: LIBERTY, N. Y., Jan. 24A woman and seven children died here today in a fire that raced through a threestory apartment building a few hours before dawn. Eleven persons, including two firemen, were taken to hospitals and two persons are still unaccounted for.

title: COURT DISMISSES ELECTION CHARGE AGAINST DURYEA
description: Election fraud charges against the two most powerful leaders of the State Assembly, Speaker Perry B. Duryea and Majority Leader John E. Kingston, were dismissed yesterday in State Supreme Court.

title: Libya and Iraq Opposing Sadat on Lifting Oil Curb
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 24Two Arab oilproducing countries, Libya and Iraq, are openly opposing the efforts of Egypt's President, Anwar elSadat, to bring about an end to the Arab oil embargo imposed against the United States.

title: Social Impact Questioned
description: Howard Samuels, the architect of offtrack betting, proosed yesterday that New Yorkers take a searching look at the social implications of gambling.

title: LAWRENCE WATERBURY
description: LOUISVILLE Ky., Jan. 24Lawrence S. Waterbury, a traffic engineer, died of pneumonia Sunday. He was 77 years old and formerly lived in Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: High School Sports
description: When Frank Mulzoff coached basketball at St. John's University, he never had to share practice time with girls team. Mulzoff, who led the Redmen into a postseason tournament each of his three seasons there, is now coaching at Connetquot High School in Suffolk County and has to split afternoon hours in the gymnasium with the girls team.

title: Impeachment Panel Seeks House Mandate for Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Senior members of the House Judiciary Committee agreed today to ask the full House Representatives to ratify formally the committee's investigation of President Nixon's contion of President Nixon conduct in office.

title: House Curb on Aid Disaster for Poor, McNamara Says
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Robert S. McNamara, the president of the. World Bank, said today that the vote yesterday by the House of Representatives to deny new United States contributions to the bank was an unmitigated disaster for hundreds of millions of people in the poorest nations of the world.

title: Police Accuse 2d Man in Killing Of Head of Schools in Oakland
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 24Police officials here said today that a second member of the mysterious Symbionese Liberation Army would be charged with the murder of Dr. Marcus A. Foster, the superintendent of Oakland's public schools.

title: Maximum Sentence Weighed by Judge In Road Fraud Case
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 24  A state judge said today that he was inclined to pronounce the maximum sentence of 10 years on Ruby Lee Latham, who was convicted of grand larceny late yesterday in the first of many pending cases involving a state highway funds fraud to come to trial.

title: Investigators Say They Find No Data Disputing Rebozo on Retention of $100,000 Donation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The Senators on the Watergate committee were told yesterday by their investigators that no evidence had been developed to contradict the contention of Charles G. Rebozo that he kept $100,000 in his safedeposit box or three years before returning it to agents of Howard R. Hughes.

title: George A. Nesbitt Dead; A Recreation Official, 82
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Jan. 24George Alexander Nesbitt, who for 47 years had been a member of the staff of the National Recreation Association and at his retirement in 1964 was director of consultation, died Friday at the Mountainside Hospital, Montclair. He was 82 years old and lived at 20 Burnside Street here.

title: COPTER HIJACKED IN ULSTER ATTACK
description: STRABANE, Northern Ireland, Jan. 24 (Reuters)Irish Republican guerrillas hijacked a helicopter today and tried to drop two milk churns packed with explosives on a police station where British troops are stationed in this border town.

title: CLERKS JOIN STRIKE OVER BOLIVIAN FOOD
Consumer Groups Seek Limits On TV Ads Aimed at Children
description: Severe limits on the advertising of sugarized products in children's television shows are prominent in a set of proposed new guidelines drafted by representatives of six consumer organizations for consideration by the Federal Trade Commission and the television industry.

title: Code on Sterilization Aid Is Clarified on Key Points
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The new government guidelines on the use of Federal money for sterilization operations provide that a decision on a person's competence to decide whether to be sterilized would be made by local familyplanning officials receiving Federal grants, not welfare officers as The New York Times reported in Tuesday's issue.

title: Howes Lead Aeros, 51
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 24 (AP)Mark Howe scored two goals on assists from his father, Gordie Howe, to lead the Houston Aeros to a 51 World Hockey Association victory over the Quebec Nordiques tonight. Gordie Howe scored his 15th goal of the season in the third period.

title: Market Place: Sifting Assets Gold Stocks
Padres'
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24 Charles S. (Chub) Feeney, the president of the National League, was prepared today to call a meeting of the league's clubowners for next week to formally approve the sale of the San Diego Padres to Ray Kroc, the 71yearold head of the McDonald hamburger chain, who will keep the team in San Diego.

title: Rail Reorganization Act Is Challenged
description: Richard Joyce Smith, trustee of the New Haven Railroad, corporate shell, confirmed yesterday that he had instructed his counsel, Sullivan & Worcester, to bring suit today in Federal district court in Washington challenging the legality of the Rail Reorganization Act.

title: Agnew Novel's Hero Reported.; To Be a Vice President of U.S.
description: The hero of the novel that former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew has proposed to write is a lawyer with Presidential ambitions who has been appointed Vice President after his prededessor has died of heart attack, informed sources said yesterday.

title: Children's Books: Best of 1973 Cited
description: Life aboard the slave ship Moonlight in 1840, with black men and women and children lifting their tormented. limbs. The arduous building of a Gothic cathedral, with peasants walking a treadmill to provide power. The bedroom of a child named Will where, in a dreadful furious moment, horror seized him like a nightmare made real...

title: 25% of Gasoline Stations Reported Dry in New YorkJersey Region
Ali, Frazier Face Possible $5,000 Fines
description: The scuffle between Muhammad All and Joe Frazier at a television studio on Wednesday, whether it was in earnest or to lift ticket sales for closed circuit television of their, heavyweight fight on Monday night, may make waves.

title: JAWORSKI STUDIES 72 FOREIGN GIFTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24A spokesman for Watergate Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski confirmed today reports that the staff was gathering matecial on contributions from foreign, sources to the Nixon reelection campaign in 1972.

title: Owner Is Accused Of Scheme to Burn $400,000 L.I. Home
description: The owner of a $400,000 Long Island summer home endangered by sea erosion was arrested here yesterday on charges by District Attorney Eugene.. Gold of Brooklyn that the man had tried to burn the house. down to collect insurance,

title: PLUMBERS OUSTED HIM, KROGH SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Egil Krogh Jr. said today that he was dismissed from his White House plumbers assignment in December, 1971, after he refused to authorize a wiretap in connection with an investigation into the publication of the IndiaPakistan papers.

title: COPIER HIJACKED IN ULSTER ATTACK
description: STRABANE, Northern Ireland, Jan. 24 (Reuters)Irish Republican guerrillas hijacked a helicopter today and tried to drop two milk churns packed with explosives on a police station where British troops are stationed in this border town.

title: L.I. Paper Says U.S. Rulings Formed Foreign Oil Cartels
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Jan. 24 (AP)Secret Federal decisions dating to the World War II years allowed American oilmen to form the foreign cartels now driving up international oil prices, Newsday said today.

title: NO LINKED TO SWINDLE FUND
description: Joseph Ferdinando, a convicted swindler, told a State Supreme Court jury yesterday that former District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens and 16 other members of Mr. Mackell's office had invested at least $200,000and probably more  in his getrichquick scheme that promised investors lucrative weekly interest payments.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE CASE WORKER. By George Konrad. Translated From the Hungarian by Paul Aston. 173 pages. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $6.95.

title: KISSINGER REPORTS SYRIAN MESSAGES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the. United States had received additional messages from the Syrian Government in the last few days that he hoped would lead to negotiations between Syria and Israel for troop disengagement.

title: British Union Asks Vote T o Shut Down Coal Mines
Coach Also Becomes GM
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 24 (UPI) Mary Levy, coach of the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League, also will assume the position of general manager next season, it was announced today.

title: Mother of Mario Puzo Dies
description: Mrs. Maria Puzo, mother of Mario Puzo, author of The Godfather, died Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. Shewas 85 years old and lived at 5419 24th Street, Astoria, Queens. She leaves, besides her son, three other sons and two daughters.

title: Senator Seeks to Delay Sale Of Signal Oil to Burmah, Inc.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Senator Floyd K. Haskell, Democrat of Colorado, asked the Justice Department today to try to delay the sale of the Signal Oil and Gas Company to Burmah Oil Inc.

title: ANGELO BUZZALLINO OF ROSE RESTAURANT
description: Angelo Buzzallino, the owner of Rose Restaurant, 41 West 52d Street, a gathering place for members of the advertising, broadcasting and publishing industries, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived in Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: Red Smith
description: On New Year's Eve, Notre Dame beat Alabama in the Sugar Bowl and was tapped as the bestcollege football team in America.

title: Carpi's Defense Rests; Summations Due Monday
description: TRENTON, Jan. 24  The defense rested today after presenting four days of testimony in the trial of Colin C. Carpi, the Princeton businessman accused of murdering his estranged wife in 1971 and dumping her body in New York's East River.

title: A Raise for 400,000
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 (UPI)  About 400,000 workers employed by the nation's basic steel industry will receive a ninecentsanhour costofliving wage increase Feb. 1, the United Steelworkers announced today.

title: Off Off Broadway
description: It is advisable to telephone theaters for schedules and prices before going to the show. Most, if not all, theaters accept Theater Development Fund vouchers.

title: LongRange Plans Could Transform West Side Highway Into U.S. Road
description: With accumulating shutdowns having chopped the West Side HighwayHenry Hudson Parkway into trafficchoked fragments, what are its longtermprospects?

title: E.E.C. Urges Price Rise In Official Gold Holdings
description: PARIS, Jan. 24A call by the European Economic Community's Commission for member states to use a higher price for gold than the present official rate, in settling intergovernmental accounts led to further bidding up of bullion on the free markets today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The 17th annual Louisville Sport, Boat and Vacation. Show will open tomorrow at the Kentucky Fair and Exposition Center, running for nine days. Last year, more than 167,000 visitors attended the show, the sixth largest in the country.

title: 4 Killed in India Riots
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 24 (UPI)  Four persons, including a police officer, were killed in shooting incidents today as riots over food continued in the state of Gujarat, the news agency Press Trust of India reported. Twentyfour persons have died in 15 days of rioting in the western state.

title: 3 FOUND NOT GUILTY IN EXTORTION CASE
description: Three reputed Mafia figures were acquitted in Federal Court here yesterday on charges that they had tried to extort $100,000 from two stock promoters.

title: SOVIET SCATHING ON SOLZHENITSYN
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 24  An eightfoothigh poster ridiculing the author Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn as a traitor appeared today in a display window on Gorky Street, the bustling main thoroughfare Moscow.

title: An Exorcism By Catholic Stirs a Furor
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26The Roman Catholic community here is embroiled in controversy over a religious ceremony of exorcism that was performer here last fall.

title: Krogh Gets 6 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Egil Krogh Jr. former head of secret White House investigative unit called the plumbers, was sentenced today to six months in prison on charges growing out of the burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist.

title: Annemarie Proell Gains Her 4th World Ski Cup
description: BAD GASTEIN, Austria, Jan, 24 (AP) Annemarie Proell of Austria wrapped up a fourth straight World Cup ski crown today with four races still to go, but not before some anxious moments in the judges quatters.

title: POLUGAEVSKY LOSES TO KARPOV IN CHESS
description: The Soviet grandmaster Anatoly Karpov defeated Lev Polugaevsky yesterday in the fourth game of their quarterfinal match of the world chess championship. They are playing in Moscow.

title: Concert
description: The splendid concert given by the Quartetto Beethoven di Roma at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night, the group's first appearance here, was hardly a debut in the usual sense. The quartet's members were old acquaintances, being former soloists of the celebrated Italian chamber, orchestra, I Musici.

title: British Union Asks Vote To Shut Down Coal Mines
U.S. Newsman Is Warned By Soviet Foreign Ministry
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 24 (Reuters) The Soviet Foreign Ministry today accused a United States news agency correspondent of I provocatory actions incompate ible with the status of a foreign journalist, the correspondent said today.

title: Case of Boy, 15, Cited
description: The request yesterday for an intensive look at the effects of legal gambling on the public comes at the height of agitation by civic groups against offtrack betting along with evidence that children are gambling with OTB.

title: Edward Butler Jr. Weds Inge von Reith
description: Miss Inge Bechtner von Georgetown University. He Reith, an actress and designalso is a manufacturers reper of folintains, was married resentative for boats. here yesterday afternoon to Edward, Enright Butler Jr., business consultant for the production of electric and mechanical devices. The Rev. Dr. Norrhan D. Stanton performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Trenton Considers Making Lobbyists Reveal Spending
description: The measure, in preparation by the state's Legislative Services Office, is being sponsored by State Senator John J. Fay Jr., Middlesex County Democrat, who said at a hearing held by the Senate Rules Committee today that it is a matter of interest of everyone to know how much money is being spent by lobbyists on any given bill.

title: Mrs. Joan Alexandre Tompkins is Married to David T. Harris
description: Mrs. Joan Alexandre Tompkins of Cedarhurst, L.I., was married here yesterday afternoon to David T. Harris of Greenwich, Conn., executive vice president of the United States Trust Company. The ceremony was performed in the Madison Avenue Pres. byterian Church by the minister, the Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read with only members of the immediate families present.

title: 6Year Study of Heart Ailments Seeks 12,000 MiddleAge Men
description: MARCO ISLAND, Fla., Jan. 24  Researchers throughout the country have begun to recruit 12,000 healthy middleaged men for a sixyear study to test the belief that lowering blood pressure, reducing fats in the diet and controlling cigarette smoking can curb the nation's epidemic of heart disease.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: ATLANTA, Jan 24 (UPI)Georgia's two Senators are calling for a Federal investigation into the decision by the Gulf Oil Company to close hundreds of Georgia service stations. Gulf firmly denies doing anything wrong and said the closings had been necessary. Senators Herman Talmadge and Sam Nunn issued a joint statement yesterday accusing Gulf of having damaged the state's economy by closing almost 400 retain outlets and 23 distributors. A ,Gulf spokesman said the number of stations closed in the last year was closer to 200, and the vast majority of those had been small, uneconomical operations, usually run in conjunction with a grocery or other small business. Gulf says it has about 1,700 outlets Georgia.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Police Department said yesterday that during 1973 there was a 3.3 per cent drop in the number reparted violent crimes against the person and a decrease of0.6 per cent in overall major crimes. This marked the second consecutive year in which there was slight decline in reported serious crime here.

title: 23 Boys Killed in Fire in a Belgian Catholic School
description: HEUSDEN, Belgium, Jan. 24 (AP)  Twentythree teenage boys were killed in a Catholic school dormitory fire here last night that police sources say may have been caused by youth smoking in bed.

title: Two Sue Over Homes of Nixon; Seek Refund of Public Monies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Two Democratic members of Congress filed a lawsuit in Federa! Court today charging President Nixon with illegally using taxpayers dollars to improve! and enhance his own properties at Key Biscayne, Fla and San! Clemente, Calif.

title: BUSINESS LOANS DECLINED IN WEEK
New Jersey Briefs
description: A former Hudson County official and two others were given suspended sentences in a scheme to use county park land for a private garbage dump. Superior Court Judge Thomas S. O'Brien said there was no purpose jailing the three when eight others charged in the case had not been jailed. The three were Anthony LeDonne, former member of the county's Mosquito Commission; Joseph F. Ruffo Jr. of Spotswood, and John Marsillo, South Nyack, N.Y. They had pleaded guilty to conspiring to dump garbage from New York on the undeveloped Liberty Park in Jersey City. The alleged scheme reportedly realized $250,000 in 196770. John V. Kenny, a former county political leader, was named as an unindicted coconspirator in the case.

title: DR. DEXTER O. ARNOLD
description: SANGERTIES, N.Y., Jan. 24 Dr. Dexter O. Arnold, superintendent of schools in this community since 1963, died yesterday in Kingston Hospital at the age of 66.

title: S.E.C. Eases Rates On Brokers'
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (Reuters)  The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today a major overhaul of the complicated informationreporting system it requires of brokerage firms.

title: Japanese Calligraphy Exalts Word as Art
description: The place occupied by the art of calligraphy in traditional Japanese culture has no exact counterpart in the esthetic conventions of the West. For the Japanese calligrapher, written characters are at once a literary medium and a form of visual art. The poet or novelist or essayist, is, in the very process of composition, an artist working in a realm of pure abstract design where perfection of visual nuance is organically related to the problems of literary expression. The writer in this tradition is an artist of the brush who is permittedand indeed encouragedto exercise a wide latitude of personal invention in the realization of his style.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES, FE
description: No one is getting any younger. It is one of those horribly inescapable facts of life. Come April 18, Jerome Robbins's ballet Fancy Free, celebrates its 30th birthday. Well, fancy that! Was anyone that young? At least the icing on the candy cake has not turned rancid.

title: G.O.P. Aide in Inquiry Albert Ernest Jenner Jr.
MRS. SOMMERICH, 94, HELPED NEW SCHOOL
description: Mrs. Edith Wise Sommerich, a leader in adult education and the widow of Otto C. Sommerich, an international lawyer, died yesterday at her home, 112 Central Park South. She was 94 years old.

title: Cable TV's Future
description: Cable television began in the United States as a technical means of bringing a clearer picture over mountains or around high city buildings. Today there are over 8,000 systems connecting almost eight million households.

title: G. E. Reports Profit Records
description: The chairman of the Genera; Electric Company said yester day that 1973 was definitely another record year, for the company. Reginald H. Jones, the G. E. chief executive, said at his annual news conference in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel that preliminary and unaudited figures showed sales of about $11.6billion, up about 13 per cent from $10.2billion for 1972.

title: House Curb on Aid Disaster for Poor, McNamara Says
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Robert S. McNamara, the president of the World Bank, said today that the vote yesterday by the House of Representatives to deny new United States contributions to the bank was an unmitigated disaster for hundreds of millions of people in the poorest nations of the world.

title: Measles Spreads; Immunization Drive Is Pressed by State
description: TRENTON, Jan. 24 (AP)The State Department of Health today warned that New Jersey had a serious measles epidemic, with more than a ten fold increase in cases over last year. One stricken child has died from measles complications.

title: The Poor Of The Earth
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24One of the bitter tragedies of the present world crisis is that the heaviest blows are falling, as usual, on the poor of the earth.

title: 2 Texans Post 65's For Lead
Chesimard Panelist Out For Reading Daley Book
description: MORRISTOWN, Jan. 24A prospective juror in the murder trial of Joanne D. Chesimard and Clark Squire was dismissed today after admitting reading in the Morris County courthouse a former police official's book dealing in part with Mrs. Chesimard.

title: U. S. Queries China on Fath Of Aide Lost in Paracels
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The United States has privately asked China to provide information on the whereabouts of a missing American and to release some 100 South Vietnamese taken prisoner during last weekend's battle in the Paracel Islands, Administration officials said today.

title: Text of Krogh Statement About His Role in the Plumbers BreakIn at Office of Ellsberg's Psychiatrist
POSTAL EMPLOYES RETURN TO WORK
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 24Both sides in the labor dispute at the New York Bulk and Foreign Mail Center here agreed today to a temporary settlement in the fourdayold work stoppage that followed management attempts to alter workshift hours

title: Excerpts From the Law and Court Ruling on Duryea Indictments
description: Section 457 of the Election Law

title: Brandt Praises Political Accord On Plans for Domestic Reforms
description: BONN, Jan. 24Willy Brandt whose Eastern policies have given West Germany relations with its Communist neighbors Thad ones, but a step beyond none at all, an adviser said recentlyhas takena step to ward another goal, to be the Chancellor of domestic reform.

title: PHILLIPS DISCLOSES OILINVENTORY DATA
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company, Bartlesville, Okla., reported yesterday that inventories of distillate fuel used for heating totaled 9.04 million barrels on Dec. 31, up from 7.47 million barrels a year earlier.

title: School Job to Giardino
description: Mayor Beame appointed Alfred A. Giardino, long a supporter of the City University and a former president of the Board of Education, as chairman of the Board of Higher Education. Page 37.

title: Cowboys Say W.F.L. Stole Data
description: Dirty tricks, which were so much a part of the drafting rivalry between the Atherican and National Leagues during their pro football war from 1960 to 1966, apparently will flavor the coming competition for top players between the N.F.L. and the new World Football League. Tex Schramm, president of the Dallas Cowboys, has claimed that the W.F.L. used confidential N.F.L. scouting reports to help conduct its draft of 72 college players last Tuesday. Schramm believed that the information was bought by the W.H.L. from someone in N.F.L. circles who had access to the reports.

title: Lindsey Becomes Coach
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 24 (AP) Dale Lindsey, who ended an eightyear playing career with the Cleveland Browns in 1972, was named linebacker coach today by the National Football League club.

title: Clergy Week Proclaimed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)  President Nixon proclaimed today the week of Feb. 3 as International Clergy Week in the United States in recognition of the spiritual and social work of the clergy throughout the world.

title: People Sports: Lions Lucci Retires
description: Mike Luce!, a 12year middle linebacker in the National Football Leaguenine with Detroit  retired yesterday and in passing, leveled a blast at Coach Don McCafferty.

title: Social Impact Questioned
description: Howard Samuels, the architect of offtrack betting, proposed yesterday that New Yorkers take a searching look at the social implications of gambling.

title: NUCLEAR OPTIONS STRESSED BY U. S.
Give Them a TryAnd Hope for Luck
description: My acquaintance with Spanish restaurants in New York has been rather drastically limited by addiction to Fornos, a venerable posada at 236 West 52d Street, where I have been in a rut for close onto 15 of the establishment's 50 years.

title: Hospital Price Rises Backed When Tied to Energy Costs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (Reuters)The Cost of Council said today that as interim measure it would permit hospitals, nursing homes and other health institutions to raise prices enough to offset higher energy costs.

title: Du Pont Planning to Phase Out Its Dynamite Business by 1976
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., announced yesterday that it would phase out its dynamite business in favor of cartridged watergel explosives sold under the name of Tovex. Du Pont said the new material was much safer than dynamite.

title: The Pop Life
description: In New York, putting the finishing touches to 10 weeks of filming, is Paul Williams, an actor turned song writer turned singer and now, completing the circle, turned film maker. Mr. Williams has done well in the song businessmillionselling versions of his compositions have been recorded by Three Dog Night and the Carpenters, and his own albums are successful.

title: ANGERED OIL MEN DISPUTE CHARGES OF SENATE CRITICS
description: The oil industry responded angrily yesterday to criticism and charges leveled at it by Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, and his Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, which is holding hearings on the nation's energy problems.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday it had been chosen to design and build a one and one half mile automatic transit system to span the Rio Grande River between the business districts of El Paso, Texas, and Juarez, Mex. The project is estimated to cost between $14million and $15million and will be privately financed.

title: HOUSTON SUSPECT HEARD ON KILLING
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 24  Elmer Wayne Henley Jr. took the stand in Harris County District Court today to describe the events of last August that led police to the graves of 27 teenagers believed to be the victims of a homosexual murder ring.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Spurs Win, 9384, As Averitt Stars
Krogh Gets 6 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Egil Krogh Jr. former head of secret White House investigative unit called the plumbers, was sentenced today to six months in prison on charges growing out of the burglary of the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist.

title: CocaCola Seeks to Buy Bottler Here
description: The CocaCola Company anounced yesterday it was holdlag discussions to acquire the CocaCola Bottling Company of New York, Inc., through a taxfree exchange of stock.

title: Article 2  No Title
CAHN AIDE TESTIFIES BEFORE GRAND JURY
description: Ronald Friedman, an assistant district attorney on the staff of Nassau County District Attorney William Cahn, testified yesterday for at least the fourth time, before a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn investigating Mr. Cahn's office.

title: Fordham, Seton Hall Defeated at Garden
William Macfarlane Dies; ExNew York Life Official
description: William Macfarlane, former vice president and chief actuary of the New York Life Insurance Company, died Tuesday at his home, 80 Park Ave. nue. His age was 85.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $779million, up 12 per cent from the. yearearlier $697million. Total retail store sales were about $8.739billion, up 6 per cent from last. year's $8.267billion.

title: Scharuk Farmed Out
description: The New York Rangers returned Lawrence Sacharuk, a defenseman, to the Providence Reds of the American Hockey League yesterday.

title: COURT DISMISSES ELECTION CHARGE AGAINST DURYEA
description: Election fraud charges against the two most powerful leaders 'of the State Assembly, Speaker Perry B. Duryea and Majority Leader John E. Kingston, were dismissed yesterday in State Supreme Court.

title: Bernstein Candide Revival Moves to Broadway Theater
description: The Chelsea Theater Center of Brooklyn will move its production of Candide to the Broadway Theater on March 5. The musical opened at the Brooklyn Academy, where the center is based, on Dec. 19, winning generally favorable notices.

title: GEN. HARRY SHERMAN
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., Jan. 24 (UPI)Brig. Gen. Harry B. Sherman, U.S.A. retired, who led infantrymen into North Africa and Sicily during World War II, died here Monday at the age of 79.

title: R. J. COAR, ENGINEER OF FIRESIDE CHATS
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan, 24 (AP) Robert J. Coar, an electrical engineer who handled the technical work on the famed fireside chats of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died yesterday in Guadalajara, Mexico. He was 68 years old

title: ShotPut Is Restored At Millrose
New Jersey Sports
description: NEWARK, Jan. 24The reason Monmouth College has triumphed in six of its last seven basketball games, is that the freshmen and sophomores have started to play as team, according to Bill Boylan, the coach.

title: Mrs. loan Alexa Is Married to ndre Tompkins David T. Harris
description: Mrs. Joan Alexander Tompkins of Cedarhurst, L.I., was married here yesterday afternoon to David T. Harris of Greenwich, Conn., executive vice president of the United States Trust Company. The ceremony was performed in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the minister, the Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read with only members of the immediate fanilies present.

title: People and Business
description: Joseph M. Mergen, president and chief executive officer of the Piper Aircraft Corporation, has resigned after more than four years in the post. Mr. Mergen, who is 57 years old, is a veteran of the aircraft industry and was formerly an executive of the CurtissWright Corporation and the Lycoming division of the Avco Corporation.

title: Art Association Meets; Considers Jobs, Royalties
description: DETROIT, Jan. 24Should artists get royalties? How does Picasso rate with art historians? Can women artists preserve both sisterhood and standards? What are the latest developments in Chinese art and archeology? And how do you sell your talents in a bearish job market?

title: Q's Defeat Squires On Big 4th Quarter
Giardino Named Chairman Of HigherEducation Board
description: Alfred A. Giardino, a longtitne supporter of the City University and a former president of tlie'Board of Education, was appointed yesterday by Mayor Beame to be chairman of the reorganized Board of Higher EducAtion.

title: Margaret Mead Puts Single Life in Perspective
description: The Barnard Columbia Alumni Social Committee, a yearold group referred to by some of its members as the city's most intellectual singles club, gathered the other night to hear one of the city's most intellectual singles, Dr. Margaret Mead.

title: Environmental Plan on Oil Given Senators by Morton
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI)  Interior Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton said today that he was planning a new approach to prevent environmental damage from increased offshore oil drilling.

title: Last Month's Price Of Market Basket Was Near Record
description: A department report indicated that the annual retail cost of the market basket reached $1,650 in December, up 1 per cent from November because of increases in both farm prices and the middleman's margin with represents the gap between farm and retail prices.

title: Pentagon Aide Cited in Plot to Head F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 A Pentagon investigator was identified tonight by informed sources as the man who, White House aides believed, tried to force hls way into the directorship of the Federal Bureau of Investigation by indicating that he might make public his knoWledge of the passing of Nafibrin Security Council documents to the Pentagon.

title: Life Sentence Given
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Jan. 24 (AP)  Henry Bys Jr., 24 years old, was found guilty yesterday of firstdegree murder and was sentenced to life imprisonment in the killing of Monica Tins, a Smith College coed.

title: Aetna Life's Directors Set 2for1 Stock Split
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company announced last night that its board of. directors had approved a twoforone stock split. The company said the directors had indicated the intention to increase quarterly cash dividend payments on May 15 to 54 cents from 50 cents per common share on existing stock.

title: About New York The Joys of Coping With City Life
description: An accountant whose car was broken into recently brooded about it for a while and then decided that his sense of outrage had to be somehow assuaged. Consequently, he got some gift boxes from Abercrombie & Fitch and filled them with garbage. Lovingly he tied ribbons around the boxes and put them on the back seat of the car.

title: TV:Shall We Have a King? Views Presidency
description: Shall We Have a King scheduled for the Public Broadcasting Service this Sunday from 5:30 to 7 P.M., follows by only a few days the Bill Moyers examination of A Question of Impeachment and provides still another valuable study of the American Presidency.

title: NEW RULES ON NOISE
Berlin Environment
description: The West German Government has leaned over back ward to avoid disputes with Moscow on Berlin and the 1972 FourPower agreement there. To normalize relations with Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Bulgaria, it shelved its implied right under that agreement to represent West Berlin courts and other institutions in Communist countries. But Bonn now has wisely put its foot downwith the backing of the Western alliesand gone ahead, despite Soviet protests, with a decision to set up a new federal office in West Berlin, the first since the quadripartite agreement was signed.

title: Roger Wilkins to Join The Times
description: Roger Wilkins, former Assistant United States Attorney General, will join the editorial board of The New York Times on May 1, it was announced yesterday by John B. Oakes, editor of the editorial page.

title: Higher Film Fees Urged for Oil Countries
description: Charles Bluhdorn, chairman and chief executive officer of Gulf & Western Industries, proposed to the Motion Picture Association of America yesterday a price increase on American films shown in countries that supply oil and other commodities to the United States. Gulf & Western is the parent company of the Paramount Pictures Corporation.

title: Sky Operators Plan Comeback With Aid of Manmade Snow
description: NEW ASHFORD, MASS., Jan. 23  In a winter when snowstorms have tapered off with rain, the morale of the northeast's ski area operators generally remains surprisingly high.

title: CHANDLER A. MACKEY
description: Chandler A. Mackey, the founder in 1914 and president since then of C. A. Mackey & Co., importer of green coffee, died Wednesday in Caledonian Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 84 years old and lived at 455 East 19th Street, Brooklyn.

title: $5,000 for a Cut
description: CHRISTIANSTED, V. I., Jan. 24 (UPI)  A United States District Court jury ordered the Coca Cola Bottling Company plant here yesterday to pay $5,000 damages to a woman who was cut, by glass from bottle of soda that burst. Mrs. Anna Deering brought the civil action against the plant, alleging that she suffered a oneinch cut above her eye when a bottle of sprite exploded March 6, 1971.

title: Brooklyn Apartments for Aged Passed, but Not Nursing Home
description: The Board of Estimate, after several hours of heated testimony by contending factions of Brooklyn residents, voted final approval for a controversial apartment project for the elderly in Bay Ridge,.but deferred a decision on a nursing home in the KensingtonFlatbuth section.

title: Details on Mideast Pullback Completed
description: CAIRO, Jan. 24  Final arrangements for separating the Egyptian and Israeli forces on the Suez front were completed today, and the formally scheduled withdrawal process is to be started by both sides tomorrow.

title: Life Sentence Given
description: NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Jan. 24 (AP)  Henry Bys Jr., 24 years old, was found guilty yesterday of firstdegree murder and was sentenced to life imprisOnment in the killing of Monica. Tims, a Smith College coed.

title: Steinbeck Whimsy Found in Kennedy Files
description: WALTHAM, Mass., Jan. 24 It might have been blatant patronage, but Adlai E. Stevenson felt compelled to pass the request along to President Kennedy because it contained a promising new foreign policy initiative. John Steinbeck, the author, was interested in a diplomatic post.

title: L.I.R.R., Signalmen Union Reach Tentative Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24The National Mediation Board announced today that the Long Island Rail Road and the Brotherhood of Railroad Signalmen had reached tentative agreement in their longstanding dispute.

title: Greece Sentences Two Arabs to Death
description: Palestinian, and Tallal Khaled Kaddourah, a Lebanese, both 22 years old, were given the death penalty on five counts for having committed a particularly odious crime. Each was also sentenced

title: State Plans to Aid Students Attending Private Colleges
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24A joint higher education committee of the State Legislature is expected to present a major program next week to subsidize students attending private colleges and universities throughout the state.

title: EDWARD F. MERREY
description: PATERSON, N. J., Jan. 24Edward F. Merrey who was said to be the oldest practicling lawyer in New Jersey when he retired in 1972 after 77 years of general practice, died today at the Van Dyk Nursing Home, North Ridgewood. He was 99 years old.

title: Earnings Soar at Mobil and Texaco,. Shell Only Oil Major to Report Dip
description: The secondand thirdlargest oil companies in the nation the Mobil Oil Corporation and Texaco, Inc.  reported yesterday substantially higher profits for the fourth quarter of 1973, when the Arab embargo began. The Shell Oil Company, also porting, became the first of the majors to show a profit decline in the period.

title: JAPAN CAUTIONED ON SALES TO U. S.
description: TOKYO, Jan. 24  Assistant Secretary of State Robert S. Ingersoll cautioned the Japanese today to avoid mounting an export drive into the American market to earn dollars for costly Middle Eastern oil imports.

title: Business Briefs
description: DETROIT, Jan. 24The General Motors Corporation announced today that about 75,000 production workers would be laid off temporarily at 14 of its assembly plants that produce large cars. Richard C. Gerstenberg, G.M.'s chairman, said that the layoffs of one or two weeks were due to cutbacks in the production of standard and luxury cars, which are not selling well because of customer concern over the fuel shortage.

title: O. BRYAN EARLES JR.
description: O. Bryan Butes Jr., president since 1972 of the Dover Corporation, manufacturer of elevators and industrial products, died Wednesday while on a business trip to Cincinnati. He was 51 years old and lived at 438 Middlesex Road, Dariend Conn.

title: Loyalty Oath
description: By holding that the Communist party in Indiana cannot be denied a place on the Presidential ballot for its refusal to sign a loyalty oath, the Supreme Court seems at first glance merely to have reaffirmed the principle that there ought to be no artificial barriers placed between candidates and the electorate. Unfortunately, the Court, though unanimous on the specific issue, divided over the reason for its ruling in a manner that has ominous forebodings.

title: Music: 2Piano Works
For a Grassroots VicePresidency
description: WASHINGTONWhen our shiny new Vice President, in his first major speech in AtlantiC City the other day, castigated the President's Watergate enemies and voiced his belief in the President's innocence, it should not have been surprising that the time, occasion and the subject were selected IV the President and that the speech was written by the President's staff.

title: MACKELL LINKED TO SWINDLE FUND
description: Joseph Ferdinando, a convicted swindler, told a State Supreme Court jury yesterday that former District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens and 16 other members of Mr. Mackell's office had invested at least $200,000and probably more  in his getrichquick scheme that promised investors lucrative weekly interest payments.

title: Independent Trucker coalition Calls For U.S.Shutdown Jan.31
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  A coalition of independent truck drivers called today for a nationwide truck shutdown on Jan. 31 unless the Government acts on problems they contend were caused by the fuel shortage.

title: Amex Stocks Rise by 0.06 Point; OTC Issues Off After 2 Gains
Gang Turning Slum Housing Into Coop
description: Four years ago, Eulogio Cedeno was a drug addict serving time for the possession of stolen goods. Today, he and others in a youth gang called the Renigades, along with members of 15 households, are using city loan funds and their own labor to treat new homes for their families out of a battered and abandoned East Harlem tenement. remained abondoned for about a year, according to the Housing and Development Administration. The agency yesterday approved a $320,000 municipal loan for the renovation, with the remaining $140,000 worth of labor to be contributed as the sweat equity.

title: Fontaine, Chapman Penalized at Roosevelt
description: Howard Dobler, the new presiding judge at Roosevelt Raceway, was both a dispenser and a recipient of disciplinary action yesterday.

title: Nixon Endorses Advance School Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The Nixon Administration sounding an old theme with new hope, called on Congress today to streamline programs of Federal aid to education.The appeal came in a Presidential education message and was coupled with an endorsement of a funding device help schools plan their budgets with less guesswork and promise of money to put it into effect.

title: Notes on People
description: Mr. Perk won a solid reelection victory in Cleveland, a;Democratic stronghold, last November. At that time he Promised to serve a full term. Yesterday he said that he :planned only a. minimum of campaigning during the primary and that he would be a fulltime Mayor throughout mach of the general election campaign.

title: 2 Arabs Condemned
description: A Greek court last night sentenced to death two Arabs Who killed five persons and wounded 55 in a grenade attack at the Athens airport last August. Page 8.

title: Wednesday Night Sports
Men Steal Scene in 2 Plays for Women
description: The W.P.A. (Workshop of the Players Art) is one of the most productive Off Off Broadway theaters. Instead of doing one play at a time, the W.P.A. rotates works and stages festivals. Currently it is presenting Women! Women!, a festival of new plays written by and about women.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: If the girl who intended to marry the ambitious Mr. Snow in the musical Carousel attained her heart's desire, she may now be suggesting to her husband that they buy a motel.

title: JUNE ADAMS QUAIN
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24 (AP)June Adams Quain, an Associated Press reporter in NeW York State for 25 years, died today after a long illniss. She was 56 years old.

title: U.S. Financial Sued By Touche Ross Firm

title: Pro Tennis Group Cuts US LTA Link
Senate Democrats Name Panel to Study if One Committee Should Handle Energy Investigations and Bills
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Senate Democrats moved today to begin a study of energy problems and bring the disarray of multiplying investigations into focus under one special committee, such as the one created to inquire into the Watergate scandals.

title: Another Agnew Deal?
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 Richard Nixon is talking more toughly than ever about his intention to stay in the White House. He is talking so toughly that some Democrats have been reminded of Vice President Agnew, just before the latter's nolo contendere plea and resignation. But the best bet is that nothing like that is in Mr. Nixon's mind.

title: Duryea Just Can't Find Sponsor For Bill to Give Lefkowitz Raise
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24In what is widely assumed to be a silent rebuke of Attorney General Louis J. Lefitowitzy by some fellow Republicans, a bill that would provide. a $10,000ayear raise for the post of Attorney General. in 1975 has failed to attract a sponsor among the Assembly's Republican majority controlled by Speaker Perry B. Duryea.

title: Births
description: GARRETTMr. and Mrs. David Garrett announce the birth of their son, JAy Todd, born January 21 1974. Mr. Garrett is an executive with the Telephonics DiVision of Instrument Systems Corp. of Huntington, N.Y.

title: Kilometer 101: Jokes and Serious Talk

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24An employe of the Howard R. Hughes organization met with President Nixon in San Clemente. Calif just after delivering half of a $100,000 campaign contribution from his billionaire employer to Charles G Rebozo, the President's close friend, the Senate Watergate. committee has been told.

title: PLUMBERS OUSTED HIM, KROGH SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24Egil Krogh Jr. said today that he was dismissed from his White House plumbers assignment in December, 1971, after he refused to authorize a wiretap in connection with an investigation into the publication of the IndiaPakistan papers.

title: ADMISSION IS LAID TO MONTEMARANO
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 24Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano was quoted at his murder trial by witness today as having said that a. former colleague, Dr. John Howard Strimas, held something over my, head because I did something unethical.

Terror Punished

title: Tito given Nehru Award
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 25 (Reuters)President Tito of Yugoslavia received the Jawaharlal Nehru Award for International Understanding today. At the ceremony, Marshal Tito recalled his friendship with Mr. Nehru, India's first Prime Minister, saying, It fills me with pride to think that we together launched the policy of nonalignment,

title: Music: A Mass of Life
description: Walter Sussklnd brought the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra to Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, and devoted his entire program to A Mass of Life by Frederick Delius. The work is not heard very often; it demands a big orchestra, chorus and four soloists. Delius is not that popular a composer. But there are signs of a return to his kind of music. Certainly the audience, a fairsized one, seemed impressed.

title: Redskins Obtain Theismann Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI)The Washington Redskins have acquired the rights to Joe Theismann, former star quarterback at Notre Dame, from the Miami Dolphins, Coach George Allen announced today. In exchange, the Dolphins will get the Redskins' firstround draft choice in 1976.

title: Argentina Enacts Contested Curbs on Terrorism
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 25The Peronistcontrolled Congress today passed a controversial terrorism bill virtually doubling prison sentences for kidnappers, conspirators and armed extremists and turning over internalsecurity functions to the federal police rather than local lawenforcement officers.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, asked the General Accounting Office today for a legal opinion on the precise authority of Congress to oversee goernment intelligence agencies.

description: Dispatch of The Times. London

title: Art: The Klee Gift for Complexity
description: it is sometimes hard to believe that only five years hence we shall be observing the centenary of the birth of Paul Klee. It doesn't seem possible that an artist whose work embodies so many of the fundamental strategies of modern painting should belong to such a distant era. As we encounter particular picturessay, in the section devoted to Klee in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Artwe are tempted to claim him as a contemporary, yet in truth he is more and more an ancestor, a progenitor of, rather than a participant in the art of our time.

description: Although David Parkin's animalaaren't like any you'll meet on safari or at the zoo, you'll have no trouble identifying his hippo, camel, tor. toise, elephant and lion. The former industrial designer has used artistic license in his Nature of the Beast collection of aluminum sculptures, but has based ihem on the study of nature.

title: P.&O. AGAIN BIDDING TO BUY BOVIS, LTD.
description: The Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company, the world's largest passenger Shipping line, ,announced yesterday in London that it had made a bid to acquire Bovis, Ltd., a major British construction company. Members of the Bovis board said they would accept the bid. They control 15.8 per cent of Bovis's common shares.
