title: 10 Killed in India Mishap
description: NE WDELHI, Jan. 25 (UPI)Ten persons were killed and 22 injured when a passenger bus hit a bridge railing and tumbled into a river today near Trichur, about 150 miles south of Madras, according to the Press Trust of India news agency.

title: Crude Oil Prices Rise at Some Auctions
Way Devised to Get Power From Rock
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25As the Government received $6.81million in high bids this week on land for geothermal exploration, the Atomic Energy Commission got a patent for a new method of extracting heat from underground reservoirs. Three inventors at the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, operated for the A.E.C. by the University of California, were granted Patent 3,786,858 on a process to get electric power from hot, dry rock. Patents of the WeekIn the current production of geothermal power, natural steam or hot brine is used. Under the patented process, holes are to be fractured in a dry rock with a temperature of about 300 degrees Centigrade and cold water is to be pumped in. Steam from the water so heated will be passed through an electric generating plant and the water recirculated.The A.E.C. has granted the laboratory $3million to explore the process. The plan is to drill several holes 5,000 or 6,000 feet deep at the site of volcano, in the Jemez mountains of New Mexico not far from Los Alamos.

description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 25Yale University announced, today that its prized Vinland Map, showing North America as discovered by Leif Ericson centuries before Columbus, had been determined to be an elaborate and highly skillful forgery.

title: SIMON BACKS IDEA OF CUTTING PRICES FOR NEW U. S. OIL;
HARLEM PREP ENDS WITH CLASS OF 74
description: Parlem Prep closed its doors as an independent school yesterday. The class of 1974, the school's seventh and last before the city takes it over, was graduated in an emotionfilled Ceremony in the Martin Luther King Auditorium at Harlem Hospital.

title: Utah Aide Named Coach
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 25 (UPI)Tom Lovat, defensive line coach of the University of Utah, was named head football coach today. The university's president, David P. Gardner, announced the selection of Lovat, 35 years old, the only remaining member of Bill Meek's staff. Meek resigned under pressure three weeks ago after six years as head coach.

title: C.A.B. INVESTIGATING AIRLINES'
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today it was investigating whether banks, insurance companies and other major creditors of the airline industry exert undue influence on airline management.

title: A Most Reluctant Witness
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  Senator Hugh Scott came out of the White House the other day announcing he bad seen evidence which, if made public; would clear President Nixon of all suspicions arising from the scandals called Watergate. After him, Vice President Ford went to the White House and came out announcing that the evidence was there, all right, but that he had not read it. Thanks to a highly placed White House leak, we produce below the minutes of the meeting between President Nixon and Mr. Ford:

title: Israelis Formally Begin Suez Bridgehead Pullout
Sports News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (UPI)Willie Mosconi, the 60yearold former world pocket billiards champion, beat the British snooker champion, Rex Williams, last night to take the Black Velvet challenge series and win $15,000. The two billiards experts concluded the 17day, sixcity tourney in snooker and straight pool at the Illinois Athletic Club. Mosconi was 88 points ahead before Chicago. The pair went 20 innings in a tight final pool match before Mosconi won, 15058.

title: Iowa. Adds ASsistant
description: IOWA CITY, Ian. 25 (AP)  Tom Cecchini, former head football coach at Xavier University, in Cincinnati, has been added. to the football staff at the University of Iowa. Xavier dropped football after the 1973 season because of financial difficulties.

title: U.S. Expects No Easing of Fuel Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 John C. Sawhill, the deputy administrator of the Federal Energy Office, said today that despite the nation's improved supplies of heating oil, he expected no relaxation of fuelconservation requirements, not even next winter.

title: SKYLAB 3 SET MARK FOR TIME IN SPACE
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 25 (UPI)The Skylab 3 astronauts entered the record books again today in logging the greatest total time in space. They said they were anxious to return home after the 84day mission.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Most postal workers returned to their jobs at the New York Bulk and Foreign Mail Center in Jersey City yesterday during the first day of a oneweek cooling off period ordered by the courts in the dispute between labor and management over changes in hours. Postal service spokesmen said negotiations between union leaders and postal service officials from Washington might begin this weekend.

title: Chilean President's Last Moments Recorded as His Government Fell
description: Photographs of the last moments' of Salvador Allende Gossens, President of Chile, have become available from a fornier member of his staff.

title: Parley Says Oil Cut Reduces Fertilizer
description: Weather changes, notably a southward migration of the monsoons, combined with sharp reduction in fertilizer production, threaten fooa supplies for a considerable part of the world population, according to experts on climate and agriculture who completed a twoday meeting yesterday at the Rocke feller foundation.

title: Clerics in Bolivia Say Crisis Is Result of Bad Government
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 25 (AP)Leaders of the Roman Catholic church here told President Hugo Banzer Suirez today that Inefficiency and corruption in high places were to blame for the worst crisis in his 29 months in office.

title: Campaneris to Get Award
description: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 25 (AP)Bert Campaneris, Oakland As shortstop, has been added to the list of sports personalities to be honored at the third annual Kansas City baseball awards dinner Feb. 3 Campaneris will receive the World Series Hero Award

title: Notes on People
description: Fifty years ago today, huge motorcade led by 40 cavalrymen escorted Crown Prince Hirohito and his bride Nagako through the streets of downtown Tokyo, as hundreds of thousands cheered. He became Emperor Hirohito of Japan less than a year later, and reigned with Empress Nagako through the most turbulent era in Japanese history  depression, war, atomic attack, defeat, occupation and recovery.

title: Dance
description: Piloholus by any other name would be easier to, pronounce, but would hardly be more enjoyable. This formerly allmale dance.company, which last summer added its first women dancers, gave its initial New York performance of the year at the Hunter College Playhouse on Wednesday evening. The happy occasion was a benefit for the Skowhegan School of Paintibg and Sculpture.

title: laneIli Set Down 30 Days
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP)  Frank lanelli, a jockey, was suspended for 30 days by Gulfstream stewards today for failing to make a proper effort in a race, track officials said.

title: Ali, Frazier Are Fined For Demeaning Boxing
description: In a courtroomlike setting involving a tape recording, missing witnesses and a defense attorney pleading that no one prejudge his client, Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier were fined $5,000 apiece yesterday for deplorable conduct that demeaned boxing.

title: Parley Says Oil Cut Reduces Fertilizer
FORD STAYS ALOOF FROM DATA FELT TO ABSOLVE NIXON
Jury Is Told Doctor Confessed Killing
description: MINEOLA, LI., Jan. 25In the most dramatic moment so far in the nineday murder trial of Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano, the chairman of the surgery department of the Nassau County Medical Center broke down on the witness stand today as he was testifying that Dr. Montemarano had confessed killing a terminally ill cancer patient.

title: On Fighting the Terrorism of Terrorisms
description: Following are excerpts from a paper presented in English at a conference in Houston on human rights that commemorated the 25th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

title: A Panhandler Gives Birth on F Train
description: A 40yearold woman who had been living in the city's parks and subways for seven months, panhandling for food money, gave birth in the predawn hours yesterday to a boy on the floor of a subway car in Brooklyn.

title: QUEENS YOUTH HELD IN DEATHS OF 2 BOYS
description: A 19yearold Queens youth, Wai Chiu Mah, was charged with homicide yesterday in the deaths of two teenage brothers who were shot in their Brooklyn apartment after four youths invaded it last Jan. 18.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE DIARY OF SAMUEL SEWALL, 16741729. Edited by M. Halsey Thomas. Two volumes. 1,254 pages. Illustrated. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $30.

title: SENTENCE BALKED IN DEATH OF GIRL, 7
description: HACKENSACK, Jan. 25 (UPI) A former schoolteacher, Joseph McGowan, who has pleaded guilty to murdering a Brownie Girl Scout, was refused sentencing today by Superior Court Judge Fred C. Galda, who said the slaying should be classified as a sex crime.

title: Amax to Lift Coal Output
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 25 (UPI) American Metal Climax, diversified, metals and minerals company, announced today major capitalexpenditure pro gram that is designed to triple the company's annual coal pro duction by 1978, from 16.6 million to 50 million tons. Ex penditures at an average an nual rate of $95million for the next three years are planned.

title: Frenchmen Ahead in Gliding
description: WAIKERIE, Australia, Jan. 25 (UPI)Francois Ragot of France averaged 68.5 miles an hour today to take provisional first place in the open class of the world gliding championships. All American pilots but George Moffat have lost any chance of winning a title at these championships.

title: FORD STAYS ALOOF FROM DATA FELT TO ABSOLVE NIXON
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 254 Vice President Ford said today that he had decided not to ex. amine evidence that the White House asserted would clear President Nixon of involve. ment in the Watergate affair and its coverup.

title: G.M. Warns of Seat Belts On 74 Intermediate Cars
description: DETROIT, Jan. 25 (UPI) The General Motors Corporation said today that some 26,500 new intermediatesize cars may have seat belts that could fail to hold frontseat occupants securely in an accident or during hard braking.

title: Mobil Lifts Payout Following Net Rise
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation yesterday followed up its Thursday announcment of higher profits by declaring both an increase in its regular quarterly dividend and an extra dividend.

title: High School Notes
description: The members of the Vikings, the highlyrated varsity basketball team at South Shore High School in Brooklyn, carries the idea of togetherness beyond the boundaries of the gymnasiuni.

title: Nixon Lifts Quotas On Wheat Imports For Five Months
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25President Nixon suspendect. import restrictions on wheat today but the White House deflied that the action Signaled an impending grain shortage.

title: Qaddafi Flies to Geneva to Meet on Merger Plan With Tunisian
description: GENEVA, Jan. 25  Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the Libyan head of state, flew here today and met with President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia for further discussions on the projected merger of their two nations.

title: Fire Kills Five in Family
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP)A mother and four of her children died early today when fire swept their South Side home, the authorities said. The victims were identified as Sandra Thompson, 38 years old; James Jr., 8, Rodney, 5, Janice, 19, and Renee, 12.

title: Israelis Formally Begin Suez Bridgehead Pullout
description: SUEZ, Occupied Egypt, Jan. 25Israeli forces on the western bank of the Suez Canal formally began their withdrawal today, pulling out tanks, trucks and tons of other heavy equipment from the bridgehead they have occupied since the Oct. 24 ceasefire.

title: Saigon Proposes Relations With Hanoi
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Satmday, Jan. 26:South Vietnam proposed today that Saigon and Hanoi establish diplomatic relations in a new effort to break the deadlock and to, explore all the paths susceptible to lead to )eace.

title: People and Business
description: In line with the recent decision by the nation's oil companies to improve their public image, the Mobil Oil Corporation has named Herman J. Schmidt to the new post of vice chairman, with specific responsibility for public affairs. Like many of the top public affairs officials in the petroleum industry, he comes from an operating background.

title: 2 Shows Offer Pleasures of Sculpture
description: The pleasures of contemporary. American sculpture.. its seriousness and its range  are readily apparent in two current exhibitions: a show of six large sculptures by as many, artists  Peter Agostini, Mary Frank, Raoul Hague, Richard Stankiewicz, George Sugarman and Michael Todd at the Zabriskie Gallery, 29 West 57th Street; and a oneman showing of figurative pieces in bronze and wax by Richard McDermott Miller at the Washburn Gallery, 820 Madison Avenue at 69th Street.

title: FireStruck Track Cited on Violations
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 25 (AP) River Downs Race Track, scene of a fire last June in which 16 horses died, has been ordered to make grandstand, jockey quarter and clubhouse repairs to meet state fire regulations, officials said.

title: HOPE IS HELD OUT FOR LOST NEWSMEN
description: At least some journalists reported missing in Southeast Asia are being held by Cambodian insurgent forces, a committee headed by Walter Cronkite has asserted.

title: Specialty Items Dominate A Lackluster Stock Market
LAW ON PRESERVING CEMETERIES UPHELD
description: TRENTON, Jan. 25 (AP)The state's second highest court today upheid a 1971 state law that regulates funds established to preserve gravesites and the grounds of private cemeteries.

title: Jury Is Told Doctor Confessed Killing
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 25In the most dramatic moment so far in the nineday murder trial of Dr. Vincent A. Montemarano, the chairman of the surgery department of the Nassau County Medical Center broke down on the witness stand. today as he was testifying that Dr. Montemarano had confessed killing a terminally ill cancer patient.

title: SHULTZ REPORTED PLANNING TO QUIT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 George P. Shultz reportedly has finally decided to resign as Secretary of the Treasury.

title: P.B.A. Ratifies Contract By 8,211 to 7,855 Votes
description: Members of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association ratified a new oneyear contract with the city by a narrow margin, the union announced yesterday.

title: Soccer Job to Sewell
description: ST. LOUIS,.Tan. 25 (AP)The St. Louis Stars soccer team named John Sewell today as playercoach for the 1974 season. Sewell 37 years old, is a fullback for the North American Soccer League team. He succeeds Casey Frankiewicz.

title: A Visit to Injured Syrian Prisoners in Israel
TRAMUNTI CALLED HEROIN MR BIG
description: Carmine Tramunti, a reputed Mafia boss, was described at the opening of his narcotics trial here yesterday as the Mr. Big who financed the wholesale distribution of heroin in a highly organized conspiracy.

title: TROOPCOST TALKS WITH BONN STALL
description: BONN, Jan. 25Negotiations between West Germany and the United States on a new agreement aimed at offsetting the cost of maintaining American troops here have been at a standstill since November.

title: Tayler First in 10,000 in New Zealand
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Jan. 25 (AP)Dick Tayler of New Zealand captured the 10,000meter track gold medal today in the Commonwealth Games after David Bedford, the world recordholder, had scrapped and elbowed for the lead with three Kenyans.

title: Dr. Paul Berlin, Professor And Obstetrician on L.I., 51
description: BAY SHORE, LI., Jan. 25Dr. Paul E. Berlin, senior obstetrician at Southside Hospital, died there yesterday after long illness. He was 51 years old and lived here.

title: Like a Cat On a Hot Tin Roof
description: MILAN, ItalySome years ago an. astute European ambassador confessed: I cannot figure these people out They slip' from crisis to crisis and one almost always assumes they are doomed. But Italy is like a cat. It can fall off the roofbut always lands on its feet and scampers away intact.

title: Gen. Albert C. Smith Dies; Commanded in World Wars
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) Albert C. Smith, a retired Army major general, died yesterday of kidney failure in Welter Reed Army Medical Center. He was 79 years old.

title: Bodies in Crash Recovered
description: PANGUITCH, Utah, Jan. 25 (UPI)Snowmobiles hauled the bodies of six northern Californians killed Sunday in the crash of a light plane off a snowcovered mountainside today. The victims were Kenneth de Meuse, a wealthy Hayward yachtsman; John Parks 4th, a former Congressional candidate, of San Francisco; his wife, Ninia; their son, Gregory, 19 years old, and daughter, Shan non, 16, and Gilbert Radzat, 34, a San Francisco banker.

title: Bank of Japan Charges Speculation Against Yen
description: TOKYO, Jan. 25 (UPI)The Bank of Japan accused today three of Tokyo's largest private banits of using their deposits to ,speculate against Japan's currency, the yen.

title: REALTY OUTFIT LOSES SUIT FOR 100MILLION
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday dismissed a $100million damage suit against the Government brought by the Trump Management Corporation, a major realty concern here, and advised the company's counsel to answer, instead allegations that the company had discriminated against blacks in apartment rentals.,

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DEBUT One of the most momentous musical events in recent years takes place tonight at 8 in Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street (CI 77459). The New York Jazz Repertory Company gives its first performance, an occasion marking the beginning of a jazz company that will, its founders hope, be as permanent a cultural asset as the New York Philharmonic, the New York City Ballet and the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Louie, Cover the Stairs. You Get the Attic.
Official Says Nixon's Deed On Gift Was Falsely Dated
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 25The deed for President Nixon's donation of his VicePresidential papers to the National Archives was signed long after his eligibility had expired for tax deductions that he claimed for them, the California Secretary of State's office said today.

title: Fire in Brussels Palace
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 25 (UPI)Fire apparently due to. a short circuit broke out above the music room of the royal palace here today, causing minor damage in the attic, a palace spokesman said.

title: Amazon Roads Extend the Reach of Civilization
description: ALONG THE TRANSAMAZON HIGHWAY, BrazilThe Brazilianbuilt station wagon speeds at 50 miles an hour along the narrow, unpaved, marooncolored road cut through the endless forest, and suddenly the jungle ,seems not so forbidding.

title: U.C.L.A. Is Waiting For Irish
Black Nurses Volunteer Their Assistance in Newark
Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Nostalgia for Old Days At the Rome Shows...
Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Sports Today
PEKING REPORTS HOLDING U.S. AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 China has informed the United States that she is holding an American Embassy observer who was reported missing last weekend during a battle between Chinese and South Vietnamese forces in the Paracel Islands, the State Department said today.

title: Ralph R. Bartelsmeyer, 64; Deputy U.S. Highway Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) Ralph R. Bartelsmeyer, Depu ty Federal Highway Adminisstrator in the Department of Transportation since 1970, died today at Sibley Hospital, He was 64 years old.

title: Appeals Court Reinstates Coast Suit Against I.T.T.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reinstated yesterday a suit against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Republican National Committee over a $100,000 convention contribution by an I.T.T. subsidiary.

title: AUTO MAKERS APPLY TO TRADE WITH CUBA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) The Treasury Department confirmed tonight that the Big Three United States automobile companies had applied for licenses for their Argentine subsidiaries to sell cars and trucks to Cuba.

title: CHARLES P. ROTHMANN
description: Charles P. Rothmann, vice president of Moran, Stahl & Boyer, Inc;, a New York realestate consulting organization, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Thursday in New York Hospital. He was 38 years old and lived here.

title: Lefkowitz Bill Seeks OilCompany Reports
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz proposed a bill yesterday requiring oil companies to submit regular reports about their production and inventories.

title: :Blacks Fear Layoffs and Rising Costs in Energy Crisis
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 25The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson reared back, gazed up at the marble facing on an immense, almost cornpleted skyscraper and said to several hundred followers: See that building? That's why you can't get gas. While that building was going up, employment going down.

title: France Said to Plan ATests
description: TOKYO, Jan. 25 (AP) France plans a new series of nuclear tests around Mururoa Atoll in the South Pacific again this year despite sharp protests from New Zealand, Australia and other nations, the Maritime Safety Agency reported today.

title: Mitsubishi Planning to Join Canadian Tar Sands Work
description: TOKYO, Jan. 25 (UPI)The Mitsubishi Petrochemical Comipany confirmed today that it planned to develop tar sands in the Canadian province of Alberta jointly with the Great Canadian Oil Sand Company.

title: COURTS POSTPONES HUGHES DECISION
description: RENO, Jan. 25Lawyers for Howard R. Hughes successfully forestalled today the issuance of a bench warrant for their billionaire clientat least until next Wednesday.

title: Mrs. ChesimardIll; Selection of a Jury. Postponed by Judge
description: MORRISTOWN, Jan. 25Jury selection in the murder.,,,, trial of Joanne D. Chesimard and Clark Squire was postponed today after Mrs. Chesimard became ill in her cell at the Morris County Jail. Judge John E. Bachman adjourned the proceedings until 11 o'clock Monday morning when he will receive reports from doctors who examined Mrs. Chesimard toaay.

title: LIVESTOCK DRUG FREED FROM BAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 The United States Court of Appeals ruled here yesterday that the Food and Drug Administration acted illegally in not holding hearings before it banned the livestock growth drug DES.

title: A Federal Agncy Approves Action by Producers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) The Government granted steel producers today another price increase and took steps aimed at relieving shortages of steel items used in production of petroleum, coal and agricultural products.

title: British 3Day Week to Go On Indefinitely
description: LONDON, Jan. 25The Government announced today that the threeday work week must continue indefinitely for most of British industry because of;1 the threat of a strike in the:I coal fields.

title: MAYOR APPOINTS 2 TO KEY POSITIONS
description: Mayor Beame yesterday appointed John T. Burnell, an executive of the New York City Central Labor Council, as the city's chief labor negotiator with municipal unions.

title: John M. Graney, Headed Constructors Association
description: John Michael Graney, executive director for construction of the Business Roundtable and former president of the National Constructors Association, died Thursday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center after a twomonth illness. He was 52 years old and lived at 473 Drury Lane, Wycoff, N.J.

title: A Time to Speak
description: President Nixon's political situation becomes each day more untenable. The widespread confusion and lack public trust in the Administration's statements concerning the oil shortage only demonstrate that the essential links of confidence between President and people are severed.

title: A Nixon News Parley To Follow His Message
description: WASHINGTON, Jin. 25 (UPI)President Nikon will hold his first news conference of the year shortly after His State of the Union Message delivering next Wednesday, the White House press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, said yesterday.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
SIMON BACKS IDEA OF CUTTING PRICES FOR NEW U. S. OIL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 25William E. Simon, the Federal energy administrator, gave conditional support today to the idea of a rollback in some prices of crude oil but declined to specify when or by how much, or to back any of several bills offered in Congress to accomplish the purpose.

title: SIR HUBERT RANCE, EXBURMA GOVERNOR
description: LONDON, Jan. 25 (AP)Sir Hubert Rance, a major general who was the last British Governor of Burma before it gained independence in 1948, died in hospital yesterday. He was 75 years old.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: DEFENSE OFFICIAL DENIES PRESSURE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25A Pentagon investigator who was Involved in the 1971 inquiry into miiltary snooping in the White House denied today that he had attempted to shake down President Nixon last year in an effort to be named director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: 7 BIG BANKS JOIN IN KEYRATE CUT
description: Seven more moneycenter banks, including the two largest in the United States, yesterday announced reductions in their prime or base lending rates to 91/2 per cent from 93/4 per cent.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Levingston Shipbuilding Company of Orange, Tex., said it had signed a contract to build a jackup drilling platform for KS Norway Jackup, a threecorn. pany group. Total price is in excess of $18million.

title: F.C.C. Rules Give Networks Mote Program Time
description: The Federal Communications Commission has adopted new rules for the apportionment of network and local time in the peak viewing hours.

title: Watergate Hearings Will Focus On Mitchell Decision on Hughes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25The Senate Watergate committee plans to focus its hearings next I week on allegations that John N. Mitchell, the former Attorney General, agreed to allow Howard R. Hughes to purchase Las Vegas hotel and casino In return for the $100,000 cash contribution that associates of Mr. Hughes gave to Charles G. Rebozo, a friend of President Nixon.

title: JOSEPH A. SAVOLDI OF NOTRE DAME, 65
description: CADIZ, Ky., Jan. 25Joseph A. Savoldi, who gained fame as a fullback on undefeated football teams at the University of Notre Dame in 1929 and 1930, died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 65 years ,old.

title: Thursday's Fight
description: Los AngelesAndy Price, 139 pounds, Los Angeles, knocked out Julio Lopez, 138, Mexico, 10 rounds.

title: U.C.L.A. Wins
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25Marquee Johnson, a freshman reserve, provided some extra botuice in the University of California, Los Angeles tonight as the Bruins prepared for their basketball rematch with Notre Dame tomorrow night.

title: Yale Says Prized Vinland Map 0f North America Is a Forgery
Court Rules 72 Federal Raise Was Illegally Delayed by Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) A Federal Appeals Court ruled today that President Nixon illegally delayed by three !months a 1972 pay rise for the Government's civilian employes and that they are entitled to the income they missed.

title: James PopeHennessy, Writer, Dies in London After Knifing
description: LONDON, Jan. 25  James PopeHennessy, the writer, died in a hospital today of injuries received in a knife attack at his home here. He was 57 years old.

title: '73 Commodity Trading Up 40% Over 72 Level
description: Commodity futures trading set another record last year. A total of 25,826,747 commodity contracts changed hands on the nation's commodity exchanges, or 40 per cent above the 1972 level. In December,. however, volume totaled 2,152,487 contracts, almost 3 per cent lower than December, 1972.

title: The Worlds of Abstraction and Representation
description: EVERY new work of art is a form of dialogue with the art of the past, whether the put in question is the 1950's, the 1850's, or the age of Perinlean classicism. The artist attempts to effect a vital connection between, on the one hand, his experience and training, which are inevitably contemporary, and, on the other, the. conventions of his medium, which are historically determined. Out of this connection he discovers for his art a principle of esthetic coherence we call style, which may echo or modify or repudiate the past in varying degrees but which can never really its relations with it.

title: 2County Project Aids Troubled Infants
description: LONG BRANCH  An innovative program for troubled children as young as 5 weeks old is under way in Monmouth and Ocean Counties. It provides training and ongoing diagnostic facilities for the youngsters and counseling for their parents as early as possible.

title: Still the Best Of TV's News Magazines
description: IF that's not football on the Columbia Broadcasting System Sundays at 6 P.M., it must be 60 Minutes. After a curious, if not highly questionable, vacation of four months, the CBS News hour is back. It still lists Don Hewitt as executive producer, Mike Wallace and Morley Safer as oncamera correspondents, and an exceptionally bright crew of news personnel as segment producers. And it is still, in terms of solid content and style, the best news magazine on television.

title: In an Economic Winter, Monetary Tides Are Shifting
description: EVEN before the latest war in the Middle East, and the reduction in flow of Arab oil, there was little prospect that development aid from the rich oildependent powers of the world to the emerging nations would increase.; dramatically.

title: Snow Halts Trains in Japan, Traps Thousands Aboard
description: TOKYO, Jan. 26 (AP)Blizzards and heavy snowstorms swept northern Japan today, paralyzing railway facilities and stranding about 7,000 passengers in snowbound trains.

title: In South America, Too, Barely Enough Oil
Ruth Bockhorn Plans Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walther Bockhorn of LtibeckTravemilnde, West Germany, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Bockhorn, to Thomas Joseph Reckford of Washington, a staff member of the Commission on the Organization of the Government for the Conduct of Foreign Policy.

title: Ancient Title Wins Coast Stakes Test
description: ARCADIA Calif., Jan. 26 (AP)Ancient Title, known as a sprinter, stretched out under Laffit Pincay to defeat the favorite, Linda's Chief by 3 lengths in the $84,000 San Fernando Stakes today at Santa Anita.

title: Miss Mirto Bride of Robert Rothschild
description: Miss Valerie C. Mirto and Robert Joseph Rothschild were married yesterday afternoon in the St. Joseph Patron Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. Msgr. Raphael J. Testagrossa performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Nickels and Dimes Add Up to a Center
description: WYANDANCH, L.I.  After more than six years of candy sales raffles fairs and directmail and doortodoor fundraising the Wyandanch Youth Center was offically opened last night with a dinner for its founder and chairman Buddy McLain.

title: E.P.A. to Test a GasolineElectric Car
description: Two inventors working to perfect a clean, fuelsaving car have just had their Federal support raised from $1 to $33,000 for three months of rigorous Government testing.

title: Turkish Justice Stuns 3 Jailed Americans
description: ANTIOCH, Turkey, Jan. 26 (AP)For Kathyrn Zenz, a ing trip to West Germany ended in a Turkish jail on the banks of the Orontes River. She says she still cannot believe what happened to her.

title: Dance: Swanilda Debut
description: Christine Sarry, with her small, delicate psysique, her precise technique, her gift for musicality and her understated but shrewd sense of humor, is one of nature's soubrettes. It was therefore somewhat of a surprise to realize that her performance as Swanilda in 'Coppelia at the City Center 55th Street Hheater yesterday afternoon was, in fact, her debut in the role.

title: In Indonesia, Luxury Amid Poverty
description: JAKARTAWhen mealtime comes Jusuf, a 23yearold Javanese who ekes out a living by pedaling a threewheeled passenger vehicle called a becak, usually squats at the road side and eats a mixture of rice and hot peppers with his fingers.

title: The Poor May Be Rich in People
description: NEW DELHISome years ago, citing India as an instance, I wrote that a traveler moving around the world could learn a good deal of the different political systems he would encounter merely by glancing at the local press. If it is filled with bad mews, he is in democracy. Good news can be an ill omen.

title: L. I. MusicianEngineer Shows How to Play a Duet With One Viola
description: MANHASSET, L. LHaving finished a stately Bach, W. Sterling Gorrill, the soloist, bowed to polite applause from the musically sophisticated audience at a recent. Hofstra University faculty recital, his viola dangling. from one hand at his side.

title: ERVIN UNIT DELAYS HEARINGS ON GIFTS TO NIXON CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Senate Watergate committee postponed indefinitely today the hearings on contributions to the 1972 Nixon campaign that were to have been held during the nexttwo weeks.

title: FINCH AND ALFRED BAR AFFILIATION
description: A proposed affiliation of Finch College, on the Upper East Side, with Alfred University, in upstate New York, was rejected yesterday by the presidents of both institutions after seven months of talks.

Asians Economic Planning Shattered By Escalation in Prices of Crude Oil
description: HONG KONGAn entirely new equation  the energy crisisthrew the grand, &once Plans of Asia into confusion in 1973 end sent the bright, young technocrats, in whom the young on had placed so much flat back to their drawing

title: Beame Names Irizarry, Puerto Rican Banker, as City's Finance Administrator
description: A Puerto Ricanborn banker who heads the Commonwealth's economic development office in New York, Ivan E. Irizarry, has been picked by Mayor Beame to be the city's Finance Administratorthe first member of the Puerto Rican community to head a superagency in the city government.

title: Paris Was Enchanted  Verdi Was Disgusted
description: IT is true that this Thursday will see the first production that the Metropolitan Opera has ever given of Verdi's I Vespri Siciliani""The Sicilian Vespers. But it nevertheless will not be the first time that the house has ever approached the opera. In 1967, at Newport, the Metropolitan had ,a summer Verdi festival, and on Aug. 23 It sponsored a concert version of I Vespri Siciliani, with a cast headed by Viriginia Zeani, Eugenio Fernandi, Kostas Paskalis and Bonaldo Giaiotti. Francesco MolinariPradelli conducted.

title: West African Crops DroughtStricken
description: ACCRA, Ghana  Drought conditions that devastated the subSaharan countries of West Africa last year were also felt in varying degrees in other parts of the continent's western bulge.

title: NEW PACIFIC STATE SEEKS BASIC UNITY
description: PORT MORESBY, Papua New; Guinea  An earnest if inexperienced indigenous government in Papua New Guinea, the world's newest selfgoverning state, has come to grips with many complex problems facing this vast, undeveloped island country in the southwest Pacific.

title: Pharmacists Study to Get Up to Date
description: After a busy day in their drugstores, a growing number of pharmacists, mostly from the Washington Heights area, have been meeting periodically for lectures about pharmacology that could upgrade the medical care their customers receive.

title: The gambler who must
Trade Fairsa Thriving Tradition
Conjure Tales; By Charles W. Chesnutt. Retold by Ray Anthony Shepard. Illustrated by John Ross and Clare Romano. 99 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton & Co. $4.95. (Ages 9 and Up)
Cost of Energy, Not Supply, Brings a New Era and New Fears
description: N0 ONEnot even the optimistswas willing, as 1973 began, to predict that economically mankind was heading for a good year. But in a world already toughened by endemic inflation and calloused by natural disaster most of the economists thought 1973 would at least be good enough. And while no one was rash enough to view the future of the Third World with optimism, there was hope that if the developing nations did not make halting progress they would, at least, pass through the year holding their own.

title: Audubon Unit Links Predator Problems To Sheep Growers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26The Audubon Society has told 21 Western Senators that it is the sheep growers rather than the Interior Department who are frustrating attempts to improve predator control.

title: Correction
description: Gogol's Evenings on a Farm Near Dikanka was published in 183132. Due to a typographical error, the date was incorrectly given in the review of Divided Soul, The Life of Gogol, which appeared on December 23.

title: Notes: Campgrounds Feel the Gas Pinch
description: THE gasoline shortage and tight money appear to have put the brakes on the feverish development of campground facilities across the United States. In addition, campground operators are cutting rates and stepping up promotional efforts to offset a drop in business.

title: Roger Casement
description: Sir Roger Casement's life was a personal tragedy enshrined in the seemingly unending collective tragedy of Britain's relations with Ireland. Born in 1864 near Dublin (but educated in Ulster), he was by nationality British and only gradually came to regard himself as an Irishman pure and simple. Indeed the greater part of his adult life was spent in the British public service. At the age of 20 he became a volunteer agent in *he privateenterprise state H. M. Stanley was setting up in the Congo basin, and which later became the private empire of Leopold II of the Belgians, under the name of the Congo Free State. The atmosphere of the place is movingly described in Heart of Darkness by Joseph Cer.rad, who met and adCasement was tall. goodlooking, sensitive and introspective, already a confirmed victim of what he described as the terrible disease of homosexuality. He was also an idealist and n passionate defender of the underdog. In 1895 he entered the British consular service, first as consul in Portuguese East Africa, later in Portuguese West, and in this capacity he carried out an investigation of conditions in the Congo under Leopold's rule. His report was a sickening indictment of the horrors of the forced labor system imposed on the natives, and also an exposure of the mendacity, hypocrisy and sheer dishonesty of Leopold himself.

title: New Violence on Cyprus
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 26 (Reuters)Several bomb blasts and machinegun bursts shook timassol in southwest Cyprus today as violence continued between supporters of President Makarios and the underground leader, Gen. George Grivas.

title: The Twain Now Meet Uncertainly
Rugs With a Special Touch That Attracts Celebrities
description: OLD BROOKVILLE L. I.Along Cedar Swamp Road just past the East Hillside cemetery is a 52yearold industry where, for three generations rugs have been made by hand.

title: To Washington, the Struggle in Vietnam Has Become Their War
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 The memory of our war, the Vietnam war until 1973, still pains official Washington. But a year after the signing of the Paris peace agreements their war the struggle that still goes on and has taken almost 60,000 more Vietnamese lives since the ceasefire has become just another fact of life here.

title: Fragments of The Century
description: I feel puzzledand cheatedat the detached, almost allegorical view Michael Harrington has taken of his own life in his social autobiography, Fragments of the Century. A man passionately involved for 25 years in the cause of social justice, and a close associate of Dorothy Day, Norman Thomas and Martin Luther King, he has chosen to tell his unique story in remote, depersonalized tones, to reduce it from poetry to chronicle. Such a muted, abstract accounting adds up, in my mind, to a missed opportunity. Others will disagree. They will defend Harrington's impersonality (I have lingered over only those parts of my experience that seem to contain the evidence of history) as a necessary, counterpart to his declared intention of extracting social trends from an individual life; they will espouse his implicit assumption that minimizing personality purifies social analysis.

title: T. Whitfield Davidson Dead; Senior Federal Judge Was 97
description: ENNIS, Tex., Jan, 26 (AP)T. Whitfield Davidson, the nation's senior Federal judge in both age and length of service, died here yesterday at the age of 97.

title: De Lesseps Marvel. of the 19th Century Remains Important in the 20th
description: PARISAfter six months of clearing old wrecks, digging out sunken iron bridges and the manifold debris of war and reallgnifig the crumbled banks. Egypt is expected to reopen the Suez Canal at a cost of some $10million. Blocked since the sixday war of 1967, the 100mile waterway, which will be 105 years old this year, will again become a major

title: Dance
description: NED ROREM has just published a collection of musical essays called Pure Contraption. Rorem is one of. those composers who write most gracefully and interestingly about music and I enjoy both agreeing and disagreeing with him. Here in this new book, one phrase caught my mind. Critics of words use words. Critics of music use words.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Uncertainty ruled Wall Street last week as the good news and the bad news seemed to cancel each other out.

title: How Dixon Made Its Mark
description: JERSEY CITYAsk any person in the street if he or she has ever heard of the Joseph Dixon Crucible Company and you probably will get a vacant stare in response. But it is likely that just about everyone in the United States has at one time or another used its products.

title: Canadian Oil Tames U.S. Elephant
description: TORONTO  Living next to you is in some ways like sleeping with an elephant, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau once told an American audience. No matter how friendly or eventempered is the beast, one is affected by every twitch and grunt.

title: Oil Mr. Nikon
description: Directly and indirectly, subtly and openly, one increasingly personal question has come to dominate all of the negative legacies of Watergate: How long can Richard Nixon remain in office? The President last week gave, his own answer to a group of visiting Congressmen. I'm going to fight like hell.

title: Life in Eastern Europe Brightens
description: BUDAPEST  After long years of austere living crowding in stores for inadequate and inferior goods, cramped housing and a pervading sense of grayness Eastern European consumers are gradually moving toward a better way of life.

title: Cemeteries Go Public
description: When a Bronx housewife told her husband some weeks ago, I'm going out to an opera recital, Louisit's at the cemetery, he didn't even blink.

title: Giant Slalom Won By Zandegiacomo
description: HUNTER, N.Y., Jan. 26Renzo Zandegiacomo of Italy took top honors today in the Benson & Hedges $15,000 professional Grand Prix giant slalom at Hunter Mountain.

title: British Loan to Sierra Leone
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, Jan. 26 (Agence FrancePresse) Britain has granted a $3.3 million loan to finance mutually agreed projects, with the em phasis on agriculture. The loan, interest free, will he repaid over 25 years.

title: Wolcott Dunham Jr., Lawyer, Marries Joan Scott Findlay
description: Miss Joan Scott Findlay, daughter of Comdr. G. Scott Findlay, U.S.N., retired, of New York and Mrs. Herman Eckhoff of Valle de Bravo, Mexico, was married here yesterday afternoon to Wolcott Balestier Dunham Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Dunham of Southwest Harbor, Me.

title: Will the Chinese Be Smiling At the Spring Canton Fair?
description: HONG KONGVisitors to China's twice yearly trade fair in the southern city of Canton tend to talk more about the mood of their hosts than about the progress of their negotiations, because it has become axiomatic that business is better when the Chinese are smiling.

title: Lois R. Portnoy To Be a Bride
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Jan. 26Mr. and Mrs. Hyman J. Portnoy have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lois Robin Portnoy, to Stephen Goldberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Goldberg of New Haven.

title: Schools Confused by Threatened Cuts
description: A financial crisis affecting half of New York City's school districts seemed to be teetering between disaster and resolution over the weekend as parents, faculty members and administrators awaited further word on the threatened mass layoffs of teachers.

title: Korea, Like Her Buses, Is Struggling
description: SEOUL  Most of the world's large cities have a distinctive mark  New York's skyline, the boulevards of Paris, the fountains of Rome, Tokyo's maze of narrow, twisting streets. In Seoul, it's busesbig green buses mounted on flatbed truck frames, crammed with people most of the time and almost always spewing black fumes from their worn, laboring engines.

title: Dartmouth Downs Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 26Dartmouth remained under feated in Ivy League hockey by defeating Yale tonight, 52. It was the Green's fifth victory in the league. Yale is 23. Tom Fleming scored twice for the victors.

title: A Pipeline in Soviet Far North Blocks Migration of Reindeer
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 26Soviet environmentalists have complained that a naturalgas pipeline above the Arctic Circle is hindering the migrations of the nearly 400,000 reindeer in the Taimyr Peninsula above northern Siberia.

title: Francine Netter Is Married To John Frederick Carlson
description: Miss Francine Mary Netter and John Frederick Carlson were married yesterday at, ternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal church here by the Rev. Terence J. Finlay. A reception followed at the Cottage on the Park in Hampshire House.

title: 63 Killed in Crash of Airliner in Turkey
description: IZMIR, Turkey, Jan. 26 (AP) A Turkish jetliner crashed and burst into flames on takeoff from Izmir's military airport today, killing 63 of the 73 persons aboard, Turkish Airlines reported.

title: OutofWedlock Girl Gets Right To Inherit From Dead Father
description: A significant decision in behalf of outofwedlock children has been issued in Surrogate's Court here in a case involving a child whose father lost his life in a steampipe explosion last May in Manhattan's financial district.

title: Stady of Impeachment Released by City Bar
description: A President may be impeached and removed from office for an offense that need not he a violation of criminal law, according to a study released yesterday by the New York City Bar Association.

title: Souvlaki Way of Life Grips Athens
description: ATHENSThe appetizing aroma of grilled meat that fills the air Of downtown Athens each noon, bears witness to the changing habits of Athenians.

title: Letters
description: Simple arthmetic?

title: A Visit by Dr. Shockley Shakes Quiet L.I. Village
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I.Not much happens in this vintage village of 5,450 people, and most of the restdents want to keep it that way.

title: Ideas &Trends;Education, Law, Anthropology, History;A Stone Age Culture Is Threatened
description: Exploited by the white man and threatened by the encroachments of the 20th century, the primitive Ache Indians in the jungles of eastern Paraguay are in danger of losing their Stone Age culture.

title: Nixon Exam Still Pending
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) President Nixon still has not rescheduled his annual physical examination that was originally set for midDecember. When asked about it Thursday, the Wtitte House press secretary Ronald L. Ziegler, said he feels good, and he hasn't raised the question of rescheduling the medical exam.

title: $67,500 for Loss of Baby
description: CHICAGO, Jana 26 (Reuters) A former Chicago policeman has been awarded $67,500 for the loss of an unborn child. The amount is believed to be the highest ever made in such a case. Carl Stadeker, 30 years old, received the amount as part of an outofcourt settlement of a $1million suit he had filed against the owner of a boat in which his pregnant wife, Gaye, drowned in 1968, his lawyers said Wednesday.

title: Une de Mai, Delmonica Hanover Race Today in Paris
description: PARIS,. Jan. 26  Sports inanship has brought together again the best American and the best French trotter. Economics will soon have the French horse going to Amera for a long stay and the American horse staying in France.

title: The Proper Hookup
description: WALLHUNG planters have shelf type bracket that must be fastened to the wall first, and there are two types of anchoring devices that can be used for mounting them. For moderate size pots and planters (up to about 15 pounds) nylon anchors are the easiest. These hollow plugs are tapered and have serrations around the outside to help them grip when inserted in a hole drilled In plaster or gypsum board. They are designed so that a wood screw of the proper size can be driven through the hollow center after they are in place in the wall. As the screw goes in it splits the plastic anchor; thus expanding it so that it grips firmly behind the plaster, as well as against the sides of the hole.

title: Home Builders Very Own Recession
description: HOUSTONEven with rising prices, for $25,000 to $35,000 Flurry H. Milke of Eustis., Fla., can still put you in a threebedroom, twobath house on a halfacre lot with grapefruit trees in the backyard and bass fishing within walking distance.

title: Recordings
description: OZART, Mozart and more Mozart. So runs a stream of releases issued recently by Philips. Divertimentos, concertos, symphonies and serenades. They fill nine disks, cover a variety of instrumental groups, span 18 years (which is to say half) of the composer's brief life and constitute an interesting Mozart samplerthough, of Course, they scarcely make a dent in the stream of music he managed to turn out in his turbulent existence.

title: New Health Programs In Suffolk
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. IThe head of Suffolk County's new Department of Health Services has initiated two programs that she believes will provide county residents with better and more accessible health care.

title: WEST BANK TALKS REPORTED OPENING
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan, 26Jordan and Israel have been engaged in preliminary negotiations on disengaging their forces in the Jordan Valley region, according to reliable Arab diplomatic sources.

title: Remembering Mr. Wilder
description: Thornton Wilder's new novel Theophilus North, begins with an autobiographical sentence that brings memories to quite a few of us who passed our young days at Lawrenceville School, in New Jersey. The sentence reads, In the spring of 1926 I resigned my job. The job was teaching French in the Barn back of Upper House with fringe benefits (benefits?) of helping Tubby Foresman to discourage the hazing of rhinies at Davis House (wire brush on the salted stomach) and to try to put a semblance of grammar in The Lit as Faculty Supervisor.

title: Bridge
description: An opening bid of one club has two advantages for the makers of systems. It permits a maximum of exploration before the game level is reached; and it names a suit that is rarely used for the final contract.

title: Ali Favored Over Frazier In Battle of ExChampions
description: For the privilege of watching two heavyweights who haven't knocked out anyone since 1972, status seekers will be paying up to $1,000 a ticket tomorrow night as they and Joe Frazier and Muhammad Ali chase a memory.

title: Writers to Honor Clarke of Flyers
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 (UPI)  Bobby Clarke, the Philadelphia Flyers captain and the National Hockey League's most valuable player last season, will be honorder Feb. 4 as the Philadelphia Sports Writers Association pro athlete of the year.

title: Polly Rogers, An Art Teacher, To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis Day Rogers of New York and Old Black Point, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Polly Washburn Rogers, to David Greenberg. He is the son of Mrs. Paula Greenberg of New York and Prof. Martin Greenberg of Brooklyn.

title: Cranford Attacking Problem of Floods
description: CRANFORD  One of the picturesque things about this Union County township is the way the treelined Rahway River meanders through pleasant residential areas.

title: News of the Camera World
description: THE Fashion Institute of Technology, 227 West 27th Street, an accredited community college of the State University of New York, Is offering three courses in photography during the coming semester, with registration to take place at the college on Wednesday evening from 6 to 8. included will be a course entitled Introduction to Photography, which will be held on Monday, Tuesday and Friday evenings, as well as on Saturday mornings; another entitled Advanced Photography which will meet on Wednesday and Thursday evenings; and a third entitled Introduction to Color Photography which will meet on Tuesday evenings. The last course will be limited to those who have completed the introductory and advanced courses, or those who obtain special permission from the instructor. All will start the first week in February, and each will cost $43.50, plus a registration fee of $2. For more information call (212) 2397647.

title: The Energy Crisis, an Upheaval No Nation Can Escape
description: Not since World War II has there been a global problem that has threatened to change relationships and ways of life more than the current energy crisis.

title: In New Delhi ,a New Soviet Grain Deal
description: NEW DELHISoviet officials, having proved themselves adept at capitalistic bargaining for American wheat a year and a half ago, are now using the grain to reap political dividends in the Third World.

title: Gilbert an AllStar
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 26 (AP) Rod Gilbert of the New. York Rangers and Henri Richard of the Montreal Canadiens were named today to the East team for Tuesday night's National Hockey League AllStar Game at Chicago. They replaced two injured Montreal Canadiens, Jacques Lemaire and Serge Sapard.

title: Child to the Moores
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Hoyt Moore of Bedminster, N. J., on Jan. 13 in the Morristown Memorial Hospital. Mrs. Moore is the former Miss Carol Hughes Stanco of South Orange, N. J.

title: 5 Feared Dead in Fire
description: BRANTFORD, Ont., Jan. 26 (AP)Five children were missing and feared dead today as a result of an early morning, fire that destroyed their twostory log home on an Indian reservation.

title: Democrats Concede Javits Is the FrontRunner in Race for Senate
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits, who plans to run this year for fourth term, is considered the undoubted front runner even by his Democratic opponents.

title: Marijane Kowalski Sets June Wedding
description: FORT SALONGA, L. I., Jan. 26The engagement of Miss Marijane Elizabeth Kowalski to Christopher Bates has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Kowalski, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chandler Bates Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Hawaii First State to Set Gasoline Sales Controls
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 26The nation's first mandatory state controls overlasoline sales will go into effect here Monday.

title: 201 Odds Drop to 31 , Horse Wins by 2 Lengths
Road Sign Meets Fitting End
description: RENO, Jan. 26 (UPI)A sign warning motorists of strong winds between here and Carson City will have to be replaced, the Highway Department said Wednesday, The sign blew down.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThe Nixon Administration is now glumly conceding that (after a year of exemplary diffidence) wage demands from labor Will be adding explosive fuel to inflationary fires in 1974.

title: Assignment in Moscow: No Soft Berth
description: MOSCOWRobert B. Costello has cut back on those long, lingering business lunches. His low90's golf game is suffering. He has had to change from liftassisted downhill skiing to the more laborious crosscountry variety. And he spends more of his social life mixing with diplomats than with other business executives.

title: ... The Senate And Big Oil Are Already Fighting
description: To those who could not resist the pun, the highlevel discussion of the oil industry last week produced considerable heat but little light: Senatodal indignation was high and corporate executives defended themselves with strong language, but gasoline supplies were still dropping and the public had learned little more than already knew about why that was happening.

title: Wohlhater Wins Mile In 3:59.1 at Indiana
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Jan. 26 (AP)Rick Wohlhuter, former University of Notre Dame runner, flurried off a plane from New York, where he won the Millrose Games 800 last night, and ran the first subfourminute indoor mile in Indiana today.

title: Woods Shatters ShotPut Mark
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 26 (UPI)George Woods brought the indoor track shotput record closer to 70 feet tonight, breaking his world indoor record with a put of 69 feet 1000BE inches at the Oregon invitation track and field meet.

title: N. Carolina Turns Back Maryland
Optional Maid Service on the Increase
description: The refrigerator defrosts automatically. A flick of the dial and the oven selfcleans. With each flush, auliquid cleanser attacks the toilet bowl. By any standards, today's luxury apartment is a model of efficiency.

title: Violence? Yes, and passion, joy, exuberance...; Pollock was no accident
description: When I began teaching around 1950, we jokingly called introductory art history Pyramids Picasso. A decade later this had become Pyramids to Pollock. To be sure, Picasso was hardly the most advancedor bestartist in the world 1950; nor was Pollock, by the time of his death 1956. But in their turns, they were the last painters whose work seemed to have embodied whole epochs. The abstract expressionist movement, of which Pollock was a part, boasted many superb painters. Yet Pyramids ,to Rothko or Pyramids to de Kooning would not have rung trueand not just because the alliteration was missing.

title: World News Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Jan 26 (Reuters)  King Baudouin appointed Flemish Christian Socialist leader, Leo Tindemans, as Premierdesignate today and asked him to form a Cabinet to replace the Socialistled coalition that resigned a week ago, the Royal Palace announced.

title: Holy Mackerel, Andy, Now He's Buying the Padres
description: When Ray Kroc bought the San Diego Padres last week, for $10.1million, he said he wasn't doing it for the money one could make. To buy a baseball team you have to be some kind of a baseball nut, he said.

title: AT HOME THE FIRE
description: The Franklin stove, which Benjamin developed in the early 18th century, is back in business, along with the potbelly stove that warmed country stores and oneroom schoolhouses, the parlor stove that made the front room livable, and some sleek modern versions. All burn wood and briquettes, so their owners should stay warm no matter what. Cheaper than custombuilt masonry fireplaces, these units are so much in demand since the fuel. crunch that manufacturers warn of a minimum sixmonth delay in deliveriesand also say that the present prices cannot be guaranteed.

title: The Horses Will Run, but Will the Cars?
description: TRENTON  The longest horseracing season in New Jersey begins next month under a handicap of gasoline shortages that could curtail attendance and the bettinghandle.

title: In Ghana, a SelfHelp Farm
description: DAWHENYA, Ghana  At this time of year  midway in the dry season  West African farmlands are usually deserted.

title: Ralph W. Piersall Jr. Dies; Haskins &
description: Ralph W. Piersall Jr., a partner in the international accounting firm of Haskins & Sells, who directed the continuing education program at its executive offices at 1114 Avenue of the Americas, died Friday of a heart ailment in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 41 years old and lived at 76 Birch Lane in Greenwich.

title: Economic Clouds Thicken Overlberia
description: MADRIDThe Iberian Peninsula, surrounded hy sea and mountains, looks a bit isolated from the rest of Europe and the world. But 34 million Spaniards and 9.5 million Portuguese became aware in 1973, as rarely before, how vulnerable they are to the economic and political problems that afflict other peopies.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: As poets and editors, George Quasha and I set out in America a Prophecy to challenge a range of assumptions about the history and nature of American poetry from preColumbian times to the present. Helen Vendler's review. (Dec. 30) is an inevitable and not wholly unwelcome response, since it confirms that we aren't simply beating a dead hone but confronting an active, parochial and deeply entrenched attempt to keep the mind within what many of us have come to feel as intolerable limits. If Professor Vendlees review makes her own position clear enough, it distorts ours sufficiently to call for some selective comments in response.

title: Charlie Simpson's Apocalypse
A Beame Aide's Company Has Left the City, in Part
description: A member of Mayor Beame's new council to keep businesses; in the city is the head of al multibilliondollar corporation that, though it has resisted the temptation to move its headquarters to the suburbs has nonetheless transferred much of its operations out of town.

title: Photography,
description: IT'Ss been one of those weeks without conjunction, without spark. Per haps it's the cold Weather, or the slow revving up of a new year. I've visited four exhibits without finding more than half a dozen images really worth looking at again, and have worked my way half through a book whose premiss I consider inordinately significant but whose execution leaves much to be desired.

title: Young Man Dies in Blaze In Room at Diplomat Hotel
description: A young man was killed last night when fire swept through his room at the Diplomat Hotel at 108 West 43d Street. The victim was identified as Peter Green, in his mid20's, who had lived at the hotel for the last five years.

title: Point of View
description: The energy crisis has thrown into question Japan's economic miracle. Higher prices alone will add close to $10billion to the country's balance of payments drain, this year, even assuming that imports are held down to last year's level.

title: Winter Is Winter
description: Every now and then, after a mild winter or two, someone announces that the climate is changing, that we soon will be growing date palms in New England. And just about the time this theory seems almost plausible, along comes a winter that makes grandfathers remember their boyhood.

title: There Exists in The 20th Century A 19thCentury Dictatorship, And Its Name Is Paraguay
description: I WELL remember. my grandfather's atlas, a standby of my obligatory weekly visits as a child. I used to sit in front of it and always turn to the maps with the white spots: Africa, and the Poles, Of course, those places weren't really unknown any more (I'm of that old), but I didn't know that, pd I was haunted by their mysteriouspegs. Ever since, I have regretted that I was born in this first century without terra Incognita. But we still, or again, pave white spots of a kind on our maps places barred not by nature but by ben. China was such a place when there, and Paraguay is still such ace, or at least up to a point.

title: Navy Officer Weds Kathryn Beyerlein
description: RIVER EDGE, N. J., Jan. 26Miss Kathryn Ann Beyer lein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Beyerlein of River Edge and Highland Lakes, was married here this afternoon to Lieut. Robert Bruce Avery, U.S.N., son of Mrs. Lyman B. Avery of Southport, Conn., and the late Mr. Avery. The Rev. William F. Shafer performed the ceremony in Grace Lutheran Church.

title: A City's Curb on Growth Upset
Plath the Woman Wins Out Over Plath the Poet
description: DURING the two or three days that have passed since I sat on bleachers in Brooldyn listening to three whitegowned women impersonal as sea gulls, chant fragment,s of the history and fragments of the poetry of Sylvia Plath, and before push ing myself to my desk to record my impressions of the event, I have found myself ducking people. Ducking questions. How is it? Did you like it? What's It like? Picking up Ariel in the interim, and rereading Robert Lowell's introduction to the volume published after Sylvia Plath's suicide in 1963, Fame upon this: Probably many, after reading Ariel will recoil from their first overawed shock, and painfully wonder why so much of it leaves them feeling empty,, evasive, and inartieulate. Yes that's how I've been feeling.

title: News of the Screen
description: Russian movie makers and Edward Lewis, the American producer of such films as Spartacus and The Iceman Cometh, have joined to make a musical version of Maurice Maeterlinck's The Blue Bird in what Mr. Lewis termed the first SovietAmerican coproduction. In English and dubbed into Russian, it will be shot starting this summer at the Lenfilm Studios in Leningrad, for release next year.

title: Music
description: Just about the time one decides that JeanPierre Rampal has come up with the last possible variant of flute concert, the French virtuoso thinks up another one and bounds onto a New York concert stage to share it with his big, adoring public.

title: Promoting Boat Safety In Alabama
description: When Bobby Smith was a youngster living on the shores of Lake Martin in central Alabama, he saw the lake claim the lives of many fishermen cruising in small boats. You could go around trying to buy a life preserver and Most of  the stores didn't even sell them, he said. This was 20 years ago. There were no laws that said you had to carry them.

title: State Budget Disappoints Klein and Caso
description: ALBANY  It is thicker than the Nassau and Suffolk telephone directories stacked on top of each other, but the key officials of both of these counties still managed to digest Governor Wilson's first budget very quickly. However, what they read did not really agree with them.

title: In West Africa, Hope for Rain
description: DAKAR, Senegal  In terms of a heavy human death toll, disaster has so far been averted in the droughtscoured West African region known as the Sahel.

title: Home Improvement
description: In an effort to catch up on the backlog of unanswered questions, the entire Home Improvement Column this week is again being devoted Questions and Answers. Many of these letters pose questions that are similar to those asked by other readers whose actual letters may not published here, but who, nevertheless, will find their answers below. Readers sending in questions about home repair problems should address them to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered on this page.

title: Onassis Refinery Plan Divides New Hampshire Area
description: DURHAM, N. H., Jan. 26the first inkling Evelyn Browne had of Aristotle Onassis plans to build a 400,000gallonaday oil refinery here came the day last September when two men in business suits pulled up in a Lincoln Continental at her rustic home, on a 170acre plot of woods, wetlands and a creek.

title: Royals Opener April
description: KANSAS CITY, Jan. 26 (UPI)  The Kansas City Royals will open their 1974 baseball season at home against the Minnesota Twins on April 5, the club said today.

title: CON ED RATE RISE OF UP TO 5070 SEEN; Need for Increase Is Laid by Swidler to Reliance on Oil from Abroad
Richard Phalon Jr. Weds Anita Dobbins
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 26Miss Anita Dobbins and Richard A. Phalon Jr. were married here this afternoon in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church by the.Rev. James Reilly. Mrs. Dale Botwin, the bride's sister, was the matron of honor and William Durkin Jr. was the best man.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  A series of reforms designed to open up the committee system to the public are expected to be approved by the Assembly tomorrow.

title: The Balance of Terror Is Uncomfortable, but It Works
description: WASHINGTONFor some years the military has been troubled by a seeming paradox of the nuclear age. It possessed nuclear weapons it probably could never use. And even if the weapons could be used, the military had more than it needed to destroy all the Russian cities.

title: Rome Being Submerged In Paint Pot of Graffiti
description: ROME, Jan. 26City Hall has just earmarked $28,000 for cleaning graffiti from monuments, but it is a losing battle.

title: The Nation
description: A Bad Year

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH Ails
Texaco Supplied Military With Oil in Arab Embargo
description: A spokesman for Texaco, Inc., said yesterday that the company supplied United States military forces with 87 million gallons of petroleum products from its nonArab sources during the Arab oil embargo over the last three months.

title: Mrs. Elwood Williams, 88, Ran Restaurants in Village
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Mrs. Jessie P. Williams, who in the nineteentwenties and thirties managed the Mad Hatter and, later, the Jumble Shop, restaurants in Greenwich Villige patronized by men and women of the theater, arts and letters, died last Sunday. She was 88 years old.

title: In France, Economic Focus Is on Jobs
description: PARISThe giant French automaker, the stateowned Renault works, has just retained an American company of manpower engineers, or efficiency experts, to help raise productivity while reducing the work force.

title: Copper Brightens Future of Zaire
description: YAOUNDE, Cameroon Because of the rise in copper prices through 1973, prospects for Zaire, the world's fifth largest producer of the :metal, are proportionately bright.

title: Edward Joseph Healy To Wed Miss Ballantine
description: DURANGO, Colo., Jan. 26  Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Ballantine, editors and publishers of The Durango Herald, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Ballantine, to Edward Joseph Healy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chain V. Healy of Wichita, Kan.president of the Parklane National Bank of Wichita, spent a year at the University of Kansas. He is the grandson of the late Dwight H. Thompson of Wichita, a Kansas wheat farmer, and of the late Edward J. Healy Jr., a partner of Healy & Co., which operated a cattle cornmission business in the Midwest.

title: Long Beach Mayor Plan Is Fading From View
description: LONG BEACH, L. I.  A change to a mayor form of government, whisked off the ballot on a technicality less than a year ago, now appears to be a lost issue here.

title: S. Carolina, U.S.C. Win At Garden

Placing of BlackVietnamese Orphans Is in Dispute
description: SAIGON, South'Vietnam, Jan. 26A group of American social workers visiting South Vietnam has urged adoption agencies here to stop their practice of placing most blackVietnamese children with white adoptive parents and begin placing them in black homes instead.

title: Beethoven Quartet To Play in Camden
description: CAMDEN  The opening event in the new Rutgers University Artists Series, to be held Wednesday evening at the College Center on the Camden campus, will feature the Quartetto Beethoven di Roma.

title: Dolphin Families. Adept At Balancing the Budget
description: The money did kind of become something you expect, said Mrs. Alice Kiick, wife of the Miami Dolphins running back, Jim.

description: WAYNE  I've always liked to do two things at once, says Dr. William J. McKeefrey, the new president of William Paterson College.

title: Davenport Triumphs In Hurdles
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 26 (AP)  Willie Davenport turned in a time of 7 seconds tonight in winning the special 60yard high hurdles event in the United States Track and Field Federation's national indoor championships.

title: Alexandra Mary Pietrasanta Fiancee of Peter Henry Rose
description: Miss Alexandra Mary Pietrasanta of New York, daughter of Mrs. Donald C. Malcom of Monte Carlo, Monaco, and the late Count Vittorio Pietrasanta of Genoa, Italy, plans to be wed, to Peter Henry Rose, also of New York. Their engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's mother.

title: OilSharing Accord in Libya Described
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26James E. Akins, the United States Ambassador to Saudi Arabia, has indicated in Congressional testimony that the AdministratiOn's 1971 approval of joint bargaining by the major oil companies included an agreement by the companies in Libya to share their oil in the event that the Government there shut down some of them.

title: 250 Antiwar Protesters Fail to Present Award
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) Two hundred and fifty antiwar demonstrators marched on the State Department today in a vain attempt to present SecIretary of State Kissinger with the Ignoble War Prize for 1973.

title: Civic Units Fight Towers
description: A Queens civic organization will begin a campaign this week to elicit the support of state and city officials in their campaign against the building of highrise apartments in the borough,

title: Mexico Struggles for New Markets
description: MEXICO CITY  We should be fighting for new markets abroad, one Mexican businessman confided, but it is so much simpler to trade with the United States. We know the market, the exchange rate is stable and transportation is easier.

title: A Woman in a Century of Struggle
description: Seeing is believingor, in some cases, disbelieving, for these pictures are of the same woman, Cicely Tyson. In the twohour course of the CBS special, The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman, Thursday night at 9, Miss Tyson grows from a Southern slave girl freed by the Civil War to 110yearold participant in the civil rights movement of the 1960's. The drama based on a novel by Ernest J. Gaines and was directed for television by John Korty. Miss Tyson, nominated, for an Academy Award for her work in the film Sounder, spent six hours a day being made up for the role of the centuryspanning Jane Pittman, and another 45 minutes being restored to her youthful self.

title: Rickenbacker Air Base
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) The Air Force has announced Mat it is renaming Lockbourne Air Force Base, Ohio, for Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker, World War I air hero who died last July 23 at age R4. He was.the top World War I ace who shot down 25 enemy planes.

title: Stamps
description: IN these days of inflation, even a slight break in favor of the consumer is somethingwhich makes it noteworthy to report that collectors of blocks of U.S. stamps are being offered a slight break by the U.S. Postal Service.

title: A CORRECTION
description: In Six Ways to Take a Trip Without Guzzling Gas (Travel Section, Dec. 23), the price given for a minivacation at Dunfey's Parker House in BostonFriday, Saturday and Sunday with Six breakfastsshould have been $40.30 for two, not per person.

Pipeline Projects Vital to U.S. Oil
description: TORONTO  Several big pipeline projects north of the 49th parallel hold the key to how much oil and gas from stilluntapped Arctic pools will get to the United States consumer by 1980.

description: The Franklin State Bank, with headquarters in Somerset and branch offices in 24 New Jersey communities, has embarked upon a new marketing approach which, it asserts, will permit persons to get bank loans without having to go to a bank.

title: Job Link to Deaths Studied
description: AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 26 (Reuters)The B. F. Goodrich Company said that it had informed the state and Federal authorities that it was investigating whether cancer deaths of three employes in its polyvinyl chloride operations were related to occupational causes. The employes worked at the company's Louisvile, Ky., facility. The company said Wednesday it had hired experts in the occupational health field to study the matter.

title: Boys Club Appeals To Mayor for Help
description: The BedfordStuyvesant Boys Club, which has been ordered to vacate a cityowned armory, has appealed to Mayor Beams to block the eviction notice.

description: ADDIS ABABA, EthiopiaFor developing Africa, 1973 was the year that might have been.

description: DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 26Mrs. Eleanor Fletcher Swanson of Darien has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Sally Symms Swanson to John Jeffery Carter, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Custer Carter Jr. of Chico, Calif. Miss Swanson also is the daughter of Dr. Irving A. Swanson of Palm Beach, Fla., formerly of New York.

title: Judge Rejects New U.S. Plea Aimed at Censoring C.I.A. Book
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26A Federal judge in Virginia turned down another request by the Government in its battle to censor a book about the Central Intelligence Agency that was coauthored by a former C.I.A., employe.
