description: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Jan. 26Prof. William Hetherington Durfee of the mathematics department at Mount Holyoke College and Mrs. Durfee have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Taylor Durfee, to Steven Edward Hengen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Erwin Hengen of Sharon, Conn. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Dave Anderson OldTimers Night
description: Somewhat sadly, The Fight II will occur tomorrow night. By itself, it might be memorable. But in comparison with the atmosphere that surrounded The Fight I, it's almost as if Joe Frazier and Muhammad Ali were about to appear in an OldTimers Night production. In assessing them, now, the extent of deterioration is as important as the qualities they have retained. Neither has been the same since their classic confronCation nearly three years ago. The suspicion is that they destroyed each other that night. Frazier has been dethroned as the world heavyweight champion by George Foreman, who clubbed him down six times in less than two rounds. Ali has been outpointed by Ken Norton, who broke his jaw, and he has been bloodied by Bob Foster, the lightheavyweight titleholder. But heavyweights of the stature of Frazier, and Ali are almost an eodangered species. What they once were is enough to create another multimilliondollar promotion. But the rematch will diminish a memory that deserved to remain untarnished. The exceptional situation of 1971 produced a $20million extravaganza. Each gladiator was unbeaten. Each was considered the championFrazier by the boxing politicians, Ali by much of the boxing public. Each was at a comparable age. Frazier settled the controversy by earning a unanimous 15round decision that even Ali acknowledged at first. The next day, wincing with soreness, he

title: Newspaper Vans Lose Right to Use Brooklyn Bridge
description: Newspaper delivery trucks, postal vans, school buses and other heavy vehicles that have enjoyed special permission to use the Brooklyn Bridge will no longer be able to use it, the city's Department Highways has ordered.

title: A Russian View of The Gulag Archipelago
description: MOSCOW Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's book The Gulag Archipelago, 19181956, not a story and not a novel, hence there is no disclosure of the truth via artistic truth, if we are to speak of literary, means of expression.

title: Inquiry Finds No Evidence of Rumored Nixon Fund in Rebozo Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26No evidence to substantiate widely publicized rumors of the existence of a secret trust fund belonging to President Nixon has been found thus far by investigators for the Senate Watergate committee, accord. ing to knowledgeable sources.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Walt Frazier of the Knicks, given a night by Southern Illinois, tells why he returned to his old college: I came back here because when I left to sign a pro contract with one year of eligibility re maining, no one came around complaining. No one said, Look what we did for you. All everyone said was Congratulations.

title: Exports Crucial for Central America
description: MEXICO CITY  Central America's economic prospects for 1974 are as buoyant the prices its exports command.

title: McCoy Triumphs In 28Hole MatCh
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. Jan. 26 (UPI)James McCoy defeated Jeff Wilhelm, I up, today then beat Joe Taylor on the 28th hole in the third round to qualify for a spot in the quarterfinal round of the Professional Golfers Association match play championship.

title: Letters: Cantor and Kaye in the Catskills
description: To the Editor: Tania Grossinger's delightful recollections An Growing Up at Grossingers (Travel Section, Jan. 13) will bring a twinge of nostalgia to all who knew Grossinger's as it then was  between 1945 and 1960. There was nothing like it before or since, with Jennie Grossinger reigning like a queen in all her glory.

title: Forkner Wins Golf
description: BELLEAIR, Fla., Jan. 16 (UPI)Tom Forkner, making his debut in the seniors circuit this year, won the sixth international seniors champion tournament today with a 288, one stroke ahead of Mal Galletta of Old Westbury, and Harvey Breaux of Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Study Lauds Drug Programs
description: TRENTONA study authorized by the State Law Enforcement Planning Agency has concluded that drugtreatment programs in New Jersey are effective in reducing narcoticrelated crime and are helping addicts and exaddicts lead productive lives.

title: Israel's Economy Burdened by War
description: TEL AVIVBetween 150, 000 and 200,000 Israelis are now in their fourth month of military reserve duty. That's 10 times as many as in the relatively normai times before the war that broke out on Yom Kippur, the day of atonement.

title: Illegal Aliens Put at 3 Million
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (UPI)Leonard F. Chapman, States immigration chief, saYs! more than three million illegal aliens may be in the United States. Mr. Chapman, a former Marine Corps commandant who ,was appointed to the irnmigrad post last November, said tat a news conference here Wednesday that the threemillion figure was the number of illegal aliens estimated to I have gone undetected in 1973. I He said some 670,000 others had been arrested.

description: It is the inability of governments here and elsewhere to deal effectively with inflation that is the basic cause of our economic problemsnot the oil shortage.

title: U.S. Groups Pledge to Support Excavation of Athens's Agora
description: ATHENS, Jan. 26  Two American foundations have pledged financial support to enable archeologists to uncover fully the Agora, the treasure[packed ancient market place of Athens north of the Acropolis.

title: Pop
description: BECAUSE contemporary songwriters express what is on their minds and in their hearts rather than what a musical comedy character has to say or what a Tin Pan Alley publisher considers commercial, listeners tend to treat the songs as autobiography. Newspaper and magazine interviews make it even more tempting to read between the lines of lyrics. Carly Simon's huge hit record You're So Vain set off a flurry of speculation about the iden tity of the song's hero.

title: Nixon Is Reported Working On Message to Congress
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Jan. 26 (AP)President Nixon was reported to be concentrating heavily on his forthcoming State of the Union Message to Congress during the weekend here.

title: JOHN C. MILLER
description: ALBANY, Jan. 26 (AP)John C. Miller, first deputy superintendent of the New York State Police, died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 58 years old.

title: Quiz Format Helps Children Get the Line on Careers
description: Glenn Krinsky's mind was working overtime. Do you perform a service in your occupation? he asked boldly as his audience sat hushed and expectant in anticipation of the response. Yes, came the hesitant reply, and Glenn smiled triumphantly.

title: Alison Lloyd Barber Bride Of James Ryan in Englewood
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 26  St. Cecelia's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Alison Lloyd Barber, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Barber Jr. of Alpine and Blue Hill, Me., to James Francis Xavier Ryan. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Ryan of Tenafly.

title: DANIEL SIMONDS
description: BEVERLY, Mass., Jan. 26Daniel Simonds, retired chairman of the Simonds Saw & Steel Company, now a division of the WallaceMurray Corporation, died yesterday in Beverly Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Beverly Farms.

title: OTHER THEATER OPENINGS
description: THE WOOD DEMON  Tuesday, Opera House/ Brooklyn Academy of Music, 7. A play by Anton Chekhov. Performed by the Actors Company.

title: Tornado Risk Study Set
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 (UPI) A countrywide tornado risk study has been started by Danes & Moore, a Los Angeles environmental consultant firm, for the Atomic Energy Commission. The $150,000 survey will last 12 months. Dames & Moore said it was one of the few nationwide tornado risk studies ever made and might be the first to incorporate both meteorological and engineering data on such a large scale.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Roy D. Chapin Jr. seems to be a man of contradictions that combine into selfassured, reflective, controlled person.

title: The Physical World of Willa Cather
description: More thatranything else I felt motion in the landscape; in the fresh, easyblowing morning wind; and in the earth Itself, as if the shaggy grass were a sort of loose hide, and underneath it herds of wild buffalo were galloping, galloping.... As in this sentence from My Antonia, WillaCather always writes of the world in a way to show it's alive..The quality of animation that seems a born part of her own prose arises from a mind comparatively uninterested, it seems to me, in direct observationand factual description; she conveys her world to us in subjective ways. Thus she may eliminate the picture, the better to make us feel something really there. It was her observation that Whatever is felt upon the page without being specifically named there  that, one might say, is created. There were none of the signs of spring for which.I used to watch in Virginia, says the narrator of My Antonia, ... there was only spring itself, the throb of it. If I had been tossed down blindfold on that red prairie, I should have knwon that it was spring.

title: Old Firehouses, Armories, etc., Find Saviors
description: On East 25th Street, a 123yearold former firehouse is being converted into a church. On West 37th Street, ramshackle former public school has provided ideal expansion space for trucking company next door. And in Brooklyn; a fortresslike armory is being turned into a hospital supply facility.

title: Yugoslays Attain Stability
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia The grim mood of expected austerity in which 1973 began for Yugoslays turned out to be not so grim after all. There was belttightening to clear up a troubling lack of liquidity among enterprises, some small factories went bankrupt and closed, but the tidal wave that had been forecast did not appear.

title: Movies; Will the Real Devil Speak Up? Yes!
description: PERHAPS the most horrifying feature of The Exorcist is its soundtrack: director William Friedkin and his experts used the cries of pigs being driven to slaughter to produce the scream of the Demon when it is exorcised from the 12yearold Regan's body. Although Warner Brothers has not made the fact public, Mercedes McCambridge, the Lady Macbeth of Orson Welles's Mercury Theater of the Air and Oscarwinning actress of All the King's Men, hairraisingly spoke the aural role of the Demon itself.

title: The World
description: Now Syria Which May Be More Difficult

title: New Red Sox Voice
description: BOSTON, Jan. 26 (UPI)Jim Woods has been named to join Ned Martin on playbyplay radio coverage of the Boston Red Sox. He formerly broadcast for the New York Yankees and Giants, the Pittsburgh Pirates, St. Louis Cardinals and Oakland A's.

title: Collombin Wins Cup Ski Race

Inflation Eats Into World's Dietary Habits
description: In West Germany, many families could not afford the traditional Christmas goose. Italians suffered unprecedented shortages of pasta, the staple food. In Spain, a new wave of consumerism rose, and at a Tokyo garden party, a Japanese housewife complained about the rising cost of living to Emperor Hirohito, no less.

title: Coach Seeks Foreign Aid In Soccer
description: This is Hubert Vogelsinger's second big step in life. The first was leaving Austria as a young man to go to the United States. As coach at Yale for eight years and author of three books, the young, blond mentor had security and prestige. But he is an American now and the American way, he says, is to always look ahead and not remain stationary. That's why he left Yale two weeks ago to become head coach of Boston in the North American Soccer

title: They Wait Hours to Be Shocked
description: THAT New York phenomenon, the longlonglonglonglong movie line, was carried to new lengths in recent weeks after William Friedkin's Christmas offering, The Exorcist, opened on Dec. 26 at Cinema I. This time, people stood like sheep in the rain, cold and sleet for up to four hours to see the chilling film about a 12yearold girl going to the devil.

title: In Verona, Everyone Works to Keep Things Nice'
description: VERONAWe're a typically suburban community, a place where everyone works to keep things nice. I guess our biggest concern is that the character of our town stays as it is. These comments were made the other day by Mrs. Bernic Evenson, who has been a resident of this Essex County borough for 42 years, and in all probability the town's character will remain as it is.

title: Ireland's New Eurocrats
description: DUBLIN, Ireland  If the study of national psychology may be considered the queen of the social sciences, then surely analysis of the Irish must be among the brightest jewels of her crown.

title: Hang Them in a Pot, Tub or Basket
description: ONE hanging plant leads to an other and another. Their trail ing vinelike habit makes then dramatic, beautiful, graceful and just plain exciting to grow.

title: California Doctors Turn to Defensive Medicine as Malpractice Suits Rise
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 26  The practice of defensive medicine is increasing among California physicians, surgeons and hospitals in the face of a rising volume of malpractice lawsuits.

title: It's Radio Comedy, But Jack Benny It Isn't
description: ELL, friends, we've come to a pretty pass indeed when a newspaper like The New York Times sends it goodnatured, wellintentioned journalist into a cistern of licentiousness, subversion and filth, but that is exactly what has happened to me, and let me tell you, after checking out the secalled National Lampoon's socalled Radio Hour of sogalled weekly comedy, I'm ready for a good, hot bath and a visit to my FBI field office.

title: Numismatics A Big Week In April
description: AN especially urgent call for action in support of National Coin Week, which this year begins on April 21, has been put out by the sponsoring American Numismatic Association. It is conducting a nationwide campaign to enlist the support of individual collectors, as well as local, state and regional clubs and associations on a greaterthanever scale.

title: Andrea LoBell Married to Barry J. Stein
description: Miss Andrea Jane LoBell, daughter of Gene LoBell of Great Neck, L. I., and the late Mrs. Irma Jeanne LoBell, was married here last evening to Barry Jay Stein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ruby Stein of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Irving KosloWe performed the ceremony at the St. RegisSheraton.

title: Two. Barns, Horses, and A Church for Mozart
description: BARNS have been on Melvin KapIan's mind for some time. Two and a half years ago, the wellknown oboist, concert manager and teacher, bought a farm in East Charlotte, Vt., and remodeled a barn on the property into a house. As a member of the New York Chamber Soloists, he played one year at the Touraine Festival in France, which is held in a barn. He was impressed by the experience. He bought a book on barns. Browsing through it he came across a picture of a spectacularly beautiful structure on 1,800acre estate in Shelburne, Vt.; overlooking Lake Champlain: It was near his summer home, but he had never seen it. Kaplan thought that here was a barn he'd like to make music in. Next summer he will be doing so.

title: Constance B. Leeds Engaged To William Lauriston Bennett
description: Miss Constance Brecker Leeds, a student at the Boston University School of Law, and William Lauriston Bennett of Cambridge, Mass., who teaches English at the Buckingham Browne & Nichols School there, will be married in the spring.

title: Looking Ahead to 76
description: WASHINGTONIn the hue and cry of Watergate and the energy crisis, genial Bob Strauss seems to be about the only man paying much attention to the Democratic party, of which he is National Chairman. He is having some fun these days using antiNixon quotes from Barry Goldwater to raise Democratic campaign funds, linking Gerald Ford to Robert Vesco as men who believe Mr. Nixon's troubles are caused by a liberal conspiracy, and figuring out how to spend the Republican money he expects to get as result of the Democrats Watergate suit against the Grand Old Party.

title: One in 3 Hotel Guests Is a Towel Thief, Bible Pincher, or Worse
description: DID you stuff an ash tray into your suitcase before checking out of that motel last summer? Not such a heinous crime, perhaps, but the fact remains that the purloining of such souvenirs from hotels and motels throughout the country has reached absolutely staggering proportions. The ripoff is so colossal, in fact, that the industryan estimated 21,000 hotels and 43, 500 motelsfinds it impossible to compute the exact value of the items taken, although some sources predict that in 1974 the figure will come to around $500million. They also predict that one of every three persons who stay at an American hotel or motel this year will take part of it with him when he or she leaves. Many guests will, of course, satisfy themselves with the ubiquitous ash tray, but an enormous number will also carry off towels, sheets, bedspreads, flatware and Bibles, while others will steal bedside lamps, television sets (by the thousands) and whole suites of furniture. One hotel even had an immense statue taken and another reported that a room had actually been

title: Child for Mrs. Winslow
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Gary Winslow. of Worthington, Mass., on Jan. 18 in the Cooley Dickerson Hdspital in Northampton, Mass. Mrs. Winslow, a kindergarten teacher, is the former Miss Arlene Madsen of Hillsdale, N. Y.

title: For Latins: 2d Industrial Revolution
description: BUENOS AIRES may come to be referred as the second industrial lution broke out last and nowhere else was it far reaching as in Latin America.

title: Fuel Crisis
description: ASBURY PARK  There is mounting public concern over the national energy crisis, to say the least, but New Jersey's boating industry apparently has not heard about it.

title: In Union, There's Vienna or Salzburg
description: UNIONAustria and New Jersey are, of course, an ocean apart, but a visit to Cafe Mozart, right in the heart of this township's business district, can result in one imagining that he Is spending brief interlude in Vienna or, perhaps, Salzburg.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Texfi Industries, Inc., a leading producer of textile fabrics, has subleased 55,000 square feet of office space at 1114 Avenue of the Americas.

title: Wall Street Again Doubts Profitability
description: Henry Ross Perot, the Texas computer millionaire who became Wall Street's biggest backer three years ago, decided recently he had had enough. He had pumped enough money into the securities business, and he was getting out.

title: Mining Is Stressed In South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa  Mining, long the bulwark of South Africa's economy, is more than ever expected to be the lifesaver of the future.

title: 91 Terriobu Is First in Bowie Dash
2 Die in Japan Hospital Fire
description: TOKYO, Jan. 26 (AP)Fire swept through a hospital today in Onomochi, 500 miles southwest of Tokyo, killing two persons and injuring 10, police officials reported. They said there were only 42 patients in the hospital when the fire broke out, and that most of them were evacuated to safety.

title: Truitt to Resign Post,
description: KENT, Ohio, Jan. 26 (AP)  Frank Truitt, the Kent State basketball coach, said today he was resigning At the end of the current sea. son, Truitt gave no reason for the resianation.

title: SECURITY EASED AT INDIANS TRIAL
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 26The judge in the Wounded Knee Indian uprising trial has relaxed security rules to allow prospective jucors to enter the Federal courthouse here without being searched after ?? torneys ?? that the St. Paul courthouse was taking on the appearance of an armed camp.

title: Dismay and Outrage Over Nixon Erupt at Conservatives Parley
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26  If President Nixon was looking to conservatives for support in his hour of travail, he would have been dismayed by the words that echoed through the meeting rooms of Washington's Mayflower Hotel this weekend.

title: Racers on Edge, And So Is Barber
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 26 (UPI).The Olympic distance gold medalist, Lasse Viren of Finland, leads a field of 350 runners Feb. 3 in the 13mile. San Blas de Yllescas run in the little mountain town of Coamo.

title: Paterson, Newark
description: PATERSON  The Health Department here will begin a campaign tomorrow to vaccinate all unprotected children in this city against measles. Officials hope to prevent a measles outbreak of epidemic proportions this spring when cases traditionally peak.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE CONSUMER price index rose in December to 138.5 per cent of the 1967 base, indicating an 8.8 per cent increase in the cost of living for 1973. The rise in December alone was 0.7 per cent.... Auto deliveries by United States manufacturers in the Jan. 11.20 period dropped more than 30 per cent from the yearearlier level to 2.92 million vehicles. Small cars accounted for 48.4 per cent of sales, compared with 36.8 per cent in the similar period of 1973.... General M'otors will lay off 75,000 production workers temporarily in 14 assembly plants.

title: Ross and Fishbach In State Net Final
Writers Dinner Honors Jackson Tonighing
description: New York's baseball writers will hold their 51st annual dinner and musical satire tonight, with Reggie Jackson of the Oakland A's sharing the spotlight with two stars of New York's past, Joe DiMaggio and Willie Mays.

title: Prosit! Beer, a Gastronomic Joy and an Economic Delight, Froths
description: They say in Australia that the water was Unfit to drink a century ago in the sinkholes that were Sydney and Melbourne, so they had to drink imported beer. There was subsequently a big effort to clean up the water supplies, and the reason, as every serious drinker knows, was so that the beer could be produced domestically and in vast quantity..

title: Steele Takes Title In U.S. Ski Jump
Late TV Listings
description: Face the Nation: Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, Channel 2, 11:30 A.M.

title: 2 Meetings on Council Rules
description: The City Council's Committee on Rules, Privileges and Elections will call on meetings tomorrow and Tuesday at 10 A.M. at City Hall to debate proposed changes in Council rules.

title: Music
description: THE man in charge of money at the Metropolitan Operahis job is no bowl of cherries these dayshas a Doctor of Music degree hangling glamorously on the wall behind his desk, but it's as phony as lago's good intentions. He ordered it in the mail strictly as a gag. William H. Hadley doesn't know beans about music or opera. He knows a lot about business though, and has a businessman's way of cutting artistic pretensions down to size and getting to the crux of a situation. The crux of the situation at the Met is that it is in one of the worst financial crises in its history and, according to the finance director, You can't spend more money than you've got, and survive.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Courtroom cases. Who does not date upon them when they are Well written? The keen district attorney and the equally keen counsel for the defense. Objections sustained or overruled. Thrust and parry; and will the bandage be removed from the eyes of the Goddess of Justice?

title: Housing Agency Is Imperiled
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey Housing Finance Agency, could be out of business by end of the year, its director dourly predicts.

title: Economist Sees Pro Football Salaries Doubling in Two Years
description: DALLAS, Jan. 26 (UFI)The World Football League held its first player draft last week and the National Football League starts drafting on Tuesday, so it is that time again when folks like George Scully might wish they were talented defensive backs graduating from Ohio State.

title: Busy Woman Keeps Eye on Courts
description: ALBANYOne dark morning this week, Louise Strassenburg woke up at 4:45 A.M., left her house in Belle Terre at 6 o'clock, met her car pool in Rockland County two and a half hours later and finally arrived at the State Capitol here at noon. Her day was just beginning.

title: Brooklyn College Digging Archeology
description: A small classroom at Brooklyn College has become a new center for the study of archeology and the final resting place for some 750 ancient skeletons and other finds from college excavations in Eastern Europe and the Mideast.

title: Ford Hopeful on End To Arab Oil Embargo
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 26 (UPI)Vice President Ford said today that he hoped to see the Arab oil embargo end shortly and declared, We will never again permit any.foreign nation to have Uncle Sam over a barrel of oil.

title: Fuel Crisis Stirs and Stymies Consumerists
description: Some national and regional consumer organizations are trying to make their influence felt in the fuel crisis with programs aimed at legislation to revamp the rate structure of the energyusing utilities and to help guide state Governments in their allocation of fuel.

title: Rangers Give Fans a Whirl at Dancing
description: Once a year the New York Rangers deign to doff their skates and mingle, with the mortals, their loud but loyal fans. And Friday night was the big occasionthe annual Ranger Fan Club dinnerdance in the ballroom of the Stetler Hilton hotel.

title: For Europe, the Alliance Is Strained
description: PARIS  Whatever happened to Secretary of State Kissingees Year of Europe? It was the year that never was  or was it?

title: SAIGON DISSIDENT BARRED TO PRESS&
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 26  Goverhment policemen today prevented about 20 foreign newsmen from entering the home of an antiGovernment figure and former political prisoner.

title: Nixon Expected to Rename Burns Reserve Board Head
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) President Nixon will shortly announce the reappointment of Arthur H. Burns to a new fouryear term as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, White House sources said today.

title: Canada Fears Inflation, Not Oil
description: OTTAWA  Unlike many of her friends and neighbors, Canada probably has enough oil this winter, or nearly enough, and inflation is the only really dark cloud on the economic horizon, as this snowcovered capital looks with guarded optimism into the new year.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: A Bluebill Hunt
description: BRANFORD, Conn.  In robes of gray, dawn slunk down Long Island Sound. The heaving waters were steaming in the bitter cold,, and no birds flew.

title: Required Exhaust Tests
description: TRENTON, Jan. 23The nation's first statewide, mandatory automobile exhaust inspection system will begin this Friday at 68 state operated inspection lanes throughout New Jersey.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Bennett College Offers Horsemanship Course
description: Bennett College of Millbrook, N. Y., will offer a threeyear program in horsemanship starting with this year's fall semester. Dr. James M. Park, dean of the women's college, situated about 15 miles east of Poughkeepsie, said the program had been approved by the New York State Department of Education.

title: New and Recommended
description: THE EYE OF THE STORM, by Patrick White. (Viking, $8.95.) The latest novel by the Australian winner of the 1973 Nobel Prize for literature; a major work as generous as it is demanding about the death of an imperious old woman and the twisted lives left behind.

title: Point of View
description: Unless means are found to resume the full flow of Japan's fuel imports, now disrupted by Middle Eastern disturbances, our country will face a near economic disaster.

title: Oil Industry Critics Chided
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) Frank Ikard, the president of the American Petroleum Institute, critcized Congress for what he called adopting a punitive attitude toward the oil industry without getting down to the fundamentals of solving the energy problem.

title: Kickback Indictments in Kansas Include Brother of the Governor
description: TOPEKA, Kan. Jan. 26The administration of Gov. Robert Docking has been rocked by 24 indictments alleging political kickbacks.

title: Giants in Strong Draft Position Tuesday
Children Supplant Cars On West Side Highway
description: The following activities took place yesterday on crucial stretch of one of the country's most heavily traveled highways:

title: New Zealand Stressing Meat
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand The clamant world demand for meat has recently, brought drastic changes in New Zealand's economic thinking.

title: Bill Widens U.S. Role on Power Sites
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 26Officials of the Nixon Administration have drafted a proposed law designed to speed up the often complex and controversial decisions involved in locating power plants, oil refineries and other large energyproducing facilities.

title: 9 Named to Advisory Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) President Nixon has announced the appointment of nine members of the National Advisory Committee on Oceans and Atmosphere. Those named for terms ending Oct. 18, 1976, include Edwin A. Link, founder of Link Aviation, Inc., in Binghamton, N. Y. The advisory committee was set up in 1971 to assist the Secretary of Commerce and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

title: Canadian Farmers Reap Profits
description: CLANDEBOYE, Manitoba The snow was heavy on the Canadian prairies, and Lawrence Macklin was in good spirits as he wintered his herd of 150 Aberdeen Angus and hauled grain by truck to the elevator.

title: News of the Stage
description: Adele Holzer, who sponsored the Galt MacDermot Gerome Ragni musical Dude, last season, is shaping up as one of New York's busiest producers this season. On Feb. 3 she will present Terrence McNally's comedy Bad Habits at the Astor Place Theater, and next spring she will open a new musical, Brainchild, on Broadway.

title: U.S. ENVOY CHOICE PLEASES CANADA
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 23  In the changing and sometimes stormy climate of relations between Canada and the United States, the appointment of William J. Porter as the American Ambassador to Ottawa has been generally welcomed here as hopeful sign.

title: Can a Skier Spoiled by Vermont Find Happiness in the Poconos?
description: DONT panic! the editorial in recent ski magazine advised, but we all did. Eastern skiers have always had to worry about getting snow; now we had to worry about getting gas, too. Stan and Chuck, stuck with a Detroit gasguzzler, loaded the trunk, with four fivegallon cansa very serious business if there had been a collisionand the fumes nearly asphyxiated us on the drive up to Stratton. Someone came up with the idea of starting the trip home from Vermont at 4 A.M. Monday morning instead of Sunday night, so by the time the tank grew empty the stations on the Thruway would be open for business. A friend with a share in a house at Mount Snow bought a Volkswagen. Other friends gave seriaus consideration to spending weekends at the Central Park ice skating rink. The energy crisis was making cowards of all the schussboomers in town.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Here are a few programs the Government would be promoting right now If it seriously believed in the energy crisis:

title: Point of View
description: JERUSALEMIsrael is small country, poor in natural resources, and, therefore, heavily dependent for her industrialization and economic development on foreign trade.

title: TORONTO BUILDS SOARING TOWER
Tomb Paintings Are Described at Art Conference
description: DETROIT, Jan. 26A painted Greek chamber tomb of the thirdcentury B.C. and some sixthcentury B.C. Greekstyle tomb paintings excavated in Western Turkey excited interest among art historians at the annual meeting of the College Art Association here. Both findings give important new evidence of ancient Greek painting styles, hitherto viewable, only on vases and other pottery.

title: Hassam at Newark Museum
description: NEWARKIn its current display of recent acquisitions, the Newark Museum is exhibiting for the first time an important addition to its collection of American Impressionist paintings. The work is Gloucester, an oil painting by Childe Hassam, done in 1899.

title: Magazines Feel the Paper Pinch
description: Norman Cousins scored a personal victory, last year when he reacquired control of his old magazine, the Saturday Review, and consolidated it with his new Publication, World magazine. But now that he's back and ready to go, he's been scrambling for the paper he needs to publish.

title: Chicago Police Saddle Up
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (UPI)The Chicago police drum and bugle corps played a musical salute to a horse in Civic Center Plaza to mark the reinstatement of the mounted patrol, which was abolished in 1947. While a 7yearold gelding quarterhorse named Lurch swished its tail and tossed its head Wednesday, the band gave forth with The Old Oaken Bucket. The occasion was the token presentation by the Chicago Jaycees of a gift horse to the police department.

title: ABUSES REPORTED IN MITCHELLLAMA
description: ALBANY, Jan. 26  The New York City Housing and Development Administration needs to take drastic and immediate action to curb abuses in the MitchellLama middleincome housing program and to restore the program to a sound financial base, an audit by State Controller Arthur Levitt concluded today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I read the article A Black Bank in Harlem Finds the Road Rocky [Jan. ,6] with great interest. However, there was an error that should be corrected.

title: Both Sides Rejoice as Israelis Start Home
Some Tips For Voters
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26President Nixon has been asking for suggestions about how to improve the way we pick Presidential candidates and if it hadn't been for a fall down a flight of stairs, we'd have had the list in sooner.

title: MRS. CHESIMARD EXPECTS A CHILD
description: Joanne D. Chesimard's lawyer confirmed reports yesterday that her client was pregnant and expressed the belief that Mrs. Chesimard's trial for the murder of a New Jersey state would be postponed.The lawyer Mrs. Evelyn Williams, declined to speculate nancy was or whether Mrs. Chesimard would seek an abortion or have her child.

title: Banks Are Rushing Abroad PellMell
description: Multinational banks to serve multinational corporations. That's where the bit growth in banking took place In 1973, and that's where things will happen in 1974.

title: Italy's Food Shops Haggler Paradise
description: ROMEAn Italian housewife's shopping job is never done because there are so many shopkeepers  more, it seems, than in any other Western country.

title: South Vietnam, a U. S. Subsidiary
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam It has been said sardonically that SoUth Vietriam is a wholly owned American subsidiary. An exaggeration of course, but not without a seed of truth, for the United States subsidizes most of the country's imports and provides most of the cash for the Saigon Government's budget.

title: Dodgers Gone, but Kennel Club R.eturns to Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn Dodger football club ended its stay in that borough in. 1946; the close of the 1957 baseball season saw the Dodgers leave for Los Angeles, and on Nov. 29, 1959, the Brooklyn Kennel Club held its last show in the armory on Bedford Avenue. Anna Katherine Nicholas, one of the four women to have judged best in show at Westminster, was arbiter at that last Brooklyn fixture. News of Dogs

title: The Land of Lafcadio Hearn
description: REMEMBER Pullman sleepers? Starched, shinyfaced porters bearing fluffy pillows and afterdinner drinks to Kay Francis and Don Ameche? Well, as I maneuvered my hulk into my thirdtier pallet on the overnight special express from Tokyo to Matsue recently, I realized that the delivers of Bclass bunks on the Japanese National Railways, had never seen these prewar films..

title: Son to Mrs. John Collin
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. John Nicholas Cain of Great Leighs, England, on Jan. 9 at Great Leighs, The child will be named Michael. Mrs. Collin is the former Miss Patricia Alexandre Herrick, daughter of Mrs. J. Alexandre Tompkins of Cedarhurst, L. I., and Walter Russell Herrick of West Hartford, Conn., and Fisher's Island, N. Y.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: BrooklynThe Art of Decoration: Drawings and Objects from the Collections of the CooperHewitt Museum, through Feb. 3, English Prints and Drawings: 17th Century to the Present, through Feb. 17 and Figures in Clay: TerraCottas from Ancient India, through Mar. 5 Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P. M. and Sundays 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Brooklyn Museum.

title: Joanne L. Brundage Married To Sgt. Horace C. Wilcox 3d
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Jan. 26 Miss Joanne Lyle Brundage, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard D. Brundage, was married here this afternoon to Sgt. Horace Cornwell Wilcox 3d of the Marine Corps, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilcox Jr. of Madison, Conn.

title: The City/Suburban Commute: Some Major Stops and Starts
description: The Henry Hudson Parkway was built in the mid30s and has done its job well for 40 years. But its maintenance has long been neglected and now the lovely ride along the river can no longer be taken for granted.

title: 1974: Year of the Mideast
description: BEIRUT Last October's wir between the Arabs and Israelis and the an crisis arising from restricted supplies and soaring prices are making..1974 the year the Middle East in economic, as well as political, terms.

title: March Bridal for Donna Humphrey
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 26Mr. and Mrs. Floyd L. Humphrey Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Donna Lawson Humphrey, to Kieran Patrick Quinn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Quinn of New York and Southold, L. I. The wedding is planned for March 16 at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of Christ the King here.

title: Mr. Nixon on Energy...
description: Either the energy shortage is not so acute as the country has been led to believe or President Nixon's message to Congress on the subject is sadly inadequate to deal with it. The evidence is that the situation is indeed serious not because the Arab oil embargo has forced Americans to scramble a bit for gasoline, but because sooner or later this country's nonrenewable resources will be too depleted to keep up with the traditional practices the world's most wasteful society. Regrettably, the President did not address himself to that salient fact.

title: Withdrawal
description: By tomorrowall going according to planIsrael will have withdrawn its forces from the southern salient of its bridgehead across the Suez Canal. The threemonth siege of Suez City will thus be lifted, the 20,000man Third Army of Egypt freed from the envelopment, it has suffered since October. For the first time since 1967, the Israelis have withdrawn from Arab lands occupied in war.

title: William Gibson Fiance Of Larissa Eve Warren
description: Dean Emeritus William C. Warren of the Columbia University School of Law and Mrs. Warren of New York and Ridgewood, N. J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Larissa Eve Warren, to William David Gibson, son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Gibson of Pittsburgh. A wedding in the summer is planned.

title: Soviet Perspective on U.S. Economy
description: Who controls the great American business enterprises like General Motors, A.T.&T., Alcoa and General Dynamics? Why do companies split their stocks? What is the leadership of the A.F.L.C.I.O.? Do manufacturers of military hardware make large profits? These are questions to which one normally seeks the answers in a standard reference work, perhaps an encyclopedia. These carry the authority in the Western world to settle even the most heated dispute of fact.

title: Diana Ettinger to Marry June
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 26  Mr. and Mrs. Curtis T. Ettinger have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diana Carol Ettinger, to Dr. WolfPeter Kloevekorn, a surgical resident at the German Heart Center in Munich, Germany. The wedding is planned for June 9 here.

title: Music in Review
description: Gabriel Chodos, an associate professor at Dartmouth College, who made his debut here three seasons ago, is something of a Schubert specialist. In his first New York appearance since his debut, in Tully Hall on Monday night, the pianist opened his program with the composer's Sonata in A (Op. 120) and closed it with the Sonata in G (Op. 78).

title: Owning a Share of America Is Global
description: Shares of United States corporations, offering bits of the world's largest and most active industrial economy, have a natural fascination for investors all over the World. Commitments can be made through Wall Street, but lately more and more of the world's stock exchanges have been welcoming American listings.

title: A Designer of Prospect Park Stepping Out of Olmsted's Shadow
description: The man who, in the opinion of some scholars, was most instrumental in designling Prospect Park, will be honored by the Friends of Prospect Park in a series of programs marking the sesquicentennial of his birth next month.

title: Owners to Skip Taxes as Fuel Costs Surge
description: The owners and managing agents of rentcontrolled buildings in the city are predicting a marked rise in tax delinquency as the inevitable result of the recent surge in fuel prices.

title: India, Pakistan, Bangladesh On the Edge of Hunger
description: NEW DELHIHis name is Paran Paswan. Every morning at 5 A.M. the peasant and his wife and four children leave their mud and straw but to work in the fields of Ranisarai, a squalid village of 22 homes in the state of Bihar.

title: Belger First In 1,000 at Track Here
description: About 12 hours after he had brought 15,000 spectators to their feet at the Millrose Games with a brilliant finishing kick in the invitation schoolboy mile run, Mark Belger toed the starting line yesterday in the 1,000yard run at the 25th annual Cardinal Hayes Games.

title: Who Will Feed the World's Hungry?
description: The Need for Aid

title: The World May Have To Live With Shortages
description: WASHINGTONAs recently as a year ago, it was conventional wisdom that the oil countries could never get together"; it was believed that they could not risk retaliation from a united. Western world. But, today, through the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the oil nations have quintupled their price. They have cut back production. They have raised fears of global depression. And they have left the consuming countries, particularly in Europe and Japan, in disarray, and alliances such as the Common Market and NATO, in peril. Indeed, Europe's every scramble for a special deal has strengthened the confidence of the oil cartel.

title: C.O.P. Legislator Won't Run
description: YORK, Pa., Jan. 26 (AP)Representative George A. Goodling, Republican of Pennsylvania, announced today that he would not seek reelection Mr. Goodling, 77 years old, was elected to the House in 1960 and was re elected in 1962, 1966, 1968 and 1970.

title: State Accused on Hospital Inspections
description: A consumers group has charged that the State Health Department has violated the state law mandating full inspection of hospitals before they are granted certificates! of operation.

title: An Alliance In Disorder
description: PARISThe weakening of the ninenation European Community, enormously accelerated by the energy crisis, comes at a time when Europe's relationships with the United States are on the downgrade. As a result, the Western world's position visavis Soviet Russia is debilitated.

title: Chess:; When Is a Bad Bishop Good? When Your Pawns Are Ajar
Brezhnev in Cuba Tomorrow
description: HAVANA, Jan. 26 (Reuters) Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, will arrive here Monday, the official newspaper Granma announced today.

title: Red Smith
description: By now, buyers of the San Diego Padres outnumber buyers of tickets for their games. A considerable segment of the population, it seems, would sooner spend $12million for the franchise than $3.50 to watch them play. This will seem odd only to those who have not seen the Padres on the field.

title: Australia Angers Business
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Restrictive policies of the new Labor Government have so incensed the multimillionaire mining magnate Lang Hancock, of Perth, that he has taken personal charge of a revived movement for the secession of the huge, oreproducing state of Western Australia from the rest of the country.

title: S.O.R.C. Starts Season Friday
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan, 26Yachting's Southern Ocean Racing Circuit starts its sixrace schedule here Friday when 96 yachts are expected to answer the starting signals for the voyage up to Anclose Key and back.

title: 63 Die in Jet Crash
description: A Turkish airliner crashed on takeoff from Izmir, kill ing 63 of the 73 persons aboard. Identified among the dead were Dr. and Mrs. Horace W. Gerarde of Tenafly, N. J. Details, Page 3.

title: In Egypt, Hope Rises From Struggle
description: CAIROOn a hot night in July 22 years ago, a few officers led 6,000 soldiers into Cairo to overthrow King Farouk and undertake a revolutionary transformation of Egypt  a country suffering from corruption, foreign domination of the backward economy and injustice.

title: Cities Tackle Ills In Diverse Ways
description: In London and Sydney people and industries are given incentives to move out into the greenery of the countryside. Bonn and Paris build new cities away from their teeming cores. Moscow limits its size by law. India, despairing of piecemeal regional remedies, nationalizes its urban programs. In Tokyo, selfcontained skyscrapers, actually ?? that use their rubbish as lifesupport systems, heighten the skyline, end In Rio de Janeiro, housesbymailorder to rePlace slums multiply by the hundreds.

title: Article 148763392 -- No Title
In Japan, a Round Robin of Trouble
description: TOKYOWhen historians look back on Japan a century from now, they may well judge that 1973 was the year ending the nation's vaunted economic progress.

title: From Baseball Hero to Hustler, Michael's a Hit
description: FOR a number a years I felt like a barren tree. I knew there were a lot of creative juices at work inside of me and yet nothing was happening. Then, in 1973, I finally bore fruit. Boy, did I ever! It was hanging all over me.

title: Linking Up the World Energy Crisis
description: The energy crisis is with usor is it?

title: Knicks Top 76ers, 12298
East and west: Trade Expands
New Novel
description: In their prime, the Heide Indians of the Queen Charlotte Islands, British Columbia, practiced potlatch, slavery and a touch of cannibalism. A young fellow named David Nail falls into the hands of the Heide in the mid19th century, when they are slightly past their prime. But the predators have kept up enough of the old customs to flog and enslave their captive and enter him in a championship potlatch ritual. (The ultimate in potlatch oneupmanship is the conspicuous destruction of property, like a Grade A slave.)

title: The President's Friend, Mr. Rebozo, is the Central Figure
description: WASHINGTONI suppose that it would sound incredible to many people who did not know how cperate, said President Nixon last October in describing to the nation how he had refused to be told who had contributed to his 1972 campaign until after the election.

title: Point of View
description: A small African country recently turned to the Swedish aid agency for help. Not for money, not for knowhow, not for equipment or food. It begged that we use our good offices with Swedish newsprint producers, so that it might buy a few thousand tons to save the country's two small gaily newspapers.

title: 3 Jersey Fishermen, Rescued By Russians, Are Back Home
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 26 (AP) Three fishermen who put out to sea on Jan. 12 for a planned fiveday trip are back home this weekend, exhausted but otherwise in good health despite a twoweek ordeal on the stormy North Atlantic.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Decorating rooms around the energy crisis?

title: F.B.I. Recovers $400,000 From Airport Bank Robbery
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 26Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigaton said today that more than $400,000 stolen in an airport bank robbery last year had been recovered.

title: Britain in Market: Idealism Dissipates
description: BRUSSELSThe idealism was quickly dissipated in the first year of British membership in the Common Market. Europeans haggled over money and jobs as the year opened and saw their fragile community strained by the energy crisis as it closed.

title: ROMAN OFFICIALS ACCUSED OF GRAFT
description: ROME, Jan. 26 One of the first sights tourists see on their way from the International Airport to the eternal city is cluster of new buildings in a bend on the Tiber River.

title: Margaret Greig Will Be Bride Of Met Curator
description: The engagement of Miss Margaret Anne Fenelle Greig of Oxford, England, daughter of Rear Adm. M. G. Greig, Royal Navy, retired, of Somerset, Bermuda, and Mrs. Margaret E. S. Greig of Haddenham, Buckinghamshire, England, to Morrison Harris Heckscher of Louds Island, Me., and New York, has been announced. The future bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Gustave A. Heckscher of Devon, Pa.

title: Youth Is Turned On To Energy Shortage
description: Some recent letters to Mm. Virginia H. Knauer, director of the United States Office of Consumer Affairs, indicate, at least among the younger gcneration, an awareness of energy problems and a willingness to cut back on power use.

title: Son to the Macombers
description: A son was born Jan. 17 in the Harkness Pavilion to Mr: and Mrs. John D. Macomber of New York. Mrs. Macomber is the former Miss Caroline Morgan, daughter of Mrs. Alexander P. Morgan of New York and the late Mr. Morgan. The child, whose father is president of the Celanese Corporation, is named William Butts Macomber 2d, for his uncle, the United States Ambassador to Turkey.

title: Curl and Nichols Share 2Stroke Lead
Kennedy Appeals for New Aid For Indochinese War Victims
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 Senator Edward M. Kennedy today called on President Nixon to chart a new beginning in relations with Indochina by giving top priority to humanitarian and people concerns in our aid to the area, and by shedding our obsession with weapons deliveries.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Smallpox Cases Up Twofold; Better Reporting Is Cited
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 26 (UPI)The number of smallpox cases reported worldwide doubled from 1972 to 1973, but the National Center for Disease Control said yesterday that this was no cause for alarm.

title: Unsung, $9.20, Wins
description: PAWTUCKET, R.I., Jan. 26 (AP)Unsung surged from second place in the stretch today to take the 1 1/16 milps Winter Marathon Purse at Narragansett Park by 1 lengths. The 7yearold geraling paid $9.20, $6 and $180 for $2 across the board. Pizzalalla paid $6.20 and $4 for second and Prince Different paid $4 for show.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: WILUAM PROXMIRE: YOU CAN DO ITINext to the sin of stuffing our children with food by forcing them to clean their overloaded plate... , the... most common crime we... commit against their health is driving them to school or insisting that the school bus stop at every corner.

title: South Vietnam, a Year After Truce, Is Still. Racked by Indecisive War
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam The year that has elapsed since the signing of the Paris peace agreements on Jan. 27, 1973, has not brought peace to South Vietnam.

title: Expansion Diverse and Multinational
Canadiens Score Over Hawks, 41
Mary Elizabeth Stroup Betrothed
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 26The Rev. and Mrs. Dudley Johnson Stroup of Scarsdale and Madison, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Stroup, to Roger Mansfield Wolters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Wolters of Ossining.

title: Sharp Gary Wins Militia By a Neck
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26Taking command late in the race after stalking the pace to the deep stretch, Edward R. Scharp's Sharp Gary scored a neck victory, in the fifth running of the $28,025 Militia Stakes at Liberty Bell Park today.

title: Mrs. Ring Has Son
description: A son was born on Jan. 11 to Mr. and Mrs. Michael Ring of Brooklyn in the Klingenstein Pavilion of Mount Sinai Hospital. Mrs. Ring is the former Miss Rochelle Friedman of Brooklyn. The child, the couple's second, is named David Alexander. His father is a salesman.

title: An Earl's Estate Becomes a Luxury Retreat
description: CULLEN, Scotland  A pale winter dawn struggles from doon the brae over the soft green moors of northeast Scotland. A party of sportsmen immaculately dressed in tweeds, plusfours and forestgreen capes emerges from a vast Georgian mansion. A pack of dogs and guns are bundled into LandRovers. And the day's shooting begins on the 100,000acre estate of the Earl of Seafield.

title: New Cabinet in Turkey Is Officially Approved
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 26 (UPI)  President Fahri S. Kortiturk today officially approved the Cabinet nominations submitted by Turkey's new coalition, ending a threemonth administrative crisis.

title: British Theater
description: A trimester report on how the heralded British Theater Season is going at the Brooklyn Academy of Music would come up with a grade of A.

title: The importance of being an ethical ethnic
description: Finishing this book, I imagined a little conversation between tame weary Jewish cabMe and its author:

title: Lawyer Who Aided Nixon's Papers Gift Defends Tax Claim
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 26 (AP)The tax lawyer who handled President Nixon's claims of a tax deduction, for the gift of his papers to the National Archives contended today that the process was legal.

title: Riding Indoors in Somerset
description: BASKING RIDGEThanks to a newly constructed indoor arena, equestrians at the Somerset County Riding Stable can now ride horseback in fair weather or foul.

title: Asians Hail U.S. Role in Aid Bank
description: MANILAA gloom that was pervasive within the headquarters of the Asian Development Bank in Manila, capital of the Philippines, throughout most of 1973 lifted suddenly near the year's end.

title: Headliners
description: The plot of the novel was that the Vice President, appointed when his predecessor died of a heart attack, was duped into a confrontation with Moscow by Iranian nationalists who want to break the SovietAmerican detente. The author submitted a sample chapter that took place aboard Air Force Two. But the president of Random House said the idea had been turned down because it was not suitable for the Random House list of published books. The author of the proposed novel? Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew. His office had no comment.

title: Getting the Mod for Family Skiing Dollar
description: EAST MADISON, N.H.In this era of inflation, some of the Northeast's ski centers are attempting to fit their prices into the budgets of skiing families. Lift tickets, for example, are News available for less of than $7 a day at such resorts as Skiing Big Vanilla at Davos and Holiday Mountain in the southern Catskills; Lost Valley in Maine, Mount Rowe in New Hampshire and McCauley Mountain in the Adirondacks. Jim Kelly, owner of the Brodie Mountain center in the northern Berkshires of Massachusetts, has a parking lot to accommodate 100 motorized campers. Squaw Mountain at Greenville, Me., has its staff teaching parents how to teach their youngsters, thereby doing away with the need of costly ski school lessons for the chil

title: Taiwan's Economy Continues to Grow
description: TAIWANThe last several years, politically among the bleakest that Taiwan has experienced, have ironically been the most outstanding economically.

title: When Is a 'Rhinoceros A Turkey?:When Is a 'Rhinoceros' a Turkey?
description: FOUR films seen. Four still to be released. With the two-day run here earlier this week of Tom O'Horgan's film version of Ionesco's "Rhinoceros," the American Film Theater has reached the halfway mark in its first subscription season designed to bring culture to the otherwise depressed, that is, the American moviegoer.That isn't exactly the way the AFT is described by Henry T. Weinstein, the organization's vice president in charge of creative affairs. He says its aim is to bring "to audiences everywhere great works of the theater, performed by consummate artists, under the guidance of major directors, on film."That definition is at my elbow in a press release I might not have read if, while scanning it, I hadn't gotten the impression it said that Mr. Weinstein, now planning the AFT's second season, was negotiating with Pirandello and Brecht. I'm aware that both playwrights have long since left us but I'm also aware that the AFT often thinks that it is thinking big. Actually the press release said that negotiations were going on with the estates of Pirandello and Brecht.Because the AFT is apparently a financial success, despite early ticket problems when a computer system broke down, and because it is apparently going into a second season in the fall, it is fair, I think, to assess what has been accomplished so far. Unlike a couple of my more enthusiastic colleagues, I didn't review the entire first season series last September on the basis of several reels of excerpts from the eight productions.Seen in New York so far have been O'Neill's "The Iceman Cometh," directed by John Frankenheimer, Pinter's "The Homecoming," directed by Peter Hall, Albee's "A Delicate Balance," directed by Tony Richardson and, most recently, "Rhinoceros." Upcoming are "Luther," "Butley," "Lost in the Stars" and "The Three Sisters."With the exception of Peter Hall's fine production of "The Homecoming," which works so well as a film that you don't pay any attention to its theatrical seams, the AFT looks to be producing a new type of filmone that may not ultimately be in the greatest demand. The AFT is manufacturing the Coffee Table Movie, something that is supposed to establish one's intellectual credentials by physical association. Purchase tickets but give them to your friends.I don't mean to sound furious about what the AFT is up to. These films won't harm anyone. They'll bore quite a few and perhaps make a lot of other people feel as if they've taken their culture vitamins for the year. The disappointing thing about the project to date is the smallness of the thinking, which, I'm afraid, accurately represents the extent of the so-called arts explosion in the United States."The Iceman Cometh" is a tremendous, primal theatrical experience, but was it really necessary to film it again just so we could have the dubious pleasure of witnessing Lee Marvin fail in the key role as Hickey? It was nice seeing Robert Ryan and Fredric March in this version, but nothing can convince me that it was worth doing if, in the archives somewhere, then exists a print of that extraordinary TV tape version directed by Sidney Lumet, produced by Worthington Miner and starring Jason Robards.Why can't the AFT be truly adventuresome? If they insist on raiding O'Neill, why not do something tough and probably recalcitrant like "Strange Interlude" or "The Great God Brown"?For that matter, why did they choose Edward Albee's "A Delicate Balance" if they wanted to give audiences everywhere great works of the theater performed by consummate artists under the guidance of major directors on film?"A Delicate Balance" is an interesting idea for a play, but it is not a great work of theater. It starts off as a satire of the type of comedy on which Broadway thrived for decades: people meeting politely in three-sided drawing rooms, talking a great deal more than necessary about how they like their martinis mixed (in an era in which people swig vodka on the rocks, the comic shock of the five-to-one martini has been lost), but instead of worrying about who isn't sleeping with whom, the crisis with which they're faced is their own emptiness. It sounds like a good idea for a play, but Albee's grasp of satire is ambiguous. You can't be sure what he's up to. The play becomes as vacuous as the form it is satirizing, and boredom sets in with the limp epigrams.Albee is a first-rate American dramatist, but why did the AFT elect to do his least interesting failure instead ofsaya double bill of "The Death of Bessie Smith" and "The American Dream"? The answer probably is that a double bill of short films wouldn't be as good box-office as somethingin this case, anything  starring Katharine Hepburn, Paul Scofield, Lee Remick and Joseph Cotten. Those names, and the drawing room setting, I suspect, still mean something to those citizens of middle America for which the AFT was designed. It's all so highly cultivatedand so dead.With the exception of "The Homecoming," none of the AFT productions has been quite the play it was written to be, or the film it is presented as being. None of the plays has been grossly "opened up," except for "Rhinoceros." They've pretty much stuck to their original theatrical locales, but they've been photographed in that dumb tennis-match stylethe back-and-forth cutting from one medium close-up to anotherthat has about as much to do with the original theatrical experience as the intermissions with which the films are presented.Intermissions are a theatrical heritage. They're also a necessity. They give live actors a chance to catch their breath, but they have the effect of anesthetizing any movie worth its salt, especially any movie less than two or three hours long.The worst of the AFT ventures so far has been the O'Horgan version of "Rhinoceros," which is not great Ionesco, and not great Theater of The Absurd, to begin with. O'Horgan, perhaps in desperation, has taken this slight and fuzzy parable, about a civilization where people break their necks to turn into rhinoceroses, and has tried to straighten out the defects of the stage version, in which Zero Mostel was the riveting object of all attention even though he played a secondary role.In spite of a lot of clumsy, badly choreographed slapstick, in spite of some nice music by Galt MacDermot and an extremely attractive performance by Gene Wilder, who plays the leading role, Zero Mostel still is the riveting object of attention in the film. The reasons are that Mostel is an audaciously surprising actor, even when you think you know his style, and that "Rhinoceros" is a far from interesting play. How much more provocative would have been screen versions (if possible) of Ionesco's "The Bald Soprano" and "The Chairs"?Plays aren't films and films aren't plays, and three of the four AFT productions to date have landed in a no man's land between theater and film. With the exception of "The Homecoming," they do not record for posterity great theatrical performances, and they do not add anything to one's cinematic experience. Almost any five-minute segment of Robert Altman's "The Long Goodbye" is a greater artistic experience (pardon my language) than any 60-minute segment of the AFT's "Iceman," "A Delicate Balance" or "Rhinoceros."For years I've wished that there were some organization that would have as its function the presevation on film of great theatrical occasions. I think of Laurette Taylor in "The Glass Menagerie," Tallulah Bankhead and Fredric March end Florence Eldridge in "The Skin of Our Teeth," Tallulah again in "The Little Foxes," Laurence Olivier and Vivien Leigh doing their back-to-back "Cleopatras," Ethel Merman shooting that stuffed seagull in "Annie Get Your Gun." I mean the simplest kind of preservation: the performance photographed, preferably from a fixed position, with no close-ups, no alternating two-shots, no cinematic junk.Today, of course, there are fewer and fewer theatrical occasions worth saving. Those that are worth saving will probably be bought by Hollywood anyway.The AFT seems bent on preserving, not really accurately, plays that either have already been better preserved by others, or plays that reflect not the vitality of the living theater but the poverty that is contributing to its decline. With its intermissions, its Playbill-like programs, its piety about great works of theater and consummate artists, the AFT is simply pumping stale air into the lungs of an audience that would be better revived by going out occasionally to see one of the works of a truly living cinema, be it "Memories of Underdevelopment," "Day for Night," "The Long Goodbye," "Sleeper," "Mean Streets," or "Heavy Traffic."

title: The First Time Out, Uncle Vanya Was Uncle George
description: TWO women stand in the early dawn in a provincial Russian house: a storm has just passed over; the country is still dripping from it. There has been tension between them for some time. Suddenly they effect a reconciliation  hugging and gasping, and shyly sharing the same glass of wine.

title: Shelley Siegel Fiancee Of Martin Zimmerman
description: Dr. Max Siegel, a professor of education at Brooklyn College, and Mrs. Siegel of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Shelley Ann Siegel, to Martin H. Zimmerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Zimmerman of Brooklyn. A December wedding is planned.

title: BULGARIAN VESSEL SEIZED BY THE U.S. OFF JERSEY SHORE
description: A 270foot Bulgarian stern trawler carrying 79 men and a 182ton catch of mackerel was seized in international waters off the New Jersey shore early yesterday by a Coast Guard cutter that gave chase after allegedly sighting her fishing illegally inside the 12mile coastal limit.

title: Arthur Lentz, 65, ExDirector Of Olympic Committee, Dead
description: Arthur G. Lentz, director of the united States Olympic Cornmittee during its recent tumultuous years, died Friday in New York Hospital, He was 65 years old, and lived at 11 Riverside Drive and in Woodstock, N. Y.

title: After Her Husband Died She Came Into Her Own
description: THE lesser lives of a great art movement have a way of pointing up its weaknesses in a way that may not be readily apparent in the fate of its greatest practitioners. The rigorous structural audacities Of the Cubist style, for exampleat least as it was practiced by such major painters as Picasso, Braque, Leger, Grisconcealed the considerable decorative impulse that was also part of its formal apparatus.

title: The once and future shining example is a superspy now
description: HONG KONG. It had never been easy to believe that he embodied the future of revolutionary China. His voice was highpitched and wheezy, his delivery rapid and nervous. Add to that the fact that his Hupeh accent had a strange, even unpleasant ring to finely tuned Peking ears and it becomes impossible to believe that the masses there ever really hung on his every word, or even understood it, as they were ceaselessly exhorted to do for five years. Besides, there was the matter of his appearance. He had been a conquering general, a master of military tactics, but in his baggy uniforms, which always seemed to be cut a size too big, he looked more like a company quartermaster or the librarian at the staff college. Indoors, when others removed their caps, he kept his on because he was sensitive about his bald pate. Invariably, if he was absent from public view for more than a month, the rumors would he

title: Britons, Their Work Week Shortened, Worry Overtime
description: LONDONFor millions of Londoners these days, the gloom begins each morning with Robert Robinson and John Timpson, the newscasters on the British Broadcasting Corporation's radio show, Today. Things got so bad the other day that for the morning's good news they had to switch to Northern Ireland for a report on a new factory. int the troubled province.

title: Germany's Guests Stay
description: COLOGNE  The Yugoslavian guest worker stood on the platform of the Cologne station, waiting for the 1:06 P.M. express to Belgrade and Athens. I'll be coming back after Christmas, he said. I have a card from the company that says my job will be waiting for me. I've been working here 10 years and I really don't worry about it.

title: The Battle of the Border Closings
description: LUSAKA, Zambia  The battle of the borderclosings that began a year ago between Rhodesia and Zambia has strained both countries economies, but Zambians seem to be doing better than their neighbors in overcoming the squeeze caused by the embargo.

title: WIKTOR LABUNSKI 78, CONSERVATORY DEAN
description: Wiktor Labunski, composer and pianist, who retired three years ago as dean and artistinresidence at the Conservatory of Music of the University of Missouri in Kansas City, died there yesterday. He was 78 yeats old and lived in, Lenexa, Kan.

description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 26The Archbishop of Rio de Janeiro today denounced rigid antiCommunism and rejected charges of Communist influence in the church.

title: Franchising, Global Venture
description: The beaming, bearded face of Kentucky's Colonel Harlan Sanders is a familiar billboard sight in Hong Kong; McDonald's is booming on the Ginza. Even in the more remote corners of the world these days, franchising everything from houseboatrentals to pizza  is becoming big busineis indeed.

title: LINES STILL LONG AT GAS STATIONS
description: The lines grew longer and the tempers grew shorter at service stations yesterday as frustrated motorists scooted over the city and suburbs in search of fuel after word circulated that most stations had begun exhausting their monthly allotments.

title: Illinois Freshman Betters 2 Marks
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Jan. 26 (AP)Charlton Ehizuelen, a University of Illinois freshman from Nigeria, bettered Big Ten indoor records in the long jump and triple jump today in the Illinois  invitation track meet.

title: Taking Care of No. In Southeast Asia
description: BANGKOK, Thailand When a group of Indonesian officials visited Bangkok recently tonegotiate the purchase of 500,000 tons of rice, a senior Thai official pointed out that Thailand would be exporting in about I million tons in 1974 and that major portion of it was already committed to other customers.

title: A Report, Two Months After the Coup
description: ATHENSNine weeks after a military coup deposed the unpopular dictator, Col. George Papadopoulos, two unanswered questions still confound the people of Greece: Which men rule the.country and where are they leading it?

title: Esther Freilich to Be Bride June
description: Miss Esther Rose Freilich, an assistant professor of mathematics at the Bernard Baruch College of the City University, plans to be married here June 4 to Rudolph Jacob Lowy of Los Angeles.

title: Linda Stern Married
description: TRUMANSBURG, N. Y., Jan. 26Miss Linda Karen Stern, daughter of Mr. and. Mrs. Robert Stern of New York and Atlantic Beach, L. I., was married here this afternoon to Kevin Caulfield Reilly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Reilly of Westport, Conn. The ceremony was performed by Justice of the Peace James Rice at his home. Mr. Stern is president of Robert Folding Box Co., Inc., in Long Island City., Queens, New York. The bridegroom's father is a vice president of Koller & Smith Co., printer of business and bank forms in New York.

description: DURBAN, South Africa, Jan. 26 (Reuters)The organizers of the Comrades Marathon, South Africa's leading longdistance race, announced today that black runners would be barred despite calls for the race to be open to all athletes.

title: Leisure Time Grows for Workers, With Some Exceptions
description: Australian workers are devoted to leisure. If they are not given it by their employers, they'll take it, curtailing the normal 40hour work week by taking what they call a sickie  a day off for feigned illness.

description: APAPA, Nigeria  There are few outward signs now that the 22member Coastal Services, Ltd., company recently took over the 200member Union Maritime Commerciale's shipping, clearing and forwarding operations under Nigeria's indigenization laws.

description: ALGIERS North Africa, whose biggest production is people, is worried. Neither Tunisia, Algeria nor Morocco can handle her present population, let alone the big increases that come every year.

description: BUENOS AIRES  If the 25 million highly individualistic Argentines hold one belief in common, it is in economic miracles  the kind that have kept their country from financial insolvency for many years.

description: The Barnard College gymnasium floor was crossed with black circles and white lines for game and performance markers. description: CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 26 (AP)Army Lieut. Gen. George M. Seignious 2d has been named president of The Citadel, the statesupported military school announced yesterday. He will succeed Maj. Gen. James W. Duckett, who will retire after his 63d birthday in July.

description: MONTREALThe bill for last year's railroad strikes has been presented, and it comes to more than $500mi1Hon for the next two years, under a recent arbitration award that is'binding on both the railroads, the Canadian National and the Canadian Pacific, and the rail unions representing 90,000 employes.

title: Dogs and Cats A $2Billion Market
description: Roast duckling for dogs? Caviar for cats? They may sound fantastic, and they're not in the shops yet. But pet food makers are straining hard to capture what looks like a $2billion market this year.

title: Cambodian Insurgents Bombard Slum Area in the Capital Again
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sunday, Jan. 27 (AP)Insurgents bombarded Phnom Penh's crowded slums with more than 100 artillery shells last night, setting wooden homes afire and driving thousands of residents from the area.

title: Tennis Schools for Novice and Ambitious
description: Classroom tennis has become a popular and profitable spinoff of the boom in the game across the country. People are flocking to enroll in an academy or institute or school for an average course of a onehour lesson a week for eight weeks at $50. It's a milliondollar. yearround business.

title: WILSON PROPOSES SEPT, 10 PRIMARY;Governor's Bill Would End June Vote on Candidates
description: ALBANY, Jan. 26Governor Wilson, contending that the traditional June primary resulted in unduly long political campaigns and magnified the risks of electoral abuse and questionable financing, asked the Legislature today to establish a permanent fall primary on.the second Tuesday after Labor Day, beginning with a primary this year on Sept, 10.

title: His Style Is NOt Cox's, but His Determination Seems the Same
description: WASHINGTONMajor criminal indictments in the Watergate scandals are now only weeks away. Former White House heavyweights who never used to pause in anyone's outer offices, now sit and wait in the anterooms of the Watergate Special Prosecutor's office to see the small, wellmanicured Texas lawyer who means so much to their future.

title: Cornell Six on Top
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Jan, 26Cornell, with gcals by five players, beat Penn, 52, in an Ivy League hockey game to day.

title: Coping
description: When the Frank Skeffingtons were defeated, some of the heart went out of American politics. But the Irishand the unmeltable Americans generallyare not easily defeated, and John Kennedy led them to new heights of political power. For millions, Kennedy was their President in a way no other will ever be. But for those who were Kennedy's immediate lieutenants, the death of the captain brought more than grief. The cause had justified and even hallowed their compromises, those adaptations to secular, liberal, industrial society which also served their personal ambitions. Kennedy's death made it all seem a cheat; the alternative was to see the process as a selfdeception. No wonder that Daniel P. Moynihan felt the time had come to attack the selfserving shams of liberal orthodoxy. And how right it was for him to speak of that American tragedy in the language of an older wisdom: I don't suppose there is any point in being Irish if you don't know the world is going to break your heart eventually. None, indeed. But it is also in character for Moynihan today to describe that comment, with modern reticence, as somewhat maudlin. When Kennedy died, the old metal had been already melted; the compromises had gone too far; there was no Way home from Mera

description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 26Nils Ryen of Staten Island won the state skijumping championship and the B. B. Hansson Memorial jumpoff trophy today.

description: THE oil industry is certainly the biggest business in the world, and it is under attack for being one of the most secretive as well. Vague distrust by the public and politicians has escalated into hostility.

title: De Gaulle
Stalin
description: More than 20 years have passed since Stalin died, and it is time for a fresh appraisal of his life. A few months ago Robert C. Tucker of Princeton University published the first installment of a projected threevolume biography of the Soviet leader, tracing his career up to the consolidation of his dictatorship in 1929. And now we have a full onevolume biography by Adam B. Ulam of Harvard, which is likely to remain the most detailed and comprehensive study of Stalin until Hacker's ambitious trilogy is completed. Not surprisingly, both new books devote considerable space to Stalin's meteoric rise to power. The son of a Georgian cobbler, Stalin was unimpressive both in physicalappearance and in intellectUal attainments, cutting an undistinguished figure in comparison with his fellow Bolshevik leaders. He could boast neither Lenin's immense prestige nor Bukharin's personal charm nor Trotsky's literary and oratorical gifts. To Sukhanov, the perceptive chronicler of the Russian Revolution, he was a grey blur, which flickered obscurely and left no trace. Yet after Lenin's death in 1924 Stalin quickly rose to the summit of power and became one of the greatest tyrants in history, faired and worshiped both in his own country and around the globe. No other man has wielded such unlimited authority over so manypeople during so long and critical a period. In the course of his 25year reign, Russia underwent one of the most sweeping social and economic transformations in modern times, becoming the second greatest industrial, scientific and military power in the world. For this achievement, however, the Russian people paid, a price in suffering and loss of freedom far greater than that paid by any other nation for its

title: BEAM IS ASSAILED ON MINORITY JOBS
description: Mayor Beame has shifted responsibility for enforcing the hiring of more minorities in the building trades from the Deputy Mayor level to the Bureau of the Budget, a move that has touched off intensive debate over whether it will strengthen or cripple that effort.
