title: Hobby Protection Act Spurs Action
description: The new Hobby Protection Act has reportedly not yet been invoked in a largescale, organized way against manufacturers, importers or sellers of unmarked replicas of coins and medals. Possibly the hobby's major organizations are studying the provisions of the law to determine how it can best be implemented; hopefully, one or more groups are even now making quiet, behindthescenes preparations for an allout drive to get rid of replicas that are not so marked and to force manufacturers to observe the law by placing the word copy in an ineradicable way (preferably incused) in a prominent area on the obverse or reverse of all replicas produced from now on. But while the big boys are checking out the situation, one individual collector has decided that the mere existence of the law is. a base strong enough to support an attack. Last month Andrew Reiz of Kansas City, Mo., read a report that the Israel government was planning to reproduce quantities of rare ancient Jewish coins for sale to tourists. The report did not say whether or not part of the reproductions, so he reasoned that a friendly word of warning might nip this problem in the bud. The following is an excerpt from his letter to Moshe Kol, Israel's Minister of Tourism.

title: Miss Garbe Leads In Speed Skating
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 26 (UPI)Nancy Class of St. Paul, last Year's Senior Women's champion, was in fourth place today after two events in the national outdoor speed skating championships at Lake Como. She fell in the 440 and failed to finish and placed third in the threequarter mile race.

title: The Region
description: Governor Malcolm Wilson has presented his first budget, including expressed compassion and programs for the needy, but his major proposals reflected little departure from his acknowledged conservativism. He urged repeal of a surcharge on the income tax, in part because it discourages business investment; at the same time, he asked continuance of the hot dog tax that falls most heavily on the poor.

title: What's Doing in Las Vegas
description: THE NAME OF THE GAMEThere are plenty of other things to do, and it's possible to have good time here without ever placing a bet. But, as the casino operators well know, the odds are that you will leave some of your money at the tables. In fact, gamblinggaming, as it is officially called hereis so inevitable that, for those who need guidance on the various ways one can be separated from his money, I herewith offer a brief rundown on the types of games and give you my own trusty system for meeting the challenge. Your resistance will be tested immediately at McCarran International Airport. A young lady in the baggage claim area will provide change to feed the battery of onearmed bandits along the wall. Thereafter you will see slot machines virtually everywhere you go. The casinos offer craps, blackjack roulette, baccarat and slots. Stakes range from a penny to $25 a shot with most casino games having a minimum of $1 or $2 roll. Keno something like bingo can be played from comfortable chairs on most casino levels. It takes as little as 60 cents a game and the top prize is $25,000. There is poker. There are gaming parlors where you can bet on any horse or dog race in the country. Most of the large hotels provide guests with brochures explaining the casino games. A more thorough basic grounding can be obtained from a series of six booklets published. by the Gambler's Book Club, 8 East Charleston Boulevard, Las Vegas, Nev. 89104. The Facts of Craps sells for $1 as does each of the rest of the series, covering blackjack, roulette, baccarat, keno and slots. The books can be purchased at newsstands in Las Vegas as well as at Newark and La Guardia airports in the New York area and by mail. Most dealers, if they are not especially busy, will give beginners a helping hand. And the MGM Grand Hotel, the newest hotel in town, operates a small school, where you can bet phony chips while learning. Like all gambling systems, mine seldom results in winnings. But it reduces pervasive guilt to a manageable feeling of stupidity. It requires only a total lack of resolution: Do not forswear gambling Do not set a limit on what, you will bet Do not decide in advance at what amount of winnings you will stop Without resolutions you will not feel bad when you break them and this system even enhances the

title: Last Days of the Bridgeport Ferry
description: BRIDGEPORTThe whistle of the ferryboat Bridgeport wailed mournfully as the vessel left the New Jersey shore and swung her rounded bow against the Delaware River tide and toward her berth in Chester.

title: Yarborough Beats Petty On the Coast
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan 26 (UPI)  Cale Yarborough of Timmonsville, S. C., holding off a late charge by Richard Petty, won the Winston Western 500 Grand National race today by four seconds, six days after it was delayed by rain.

title: Policewomen Succeed in Tough World of Streets
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26On a humid night here last summer, Ann Falkinburg, who is 5 feet 4 inches tall and who weighs 120 pounds, broke up fight between two hulking men and, in the process, fractured couple of her ribs.

title: Fashion: Five ways to get it all together
description: The paper shopping bagthat clue to taste and statusisbecoming an endangered species. Now is the time to invest in your own bag to carry around all the paraphernalia that seems essential for women on the go.

title: Susan B. Miness Is Betrothed to Martin Farber
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. L, Jan. 26  Miss Susan Beth Miness and Martin Stuart Farber, students at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University, plan to marry March 31 at Temple Judea in Manhasset.

title: FORD LEADS POLL OF G.O.P. FOR 76
description: Vice President Ford, Gov. Ronald Reagan of California and former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York are in close competition among Republican voters as the leading choices for their party's nomination for President in 1976, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

description: Hunched over by the years, topped by a Wisp of white hair, Casey Stenge looks old and tired.

title: Arab Oil Ministers: No Individual Millionaires
description: KUWAITThe Arab oil ministers, whose collective decisions shape world oil supplies and prices, are not millionaires and are not particularly powerful politically in their countries.

title: MERCURY TRACED IN RADAR STUDIES Measurements of the Planet Hint Gentle Hills and Dales
description: The most accurate radar studies so far of the planet Mercury, announced yesterday, indicate gentle hills and valleys and possible craters near the Equator.

description: For years, telephone credit cards have had slots cut in them for holding the dime that could be used again and again at pay phones to get the operator, who would return the coin while putting the call through on credit.

title: Cleveland Orchestra Votes Strike Tonight
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 26Members of the Cleveland Orchestra have voted, 83 to 2, to go on strike after tomorrow night's concert unless a new contract agreement is reached with the Musical Arts Association, which operates the orchestra.

title: jazz Organist Glad
description: EAST ORANGE  Rhoda Scott was born and grew up in New Jersey, and went to Westminster Choir College in Princeton with the intention of being a concert organist. Instead, she became a star jazz organist in Europe.

title: Queens Zoning Vote Delayed
description: The Board of Estimate has delayed consideration of a controversial rezoning proposal that would permit the construction of an air cargo truck terminal on three acres of marsh land near Kennedy International Airport.

title: Brazil Grows as a Dynamic Power
description: RIO DE JANEIROWhen Adam and Eve were expelled from here, so the Brazilian saying goes, the Lord hid their paradise from the rest of the world.

title: Point of View
description: The events of the last year have produced dramatic changes in the climate for longterm, fixedrate financing of multinational companies. As result, a strengthened United States dollar will probably be the principal currency for such financing.

title: Roseann Sica Fiancee of Walter Dzuban
description: BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., Jan. 26Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas A. Sica have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Roseann Sica, to Walter George Dzuban, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Dzuban of Port Chester.

title: Playing With Fire Can Mean Getting Burned
description: THIS writer is not one who believes that only whales or sea captains should review books like Moby Dick and no matter the rationale, I will not look for Eddie Egan's review. of Adam12, but I do think it appropriate that a professional firefighter comment on a new series like ABC's Firehouse (Thursdays at 8:30 P.M.).

title: Russians Develop Siberian Fields
description: While Congressional opposition to investment loans appears to have a cast a shadow on ambitious SovietAmerican gas deals, the Russians have been quietly moving forward on their own to develop their ample oil and gas resources.

title: COMMUNISTS OPEN EUROPEAN PARLEY
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 26Leaders of 21 Western European Communist parties began a threeday conference here today in an attempt to define a common strategy on domestic and international issues.

title: Volunteers Help Blind See With Tapes
description: PRINCETONIn the basement of a Princeton Theological Seminary building are six soundproof booths, most of them occupied all day. From these cubicles comes enlightment for blind studdents and professionals in many parts of the United States,

title: Just Keep the Hemlock on Hand
description: WHEN the triumph of impressionism transformed former underdogs like Monet into the champs of the 20thcentury salesroom, their old academic enemies (Bouguereau, Meissonier, Gerome, Cabanel) were defrocked and put under torture by every art critic and historian under the age, of ,90 who expected to be taken seriously. The academicians made marvelous victims. For one thing, during all those years while they were on top they had treated the future favorites abominably. And in a century that has been increasingly suspicious of sentiment and less and less respectful of discipline, the academicians fondness for pictorial storytelling could be laughed at as corny and their technical finish could be derided as a form of esthetic constipation.

title: Friday's Fight
description: Ban Diego  Duane Bobick, 212 pounds, Bowlus, Minn., knocked out Lee Mandingo, 277, Penis, Calif., 2 rounds.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
U.C.L.A. Routs Irish by 9475
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26Breaking the game open midway through the second half after being on the verge of doing it in the first half, the University of California, Los Angeles trounced Notre Dame, 9475, tonight at the Pauley Pavilion. Bill Walton scored 32 points before fouling out with 5 minutes 39 seconds to play and his team ahead by 26 points.

title: Nuptials Here for Judith Lynn Tunstall
description: Miss Judith Lynn Tunstall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Tunstall of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to James Andrew Kennedy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kennedy of Short Hills, N. J.

title: Nevada Officials Hope Hughes Will Sell Casinos
description: RENO, Nev., Jan. 26 Among Nevada gambling con. trol officials who once greeted Howard R. Hughes as a solution to a serious problem with the Federal Government, there is now an undercurrent of hope that he will sell out to anybody of good repute who is not under Federal indictment.

title: Small Atomic Arms Are Urged for NATO
Truckers in Ohio To Vote on Offer To End Shutdown
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 26 (AP)Independent truckers in Ohio will vote tomorrow on an offer aimed at ending a violencemarred threeday shutdown, a spokesman said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs,
description: A 70yearold Bronx man returning home from his: job as a doorman in Manhattan was slain yesterday in an apparent robbery just a few doors from his apartment, building. The police said the victim, Austin Thai of 1160 Cromwell Avenue, in the High Bridge section, had suffered fatal head injuries. as a result of a beating and, pending autopsy results, possibly a gunshot. He was found at 1:40 A.M. on the sidewalk outside 1164 CromWell Avenue, where he was apparently attacked as he made iris way home from work at 68th Street and Central ParkWest. His left pants pocket had been ripped off, but detectives said they were not sure whether anything of value had been taken.

title: Since Watergate, Major Shifts in Power Have Given the Presidency Gains and Losses
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 When President Nixon began his second term a year ago, two items on his list of goals were an effective attack on hard drugs and a new approach to education research that would put an end to pouring money into projects that do not work.

title: BARAKA CRITICIZES BLACK OFFICIALS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Jan. 27 New Jersey's black elected officials, particularly those of Essex County. came under criticism here yesterday at the New Jersey Black Political Convention for not appearing at the parley.

title: SOVIET SEES BOOKS ON HITLER AS PLOT
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 27Do recent Western books, articles and films about Hitler add up to a nefarious plot to soften up unsuspecting Westerners for a return to the days of the Third Reich?

title: 4 at White House Arrested On Anniversary of Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) Four followers of the antiwar activist, the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan, were arrested outside the White House today, and second group announced it would circle the building in two vehicles in an effort to obtain a meeting with President Nixon. Before the arrests, Father Berrigan, a former priest and a defendant in the Harrisburg Seven trial, and about 30 other persons protested continued support of South Vietnam.

title: Crash Kills 2 in Michigan
description: ROMULUS, Mich., Jan. 27 (AP)  Two Michigan men were killed last night in the crash of a light plane near Detroit Metropolitan Airport. Wayne County Sheriff's deputies identified the victims as Steve Crick of Livonia and Allen Repp of Dearborn.

title: WOMEN OFFICIALS MEET WITH BYRNE
description: PRINCETON, Jan. 27A conference of New Jersey's female elected public officials yesterday called on Governor Byrne to increase the number of women in key agency posts, particularly in those areas from which women traditionally have been excluded.

title: Nixon and Staff Preparing State of Union Message
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Jan. 27 (AP)President Nixon, spending the weekend at his Camp David retreat, continued to work today on his State of the Union Message due Wednesday.

title: Sander Wins Run
description: Dr. Norbert Sander of the Milirose Athletic Association won the first in a series of four national postal runs yesterday at Central Park. Sander's time for the 9.3mile race was 48 minutes 3 seconds. Bill Bragg, running unattached, was second, 350 yards back, in 49:29. Anita Scandurra of Greenlawn, LI., was the first woman finisher in 61st place.

title: HARRY KATZ
description: Harry Katz, Assistant Administrator for legal affairs of the city's Finance Administration, died yesterday in. North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L.I., where he had undergone heart surgery last week. He was 60 years old and lived at 113 Pine Street, Woodmere, L.I.

title: Berra 10Time Winnar
description: Yogi Berra played on the winning team in 10 World Series.

title: Chile Four Months Later: Leftists Falling Into Line
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 23 The 11th of September, the radio announcements blare, was for all Chileans, not just for some.

title: Thousands Flee Phnom Penh as Shelling Increases
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 27 (UPI}Thousands of people fled their homes in the crowded southern and southeastern sections of Phnom Penh today, seeing to escape artillery attac1cs by Communistled insurgents in which 84 people were killed in the last three nights.

title: Coronado's Dances Teem With Rites and Images.
description: Jose Coronado, a former member of Mexico's Ballet Folidorico who performed with Anna Sokolow and the late Jose LimOn, two AmeriCan moderndance leaders who worked extensively in Mexico, presented his own yearold dance company Saturday night in eight works at the American Theater Laboratory, 219 West 19th Street.

title: CRANGLE AND ROSE WEIGH ALLIANCE
description: Less than a year after the Democratic and Liberal parties split over a mayoral candidate and the Court of Appeals chief judgeship, leaders of both parties have begun discussions looking toward an alliance in the forthcoming gubernatorial campaign.

title: NET OFF SHARPLY AT OHIO STANDARD
description: While the major international oil companies have been reporting unprecedented earnings primarily because of their flourishing foreign operations, the Standard Oil Company of Ohio, a refiner and marketer operating mostly in this country, yesterday announced a 40 per cent drop in its profits for the final quarter of 1973.

title: A january Thaw Evokes Early Reveries of Spring
description: It has been a confusing season. First, through an act of Congress, the mornings became darker; then, through an act of nature, the winter became warmer. Yesterday was a case in point.

description: To the Editor:

title: RACKETEERS PREY ON CHINA SYSTEMS
description: PEKING, Jan. 27  Almost everyone who has read anything about life in contemporary China knows that a foreigner can tour the country without ever locking his hotel room or fearing for his wallet.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27The Soviet Union has begun preliminary discussions on the feasibility of having its top tennis players join World Team Tennis.

title: Saigon Detains 4 From A.B.C., Holds Film of Vietcong
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 27 (AP)A fourman crew from the American Broadcasting Company was arrested yesterday by Government troops after filming in a Vietcongcontrolled town about 65 miles northwest of Saigon. Authorities held the four more than 24 hours at the national police headquarters and released them today.

title: Grivas Dies in Cyprus
description: Gen. George Grivas, the Greek Cypriote guerrilla leader, died of a heart attack, his political organization announced last night. Page 30.

title: Crime in City's Schools Reported Up
description: Crime and violence in and around the city's schools continued to increase last year, despite the steady strengthening of security patrols to maintain calm and safety for school personnel and pupils.

title: PROBLEMS BESET MAIL RETAILERS
Fire Company Cools RacialDiscrimination Issue
description: NEPTUNE, Jan. 27The Liberty. Fire Company, which was involved in a dispute charging discrimination, has quietly accepted two more black members. A spokesman for the Fire Department said there had been no attempt to publicize it because we took these guys just like we took everyone else.

title: JUDGE'S SON HELD IN A BAR INCIDENT
description: Gareth Martinis, the judge's son who won acquittal in 1963 on charges of drunken driving and leaving the scene of an accident, then served a 90day jail sentence in 1970 after pleading guilty to almost similar charges following another accident, was arrested early yesterday for allegedly fighting with police officers in an East Village bar.

title: MONDALE CRITICIZES FOREIGNTAX CREDIT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) A new Treasury Department report shows that American oil companies used the foreigntax credit to cut their United States taxes by 75 per cent in 1971, Senator Walter F. Mondale said today.

title: KerrMcGee in Takeover
description: The KerrMcGee Corporation, Oklahoma City, a large, integrated oil developer and mar keter, and the Southwestern Oil & Refining Company, Corpus Christi, and Royal Petroleum Corporation, New york, have announced as agreement under which KerrMcGee will purchase all of the outstanding stock of Southwestern and Royal.

description: Reggie Jackson of the Oakland A's was honored last night as the major leagues best performer of 1973 when New York's baseball writers held their 51st annual awards dinner and follies.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds

description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 27The Israeli Cabinet today expressed full support for the Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gem David Elazar, whose fitness to lead the nation's forces wasquestioned this weekend by Maj. Gen. Ariel Sharon, a hero of the October war.

description: The mammoth 45yearold pipe organ at Loews Kings Theater on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, which used to accompany singalongs that packed the 3,195seat house, played its farewell performance there yesterday for nearly 200 theaterorgan buffs, a proliferation of taperecorders and just possibly the ghost of Charlie Chase, the silentmovie comic.

title: FOUR HERE DEPICT SOVIET PRISON LIFE
description: Four men who served terms is Soviet prison camps, during he Stalin era and more reently, recalled their experiences yesterday evening on the gational Broadcasting Comiany's television news program Special Edition.

title: Youth Back From Cuban Custody
description: MIAMI, Jan. 27 (AP)A New Jersey youth, whose summer job aboard a 110foot yacht turned into a sixmonth forced visit to Cuba, has returned to this country after spending the last 44 days of his ordeal locked in a tiny jail cell.

description: When they began rehearsals, the principal parties involved in the Broadway production of Eugene O'Neill's A Moon for the Misbegotten dubbed themselves The Resurrection Company.

title: PURCHASE BY STATE BARS FOREST HOMES

description: Commission on the Status of Women  11 A.M. and 3 P.M.; working group on program for International Women's Year10 A.M. and 5 P.M.

Kandel of Rockville Centre, L. I., and Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Max Routeenberg performed the ceremony at the St. RegisSheraton.

title: About New york
description: Five women who had been graduated from Barnard College nearly 40 years ago met for lunch one day last week. They had been great friends in school, but over the years they had gone separate ways, and while one or the other would meet now and then, this was the first time they had all been together since graduation.

title: Regina Beth Stein Is Married To Bruce H. Wilson in Suburb
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 27Miss Regina Beth Stein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jess Stein, was married here this afternoon to Bruce Hamilton Wilson, son of Prof. and Mrs. H. Van Rensselaer Wilson of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Donald McKinney, a Unitarian minister, and Rabbi David Greenberg at the Woman's Club of White Plains.

title: Girl Held in Fatal Knifing Of Youth in Plainfield

title: JACOB L SILVERMAN, A HEART SPECIALIST
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 27Dr. Jacob J. Silverman, a cardiovascular speialist, died today in Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 80 North Wyoming Avenue. His office was at 100 Central Avenue,. St. George, S. I.

title: Dog Gives Fire Alarm, Dies
description: MAHOPAC, N.Y., Jan. 27 (AP)  Princess, a pet collie, barking furiously, aroused a family of 11 early this morning and led them safely from their home which then burned to the ground Firemen said. Princess. 8 years old, went back into the house and was suffocated. About 75 firemen from Mahopac and Mahopac Falls, about 50 mile north of New York City, fought the fire at he home of Joseph Wehrenberg, his wife and nine children.

title: Blyth Eastman Insuring
description: Blyth Eastman Dillon & Co., Inc., announced over the weekend that it would offer its clients a total of $500,000 each in investor insurance coverage, a sum it called the largest for this type of securities protection. The insurance takes effect immediately.

description: White House intervention prevented Adm. Thomas H. Moorer from courtmartialing a yeoman suspected ofleaking secret documents to Jack Anderson, the columnist, Newsweek magazine said yesterday.

description: NEWARK, Jan. 27  With health costs higher than they have ever been, expenses for mentalhealth care, which is often necessary over a prolonged period, have soared beyond the reach Jersey of many coping with New Jersey's Consumer inadequate, outNotes dated facilities.

description: Tense? Fidgety? Irritable? Feel like punching your coworkers in the mouth? Well, two serene and slender individuals named Alan Levy and Dick Shea think they may have an answer for you: Yoga and lunch.

description: AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 27 (AP) More than 2,200 independent truckers voted to continue their work stoppage tonight because they said proposals from Washington to alleviae their problems were too vague.

description: BOSTON, Jan. 27 (AP)NevIn England's 1973 apple crop was the smallest in 17 years, the United States Department of Agriculture reported. The region's crop was 235.2 million pounds, down from the 1972 yield of 294 million pounds.

title: 4,000 March in Londonderry To Mark Bloody Sunday
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Jan. 27 (Reuters) About 4,000 people took part today in a peaceful protest commemorating Bloody Sunday two years ago, When 13 civilians were killed when British troops fired on demonstrators.

description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 23 The 11th of September, the radio announcements blare, was for all Chileans, not just for some.

title: JOSEPH W. LOVAS
description: MANHASSET, L.I, Jan. 27Joseph W. Lovas, president of the East River Wire Works, Inc., Long Island City, Queens, died today of a heart attack in St. Francis Hospital, Port Washington. He was 56 years old and lived at 106 Country Club Drive.

title: Islanders Top Hawks First Time
Boldness and Objectivity Rare in the French Press
description: PARIS, Jan. 27Roger Fressoz, the rumpled, waggish director of the celebrated satirical weekly Le Canard Enchaine emphatically told a visitor in his grubby digs last month: Watergate could never happen in France.

title: Bulls Pin 10991 Loss On Pistons
Music: Erick Friedman
description: At 34 and with many years of performing experience behind him, Erick Friedman has presumably made up his mind about the kind of violinist he is going to be. Blessed with a technique that must enable him to do almost anything he wants, he appears to have opted for beautifully executed performances, in which ingratiating tone and good musical manners are the dominant characteristics. This, at least, is the impression left by the recital he gave at Tully Hall on Saturday night, and it is verified by reports of other appearances here in recent years.

title: Hassan Curbs Unrest With Iron Hand
description: RABAT, MOROCCO, Jan. 27 The prospects for economic development have brightened considerably in this North African kingdom after a bold move tripling the selling price of phosphates, the principal export.

title: Shopping Malls Pinched By Shortages of Gasoline
description: DETROIT, Jan. 27  A small women's store in one of the nation's huge supermalls normally has a profit of $100 to $150 a day. But one night there was only an $18 sale.

title: Trial in TortureMurder Ring Is Lagging
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 27  Every weekday for two weeks, a patient crowd of bereaved parents, law students and the curious has made its way through the cordon of deputies at the Harris County Courthouse here to sit in on what this sprawling city calls its trial of the century.

title: 10% Use Tax Checkoff Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 27 (UPI) In early tax returns, one taxpayer in 10 is earmarking $1 of his Federal taxes for use by Presidential candidates in the 1976 campaign. Figures compiled by the Internal Revenue Service from the first 403,000 tax forms show that 10.7 per cent carry a check mark in the box where taxpayers indicate they want to designate $1 of their taxes to a Presidential campaign fund.

title: GEN. SPEARS DIES; HELPED DE GAULLE
description: LONDON, Jan. 27  Maj. Gen. Sir Edward Spears, who brought Gen. Charles deGaulle to Britain to form the Free French forces during World War II, died today at the age of 87.

title: Hinterseer Captures Cup Slalom
Dr. S. A. Cole Weds Dalen Sciarra
description: Miss Dalen Lucia Sciarra of New York and Dr. Stephen Adams Cole, also of New York and Stratton, Vt., were married here yesterday afternoon in the Ceremonial Hall of the Ethical Culture Society by Jerome Nathanson.

title: Orr to Miss Stars Game; Bruins Win
description: BOSTON; Jan. 27 (UPI)Bobby Orr, the Boston Bruin's stellar defenseman, suffered a left leg injury today that will keep him out of Tuesday's National Hockey League AllStar Game in Chicago.

title: Personal Finance: Quizzing Quizzers
description: A Long Island homeowner, In a Dear Policyholder notice from the Allstate Insurance Company, was routinely informed the other day that the company might send an investigator around to his neighbors to ask a few questions.

title: Cancer Coordinator Named
description: BOSTON, Jan. 27 (AP)Dr. Howard Ulfelder has been appointed coordinator of cancer treatment and cancer research projects at the Massachusetts General Hospital.

title: Governor Shows His Wit and Humor And an Air of Relaxation in New Post
description: TRENTON, Jan, 27It was Jan. 16, Governor Byrne's first day on the job, and some of his freinds in the cabinet stopped by to see how he was getting along.

title: Capitol Weighs Tax Cuts As AntiRecession Move
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 With fears mounting that a recession is under way or soon will be, influential members of Congress have begun serious talk of tax reductions in the last three or four days.

title: Red Smith
description: Cassius Clay was screaming gibberish and his eyes rolled in his head as he shoved. through the crowd Miami Beach Convention Hall, hammering on thefloor with a heavy, walking stick. It was a month less than years ago and Clayhe had not yet taken the name Muhammad Aliwas a rookie of 22 challenging Sonny Liston for the heavyweight championship of the World, While officials of the Miami Beach Boxing Commission weighed him in and Dr. Alexander Robbins strove. to make a final physical examination, Clay threshed and howled, flinging his arms about, wrestling and writhing as though in a convulsion. Dr. Robbins, looking concerned, said the fighter's ptilse rate had risen from 54 more than 110. I've known men to be committed on weaker evidence, said Tommy Holmes; one of the New York Herald Tribune men on the fight.

title: Volkswagen to Keep the Beetle But Add 3 FrontEngine Lines
description: DETROIT, Jan. 27Volkswagen, after telling American car buyers for years that the proper place for an automobile engine was in the rear, is now preparing to market three lines of cars with watercooled front engines.

title: Gasoline Dealer Is Skeptical of Energy Drought
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., Jan. 24Maurice B. (Tiny) Holdgraf, a former vice president of the Shell Oil Company, who now manages a large chain of gasoline.stations, is a skeptic. He doesn't believe there is currently an energy crisis. He doesn't think the oil companies are doing all they can to meet present demand. And he doesn't think either the oil industry or the Government has leveled with the AmeriCan people.

title: Corrock Captures Pro Skiing
description: HUNTER, N.Y., Jan. 27Ken Corrock of Sun Valley, Idaho, gained his first triumph in two years of professional skiing today when he defeated Spider Sabich of Snowmass, Colo., in the $15,000 Benson & Hedges special slalom final on Hunter Mountain.

title: Peron Against the Left
description: While waiting in Spain for the events that were to bring him home from exile and then return him to the presidency of Argentina, Juan Domingo Perlin declared: If I were 50 years younger I would understandably go about planting bombs or meting out my own brand of justice. Now President Peron has called on all Argentines to join in an effort to annihilate as soon as possible this criminal terrorism that he once admired.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Aid Given Outdoor Play on Revolution

title: KISSINGER HOPEFUL OF A SYRIAN PACT
description: Secretary of State Kissinger said yesterday that he was moderately optimistic about the prospects for getting Syria and Israel to negotiate a disengagement of their military forces.

title: PENSION MEASURE FOUGHT IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Jan. 27Labor and industry groups have intensified their efforts to defeat a proposal before the Legislature that would guarantee a worker's right to a pension once he had been a member of a pension plan for 15 years.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BOSTON, Jan. 27 (AP)Derek Sanderson, the flamboyant center of the Boston Bruins, suffered a broken bone in his left foot in a National Hockey League game last night against the New York Islanders at Uniondale, LI., Xrays showed today. Sanderson, struck by a puck fired by the Islanders Brian Spencer, had his left leg placed in a cast at Massachusetts General Hospital. Doctors said he would wear the cast for four to six weeks. He suffered a back injury on the opening day of preseason training and eventually was sent down to the Boston Braves of the American Hockey League to get into shape. He didn't rejoin the parent club until Nov. 22. In 26 games, Sanderson had eight goals and 11 assists.

title: OIL MILLIONAIRE KEY IN DRUG CASE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27Jury deliberations resume tomorrow in a threemonthold, multimilliondollar drug case that has pitted William Mellon Hitchcock, an heir to the Gulf Oil fortune, as the key Government witness against three former friends.

title: Jazz Repertory Group Scores Big on Opening
description: The New York Jazz Repertory Company indicated the scope of its intentions at its debut performance Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall when it presented three big bands, totaling 66 musicians, that cut right across the spectrum of orchestral jazz.

title: Simon Resigning Post At Burlington Northern
description: Norton Simon, the financier who recently called for a public protest on the crisis of the nation's railroads, announced at the weekend his resignation from the board of Burlington Northern, Inc., after 22 years service on its board and those of the railroad's predecessors.

title: Times AChangin
description: Bob Dylan comes home to New York this week, 39 appearances and 21 cities after he set out on his first concert tour in eight years. The crowds have probably been bigger than they used to be, and they've certainly been older. Now nostalgia has been added to the magic and the message that captured an American generation a decade ago.

title: UTILITIES TO RECEIVE 95% OF POWER NEED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) The Federal energy chief, William E. Simon, announcer fuel allocations today to provide utilities with about 95 per cent of their power needs next month.

title: Corrock Captures Pro Skiing
description: HUNTER, N.Y., Jan. 27Ken Corrock of Sun Valley, Idaho, gained his first triumph in two years of pro. fessional skiing today, when he defeated Spider Sabich of Snowmass, Colo., in the $15,000 Benson & Hedges special slalom final on Hunter Mountain.

title: Burma to Pick Hunters for Offshore Oil
description: RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 22After one of the most feverish oil scrambles Southeast Asia has seen, Burma is on the verge of forsaking her economic reclusiveness and entering into collaboration with international companies that have been bidding for offshore exploration rights along her 1,100mile coast.

title: Muncie Wins Award's
description: BERKELEY, Calif. (UPI) Chuck Muncie, the first Cali fornia running back to excess 800 yards since Johnny ols zewski in 1952, won the team's mostvaluable player award in football as a sophomore in 1973.

title: Erving Hits 46 Points in Net Victory
Pact Said to Allow Israeli Cargo but Not Her Ships
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 27Israeli cargo; but not Israeliflag ships, will be permitted to pass through the Suez Canal. when the waterway is cleared and reopened, according to reliable Sources here.

title: Norton's Prediction: Frazier by Knockout
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27 (UPI)Ken Norton, who will try to take George Foreman's heavyweight title March 26, picked Joe Frazier today to win by a knockout in tomorrow night's fight with Muhammad Ali.

title: One Year After the. Paris Accord
description: CAMBRIDGE, MassA year ago yesterday the United States signed the Paris Agreement on Ending the War and Restoring Peace in Vietnam. Since then the number of combat deaths in Vietnam has reached far above 50,000, or to about the level it reached in 1966, an average year in the war. Only the circumstances of these deaths have changed.

title: A Cautionary Tale
description: Freedom for me is not a privilege but a right protected by our Constitution. It is one of a host of rights that I as an American citizen am fortunate to share with Dr. Ellsberg and Dr. Fielding. These rights of the. individual, cannot be sacrificed to the mere assertion national security.

title: Ross Wins Title In State Tennis
description: GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 27 Joel Ross of Westbury, L.I., defeated Peter Fishbach of Mill Neck, L.I., 64, 61, in the final match to win the New York State men's indoor tennis championship today at the Cove Racquet Club.

title: Shipping/Mails Ali Hours Given In Daylight Saving Time
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Mrs. Henry Schapper, 67, Magazine Writer, Teacher
description: Mrs. Beatrice Aronson Schapper, a founder and past secretary of the Society of Magazine Writers, died yesterday in University Hospital. The wife of Henry Schapper, en executive recruiter in the communications field, she was 67 years old and lived at 1080 Fifth Avenue.

title: Sports Today
description: Muhammad Ali vs. Joe Frazier, 12round heavyweight bout at Madison. Square Garden, 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. First preliminary, 8:30 P.M.

title: Krogh Says Dean Reported CoverUp To Nixon in March
description: Egli Krogh Jr. said yesterday that John W. Dean 3d told him last March 20 that President Nixon had previously been unaware of the Watergate coverup. It was after a conversation the two had that day, Mr. Krogh said, that Mr. Dean decided to tell the President the coverup details.

title: Bulgaria Reports Contact With U. S. on Ship Seizure
description: A Spokesman for the Bulgarian Embassy in Washington said yesterday that contact had been made with the State Department over the seizure Saturday of the Bulgarian fishing trawler Litnoza off the New Jersey coast.

title: It Looks Like Walter Matthau It Could Be Walter Matthau... It...
description: In the eerie light of a subway tunnel under downtown Brooklyn, a drolllooking, rubberfaced man wearing a smasheddown hat, trench coat and garish yellow tie is poised on the catwalk above the tracks and pointing a snubnosed revolver.

title: Gen. George Grivas Dies; Led Cyprus Underground
description: Gen George Grivas, who helped lead Cyprus to independence from Britafn in 1960 but failed despite years of underground activity to achieve his dream of union with Greece, died a 75yearold fugitive yesterday in a hideout in the southern port city of Llmassol, Cyprus.

title: Hotel Boom Could Revitalize City's Image as Swell Place to Visit
description: Next time a tourist says New York is a swell place to visit, he might just find a realestate developer nodding in enthusiastic agreement.

title: F.B.I. TELLS OF FILE ON JERSEY GIRL, 16; Admits It Saw Subversion in Letter to Socialists She Wrote in School Project
Hinterseer Captures Cup Slalom
Dichter Spins Silken Thread in Beethoven Sonatas
description: At his concert in Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium on Satueday night, Misha Dichter played five Beethoven piano sonatas, and each sounded prettier than the last. It was not exactly a salonish approach to the composer, but Mr. Dichter's larklike phrasing, purring scales and crushedvelvet sonority smoothed over many of the characteristic rough edges and much of the brusque vitality that spell out Bee thoven for most pianists.

title: Fuel Cost Perils New England Colleges
description: BOSTON, Jan. 27  The colleges and universities of New England, which had just about scrimped their way back to financial security, are now watching their bestlaid plans for balanced budgets collapse under the weight of staggering fuel bills.

title: Dr. Ralph R. Wolf Jr., 68, Recruited ABomb Scientists
description: ALSTEAD, N.H., Jan. 27Dr. Ralph R. Wolf Jr., assistant personnel director of the Manhattan Project In World War II, died Friday at his home here. He was 65 years old.

title: Sadat Is Expected to Use Waterway as Trump Card
description: CAIRO, Jan. 27To Egyptians, the Suez Canal is more than the dividing line between Africa and Asia and an allimportant economic asset. It is a national monument like the Pyramids and the Aswan Dam.

title: Syria Calls Israeli Losses High in Artillery Clashes
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan 27 Syrian and Israeli artillery clashed all along the Golan Heights today, a Syrian military spokesman in Damascus reported.

title: Exorcist Adds Problems For Catholic Clergymen
description: A young man recently left a Denver theater that was showing The Exorcist and walked to the nearby Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception.

title: New Local Legislators Learn ABC's of Governing in Classes
description: ATHENS, N. Y.Fifteen town and county legislators, most of them newly elected, gathered the other night in a 60degree classroom of the ColumbiaGreene Community College here.

title: EXPRESIDENT'S MOVE EXPLAINED BY PENNSY
description: The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company said yesterday that William H. Moore, the company's former president now the object of an inquiry by the Interstate Commerce Commission on alleged misappropriations of funds, has reimbursed the company for work done at his Maryland home by company employes.

title: Crime and Punishment
description: BOSTON, Jan. 27In a few days Egli Krogh Sr. will surrender to Federal. marshals and begin serving a sixmonth sentence for his part in the burglary of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist's office. He will be the first Nixon White House aide imprisoned since the original Watergate breakin led to the disclosure of higher crimes.

title: Mrs. Miriam Sloan Dead; Transcriber for. the Blind
description: VENTNOR, N. J., Jan. 27Mrs. Miriam Marcus Sloan, a former New York highschool teacher who became a leader in volunteer work for the blind, died today at her home here at the age of 73. She was the widow of Dr. Samuel Louis Sloan, a surgeon.

title: Grivas Dies in Cyprus
description: Gen. George Grivas, the Greek Cypriote guerrilla leader, died of a heart attack, his political organization an nounced last night. Page 30.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 29

title: STANLEY WOLFF, 65, A RADIO SPECIALIST
description: TRENTON, Jan. 27 (AP)Stanley Wolff, who helped organize worldwide communications facilities for The Associated Press, died Friday night of a kidney ailment at Helene Fuld Hospital here. He was 65 years old.

title: Joanne Blumberg Bride of Jeffrey Joseph
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 27Miss Joanne R. Blumberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Blumberg, was married here this afternoon to Jeffrey Jay Joseph of Westwood Village in Los Angeles, where he practices law. Rabbi Harvey J. Fields performed the ceremoney at the Anshe Emeth Memorial Temple.

title: News Summary and Index
description: In the last few months, since the deepening of the oil crisis; Western and Japanese government and business delegations have concluded $6billion in deals, including loans, services and investment, for longterm oil contracts with the oil countries of the Middle East. Additional deals, valued at about $5billion, are being negotiated or are under study by Middle East governments. France and Britain are among the Western.countries negotiating for oil. [1:67.]

title: Pop Music: Bromberg, A Complete Entertainer
description: David Bromberg was late for his concert at Town Hall on Friday evening because his band got caught in a traffic jam. And he had one of his numbers completely deflated when, at a moment of pipdrop quiet as he was setting a mood, an usher came down the aisl and shouted, No smoking! But Mr. Bromberg is not easily flustered, and he and his sevenman band went on to project It program that bubbled with high spirits, instrumental versatility and casual, offhand showmanship. The concert was a benefit for the New York University radio station, WNYU

title: Feminists Find That Words Fail Them
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 27Lexicographers beware Months ago a group of women from the Chicago area who had been meeting in a writers workshop informally began compiling a list of words reflecting sexist attitudes toward women in patriarchal society.

title: Larry Brand Marries Miss Regina Fenster
description: Miss Regina Fenster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Fenster of Whitestone, Queens, was married: there yesterday to Larry Brand, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Brand of Minneapolis. Rabbi E. Yechial Simon performed the ceremony at the Clearview Jewis Center.

title: Fuel Cost Perils New England Colleges
description: BOSTON, Jan. 27  The colleges and universities of New England, which had just about scrimped their way back to financial security, are now watching their bestlaid plans for balanced budgets collapse under the weight of staggering fuel bills.

title: Sheepdog Gains 5th Top Award
DROP IN ACCIDENTS LAID TO FUEL CUT
description: The state police reported yesterday, that the gasoline shortage and lowerspeed limits had probably helped cause the sharp decrease in automobile accidents they investigated during the last two months, mainly openroad cases.

title: DATA ON U.S. ARMS FOR SAIGON GIVEN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan 27Official American figure show that since the ceasefin agreements were signed a year ago, the United States has pro vided South Vietnam wits approximately $284.7millior worth of weapons and ammu nition.

title: New Books
description: Black Children, Whiff, Dreams, by Thomas J. Cottle, foreword by Senator Walter F. Mondale (Houghton Mifflin, $5.95). Daily lives of several black children and their families living in northern city.

title: Step Right Up and Take a Shot
description: EAST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 27Spectators attending Upsale College's home games in Viking Memorial Hall get their money's worth. They not only see a Jayvee and varsity Contest, but also are treated to a halftime show that is unmatched in New Jersey.

title: Playful All Is 212; Frazier 209, Quiet
description: Separately and almost formally, Joe Frazier weighed 209 pounds and Muhammed All 212 yesterday for their 12round heavyweight confrontation at Madison Square Garden tonight.

title: HRS. LOUISA HAGER, A Y.W.C.A.EXECUTIVE
description: Mrs. Louisa Wilson. Hager, communications direntor for the National. Board of the Young Women's Christian Association from 1953 until her retirement in 1970, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 68 years old and lived at 140 West 16th Street.

title: Robert R. HeywOod Jr., 74, And His Wife Found Dead
description: SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 27 Robert R. Heywood Jr., 74 years old,, chairmin of the board of the R. R. Heywood Company Inc., in New York and his wife, Marie Avery Heywood, 71, were found dead in their home at 70 Parsonage (Hill Road here, the police reported yesterday.

title: Newark Businessmen Discuss Trade With Nationalist Chinese
description: NEWARK, Jan. 27The prospect of $50million to $100million in annual exportimport business involving New Jersey industry and private interests and government agencies on Taiwan. Was foreseen today following a meeting of representatives of the greater Newark business community and a trade delegation from Nationalist China.

title: Exorcist  Adds Problems For Catholic Clergymen
description: A young man recently left a Denver theater that was showing The Exorcist and walked to the nearby Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception.

title: Bridge: Partnership Understanding Not Necessary for Success
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 27The overwhelming success of the biggest tourna ment ever held in these sundrenched islands was marred here yesterday by the sudden death of one of the game's most famous personalities.

title: Capitol Weighs Tax Cuts As AntiRecession Move
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 With fears mounting that a recession is under way or soon will be, influential members of Congress have begun serious talk of tax reductions in the last three or four days.

title: Mrs. Reiss Remarried
description: The marriage of Mrs. Marianne Lowy Reiss of New York to Benjamin Balshone, president of the Lynn Drug Company in Columbus, Ohio, took place here yesterday. Rabbi Morris Talansky performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's aunt, Mrs. Nathan Zucker. Mrs. Balshone is the daughter of Mrs. Aranka Z. Lowy of New York and the late Andrew Lowy. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. Mr. Balshone's first wife died.

title: A GIRL, 7, IS BEATEN AND RAPED IN BRONX
description: A 7yearold girl was beaten and raped last night in a vacant lot in the South Bronx on her way to a candy store. The police said they were searching for an 18yearold suspect.

title: Step Right Up and Take a Shot
description: EAST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 27Spectators attending Upsala College's home games in Viking Memorial Hall get their money's worth. They not only see a Jayvee and variety contest, but also are treated to a halftime show that is unmatched in New Jersey.

title: Michigan Residents Add to Opposition To Navy Radio Plan
description: MARQUETTE, Mich., Jan. 27 The Navy, after unsuccessful attempts to place a controversial communications project in Wisconsin, is now trying to develop it here but is meeting with local opposition.

title: Canadian Woman Takes 2d Commonwealth Gold
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Jan. 27 (AP)  Mike Bull of Northern Ireland overcame a painful back and sore arm in winning the decathlon today, while Jane Haist of Canada captured the shotput to become the first athlete to win two gold medals at the Commonwealth Games.

title: Film Critics Here Present Plaques to Poll Winners
description: Awards for outstanding achievements in movie making last year were presented last night by the New York Film Critics Circle at a reception at Sardi's Restaurant, 248 West 44th Street. The winners received plaques emblematic of the voting early this month in the 39th annual canvass of the 26 critics working for newspapers, magazines and other media.

title: Rangers Defeat Kings by 53 As Irvine Scores Two Goals
Spaniard Who Founded Nuns Order Canonized
description: ROME, Jan. 27Pope Paul VI today proclaimed the sainthood of Teresa Jornet Ibars, a 19thcentury Spanish nun who founded the Congregation of the Little Sisters of Abandoned Old People.

title: Laver Wins Pro Tennis Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27Arthur Ashe teased Rod Laver about the color of Laver's championship tennis trophythat it was darker then Ashe's runnerup model, and that maybe it was supposed to be the other way around today at the Spectrum.

title: Photos Owned by Hitler Sold in U.S. for $1'0,000.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27 (UPI)A bidder has purchased for $10,000 a pair of photograph albums owned by Hitler.

title: Manhattan Sets 7 Track Marks
Delmonica Hanover's Triumph Gives Prix d'Amerique an American Accent
description: PARIS, Jan. 27Delmonica Hanover. found winning in France today as easy as winning in the United States.

title: Car Buyers Putting Limits On FuelEconomy Efforts
description: DETROIT, Jan. 27American motorists may no longer be favoring the gasolineguzzling dinosaurs, but they are also not exactly going after the fuelsaving misers.

title: Pipeline Supervisor
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 27If Andrew P. Rollins Jr. were the demonstrative type, he would probably be jumping with excitement even at the sedate age of 55. He has just fallen in, as he Man. puts it, to probably the most in the imposing assignNews ment a professional engineer could draw: supervision of the building of the $3.5billion Alaska oil pipeline, the biggest private construction project in history.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 28 (AP)Homer Smith, an assistant coach at Georgia Tech and former head coach at Davidson College, has accepted the job as head football coach Army, The Atlanta Constitution said in its Tuesday editions. The newspaper said the official announcement would be made later this week at the United States Military Academy.

title: Events Today
Sports Today
Teachers Schedule Strike At State Colleges Monday
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Jan. 28 Negotiators for the union representing 2,800 teachers at the eight New Jersey state colleges said today they were going ahead with plans to strike the entire system on Monday.

title: Video Fails, Fans Erupt In Dayton
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 28 (UPI)  Some 8,000 persons attending the closed circuit attending the closedcircuit AliJoe Frazier fight in New York rioted at Hara Arena near here tonight when the video portion of the telecast went blank minutes before the bout started.

title: From the Squalor of the Ghetto, A Hero Is Stamped Super Fly
description: Super Fly is coming, Those words, stamped across envelopes leaving Austin Peay University in Clarksville, Tenn., herald the arrival of James (Fly) Williams, the school's sophomore hasketball star, a product of the slums of Brooklyn.

title: FOREIGN SECURITIES
TCHERKASSKY ROLE GRACES MIDNIGHT
description: Marianna Tcherkassky made a very springlike and floating first appearance in Elior Feld's At Midnight Sunday evening at the City Center during the American. ballet Theater's current rent season.

title: Lee Hill, Engineer, Dies at 74; Headed Firm of Consultants
description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 28Lee H. Hill, chairman of the New York management consultant firm of Rogers, Slade & Hill, died here yesterday on a business trip. He was 74 years old and had made his home in recent years in West Palm Beach.

title: Tests Show That 74 Cars Are Still Damage Prone
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety ?? ?? that new American cars were generally no better, and in some cases were much worse, than last year's at avoiding damage in minor collisions.

title: Eliminating Statistical Garbage
description: In June, 1970, when all President Nixon had to worry about were little things like Vietnam and the skyrocketing cost of living, he went on television to bid Americans be of good cheer: He had invented a device for checking inflation without forcing the nation down the slippery road of wageprice controls,

title: Handy &
description: In its annual silver market review published yesterday, Handy & Harman, silver refiner and processor, predicted that current high prices for silver might weaken this year.

title: NIXON HEALTH PLAN, WOULD TAX WORKERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI) The Administration's national health insurance proposal, scheduled to go to Congress soon, would require workers to pay income tax on health insurance premiums contributed by their employers, Administration officials disclosed today.

title: TRIAL IN SLAYING OF OFFICERS OPENS
description: The former Panther, identified only as Akbar, is a felon, Mr. Katz said, and you judge his credibility. Akbar would say anything the District Attorney wanted him to say, Mr. Katz asserted, because he has everything to gain from cooperating with the prosecution.

title: A.E.C. TO ALTER RULE ON PLANT LICENSING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) The Atomic Energy Commission said today it was proposing changes. in its procedures for licensing nuclear power plants, in an effort to shorten the time needed to put such plants into operation.

title: WHARTON POOR, 85, ADMIRALTY LAWYER
description: Wharton Poor, an admiralty lawyer who was senior partner in the New York law firm of Haight, Gardner, Poor & Havens, died Sunday in Flushing Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 14149 33d Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

title: TERRY ORR EXCELS AS ALAIN IN GARDEE
description: Terry Orr maynot have got his girl in American Ballet Theater's La Fille Mal Gardee on Sunday afternoon, but he certainly won over the City Center audience.

title: St. Louis Parking. Lot?
description: Adler and Sullivan's Garrick Theater was leveled for a parking garage some years ago in Chicago; their Wainwright Building was scheduled to be torn down for parking lot in St. Louis this spring. That is the classic route to oblivion for America's landmark buildings. The way to blacktop is paved with this country's architectural heritage.

title: MRS. OSWALD VEBLEN
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 28Mrs. Elizabeth Richardson Veblen, widow of Dr. Oswald Veblen, a mathematician, died Saturday at the Princeton Medical Center. She was 92 years old and lived at 452 Herrontown Road here.

title: N.L.R.B. Aide Orders Farah Penalties
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 28 In a sweeping and harshly worded decision, a National Labor Relations Board judge accused the Farah Manufacturing Company of Texas today of wholesale lawlessness and ordered the company to restore all striking workers to their jobs and to permit union organization of its factories.

title: Philadelphia Track Classic Summaries
ENRIQUE ZANETTI, CHEMIST, 89, DEAD
description: GERMANTOWN, N. Y., Jan. 28Dr. S. Enrique Zanetti, an expert on chemical warfare and emeritus Professor of chemistry at Columbia University, died Saturday in Livingston. He was 89 years old and lived here.

title: AVOID RATE RISE, TAXI MEN URGED
description: Officials of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission urged operators of taxi fleets yesterday to pursue all alternatives to avoid a rate increase, and agreed to support a bid for exempting the taxi industry from state fuel taxes in the same way that Governor Wilson has proposed to exempt buses.

title: Chemical Maker Gains
description: Fourthquarter net income of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., reached $143million, or $2.93 share, compared with $105million, or $2.14 a share for the 1972 quarter, the nation's largest chemical producer said yesterday in a preliminary report.

title: Harvey Resigns House Seat

title: Briefs on Energy
description: Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank, said yesterday that the energy,crisis was not just a crisis of shortage but especially one of price, particularly for poor nations. He cited a fourfold rise in the price of light crude oil in two years. We estimate that this price increase will cause the developing countries to spend $10billion more this year than they did last year, assuming theyre able to continue their oil import. Mr. McNamara said on the NBC television program Today. The probability is theyre going to have to cut back on oil imports and this is going to deprive their. economies of the energy they need to make the modest increases in growth they previously planned. Unless Congress reverses its vote of last *eek, turning down a $1.5billion contribution the International Development Association, Mr. McNamara said, the I.D.A. will be bankrupt by July 1 of this year.

R., Jan. 27 A; A loss in match play has a far more damaging psychological effect than a loss in tournament play because the match contestant must sit down again the next day to face the same victorious opponent. While it's advisable to put defeats out of mind before beginning a new game, that's scarcely possible when staring across the table at a face that all but creates the debacle all over again in imagination.

title: Ailing East Meets West In Hockey
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 28The best players in the National. Hockey League do not necessarily insure the best kind of hockey game, but the league's allstar game usually creates a lot of hoopla, and the 27th annual game,tomorrow night is expected to fill the 16,666 seats of Chicago Stadium. The game, matching players selected from the East and West Divisions of the N.H.L., will be nationally televised. In the New York area the game will be broadcast over WORTV, Channel 9, beginning at 8:30 P.M. For the first time in the 27year history of the game the possibility of a tie has been removed with a league decision to to to unlimited, suddendeath overtime. Of the 26 previous games, seven ended in ties, the most recent in 1969.

title: Red Smith
description: This time they fought from memory. This time the officials said Muhammad Ali had won in 12 rounds, though many in the bawling crowd of 20,748 in Madison Square Garden disagreed, and one of these could have been Angelo Dundee. You gotta stop him to win! Ali's trainer shouted as a frenzied Joe Frazier chased his man in the last round. You gotta stop him to win! Maybe Dundee was only trying to spur the weary All to greater effort, and maybe he was scoring the bout. The card in this corner gave Frazier seven rounds, Ali five, with 7 points for Joe and 6 for Muhammad. I have been wrong in the past and expect to be wrong in the future, probably when Ali is 35, Frazier 33 and they do it all over again. I think we should go again, the official winner said afterward, because we draw more people to an eevent than anybody in the recorded history of records.

title: Books of The Times
description: If you can tear yourself away from the immediate surroundings and gaze off at the horizon of Peter Farb's Word Play: What Happens When People Talk, you'll see that the author is going somewhere. You'll see that he's summarizing for a popular audience the present state of the science of linguistics. You'll see that he's trying to blend two approaches to language that have often been in conflict"one being the recent generative transformational grammar, which seeks to explain the ability of native speakers to produce wellformed sentences"; and the other being the even more recently developing field of psycholinguistics, which is concerned with the strategies of language interac tion In social contexts. And you'll see that he's organized his book loosely enough to accommodate both these approaches without forcing them into a reconciliation that they have not yet in reality undergone (although, as Mr. Farb points out in his reference notes, Eventually the two views will probably be. reconciled, and at this time efforts to do just that can be detected in both camps.).

title: CAREY WON'T ABIDE BY SPENDING LIMIT
description: ALBANY, Jan. 28Replying to the Democratic party leadership's call for spending limitations in the party's primary, Representative Hugh L. Carey said today that he intended to spend whatsoever is needed to reach the people.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: According to The Times of Jan. 21 Senator Adlai E. Stevenson has called hearings by a Senate subcommittee to review the potentially adverse effects of growing foreign investment in the country. However, such investment should be encouraged, not discouraged.

title: NEWS INDEX
Man's Check for Good Deed Goes to the Neediest
Heath Says Miners Families May Get No Benefits in a Strike
description: LONDON, Jan. 28  Prime Minister Heath said tonight that he Government was considering withholding unemployment benefits from the families of coal miners in the event of a strike against the coal industry.

title: Stiff Fight Looms Over Ratification of Equal Rights Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 Ratification of the Equal Rights, Amendment came up for a vote today in the Georgia legislature and was defeated. It will come up Ohio in a week or so, and will probably pass.by Prof. Paul Freund of the Harvard Law School, who believes the 14th Amendment already provides women with all necessary protections. But he said that further study had convinced him that the Supreme Court was going to take a long time before it applied the 14th Amendment fully to women.

title: HEATING OIL PRICE IN EUROPE FALLS
description: PARIS, Jan. 28Light heating oil in the Rotterdam market, which influences the level of prices of petroleum products in the European market, has fallen more than 50 per cent from the high of early December.

title: Palestinians Speaking Out Against the Israelis'
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 17Three months after the October war, the Palestinian Arabs on the West Bank of the Jordan River and in the Gaza Strip speak more openly against Israeli occupation than at any time since they were conquered six and a half years ago.

title: Treasury Bills Fell At the Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 28Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: France Offering Kuwait Arms and Plants for Oil
description: KUWAIT, Jan. 28 (AP)Foreign Minister Michel Jobert of France offered arms and large industrial investments to Kuwait today in exchange for longterm oil deliveries; Government sources reported.

title: SLUMP IN BIG CARS SEEN LEVELING OFF
description: DETROIT, Jan. 28The slump in big car sales may have reached bottom, according to some auto industry officials.

title: CORPORATE BONDS ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: Corporate bond prices turned up yesterday, buoyed (partly at least) by the psychological lift of the broadening decline to 9 per cent prime rate. Traders, noting gains of  to  point in some recently offered corporate issues, said the banks lower prime rate, along with declines in other shortterm rates, helped to stimulate the bond market.

title: Heroin Dealer Gets Life
description: ALBANY, Jan. 28 (AP)Theodore Paul, 32 years old, of Albany, convicted on two counts of selling heroin, was sentenced today to life imprisonment. Judge John Clyne of Albany County Court gave Mr. Paul minimum sentence of 14 years with probation for life. A jury last week found Mr. Paul guilty of selling heroin to a state police undercover agent last September.

title: INTERNATIONAL LINES VOTE RISE IN AIR FARE
description: The International Air Transport Association said yesterday in Montreal that its member airlines had voted to raise passenger fares on most international routes by 7 per cent on March 1 to defray higher jet fuel costs. It will be the second rate increase attributed to higher fuel prices in two months.

title: Exxon Chief Admits Industry Mistakes
description: DETROIT, Jan. 28J. K. Jamieson, chairman and chief executive officer of the Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, conceded in a speech here today that the oil industry and his company had made mistakes in the past that had contributed.to the energy crisis.

title: Alfred Good, 86, ExOfficer Of Metropolitan Life, Dies
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Jan. 28  Alfred H. Good, who retired as an assistant vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in 1955 after 51 years of service, died Saturday in Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco. He was 86 years old and lived here.

title: Music: Average Effort
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 28 Bob Dylan and The Band's first concert in the New York area at the Nassau Coliseum tonight probably represented about the average level of the current tour. Some of it was very, very good. Some of it was perfectly wretched. Most of it added up to convincing, if idiosyncratic, performances of some of the great songs of the nineteensixties.

title: NoFault Era Opens Friday in State
description: Nofault auto insurance becomes compulsory Friday for New York State's estimated seven million motor vehicle operators.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: The Tautog
description: Thickbodied, strong and with a heavylipped mouth and powerful teeth that can crush mussels, barnacles or fiddler crabs with ease, the tautog is not a handsome fish, but he makes a splendid chowder.

title: LAURENCE SINCLAIR
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Jan. 28Laurence Sinclair, who retired in 1957 as a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, died Friday at his home, 635 Coleman Place. His age was 81.

title: New Zealand Bars Athlete At Games
description: CHRIST CHURCH, New Zealand, Jan. 28 (AP)David Quax of New Zealand, a distance runner, was suspended today from his country's team for publicly accusing the Kenyans of rough tactics in the 10,000meters race in the Commonwealth Games last Friday.

title: The Noblest City of Them All
description: ROME, Ides of MarchDespite doomsayers forecast of the end of the western part of the Roman Empire in this year A.D. 476, a survey by Danielius Yankeloviclus, a leading publice opinio research organization, found that twothirds of those questioned thought that Rome would not decline or fall.

title: The Fight II Deflates Market for Scalpers
description: In terms of scalping, The Fight II was worth only an Arabic number.

title: Listing of Prices for Transactions in Commodity Futures
Soviet Offers to Sell Grain to U.S. To Replenish Depleted Supplies
description: A Soviet trade official offered yesterday to sell wheat to the United States to help replenish grain stocks that have been drawn down to low levels after heavy exports over the last two years.

title: Football at Syracuse Needs Speed, Money
description: Syracuse University's Chancellor, Dr. Melvin Eggers, and his new head football coach, Frank Maloney, gave their versions yesterday of what they expect in.the way of achievement from the Orange team in the seasons just ahead. To the university's chief executive, used to the eagerness of new staff members, there appeared to be no urgency about becoming number one although he obviously wanted to balance the football budget as soon

title: Temple Nears Milestone
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 (UPI)Temple University can become the seventh team in intercollegiate basketball history to reach the 1,000victory plateau when the Owls host Drexl tomorrow night. Kentucky is the winningest team with 1,100 victories, followed by Kansas, Oregon State, St. John's, Pennsylvania, North Carolina and Temple.

title: Nuclear Targeting
description: Defense Secretary Schlesinger's explanation last week of the Administration's altered nuclear strategy answered somebut not allof the major concerns advanced by its critics.

title: Screen: Kick-and-Slash:' Black Belt Jones' Is Played by Jim Kelly The Cast ' Black Belt Jones' Is Played by Jim Kelly
description: The Hollywood production team of Fred Weintraub and Paul Heller, who, with Robert Clouse, the director, gave us that Hong Kong-based kung fu bash, "Enter the Dragon," last summer, now have come up with the Hollywood-made "Black Belt Jones" to prove that travel isn't broadening.This latest of the slew of kick-and-slash melodramas, which is playing at the Cinerama and 86th St. Twin 2 Theaters, is as basically silly as many of the previous, similarly action-packed adventures it imitates and is as obvious as a karate chop.A minor change in the norm should be noted, however. In this case, "Black Belt Jones," played by the young, handsome, black, muscular martial arts devotee, Jim Kelly, one of the heroes of "Enter the Dragon," is ably assisted by Gloria Hendry, a photogenic soul sister who is just as roughly efficient as her tough, stoic partner in dispatching squads of white or black bad guys.What they're fighting about is not really earthshaking except to indicate that Mafia-like citizens, with the aid of black hoods they have strong-armed, are trying to take over a karate school building owned by Scatman Crothers, our hero's beloved mentor, and our heroine's father, in order to make a big realty killing.Of course, the fearless team, assisted by the school's students and, unexpectedly, a covey of pretty trampoline experts, take the opposition in stride and also manage to make it romantically. But the succession of clashes and explicit street language tend to become repetitious and as unwittingly comic as the cast's largely mechanical performances. This "Black Belt Jones" is stale and over-trained despite all the chops, kicks and belts.

title: Montemarano Trial
description: The state's chief witness in the murder trial of Dr. Vincent Montemarano testified yesterday that Eugene Bauer was dying and could have been dead when he was being examined for vital life signs. Page 66.

title: ..L.I.R.R.Assailed on Failure In Ice Storm Emergency
Blackout in Ft. Worth
description: FORT WORTH, Jan. 28 (UPI)The closed circuit television feed of the MuhamAliJoe Frazier heavyweight fight failed minutes before the opening bell tonight at the Convention Center. About 3,000 fans, who paid up to $12.50 a ticket, were able only to hear the roundbyround description. A fight insurance company will refund the ticket price tomorrow.

title: Assembly Passes a Bill to Ban ChainSale Schemes
description: ALBANY, Jan. 28  The Assembly passed and sent to the senate today a bill prohibiting chaindistributor schemes. Under such plans, a person is enticed into purchasing a line of usually worthless products and the right to sell distributorships for them.

title: U.S. Pipes Methane From Coal Mine; Use Could Double Natural Gas Supply
description: BULA, W. Va., Jan. 28Methane from deep in a coal bed began to be piped into, a commercial line today, demonstrating the practicality of a Governmentdeveloped technolagy that Interior Department researchers say, could almost double the nation's reserves of natural gas.smalldiameter shaft hundreds of feet down to the coalbed level, and then to bore holes 1,000 feet or more horizontally along the coal seam to collect the methane and pipe it to the surface.

title: Police to Study HeartAid Techniques
description: Thirty members of the Police Department's Emergency Services Section will start school tonight in a new program that it is hoped will save as many as 4,000 victims of heart attacks in the city each

title: Gold Is the Big Word at Jewelry Trade Fair Here
REPUBLICANS SET HOUSE GUIDELINES ON IMPEACHMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28Republican members of the House Judiciary Committee have reached informal agreement that President Nixon could not be impeached for criminal acts of subordinates without evidence of his personal knowledge or direction.

title: BYRNE AND SPASSKY ADJOURN 6TH GAME
description: Robert Byrne of the United States and Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union adjourned the sixth game yesterday in their quarterfinal Candidates Match in the world chess championship preliminaries.

title: No Reason To Retire
description: It was near midnight, and Joe Frazier's right eye was about to close.

title: Study Group Says Nixon Fails To Give Details on TV Charges
description: The National News Council said yesterday that the White House had failed to support with specific details President Nixon's charges against the television networks of outrageous, vicious, distorted reporting. Mr. Nixon had made the charges at his news confer. ence in Washington on Oct. 26, 1973.

title: DEMOCRATS FOILED BY GM. STRATEGY
description: TRENTON, Jan. 28Efforts of the Democratic majority in the State Assembly to enact a series of reforms designed to open up the Assembly committee system to the public were stymied today by the Republicans. At the same time, the 14 Republican Assembly members served notice on their 66 Democratic colleagues that while they were short on numbers, they were not short of parliamentary ingenuity.

title: NoFault Era Opens Friday in State
description: Nofault auto insurance becomes compulsory Friday for New York State's estimated seven million motor vehicle operators.

title: Steel Production Rose 0.5% in Week To 2.9 Million Tons
description: Production of steel during the week ended Jan. 26 rose by 0.5 per cent to 2.9 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The production index rose to 118.9 from 118.3 in the preceding week when production totaled 2,887,000 tons.

title: CITY'S RIGHTS UNIT DENIES T.W.A PLEA
description: Mrs. Eleanor Holmes Norton, chairman of the city's Human Rights Commission, disclosed yesterday that her agency had denied the Trans World Airlines request to reopen a 1969 case in which a former Jewish employe was awarded $11,889 after the agency found the airline had tolerated religious discrimination.For 27yearold Malcolm Rattner, the former employe and a Vietnam veteran, the decision meant a lot to me.Mr. Rattner, who now drives a taxi said: It means that no one can discriminate because of race, creed or color, and that New York can be proud of its Human Rights Commission.Mr. Rattner was dismissed as a T.W.A. ramp handler on Sept. 27, 1969, after 37 days of employment.In speaking of her. agency's action, Mrs. Norton said:It is easy to believe antiSemitism has been eliminated in America. This case demonstrates the need for continued vigilance.T.W.A.'s publicity director, Franklin Parisi, issued a blanket rejection on Sunday of the commission's charges of antiSemitism. He said T.W.A. would contest the decision in State sion did not consider the request to reopen the case.The Human Rights Commission decision found that Mr. Rattner had suffered humiliation, outrage and mental anguish because of the discrimination. It also ruled that the airline had refused to give Mr. Ratter time off to observe Yom Kippur and had failed to give him advance notice of his dismissal. The decision also detailed other antiSemitic incidents directed against Mr Rattner.

title: JOHNSON OPPOSES NOMINEE FOR F.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28Nicholas Johnson, a former member of the Federal Communications Commission, urged a Senate ?? today to reject his nominated successor to assure that the country's communications systems and policies are not subjected to excessive White House control.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
description: Fair to partly cloudy skies and milder temperatures are forecast today for the Northeast. Cooler conditions and rain will prevail throughout the rest of the Eastern Seaboard with showers ending early in the day in the. eastern Ohio Valley. It will be mostly cloudy from the western Ohio Valley to the upper lake region; while fair to partly cloudy skies will cover the Mississippi Valley, Plains States, Southwest and California. Occasional snow will occur from northern Minnesota across the northern Rockies and change to rain in the Pacific Northwest. Snow will be scattered from the northern portions of the plateau region to the Colorado Rockies.

title: For Dylan Fan, Not Even Rain Can Dampen the Pilgrimage...
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Jan. 28This is a pilgrimage; I ought to be crawling on my knees, a wet, bedraggled young man said tonight.

title: Council Takes Up Thorny lssues; Full Transcripts Are Debated
description: Words that sound all right in the heat of debate somehow look different in cold prin Mr. Troy said. And keeping verbatim transcripts could entice Councilmen into what he said was a common practice among Congressmen: speaking on one side of an issue and voting on the other, for a record to please all constituents.

title: Dr. Paul Stewart, Headed Waynesburg College, 2163
description: WAYNESBURG, Pa., Jan. 28 Dr. Paul R. Stewart, president of Waynesburg College from 1921 to 1963, when he became chancellor, died yesterday, He was 86 years old.
