description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28Despite widespread speculatior that the Senate Watergate committee had held its last public session, Samuel Dash, the committee's chief counset, insisted today that the hearings would resume and instructed his staff to continue to prepare for therm

title: In Albany, the Women Show Their Strength
description: ALBANYTwo weeks into the new legislative session may seem a bit early to be spotting trends, but there is one development here sosudden and dramatic that it has taken the normally slowstarting state capital almost completely by surprise. Women have become good politics in New York State.

title: Dacca's 5Year Plan Faces Fact of Poverty
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Jan. 27 After two years of economic crisis and political instability, Bangladesh has taken a few fragile steps forward.

description: G. D. Searle & Co., which has been reducing its dependence on the ethical drug business, is further diversifying its operations by planning to buy Oxford Laboratories, a manufactuer of liquidhandling systems, re lated supplies and chemical diagnostic products for clinical laboratories.

description: MOSCOW, Jan. 28The Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, new to Cuba today on what he described as.a. friendly visit to "the island of freedom.

title: SAIGON ARRESTS TIMES REPORTER
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28The Saigon Government ?? today arrested James M. Markham, Saigon bureau chief of The New York Times, as he ?? from a week in a Vietcongheld area near the central coast of South Vietnam.

title: VIOLENCE ERUPTS IN TRUCK DISPUTE
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 28 (UPI) A truck driver was shot, five trucks were hit by bullets and two truckers were pulled from their rig and beaten in northern Ohio late yesterday and early today as the deadline approached for a nationwide trucking. shutdown in protest against rising fuel costs.

title: Results at Roosevelt Raceway
DR. MARINA P. MEYERS
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 28Dr. Marina P. Meyers, an ophthalmologist and staff member of the Glen Cove Community Hospital, died yesterday at her office, 9 Medical Plaza. She was 49 years old and lived here.

title: Open Interest
NEW ATTACK KILLS 6 IN PHNOM PENH
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 28 (UPI)Insurgent gunners bombarded Phnom Penh for the fourth day today, hitting the captial, a refugee camp and an area near Pochentong airport with artillery, rockets and recoillessrifle fire.

title: Advertising: New S.A.S. Plans
description: The Scandinavian Airlines System 1974 advertising campaign was to have been an extension of the Viking idea introduced when the William Esty Company took over the account.

title: CHESIMARD TRIAL DELAYED BY TESTS
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Jan. 28 The trial of Mrs. Joanne Chesimard, who is accused of murdering a New Jersey state trooper, was postponed today for five days because she is in danger of having a miscarriage.

description: The president of the union representing floor personnel and clerical employes at the New York Stock Exchange warned yeSterday of a possible strike next Monday if current contract talks failed to resolve differences,

title: Democrats to Respond To Nixon on TV Friday
description: The three major commercial television networks said yesterday they were setting aside time Friday night for the Democratic party's response to President Nixon's scheduled State of the Union Message on Wednesday night to Congress, according to an Associated Press report.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Federal appeals court affirmed a decision to free narcotics defendant who had been arrested and searched under a state loitering law that was later declared unconstitutional. The case involved Leon Newsome, who appealed his conviction on a narcoticspossession charge that grew out of evidence seized when he was arrested for loitering in the lobby of a City Housing Authority building in Queens four years ago.

title: Mackell Trial Told Few Asked of Plan's Legality
description: The defense in the trial of former Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell sought yesterday to show that people who invested in a cashonly getrichquick scheme believed the operation was a legitimate business enterprise.

title: College Conference Standings
Article 1  No Title
Hanna Kolesnik, a Former Star Of Kiev Opera, Sings. Strongly
description: Hanna Kolesnik took total command of the, stage at Hunter College's Assembly, Hall Sunday night,, communicating much of the presence and authority that she undoubtedlY brought to the Ukrainian Kiev Opera, where she was a leading artist.

title: Dow Jones to Reduce Its Papers Page Width
description: The page width of both The Wall Street Journal and The National Observer will be reduced by about 2 inches to standard newspaper size in March, to stretch tight newsprint supplies and to save about $2.3million year, Dow Jones & Co., Inc., the publisher, announced yesterday.

title: MRS. ALBERT A. BLINDER
description: Mrs. Meredith Zaretski Blind er, wife of Judge Albert A Blinder of the Court of Claims died yesterday of a recurrenc, of ulcerative ileitis at thei home, 180 Cabrini Boulevard She was 35 years old.

title: People and Business
description: Joseph V. McKee Jr. has been named chairman, president and chief, executive officer of the National Union Electric Corporation. He succeeds C. Russell Feldmann, who founded the floorcare equipment and airconditioning company in 1947 and who died last month.

title: Carpi Made 3 Fatal Errors, Prosecution Says in Summary
New Jersey Sports
description: For basketball fans. of Orange High School the shouting begins when their team starts pregame warmup drilla:and does not cease., until the final buizer. It's been that way through. the first 14 genies of the.season; all victories.

title: SANDMAN TO GET HELP FROM FORD
description: TRENTON, Jan. 28Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. New Jersey's highly unsuccessful Republican candidate for Governor last year, announced today that Vice President Ford would appear at a March 23 party fundraising dinner in Atlantic City to help pay off last year's Republican campaign debt.

title: FIREMEN THREATEN HACKENSACK STRIKE
description: HACKENSACK, Jan. 28 (AP) Firemen have voted to strike Feb. 5 in a dispute involving working conditions, fringe benefits, and the disciplining of the local union president for speaking to the press.

title: MRS. KLEIN WINS SENATE APPROVAL
description: TRENTON, Jan. 28Mrs. Ann Klein was overwhelmingly confirmed by the State Senate today as Governor Byrne's Commissioner. of Institutions and Agencies after a weeklong delay caused by questions raised by her husband's business interests.

title: JULIAN BENTON
description: Julian Benton, who retired in 1970 as a communications supervisor for The New York Times, died yesterday in Leesburg, Fla., where he lived. His age was 73.

title: PORTER IS GUILTY OF LYING TO F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28Herbert L. Porter, the former scheduling director for the Committee for the Reelection of the President, pleaded guilty today to a charge of lying to the F.B.I. during its early investigation of the Watergate scandals.

title: Advance Registered in Fourth Quarter
description: Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the sixthlargest oil company in the nation, yesterday joined the parade of industry leaders showing a dramatic earnings growth in the fourth quarterup 53 per centand an overall growth in yearly performance.

title: RECORD SURPLUS IN NATION'S TRADE SET IN DECEMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28The nation's foreign trade showed a record surplus off exports over imports in December and finished the year 1973 with a large and unexpected surplus of almost $1.7billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Rabbi Solomon Shapiro, 57, V.A. Hospital Chaplain, Dies
description: Rabbi Solomon Shapiro, chaplain of the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan, died Saturday of heart attack at his office, Park Avenue. He was 57 years old and lived at 230 West 79th Street.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
Mrs. Nixon Expresses Great Faith in Husband
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI)Her fist clenched, a tense Mrs. Richard M. Nixon said today the President is in great health and I love him dearly and I have great faith.

title: Bombshell From Dior: The New Look Updated
description: PARIS, Jan. 28The house of Dior dropped a bombshell today. Not as startling perhaps as the one called the New Look back in 1947that would be too much to expect. But given the uneasy state of fashion, its newest look is certainly welcome.

title: JULIUS PATZAK DIES; VIENNA OPERA TENOR
description: ROTTACH EGERN, Germany, Jan. 28Julius Patzak, noted Austrian tenor, died here Saturday, He was 75 years old.

title: Headmaster Is Named
description: NORTHFIELD, Mass, Jan. 28 (AP)Dr. Paul W. Raluneler, Dartmouth College chaplain since 1947, was named today as headmaster of the Northfield Mount Hermon School here.

title: DR. JANET BRIGGS
description: Dr. Janet Zaph Briggs, vice president for technical information of the Climax Molybdenum Company division of American Metal Climax, Inc., of New York, died Thursday in Tokyo after a heart attack, where she was on a business trip. She was 62 years old lived at 320 East 42d Street.

title: Saudi Says OilPrice Cut Must Be Joint Arab Step
description: TOKYO, Jan. 28  Sheik Ahmed Zaki alYamani, Saudi Arabia's Minister of Petroleum Affairs, stressed here today that any reduction in his country's oil prices must be part of joint reduction with the five other oilproducing countries yr the Persian Gulf.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Colonialism 11 A.M.

title: Bread, an Allegory, At American Place
description: There is almost always something fascinating about plays in which the characters are engaged in an almost documentary depiction of work. Arnold Wesker recognized this in The Kitchen, just as did David Storey in The Contractor. Last night at the American Place Theater we were given another example of naturalism and metaphor, David Scott Milton's Bread.

title: Notes on People
description: The fifth announced candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor of California is Secretary of State Edmund G. Brown Jr., whose father had to step down from the Governorship in 468 after Ronald Reagan defeated him for the office. Mr. Brown, who is 35 years old, is believed by some politically wise Democrats to be the frontrunner in the party race, partly because public opinion polls show he has high name identification.

title: Aramco Adds to Capacity
description: The Arabian American Oil Company said yesterday that it was continuing to expand its petroleum capacity despite Arab, oil restrictions although at a slower rate than had been planned before the Saudi Arabian embargo and production cutbacks.

title: MINISTER SENTENCED TO 3 MONTHS IN JAIL
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Jan. 28 (UPI)A Unitarian minister was sentenced to three months in the.county workhouse today for embezzling $109,000 from a family counseling service while he was treasurer of the organization in 1972.

title: Impressive Singing By Betty Lane Has Bright, Free Sound
description: Betty Lane, a soprano from Detroit who has studied in Atlanta and at the Juilliard School, gave a most impiessive recital Souday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. The program was presented by the Harlem School of the Arts, where Miss Lane is studying with Dorothy Maynor, as part of its 10th anniversary celebrations. If there are other students there who approach Miss Lane in quality, then the school should be able to celebrate many more anniversaries in the years to come.

title: A GRIVAS FUNERAL IN ATHENS BARRED
description: ATHENS, Jan. 28  The Greek Government today described Gen. George Grivas, the underground leader of the campaign for a union of Cyprus with Greece, as a national hero, but decided against having his funeral in Athens.

title: JACK KATZ
description: Jack Katz a pharmacist at Roosevelt Hospital, died of cancer Monday evening in the Fort Hamilton Veterans Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 50 years old and lived In Bay Ridge Brooklyn. He was a graduate of the Brooklyn Col lege of Pharmacy.

title: Paris M. Pitt. Dies at 38; Cross &
description: Paris M. Pitt, vice president of Cross & Brown, realestate broker, died yesterday at his home, 240 East 79th Street, at the age of 38.

title: Gentle Slopes, Modest Fees for Ski Tyros
description: NEWFOUNDLAND, N. J., Jan. 29  There are no towering mountains at the Craigmeur Ski Area, no fancy skiers in skyblue tights, no bons vivants drinking brandy by an open fire. At Craigmeur they ski in corduroy pants and longjohns, they slide and fall and, in most cases, drink hot chocolate and use rented equipment.

title: City Said to Reward Inefficient Hospitals
If They Chose To They Could Go to a Dinner Party Every Night
description: They're all good conversationalists. Most of them have impeccable manners, are easy to get along with, adaptable and amusing(indude Norman Mailer because when he's on his best behavior, he's good). They are, perhaps, the most sought after element on the New York social scene.

title: MRS. MYRON ACKERMAN
description: Mrs. Irma Hirsch Ackeman, the wife of Myron H. Ackerman, president of Ackerman Associates, a textile manufacturer, died of anemia yesterday at her home, 1130 Park Avenue. She was 56 years old.

title: City's Jail Population Fell 20 Per Cent in Last Year
description: The city's jail and prison population has dropped sharply, and observers of the criminal justice system gay some of the reasons are reductions in both the crime rate and drug addiction as well as new alternatives to pretrial detention and more efficient court administration.

title: Nordiques Blank Sharks
description: UEBEC, Jan. 29 (AP)J. C. Tremblay and Guy Dufour scored, two goals each and Richard Brodeur stopped 28 Los Angeles shots to lead the Quebec Nordiques to a 5.0 World Hockey. Association triumph over the Sharks tonight.

title: Pickering to Be Nominated As Ambassador to Jordan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 The White House announced today that Thomas R. Pickering, currently the Executive Secretary of the State Department, would be nominated as Ambassador to Jordan. He will replace L. Dean Brown, who was earlier named Deputy Under Secretary of State for Management.

title: 4 AT MURDER SITE TESTIFY AT TRIAL
description: Four persons who were nearby when police officers Rocco Laurie and Gregory Foster were slain two years ago on the Lower East Side testified yesterday in the murder trial of Henry Brown, a reputed leader of a group that the police call the Black Liberation Army.

title: U. S. TERMINATES CURB ON LENDING DOLLARS ABROAD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 The Government ended today its array of controls over the outflow of dollars for lending and investing abroad. Some of the controls were more than decade old.

title: EUROPE ACCEPTS U.S. DOLLAR STEP
description: PARIS, Jan. 29The dismantling of. United States controls on foreign investment by Americans was interpreted in Europe today as an effort to check the rise in the dollar's value abroad to preserve American trading surpluses.

title: Carpi Trial Jury Asks for a Rereading of Testimony
description: TRENTON, Jan. 29  After four hours of deliberation, jury of seven men and five women in the Carpi murder trial demonstrated their uncertainty today by asking for lengthy rereading of the testimony of four witnesses.

title: ISRAEL CUMMINGS
description: Israel Cummings, president of the Shamokin Woolen Mills, 450 Seventh Avenue here, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 12 East 86th Street.

title: G.A.O. CHALLENGES GUARD FOR AGNEW
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The General Accounting Office told Congress today that President Nixon had no legal authority to order Secret Service protection for Spiro T. Agnew after Mr. Ag new resigned as Vice President.

title: FOOD SMUGGLERS ANGER ARGENTINA
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 29Severe price controls, the cornerstone of President Juan D. Peron's economic policy, are contributing to largescale smuggling of Argentine goods into neighboring countries.

title: Knights Win, 6 to 1, And Leave Cellar
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Jan. 29 (AP)  Mike Laughton scored a goal and picked up two assists tonight as the Jersey Knights beat the Toronto Toros, 61, and left the World Hockey Association's East Division cellar.

title: Corporate Bonds Continue to Show More Advances
TV: Press Review's Topic Is Conflict of Interest
REFORMS URGED ON CITY COUNCIL
description: A City Council committee that is considering reform suggestions spent much of its time yesterday fending off proposals from two freshmenone that would punish chronic absentee. ism and another that would change the word Councilman to Council Member, out of deference to women.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Western Star Six Wins, 64
Merrill Lynch Up in Quarter
description: Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc., reported yesterday that net income rose 5.8 per cent in the fourth quarter of 1973 but fell 44.2 per cent for the year as whole.

title: But Quarry Looms as Next Foe
description: Microphone in hand, a jubilant Muhammad. All informed the world yesterday, that he didn't need George Foreman.

title: SAYING FARMLAND CALLED PRIORITY
description: TRENTON, Jan.29The preservation of the state's vanishing farmland should be given top priority, a panel of experts representing farm interests, citizens and legislators told the opening session of New Jersey Farmers Week here today.

title: U.S PRODUCTIVITY SHOWS RARE DROP
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The ration's productivity, or output ter manhour, showed a rare lecline in the fourth quarter of ast year, the Labor Department eported today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A convicted murderer was found guilty in Camden raping a 17yearold girl last March 8 while he was on parole from a Pennsylvania prison. A jury returned the verdict against John Schnurr, 37, after deliberating for hours on the charge, which involved a Woodlynne girl.

title: RollCall Vote in Senate On Energy Bill Action
Business Briefs
description: A further decline in housing starts and a shortage of some critical building materials for nonresidential building has resulted in a decline in December construction contracts, F.. W. Dodge reported yesterday. Dodge, a division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company, said contracts last month totaled $6.13billion, 5 per cent below the level of those in December, 1972.

title: LABORITES ASSAIL RED UNION LEADER
description: LONDON, Jan. 29  Controversy broke out today over the efforts of a Communist leader of the mineworkers union to marshal support for a strike. The issue placed a strain on the tacit alliance between the miners and the Labor party Opposition.

title: Bridge: Declarer Prefers to Ignore Opportunities That Are Lost
description: The attitude toward the big one that got away is one of the many difference between the fisherman and the bridge player. The angler is eager to tell his story to any listener, but the declarer who has missed the chance to make the play of a lifetime is usually,, reticent. Luckily his opponents, if observant, will insure that the deal is not lost to posterity.

title: Theater: Britain's Actors Company in Chekhov's Delightful Wood Demonat the Brooklyn Academy
HOGAN SUCCESSOR MAY BE DEMOGRAT
description: Vincent F. Albano, the Republican leader in Manhattan, said yesterday that Governor Wilson would appoint a Democrat as interim district attorney to succeed the ailing Frank S. Hogan, who officially retires next Wednesday.

title: Pravda Says Pentagon Seeks To Prevent Trade With Soviet
Each to Get About $2.6Million
description: For their 47 minutes in the ring Monday night (including 11 minutes of rest periods), Muhammad All and Joe Frazier each wound up With the biggest payday in sports historyat least $2.6million apiece.

title: EHRLICMAN MOVE CALLED LEGAL ACT
About New York
description: I only regret that it is so late in the day, Artur Rubinstein was saying, although he did not sound truly regretful at all. Ah, 87 a large number, he said. I should respond to it. He was talking about his 87th birthday, which was on Monday. He celebrated by taking his wife to lunch.

title: Proxmire Sees Plant Sale To Lockheed as Improper
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP)The head of the General Services Administration acted, improperly in selling an Air Force facility to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation without bids, Senator William Proxmire said today.

title: Byrne, Seeking a Nominee, Talks to Environmentalists
description: TRENTON, Jan. 29  After conceding that they could and should have done more to prevent the resignation of Commissioner Richard J. Sullivan, some of New Jersey's leading

title: BOKY SUBSTITUTES FOR SUTHERLAND
description: The Metropolitan Opera, which seems to have had more than its share of difficulties this season, ran into another one yesterday that left a lot of operagoers disappointed last night.

title: Jury Witness Found Dead
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan 29 (AP) A druggist who bad testified before a special grand jury in vestigating possible ?? was found dead early today at Philadelphia International Airport, the police said. He was identified as Herbert Schindler, 53 years old, of Cherry Hill, N.J., who operated a pharmacy in Philadelphia.

title: 25Hour Day Isn't Enough
description: COLUMBUS, OhioCould I share with you a few thoughts from your sophomore president as he looks back on the past fifteen months?

title: Soviet Is Thought to Modify Craft to Let Its Astronauts Maneuver
Peron Asks the Permission Of Congress to Go Abroad
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 29 (UPI)President Juan D. Perlin asked Congress today for permission to leave the country at any time during the year.

title: People in Sports: Fly Williams Of Austin Peay Five Suspended
description: James (Fly) Williams; the No. 2 scorer in the nation in college basketball, was suspended from the Austin Peay State basketball team. As of now he is not a member of the team, said Coach Lake Kelly. It is not a closed situation.

title: Cardinal Going to Ireland
description: BOSTON, Jan. 29 (AP)Humberto Cardinal Medeiros will travel to Ireland in July, the Archdiocese of Boston announced today.

title: Notes on People
description: The first head of state to visit Bangladesh since it came into being two years ago is President Tito of Yugoslavia. He and his wife arrived in Dacca yesterday following a fiveday visit to India. The Titos were met by President Mohammad Ullah and the Prime Minister, Sheik Mullbur Rahman, and on the way into the city thousands of cheering people lined the streets.

title: BREZHNEV HAILED BY CASTRO IN CUBA
description: MIAMI, Jan. 29 (UPI) Premier Fidel Castro told crowd gathered in Havana welcome Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist Party Leader, tonight that Cuba would always be grateful the Soviet Union for its help in coping with the United States economic blockade the island.

title: Net at Union Pacific Up 9% for Quarter
description: The Union Pacific Corporation, which owns the railroad of the same name, reported yesterday its earnings rose per cent in the fourth quarter of last year and 22 per cent in the full year.

title: CORRECTION SLATE UNDER CHALLENGE
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29The eligibility of four, of Governor Wilson's reappointments to the Commission of Correction came under challenge today as the Senate Finance Committee questioned the ability of the commission to fulfill its new role as a prison ombudsman.

title: 4 WHITES KILLED BY ROVINGUNMEN
Hicks Is Signed as Key to New Offensive Front
description: John Hicks, the No. I draft choice of the New York Giants, has no preference as to whether he plays offensive guard or tackle next year, as long as he plays.

title: JUDGE WILL ORDER NIXON TO TESTIFY AT EXAIDES'TRIAL
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29A state judge said today that he would order President Nixon to testify in person at the trial or John D. Ehrlichman and two other former White House aides, now under indictment here for the 1971 breakin at the office of Dr. Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: Joyous Throngs in Suez Hail Reunion With Egypt
description: SUEZ, Egypt, Jan. 29Egyptian troops in the Sinai along with soldiers and civilians in this Tubblestrewn city celebrated their reunion with the rest of Egypt in an explosion of joy today.

title: Merck Reports Net Rises 16%
Truckers Disrupt Oil Deliveries And Harass Working Drivers
description: Independent truckers, intent upon a nationwide strike, disrupted some fuel deliveries and harassed working drivers yesterday. Violence was reported in two states.

title: SecondHand Dealer, 71, Knifed And Robbed in Garment District
description: A 71yearold dealer in secondhand clothes racks, a familiar figure in the city's garment district for many years, was found robbed and bleeding from about half a dozen stab wounds shortly after noon yesterday in his basement shop at 23 West 36th Street.

title: '72 Election Is Contested
description: BOSTON, Jan. 29. (AP)We the People, a group of about 20 persons who got together last June to protest the 1972 Presidential election, went into United States District Court yesterday to have President Nixon and Vice President Ford removed from office. The President and the Vice President are the only defendants in the civil suit, which contends that because of the illegal acts committed during the campaign, the people's right to a free and honest vote was abridged, a ?? said.

title: EXSAILOR INDICTED IN BRITISH ARMS CASE
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 (AP) A Federal grand jury indicted a 31yearold former sailor yesterday on charges of attempting to smuggle five pistols and 150 rounds of ammunition into Britain in the false bottom of trunk.

title: Riklis Seeks to Add A New Retail Chain
description: Meshulam Riklis, the retailing tycoon, moved yesterday to acquire a substantial interest in yet another retail chain. In the process, he bailed out a financially troubled merchandising concern and solved a major executive personnel problem. In a complex set of financial moves, Mr. Riklis, chairman of the RapidAmerican Corporation, his directors and the boards of the'McCrory Corporation and of Interstate Stores, Inc., announced that:

title: Music
description: The season's second concert in the series known as The Continuing AvantGarde, presented on Monday night by the Dorian Woodwind Quintet at Carnegie Recital Hall, held to a determinedly constricted view of contemporary music. Without exception, the five works on the program were immersed in theoretical complexities of the sort that schoolmen delight in but that do not necessarily add up to much musically.

title: Barzilauskas's Attitude Admired by Winner
description: The Jets, sorely in need of defensive help, like Carl Barzilauskas, their No. 1 draft choice, because he played all last season for Indiana with a broken foot. Barzilauskas likes the Jets because the National Football League has a good pension plan.

title: DELAY IS REQUESTED FOR OPTIONS TESTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The president of the Chicago Board Options Exchange asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to refuse to perlink other securities exchanges to trade in stock options until an integrated market system could be devised.

title: Senate, 5737, Recommits Energy Bill to Conferees
Metropolitan Briefs
description: At a ceremony in the Board of Estim'ate chamber yesterday, Mayor Beame swore in two top aides on labor matters: Theodore W. Kheel, lawyer and mediator, as special adviser on labor relations, and John T. Burnell, a labor union official, as director of the Office of Labor Relations. Mayor Beame said that Mr. Kheel, an old friend and great public servant, would help him with labor affairs for the magnificent salary of less than $1 a year. Mr. Burnell's salary will be $43,255 a year. Also sworn in at the same ceremony was Alfred Eisenpreis as Economic Development Administrator.

title: MARKET BLOC SEEN IN A STATE OF CRISIS
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 29  The fresh sense of crisis in Brussels about the future of the Common Marekt was heightened today as the Belgian caretaker, Foreign Minister Renaat van Elslande, called for a fundamental political debate among the nine on the problems facing the community.

title: Contract Awards
description: American Airlines, Inc., announced yesterday that it had sold two of its 747 aircraft to the Boeing Company, Seattle, Wash., at book value  about $18.5million each. At the same time, the airline reported that it had placed an order with Boeing for 14 Boeing 727200 at $7 to $8million each. The 747's will be delivered to Boeing in February while American Airlines will accept the first four of the 727's in 1975.

title: City's Jail Population Fell 20 Per Cent in Last Year
description: The city's jail and prison population has dropped sharply, and observers of the criminal justice system say some of the reasons are reductions in both the crime rate and drug addiction as well as new alternatives to pretrial detention and more efficient court administration.

title: Rebozo Said to Have Used Nixon Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29Senate Watergate committee investigators have developed information that Charles G. Rebozo, President Nixon's close friend, may have converted Presidential campaign money to his personal use, according to wellplaced committee officials.

title: Music: Excitement From Comissiona
Dr. Marvin J. Stern, Chemist Who Taught at Yeshiva, 38
description: PARAMUS, N. J., Jan. 29Dr. Marvin J. Stern, a chemistry professor and research scientist, died at his home here this afternoon at the age of 38.

title: Israeli General Rebuked for Faulting Superiors
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 29Israel's Attorney General has rebuked the military commander who led the Israeli breakthrough to the west bank of the Suez Canal in the October war. At issue were newspaper interviews in which the commander criticized his superiors.

title: Universal Gas Vessel Sale
description: The Universal Gas and Oil Company, Inc., announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell one of three liquified petroleum gas carrier vessels under construction in France to an unnamed international shipping company for $32.5million. The ship, scheduled for delivery in April of 1974 has a capacity of 52,500 cubic feet and is named Dovertown. It is being built by Construction Navales et Industrielles de la Mditerrane of La Seyne, France. such energyrelated issues as Halliburton, North American Coal, Hughes Tool and Williams Companies.

title: In East Germany, Church Organ Music Continues to Flourish
description: WEIMAR, East GermanyReligion is tolerated, definitely not encouraged, under Communism in East Germany, but musicians here and in the other cities where Johann Sebastian Bach lived and worked from 1685 to 1750 are maintaining a lively tradition of church music, through sometimes difficult conditions.

title: Stocks Drift Lower as Trading Slows
NORA HOLT DEAD; MUSIC CRITIC 89
description: Nora Holt music critic of The New York Amsterdam News for many years, died Friday in a nursing home in Los Angeles. She was 89 years old.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Herb Gardner, whose playwriting credits include A Thousand Clowns and The Goodbye People, has written a new play, Thieves, that will have its Broadway premiere at the Broadhurst Theater on March 21.

title: Two Mediators Appointed In Big Board Union Dispute
description: Paul Yeager, regional director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, appointed a panel of two mediators yesterday to assist the New York Stock Exchange and Local 205 of.the United Financial Employes in settling their contract dispute.

title: Fire Union Is Fined
description: A State Supreme Court justice fined the Uniformed Firefighters Association $650000 yesterday for its fiveandahalfhour strike last Nov. 6. Details on Page 40.

title: H E. BATES DIES; BRITISH NOVELIST
description: LONDON, Jan. 29  H. E, Bates, the author, whose best work was inspired by the English countryside, as in the Darling Buds of May, died today in a hospital at CanterburyKent., He was 68 years old.

title: CHRYSLER PLANNING 2 PLANT SHUTDOWNS
description: DETROIT, Jan. 24 (UPI)The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it would shut its two big car plants for oneweek and twoweek periods in February and March,. idling 19,540 workers temporarily to bring inventories in line with sagging sales.

title: Sadat's Oil Plea to Arabs Termed Result of Pledge
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Appeals by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt to other Arab leaders to lift the oil embargo against the United States were described today as fulfillment of a pledge he made to Secretary of State Kissinger.

title: Homosexual Students Club
description: CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 29 (AP) United States District Court Judge Hugh Bownes rejected today a motion by Gov. Meldrim Thomson that the Gay Students Organization at the state university be declared illegal.

title: Peak Payments Deficit Is Suffered by Japan
description: TOKYO, Jan. 29 (AP)Japan suffered a record annual balanceofpayments deficit totaling $10.07billion in 1973, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Changing Fundamentals
description: The energy crisis is forcing economists to rethink their most fundamental concepts, such as growth and interdependence.

title: Advertising: On Health Cereals
description: The hottest category in the breakfast cereal business these days is the natural or health cereal (a direct descendant of granola). In a little over a year it has become a $120million market.

title: Spassky Beats Byrne a 3d Time, Taking Him Out of the Title Play
Knicks Crush Celtics
FAULTY GYRO CUTS MARINER 10 FUEL
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jane 29 (UPI) A gyroscope on Mariner 10, speeding through Space toward Venus and Mercury acted erratically yesterday, wasting about 25 per cent of the spacecraft's control fuel

title: Unease in Israel as Skepticism Replaces Confidence
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 29The headlines that confronted the Israeli newspaper reader today could hardly have brought cheer to the breakfast table:

title: FUELOIL, SCARCITY IS BEING DOUBTED BY MANY DEALERS
description: While the Government warns that the nation still faces a critical heatingfuel situation, many dealers and distributors who provide fuel.oil to homes in the Northeast say their storage tanks are full and the threat of a shortage this winter has been all but eliminated.

title: CHINESE TO RELEASE U.S. AIDE TOMORROW
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI)  The State Department said today that it had officially been informed by China that Gerald Emil Kosh, the 27yearold American captured when Chinese forces took control of the Paracel Islands, was suffering from hepatitis and would, be released Thursday at the Hong Kong border.

title: Montclair Busing Split Growing Bitter
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Jan. 29 A 10year dispute over school busing in this community has grown more bitter in the last two years and, in the estimation of many residents, now threatens to intensify divisions between some blacks and some whites.

title: PRINCESS EMILY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The death on Saturday, of Princess Emily CitoFilomarino di Bitetto of Paris, widow of Prince Carlo of that Neapolitan princely family, was reported today by her cousin, Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island. She was 90 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: It is tempting to say of Gertrude Stein, as F. R. Leavis said of the Sitwells, that she belongs more to the history of publicity than to the history of literature. She certainly was more highly regarded as personality, an eccentricnot.to say freakthan as a writer, People who yawned over her books or avoided them altogether still sought her company. A great Many of these people were celebrities, and without the glamour they reflected on her, it is doubtful that she would have been known at all.

title: Mitchel Field Plan Announced by Caso Prior to a Ruling
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 29Plans for a 52acre industrial park. at Mitchel Field were announced today by Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso in the face of a Federal Court ruling that is expected shortly, on a suit seeking to halt development at the 574acre site tunless lowincome housing was included.

title: We Might Sue Again: A.B.A.'s Storen
Van Dillen Is Toppled; Martin Wins
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 29 (AP) Patrice Dominguez of France upset eighthseeded Erik Van Dillen of San Mateo, Calif., the American Davis Cup player, 6.3, 7.5, in the opening round of the $50,000 Fidelity tournament, a World Championship Tennis tour event.

title: WLIB Says Daylight Law Cuts Income
description: The yearround daylight saving time law Is costing radio station WLIB around $1,700 a week in lost revenues and is threatening the survival of the Harlembased station, according to Dorothy Brunson, its general manager.

title: PROF.E.H.KEUTMANN, ENDOCRINOLOGIST,77
description: ROCHESTER, Jan. 29  Dr. E. Henry Keutmann, emeritus professor of medicine and pharmacology at the University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry, died yesterday in Strong Memorial Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in nearby Brighton.

title: DYLAN VISIT BRINGS CALM TO COLISEUM
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 29Bob Dylan's second metropolitanarea concert started just like the first one tonighta pleasant mature crowd sitting and listening to the words and the music.

title: DraftEvasion Cases Dismissed by Court; Rights Error Cited
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 29  Two Federal District Court judges ruled here today that 153 men accused in 1972 of draft evesion by the Government were deprived of their constitutional protection against false accusation.

title: Senate, 5737, Recommits Energy Bill to Conferees
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The Senate sent the energy emergency. bill back to a HouseSenate conference today, raising doubts that Congress will give the Nixon Adrninistration rationing authority in time for the expected tightening of gasoline supplies this spring.

title: C.I.A. Destruction of Tapes Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 29 (AP) William E. Colby, director of Central Intelligence, said tonight that the C.I.A. could find only one tape recording bearing on the Watergate affair and that it had destroyed all its other tapes from that period.

title: Notre Dame Vanquishes Marquette
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind. Jan. 29 (AP) John Shumate scored 27 points and Bill Paterno got 14 tonight, leading thirdranked Notre Dame to a 69.63 victory over No. 5 Marquette.

title: Hard Times for the Mushroom: Costly Recalls Are Latest Blow
description: The lowly mushroom was doing all right a year ago with production and sales growing and the price going up,.But then came a series of recalls after botulinus bacteria were discovered in one batch, and the world of the American mushroom eater has not been the same since.

title: JUDGE WILL ORDER NIXON TO TESTIFY AT EXAIDES'
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29A state judge said today that he would order President Nixon to testify in person at the trial of John D. Ehrlichman and two other former White House aides, now under indictment here for the 1971 breakin at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: HOGAN SUCCESSOR MAY BE DEMOCRAT
description: Vincent F. Albano, the Republican leader in Manhattan, said, yesterday that Governot Wilson Would appoint a Democrat as interim district attorney to succeed the ailing Frank S. Hogan, who officially retires next Wednesday.

title: Sauce for the Gander
description: PARISWhatever happens at President Nixon's conference of petroleum consumers next month, the kind of united front both he and Secretary Kissinger have been proposing to our allies has seemingly vanished long before the opening session.

title: SHULTZ SURVEYS SECURITIES FIELD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz gave his personal answers today to three of the most controversial questions confronting the securities markets and their regulators. They were:

title: CORRECTION SLATE UNDER CHALLENGE
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29The eligibility of four of Governor Wilson's reappointments to the Commission of Correction came under challenge today as the Senate Finance Committee questioned the ability of the commission to fulfill its new role as a prison ombudsman.

title: Dr. Lukash Cites Injection As Fatal, Then Backs Off
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan, 29Dr. Leslie Lukash, the Nassau County Medical Examiner, testified today that Etigene Bauer had died as a result of an injection of potassium chloride, among other physical reasons, but later conceded that there was no scientific basis for his conclusion.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Under a low ceiling in the dusty basement of the old Madison Square Garden seven years ago,.Muhammad Ali, training to defend his world Heavyweight title against Zora Folley, interrupted his shadow boxing and looked down from the ring.

title: PRESIDENT TO ASK NEW AID FOR POOR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29President Nixon in his State of the Union Message tomorrow will propose what is described as a big, new incomemaintenance program a of negative income tax for the poor.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (UPI)National Hockey League governors failed today to complete a vote on whether to go through with a proposed settlement of litigation with the World Hockey Association. Clarence Campbell, president of the N.H.L., said the league would complete the vote tomorrow.

title: Fight Rouses Frankfurt In First Flush of Victory
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Jan. 29 (AP)The Muhammad AliJoe Frazier fight last night put a strain on Frankfurt's telephone and water services.

title: Brezhnev in Havana
description: The cordial greeting cabled to President Nixon by Leonid Brezhnev, flying close to the shores of the United States on his way to Cuba, symbolizesif taken at face valuethe improvement in SovietAmerican relations of recent years.

title: Alumni of Film School Now Star as Directors
description: For a while film schools seemed to have a stigma, said Martin Scorsese, director of the brutal hit Mean Streets. Citing some critical carping, he added wryly, A few reviewers would write, His work is full of student pretensions. But there are too many of us now. Actually, film school is a microcosm of the industry.

title: Whitey Ford Named at Mackell Trial
description: Whitey Ford, the forme Yankee pitcher who was admit ted to the Baseball Hall of Fame early this month, was identi fled yesterday by Joseph Ferdnando, a convicted swindler, as an investor in his multimilliondollar getrichquick scheme.

title: ZIMMERMAN MAKES PIANO RECITAL DEBUT
description: As those who go to the New York City Ballet know, Jerry Zimmerman is the company's piano soloistthe one with the spectacular halo of blond hair, Monday night he moved from the New York State Theater to Alice Tully Hall to make his debut here as a recitalist. Scanning the audience, one felt as if most of the ballet company had moved with him to cheer nim on.

title: CARL BILLMAN DIES; LED PHI BETA KAPPA
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Carl Billman, national secretary, of Phi Beta Kappa, the collegiate honor society, until his retirement Jan. 1 after 26 years as chief operating officer, died of a stroke Saturday in the Winchester (Mass) Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.,

title: Dean of G.O.P. Delegation To Retire From House
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Citing frustration stemming from his disappointment with the Nixon Administration as major factor, Representative Howard W. Robison, dean of New York State's Republican Congressional delegation, announced today that he would retire at the end of the session.

title: Nixon Appoints Silbert
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI) President Nixon named today Earl J. Silbert, a Justice Department official who directed the early stages of the Watergate investigation, as United States Attorney for the District of Columbia. Mr. Silbert, 37 years old, succeeds Harold H. Titus Jr.

title: Risks of Missile Tests in the Pacific Northwest
description: WASHINGTONThe Air Force has long wanted to testlaunch Minuteman intercontinental ballistic missiles from operational silos. Under its plan the missiles would be fired from Malmstrom Air Force Base in Montana, pass some 350 miles above parts of five states in the Pacific Northwest, and land 5,000 miles away at Canton Island, southwest of Hawali.

title: Stop Me if You've Heard This
description: PARIS, Jan. 29Today we give you the early nineteen forties before the New Look, ancient Greece, Marjorie Morningstar Goes to Grossinger's and other irrele vancies. This trip in the time machine in search of elegance is courtesy of the Paris couture, whose spring showings on the second day proved far less auspicious than on the first day.

title: Fire Union Is Fined
description: A State Supreme Court justice fined the Uniformed Firefighters Association $650000 yesterday for its fiveandahalfhour strike last Nov. 6. Details on Page 40.

title: Wilkie Wins Swim; Sets Games Record
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Wednesday, Jan. 30 (UPI)David Wilkie, a student at the UnNersity of Miami, won Scotland's first gold medal of the Commonwealth Games today in the 200meter individual medley swimming.

title: Tennessee State Dominates N.F.L. Draft With 5 Picked
description: The first round of the National Football League draft went smartly if slowly yesterday with an indifference of the establishment toward the challenge of the new World Football League, a challenge still to be defined. The first roundlike mining diamonds at Tiffany's, according to one scoutbegan with the predictable choice of Ed (Too Tall) Jones of Tennessee State by the Dallas Cowboys, owners of the No. 1 pick, which originally belonged to Houston.

title: Phillips and Sun Oil Cite Sharp Increases in Profit
description: Two more of the major oil companies announced yesterday sharply higher earnings for the fourth quarter 1973.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ONTARIO, Calif., Jan. 29 (AP)Mario Andretti was injured today when his Indianapolis racing car spun 185 miles an hour and hit the wall during tire tests Ontario Motor Speedway. The 33yearold ace was momentarily unconscious, but was reported conscious and alert at nearby San Antonio Community Hospital. He Was said to have suffered a slight concussion and whiplash.

title: President Returns From Camp David; Worked on Address
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (UPI)  President Nixon returned to the White House tonight from Camp David, where he spent a long weekend preparing for his State of the Union message to Congress and the nation tomorrow night.

title: Security for Pensions
description: The disgraceful jurisdictional squabble between two House committees that blocked final action on pension reform last year has apparently been broken. The welcomebut still by no means certainresult is an improved prospect for enactment of legislation to reinforce the private pension plans on which thirty million workers rely for an important part of oldage security.

title: Market Place: Is It Now Time To Buy Stock?
description: The inveterate stockmarket optimist is probably wondering whether the time has, come at last to begin giving serious consideration to an aggressive stockpurchase program.

title: WHEAT FUTURES SHOW A DECLINE
description: March wheat future prices swung widely yesterday before the contract closed at $5.85$5.86 a bushel, down from $5.951 on Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade. During the session it managed to set a record high of $6 after opening at $5.80.

title: New Phoenix Extends Run
description: The New Phoenix Repertory Company, which is presenting The Visit, Chemin de Fer and Holiday at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, has anflounced the second and what it says will be the final extension of its New York engageorient. The troupe will now close on Feb. 16, instead of Saturday.

title: Handicapped Girl, 7, Injured In L. I. School Bus Crash
description: OLD WESTBURY, LI., Jan. 29A 7yearold handicapped girl was critically injured today in a crash of the school bus in which she was riding and a small automobile at the intersection of Red Ground Road and Old Westbury Road, the Nassau County police said.

title: PRESIDENT TO ASK NEW AID FOR POOR
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29President Nixen in his State of the Union Message tomorrow will propose what is de scribed as a big, new incomemaintenance program; a form of negative income tax for the poor.

title: Texaco and Cities Service Plan Higher Outlays for Expansion
description: Increased expenditures for exploration and refinery, expansion were announced yesterday Iby two major oil companies.

title: U.S STEEL RAISES QUARTER NET 91%
description: The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday 91.1 per cent increase in net income for the fourth quarter of 1973, and a gain of 107.5 per cent for the 12 months of 1973. However, the nation's largest steel producer still said that the return on sales was modest in comparison with other years.

title: The Coney Island Ruling
description: In ordering the housing authorities to play a major role in the integration of Mark Twain Junior High School, Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein has put the spotlight on the basic underlying cause of the increase in urban school segregation. Regrettably, the ruling followed up its perceptive diagnosis with the imposition of unrealistic remedies in the effort to balance the Coney Island school's racial composition.

title: U.S. Steel Net Up 91%
description: The United States Steel Corporation reported its net income for the fourth quarter of 1973 rose by 91.1 per cent to $104.4million from $54.7million a year earlier. Profits for the full year were up 107.5 per cent, to $325.8million from $157million in 1972. Details on Page 43.

title: FAULTY GIRO CUTS MARINER 10 FUEL
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 29 (UPI)A gyroscope on Mariner 10, speeding through space toward Venus and Mercury acted erratically yesterday wasting about 25 per cent at the spacecraft's control fuel.

title: International Paper Plant
description: The International Paper Company announced yesterday that it would build a $5.5million lumber and sawmill product plant at Georgetown, S. C. Construction is scheduled for completion in 14 months.

title: French Are Relieved As Odd Dispute Ends
description: PARIS, Jan. 29One of the longest and strangest labor disputes in the history of France ended today with a partial and dearly bought ,victory for the workers and a sigh of relief from a watching nation.

title: Burial of General Grivas Set For Today at Cyprus Hideout
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 29 (UPI)Followers of the late Gen. George Grivas became embroiled in a dispute today over where he would be buried.

title: Rozelle Fines Grant FortheBirds Remarks
description: Remember the sparrows? Yes, the sparrows in the Minnesota Vikings locker room in Houston at the Super Bowl. The ones that got Coach Bud Grant rather upset when he saw what the Vikings dressing room facilities looked like.

title: Montclair's Busing Split Growing Bitter And May Intensify WhiteBlack Division
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Jan. 29 A 10year dispute over school busing in this community has grown more bitter in the last two years and in the estimation of many residents now threatens to intensify divisions between some blacks and some whites.

title: U. S. TERMINATES CURB ON LENDING DOLLARS ABROAD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 The Government ended today its array of controls over the outflow of dollars for lending and ,investing abroad. Some of the controls were More than a decade, old.

title: Europeans Ruled Owners of Steelmaking Patent
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 29 (AP) A Federal judge ruled today that a European steel concern owns the patent to the basic oxygen furnace steelmaking process that is used to produce the bulk of American steel.

title: Nixon Faces G.O.P. Move For Data in House Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 The ranking Republican on the House Judiciary Committee said today that President Nixon could not use executive ?? to withhold information from the impeachment inquiry.

title: City Found to Reward Inefficiency in Hospitals
JOHN F. MASON JR.
description: John F. Mason Jr., who had held various posts with the International Nickel Company for 35 years at his retirement in 1962 as chemical group manalter in the New York office died on Sunday at his home in Raleigh, N. C. He was 62 years old.

title: NixonWill Disclose Plan for Subsidy Of Mass Transit
description: A senior official of the Nixon Administration said yesterday that President Nixon would disclose a new Federal transit aid program tonight that, for the first time, would help cities such as New York defray daytoday losses of their subway and bus lines.

title: Bolivian Peasant Uprising Brings Crisis Measures
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 29 (UPI)  Bolivia's President de. dared a state of emergency last night as thousands of peasants blockaded roads in the central provinces in protest against huge increases in the cost of living.

title: Army Hires a Head Coach Who Leans to Wishbone
description: Homer Smith, a 42yearold believer in option football and the wishbone attack in particular, became Army's 27th head football coach yesterday. The former Princeton fullback and linebacker succeeds Tom Cahill, who was dismissed Dec. 13, just 12 days after the Cadets capped a nonwinning season with a 510 loss to Navy.

title: Congress Asleep
description: The Nixon Administration has conspicuously failed its responsibility to tell the truth to the public about the military spying on civilian officials in 197172. Secretary of State Kissinger plays down his own role in this murky affair. Secretary of defense Schlesinger deprecates its importance. The White House refuses to comment.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LOOKBACK Art Deco is the sort of modernistic art that flourished during the nineteenthirtiessleek, geometric lines, luxurious curves, lb short the late liner Normandie and the very rhuch alive Radio City Music Hall.

title: The World Energy Conference
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29In midFebruary, most of the leading oilprodueing and oilconsuming countries will hold a conference here to see what can be done about the supply, price and distribution of fuel in the short run, and the development of nuclear energy for civilian purposes in the long run.

title: 2 Die, 4 Rescued at Sea As Schooner Hits Shoals
Parliament Dissolved by Belgian King
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 29King Baudouin dissolved the Belgian Parliament tonight after efforts to form a new coalition Cabinet had failed. As a result, new elections are mandatory within 40 days, and March 10 was mentioned as a likely date.

title: KUWAIT SIGNS PACT WITH GULF AND B.P.
description: KUWAIT, Jan. 29 (AP)An oil participation agreement was signed today giving Kuwait a 60 per cent controlling interest in operations of the Gulf Oil Corporation and the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., in this Persian Gulf sheikdom, semiofficial sources reported.

title: Dillon Anderson, Lawyer, Dead; Special Assistant to Eisenhower
description: HOUSTON Jan 29  Dillon Anderson, a special assistant to President Dwight D. Eisenhower for national security alfairs in 195556, died yesterday. He was 67 years old and had practiced law here since 10.39.

title: People and Business
description: In preparation for the retirement in the middle of the year of Edward R. Rowley, its 64yearold chairman and chief executive officer, N. L. Industries, Inc., named a new president and created the post of vice chairman.

title: The Hub of New York
description: The time: 6:45 P.M. The place: bus stop near the southwest corner of Seventh Avenue and 42d Street. Outside several sexploitation movie houses, clusters of street people, drinking and arguing raucously, send an occasional empty bottle crashing in the path of office workers on their way home. Passersby give the groups a cautiously wide berth. The absence of any uniformed police, which in itself encourages such potentially dangerous loitering, adds to public uneasiness.

title: FUELOIL SCARCITY IS BEING DOUBTED BY MANY DEALERS
Kissinger's Trips Reported to Delay Arms Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The talks between Moscow and Washington on the limitation of strategic arms, which the Nixon Administration hoped would be resumed on Jan. 31, are now scheduled to resume early in February, according to an official source.

title: U.S. DEMANDS DATA ON GASOLINE HERE
description: Gerald J. Turetsky, regional administrator of the Federal Office here, has ordered the major oil companies that supply gasoline to New York and New Jersey to submit records of their volume sales and their station closings to determine if the New York area is being shortchanged on gasoline allocations.

title: Africa, With 800 Tongues of Its Own, Labors to Master Others
description: DOUALA, Cameroon Holding a cardboard figure of a man against a black cloth stretched across one classroom wall, Sam Koff, an English teacher, asked, Who is this man? And 45 pupils told him in unison, That is Mr. Jones.

title: Saudi Says a Rise in Oil Output May Follow Peace in Mideast
description: TOKYO, Jan. 29 (AP) Saudi Arabia's Minister of Petroleum Affairs told Japanese oil company officials today that his country hoped to increase the production of petroleum after peace returns to the Middle East.

title: Gentle Slopes, Modest Fees for Ski Tyros
description: NEWFOUNDLAND, N. J., Tan. 29  There are no towsting mountains at the Craigmeur Ski Area, no fancy ??as in skyblue tights, no ?? vivants drinking brany by an open fire. At Craigseur they ski in corduroy pants and longjohns, they slide and fall and, in most eases, drink hot chocolate and use rented equipment.

title: Court on Malpractice Suits Advances in State Senate
Ocean Mining Project Is Led by Kennecott
description: An international consortium of major metals producers led by the Kennecott Copper Corporation announced yesterday a fiveyear research and development program to determine the feasibility of mining manganese nodules from the deep sea.

title: Landlords Deny Windfall Over Vacancy Decontrol
Briefs on Energy
description: STOCKHOLM, Jan. 29 (UPI)The Swedish Government said today that gasoline and oil rationing would be lifted tomorrow. Original plans called for the rationing last until the end of February. The Government's energy board said it had consulted the major oil companies and found that Sweden's present supplies of oil and gasoline were sufficient. While Norway and Denmark are using'. weekend driving ban to protect their dwindling ,gasoline supplies, the Swedish Government began. rationing Jan, giving drivers 26 gallons for a 52day period.

title: BAR UNIT SHIFTED IN KUNSTLER CASE
description: The city bar association's grievance committee apparently disregarded its own longstanding policy when it decided last week to initiate disciplinary action against William M. Kunstler, the outspoken defender of radical causes who is now appealing contemptofcourt conviction stemming from his conduct during the tumultuous Chicago Seven trial four years ago.

title: Wilson Acting to Avert Auto Insurance Windfall
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29Governor Wilson said today that he would submit to the Legislature a proposal requiring that automobile insurance coin, panies pass on to their policyholders any savings brought about by the energy shortage.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: State Department Advises Americans To Leave Grenada
description: ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, Jan. 29 (AP)The United States Government has advised Americans in Grenada to leave the Caribbean island because of increasing political and economic tensions there.

title: 4th Day of Fighting InGolan Is Reported By Israel and Syria
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 29 (Reuters) A clash between Israeli and Syrian troops was reported today on the northern front for the fourth consecutive day.

title: TIMES BUREAU CHIEF IS FREED BY SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Jan. 30James M. Markham, Saigon bureau chief of The New York Times, was released , last night after 39 hours in the custody of the Government police, who had arrested him for making a oneweek visit to a Vietcongheld area.

title: Benjamin Steinberg Dies at 58; Began Symphony of New World
description: Benjamin Steinberg, founder Of the Symphony of the New World, died yesterday at his home, 520 East 90th Street. He was 58 years old.

title: Joyous Throngs in Suez Hail Reunion With Egypt
Ray's Guilty Plea In Dr. King's Death Will Be Reviewed
description: CINCINNATI, Jan. 29 (AP)James Earl Ray was given a chance today to contest his guilty plea in the murder of Dr Martin Luther King Jr. because of allegations that his attorneys had compromised his interests to enrich themselves.

title: Multinational Oil Concerns Said to Peril Independents
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Some Senators and witnesses contended at a Congressional hearing today that large international petroleum corporations were taking over smaller independent oil companies or squeezing them out of business.

title: Both Sides Urge shift of Houston Trial
description: HOUSTON, Jan, 29  Both sides in the proceeding against the first defendant in this city's largest mass murder case agreed today that he could not get a fair trial in this area of Texas because of wide publicity about the 27 killings.

title: Nixon Faces G.O.P. Move For Data in House Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29The ranking Republican on the House Judiciary Committee said today that President Nixon could not use executive, privilege to withhold information from the impeachment tnquiry.

title: JURY CITES A MAYOR IN THREAT TO WOMAN
description: MORRISTOWN, Jan. 29 A Morris County grand jury has indicted Mayor Ralph Atkinson of Jefferson Township on a charge of threatening to kill a township woman.

title: Railway Act Is Target Of Penn Central Suit
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (AP)The Penn Central Company said today it was challenging the constitutionality of certain provisions of a Federal law intended to aid financially ailing railroads.

title: Handicapped Girl, 7, Injured In L.I. School Bus Crash
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I, Jan. 29A 7yearold handicapped girl was critically injured today in a crash of the school bus in which she was riding and a small automobile at the intersection of Red Ground Road and Old Westbury Road, the Nassau County police said.

title: Washington's Men of Influence Join in Prayer Groups
description: WASHINGTON  Every other Tuesday at 6:30 A.M., before concentrating on matters of war and peace, dozen admirals and generals assemble in the Secretary of the Army's private dining room at the Pentagon for coffee, doughnuts and 90 minutes of Bible study.

title: NADJARI USES SPY IN COURT INQUIRY
description: The law secretary of a State Supreme Court justice has been secretly recording incriminating conversations with Brooklyn political figures and lawyers as an undercover agent for the state's special anticorruption prosecutor, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Byrne Seeks a Fair Share of Gasoline
description: TRENTON, Jan. 30 Pledging to fight for fair and equitable distribution of gasoline supplies in New Jersey, Governor Byrne today announced that he would meet with more than a dozen petroleum industry, officials Monday to make a case to bring to Washington within three weeks.

title: Proposal to Aid Truckgrs. Is Offiredb White House
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Nixon Administration offered truck operators today the prospect of relief from fuel shortages and rising costs in an effort to head off nationwide work stoppages by independent ownerdrivers, sched uled to start at midnight tomorrow.

title: Dr. A. David Gurewitsch Dies; PhysicalRehabilitation Teacher
description: Dr. A. David Gurewitsch, a specialist in rehabilitation medicine who taught at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center and who was both physician and close friend to Mrs. Franklin Roosevelt, died yesterday of cancer, He was 71 years old.

title: U.S. to Reduce Okinawa Bases; Troop Strength on Isle Is Down
description: TOKYO, Jan 30American and Japanese officials disclosed today that the United States would reduce or relocate some of its bases on Okinawa, the island fortress in the East China Sea that the American military calls the keystone of the Pacific.

title: G.M. Announces Layoffs Of 1,150 at Rochester Unit
description: ROCHESTER, Jan. 30 (AP)The General Motors Corporation has announced that 1,150 employes at its Rochester Products Division will be laid off at the end of their shifts Friday.

title: L.I. Murder Trial Witness Backs State
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 30The first witness for the defense in the murder trial of Dr Vincent A Montemarano testified unexpectedly today that he attributed the death of Eugene Bauer, a terminal cancer patient, to an injection of potas. sium chloride. The state has charged that Mr. Bauer was killed this way.

title: Chess An EndGame Error Gave Spassky the Key to Victory
Cambodian Rebels Said to Withdraw Guns Near Capital
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia. Jan. 30 (Agence FrancePresse) Insurgent forces have reportedly withdrawn their artillery out of range of Phnom Penh, and the capital today went through its third day without being hit by shells.

title: Saint Laurent Goes His Own Way
description: PARIS, Jan. 30Norman Norell said designing was easy. All you bad to do was see what other people were doing and then do something else.

title: 3 Viewed as Nevada Senate Candidates
description: CARSON CITY, Nev.A vacant United States Senate seat, that most rare of political opportunities, will be filled by Nevada voters this year, and talk of potential candidates is dominated by three former Governors of the state.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The threatened closing of the Rheingold Brewery Orange, N. J., could result in the liquidation of a statewide pension fund that could strip several hundred eligible workers of their retirement benefits, according to New Jersey Teamster officials. The union officials said that liquidation of the fund, the New Jersey Brewery Employes Pension Plan, also could deprive some 1,500 men now receiving pensions of related welfare benefits such as life and hospitalization insurance. Workers at Rheingold's plant Brooklyn, also threatened with a shutdown, apparently will not have any pension problems. A spokesman for the teamsters locals said the New York City brewery workers pension fund had assets to cover all those eligible for retirement.

title: Coast Stakes Won By Special Team
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 30 (UPI)  Fred W. Hooper's Special Team pulled away in the stretch under Bill Shoemaker today to capture the $35,450 Pasadena Stakes at Santa Anita.

title: SUPPLIERS PLEDGE CHEAPER FUEL OIL TO THE CITY AREA
description: Major oil companies have agreed to provide tens of millions of gallons more of domestic homeheating oil for independent dealers in the New YorkNew Jersey area to bring down costs for consumers hit by sharply rising uncontrolled costs of imported oil.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: An Alfred University Coed Is Found Dead in Woods
description: ALFRED, N.Y., Jan. 30 (AP) An Alfred University coed was found dead yesterday in a wooded area on the edge of the campus.

title: Briefs on Energy
description: LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP)Norway lifted all oilsaving restrictions today, and Denmark resumed normal fuel supplies to public transportation in the latest indications that the oil crisis is easing in Europe. The Dutch and the Swedes have ended hastily imposed gasoline rationing. Belgium and Switzerland have lifted Sunday driving bans. And Norway now has joined Britain in shelving rationing plans. But the cost of gasoline has gone up as much as 30 per cent at the pumps in Europe, and larger increases are predicted.

title: 4 Ethnic Germans Arrested by Soviet In Fight at Embassy
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 30 (AP)Four Soviet citizens of German extraction seeking to emigrate to West Germany were arrested today after a fistfight with policemen in front of the West German Embassy.

title: Irvington Slaying Suspect T racked by Photo Machine
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 30An 18yearold youth from Tarrytown was charged today with the knife slaying on Jan. 17 of an Irvington housewife, after having been tracked down with the aid of a photographic montage composed on the only machine of its kind In the United States.

title: Colts Draft Tim Berra
description: Tim Berra, son of the New York Met manager, Yogi Berra, was selected in the 17th and final round in the National Football League draft yesterday by the Baltimore Colts. Berra, a wide receiver at Massachusetts, was the 421st player picked of 442.

title: Inflation Breathes New Life Into Japan's Pawnshops
description: TOKYO, Jan. 30  Japan's traditional pawnshops, which appeared headed for extinction because of two decades of spectacular economic growth, are suddenly back in business, thanks to inflation.

title: Battrick Signs Up
description: The Pittsburgh Triangles of the World Team Tennis League announced the signing today of Gerald Battrick, thirdranking player in Bri

title: Quirk in Military Pay Setup Costs U.S. $200Million
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30A peculiarity in the military pay system is costing the Govern, went more than $200million a year, but neither the execu tive branch nor Congress seems particularly eager to correct the situation.

title: NO SHORTFALL IN OIL SEEN FOR FIRST HALF
description: The Conference Board, a nonprofit research organization, said yesterday that it appears, likely that the first half of this year will see no oil shortfall at all on a nationwide basis, although various regions of the country will have specific proble

title: 73 Pledges: Victories and Some Defeats
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 30Only a year ago, President Nixon, beginning his second term after an overwhelming reelection victory, sent a series of written messages to Congress to describe his vision of the State of the Union.

title: A WomanWho's Learned to Cook Her Way Out of Tight Spots
Bethlehem Steel Quarter Net Is Steady
People and Business
description: President Nixon announced yesterday that he would nominate Irving M. Pollack as a member of the Securities and Exchange CommiSsion. As expected, Mr. Pollack, the 55yearold director of the commission's enforcement division, will fill the $38,000ayear seat vacated last November by Hugh F. Owens for the remainder of a fiveyear term expiring on June 5, 1975.

title: 2d Briton Indicted in Killing
description: LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP)An unemployed Londoner was indicted today on charges of having murdered James PopeHennessy, the royal biographer. He was the second man arraigned in the Jan. 25 murder.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: Officials of the. International Brotherhood of Teamsters Local 877, which represents nearly 1,000 employes at Exxon Corporation's. Bayway refinery in Linden, charged management with refusal to reopen contract negotiations despite the fact that oil companies are choking with embarrassment over their corporate profits.

title: Witness in HitRun Trial Describes Erratic Car
description: MORRISTOWN, Jan. 30  A former Madison auotomobile mechanic testified today that he had seen a red Toyota moving erractically less than half an hour before a red Toyota driven by John Ellmers hit and killed two young girls and injured a third near the campus of Drew Uiiversity.

title: Slate of Socialist Workers For State Election Listed
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30The Socialist Workers party today announced its slate of candidates for statewide election this year, led by Derrick Morrison, a 27yearold writer for the party newspaper.

title: Petrochemical and Tire Prices Are Freed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) The Cost of Living Council lifted most price controls today from petrochemical feed stocksraw materials used mainly in the plastics, fiber and rubber industries.

title: Food Prices Here Continue Rise
description: Food prices in New York City continued an eightweek climb during the week ended last Friday, according to the Department of Consumer Affairs weekly Market Basket survey.

title: Personal Finance
description: The United States Court of Appeals in Richmond, in a decision expected to affect hundreds of thousands of divorce settlements, has ruled thata lumpsum payment made by a man to his former wife when she remarries is not considered alimony, and, therefore, not taxdeductible.

title: U.N. Reports on Sexist Attitudes Around the World
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 30What is the image of today's woman in Canada, the Netherlands, Finland or Mexico?

title: N.C. State 8680 Victor Over Maryland
Beame Asks F.C.C. to Allow WNYC to Sign On at 6 A.M.
description: Mayor Beame requested the Federal Communications Commission to allow the municipal radio station, WNYC, to go on the air at 6 A.M., as it had before daylight saving time, so that it may resume its earlymorning service of continuous information on weather, traffic and commuter conditions.

title: A Transcript of the State of the Union Address to Congress by President Nixon
Nastase Is Easy Victor Oyer DuPre
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 30 (AP) Topseeded lie Nastase of Rumania defeated Pat DuPre of Palo Alto, Calif., 60, 61, tonight in the first round of the $50,000 World Championship Tennis tour stop here.

title: JIM WALTER SETS $24MILLION DEAL
Assembly's Debate to Be Shown Over State Public TV Network
description: TRENTON, Jan. 30  New Jersey's state legislative proceedings will be opened to the state's public television network tomorrow, beginning with the debate on rules changes scheduled for 2 P.M. in the General Assembly.

title: ARAB UNITY PLANS OPPOSED IN LIBYA
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 30Several members of Libya's governing Revolutionary Command Council have reportedly urged Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the head of the council, to discontinue for the time being all efforts to bring Libya into a union with other Arab states.

title: White House Offers a Plan To Ease Trucker Problems
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  The Nixon Administration offered truck operators today the prospect of relief from fuel shortages and rising costs in of effort to head off nationwide work stoppages by independent ownerdrivers, scheduled to start at midnight tomorrow.

title: Mets Sign 11 as Pay Arbitration Starts
description: With the final stumbling block out of the way, baseball's salary arbitration season opens tomorrow, but Bob Scheffing doesn't think any of the Mets will play the game.

title: Connecticut Says It Has U.S. Pledge of More Gasoline
description: The Federal Government has assured Connecticut that it will receive more than 80 million gallons of gasoline formerly sold in the state by three concerns that have curtailed or canceled service, Eckardt C. Beck, the state energy chief, reported yesterday.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Commission on human Rights, working group on procedure for dealing With violations of human rights3 P.M.

title: Highlights of Message
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Following are highlights of President Nixon's State of the Union Message:

title: Copter Aids Injured Seaman
description: BOSTON, Jan. 3A (AP)  An injured Russian seaman or board a refrigerator trawler 18 miles southeast of Nahant Beach was flown today by Coast Guard helicopter to Logan i.irport and then transported by ambulance to Brighton Public Health Hospital, the Coast Guard said. He apparently had a broken hip.

title: President to Refuse to Testify at Ehrlichman Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The White House said today that Peesident Nixon would refuse Ito testify personally in the Calk fornia trial of John D. Ehrlichman but left open the possi[bility that he would respond to written interrogatories about his role in setting up the special Investigations unit known as the plumbers.

title: MRS. MEIR BEGINS FORMING CABINET
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 30 (Reuters)A month after the Israeli election, Premier Golda Meir today formally accepted President Ephraim Katzir's request to form a new cabinet.

title: 10POINT PROPOSAL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30President Nixon proposed to Congress tonight a 10point program for this year that he said would lessen the energy crisis, check inflation, make new progress toward world peace and institute reforms in such domestic programs as health, welfare and transportation.

title: Wilkie Scores a Double in Swimming
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Jan. 30 (AP)  David Wilkie, a Scotsman studying at the University of Miami, scored a swimming double at the Commonwealth Games today and the Canadians surprised a confident Indian contingent by capturing five gold medals in wrestling.

title: And Up on the Garden Stage, It All Came Together
description: You could sense it even before the concert began. The audience was expectant, even exultant. And when Bob Dylan and the Band trotted onstage last night at Madison Square Garden for their first Manhattan concert, they were clearly exultant, too.

title: 2 ASTHMA SPRAYS RECALLED BY F.D. A A.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration announced today the recall of two defective aerosol asthma sprays that it said could pose a potentially serious health hazard to users.

title: Jury Acquits Carpi in Murder of Wife
description: TRENTON, Jan. 30Colin C. Carpi was acquitted today of charges he murdered his wife in 1971.

title: DeBusschere Will Get Night Here March 26
description: The Knicks will honor Dave DeBusschere, their retiring allstar forward, with a night on March 26 when they meet the Philadelphia 76ers at MadisOn Square Garden. It will be New York's final National Basketball Association regularseason game. Robert Tisch, president of Loew's Inc., will be chairman of the event.

title: Hughes Indictment Dismissed in Reno
description: RENO, Jan. 30A criminal indictment charging Howard R. Hughes and four codefendants with stock manipulation, conspiracy and wire fraud was dismissed here today.

title: Screvane Is OddsOn to Direct OTB, Though Samuels Will Linger on Board
description: Former City Council President Paul R. Screvane has agreed to head the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation, despite his irritation over the fact that the current president, Howard J. Samuels, is insisting on retaining a seat on the OTB board.

title: Stage: Edna O'Brien's Pagan Place
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Dog Trainer Is No Fair Weather Friend
description: When kennel clubs in the Maryland area want to know what the weather forecast will be for their shows, they call Kenneth M. Nagler, a member of the Rock Creek Kennel Club and the Hyattsville Training Club. A Dabnatian Dogs fancier, Nagler Is also Chief of Space Operations Support Division, National Weather Service.
