He has headed the meteorological team that has worked on the Mercury, Gemini, Apollo and Skylab missions for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Three Signed by W.F.L. Are Drafted by N.F.L.
description: The National Football League's twoday draft of. college talent was completed yesterday with the last 312, of the total of 442 players, selected on the final 12 rounds by the 26 teams. Of significance was the drafting of three prominent players, Jim McAlister, Kermit Johnson and Booker Brown, who had been signed on Monday by the Southern California team of the new World Football League.

title: Nixon Asks 50% Rise for Mass Transit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Spurred by the fuel shortage, President Nixon proposed in his State of the Union address tonight an increase of nearly 50 per cent in Federal assistance to urban mass transit.

title: A.B.A. Renews War
description: NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 30 Less than four hours before its AllStar game tonight, the American Basketball Association said it had filed a $300 million antitrust suit against the rival National Basketball Association.

title: For Dylan, the Dollars Are a Changin for the Better
description: The show Boy Dylan and the Band put on at Madison Square Garden is the midpoint climax of what should wind up as one of the most profitable rock n roll tours ever produced.

title: Rangers Top Penguins, 42, After Losing 20 Advantage
Jersey Investment Analyst Cleared in Slaying of Wife
description: TRENTON, Jan, 30Colin C. Carpi was acquitted today of charges he murdered his wife in 1971.

title: Judge Grants Shift Of Murders Case Outside of Houston
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 30  Judge William M. Hatten granted A change of Venue today in the trial of the first defendant in this city's mass murder case.

title: Socal's Net Up 94% for Quarter
Bridge:Unknown Italians Win Prestigious London Tourney
description: Nobody raises an eyebrow when the Old Guard of Italian bridge wins yet another title, but a victory by unknown Italians in an international event is a distinct surprise. G. Facchine and S. Zuchelli, both from Turin, won the prestigious Sunday Times invitational pair contest in London last weekend, heading a distinguished field of 20 pairs.

title: Matket Place: Ups and Downs Of Perot Wealth
description: Back In 1970, the stock market began responding to conflicting currents. Lots of stocks had already begun their declines in what was to become the worst bear market in modern market history.

title: Theater: Where the Children Join In
description: Two popular, firmly established New York children's theatersthe Meri Mini Players and the City Center Young People's Theaterencourage children to be actors as well as audience.

title: 507th Golden Gate Suicide
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 (UPI)  An unidentifed young man plunged to his death from the Golden Gate Bridge yesterday. The California Highway patrol listed it as the 507th known suicide from the bridge.

title: Correction Chief Scores Legislature on Prisons
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30The acting chairman of the State Commission of Correction complained to a Senate committee today that the Legislature had created three fulltime commissions to regulate horse racing but wanted his commission to monitor conditions at 400 prisons in the state on a parttime basis.

title: Grenadian Woman Describes Escape During Disorders
description: A Grenadian teacher, her feet wrapped in thick bandages, said yesterday that she escaped under gunfire nine days ago from the Caribbean island of Grenada.

title: Dr. Levinson Is Appointed As Member of Times Board
description: The directors of The New York Times Company yesterday named Dr. Judith S. Levinson as a member of the board to fill the unexpired term of Richard N. Cohen, whose resignation bas been accepted. At the company's annual meeting on April 23, Dr. Levinson will be nominated then to serve a full term.

title: 10POINT PROPOSAL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30President Nixon proposed to Congress tonight a 10point program for this year that he said would lessen the energy crisis, check inflation, make new progress toward world peace and institute reforms in such domestic programs as health, welfare and transportation.

title: Consumer Notes
description: What's in a supermarket housebrand name? Very often the same thing as in a brandname product and even made by the same manufacturer. But it often costs a lot less.

title: All Bond Markets Reflect Firmness
The President's 10 Goals
description: An improvement in the energy supply that would assure reasonable prices with adequate environmental protection.

title: SlaIom to Miss Eberle
description: FOLGARIDA, Italy, Jan. 30 (UPI)Ingrid Eberle of Austria won the women's giant slalom today counting toward the European Cup for Alpine skiing. Conchita Puig of Spain was eighth and retained first place in the cup standing with 84 points, followed by Agnes VivetGros of France with 80 and Miss Eberle with 71.

title: Diverting Testimony
description: John D. Ehrlichman's attempt to obtain sworn testimony from his former boss, Richard M. Nixon, seems destined only to confuse and compound the disorder besieging the Administration.

title: TREASURY TO TRIM ITS CASH BALANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (Reuters)  The Under Secretary of the Treasury for monetary affairs, Paul Volcker, said that the Treasury's cash position was quite comfortable at present and that it would be reducing its cash balance for while by a $450million pay. down.

title: A PLEDGE TO STAY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Al the end of a traditional State of the Union Message, Presi. dent Nixon pledged anew tonight that he would not resign, and he called for a speedy conclusion to all Watergate investigations.

title: Heath Bids Labor and Business Meet to Head Off Miners Strike
description: LONDON, Jan. 30 Prime Minister Heath tried tonight to held off a strike in the nation's coal fields by proposing a meeting of business and labor leaders at 10 Downing Street to draw up a wage settlement agreeable to the coal miners.

title: Soviet Prods Syria To Seek an Accord On Troop Pullback
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 30The Soviet Union prodded Syria today to follow the Egyptian example of reaching a trooppullback agreement with Israel to maintain tactical solidarity with Cairo.

title: Bolivia Says Troops End Farm Workers Uprising
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 30 (Reuters)Bolivian troops have reopened three highways blocked by rebellious farm workers and the situation in the province of Cochabamba is totally under control, Information Minister Guillermo Bulacia said tonight.

title: Coviello Will Coach St. Peter's
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 30Joe Coviello, whose Memorial High School teams in West New York, N. J., made football history for more than a quarter of a century, has returned to the gridiron.

title: The Siamese Twins
description: In criticizing what he regards as the failure of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy to supervise adequately the work of the Atomic Energy Commission, Ralph Nader observed the other day that this Com mittee... is supposed to be a watchdog but instead is a Siamese twin.

title: Crozier Hospitalized
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 30 (AP)The Buffalo Sabres goalie, Roger Crozier, was hospitalized today, suffering from an attack of pancreatitis, a spokesman for the National Hockey League club said. Crozier had just rejoined the club following a fourweek leave of absence for health reasons.

title: LEFKOWITZ TO SEEK COMMUNE'S BOOKS
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30  Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said today that he had be gun subpoenaing the books and records of the Children of God religious cult as a first step toward a possible injunction to prevent future operations of the communes in New York State.

title: WHEAT FUTURES CONTINUE TO DROP
description: Wheat Futures prices dropped further yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. March delivery wheat closed at $5.70 $5.72, down from $5.85 Tuesday.

title: Notes on People
description: Kenneth W. Clawson, a reporter who left The Washington Post, two years ago to join the Nixon staff, was appointed by the President yesterday to be White House Director of Communications.

title: State Assembly Urges Congress to Roll Back Petroleum Prices
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30  The State Assembly today adopted a Republicansponsored resolution that called on Congress to roll back petroleum prices and impose an excess profits tax on the oil industry.

title: SCHOOLS ASK END TO DAYLIGHT TIME
description: Leaders of the nation's public schools'have won major concessions from the makers of Federal energy policy, but are continuing to press for action on one of their biggest worries, the danger to children posed by daylight saving time in winter. The recent regulations from the Federal Energy Off ite, coupled with public and private assurances of cooperation, have in effect granted the schools the status of a leading national priority in energy planning.

title: ALVIN SYLVESTER, 71, AIDE OF LA GUARDIA
description: Alvin McKinley Sylvester, counsel to the law firm of Warshaw, Sylvester, Burstein & Franks, and the city's deputy controller in the La Guardia Administration, died yesterday while touring in Yosemite National Park in California. He was 71 years old and lived at 315 East 68th Street.

title: MARKET AID FUND REPORTED TO GAIN
description: BRUSSELS, Jan. 30Foreign ministers of the nine Common Market nations reportedly made progress today toward ending the deadlock that has held up eitaglishment of a fund to aid economically ailing regions in their community.

title: Murder Witness Recants on Identity
description: A witness changed his mind in court yesterday, and took back the positive identification he had made two years ago of a man the police believe participated in the killing of Police Officers Gregory Foster and Rocco Laurie on the Lower East Side.

title: He Specializes in NameDropping
description: Easy to name a racehorse, Isn't it?

title: Recital
description: Sandra Miller's debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night proved her to be a fine young flutist whose musical personality and interpretative ideas have not yet blossomed as fast as her talent. Miss Miller, who gave her recital as a winner of the Concert Artists Guild Auditions, adopted a generally unassertive approach to trio sonatas by Telemann and Bach, and let herself be rushed to the breathless point in finales. Slightly more comfortable tempos could have allowed her to suggest greater brio with sharper articulation and unrushed phrasings.

title: Dial Bid by Chase Denied by Reserve
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (Reuters)  The Federal Reserve denied today an application by the Chase Manhattan Corporation to acquire the Dial Financial Corporation of Des Moines.

title: Westinghouse Net Off Southern Pacific Gains
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation confirmed yesterday a prediction about lower earnings that it issued on Dec. 20. The company showed a decline of 55.97 per cent in fourth quarter earnings from their 1972 level, although sales rose 14.7 per cent. Sales for 1973 were up 12.2 tper cent from 1972, but earnings slipped by 18.5 per cent.

title: 3% Increase for Imports of Oil Reported by Petroleum Group
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) The American Petroleum Institute issued today its weekly statistics on United States oil supplies. It reported a 3 per cent increase in oil imports for the week ended Jan. 25, due to increased crude oil shipments to the West Coast. But there was no indication that the impact of the Arab oil embargo had yet bottomed out. Crude oil imports to the eastern United States dropped again, and so did imports of refined products.

title: A judicial Undertaking
description: Regardless of the judgment on impeachment finally reached by the House of Representatives, it is profoundly important that the members of the House Judiciary Committee approach this grave question in the proper spirit. This is only the second time in nearly two centuries of national independence that a Presidential impeachment has been seriously considered. Impeachment is patently not a narrow partisan issue. Rather, it is second only to a declaration of war as a somber exercise in constitutional responsibility.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Nixon announced that the Arab oil producers would hold an urgent meeting to discuss lifting the oil embargo against the United, States following Secretary of State Kissinger's role in bringing about an agreement on a separation of troops by Egypt and Israel. The disclosure was the major foreignaffairs surprise in the State of the Union Message by Mr. Nixon, who also said the United States had a responsibility to stay involved in Southeast Asia. [1:67.]

title: People in Sports: Gamecocks Frank McGuire Hospitalized
description: A spokesman for Baptist Hospital in Columbia, S. C., reported yesterday that Frank McGuire was improved, resting comfortably and seemed to be in a satisfactory condition. The head basketball coach at the University of South Carolina was admitted to the intensive care unit Tuesday night with what was described as an acute intestinal disorder.

title: Senate RollCall Vote On Legal Aid Closure
The President's 10 Goals
description: An improvement in the energy supply, that would assure reasonable prices with adequate environmental protection.

title: City Action Opening Tudor City Parks To Public Is Voided
description: The city's rezoning of two private parks in Tudor City, making them available to the public, was declared unconstitutional yesterday by Justice Wilfred A. Waltemade in State Supreme Court here. He described the rezoning as inverse condemnation without adequate compensation to the owners.

title: No Racing: Potholes
description: BOSTON, Jan. 30 (AP)Thoroughbred racing at Suffolk Downs was canceled today for the fifth time since the track opened Jan. 19 because unseasonable weather had thawed the ground, leaving holes in the turf and creating hazardous conditions.

title: B. P. DENIES NET SHOWS HUGE GAIN
description: LONDON, Jan. 30  Jean Chenevier, chairman of British Petroleum's French subsidiary, was reported today to have said in Paris that the company's 1973 earnings had risen some 240 per cent to $528million from $154million in 1972.

title: And the Problems Remain
description: LONDONAll democratic states, an indeed some autocratic ones as well are experiencing a crisis of selfconfidente, as social and other domestic change accelerates. But in few nations is the crisisthe need for decisionmore acute than in the United States Its roots are similar to those in Britain or France: diminishing respect for political leadership; the divorce between social and political loyalties; the adjustment from rural to urban values; the increasing dominance of the mass media.

title: WAGE TALKS OPEN IN STEEL INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Labor and management in the steel industry began wage negotiations today, with both sides saying they wanted no interference from the Government.

title: Coviello Will Coach St. Peter's
description: JERSEY CITY, Jan. 30Joe Coviello, whose Memorial High School teams in West New York, N. J., made football history for more than a quarter of a century, has returned to the gridiron.

title: Carpi Is Acquitted
description: A jury in Trenton acquitted Colin C. Carpi, a security analyst from Princeton, in the 1971 slaying of his wife, Laura, after deliberating two days. Page 37.

title: Nixon Says Arab Meeting Will Weigh End to Oil Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 President Nixon announced tonight that the Arab oilproducing nations would hold an urgent meeting to discuss lifting the oil embargo against the United States following Secretary of State Kissinger's role in bringing about a troopseparation agreement between Egypt and Israel.

title: He Specializes in NameDropping
description: Easy to name a racehorse, isn't it?

title: Dylan Sends Garden into MatureFrenzy
description: Staring impassively into the darkness, Bob Dylan gritted the words, alt honor to be here, and sent 20,000 fans into a mature frenzy last night.

title: PROFIT INCREASED BY CHICAGO EDISON
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company reported yesterday sizable gains In revenues and net income for both the fourth quarter and all of 1973.

title: If Rheingold Shuts Plant, Pensions May Die, Too
description: ORANGE, Jan. 30  The closing of the Rheingold Corporation brewery here could liquidate a statewide pension fund and strip several hundred eligible workers of retirement benefits.

title: Japanese Investment Potential Attracting Worldwide Interest
description: TOKYO, Jan. 30While everyone here this week has been, watching the royal reception of the visiting Saudi Arabian Oil, Minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki alYamani, a delegation. of 40 Algerians NM been fanning out across Tokio to invite Japanese business to invest in their country.

title: Council Is Expected to Approve Rules Committee's Reform Plan
description: The City Council Committee on Rules is expected to approve today a series of reforms in Council procedures, including the keeping of attendance records, restricting proxy voting, limiting executive sessions and easing the method of getting bills out of committees.

title: GUILTY PLEA FILED ON EQUITY CHARGES
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30 (AP)  Michael E. Sultan, 30, former controller of the Equity Funding Corporation of America, has pleaded guilty to charges of conspiracy, mail fraud and filing false bank statements. He is scheduled to be sentenced May 13.

title: NAME PUTS TATUM IN GARMENT POST
Mets Sign 11 as Pay Arbitration Starts
description: With the final stumbling block out of the way, baseball's salary arbitration season opens tomorrow, but Bob Scheffing doesn't think any of the Mets will play the game.

title: CONGRESS BALKS CONVENTION SITE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  A HouseSenate conference committee today imperiled the construction of a proposed $200million convention center in New York City designed to lextend over the Hudson River  by failing to grant a declaration of nonnavigability.

title: Ford Gets Defense Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI)  Assistant Defense Secretary John O. Marsh Jr. is resigning to become assistant for defense affairs to Vice President Ford, Mr. Ford's office announced yesterday.

title: Reduction Refused 100Year Sentence For Marijuana Sale
Briefs on the Arts
description: Frederick Burkhardt has been elected chairman of the board of trustees of the New York Public Library, it was announced yesterday by John E. Lockwood, who,has retired as board chairman in accordance with the bylaws of the library. Mr. Burkhardt, a former trustee of the library, is president of the American Council of Learned Societies, a former board chairman of the Board of Higher Education for the City of New York and a former member of the United States National Commission for UNESCO.

title: Council Is Expected to Approve Rules Committee's Reform Plan
description: The City Council Committee on Rules is expected to approve today a series of reforms in Council procedures, including the keeping of attendance records, restricting proxy voting, limiting executive sessions and easing the method of getting bills out of committees.

title: Jane Show: Tale of Hope And Efforts
description: It looked like a miniMarch on Washington, as Roy Wilkins and his wife, Minnie; Bayard Rustin, Nikki Giovanni, Mrs. Jackie Robinson and her daughter and other familiar faces were in rapt attention in the cozy screening room on the 29th floor of the Gulf Western Building.

title: Catholic Activists Arrested in Brazil, Alarming Church
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Jan. 30 Roman Catholic churchmen here are concerned over the recent wave of arrests among Catholic activists.

title: Sohio and U.S. Banks Plan an Oil Venture
description: CLEVELAND, Jan, 30 (Reuters)The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said today that it had signed a $300million loan agreement with a group of banks led by the Chase Manhattanthe largest domestic oil financing venture ever entered into by United States commercial banks.

title: Contract Awards
description: The American Ship Building Company announced yesterday that it had received a $40million contract for 48 barges and four towboats from the Ingram barge unit of the Ingram Corporation.

title: ENGINEER TESTIFIES ON AGNEW KICKBACKS
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 30 (UP1)Lester Matz, an engineer, testified in Federal court today that he paid $40,000 in cash kick; backs to Spiro T. Agnew. while Mr. Agnew was Baltimore County Executive, Governor of Maryland and Vice President.

title: 4 YOUTHS SET AFIRE DOZING LAUNDRYMAN
description: Four youths doused a sleeping man with lighter fluid in an Upper West Side coinoperated laundry yesterday and reported.

title: Byrne to Propose Raises For Members of Cabinet
description: TRENTON, Jan. 30 (AP)Governor Byrne said today he would propose an increase in salaries for cabinet members in his administration.

title: U.S. Notes Statements
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Washington officials concerned with Cuban affairs focused attention today primarily on two statements made in Havana last night.

title: Senate Cuts Off Filibuster on Legal Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The Senate voted today to cut off debate on legislation that would create a public corporation to operate the legal services program for the poor now in the expiring Office of Economic Opportunity.

title: PARROT SILENT HERE IN OWN CUSTODY CASE
description: A parrot that allegedly flew the coop also blew its chance when it took the witness stand in a Queens courtroom yesterday. The green and yellow wouldbe starwitness was the center of a custody battle and the only parrot on record called to a witness stand in Queens.

title: REV. HENRY J. CAUER
description: REV. HENRY J. GAUERFLORAL PARK, L. I., Jan. 30 The Rev. Henry J. Gauer, pastor of St. Hedwig's Roman Catholic Church here, died of a stroke today at the Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park. His age was 55.

title: Soviet Prods Syria To Seek an Accord On Troop Pullback
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 30The Soviet Union prodded Syria today to follow the Egyptian example of reaching a trooppullback agreeinent with Israel to maintain tactical solidarity with Cairo?

title: Brezhnev Says Cuba Is Not a Vital Base for Soviet
description: MIAMI, Jan. 30 (UPI)Leonid I. Brezhnev declared last night in Havana that the Soviet Union did not consider Cuba a strategic base for influence..

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FOLKSY The Museum of American Folk Art, 49 West 53d Street (LT 12474) has just opened two shows weather vanes and signs in the rear, paintings in the front and no waiting inbetween. The shows, through April 7, represent two aspects of Americans, each somewhat offbeat.

title: ASHLAND OIL GIVES DATA ON INVENTORIES
description: Ashland Oil, Inc., announced yesterday that its inventories of crude oil and oil products on hand were lower this year compared with 1973, except for distillate fuels and kerosene, which were substantially more abundant.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Up to now, Muhammad Ali has never been bashful. Years ago he kept shouting, Get me Sonny Liston, get me the big ugly. bear. After his 3year exile, he kept shouting, Get me Joe Frazier, and after he lost, he kept shouting, Get me Joe Frazier again, I must have Joe Frazier. But now you don't hear him shouting, Get me George Foreman. Instead, he's talking about a third bout with Jerry Quarry and a third bout with Joe Frazier while trying to pretend that George Foreman doesn't exist. When the world heavyweight champion's name comes up, All reacts with uncharacteristic caution. His tone of voice also is unchar acteristic. Quietly respectful., George is a good fighter, Ali says softly. But he's not the real champ, I'm The. real champ. I don't need a fight with him.

title: Style Moderne Kitsch or SeriousIs in Vogue
description: The image of Ginger Rogers dashing down a sweeping stairway might not seem quite is natural for the Bronx as it would be for Radio City, the shrine of the nineteen thirties style.

title: ATLANTIC POSTS 41% PROFITS RISE
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, ninth largest oil concern in the nation, reported yesterday fourthquarter earnings of $91.7million, a 41 per cent increase over profit of $65million in the 1972 period. Earnings for 1973 were up 38 per cent.

title: Mislead or Conceal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Certain nuggets of information that have surfaced lately add weight to the possibility, much discussed among tax experts, that there was fraud in the preparation of President Nixon's disputed tax returns. The particular issue is Mr. Nixon's claim of $482,000 in deductions, so far, for a gift of personal papers to the National Archives. First there was the strange remark of Edward L. Morgan, who as Deputy Counsel to the President signed over Mr. Nixon's typed name a deed purporting to give those papers to the Archives. On suddenly resigning as Treasury official, Mr. Morgan said he now doubted that he had authority to sign that deed. He made the remark after being questioned in secret. by the Congressional committee that is investigating the Nixon taxes.

title: Democrats Asking $1.25Million To Settle Suits Over Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Robert S. Strauss, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today that the party was willing to settle the damage suits with the Republicans. over the Watergate breakin for $1.25million but not for the $600,000 that has been offered in the last few weeks.

title: CITY HALL PICKETS BACK JUDGE WRIGHT
description: The sun shone on the steps of City Hall yesterday as two groups of demonstrators marched. On the west, the Broadway side, marched 50 supporters of Criminal Court Judge Bruce Wright who, they said, was the target of harassment because of his lowball policy. On the east or Park ROw side marched 300 owners of rentcontrolled property who protested that they were unable to buy fuel oil at current high prices.

title: School Election Set
description: ALBANY, Jan. 39  Governor Wilson announced today. that he had set March 5 as the date of a special election to fill a vacancy on the community school board in District 23 in Brooklyn.

title: Saigon Retains Materials Of Times Man It Detained
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 30The South Vietnamese Government retained today the film and notebooks seized from James M. Markham, Saigon bureau chief of The New York Times, after he visited a Vietcong area in Binhdinh Province for a week.

title: TV: Splendid Jane Pittman Relates Black History
description: For The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman, the Columbia Broadcasting System is proclaiming that it proudly presents a major television special. In one of those alltoorare instances, the puffery is entirely justified. This TV special, being shown this evening from 9 to 11, is indeed mafor, and the network has every right to be proud.

title: Carpi Is Acquitted
description: A jury in Trenton acquitted Colin C. Carpi, a security analyst from Princeton, in the 1971 slaying of his wife, Laura, after deliberating two days. Page 37.

title: Canucks Win at Detroit
Colorado Death Bill Gains
description: DENVER, Jan. 30 (UPI)  Ignoring a lastminute plea for compassion by a black legislator, the Colorado Senate approved legislation today that could restore the death penalty to Colorado  the last state to carry out an execution. Senator George Brown pleaded with his colleagues to reject the bill.

title: No Light Matter
description: The brakes screeched. The bus, traveling too fast stop, slowed and swerved just enough barely to miss hitting a terrified little girl.

title: Oil Profits, Treasury Loss Linked to Secret Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Senators and witnesses at a Congressional investigation of international oil corporations told today of an intricate pattern of financial dealings dating back a quarter century that gave the companies the privileges that have led to enormous profits.

title: Murray Chotiner Dies
description: Murray M. Chotiner, President Nixon's longtime political adviser and friend, died yesterday morning in Washington from the injuries he suffered in an automobile accident Jan. 23. Page 36.

title: MAJOR LABOR CRISIS IS CONFRONTING BONN
description: BONN, Jan. 30  Record inflation, more than 7.5 per cent in a year, has brought WestGermany close to a crisis in labor relations. The first nationwide strike of civil servants, from garbage collectors to mailmen and railroad workers, since World War II is now viewed as a distinct possibility next month.

title: Philip Morris and Singer Break Quarterly and Annual Earnings Records
Books of The Times
description: THE OLD MAN. And Lesser Mortals. By Larry L. King. 300 pages. Viking. $8.95.

title: HIJACKINGS BY I.R.A. SNAG DUBLIN TRAFFIC
description: DUBLIN, Jan. 30  At least 15 armed men hijacked buses and trucks all over the city today in a coordinated operation that tied up traffic.

title: American Captured On Disputed Island Is Freed by China
description: HONG KONG, Thursday, Jan. 31 (Reuters)  An American and several South Vietnamese captured during recent fighting in the disputed Paracel Islands in the South China Sea were freed today by China and crossed into Hong Kong, a government official said.

title: Oil Profits, Treasury Loss Linked to Secret Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 Senators and witnesses at a Congessional investigation of international oil corporations told today of an intricate pattern of financial dealings dating back a quarter century that gave the companies the privileges that have led to enormous profits.

title: Nixon hiays Arab Meeting WiII Weigh End to Oil Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30President Nixon announced to night that, the Arab oilproducing nations would hold an urgent meeting to discuss lifting the oil embargo against the United. States following Secretary of State Kissinger's role in bringing about a troopseparation agreement between Egypt and Israel.

title: MitchellLama Supporters Cool To Aid Tied to Poor Outsiders
description: Under sharp questioning by members of the City Planning Commission, supporters of proposed cityaided MitchellLama apartment development in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn said they were reluctant to accept any government subsidy that would require admitting lowincome families from outside of the neighborhood.

title: REBOZO MAKES BID TO REBUT CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30An attorney for Charles G. Rebozo sent a telegram today to each member of the Senate Watergate committee asking that immediate public hearings be called to rectify malicious, false and inaccurate leaks of information about Mr. Rebozo, who is President Nixon's close friend.

title: G.M. Adds Storage Tanks
description: DETROIT, Jan. 30 (AP)The General Motors Corporation said today It had purchased oil storage tanks in Michigan. Ohio and Indiana to head off fuel shortages at any of its production facilities. The storage tanks were purchased from the Gulf Oil Co.

title: FRANCISZEK PAWLISZAK
description: Dr. Franciszek Pawliszak, a writer and broadcaster with the Polish desk of the Voice of America for more than 20 years, died Sunday in St. Rose's Home. He was 67 years old and lived at 413 East 72d Street.

title: Front Page 1 No Title
BONN EASES CURBS ON MONEY INFLOW
description: PARIS, Jan. 30Within 24 hours after the United States ended controls over dollar investment abroad,. West Germany today lifted most of its restrictions against inflows of money. The action was understood to have been worked out in cooperation with Washington.

title: T.S. Eliot: A Verse Letter
description: This letter to Leonard and Virginia Woolf, probably written in 1940, is from Other People's Mail, edited by Lola L. Szladits, curator of the Berg Collection, New York Public Library, which published the volume.

title: Auto Interlock System Studied for Modification
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) The Department of Transportation said today that it was considering a modification ot its controversial seat beltstarter interlock system.

title: Insiders Stockholdings
INSURER FILES SUIT OVER STATE RULING
description: The $500million American Reinsurance Company, fighting off a possible takeover by the American International Group, filed suit here yesterday to overturn a ruling of the New York State Insurance Department granting American International the authority to buy more than 9.9 per cent of American Reinsurance stock.

title: SUPPLIERS PLEDGE CHEAPER FUEL OIL TO THE CITY AREA
description: Major oil companies have agreed to provide tens of millions of gallons more of domestic homeheating oil for independent dealers in the New YorkNew Jersey area to bring down costs for consumers hit by sharply rising uncontrolled costs of imported oil.

title: WHEAT EXPORTS AT 6MONTH PEAK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) A record 714 million bushels of wheat was exported during the first six months of the fiscal year, which began last July 1, new figures by the Agriculture Department showed today.

title: Stock Prices Climb Across Broad Front
First Lady Has Lunch And So Do Celebrities
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI) Richard M. Nixon strolled out of the White House today to have lunch in a French restaurant packed with Washington celebrities.

title: WILSON PONDERS ROGAN SUCCESSOR Asserts He Will Not Consult With Politicians on Choice
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30Governor Wilson said today that he had a large number of candidates for Manhattan District Attorney under consideration, including prosecutors and judges, and that he would not consult political leaders in making his choice.

title: BOULEZ SAYS STORY ON QUITTING ERRS
description: Pierre Boulez, contradicting a report in the Paris weekly magazine L'Express, denied yesterday that he planned to leave the New York Philharmonic in 1977 when his second threeyear contract as music director runs out. No, I have not closed the door to the Philharmonic. I could not, because it has not been opened yet, the French conductor told The New York Times.

title: SCHOLARS IN WEST ASSAIL BELGRADE
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 30Yugoslavia's Communist party is finding itself subjected to growing international criticism for a bitter campaign to oust eight nonconformist Marxist professors at Belgrade University.

title: Advertising: Explaining Oil Woes
description: Only time will tell how much the general public is impressed by the current outpouring of explanatory advertising from oil companies. But you don't have to wait to find out that a good number of top professional communicators don't give it high marks.

title: Oakland Arraignment Delay
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 30 (AP)  Arraignment of two men charged with assassinating th4 Superintendent of Oakland Schools, Marcus Foster, was delayed today to permit one to meet with his courtappointed attorney. Municipal Court Judge Stafford P. Buckley ordered bailiffs to allow Joseph M. Remiro, 27 years old, to meet with Jules G. Bonjour Jr. of Oakland, named to his defense. Mr. Remiro and Russell Jack Little, 24, are charged with muckier.

title: WELFARE CHECKS TO BE STAGGERED
description: Beginning tomorrow the City's Department of Social services will stagger the distribution of welfare checks to its 335,000 clients to eliminate congestion at welfare centers and banks. The last digit of, client's case number will determine the days on which he will get his check.

title: LeRoy A. Petersen Dies at 80; ExChairman of Otis Elevator
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 30 LeRoy A Peterson who retired In 1966 as chairman of the Otis Elevator Company, died of a heart attack Yesterday while golfing at the Round Hill Club. He was 80 years old and lived on West Brother Drive.

title: SCREVANE ODDSON TO DIRECT THE OTB
description: Former City Council President Paul R. Screvane has agreed to head the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation, despite his Irritation over the fact that the current president, Howard J. Samuels, is insisting on retaining a seat on the OTB board.

title: Botany Sues Boston Bank
description: Max Robb, trustee of Botany Industries, has filed a $25million suit in United States District Court in Boston against the First National Bank of Boston, it was learned yesterday. The suit, filed Jan. 7, charged that the bank had breached a factoring contract with three Botany. subsidiaries, H. Daroff & Sons, House of WorstedTex and Josam Tailorswhich led to their bankruptcy petition in April, 1972. A spokesman for the bank, said: We don't believe the suit has any merit.

title: The President's Trump Cards
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 President Nixon played his trump cards tonight.

title: Audience Is Gripped by the State of the Presidency
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30President Nixon went before a joint session of Congress tonight to deliver a report on the State of the Union, out he seized his audience most firmly when he discussed the state of his Presidency.

title: Chile Gets I.M.F. Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (Reuters)The International Monetary Fund said today it had approved a $79million Special Drawing Right standby facility for Chile. The fund said its action was in support of the Chilean Government's economic and financial program.

title: FERDINANDO CITES POLICE INVESTORS
description: Thirtyeight policemen, most of them using aliases, put cash in his pyramid investment scheme, Joseph Ferdinando, convicted swindler, testified yesterday.

title: Murray Chotiner, Nixon Mentor, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30Murray M. Chotiner, President Nixon's first formative tutor it a tough school of campaign politics, died this morning, a week after having suffered a concur. sion, a broken leg and other injuries in an automobile ac. cident.

title: A PLEDGE TO STAY
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30At the end of a traditional State of the Union Message, President Nixon pledged anew tonight that he would not resign, and he called for a speedy conclusion to all Watergate investigations.

title: Army Drug Plan in Germany Hinges on Court Suit
description: HEIDELBERG, West Germany, Jan. 23A year ago, having heard that the Army would give amnesty to drug users who volunteered for treatment Pvt. Joseph Garback turned himself in to his command in Mainz.

title: A. &P. SEES PROFITS FOR FINAL QUARTER
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, I,nc., the nation's largest supermarket chain which has had a struggle in maintaining profitable operations, expects to have the best results for any quarter in two years in the 13 weeks ending Feb. 23, according to William S. Kane, chairman.

title: CLARENCE SHARP, 77, EXMAYOR OF GROTON
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 30Former Mayor Clarence Byran Sharp, died yesterday at Lawrence Memorial Hospital after having undergone surgery two weeks ago. He was 77 years old.

title: British Life on 3Day Week: Pinch With Little Pain
description: LONDON, Jan. 30  Leonard James, a 54yearold furniture maker, went fishing yesterday instead of going to work. He is one of the millions in Britain on a threeday iveek because of the miners dispute and, for the time being, he's enjoying the experience.

title: Two Law Firms Cited For Antiwomen Bias
description: After a 20month investigation, the City Commission on Human Rights determined yesterday that there was probable cause that Sullivan & Cromwell, one of the country's largest and most prestigious law firms, engaged in unlawful discrimination by not hiring enough women lawyers.

title: Fans of Era Flock to Music Hall
description: Glittering, sumptuously decorated Radio City Music Hall never seemed so small, so dim, or even so crowded as it did yesterday when the New York Art Deco Exposition opened for a fiveday run.

title: STATE FACES CUT IN U.S. SCHOOL AID
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30The House Committee on Education and Labor approved a new formula today for school aid to underprivileged children that would cost New York State $35.5million in Federal funds.

title: GILBERT W. DOUGLAS
description: INDIALANTIC BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30Gilbert Wilson Douglas, former president of Chipman Knitting Mills in Easton, Pa., died last Thursday at Brevard Hospital. He was 78 years old and had lived here since 1950,

title: FRENCH BAN BOOK ON ZAIRE'S LEADER
description: PARIS, Jan. 30The French Interior Ministry today banned publication here of a work on Zaire's President, Gen. Mobutu Sese Seko.

title: Army Puts Soft Soap On Blade
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Jan. 20The United States Military Academy introduced its new football coach, Homer Smith, today and also introduced a different approach to its football recruiting problemthe mandatory post graduate fiveyear tour of military duty.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: While his teammates were being drafted all alround him, Ken Pettiford, the Tennessee State University quarterback, sat around the athletic dormitory on the Nashville campus yesterday waiting for news about himself. After 11 rounds of the National Football league draft, he hadn't been mentioned.

title: Bleak Grenada Outlook
description: A political scientist seeking a prototype for the desperately poor ministate, lurching toward independence in a difficult world, would need look no further than Grenada. This southernmost of the Windward Islands, only 21 miles long and twelve wide but crammed with more than 100,000 people, has particular problems that make its prospects more bleak than those of other ministates, even in the highly volatile Caribbean.

title: McCrory President Is Expected To Be Chairman of Interstate
description: Stanley H. Kunsberg, president of the McCrory Corporation, is expected to become chairman of Interstate Stores. Inc., if Interstate's stockholders approve the proposed purchase of most of the retail properties of McCrory.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 30 (Reuters)  Paul Elvstrom of Denmark won the second race of the world soling championships in Boken Bay today after a stirring tacking duel with the Australian champion, David Forbes. The Olympic gold medalists tacked 28 times in the last windward leg of the 10mile course.

title: Faithful Figaro
description: WASHINGTONThe President does not dye his hair.

title: Areain Bear Mountain Is Only Bare of Skiers
Ronan Is Praised for Role In Getting MassTransit Aid
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was praised last night for his role in winning Federal aid for mass transportation at the first annual award dinner of the Travelers Aid Society.

title: Impeachment group Aims Mail Campaign at 6 Million
description: The National Committee on the Presidency, seeking President Nixon's impeachment, announced yesterday that it would, through a mail campaign, try to reach 6,000,000 voters within the next 45 days.

title: CONGRESS BALKS CONVENTION SITE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  A HouseSenate conference committee today imperiled the construction of a proposed $200million convention center in New York City  designed to extend over the Hudson River  by failing to grant a declaration of nonnavigability.

title: Lockheed Sets Soviet Pact
description: LONDON, Jan. 30 (Reuters) The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation said today that it had signed a reciprocal technology information exchange agreement with the Soviet Union. The pact covers a wide range of products including the RollsRoyce powered Tristar jetliner, medical electronics, oceanography and air traffic control systems, the company said.

title: Queens Youth, 17 Slain While Walking Dog
description: A 17yearold boy was shot and killed Tuesday night in East Elmhurst, Queens, while walking his dog at a local run.

title: Thousands At Rites As Grivas Is Buried At Cyprus Hideout
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 30 (UPI)  Thousands of Greek Cypriotes today attended the funeral of Gen. George Grivas, leader of the guerrilla campaign to unite Cyprus with Greece. Burial was in a simple hideout that had been used by the General.

title: Owner Driver Gives Case for Fuel Protest
description: AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 30Joseph Lehoe, who has been driving a truck since he could see over the dashboard, spread out on a desk his fuel receipts for the last month.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)Net new savings receipts of insured savings and loan associations totaled $10.5billion in 1973, about half the 1972 total, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: Rear Adm. Charles Lyons; Led Boston Naval Station
description: MILTON, Mass., Jan. 30 (AP) Rear Adm. Charles M. Lyons former Commander of the Naval Station to Boston, died yesterday in Milton Hospital. He was 64 years old

title: STOCKS ON AMEX REGISTER ADVANCE
